div.p: ETERNALL TRVTH OF SCRIPTVRES, AND CHRISTIAN BELEEFE, THEREON WHOLLY DEPENDING, MANIFESTED BY IT OWNE LIGHT.
DELIVERED IN TWO BOOKES Of Commentaries vpon the Apostles CREEDE:
The former, Containing the positiue grounds of Christian Religion in generall, cleared from all exceptions of Atheists or Infidels.
The later, Manifesting the Grounds of Reformed Religion to be so firme and sure, that the Romanist cannot oppugne them, but with the vtter ouerthrow of the Romish Church, Religion, and Faith.
By THOMAS IACKSON, Bachellar of Diuinitie, and Fellow of Corpus-Christi Colledge in OXFORD.
LONDON Printed by W. Stansby and are to bee sold by Iohn Budge, at the Great South doore of Pauls, and at Britaines-Bursse. 1613.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONRABLE, RALFE LORD EVRE, BARON Of Malton and WITTON, Lord President of his Maiesties Court established in the Principalitie and Marches of Wales: My singular good LORD.
div.p:
RIGHT HONOVRABLE, Though few others would, I trust Your Lordship will vouchsafe countenance to these Cōmentaries, rude and imperfect I must confesse, but whose vntimely or too hastie birth (if so it proue, and mu ••
• ee ••••
red) hath not beene caused by any inordinate appetite, but only from a longing desire of testifying that loue and dutie which I owe vnto your Honourable Familie and Person, as in many other respects, so chiefly in this: That being ingaged vnto a more gainefull, but not so good a course of life, and welnigh rooted in another soile; I was by your Lordships fauourable aduise and countenance transplanted to this famous Nurserie of good learning. Wherein (by his blessing who onely giues increase to what his seruants plant or water) I haue growne to such a degree of maturitie, as these raw meditations argue, or so wilde a graffe was capable of. Course and vnpleasant my fruit may prone: but, whiles it shall please the Lord to continue his wonted blessings of health and other opportunities,
altogether vnfruitfull (by his assistance) I will not, altogether idle I cannot, be. Such as these first fruits are (much better I dare not promise,) the whole after-crop (I trust) shall be: both, for the sinceritie of my intention, acceptable (I doubt not) to my God; the later, I hope, more ripe in the iudgment of men, then can in reason bee expected the first fruites of the same mans labours should be. Thus humbly beseeching your Honour to accept these as they are, and to esteeme of them (howsoeuer otherwise) as an vndoubted pledge of a minde indeuouring to shew it selfe thankful for benefits alreadie receiued; and much desiring the continuance of your honourable fauours: I continue my prayers vnto the Almightie that he would multiply his best fauours and blessings vpon you. Corpus-Christi College in Oxford. October 5.

closer.signed: Your Lordships much deuoted Chaplaine THOMAS IACKSON.

div.head: To the Christian Reader.
div.p:
IGnorant altogether I am not of the disposition, though not much acquainted with the practises of this present age: wherein, to haue meditated vpon so many seuerall matters as I heere present vnto thy Christian view, will vnto some (I know) seeme but an effect of melancholie, as to haue taken the paines to pen them, will argue my want of other imployments, or forlorne hopes of worldly thriuing. Vnto others (and those more to be regarded) so soone in print to publish what had beene not so well concocted, and more rawly penned, will be censured as a spice of that vanitie which vsually haunts smatterers in good learning, but wherewith iudicious Clearks are seldome infected. To the former, I only wish mindes more setled, or lesse conscience of their owne extrauagancies and carelesse mispence of choicest time, faults apt to breed a mislike of others industrie in such courses as will approue themselues in his sight that sits as Iudge and trier of all our waies, howsoeuer such as desire to be meere by-standers as well in Church as Common-wealthes affaires, may vpon sinister respects, mutually misinforme themselues. For many of the later, I am afraid, least, being partly such and so esteemed, they preposterously affect not to be takē for more iudicious scholers then indeed they are: for the fostering of which conceit in others, their vnwillingnesse to publish what they haue conceiued aright, may well be apprehended as a meanes not improbable. Not to expose their meditations to publike censure, is and hath beene (as the Christian world too well can witnesse) a resolution incident to men of greatest iudgement: though no such essentiall propertie, as necessarily argues, eyther all so minded to be, or all otherwise minded, not to be, alike iudicious. Certaine it is, the more excellent the internall feature of mens minds is, the greater disparagement to them will an ordinarie representation of it bee, and to adorne their choice conceits with such outward attire as best beseemes them,
would require too great costes and charges. Thus from perfection ofttimes springs defect: whilest iudgement, too much ouergrowing fancie, and drying vp that kinde affection, whereby the fruit and vertue of one soule is diffused vnto another, makes men more iealous of diminishing the high estimate of their foreprized worth, then zealous of their inferiours good, which many times might be reaped in greatest abundance from such labours as yeeld least contentment to their Authors. In this respect alone can I gratulate my imperfections: hoping that as my meditations can neither please the delicate, for their forme, nor informe the iudicious for their matter: so they may proue neither offensiue for the one, nor vnfruitfull for the other, vnto many of a middle and inseriour ranke.

At the least (I trust) they will occasion some others, whom God hath blessed with better abilitie and opportunitie, to hunt that out which in this long range I may chance to start, or make full conquest of that goodly field wherein that inestimable pearle lies hid, for whose discouerie these my trauels may happily yeeld some obseruations not impertinent. To this end haue I purposely trained my wits to vntroden pathes, to aduenture on new passages, vnto that true treasure which all of vs trafficke for, ofttimes one to anothers hindrance, the more because wee beate one place too much, when as many others might affoord vs the same or greater commodities better cheape. Though the truth be one: yet it is not alwaies of one shape, whiles we looke vpon it diuers waies. The mine wherein it lies, is inexhaustible; oft times more full of drosse and rubbidge, where most haue digged: and, though the inward substance of it be the same, yet the refining of it admits varietie of inuentions. Doe not preiudice me (charitable Reader) so much as in thy secret censure, as if these premises might seeme to argue my dissent in any conclusions which our Church professeth: the euent (I trust) shall acquit mee, and condemne all my accusers, if any I haue; and how I stand affected in points of spirituall obedience to my superiours, thou mayest be informed, if it please thee but to peruse some few sheetes of these my first fruites, which I presume thou wilt, surely thou oughtest, ere thy censure passe vpon me. If in the explication of some points I fully accord not with some well esteemed domesticke writers: I trust Sarahs free borne children may enioy that priuiledge amongst themselues, which is permitted the sonnes of Hagar, in respect of their brethren, though all absolute bondmen to their mother. Yet that I doe not thus
farre dissent from any of my mothers children, vpon emulation or humour of contradiction, thou wilt rest satisfied vpon my sincere religious protestation, That the whole fabricke of this intended worke was set, and euery maine conclusion resolued vpon, before I read any English writer vpon the arguments which I handle. From some indeed which had written before me, I haue since perceiued a direct dissent in one or two points of moment; but wherein they had (in my iudgement) contradicted the most iudicious writers of our Church and all antiquitie I am acquainted with, more rashly, then I would doe the meanest this day liuing. Yet shall they, or whosoeuer of their opinion, finde the manner of my disputing with them, such as shall not (I trust) exasperate, howsoeuer the dissonance of matter may dislike them. For outlandish or forraine Latine writers, I must ingeniously confesse, when I first laboured to bee instructed in the fundamentall principles of faith and manners, some points which I much wished, I found they had not handled, in others, wherein I misliked nothing as vnsound, I could not alwaies finde that full satisfaction, which (me thought) a more accurate Artist (for a meane one I was then my selfe) would require. The greater since hath beene my desire eyther of giuing, or by my attempt, of procuring satisfaction. But will not others, when I haue done my best, so thinke and say of mine, as I haue done of these much better indeauours? It were great arrogance to expect any lesse. Notwithstanding, if what they shall finde defectiue in my labours, moue them to no worse patience, then what I thought (at least) was so in theirs that euery way goe before mee, hath done mee: nor I, nor they, nor the Church of Christ, (by this meanes paitaker, and free to dislike or approue of both our labours) shall (I trust) haue any great cause to repent vs of our paines. For thy better satisfaction, I will acquaint thee with the particulars which moued mee to write.

First, in vnfolding the nature and properties of Christian faith, to omit the errours of the Romish church, (wherein it is impossible it should euer come to full grouth,) many in reformed, too much followed in particular Sermons, did striue to ripen it too fast. I haue heard complaints immediately from the mouthes of some yet liuing, of others deceased, that they had beene set too farre in their first Lessons: that the hopes they had out of hand directly built vpon GODS generall promises applied to them by their instructours,
were too waightie, vnlesse the foundations of their faith had first beene more deepely and surely planted. That certainty of iustification and full perswasion of inherent sanctifying grace, whereat these worthies (whose footsteps I precisely tracke not) ayme, is (I protest) the marke which I propose vnto my selfe, but cannot hope at the first shoote to hit; if at the second, third, or fourth (as shall please God,) it must content me. In the meane time (I hope) I shall neither offend him, nor any of his, as long as I gather ground of what I prosecute, and still come nearer & nearer the proposed end. The first step, me thought, that tended most directly to this certaine apprehension of sauing faith, was our vndoubted assent vnto the diuine truth of Scriptures in generall: and for the working of this assurance, meanes subordinate I could conceiue none better for the kinde (particulars others happily may finde more forcible,) then such as I haue prosecuted at large in the first booke: not ignorant, that such as moued me more, might moue others lesse, those euery man most, that were of his owne gathering, wherein the disposition of the diuine prouidence (alwaies concurrent to this search, so men would marke it) is most conspicuous. For this purpose I haue proposed such varietie of obseruations, as almost euery one able to read the Scriptures or other authors, of what sort or profession soeuer, students especially, may bee occasioned to make the like themselues, well hoping to finde a m • thode as facile and easie for establishing the assent of the simple, and altogether illiterate, vnto those articles, whose distinct explicit knowledge is most necessary to saluation. But many (I know) will deeme the broken traditions, or imperfect relations of heathen men (for these I vse,) but weake supporters for so great an edifice: nor did I intend them for such seruice. Their ignorance notwithstanding, and darkned minds, doe much commend the light of diuine truth so may the experience of their vanitie dispose our minds to embrace the stabilitie of Gods word with greater stedfastnesse. We know the vertue and benefit of the Sunne, not so much by looking vpon it selfe continually or directly, as by the varietie of other obiects or colours, all pleasant with it to the eye, but altogether inuisible or indistinguishable without it: so for mine owne part, I must professe, that such historicall narrations, poeticall fictions, or other conceits of Heathens as they themselues knew little vse of, nor should I haue done had I beene as they were, being compared with this heauenly light of Gods word, did much affect me euen in my best and most retired meditations of sacred mysteries, their obseruation, as it were, tied my soule by a new knot, or fest, more surely
vnto that truth, which I knew before to be in it selfe most sure, most infallible. Yea euen in points wherein my heart, vnto my seeming, was best established, it much did nourish, augment, and strengthen beleefe alreadie planted, to obserue the perfect consonancie of profane, with sacred writers, or the occasions of their dissonancy, to be euidently such, as Scriptures specifie: that of many euents wondred at by their heathenish relators, no tolerable reason could be giuen, but such as are subordinate to the neuer-failing rules of Scripture. And whosoeuer will, may (I presume) obserue by experiment, the truth of what I say. There is no motiue vnto beleefe so weake or feeble, but may be very auailable for quelling temptations of some kinde or other, eyther in speculation or practise, oft-times such as are absolutely more weake or feeble, more effectuall for expelling some peculiar distrust or presumption, then others farre more forcible and strong for vanquishing temptations of another kinde, in nature most grieuous. Many, halfe students, halfe gallants, are often tempted eyther to distrust the commendatiōs of this Eden which we are set to dresse, or distast the food of life that grows within it, from delights suggested by profane bookes, wherewith commonly they are first acquainted, and hence much affect the knowledge their Authors profer, as likely to deifie them in the worlds eyes. Our pronenesse to be thus perswaded, is a witnesse of our first parents transgression, and these suggestions as relicks of Sathans baites, whereby he wrought their bane. But what is the remedie? not to tread in any heathenish soile, least these serpents sting vs? rather the best medicine for this maladie would be a confection of that very flesh wherein such deadly poyson lodged. Other arguments may more perswade the iudicious, or such as in some measure haue tasted the fruits of the spirit: But none the curious artist better, then such as are gathered from his esteemed Authors Euen such as are in faith most strong, of zeale most ardent, should not much mispend their time, in comparing the degenerate fictions or historicall relations of times ancient or moderne, with the euerlasting truth. For, though this methode could not adde much increase, eyther to their faith, or zeale: yet would it doubtlesse much auaile for working placide and milde affections. The very penmen of sacred writ themselues were taught patience, and instructed in the waies of Gods prouidence, by their experience of such euents as the course of time is neuer barren of, not alwaies related by Canonicall Authors, nor immediately testified by the spirit, but oft-times beleeued vpon a morall certaintie, or such a resolution of circumstances
concurrent into the first cause or disposer of all affaires, as wee might make of moderne accidents, were we otherwise partakers of the Spirit, or would we minde heauenly matters as much as earthly.

Generally two points I haue obserued, not much for ought I know, if handled at all by any writer: albeit their fruite and vse would fully recompence the best paines of any one mans life-time, though wholly spent in their discussion, whose want in my mind hath beene the bane of true deuotion in most ages. The first is an equiualencie of means in the wisedom of God so proportioned to the diuersity of times, as no age could haue better then the present, howsoeuer they may affect the extraordinarie signes and wonders of former generations. Of this argument here and there, as occasion shall serue in this worke; elswhere at large, if God permit. The second is an equiualencie of errours, hypocrisie, infidelitie, and idolatry, all which varie rather their shape then substance, in most men, through ages, nations, and professions, the ignorance of God remaining for the most part the same, his attributes as much (though in another kinde) transformed by many in outward profession ioyned with the true Church, as in times past by the heathen. The truth of which assertion, with the originall causes of the error, & means to preuent it, are discussed at large in the article of the Godhead. Many likewise for ought their consciēce (because not rightly examined) wil witnesse to the contrary, are strongly perswaded they loue Christ with heart & soule, and so detest as well the open blasphemy or professed hatred, which the Iew; as the secret enmity the Iesuit or other infamous heretiks, beare against him: • hen as oft-times the on • y ground of their loue to him, is their spite to some or all of these, as they are deciphered to thē in odious shape, the only originall of their despite to these, the very dregs of Iewish, Popish, or other hereticall humors in thēselues, by some light tincture of that truth which they outwardly professe, exasperated to more bitter enmity against them with whose internall tēper they best agree, then otherwise they could conceiue; as admission to place of credit or authoritie makes b • se minds, conscious of their own forepast villanies, more rigid censurers of o • hers misdemeanors, or cruell persecutors of such malefactors as thēselues in action haue beene, & in heart yet are (were all occasions and opportunities the same) then any moderate or syncere man in life & action could be. Of the originall of this disease, with the crises & remedy, a • also the triall of faith inherent, in the articles concerning Christ and remission of sinnes.

From the manner of Ierusalēs progresse to her first destruction, and discouery of the Iews naturall temper (the principal subiect of my subcisiue
or vacant houres from these meditations & other necessary imployments of my calling) I haue obserued the originall as well of most states as mens miscarriages professing true religion, to haue bin from presumption of Gods fauour before dangers approch, & distrust of his mercy after calamities seaze vpon thē: the root of both these misperswasions to be ignorance or error in the doctrine of Gods prouidence, whose true knowledge (if I may so speak) is the fertile womb of all sacred moral truths, the only rule of rectifying mens wils, perswasions & affections, in all consultatiōs or practises priuat or publik. Vnto this purpose much would it auaile to be resolued, whether all things fal out by fatal necessity, or some contingētly; how fate & contingency (if cōpatible each with other) stand mutually affected, how both subordinate to the absolute immutability of that one euerlasting decree. Want of resolutiō in these points (as far as my obseruation serues me) hath continually bred an vniuersal threefold want: of care & vigilancy for preuenting dangers in thēselues auoidable: of alacrious indeauors to redeeme time in part surprised by them; of patience, of hearty submissiō to Gods will, & constant expectation of his prouidence, after all hope of redēption from tēporal plagues long threatned by his messengers, is past. For here we suppose (what out of the fundamētal principles of Christian religiō shal in good time be made euidēt) that in all ruinated states or forepast alterations of religiō from better to worse, there was a time wherin the possibility of misfortunes which afterwards befell thē, might haue bin preuēted, a time wherin they might haue bin recouered frō eminent dangers, wherewith they were encompast, a time after which there was no possibility left them of auoiding the day of visitation, neuer brought forth but by the precedent fulnesse of iniquity, but alwaies necessarily by it. In the discussion of these & other points of like nature (because more depending vpon strict examination of consequences deduced from the vndoubted rules of Scripture, then vpon authorities of antiquity, skil in the tongues, or any other learning that required long experience or obseruation) I laboured most, whilst those arts and sciences which are most conducible to this search, were freshest in my memory. And could I hope to satisfie others in all or most of these, as fully as I haue long since done my selfe, I should take greatest pleasure in my pains addressed to this purpose. But would it please the Lord in mercy to raise vp some English writer, that could in such sort handle these points, as their vse and consequence, or necessitie of present times requires: succeeding ages (I am perswaded) should haue more cause to blesse the day of his natiuitie, then of the greatest States-mens or stoutest warriours this land hath
yeelded since the birth of our Fathers this day liuing. It shall suffice me to beginne the offering with my mite, in hope some learned Academicks (for vnto them belongs the conquest of this golden fleece) will imploy their talents to like publike vse. What I conceiue, shall be (by Gods assistance) vnfolded in as plaine and vnoffensiue termes, as the nature of the subiect will beare, or my faculties reach vnto, partly in the Article of Gods prouidence, partly in other discourses directly subordinate vnto it.

Lastly, for the full and perfect grouth, at least for the sweet and pleasant flourishing of liuely faith, one of the most effectuall meanes our industrie that can but plant or water, attaines vnto, would bee to vnfold the harmonie betwixt propheticall predictions and historicall euents concerning the kingdome of Christ, and time of the Gospell: a point, for ought I know, not purposely handled by any moderne writer, except those whose successe cannot be great, vntill their delight in contention and contradiction be lesse. Notwithstanding, whatsoeuer I shall finde good in them or any other, without all respect of persons, much more without all desire of opposition, or occasion of contention (a matter alwaies vndecent in a Christian, but most odious and loathsome in a Subiect so melodious and pleasant,) I will not be afraid to follow, intending a full Trea-tise of the diuers kindes of prophecies, with the manner of their interpretations, before the Articles of Christs Incarnation, Passion, and Ascension.

These are the especiall points, which for the better confirmation of true Christian faith, and rectifying perswasions in matters of manners or good life, are principally aymed at in these meditations. The maine obstacle the Atheist stumbles at, is the Article of the bodies resurrection. Whose passiue possibilitie shall by (Gods assistance) be euidently demonstrated against him by the vndoubted rules of nature, whose Priest or Minister he professeth himselfe to be. That de facto it shall be, the Scriptures, whose truth ere then will appeare diuine, must assure vs; Nature cannot, though thus much were in some sort knowne and beleeued by many naturall men from traditions of the ancient, or suspected from some notions of the law of nature not quite obliterated in all sorts of the heathen, as shall in that Article (God willing) be obserued. But why our assent vnto this and all other Articles in this Creed, being in good measure established, the momentarie hopes or transitorie pleasures of this world, should with most in their whole course of life, with all of vs
in many particular actions in priuate and secret temptations, more preuaile, then that exceeding waight of glorie, which Christian hope would fasten on 〈◊〉 soules, to keepe vnrulie affections vnder, hath often enforced mee to wonder, and wonderment hereat first moued me to vndertake these labours, if by any meanes I may attaine vnto the causes of this so grieuous an infirmitie, or finde out some part of a remedie for it. Doubtlesse, had the heathen Philosophers but knowne or suspected such ioyes as we professe we beleeue and hope for, or such a death, or more then deadly torments, as after this life ended we might feare; their liues and manners would as farre haue surpassed the best Christians now liuing, as their knowledge in supernaturall mysteries came short of the most learned that are or haue beene in that profession: and yet whatsoeuer helpes any Christian or heathen had for increasing knowledge or bettering manners, are more plentifull in this then any precedent age, so that the fault is wholly in our selues, that will not apply medicines alreadie prepared, as shall (God prospering these proceedings) be declared in the last Article of this Creed.

For controuersies betwixt vs and the Rom • sh Church, beside such as are directly opposite to the end and methode proposed, I purposely meddle with none: of that ranke, some (as that of the Churches infallibilitie) vndermine the verie foundation, others (as the doctrine of merite and iustification, the propitiation of the Masse) vnroofe the edifice, & deface the walls of Christian faith, leauing nothing therof, but altar-stones for their Idolatrous sacrifices. For this reasō haue I built with one hand, & vsed my weapon with the other: laying the positiue or generall grounds of faith against the Infidell or Atheist in the first booke, and guarding them in the second by the sword of the spirit, against all attempts of Romish Sanballets or Tobiahs, who stil labour to perswade our people, the walles of Christs Church heere erected since our fore fathers redemption from captiuitie, vnlesse supported by their supposed infallibilitie, are so weake, Nehem. 4. v. 3. That if a Foxe should goe vpon them, he should breake them downe. In the third (which was at this time intended, but must stay a while to bring forth a fourth) I batter those painted walles, whose shallow foundations are discouered in the second. The other controuersies about the propitiatorie sacrifices of the Masse, Merits, and Iustification, I prosecute in the Articles of Christs passion and of finall iudgement.

By this (beloued Reader) thou maist perceiue my iourney is long, and may well plead my excuse for setting forth so soone: but from that course which I haue chosen, or rather God hath set me, I trust nor hopes of preferment, nor any desires of worldly wealth, nor affectation of popularitie, by handling more plausible or time-seruing arguments, shall euer draw me away. So farre I am from ayming at any such sinister end, that since I begun to comment vpon the nature of Christian faith, I neuer could, nor euer shall perswade my selfe it possibly cand finde quiet lodging, much lesse safe harbour, but in an heart alike affected to death and honour; alwaies retaining the desires, and feare of both (eyther seuerally considered, or mutually compared) in equall ballance. Both are good when God in mercie sends them, both euill, and hard to determine whether worse, to vnprepared minds, or whilst procured by our sollici • us or importuna • e suite, or bestowed vpon vs in their Donours anger. Only this diff • rence I finde; death is mankinds ineuitable doome, but wor ••• y preferment neither so common to all, nor so certaine to any. the less • in reason) should be our indeauours eyther for prouiding it, or preparing our selues to salute it decently, though comming of it owne accord to meete vs. But what meditations can be too long, or what indeauours too laborious for gaining of an happie end, or giuing a messenger of so importunate & waightie consequence as death one way or other brings, correspondent entertainment? This Christian modestie I haue learned long since of the heathen Socrates, to beseech my God he would vouchsafe me such a portion of wealth, or whatsoeuer this world esteemes, as none but an honest, vpright, religious minde can beare: or, to vse the words of a better teacher, that of all my labours vnder the sunne, I may reape the fruit in holinesse, and in the end, the end of these my present meditations, euerlasting life.

div.head: An Addition, or Appendix vnto the seuenth Chapter, Sect. 3. Lib. 1. Parte secunda.
div.p: ALbeit lawfull in euery age it hath beene, to varie, if without dissension from former interpreters, in vnfolding diuine mysteries, without censure of irregularitie, so the explication be parallel to the analogie of faith: yet partly, to cleare my selfe from all suspition of affecting nouelties; partly, more fully to satisfie the ingenious and vnpartiall Reader, I haue thought good to acquaint him with some obseruations, which haue almost betrothed my minde vnto that exposition of our Sauiours word, related by Saint Mathew, and Saint Luke, which in the first booke I commended to his Christian consideration.

That happily will cause others to suspend their iudgements, which for a long time did retardate my perswasion, and inhibite my assent vnto the truth I there deliuered. For albeit the reasons there alleaged seemed very probable, whilest weighed apart, but farre more pregnant from comparing the concurrence of all circumstances, which had led me to that opinion: yet on the other side strange it seemed, that my best grounds being borrowed from the relation of antiquitie, no ancient writer, liuing shortly after those times, should haue obserued the like. But whilst I considered againe, how the Almightie, whether, in his iust iudgement fot the sinnes of that present, or, in his wisedome and mercie for the greater good of future generations, had depriued vs of all their sacred meditations, that liued about Titus his time, or immediatly after: both effects, as I conceiued, might haue one and the same iust cause, though secret and onely knowne to God, not fit for vs to make any further inquirie after, then might stirre vs
vp to true admiration of his wisedome. And truly admirable his wisedome seemed in this, that the Canon of the new Testament being finished in the most knowne tongue then extant in the world, (in which respect besides others, The Gospell of the Kingdome might be truly said to be preached through the whole, for a witnesse to all Nations) he would haue it seuered from all other writings, as well by the subsequent as precedent silence of Ecclesiasticall sacred writers. He that would not haue any Prophet in Israell after the erection of the second Temple, would not for the same cause onely knowne to him, haue any writings of men, otherwise most religious and deuout, to be extant in the age immediately following the Gospels promulgation, that it thus shining like a solide or compact glorious starre in the transparant spheare, enuironed euery where with vacuitie, might more clearely manifest it selfe by it owne light be to supercelestiall.

Necessarie it was the period of that generation, wherein our Sauiour liued and died, should haue the diuine truth of his Gospell confirmed vnto them by signes (as the Joel. 2.30. Prophet speakes) in the heauens and in the earth, to increase their care and diligence in commending it to posteritie, who were to relie on it immediatly, not on their fore-fathers relation of signes past, the like or more effectuall, and as fully answerable to the rules set downe in it, they could not want; so long as they carried soules or minds carefull to obserue and practise what it prescribed. And who knowes whether the Lord had not appointed, that the serious consideration of those prodigious signes, which followed the publishing of the Gospell, should sleepe in all or most intermediate ages, till these latter daies wherein we liue, wherein such obseruations are more seasonable, as we being the men on whom the latter ends of the world are come. Happily had Ecclesiasticke writers commented vpon those times, our curious moderne wits, too much addicted vnto Gentilisme, would haue giuen lesse credence to the pregnant testimonies of profane Authors, as suspecting, lest Christians, in whose custodie their writings for many generations haue beene, had infected either the whole discourses or some peculiar circumstances pertinent to their purposes, or apt to countenance their opinions, otherwise improbable in the worlds iudgement. But now, by how much the silence of Ecclesiasticke
Authors in these narrations hath beene greater, and the testimonies of heathen writers more plentifull or pregnant, so much the more vnexcusable is the curious vnregenerate Artist, or incredulous Athist. That most generations, since those times whereof we treat, should expect signes in the Sunne, and Moone, to come before the day of iudgement, cannot seeme either strange in it selfe, or preiudiciall to this doctrine which we deliuer, if we call to mind how men otherwise truly religious haue beene vsually ignorant, or mistaken in the meaning of diuine mysteries, vntill the time appointed for their Reuelation, or vntill they vnfold their enigmaticall construction by the approch or reall existence of the euents foretold. Thus many well affected to our Sauiour and his doctrine did expect Elias should come before the kingdome were restored to Israel, euen whilst they had Iohn Baptist, of whom that prophecie was properly meant, amongst them, yea after hee had sealed his embassage with his bloud. Euen in the Apostles time, That our Sauiour should instantly come to giue final iudgement, was an opinion (as it seemes from S. Paul his admonition to the2. Thess. 2.1.2. Thessalonians) generally receiued amongst Christians: first occasioned as is most probable, from misconstruction of our Sauiours prophesie, Verily I say vnto you, this generation shall not passe till all these things be done, and this misconstruction caused from a a common erour or ignorance in not distinguishing betwixt the typicall and the mysticall or substantiall sense of prophesies, ofttimes, both alike literally and necessarily imported in the selfesame words.

From this errour of Christians in misapplying our Sauiours words, vnto the substance, which, for that time, were onely appliable to the type, was the like tradition propagated to the heathen of those times: as may be gathered fromLuca. lib. 1.
Lucan, who liued when S. Paul florished, and died by the same tyrants appointment. His description of the last day is but a poeticall descant vpon our Sauiours words related by three of his Euangelists: The Sunne shall waxe darke, and the Moone shall not giue her light, and the Starres of heauen shall fall, and the powers of heauen shall be shaken.

Machina diuulsi tur babit foedera mundi.

div.p:
The Romanes might well haue taken their martyred Poet for a Prophet, at least in this prediction, when within few yeares after they did behold the Sunne, and Moone, with all the host and powers of heauen, tragically acting what he had pend. The Romanes conceit of that ruefull spectacle, whose admiraration had brought her great Philosopher, natures curious secretarie, to his vntimely death, in Dions words was thus: Postremo tantus fuit cinis, vt inde peruenerit in Africam, Syriam, & Aegyptum, introierit{que} Romam, eiusque aerem compleuerit, & solem obscurauerit. Nec mediocris etiam Romae trepidatio complures ad dies accidit (or as some read) [id Rome accidit paucis post diebus,] quum omnes ignorarent id quod factum erat in Campania, nec quid esset, coniectura assequi possent. Itaque etiam ij putare coeperunt, omnia sursum deorsum ferri, selem{que} in terram cadere, ac terram in coelum conscendere. So well doth this heathen expresse the Prophets words: Ioel. 2.30. I will shew wonders in the heauens, and in the earth, bloud and fire, and pillars of smoake. But most admirable is the consent betweene the same Prophet, and Plinie the younger, who was an eye-witnesse of the first rising of that smoak, portending such dismall times. That great and terrible day of the Lord, before which (as the Prophet speakes,) the Sunne was to be turned into darknes, & the Moone into bloud, was not to be terminated vnto one set, naturall, or artificiall day, but to be extended vnto all the prodigious calamities, which after Ierusalems destructiō successiuely ensued throughout the world, or (as another Ier. 25.31. Prophet speaks) vnto the continuance of that great controuersie which the Lord had with the nations: before which, the burning of Vesuuius was as a Beacon to giue warning to all flesh. And the ingenious Reader, will, I hope, be incited, by Plinies expressing the beginning of that prodigious sight, to admire the hidden mysteries, that are often enwrapt in the enygmaticall proprietie of propheticall words, rather then censure this obseruation following for a tale of smoake or criticall coniecture, set beyond
that Region wherein these fiery comets appeared. The Word in the originall, rendred by pillars, properly signifies a Palme-tree, from the analogie betwixt pillars, and whose long trunke and broad toppe, it comes to signifie a pillar, or supporter. Plinie the younger setting downe the occasion and manner of his Vncles death, resembles the first apparition of that huge and strange cloude vnto aPinaster nihil est aliud quam •• na syluestr • s m •• a a • litudine, & a medio ramosa, sicut pinus in vertice. Plin. lib 16. cap. 10. Pine-tree, for to no other (as hee saith) he could more fitly compare it, though, for this reason, it might altogether as fitly haue beene compared to a Plinie the Philo • opher saith of palme-trees, merito d cetur ext • rne. Nulla est in Italia sp • nte genita. Teretes atque procerae sum. Coma omnis in cacumine. l. 13. c. 4. Palme-tree, had that tree beene aswell knowne in Italy, as in the Region wherein the Prophet liued, that did foretell this strange apparition so long before.Plin. lib. 6. Epist. 16.
Plinies words are these, Mater mea indicat ei apparere nubem inusitata & magnitudine & specie. Surgit ille, vt è sole solebat, frigida gustata; tacens enim studebat. Proposcit soleas, ascendit locum, ex quo maxime miraculum illud conspici poterat. Nubes, incertum procul intuentibus ex quo monte (Vesuuium suisse postea cognitum est) oriebatur: ouius similitudinem & formam non alia magis arbor quàm pinus expresserit. Nam longissimo velut trunco elata in altum quibusdam ramis diffundebatur. Credo, quia recenti spiritu euecta, dein senescente eo destituta, aut etiam pondere suo victa, in latitudinem vanescebat, candida interdum, interdum Represēting bloud and fire as the Prophet had foretold. sordida & maculosa, prout terram cineremuè sustulerat. Magnum id, propiusque noscendum vt eruditissimo viro visum est. That the Sunne was turned into darknesse, that with this smoake was mixed fire, may appeare from the the same authours words a little after: Iam dies alibi, illic nox omnibus noctibus nigrior, densiorque, quam tamen faces multae, variaque lumina soluebant.

This, which occasioned Wonderment to the Heathen, was (no doubt) a sufficient warning to all godly Christians, to betake themselues to their prayers; to expect the confirmation of their faith by their mightie deliuerance from those dangers, wherein innumerable Heathens vtterly perished, which made the heartes of all mankind, (besides,) to faile. This corporall preseruation of the elect from feare or danger, whilest cast-awaies perished, and trouble raged among the Nations, was that redemption which our Sauiour speakes of.

And Luk 21.28. when these things begin to come to passe, then looke vp, and lift vp your heads: for your redemption draweth nigh.
For this was a sure type or pledge of their and our eternall redemption. And before the bursting out of that fire, and the erection of those pillars of smoake before mentioned, God, as our Sauiour foretold, had sent his Angels to gather his elect together, either to places free from those general calamities, or miraculously to preserue them in the midst of them. For to denie or suspect the truth of Dions relations, I haue no reason: and yet what other cause to assigne of those Giants apparitions in Vesuuius, and the Townes about it immediatly before that danger, I know not, but onely that which our Sauiour had giuen.

p.hi: And hee shall send his Angels with a great sound of a trumpet, and they
shall gather together his elect from the foure winds, and from the one end of the Heauen to the other.

div.p: Thus Dion; Ita vero res acta: Viri multi & magni omnem naturam humanam excedentes, quales exprimuntur Gigantes, partim in ipso monte, partim in agro circumiacente, ac in oppidis interdiu noctuque terram obire, atque aera permeare visebantur. Posthaec consecuta est maxima siccitas, ac repentè ita graues terrae motus facti &c.

The like gathering of the elect Ecclesiastique writers mention in the seige of Ierusalems and Iewish warres; the godly sit at ease and in peace, whilst the obstinate and seditious were ouerwhelmd with calamitie vpon calamitie. And yet all the calamities which accompanied Ierusalems destruction, did in greater measure afflict the Heathens within few yeares after it was destroyed. Aboue other places, Gods plagues haunted the Romane Court, that all the world might take notice of our Sauiours prophesies. And the Romans albeit they knew not who had giuen the aduise, resolued yet to practise as our Sauiour aduised. Let
Ma • ke 13.15.16. him, sayth our Sauiour, that is vpon the house top not come downe into the house, neither enter therein, to fetch any thing out of his house. And let him that is in the field, not turne backe againe vnto the thinges which hee left behind him, to take his clothes. So Plinie testifies, that, in the times aboue mentiond, albeit the Pumicke stones did flie about mens eares in the open fields; yet they held it more safe, to bee abroad then within doores, arming their heads with pillowes and bolsters against the blowes they expected. In commune consultant, intratectane subsistant, an in aperto vagentur: nam crebris vastisque tremeribus tecta nutabant, & quasi emota sedibus suis, nunc huc, nunc
illuc abire, aut referri videbantur. Subdio rursus, quanquam leuium exesorum{que} pumicum casus metuebatur: quod tamen malorum collatio elegit. Ceruicalia capitibus imposita linteis constringunt. Id munimentum aduersus incidentia fuit

This was the beginning of that great and terrible day of the Lord, foretold by the Prophet, wherewith the world was for a long time shaken by fits, as it were by a deadly feuer, as may appeare from the like calamities in Traianes times, related by Dion. Our Sauiour himselfe expounds the Prophets wordes not of one day, but dayes; for
Mark. 13.19. there shall be in those dayes such tribulation, Vide Ch. 1. part. 2. sect. 3. cap. 7.
as was not from the beginning of the Creation which God created, neither shall be. So terrible were these dayes, that, as our Sauiour in the next word addeth, except the Lord had made an end of them, they had quickly made an end of all mankind. Euen at that time the world by the ordinarie course of Gods iustice should haue bin destroyed, but hee spared it at the instant prayers of his chosen, as hee would haue saued Sodom after iudgement was gone out, had there beene but a few such faithfull men in it, as in the fore mentioned times the world had many. So mercifull is our God, so louing vnto all the works of his hands, that his Son cannot come to iudgment so long as he shall find faith vpon the earth. Whosoeuer, saith the Prophet, shall call vpon the name of the Lord, shall bee saued; yea he shall saue others, as our blessed Sauiour more fully foretels what the Prophet sawe but in part: Except
Mark. 1.20. that the Lord had shortned those dayes, no flesh should be saued: but for the elects sake, which he hath chosen, he bath shortned those dayes. Other prophesies there be of those times, which seeme to intimate a finall destruction of all flesh without delay: and so, no doubt, the Prophets themselues conceiued of the world, as Ionah did of Niniue, which he looked should instantly haue perished vpō the expiration of the time he had foretold: Wrath they had seene goe out from the Lord, of force enough to haue dissolued the frame of nature, but could not vsually foresee either the number of the faithfull, or the dispositions of mens hearts vpon their summons: but this great Prophet, who onely foresaw all things, not onely foretels the calamities or iudgments due vnto the world, but withall foresees the number of the elect, their inclination to heartie prayers and repentance, by which he knew that fierce wrath of God, whose representation
presentation the Prophet saw, should be diuerted from the world; that his stroke should be a little broken.

Ʋide Cyprianum ad Demetr • anum.Out of such fathers as liued in the ages following, it is euident the calamities of these times had beene such, as did threaten the worlds end; many reliques of that grieuous disease, wherewith the world was sicke almost vnto death, remained vntill Saint Cyprians time. But as Ierusalems plagues did prognosticate the stormes of Gods wrath which were shortly after to bee shewed vpon the Nations; so these cast-away Iewes prefigure the Heathnish Temper: of whom that saying of our Sauiour holds as true, They
Luke 7.32. are like vnto children sitting in the market plaee, and crying one to another, and saying; wee haue piped vnto you, and yee haue not daunced: we haue mourned vnto you, and ye haue not wept.

In our Sauiours time, God inuited them with peace and plentie, which they foolshly atribute to their gods, or their owne policie: after his death hee threatens them with the former calamities, all which theyDixisti per nos fieri, & quod nobis debeant imputari omnia ista, quibus nunc mundus qualitur & vrgetur; quod di • vestri a nobis non colantur Cyprian ad Demet. falsely ascribe, as the superstitious in like cases vsually doe, to the alteration of Religion, and the decay of Idol-ship.

Would God, the tempter of this present age were not much worse then either the Iewes or Gentils was; not such as did threaten the finall destruction of the world, from which faith hath vtterly perished. But of this argument, as farre as befits Christian sobrietie to inquire, by Gods assistance, in it proper place. Thus much in this place I haue added, to perswade the Reader, that for ought any man knowes, or for any precedent signe can bee expected, they may, this might sound to iudgment: Watch we therfore, and pray continually, that we may be counted worthy to escape all these things that shall come to passe, and that we may stand before the Sonne of man.

div.head: THE ETERNALL TRVTH OF SCRIPTVRES, AND CHRISTIAN BELIEFE, THEREON WHOLLY Depending: manifested by it owne LIGHT. THE FIRST BOOKE.
SECT. I. [I beleeue in God the Father, &c.]
div.p: IF in any at all, most of all in this present argument, may the truth of that vsuall axiome best appeare, Dimidium facti qui bene coepit, habet.
What's well begunne, is wel nigh done.

If God shall enable mee rightly to vnfold the contents and meaning of this first word [Beleeue] I may iustly presume, the one halfe of this intended worke to be finished in it; seeing it is an essentiall part of euery Article in the Creed: such a part, as, if it be vnderstood amisse, we can not possibly vnderstand any one proposition of this whole confession aright. I shall not therefore seeme tedious (I trust) vnto the iudicious Reader, although I be somewhat long in vnfolding the nature and conditions of beliefe; the diuers acceptions and degrees of the same; with the meanes how it is, or may be wrought in our hearts.

Whether we speake of the Act, and operation of beleeuing, or of the disposition, and inclination of the mind, whence this operation
proceedeth, it skilleth not much: hee that knoweth the true meaning of the one, without anie further instruction may know the other. And because the Act or Operation is more easie to bee knowne, let vs beginne with the most common and general thereof, that is, with the best and most vsually knowne acception or notion of beliefe.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of Beliefe in generall.
div.p: TO beleeue a thing, is to assent vnto it as true, without any euident certaintie of the trueth thereof, either from our sense or vnderstanding.

2 That beliefe is an assent; that to beleeue is to assent, all agree: but what more besides assent is required to some, especially to Christian beliefe, is much controuersed amongst Diuines: of which (God willing) in the Articles following.

3 That euident certaintie, either of sense or vnderstanding, must be excluded from the assent, which is properly called beliefe, is euident and certaine by our vsuall and common speech. Thus whiles we demaund of him that relates any thing vnto vs for true (as newes or the like) whether he know his relation to be certainly true, or no: if he neither haue immediately heard nor seene the things which he relates, but haue onely taken them at the second hand, his vsuall answere is: Nay, I know not certainly, but I verily beleeu • they are true, for diuers reasons and credible reports: but if he had either seene or heard them himselfe, he would not say, I beleeue, but, I know they are most true. For euident certaintie doth drowne beliefe.

4 Yet is this euident knowledge (whether sensitiue or intellectuall) to be excluded only from the thing it selfe which is to be directly beleeued, not from other things that are linked or vnited to it by nature.

5 That which we euidently know, may oft-times be the cause, why we beleeue some other matters, that haue affinity with it. As he that seeth it very light in the morning, when he first openeth his eyes, may probably beleeue the Sunne is vp, because he euidently
seeth the ayre to be light. But no man (if you should aske him the same question) would say, that hee beleeued the Sunne was vp, when either the heate thereof doth scortch his face, or the beames dazell his eyes; for now he knoweth this trueth directly and euidently in it selfe. Nor is there any man that hath his right minde, that will say he verily beleeueth twice two make foure: for this is euident, and certaine to ordinarie capacities, and hee that onely beleeueth this, knoweth nothing. For what men know certainely and euidently, they will not say, they only beleeue, but know: what they so know not, they may truely and properly say, they beleeue, if their assent to it be greater than to the contrary.

6 Some againe distinguish this vneuident assent (which is properly called beliefe) from other assents or opinions, by the grounds on which it is built. The ground of it (in their opinion) is authoritas docentis, the authoritie of the teacher or auoucher of the points proposed to be beleeued.

7 This distinction in some cases is true, but it is not necessarie to all beliefe; nor doth it fully and properly distinguish beleefe from other vneuident assents or perswasions. For euen those assents or perswasions, which seeme most to relie vpon authorities, may be strengthened by other motiues or inducements: yea our beliefe, or relying vpon authorities, vsually (alwayes if it be strong) ariseth from experiment of our Authors fidelity and skill, as shall appeare hereafter. For our present proceedings we take it here as granted or supposed, that this word [Beleefe] as it is vsually taken, is more generall than that assent or perswasion, which relies vpon authoritie; yet not so generall, as to comprehend these assents or perswasions, which are euidently certaine.

8 It may be obiected, that the Apostle calleth euident knowledge, beliefe, when he saith, The diuells beleeue there is a God, and tremble. For it should seeme, that the diuels know as euidently that there is a God, as we do that the Sunne did shine but yesterday, or this morning. For they once enioyed the presence of God, and sawe his glorie, and since haue had euident experience of his power.

9 Of Gods being (no doubt) they haue euident certaintie, albeit of his other attributes their knowledge is not so directly nor euident, but coniecturall, or a kind of beliefe. Wherefore vnto this
place of our Apostle we may answere two wayes: Either that vnder this word [Beliefe] he comprehends not onely their assent vnto the being, or existence of the Godhead; but their assent vnto other attributes of God, which they know not so euidently, and therefore may be said to beleeue them. Or if he vnderstand onely that assent, which they gaue vnto the existence or beeing of the Godhead, he calleth this (though ioyned with euident knowledge) a beliefe, in opposition or with reference vnto the beliefe of hypocrites (against whom he there speakes) which was much lesse than this assent of diuells. For albeit that which is greater in the same kind, cannot be properly and absolutely said to be the lesse; as wee cannot properly and absolutely say that foure is three, but rather containes three in it: yet vpon some reference of the greater vnto the lesse contained in it, or vnto some other third, we may denominate the greater with the name of that which is lesse in the same kind: as wee may say of him that promised three and gaue foure, that he gaue three, because three is contained in foure. So the Philosopher saith, that Habitus est dispositio, euery habite is a disposition, not absolutely and properly, for it is more; yet because it is more, with reference vnto that which is lesse, or vnto the subiect in whom it is, we may say it is dispositio, that is, it containes disposition in it, albeit no man would say that habitus were dispositio, if he should define it.

10 And men vsually obiect to such as scoffe at matters of religion, that the day will come, wherein, if they repent not, they shal beleeue the things which now they little regard. Albeit they cannot be said in that day to beleeue them, if wee speake properly and absolutely, without reference to their former incredulitie. Our meaning is, they shall doe more than beleeue them, for they shall feele them. Nor can we say properly, that the elect after the resurrection shall beleeue the articles of faith: seeing all agree, that of these three principall vertues, Faith, Hope, and Loue, onely Loue shall then remaine. The reason is that which you haue heard alreadie; because euident knowledge must be excluded from the nature of faith and beliefe; and the godly shall then clearely see Christ face to face, and fully enioy the fruit of his passion, which now they only beleeue.

11 As for certaintie, we may not exclude it from the nature
of beliefe, vnlesse this speech be warily vnderstood. For the certaintie of the articles of our saith ought to be greater, than the certaintie of other knowledge; for we must beleeue them, although they be contrarie to the capacitie of our vnderstanding: for euen this must we beleeue, that many things (as all supernatural things) surpasse the reach of our vnderstanding. Yet this we may safely say, that the certaintie of the articles of our beliefe, [as of Christ his death, of his and our resurrection,] cannot be so great to vs in this life, as it shall be in the world to come, when we shall euidently know them. This rule then is infallible; that the knowledge of any thing is more certaine, than the beliefe thereof: although the beliefe of some things (as of Christ his passion) bee more certaine, than the knowledge of other things; as namely, than the knowledge of humane sciences. So then out of this it is euident, that beliefe, taken generally, doth neither exclude all certaintie, nor necessarily require any; seeing some beliefe hath a kind of certaintie adioyned with it, and some cannot admit it. Wherefore it remaineth, that assent is the essence of beliefe in generall; I say such an assent, as is not ioyned with euidencie.

12 This assent may be weaker or stronger, and so come nearer vnto, or be further from certaintie, according to the nature of that obiect, whereunto we giue assent; or according to the nature of that, whereupon our beliefe is grounded; or lastly, according to our apprehension either of the obiect, or that which is the ground of our assent. Excesse in the first of these [to wit, in certaintie or stabilitie of the obiect] doth rather argue a possibilitie of firmer beliefe, or more credibilitie; not more firme or actuall beliefe. For as many things are more intelligible than others, and yet are least vnderstood of many: so many that are most credible, are least beleeued.

13 Excesse in the second of these, whence the assent of beliefe may be strengthened, [that is, in the ground of beliefe,] doth rather argue a stronger hypotheticall beliefe, than any absolute beliefe; vnlesse the apprehension or conceit of this ground be strong and liuely. In ordinary reports or contracts, it skils not of what credit the partie be, vnto whose credence or authoritie we are referred for the truth of any promise or report; vnlesse wee haue good inducements to thinke, that he did either say, or promise as
we were told. If we be not thus perswaded by some apprehension of our owne; we giue onely conditional assent vnto the report or promise, and beleeue both with this limitation, [if he say so, whose credit wee so esteeme.] But if we can fully apprehend that he said so; we beleeue absolutely.

14 As in science or demonstrations it is requisite, both that we know the true cause of the effect, and also that we apprehend it certainly as the true cause; (otherwise we haue only an opinion:) so in true and absolute beliefe it is requisite, that we haue both a sure ground of our beliefe, and a true apprehension of that ground▪ otherwise our beliefe must needs be conditionall, not absolute. It remaineth therefore that we set downe, first the nature of the obiects that may be beleeued: secondly, the seuerall grounds of beliefe: and thirdly, the manner of apprehending them, albeit in some the apprehension of the obiect in it selfe, and the ground of beliefe, are in a sort all one; as in that beliefe, which is not grounded vpon the auhoritie of the teacher. This rule is generall; wheresoeuer the obiects are in themselues more credible, the ground may be more strong, and the apprehension more liuely, so men be capable of it, and industrious to seeke it: and equall apprehension of such obiects as are more credible in themselues, (vpon such grounds as are more firme) makes the beliefe stronger, than it could be of obiects lesse credible, or vpon grounds lesse firme. Ceteris paribus, euery one of these three, first, Greater credibilitie of the obiect, secondly, Surer ground of beliefe, thirdly, More liuely apprehension of the obiect or ground, encrease beliefe.

15 For the obiects of beliefe, (whence this assent must bee distinguished,) they are either naturall, or supernaturall; but first of tha • which is naturall. The obiects of naturall beliefe are of two sorts, either scibilia, or opinabilia; either such things as may be euidently knowne in themselues, but are not so apprehended by him that beleeues them; or else such things, as we can haue no euident or certaine knowledge of, but onely an opinion. And of this nature are all the monuments of former ages, and relations of ancient times, in respect of vs which are now liuing: all future contingents, or such effects, as haue no necessarie naturall cause why they should bee, nor no ineuitable let or hinderance why they may not be; as whether wee should haue raine or faire weather the next
moneth, whether such or such nations shall wage warre against each other the next yeare. These matters past, and contingent which are not yet, but may be, albeit they agree in the generall nature of opinabilia, that neither of thē can be exactly knowne, but only by opiniō beleued: yet both differ in that which is the ground of our assent or beliefe. The ground or reason why we beleeue things past, (as that Tully liued in Iulius Caesars time, or that the Saxons inhabited this land,) is the report of others. The ground or reason why we beleeue future contingents, is the inclination or propension which we see in second causes to produce such effects; or the coherence betwixt any naturall or morall contingent cause, & their possible or probable issue. As if we see one kingdom mightie in wealth, & at peace & vnitie in it selfe, bearing inueterate hate to another; or if we know that the one hath suffered wrong, not likely to be recompenced, and yet able in politique estimation to make it selfe amends: we beleeue that such will shortly be at open hostilitie one with another. Or if we see the ayre waterish, we beleeue it will shortly be rainy. Yet are not the grounds why we beleeue things past, and the grounds of beleeuing future contingents, alwayes so opposite, but that they may iumpe in one, and conspire mutually for the strengthening of beliefe. For we would beleeue our former coniecture of warre or weather a great deale the better, if a cunning States-man should giue iudgement of the one, or an Astronomer, or some that we know very weather-wise, his opinion of the other. For now, besides the probabilitie of our owne coniectures, we haue other mens authoritie to confirme our beliefe. In both kinds (either where the grounds of each are seuerall, or where both conspire together) as the ground of beliefe, or our apprehension of the ground is greater, so our beliefe waxeth stronger. THVS we beleeue the Romane stories of Caesars times more firmely, than the relations of Herodotus concerning matters of Aegypt, or other countries; because more Writers, and they such as are lesse suspected of vanitie or imposture, do testifie the truth of Romane affaires.

16 Other things, which are credible, or may be beleeued, are (as we said) scibilia; such things as may be exactly knowne by natura • l reason, though not of the partie which only beleeues them; (for exact knowledge alwayes expels meere beliefe of the same
thing in the same partie.) That the Sunne is bigger than the earth, or that the motion thereof is swifter than any arrowes flight, may bee knowne exactly by a Mathematician; but ordinarie country-men (such as are not rustically wayward) do beleeue it; euidently and exactly know it they cannot. The ground of their beliefe in such a case is authoritas docentis. And this authoritie of teachers, or others, vpon whose assertions we rely, consisteth partly in a perswasion of the teachers or relators skill in those matters which he teacheth or relateth; and partly in his honestie, fidelitie, or veracitie in his dealings, or sayings. And as these are reputed greater, so do we more beleeue him in these things which he auoucheth for true, and rely more securely vpon his authoritie. For as we said before, Caeteris paribus, the certaintie of beliefe encreaseth as the ground of beliefe doth, both for the number of points belieued, and for the firmenesse of the beliefe it selfe. If two of the same facultie teach vs diuers things, whereof we haue no other ground but their assertion, we beleeue him better, whose skill and fidelitie we account of better; and the more the parties be that report or auouch the same thing, the more we beleeue them, if they be reputed skilfull and honest. And where the authoritie is the same, both for extension and degrees: yet we beleeue the things taught better, from the better or more immediate apprehension of the authoritie. As if Aristotle, Euclide, or Archimedes were aliue, and in that reputation for skill in their seuerall professions, which their workes are in; we would beleeue those conclusions, which wee heard them teach, better than such as we had from them by others, or (as we said) at the second hand. For though the authoritie in both cases were the same: yet should not our apprehension of it be so; but more immediate in the former. We see by daily experience, how opinions, only grounded vpon the authoritie of teachers for their skill in such matters well reputed of, doe inforce others (especially inferiours in that kind of skill) to giue an assent vnto the same truth, although they haue good shew of reason to the contrarie. As what country-man is there, but would thinke he might safely sweare, that the earth were an hundred times greater than the Sunne? yet if an Astronomer, (of whose skill he hath had experience in other matters, which he can better discerne) one whom he knew to be an honest plaine dealing man, not accustomed
to cog with his friend, should seriously auouch the contrarie, that the Sunne is bigger then the earth; few country men would be so wayward as not to beleeue their friend Astronomer, albeit (his authoritie set aside) they had no reason to thinke so, but rather the contrarie. And it were a signe of ignorant arrogancie, if punies or fresh-men should reiect the axiomes and principles of Aristotle, vsuall in the schooles, because they haue some reasons against them, which themselues cannot answere. For reason might tell them, that others (their betters) which haue gone before them, haue had greater reasons to hold them, then they can yet haue to deny them. This perswasion of other mens skill or knowledge will winne the assent of modest and ingenuous youths, vnto such rules or axiomes, as otherwise they would stiffely deny, and haue wittie reasons to ouerthrow. But albeit this assent, which men giue to conclusions, they know not themselues, but onely beleeue vpon other mens asseuerations, may be very great; as many countrymen will beleeue an Astronomer affirming that the Sun is greater then the earth, better then they will the honestest of their neighbours in a matter that may concerne both their commodities: yet if the relators or auouchers could make them conceiue any probable reason of the same conclusions, [as if the Astronomer in the mentioned case could shew, how euery body the further it is from vs seemeth the lesse, and then declare how many hundred miles the Sunne is from vs:] mens minds would be a great deale better satisfied, and this assent or beliefe, which formerly did onely relie vpon authoritie, would be much strengthened by this second tie or hold-fast. And if we would obserue it, there is vsually a kind of regresse betwixt our beliefe of authorities, and our assent vnto conclusions taught by them. First (vsually) we beleeue authoritie, and afterwards the conclusions taught by it, for the authorities sake. But after we once find experiment of the truth of conclusions so taught, we beleeue the authoritie the better from this experimentall truth of the conclusion.

17 But of all these acceptions and degrees of beliefe or assent, something may be gathered for better expressing the seuerall degrees of true Christian beliefe; which like Iacobs ladder reacheth from earth to heauen. The first step whereof is beliefe or assent vnto things supernaturall.

div.head: The first generall part. SECT. 2.
CHAP. I. Of assent vnto obiects supernaturall.
div.p: THings supernatural we call such, as the naturall reason of man cannot attaine vnto; or such, as naturally can neither bee knowne or assented vnto as probable, but are made knowne or probable by reuelation. Such are the mysteries of our saluation, and the articles of christian beliefe. For no article of our beliefe (if we consider them with all the circumstances, and in that exact manner as they are proposed in Scripture to be beleeued) could euer haue come into corrupted mens cogitation, vnlesse God had reuealed it vnto him. Seeing then we cannot know them in any sort by humane reason and authoritie; neither can humane reason or authority be the ground of our assenting to them; it remaineth then, that authoritas docentis, the word of God, be the ground of our beliefe.

2 Here then must you call to mind what wee said before, that authoritas docentis did consist in two things; namely in the ski • l, and fidelitie, or sinceritie of the Teacher: and by how much we know those to be greater, by so much is our assent or beliefe strengthened. Now it is euident to reason that God is infinitely wise, and therefore can not be deceiued; whence necessarily it followeth that hee knoweth, and can tell vs the truth. Againe it is euident that God is most iust and true, and therefore will not deceiue vs, but will tell vs the truth if hee professe so. Againe, wee can not conceiue of God aright, but wee must conceiue of him as omnipotent, and full of power; and consequently such a one as needes not in policie, or iealousie of our emulating him in knowledge, to tell vs otherwise than he knowes. Lib. 1. ca 2. And therefore Aristotle in the beginning of his Metaphysickes reprehendeth the Poets, for saying,
that the Gods did enuie men knowledge. His resolution is in English to this effect,
That Poets should the Gods belie,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
More like, than Gods should men enuie.

3 And if the Heathen were of opinion, that the Gods did not enuie men knowledge; then must they needes beleeue, that if they taught them any, they would teach them true knowledge. Wherfore this must be laid downe as a certaine ground, that whatsoeuer God teacheth vs, is most true. Nor is there any (admitting there were a God) but would assent vnto this. But here is the difficultie. How can we be assured that God doth teach vs any of these things? Or, how shall we know, that this wee call Scripture, is the word of God? If our apprehension of this ground be sure, our faith is firme and absolute: if our apprehension hereof be doubtfull, our faith must needs be vnstable, or, at the best, but conditionall.
4 Let vs first therefore looke what this conditionall assent or beliefe doth bind vs vnto.

Although many, that firmely beleeue whatsoeuer God saith, is true, either doe not acknowledge or doe not firmely beleeue that these Scriptures are the word of God: yet thus much in all sense and reason any naturall man will grant; there bee great presumptions and probabilities, why they should be taken for the word of God. And he that doth acknowledge but thus much, doth by this acknowledgement bind himselfe to reuerence them aboue all humane writings. For all men naturally know, that if they be Gods word, they are worthy all possible reuerence. Wherefore if a man suppose it only as probable, that they are, or know nothing ro the contrary why they may not be Gods word: he is bound to reuerence and esteeme them aboue all words or writings of man. As for example; If any subiect in this land should receiue letters concerning some lawfull and indifferent request from any other his equal or fellow subiect, whom he had great reason wel to respect; suppose he certainly knew that they were such a mans letters, and no counterfaite: yet if hee should receiue letters in his Maiesties name, containing the same or other as reasonable request: although he knew not so certainly that these were his Maiesties letters,
as that the others were some wel-respected Subiects, yet is he in duty bound to vse them with greater respect and reuerence, than the former. The bare presumption and probabilitie that they were the Kings letters, doth bind him to inquire further, whether they were his Letters or no: nor were his fault excusable, if hee should shew any signe of disloyalty, or irreuerence towards them, vntill hee knew that they were not such, as their Title or Superscription did import.

5 He that hath but the same probabilitie, that the Scriptures containe in them Gods owne wordes, as that Liuie his Histories containe the Roman affaires, must needs esteeme of them infinitly aboue all humane workes. And this fruit hypotheticall or supposed beliefe may bring forth, euen in the vnregenerate or natural man. And what hath beene said of reuerence to the Scriptures vpon this supposall, is also most true of mans actions. If men doe but beleeue it as probable, that the Scriptures are the Word of God: this beliefe will procure many good morall actions, and much amendment of life; though not such spirituall perfection, as God in his word requireth. And the reasō of this assertion is euident. For we see daily, that men vndertake actions of great difficultie and danger, not so much according to the probabilitie of attaining some good, as according to the greatnesse of that good which possibly may be attained. So we see many, that might liue in ease at home with certaintie of moderate gaines, to vndertake voyages to the West or East Indies, onely vpon this resolution, That if it be their lucke or lot to bee rich, there they may haue enough; although the aduenture bee subiect to great dangers, and obnoxious to infinite casualties. And many there be, that wil not vsually lay out a penny, but vpon very faire ground of some gaine or sauing thrift, who yet will be well content to venture a crowne or an angell in a Lotterie, where there may bee some possibilitie, though no probabilitie, of obtaining twentie or thirtie pounds. These and infinite other examples, obuious to daily experience, may serue as a perfect induction of our generall assertion: That the meere possibilitie of obtaining some great and extraordinary good, is of greater moment in swaying mens actions, than certaintie of accomplishing pettie desires, or greatest probabilities of purchasing ordinarie commodities or delights. To deduce then out of this
generall the particular we intended: In the Scripture are promised to all such as loue God and do his will, farre greater blessings, than humane knowledge could euer haue conceiued. The like is true in auoyding dangers. Men oftentimes vndertake matters of more difficulty and charges, to preuent some grieuous mischaunces which may insue, than they would doe to escape some imminent but ordinary daunger, or to release themselues from some smaller harmes that already haue befallen them. Could men consider these things seriously, and account of them but as probable: what is there in this life, which in any reason they should not venture for the obtaining of so great a good? Were men but probably perswaded that there were (as the Scriptures and the articles of our Beliefe tell vs) a life euerlasting, full laden with all the fruites of true life, ioy, peace and all choisest pleasures, without any annoyance: how could they not be most readie, and willing to spend this whole transitorie life (whose dayes are but few, and most of them euill, full fraught with griefe and distresse) in the seruice of God, who would thus reward them? Yea, how could they not be desirous to lay downe this life it selfe, vpon hope of obtaining such a life? For this life compared to that to come, hath not the proportion of a farthing to whole millions of Golde, or all the treasures in this world. Nor is the case herein like vnto that of aduentures or Lotterie; where a man may venture his life, or goods if he list, but if hee doe not, none calleth him to an accompt for not doing it: But in the Scriptures euerlasting torments, griefe, and perpetuall horror are threatned to all such, as frame not their liues according to Gods will in them reuealed.

div.head: The first generall Part. SECT. 2. CHAP. II. Of generall incitements to search the truth of Scriptures or Christian beliefe.
div.p: WE may hence clearely see how inexcusable, euen in the iudgement of flesh and bloud, all men are, that either by hearing or reading haue anie accesse vnto the Gospell, and doe not vse the best indeuours of their naturall witte (if God as yet haue touched their hearts with no better grace) to search out the truth thereof. For seeing in the Scriptures are proposed to euery mans choice euerlasting life, or euerlasting death: what extreame madnesse is it for men to enter into any course of life, or to vndertake any matter of moment, which may exact their chiefe imployments, before they haue diligently looked to the maine chaunce? before they haue tried the vtmost of their wits, and others best aduise, to know the tenour of their owne estate? Wee see daily what great paines men of no small account doe take in the studie of Alchymie, spending their spirites, and most of their substance in trying conclusions, and searching out the truth of those things, for which they haue but weake grounds of Philosophie or reason; onely the conceit of the good they aime at, (which is rather possible than probable for them to attaine) inforceth a kinde of hope, and incourageth them to goe forward.

2 To speake nothing of the good the Scripture promiseth, the very conceit of eternall death (me thinkes) should moue, either the Chymickes, (which spend much gold only vpon hope of getting more) or any other man whatsoeuer, to spend all the treasure, whatsoeuer either this their Art, or all other could yeeld, to secure themselues from such horrible torments, as the Scriptures
threaten to their Contemners or negligent Hearers. And why should not all men then in reason bestow most time and paines, in searching the truth of those things, which concerne their soules estate; whose securitie in all reason they should purchase with the highest hopes, and vtmost aime of all other trauelles in this life. Here then (as I said) the full height of mans iniquitie, and his inexcusable madnesse, is most plainely discouered; that hauing these two motiues, which in naturall reason doe sway all humane actions, offering themselues to incourage him in searching the Scriptures: yet notwithstanding most men bestow lesse labor in them, than in other ordinarie studies. First, if we compare the good they set before vs, as a recompence and reward of our trauelles, it is beyond all comparison greater than the scope of any other trade, or science. For here is a double infinitie of solid good; first, they promise ioy two waies infinit, both in degree & continuance; secondly, they threaten vnto their contemners and despisers death and torments doubly infinite, both in degree and continuance. Now if the probabilities of the truth of Scriptures were farre lesse, than is vsually found in other studies, or humane hopes: yet could this in humane reason be no reason why wee should labour lesse in them, than in other affaires; seeing the incomparable excesse of the good they promise, doth aboundantly recompence this. But if the probabilitie of the truth of Scripture, be in naturall reason equall to the probabilities which men vsually take for their grounds in many greatest attempts; then certainly not to bestow as great paines and trauell, in trying the truth of their promises, as in any other humane attempts, or affaires, doth argue infinit madnesse. Aske we the Chymick, what reason he hath to toile so much in the studie of Paracelsus, or other intricate writers of his facultie; (the like we may say of any Physitians:) their answere (as you may reade in their writings) is this: Many Philosophers in former ages haue laboured much in this studie, and haue set downe good rules of their experiments; who (as is probable) would neuer haue taken such paines vpon no ground. And verily this tradition, or the authoritie they giue to their Writers, is their chiefe motiue. For I thinke few of their ancient Authors haue bequeathed to their successors any gold made by this art, thereby to encourage them. If then tradition, consent of time, or approbation of authors, or
relation of experiments, be an especiall inducement for men to aduenture their charge, paines, and trauell in this facultie, as in all other affaires: without all controuersie the Scriptures in all these motiues haue an especiall prerogatiue aboue all other faculties or sciences, albeit humane reason were admitted iudge. For the authoritie of Gods Church is farre more generall, then the consent of any writers in one faculty whatsoeuer. The consent of time likewise is greater. For no age since Christs time in these ciuill parts of the world, but by the report of other Writers, as well as Christians, hath yeelded obedience vnto Scriptures as the word of God.
