Men of most excellent spirits and learning in euery age, haue addicted their studies vnto this truth. About the time of our Sauiours comming, curious arts, and other ciuill disciplines did most flourish. The Grecians sought after wisdome and secular Philosophie with the like; the Romans after policie, state-knowledge, and discipline of warre; all the world almost, (aboue others, those places wherein Christianitie was first planted) was then set vpon curious arts: yet we see how the studie and search of Scriptures in short time did proue, as Aarons rod amongst the Magitians serpents. It hath deuoured all, and brought them to acknowledge allegiance vnto it; vsing the helpe of best secular arts, as it were nutriment for the growth of Christianitie, and expelling the rest as excrements out of the Church. Nor can the Atheist name any age, wherein the Heathen had an Oliuer to oppugne our profession,Porphyrius in vita Plautini. but we had a Rowland to defend it: if they had a Porphyrie or Celsus to oppose philosophie against it, we had an Origen (a man, by their owne confession, of the most rare wit and hope for philosophie then liuing,) to forsake philosophie and follow Christianitie. It was not despaire which made him and many other excellent schollers, Christians: but the sure hope which they found in this profession, made them contemne all other hopes, and cleaue to it with their hearts and soules; albeit their soules should for so doing be violently separated from their bodies. This triall, I am perswaded, few of their greatest Philosophers would haue endured; but they had the potentates of the world, as readie to applaud them, as to disgrace the Christians; and yet the Christians multiplied as the Israelites did by oppression in Aegypt. How resolute they were, if we may not be beleeued bearing witnes of our own
profession, letEpistol. lib. 10. ep. 100. ad Traianum. In ijs, qui ad me tanquam Christiani deferebantur, hunc sum sequntus modum. Interrogaui ipsos, an essent Christiani: confitentes iterum, ac tertio interrogaui, supplicium minatus persenerantes duci iussi. Ne{que} enim dubitaui, qualecun{que} esset quod faterētur? peruicaciam certè, & inflexibilem obstinationem debere puniri. Plinie testifie, in whose iudgement, constancie and resolution was the only crime in our profession deseruing punishment. And for this cause he tooke want of resolution, in such as had been accused before him vnder the name of Christians, as a sufficient argument that they were not ChristiansIbid. Propositus est libellus sine autore multorum nomina continens, qui negint se esse Christianos aut fuisse. Quum prae eunte me déos appellarent, & imagini tuae, quam propter hoc iusseram cum simulachris numinum adferri, thure, ac vino s • p • l carent, praeterea maledicerent Christe; quorum nihil cogi posse dicuntur, qui sunt re vera Christiani; dimittendos putaui. in deed or heart; for such, as he had been informed, could not be inforced to any such idolatrous practise as he perswaded these men vnto.

3 Lastly, the experiments which are related by Authors of this profession, men (in any reasonable mans iudgement) as much to be beleeued herein, as any other writers in theirs; are farre more notable, and apt to produce beliefe, and hope of attaining the truth in this profession, than any others can haue in theirs. The experiments of others were but ordinarie and naturall; these are extraordinarie and supernaturall. If the Atheist should impudently deny the truth of their report: we may conuince him with Saint Augustines acute dilemma. If the miracles related by our Writers be true, they giue euident experiment of the truth of Scripture: if there were no such particular miracles, but all feigned; then this was a miracle aboue all miracles, that Christian religion should preuaile against all other arts, power, or policie, without any extraordinary euent or miracle. It was not so easie a matter to cozen all the Romane Emperours, and their deputies, with feigned tales; the world, which hated Christians so much, was inquisitiue enough to know the truth of their reports. I may conclude; nisi veritas magna fuisset non praeualuisset. It was miraculous, doubtlesse, that it should so encrease without armes; without any promise of carnall pleasure, or securitie: but euen against their naturall inclination that did professe it, and all the worlds opposition against it. It had enemies both priuate and publike, domestique and forren, euen the flesh and sence of those which followed it fought against it.

4 Mahomet since that time hath found a multitude of followers; but all either inforced to follow him by threats of shame, disgrace, and tortures in this life; or else allured thereto by faire promises of carnall pleasures to be perpetuall without interruption in the life to come. He hath set his followers such a course, as they might be sure both of winde and tide. And if the hauen whereat they arriue were as safe as their course is e • sie, they were of all men
the most happy. But Christianitie from its first beginning, was to rowe against the streame of flesh and bloud, and to beare out saile against all the blasts that the diuell, world, or flesh could oppose against it. In a word, the increase of Mahumetisme hath followed the barbarous Turkish monarchies aduancement, as moysture in bodies doth the increasing fulnesse of the Moone. And it had bin an extraordinary miracle, if a barbarous multitude (neuer acquainted with any ciuill pleasures,) should not haue composed theyr mindes vnto their Emperours; in following a religion, framed, as it were, to court the senses, and wooe the flesh. But Christianitie then flourished most, when the scorching heat of persecution was at the height: When the countenance of Emperours, as terrible to their foes (for their heroicall valour) as plausible to their friends (for their louely carriage) were most fiercely set against it. What Princes either more terrible to their enemies, or more amiable to their friends, than Traian, Dioclesian, or others of the Christians persecutors were? What man liuing is there of ciuill education, that would not haue lothed Mahomet, and the whole succession of the Ottoman familie, in respect of these Roman Princes? And yet a great part of their natiue subiects, men, as otherwise excellently qualified, so of a quiet and peaceable disposition; yet readie alwayes to venture their liues for these heathen Princes, in most dangerous seruice against the enemies of the Roman Empire, but most ready to follow the crucified Christ through fire and sword, against their Emperors command (dearer to them than this mortall life) and all the worlds threats, or allurements. It were sottish to thinke, that such men had not perfect notice of some higher powers commaundement to the contrarie, (whom they thought it safer to obey) when they contradicted the commaundements, or faire allurements of these supreame earthly powers. And it were as seely a persuasion to thinke, that, if the great Turke would change his religion for any other, that might yeeld like hopes of carnall pleasure after this life, any great number of his subiects would loose their dignities for refusing Subscription.

5 The briefe of what hath beene, or may be said concerning the grounds or motions of our assent vnto obiects supernaturall, may be comprised in these 4. propositions following; of which the first two are axiomes euident in nature, and receiued by all:
The two latter vndoubted axiomes amongest true beleeuers, but suppositions onely to meere naturall men, or nouices in Christianitie.

6 The first, The stile or title of these sacred Books pretending diuine authoritie, binde all men to make triall of their truth, commended to vs by our ancestours, confirmed to them by the bloud of Martyrs their predecessors; to vse the meanes which they prescribe for this triall; that is, abstinence from things forbidden, and alacritie in doing things commaunded by them.

7 The second, Ordinarie apprehension, or naturall beliefe of matters contained in Scriptures, or the Christian Creede, are of more force to cause men vndertake any good, or abstaine from anie euill, than the most firme beliefe of ordinarie matters, or anie points of meere naturall consequence.

8 The third, Obiects and grounds of Christian beliefe, haue in them greater stabilitie of truth, and are in themselues more apt to found most strong and firme beliefe, than any other things whatsoeuer meerely credible.

9 For, as the most noble essences, and first principalls of euery Art, are most intelligible: so are diuine truths of all other most credible. Not that they are more easie to be assented to of anie, at their first proposall, but that they haue a greater measure of credibilitie in them: and as their credibilitie and truth is inexhaustible, so beliefe of them once planted, can neuer grow to such fulnesse of certaintie, as not to receiue daily increase, if we apply our minds diligently vnto them: so that true Christian beliefe admits no stint of growth in this life, but still comes nearer and nearer to that euidencie of knowledge, which shall swallow it vp in the life to come. For the conceit of impossibilities are repugnances in nature, obiected by the obdurate Atheists to make the principles of Christian Religion seeme incredible (that they might like olde truants haue the company of nouices in Christianitie to loiter, or mis-spend good houres with them:) we shall by Gods assistance dispell them, and all other cloudes of like errours, in vnfoulding the truth of those Articles, which they most concerne.

10 The fourth, the means of apprehending the truth of Scriptures, and experiments confirming their diuine authoritie, are, both for varietie of kindes, and number of indiuidualles in euerie
kind, farre more and more certaine, than the meanes of apprehending the grounds of any other beliefe, or the experiments of anie other teachers authoritie.

11 Some particulars of euery kinde, with the generall heads or common places whence like obseruations may be drawne, we are now to present, so farre as they concerne the confirmation of the truth of Scriptures in generall. For the experiments, which confirme the truth of such particular places of Scripture, as teach the Articles of our Creede expresly, will come more fitly into the vnfolding of the Articles themselues.

div.head: The second generall part of the first Booke.
SECT. 1.
Containing Experiments or Obseruations confirming the truth of Scriptures in generall.
div.p: ALthough the Experiments confirming the trueth of Scriptures be, as I haue said, many and diuers; yet all may bee reduced into these two generall heads or kinds. They may be found, either in the stile or character of these writings themselues; the affections or dispositions of their writers; or in euents or experiments (whatsoeuer the course of times affords) answerable to the rules set downe in scriptures.

div.head: SECT. I. Of Experiments of the former kind. CHAP. I. Of Historicall Characters of sacred writings.
div.p:
TO anie man indued with reason not peruerted, the Bookes of Moses giue more perfect proofe of matters done and acted, than anie other historie in the world can possibly doe: albeit we set aside the secret Characters of Gods spirit speaking in them, which
we suppose can be discerned of none, but such as haue the marke of the Lambe answereable to it ingrauen vpon their hearts: But now wee seeke such inducements to beliefe, as may perswade the naturall vnregenerate man of the historicall truth of these sacred volumes.

2 The preiudices arising from the strangenesse of matters related by him, the Reader shall finde mitigated in the next discourse: In the meane time I must request him to suspend his iudgement of them, and onely to intend the liuely characters of historicall truth in other relations, of matters neither strange nor incredible in themselues. Either he wrote a true historie, or else his wordes are but a fiction: either poeticall to delight others, or politicall to aduantage himselfe or his successors. Ler such as doubt of theyr historicall truth, duely examine, whether many things related by him can possibly be referred to any of these two ends. As for example, if these relations, Genesis 4.1, and the 25. had not beene either reall adiuncts of some famous truth then sufficiently known, or else appoynted by God to be notified for some speciall purpose to posteritie: Low could it possibly haue come into anie mans thought, or to what end should it haue gone thence into his pen, to shew the reason why Euah should call her first son Caine, or her third Seth?

3 He that would set himselfe to contradict, might replie; Moses his inuention was so copious, as to forecast that those insertions might make his Historie seeme more probable: or that hee spake vnawares according to the custome of the times wherein he liued. But why then should he omit the like in all the generations from Cain and Seth vnto Noah; the reason of whose name giuen him by his father he likewise specifies, Genesis 5.29. Then Lamech begate a sonne, and called his name Noah, saying, This same shall comfort vs concerning our worke, and sorrow of our hands, as touching the earth which the Lord hath cursed? It was doubtlesse from some diuersitie in the matter presupposed vnto this worke, not from the workemans choice or inuention, why the reason of these three mens names should be specified; as afterwards will more plainly appeare. For the positiue notes, or sure tokens of a true historie, they are most plentiful • in the Stories of Abraham, Iacob, and Ioseph. Each part of which the Diuine Prouidence, (where of these
are the most ancient, most perfect, most liuely patternes,) would haue set out with such perspicuitie of all circumstances, that the Reader might bee an eie-witnesse of their historicall truth. The subiect and issue whereof is in it selfe so pleasant, as will rauish sober and attentiue mindes, and allure them to follow the maine current of Diuine Mysteries, which flowe from these Histories mentioned, as from their first heads or fountaines. To point at some few, rather than handle any particulars.

4 If we may iudge of the truth of mens writings by their outward forme or character, as wee doe of mens honestie by their lookes, speach or behauiour: what historie in the world beares so perfect resemblance of things done and acted, or yieldes (without further testimonie than its owne,) so full assurance of a true narration, as the stories of Abrahams departure out of his Land, his answers to God; Sarahs distrust vpon misconceit of Gods promises; her seeking to fulfill it by giuing her Maid to Abraham, the maner of her speach vpon her Maides contemning her; the debatement and issue of her controuersie, the dialogue betweene the Angells of God and Abraham, with Sarahs apologie for her laughing at their message; Abrahams iourney to mount Moriah, his seruants expedition to Aram Naharim, with his commission to prouide his young maister a wife? There appeares not in any of these the least surmise of any politicall respect, not any signe of affected delight, or poeticall representations: seeing this Author falles immediately into other matters, and relates euerie thing (though many of most diuerse natures) with such naturall specification of euerie circumstance, as vnlesse our hearts were praepossest with beliefe, that hee had writ them by his direction, who perfectly knoweth all things, aswell fore-past, as present, or to come, we would be perswaded that most of them were relations of such as acted them, vttered to their familiar friends immediatly vpon the fact, whilest all circumstances were fresh in memorie.

5 How others are affected I can not tell, mee thinkes when I reade that storie, Genesis 34. I am transformed into a man of the old world, and become a neighbor of old Iacob, ouer-hearing him and his sonnes debating the slaughter of the Sichemites. The old man complaines; Yee haue troubled mee, and made me stincke among the inhabitants of the Land, as well the Canaanites as the Perizites:
and I being few in number, they shall gather themselues together against me, and so shall I and mine house be destroyed and they answered and said; Shall he abuse our sister as a whoore?

6 Or if this description, though issuing as naturally out of the reall disposition of the true, no fained parties described, as brightnesse out of the bodie of the Sunne, yet because but short, may seeme more imitable by art: I will propose a longer dialogue betwixt this old man and his sons for a patterne: of which the fairest colours, that Art or Inuention can put vpon any fained Subiect, will come as farre short, as Salomons gawdy, but artificiall attire, did of the natiue beautie of wild Lillies; or any die that Arte can giue of the naturall splendor of finest pearles, the Onix or other more precious stone. The story is, Genesis 42.29. And they came to Iacob their father vnto the land of Cana • , and told him al that had befallen them, saying, vers. 30. The man, who is Lord of the Land, spake roughly vnto vs, and put vs in prison as Spies of the Countrey v. 31. And we said vnto him, wee are true men, and are no Spies. verse 32. Wee bee twelue brethren, sonnes of our father: one is not, and the yongest is this day with our father in the Land of Canaan, verse 33. Then the Lord of the Countrey said vnto vs, Hereby shall I know if yee be true men. Leaue one of your brethren with me, and take food for the famine of your houses, and depart, verse 34. and bring your yongest brother vnto me; that I may know that ye are no Spies, but true men: So wil I deliuer you your brother, and ye shal occupie in the Land. verse 35. And as they emptied their sackes, behold, euery mans bundell of money was in his sacke, and when they and their father saw the bundels of their money, they were afraid verse 36. Then Iacob their father said vnto them, Ye haue robbed me of my children: Ioseph is not, and Simeon is not, and ye will take Beniamin: all these things are against me, verse 37. Then Reuben answered his father, saying, Slay my two sonnes, if I bring him not to thee againe: Deliuer him to mine hand, and I will bring him to thee againe, verse 38. But he said, My sonne shall not goe downe with you: for his brother is dead, and hee is left alone: if death come vnto him by the way which yee goe, then yee shall bring my gray gead with sorrow vnto the graue. Chapter 43. verse 1. Now great famine was in the land. verse 2. And when they had eaten of the vict • als, which they had brought from Aegypt, their father said vnto them, Turne aga • ne, and buy vs a little food. verse 3. And Iudah answered him, saying, The man charged vs by an oath, saying, Neuer see m •• ce, e • cept your brother be with you. verse 4. If thou wilt send our Brother with vs, wee will goe downe and buy thee food: verse 5. but if thou wilt not send him, wee will not goe downe: for the man said vnto vs, Looke me not in the face, except your Brother be with you. Genesis 42. from the 29. vnto the 15. verse of the 43. Chap. The circumstances, which I would especially commend vnto the Readers consideration, are; first, the old mans iealousie, verse 36. vpon his sonnes relation what had befallen them in their iourney, and the Gouernours desire of seeing Beniamin, verse 31.32.33.34.35. his peremptorie replie, v. 38. to Reubens answer, v. 37. the manner of his relenting, chap. 43. v. 6. vpon necessitie of their going for more food; and his sonnes peremptorie refusall to goe without Beniamin, in the fiue first verses
of the 43. Chap.Verse 6 And Israel said, Wh • refore draft yee so euill with me, as to tel the man, whe • her yee had yet a brother, or no? verse 7. And they answered, The man asked straitly of our selues, and of our kinred, saying, Is your father yet aliue? Haue yee any brother? And we told him according to these wordes. Could we know certainly that hee would say, Bring your brother down? verse 8. Then said Iudah, to Israel his father, Send the boy with me, that wee may rise and goe, and that wee may l ue and not die, both we, and thou, and our ch ldren verse 9. I will bee suretie for him: of my hand shalt thou require him: If I bring him not to thee, and se •… him before th • e, then let mee beare the blame for euer. verse 10 For except yee had made thi •… tarrying, doubtlesse by this wee had returned the second time. verse 11. Then their Father said vnto them, If it must needes bee so now, doe thus: Take of the best fruits of the Land in your vessels▪ and bring the man a present, a little rozen, a little hony, spices and myrrhe, nuts, and almonds, vers •… 12. And take double mony in your hand, and the mony that was brought againe in your sack • mouths 〈…〉 carry it againe in your hand, lest it were some ouersight. verse 13. Take also your brother, and arise, an •… goe againe to • he man, verse 14 And GOD Almightie giue you mercie in the sight of the man 〈…〉 that hee may deliuer you your other brother, and Beniamin: but I shall bee robbed of my child, as 〈…〉 haue beene. his condescending, verse 11. vpon their iust apologie for mentioning their yongest brother to the Gouernours & Iudahs vndertaking for Beniamins safe conduct backe, and forth, in the 10.9.8. and 7. verses; lastly, the close or epiphonema of his speech, verse 13 and 14. Whilest I compare one of the circumstances with another, and all of them with other precedent and consequent, (chiefly with Iudahs speech to Ioseph, Genesis 44. from the sixteenth verse to the end of the Chapter) although I knew no other Scripture to make me a Christian, this one place would perswade me to become a Pythagorean, and thinke that my soule had been in some of Iacobs sonnes, where it had heard this controuersie; rather than to imagine, that it could haue beene fained by any that liued long after.

7 Or if we consider not the particular relations onely, but the whole contriuance and issue of this storie; what paterne of like inuention had Moses to follow? If the Atheist graunt such a Diuine prouidence, as hee describes; let him tell vs whence hee learned it. If from any more Ancient description, let this be suspected for artificiall; if not, let this bee acknowledged for the first and naturall representation of it. Without either a former patterne to imtate, or true resemblance of such a Diuine Prouidence in euents immediatly to bee related; how could such a Supreame power, gouerning and disposing all thinges contrary to the designes and purposes of man, be by mortall man conce • ued? More probable is the Poets fiction, that Minerua should be conceiued in Iupiters braine; than that humane fancie should bring forth a more Omnipotent, more wise or excellent deitie, than the Poets make their Iupiter, without any true Image of his Prouidence, manifested in the effectes? But after the manifestation of it in the story of Ioseph,
and the liue-picture of it taken by Moses; all imitation of it was not so difficult, though he that would seeke to imitate him fully should herein come as far short of the solide marks of his historicall truth, as the Egyptians Iuglers tricks did of true miracles.

8 As all these, and many other places yeelde vndoubted characters of true historicall narrations, so doe his speeches vnto this people, Deut. 39.30, 31. infallible symptomes of a dying man, and one that indeed had borne this mighty nation, as an Eagle beares her yong ones vpon her wings. These admirable straines of his heauenly admonitions, and diuine Prophecies, compared with the liue images of former truths, witnesse, that hee was the Ianus of Prophets, Va • es oculatus tam praeteritorum quam futurorum, one that could both cleerely see what had beene done before his birth, and what should fall out after his death: Both which shall hereafter (God willing) better appeare, by matters related, and euents foretold by him.

9 But to proceede, the whole historicall part of the Bible, not Moses his Bookes alone, yeeld plenty of such passages, as beeing compared with other circumstances, or the maine drift and scope of the entire stories, whereof they are parts, leaue no place for imagination, either why they should, or how possibly they could haue beene inserted by Art or Imitation; or haue come into any mans thoughts, not moued by the reall occurrence of such occasions a • are specified in the matters related. And seeing all of them are related by such as affect no Art; many of them by such as liued long after the parties that first vttered or acted them: wee can not conceiue how al particulars could be so naturally and fully recorded, vnlesse they had beene suggested by his spirite, who giueth mouth and speech to man, who is alike present to all successions, able to communicate the secret thoughts of forefathers to their children, and put the very words of the deceased, neuer registred before, in the mouths or pennes of their successours for many generations after, as distinctly and exactly, as if they had bin caught in characters of steele or brasse as they issued out of their mouths,
10 When I reade that Speech in Ouid, 4. Metam. Fab. 8.

l.hi: Siue es mortalis, qui te genuere beati
Si qua tibi soror est, & quae dedit vbera nutrix.

q.l: If mortall thou, thrice happy sure thy parents bee;
Or if thou any sister hast, thrice happy shee;
Thrice happy Nurse, whose breasts gaue sucke to thee.

div.p: I see no inducement to beleeue this for a true Storie, because I know the end and aime of his writing was, to inuent Verisimilia, to faine such speeches, as best befitted the persons whose part hee tooke vpon him to expresse, thereby to delight his hearers with varietie of liuely representations. But when I reade that narration of our Sauiors Apologie for himselfe against the Iewes, which said he had an vncleane spirit, Luke 11.14. and a woman comming in with her verdict; Now blessed is the wombe that bare thee, and the pappes that gaue thee sucke, verse 27. This vnexpected straine, with our Sauiours reply vnto it; Yea rather, blessed are those that heare the word of God and keepe it, verse 28. so briefly inserted into the storie, inforce me to thinke, that it was penned by one that sought only to relate the truth, part of which was this womans speech. But with the meanes of knowing the New Testament to be the word of God, I will not heere meddle: the Old Testament sufficiently proueth it, besides many other experiments to bee prosecuted in the vnfolding of sundry articles.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Harmonie of sacred Writers.
div.p:
AN other Inducement for beleeuing the truth of the Old Testament, is the harmonie of so many seuerall writers, liuing in such distance of Ages, handling such diuersitie of arguments, and couering them with stiles, for the maiestie of some, and the familiaritie of others, more different, than Virgils verses, and the rudest countrymans talke; and yet all of them retaining the selfe same relish. Whiles we reade Tully, Virgil, Liuie, Salust and Ouid, though all liuing neare about one time; yet their writings differ as much as flesh & fish. Many learned men like some one or few of these, and yet much mislike others, reputed as excellent writers in their
kind, liuing about the same time: much more might he that should haue read the common or vulgar Historiographers, Poets, or Orators of that time, haue contemned them as base in respect of the former. But the Prophets of the Old Testament, and the Historiographers of the same, though differing infinitely in degrees of stile and inuention; yet agree as well in the substance or essentiall qualitie of their writings, as the same Pomander chafed and vnchafed. There is the same odour of life, and goodnesse in both, but more fragrant and piercing in the one than in the other. And no man that much likes the one, can mislike the other: hee may like it • esse, but dislike it he cannot, if he like the other: Omnibus est illis vigor & coelestis origo.

2 Many other inducements of this kind are set downe at large, by that Flower of France, and glorie of Christian Nobilitie, in the 24. and 25. chapters of his booke De Veritate Christianae religionis, of the Truth of Christian religion: as also in Ficinus and Viues, whose labours it is hard to say whether he hath more augmented or graced. One especiall motiue is from the drift, and scope of all these sacred writings; whether Histories, Prophets, Psalmes, or the Gospel. The end and scope of all these, is onely to set out the glorie of God, and the good of mankinde. In their most famous victories, and good successe of their best contriued policies, they ascribe the glorie wholly to God. There is no circumstance inserted to erect the praise of man, not of the chiefest managers of such affaires. They account it the greatest praise that can be giuen vnto their Worthies, to let the world know they were beloued of God, and that God did fight for them. Not one Writer in this sacred volume bewraies the least signe of enuy towards others, that liued with him, or had gone before him: Not one that giueth the least suspition of seeking his owne praise by lessening others deserts, as if hee had corrected wherein others had erred, or finished what they had well begunne, but left imperfect. No imitation in any of them to let posterity vnderstand, that it should thinke it selfe beholding to them for their good directions. They seek no thanks, as if they vndertooke their labors voluntarily, only for the good of others; but proclaime a necessitie laide vpon them, for doing that which they doe, and a woe, if they doe it not. They spare not to rehearse the iniquitie, and shame of their progenitors
and nearest kinsfolkes, with Gods fearefull iudgements vpon them for the same, to register their prince and peoples, or their owne disgrace (as the world counteth disgrace) to all posteritie: so Gods name may thereby be more glorified, & his church edified, Ierem. 9. verse 23, 24. Let not the wise man glorie in his wisedome, nor the strong man glorie in his strength: but let him that glorieth, glorie in that he vnderstandeth and knoweth the Lord. Ieremy himselfe reuealeth his owne slackenesse, in vndertaking his appointed charge, Iere. 20. verse 7, 8, 14, 15, 16, 17, 19: hee no where bewrayes any desire of praise, as if he had excelled all his equalls in wit: all that is good in him, or his people, hee giueth to God. Daniel, who did excell in the interpretations of dreames and prophecies, and had the estate of many kingdomes for many yeares to come reuealed vnto him; so as if he would haue chalenged the reuelation of his Countries returne from captiuitie, he could not haue bin disproued, yet ingeniously sheweth that he learned this out of the Prophecie of Ieremie, Dan. 9 verse 2. Although his measure of knowledge was exceeding great, yet he affects not the reputation of Knowing aboue that measure, which God had giuen him, Rom. 12.3.

3 This one qualitie (in them all) of not seeking their owne, nor their countries praise, but onely the praises of their God, and the profit of his church (if we consider it well) may sufficiently testifie, that they speake not vpon priuate motions, who were thus cleere from all suspition of priuat respects. Nor can we suspect, that they should thus conspire together vnto one end, from the will and purpose of man. For what man could limit others thoughts, or rule their wits which liued after him? Least of all can Chaunce be imagined the author of so many seuerall Writers constancie, in conspiring thus to one end in seuerall Ages. Let vs coniecture what causes we can, Saint Peter must resolue the doubt, 2. Peter 1.20, 21. All of them spake as they were moued by the holy Spirit, which was present one and the same to all? If they had not spoken as they were moued by the Spirit, but as if they had moued themselues, to finde out matter, or stretched their wits to inlarge inuention: then would the later sort especially haue catched at many by-narrations, and inserted many 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , little pertinent to that foundation which others had laied before them. But now wee see the
continuall drift of their writings so seriously set vpon one and the selfe same end, as if they had all wrought by an others direction, who had cast the platforme of the edifice himselfe, not minded to finish his worke in any of the first worke-mens age: and yet will haue the later to beginne where the other left, without any alteration or trickes of their owne inuention.

4 All these properties of these sacred Writers, doe sufficiently witnesse their motiues to haue been Diuine, but more abundantly whilest we consider the vanitie of the Iewish people, if we take them as they are by nature, not sanctified by the Spirite of God. For naturally they are giuen to magnifie their owne nation, more than any other people liuing, yea to make God beholding vnto them for their sanctitie: few of them would seek the praise of their God, but with reference to their owne. Hence our apostle S. Paul brings it as an argumēt of the truth of his gospel, 2. Cor. 4.5. in that he did not preach himselfe but Christ Iesus the Lord, and himselfe their seruants for his sake, so doth our Sauiour, Iohn 7. verse 18. He that speaketh of himselfe seeketh his owne glory, but he that seeketh his glory that sent him, the same is true, and no vnrighteousnesse is in him. This sinceritie in teaching, (especially in a man of Iewish progenie) when it is tried to continue without all affectation or dissimulation, is the true 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or touchstone, the liuerie or cognisance of a man speaking by the Spirit of God. The like liue characters of sinceritie are not to be found in any else, saue only in these sacred Writers, or such as haue sincerely obeyed their doctrine. And in many of those Books which our Church accounts Apocryphall, there euidently appeares a spice of secular vanitie; howsoeuer the pen-men of them were truely religious sanctified men, and haue sought to imitate the writings of the Prophets, and other Writers of this sacred volume; But much more eminent is the like vanitie in Iosephus, a man otherwise as excellent for meere naturall parts, or artificiall learning, as his Countrey yeelded anie, not inferior to any Historiographers whatsoeuer.

5 Seeing in this whole bodie of Scriptures there appeares one and the same Spirit, albeit the members be of diuerse fashion and qualitie: this sacred volume it selfe may serue as a liuely type or image of that Vnitie of the Spirite in the bond of peace, which ought to be in the Church and mysticall bodie of Christ, Ephesians 4. v. 3.
They all indeuour to keepe the vnitie of the Spirite in the bond of peace: None of them presumed to vnderstand aboue that which was meete for them to vnderstand: all according to sobrietie, as God dealt to euery one of them the measure of faith. They are as many members of one body, which haue not one office, verse 4. And wee may see that verified in the Canon of the Old Testament, which Saint Paul attributes vnto the Church in Christ;1. Corint. 12.4. There are diuersities of giftes, but the same Spirite. Verse 14. And againe, To one was giuen the spirit of wisedome, as vnto Solomon; to another knowledge, as vnto Ezra, Nehemiah; to another faith, as vnto Moses, Abraham; to another prophecie, Verse 11. as vnto Esay, Ieremy: All these giftes were wrought by one and the same Spirite, which distributeth to euery one as hee would. The best meanes to discerne this harmony in their seuerall writings, would be, to retaine the vnitie of the Spirite by which they wrote. But alas wee haue made a diuision in the bodie of Christ, whilest one of vs detracts, enuies or slaunders another; or whiles we wrangle vnmanerly about idle questions, or termes of art or iarres, (ours that haue the name of Christs messengers) make all the world besides, and our selues oft-times (wee may feare) doubt of the true and reall vnitie betwixt Christ and his members, now eclipsed by our carnall diuisions. But howsoeuer, these here mentioned are in their kinde good motiues vnto sober minds; and the more diligent and attentiue men are to obserue these and the like, the more fully shall they be perswaded, that these writings are the dictates of the holy Ghost.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the affections or dispositions of the sacred Writers.
div.p:
WIth the experiment of this kinde wee may rancke the vehemencie of affection, which appeares in many of these sacred writers, most frequent in the booke of Psalmes: And to distinguish fained or counterfait from true experimentall affections is the most easie, and most certaine kind of Criticisme. He that neuer had any himselfe may safely sweare, that most Poets ancient or moderne,
haue had experience of wanton loues. For who can think that Catullus, Ouid, and Martial had neuer beene acquainted with any but painted women, or written of loue matters onely as blinde men may talke of colours? Or, who can suspect, that either Ouid had penned his bookes de Tristibus, or Boetius his Philosophicall Consolation, onely to moue delight, (as children oft-times weepe for wantonnesse:) or fained these subiects to delude the world, by procuring reall compassion to their counterfait mourning? But much more sensible may wee feele the pulses of our Psalmists passions beating their ditties, if wee would lay our hearts vnto them. Albeit wee seeke not to prooue their Diuine authoritie from the strength of passion simply, but from the obiects, causes, or issue of their passions. And the argument holds thus; As the Ethnicke Poets passions, expressed in their writings, bewray their experience in such matters as they wrote of; as of their carnall delight in loue inioyed, or of earthly sorrow for their exiles, death of friends, or other like worldly crosses: So doe these sacred Ditties witnesse their pen-mens experience in such matters as they professe; as of spirituall ioy, comfort, sorrow, feare, confidence, or any other affection whatsoeuer. If we compare Ouids elegie to Augustus with that Psalme of Dauid, Trist. lib. 2. (in number the 51.) why should wee thinke that the one was more conscious of misdemeanour towards that Monarch, or more sensibly certaine of his displeasure procured by it; than the other of foule offences towards God, and his heauie hand vpon him for them? Dauids penitent bewayling of his soules losse, in being separated from her wonted ioyes, his humble intreatie and importunate suite for rest • uration to his former estate, argue hee had beene of more entire familiar acquaintance with his heauenly, than Ouid with his earthly Lord; that hee had receiued more sensible pledges of his loue, more deepely touched with the present losse of his fauour, and better experienced in the course and meanes of reconcilement to it againe. Haue mercie vpon me, O God, Psalme 51. • . according to thy louing kindnesse: according to the multitude of thy compassions put away mine iniquities. Wash me throughly from mine iniquitie, and cleanse me from my sinne. For I know mine iniquities, Verse 2. and my sinne is euer before me. Against thee, against thee only haue I sinned, and done euill in thy sight. What was it then which caused his present griefe?Verse 3. bodily paine? exile, losse of goods, want, or restraint of sensuall
pleasures? Yea, what was there that worldly minded men either desire or know, which was not at his command? And yet, he, well for health of bodie, onely oppressed with griefe of mind, most desirous to sequester himselfe from all solace, which his Court or Kingdome could afford, in hope to finde his company alone who was inuisible, and to renew acquaintance with his Spirite. Create a cleane heart (O God) and renew a right spirite within me. Cast mee not away from thy presence, and take not thy holy Spirite from me. He accounts himselfe but as an exile, though liuing in his natiue soile, but as a slaue, though absolute Monarch ouer a mightie people; whilest hee stoode separate from the loue of his God, and liued not in subiection to his spirite. If one in hunger should loathe ordinarie or course fare, wee would coniecture hee had beene accustomed to more fine and daintie meates. Heereby then it may appeare, that Dauid had tasted of more choice delights, and purer ioyes, than the carnall minded knew, in that hee loathes all earthly comfort in this his anguish, (wherein he stood in greatest neede of some comfort,) desiring only this of God; Restore me to the ioy of thy saluation, and establish me with thy free Spirit. So farre was hee from distrusting the truth of that ineffable ioy, which now hee felt not (at the least) in such measure as hee had done before, that hee hopes by the manifest effects of it once restored, to disswade the Atheist from his Atheisme, and cause lasciuious or bloud-thirstie mindes to wash off the filth, wherein they wallow, with their teares. For so hee addeth; Then shall I teach thy wayes vnto the wicked, and sinners shall be conuerted vnto thee. Deliuer me from bloud, O GOD, which art the GOD of my saluation, and my tongue shall sing ioyfully of thy righteousnesse. Open thou my lippes, O Lord, and my mouth shall shew foorth thy praise; which as yet hee could not shew foorth to others, because aboundance of ioy did not lodge in his heart; for God had sealed vp sorrow therein, vntill the sacrifice of his broken and contrite heart were accomplished. From the like aboundant experience of this heauenly ioy, the Psalmist in the threescore and sixt Psalme and sixteenth verse, bursteth out into like confident speeches; inuiting vs, as Christ did his Apostle Thomas, to come neere and lay our hands vpon his healed sore, and by the scarres to gather the skill and goodnesse of him that had thus cured him beyond all expectation:
Come and hearken all yee that feare God, Psalme 66.16. and I will tell you what hee hath done to my soule; I called vnto him with my mouth, Verse 17. and hee was exalted with my tongue. Verse 20. Praised bee GOD which hath not put backe my prayer, nor his mercy from mee. The fulnesse of his inward ioyes was such, and Gods prouidence ouer him so manifest and wonderfull, that the present age wherein hee liued could not (to his seeming) but take notice of it, whilest the particulars, wherein the Lord had heard him, were in fresh memorie: and all posteritie, he presumes out of the aboundance of his owne beliefe, should still beleeue the goodnesse of God, from this experimentall relation of his goodnesse towardes him. Hee that hath least experience of the like in himselfe, would hee but attentiuely marke the feruencie of those mens zeale, and vehemencie of their godly passions, expressed in these heere mentioned, and many like vnaffected straines, could not but acknowledge that famous inscription, which a later degenerate lasciuious Poet, (out of such a vaine glorious humour, as moues some basely descended to vsurpe the armes of Noble men whose names they beare,) sought to bestow on all, euen vpon such as himselfe was, Vates in name, but not in qualitie, to belong of right onely to these Psalmists or auncient sacred Poets.

l.hi: Est Deus in vobis, agitante calescitis illo:
Impetus hic sacrae semina mentis habet.

lg.l: Since in your breasts Gods Spirit hath his seate,
T'is Diuine motion breeds this heauenly heate.

div.p:
For who can imagin, that the Author of the three score and fourteenth Psalme and the ninth verse should complaine, without some touch of that Spirite, which hee knew had beene more plentifull in such as had gone before him; Wee see not our signes, there is not one Prophet more, not any that knoweth how long. Verse 10. O GOD, how long shall the aduersary reproach? shall the enemie blaspheme thy name for euer? Verse 11. Why withdrawest thou thine hand, euen thy right hand? Drawe it out of thy bosome and consume them. Verse 12. Euen God is my King of olde, working saluation in the middes of the earth. These sober and constant motions, as it were of Systoles and Diastoles betweene Despaire and Hope, exprest
in this and the foure and fortieth Psalme, argue that those woonders and noble workes, which they had heard with their eares, and their fathers had told them, were no fables, but matters truely and really acted, which had left deepe impression in their forefathers hearts, who had so thorowly felt and tasted the extraordinarie goodnesse of their God, that the longing desire of like fauour is transfused as hereditarie to posteritie, as the desire of such meates as parents best affect, and vse most to feede vpon, vsually remaines in their children.

2 Or, to vse the Author of the two and fortie Psalme his owne comparison; Braying doeth not more sensibly notifie the Hartes panting after the water brookes, than that Psalme doth his thirsting after the Spirite of Life; which sometime had beene diffused through his faculties, and had fructified in ioy and comfort, but now in these stormes of affliction lieth hid in his heart, onelie supporting it with hopes of like fruit against a better season; as the sap whereby trees flourish in Summer, retiring to the roote in Winter, preserueth them sound within, so that although frosts may nippe, and stormes outwardly deface them, yet they breake forth againe, and beare fruit in the Spring. And although I neuer mistrusted the truth of that dissension, betwixt the willingnesse of the Spirite, and weakenesse of the flesh, oft mentioned in Scripture; yet, I know not how, it addeth more life to my beliefe, whilest I see this conflict acted by the Author of the two and fortie and the three and fortie Psalme. The flesh complaines, as if his heart were readie to close with deiected feare; My soule is cast downe within mee, all thy waues and flouds are gone ouer mee: the Spirite like a good Physitian, by reiterating that speech of comfort, Why arte thou cast downe, O my soule, and why art thou so disquieted within mee, raiseth it vp againe, and dilateth his heart with hope in God against all hope in worldly sight. For so hee concludeth both these Psalmes, Wait on God: for I will yet giue him thankes: hee is my present helpe and my God. Generally, though the Psalmists complaints bee oft-times grieuous, yet they neuer end them but with hearty praier; though God oft-times lay great plagues vpon them; yet is their confidence alwayes as great that hee will heale them. The beginning of their mournefull Ditties,
alwayes represent the stormes of griefe and sorrow, that had gone ouer their soules: their end and cloze is like the appearing of the Morning Starre, fore-shewing the remoueall of the shadow of death, wherein they sate. Their sodaine transitions from griefe to ioy, is euen as the breaking out of the Sunne from vnder a thicke tempestuous cloude: So that the outward Character of theyr Songs, is a liuely representation of that trueth, which one of them out of his inmost experience hath left registred to the world; His wrath endureth but the twinckeling of an eie, and in his pleasure is life: heauinesse may endure for a night, but ioy commeth in the morning.

3 This Patience in Aduersitie, and confident expectation of deliuerance from aboue, compared with the Heathens impatience, alwayes readie to accuse their Gods in their vnexpected calamities, and seeking to vent their griefe in Poeticall Inuectiues against them: infallibly testifie, that the one did onelie know the Diuine Powers by heare say, the others by experience; and that GOD was neare to this people in all which they called vppon him, and beheld the affaires of the Heathen onelie a farre off.

4 Yet beside these particular liuely Characters of experimentall ioy or griefe, feare or confidence: their consonancie with the historicall trueth of alterations in the state of Iewrie, will much illustrate the former obseruations. For albeit the Psalmists in their greatest distresse or calamities, murmure not against the Lord God, as the heathens doe: yet the tenour of some late mentioned, with diuerse other Psalmes, argue that the people of God in those times wherein they were written, either had not such manifest signes of Gods fauour; or else found not such speedie deliuerance from the daungers feared, or calamities suffered by them, as the Prophet Dauid in the seauen and twentie Psalme and the first verse, and other of their godlie Auncestours had done. The Lord (saieth Dauid) is my light and my saluation, whome shall I feare? The Lord is the strength of my life, of whome shall I bee affraide? Though an hoast pitched against mee, mine heart should not be afraide: though warre bee raysed against me, yet I will trust in thi • ; to wit, vppon his former experience of
Gods mercies specified in the second verse; When the wicked mine enemies came, and my foes came vpon me to eate vp my flesh, they stumbled and fell. But greater was his confidence from the more often experience of Gods fauour, when as his case otherwise, for the multitude and malignitie of his enemies, was more desperate, Psal. 3. vers. 1. Many were his aduersaries that rose vp against him; and many that said vnto his soule (when hee fled from his sonne Absolon) Verse 2. There is no helpe for him in his God. Yet hee, as an expert souldier, can not be terrified with stales or bragges, but betaketh himselfe vnto his weapons; Verse 3. Thou Lord art a buckler for mee, my glorie, and the lifter up of my head. So little is he dismaied, that after his prayers hee taketh his quiet rest; Verse 4. I did call vpon the Lord with my voyce, and hee heard mee out of his holy mountaine. I laide mee downe and slept, and rose againe, for the Lord sustained me. Verse 5. I will not bee afraide for tenne thousand of the people, that should beset me round about. The same confidence, raised from the experience of Gods assistance, was in the Author of the sixe and fortie Psalme; God is our helpe and strength, a very present helpe in trouble: Therefore will wee not feare though the earth be moued, and though the mountaines fall into the middest of the Sea. The manner of Dauids carriage, his confident presaging of good successe in times more apt to breede despaire in others lesse experienced in assistance from aboue, exprest in sundry Psalmes, composed when hee fled from Saul, yeeld aboundance of obseruations pregnant for this purpose.

5 Other-whiles this Kingly Prophet expostulates the wrongs offered by his enemies so confidently, and relateth his owne integritie in such patheticall and serious manner, that vnlesse the Inscription of his Petitions, or other historicall circumstance, did giue vs notice, to whome hee tendered his complaints, wee would thinke that they had beene so many reports, of what hee had openly pleaded at some Barre, or Court of ciuile Iustice, in the personall presence, sight, or audience of some visible Iudge, ready to giue sentence for him vpon the first hearing of his cause. If any ciuile Heathen, that neuer had heard of any inuisible God, should haue taken vp some of his Psalmes (the ninth for example) in the streetes, hee would haue imagined that the Author
of them had either heard some supreame Magistrate in his time, deepely protesting his resolution for righting the poore, or else had beene most intimately acquainted with the integritie of his proceedings in matters of Iustice, that hee durst so confidently auouch vnto the world on his behalfe; Psalme 9. verse 8. He shall iudge the world in righteousnesse, and the people with equitie. Verse 9. The Lord also will bee a refuge for the poore, a refuge in due time, euen in affliction. Verse 10. And they that know thy Name, will trust in thee: for thou Lord hast not fayled them that seeke thee. So liuely was Dauids, and other ancient Psalmists experience of the Inuisible Gods assistance alwayes readie, aswell in warre as in peace, as well in executing iudgement vpon their treacherous, deceitfull, or secret enemies, as in giuing them victorie ouer their profest and potent foes.

6 But posteritie had not often times so full experience of the same assistance, as appeareth from the manner of their complaints. The reason of this Diuersitie, in the auncient and latter Psalmists apprehension of GODS fauour; eyther in deliuering them from daunger, or righting them from wrong; was from the Diuersitie of Times, the later not yeelding so manifest and frequent Documents of GODS mercie or iustice, as the former had done. As Gods plagues vppon the auncient Israelites were oft times sodaine, and (for the time) violent: so their deliuerance from them was speedie, because their stubbornenesse was lesse, and the sinnes, for which they were to repent, of lesse continuance. But the continuall increase of this peoples wickednesse, in their successions, and Posterities slackenesse, in sorrowing either for theyr owne or Predecessours sinnes, made Gods plagues inflicted vppon them more durable, as appeareth by the long captiuities and oppressions of this people in later Ages, if wee compare them with the often, but short afflictions, which in former times had befallen them. This long duraunce of great calamities, made Posteritie lesse apprehensiue of Gods promises than theyr Forefathers had beene; at the least whiles these continued, they were lesse acquainted with Gods fauour than their Predecessours were. And from the want of like sensible experience of his present helpe in the time of trouble, of later
generations are more querulous and lesse confident in their prayers vttered in their distresse, as wee may see in the foure score and eighteenth and other Psalmes, conceiued by the godlie amongest this people in the calamities of later Times. Thus wee may see how truely the diuersitie of Gods dealing with his people in different Ages, is represented in the Character, Stile, or Affection of these sacred Writers, all much different in former and later Ages: much more may wee presume, that the generall and true Diuersitie of Times, and GODS diuers manner of proceeding with mankinde in their seuerall Generations, is most truely related and exemplified in the Historicall relations of the same sacred Volumes; of which in the Section following.

7 Thus much of Experiments, or Obseruations drawne from the Character, or tenor of these sacred Writings themselues, or their Writers affections represented in them. These I haue gathered, not that I can hope to perswade any man so much by reading them, as by occasioning him to obserue the like, whiles hee readeth these sacred Volumes. For euerie man that readeth them with attentiue Obseruation, may apprehend much more for the framing of true beliefe in his owne heart, than hee can expresse to others: yea, to seeke to make full resemblance of our inward beliefe, or such Experiments as confirme it, by outward discourse, were all one, as if a man out of the slight impression or transitorie representation of his owne face which hee had lately beheld in a Glasse, should seeke to describe it as fully and perfectly to an other mans apprehension, as if he had looked vpon it with him in the same Glasse.

8 As the representation of our bodily shape, is liuely and perfect whilest wee beholde it in a true and perfect Glasse; but the memoriall or phantasie of it when wee are gone thence, imperfect and dull: So is the apprehension of our owne, or Experiments of others beliefe, sensible and fresh, whilest we set our harts and mindes vnto this perfect Lawe of Libertie, the onely true Glasse of our Soules; but more hard to retaine in memorie, or to bee fully represented to an other by Discourse, than our bodily shape is by a bare description. And as in the Arte of Painting, generall rules may bee giuen for the right drawing of Pictures, yet
he that will take any particular mans, must looke vppon the liue face it selfe, or vse the benefite of his Glasse: So in this case, there may bee good directions giuen, how men should drawe Experiments, or take Obseruations of this kinde, which being taken, can not bee fully imprinted in an other, by him that tooke them: but euerie man must haue continuall recourse vnto this Spirituall Glasse, which farre surpasseth all bodily Glasses in this; that in it wee may see, not onely the true shape and proportion of our Soules as they are, or of what fashion they should be; but it hath also an operatiue force of assimilating them vnto the patternes of godly and religious mens Soules represented herein, yea euen of transfourming them into the similitude of that Image wherein they were first created. The Idaea of Sanctitie and Righteousnesse contained in this Spirituall Glasse, are the causes of our edification in good life and vertue: as the Idaea or platforme in the Artificers head, is the cause of the materiall house that is builded by it.

div.head: SECT. 2.
Of Experiments and Obseruations answerable to the rules of Scriptures.
CHAP. I. Containing the topicke, whence such Obseruations must be drawne.
div.p:
1 IF the Bookes of some auncient rare Author, who had written in sundry Arts, should be found in this Age; all bearing the Authors name and other commendable Titles prefixed: a reasona- man would soone be perswaded, that they were his whose name they bore; but sooner, if hee had any positiue arguments to perswade himselfe of their Antiquitie, or if they were
commended to him by the authority or report of men in this case credible. But, besides all these, if euery man according to his experience or skill in those arts and faculties which this ancient writer handles, should vpon due examination of his conclusions or discourse finde resolution in such points as he had alwayes wauered in before; or be instructed in matters of his profession or obseruation, whereof he was formerly ignorant: this would much strengthen his assent vnto the former reports or traditions concerning their Author, or vnto the due praises and titles prefixed to his workes; albeit he that made this triall, could not proue the same truth so fully to another, nor cause him to beleeue it so firmly as he himselfe doth, vnlesse he could induce him to examine his writings by like experiments, in some facultie wherein the examiner had some, though lesse, skill. And yet, after the like triall made, he, that had formerly doubted, would beleeue these workes to be the supposed Authors, and subscribe vnto the titles and commendations prefixed; not so much for the formers report or authoritie, as from his owne experience. Now we haue more certaine experiments to proue that the Scriptures are the word of God, than we can haue to proue any mens workes to be their supposed Authors: for one Author in any Age may be as good as an other; he perhaps better, of whome we haue heard lesse. We could in the former case onely certainely beleeue that the Author, whosoeuer, was an excellent Scholler; but wee could not bee so certaine that it was none other but hee whose name it did beare: for there may be many Aristotles, and many Platoes, many excellent men in euery profession, yet but one God that is all in all; whose workes we suppose the Scriptures are, which vpon strict examination will euince him alone to haue beene their Author.

2 The meanes then of establishing our assent vnto any part of Scripture, must be from experiments and obseruations agreeable to the rules in Scripture. For when we see the reason and maner of sundry euents, either related by others, or experienced in our selues, which otherwise we could neuer haue reached vnto by any naturall skill; or, generally, when we see any effects or concurrence of things which cannot be ascribed to any but a supernaturall cause, and yet they fully agreeing to the Oracles of Scriptures
or Articles of Beleefe: This is a sure pledge vnto vs, that he who is the Author of Truth, and giues being vnto all things, was the author of Scriptures.

3 Such euents and experiments are diuerse, and according to their diuersities may worke more or lesse on diuerse dispositions: some may finde more of one sort, some of another, none all; some againe may be more induced to beleeue the truth of Scriptures from one sort of experiments, some from others. Those obseruations are alwaies best for euery man, which are most incident to his vocation. With some varietie of these obseruations or experiments we are in the next place to acquaint diuerse Readers.

div.head: CHAP. II. That Heathenish fables ought not to preiudice diuine Truth.
div.p:
1 NOthing more vsuall to men, wise ynough in their generation, than for the varietie or multitude of false reports concerning any subiect, to discredit all that are extant of the same. And all inclination vnto diffidence or distrust is not alwayes to be misliked; but onely when it swayes too farre, or extends it selfe beyond the limits of it proper circumference, that is, matters of bargaine or secular commerce. As this diffident temper is most common in the cunning managers of such affaires: so the first degree or propension to it were not much amisse in them, did they not transcendere à genere ad genus; that is, were not their mistrust commonly too generally rigid and stiffe. For most men of great dealings in the world, finding many slipperie companions, hold it no sinne to be at the least suspitious of all: others, being often cosened by such as haue had the name and reputation of honest men, begin to doubt whether there be any such thing indeed, as that which men call honestie; and from this doubting about the reall nature of honestie in the abstract, they resolue vndoubtedly, That if any man in these dayes doe not deale ill with others, it is onely for want of fit oportunitie to doe himselfe any great good. But as facilitie in yeelding assent, vnlesse it be moderated by discretion,
is an infallible consequent of too great simplicitie, and layes a man open to abuse and wrong in matters of this life: so generall mistrust is the certaine fore-runner of infidelitie, and makes a man apt ynough to cousin himselfe, without a tempter, in matters of the life to come; though otherwise this is the very disposition which the great Tempter workes most vpon: who for this reason, when any notable truth of greater moment falls out, labours by all meanes to fill the world with reports of like euents, but such as vpon examination he foresees will proue false: for hee knowes well, that the beleefe of most pregnant truthes may by this meanes be much impaired, as honest men are vsually mistrusted when the world is full of knaues. And, to speake the truth, it is but a very short cut betwixt generall and rigid mistrust in worldly dealings, and infidelitie in spirituall matters; which indeed is but a kind of diffidence or mistrust: and he that from the experience of often cousenage comes once to this point, That he will trust none in worldly affaires but vpon strong securitie or legall assurance, may easily be transported by the varietie or multitude of reports, in spirituall matters, notoriously false, to beleeue nothing but vpon the sure pledge and euidence of his owne sense or naturall reason. This is one maine fountaine of Atheisme; of which (God willing) in the Article of the Godhead. In this place I onely desire to giue the Reader notice of Sathans policie, and to aduertise him withall, that as there is a kind of ingenuous simplicitie, which if it maketh with sobrietie and serious meditation, doth prepare our hearts to Christian beleefe: so there is a kind of suspition by which we may out-reach the old Serpent in his subtiltie, and preuent his former method of deceit. So, whilest wee read or heare varietie of reports concerning any notable euent, or many Writers beating about one matter, euery one of which may seeme vnprobable in particular circumstances, or else their diuersitie such as makes them incompatible; we should be iealous, that there were some notable truth, whose beleefe did concerne vs, which Sathan hath sought to disparage by the mixture, either of grosse improbable fruitlesse fables, or else of dissonant probabilities.

2 Truth is the life and nutriment of the world, and the Scriptures as the Veines or Vessels wherein it is contained; which
straight corrupts and putrifies, vnlesse it be preserued in them, as in it proper receptacles, as both the fabulous conceits of the Heathen and foolish practises of the Romish Church in many points may witnesse. But as from Asphaltites, or the dead sea, we may finde out the pleasant streames and fresh springs of Iordan: so from the degenerate and corrupted rellish of decayed truth, which is frequent in the puddle and standing lakes of Heathen Writers, we may be led into the pure fountaine of truth contained in these sacred volumes of Scripture.

3 The experiments, which now wee seeke or would occasion others (chiefely young students) to obserue, are such as the Heathen did guesse at, or men out of the workes of nature, by reading of Poets, or auncient Writers, may yet doubt of; whereas the true resolution of them onely depends vpon the truth set downe in Scripture.

div.head: CHAP. III. Obseruations out of Poets in generall, and of Dreames in particular.
div.p:
1 THe most exquisite Poemes are but a kind of pleasant waking dreame, and the art of Poetrie a liuely imitation of some delightfull visions. And as nothing comes into a mans fancie by night in dreames, but the parts or matters of it haue bin formerly in his outward senses (for euen when we dreame of golden Mountaines or Chymeraes, the seuerall ingredients haue a reall and sensible truth in them; onely the frame or proportion is such, as hath no sensible example in the workes of nature:) so in auncient Poemes, which were not made in imitation of former, as pictures drawne from pictures, but immediately deuised (as wee now suppose) from the sensible experiments of those times (as pictures drawne from a liuing face) many parts and limmes haue a reall and sensible truth, onely the composition or frame is artificiall and fained, such as cannot perhaps be paralelled in euery circumstance, with any reall euents in the course of times. And albeit
the euents (which the most auncient Poets relate) through long distance of time, seeme most strange to vs, yet is the ground of their deuises (especially) such, as vpon better search may alwaies be referred to some Historicall truth, which yeelded stuffe to Poeticall structure, as dayes spectacles doe vnto nights visions. This Aristotle had obserued out of the practise of the best auncient Poets, and prescribes it as a rule to Poets, to haue alwayes an Historicall truth for their ground. Nor durst the Poets haue been so audacious in their fictions at the first, seeing their profession was but either to imitate nature, or adorne a knowne truth; not to disparage any truth by prodigious or monstrous fictions, without any ground of like experience. For this is a fundamentall law of their Art;
Hieronym. Vida, • b. 2. Poet. Curandum, vt quando non semper vera profamur,
Fingentes: saltem sint illa simillima veri.
Though all's not true that faining Poets sing,
Yet nought on Stage but in truths likenesse bring.

None, I thinke, will be so foolish as to take Homer in the literall sence, when he tels vs how Iris by day, and Sleepe by night, runne errands for the greater Gods, and come with these and the like messages vnto Kings chambers:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,
Who will by counsell guide a State,
Must early rise, and lye downe late.

Yet with such artificiall and painted plumes oftentimes are couered true and naturall bodies, though the messengers be poeticall and fained; yet these kinds of night-messages had an Historicall truth: for not the Poets onely, but many great Philosophers of the old world, haue taken nocturnall presages for no dreames or fancies. Hence did Homer vsurpe his libertie, in faining his Kings and Heroickes, so often admonished of their future estate by the gods: he presumed at least, that these fictions might carrie a shew of truth in that age, wherein such admonitions by night were not vnusuall. And his conceit is not dissonant vnto the sacred
storie, which beares record of like effects in auncient times, and giues the true cause of their expiration in later.

2 So vsuall were dreames amongst the Patriarchs, and their interpretations so well knowne, that Iacob could at the first hearing interprete his young sonne Iosephs dreame, Gen. 37. vers. 10,Gen. 37.10. 11. What is this dreame that thou hast dreamed? Shall I, and thy mother and thy brethren come indeed, and fall on the ground before thee? Nor did he take it only for a fable, no more than his brethren had done his former for a fancie; for, as the Text sayth,Vers. 11. his brethren enuied him, but his father noted the saying. And Ioseph himselfe comming to riper yeares, was as expert in interpreting Pharaohs and his seruants dreames, Gen. 40. vers. 12, 13. Then Ioseph said vnto him, this is the interpretation of it: The three branches are three dayes; within three dayes shall Pharaoh lift vp thine head, and restore thee vnto thine office, and thou shalt giue Pharaohs cup into his hand, after the old manner when thou wast his Butler. And vers. 19. Within three dayes shall Pharaoh take thine head from thee, and shall hang thee on a tree, and the birds shall eat thy flesh from off thee. These considerations will not suffer me mistrust diuerse auncient Historiographers, making report, how Princes and Fathers of Families haue had fore-warnings of future euents, either concerning themselues, their Kingdome, or Posteritie. Nor were all dreames among the Heathens illusions of wicked spirits:Iob. 33. for Elihu spake out of the common experience of those auncient times wherein hee liued; God speaketh once or twice (that is,Vers. 14. Vers. 15. vsually) and one seeth it not. In dreames and visions of the night, when sleepe falleth vpon men and they sleepe vpon their beds, then he openeth the eares of men, Vers. 16. Vers. 17. euen by their corrections, which he had sealed, that he might cause man to turne away from his enterprise, and that he might hide the pride of man, and keepe backe his soule from the pit, and that his life should not passe by the sword. A liuely experiment of Elihu his obseruation wee haue Gen. 20.3. When Abimelech King of Gerar had taken Sarah, Abrahams wife, God came to him in a dreame by night, and said to him, Behold, thou art but dead, because of the woman which thou hast taken; for she is a mans wife. And againe, vers. 6, 7. God said vnto him by a dreame, I know that thou didst this euen with an vpright minde, and I kept thee also that thou shouldest not sinne against me, therefore suffered I not thee to touch her: Now then deliuer the man his wife
againe; for he is a Prophet, and he shall pray for thee, that thou mayest liue: but if thou deliuer her not againe, be sure that thou shalt die the death, thou, and all that thou hast. And Moses witnesseth the ordinarie prophecie of auncient times to haue consisted of dreames and visions, Numb. 12.6, 7. If there be a Prophet of the Lord amongst you, I will be knowne vnto him by a vision, and will speake vnto him by a dreame. My seruant Moses is not so (that is, he is no ordinarie Prophet) vnto him will I speake mouth to mouth, and by vision, and not in darke words, but he shall see the similitude of the Lord.

3 These allegations sufficiently proue, that night-dreames and visions were frequent, and their obseruation (if taken in sobrietie) to good vse, in auncient times, euen amongst the nations, vntill they forgot,Gen. 40.8. as Ioseph said, That interpretations were from God, and sought to find out an art of interpreting them: Then night-visions did either cease, or were so mixt with delusions, that they could not be discerned; or, if their euents were in some sort foreseene, yet men being ignorant of Gods prouidence, commonly made choise of such meanes for their auoidance, as proued the necessarie occasions or prouocations of the euents they feared.

4 Much better was the temper of the Nations before Homers time: They, amongst other kindes of Prophecyings and Southsayings, held dreames and their interpretations (as all other good gifts) to be from God; as no euill was done in the Grecian campe, which the gods, in their opinion, did not cause. So Homer brings in Achilles, aduising Agamemnon to consult their gods interpreters with all speed, for what offence committed against them they had sent the pestilence into their Campe.

lg.l: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
But to what Priest, or Prophet shall we wend,
Or dreamer? for euen dreames from Ioue descend.

div.p:
All those kindes of predictions had beene in vse amongst the Heathens, as they were amongst the Israelites; albeit in later times they grew rare in both: for the encrease of wickednesse throughout the world, the multiplicitie of businesse and solicitude of humane affaires, and mens too much minding of politike meanes,
and other second causes of their owne good, did cause the defect of true dreames and other diuine admonitions for the welfare of mankind.

5 This cause the Scriptures giue vs, 1. Sam. 28.6. After Saul (who had followed the fashions of other Nations, not the prescripts of Gods word) asked counsell of the Lord, and the Lord answered him not, neither by dreames, nor by
i. by Priests. Vrim, nor by the Prophets, his sinnes had made a separation betweene him and the god of Israel: who for this cause will not affoord his presence to his Priests or Prophets, that came as mediators betwixt Saul and him; much lesse would hee vouchsafe his spirit vnto such Priests or Prophets as were carnally minded themselues. This was a rule so well knowne to the people of God, that Strabo from the tradition of it (for Moses his storie he had not read) reckons vp this as a speciall point of Moses his doctrine, concerning the worship of the god of Israel; his words are to this effect: Moses taught,
Strabo, lib. 16. in the description of Iurie. that such as liued chastly and vprightly should be inspired with true visions by night, and such men, it was meete, should consult the Diuine Powers in the Temple by night-visions: but others, who were not so well minded, ought not to intrude themselues into this sacred businesse; or, if they would, they were to expect no true visions, but illusions or idle dreames; from God they were not to expect any. Yet may it not be denied, but that the Heathens were oft times, by Gods permission, truly resolued by Dreames or Oracles (though ministred by diuels) of euents that should come; but seldome were such resolutions for their good: So the Witch which Saul most Heathen-like consulted, when God had cast him off, did procure him a true prediction of his fearefull end. This is a point wherein I could be large; but I will conclude. As the Heathens relations of sundrie euents vsuall in auncient times, confirme the truth of the like, recorded in Scripture; so the Scriptures giue the true causes of their being, ceasing, or alteration: which the corrupt and polypragmaticall disposition of later ages, without reuelation from the cause of causes and disposer of times, could neuer haue dreamed of; as may partly appeare from what hath beene said of Dreames, more fully from that which followes next of Oracles.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. Of Oracles.
div.p:
2 Plutarchs relation of his daemoniacall spirits mourning for great Pans death, about this time, is so strange, that it might perhaps seeme a tale, vnlesse the truth of the common bruite had beene so constantly auouched by eare-witnesses vnto Tiberius,
that it made him call a conuocation of Wisemen, as Herod did at our Sauiours birth, to resolue him who this great Pan, late deceased, should be. Thamus, the Aegyptian Master, vnknowne by that name to his passengers, vntill he answered to it at the third call of an vncouth voice, vttered (sine authore) from the land, requesting him to proclaime the newes of great Pans death, as he passed by Palodes, was resolued to haue let all passe as a fansie or idle message, if the winde and tide should graunt him passage by the place appointed: but, the wind fayling him on a suddaine, at his comming thither, he thought it but a little losse of breath to crie out aloud vnto the shoare, as hee had beene requested, Great Pan is dead. The words, as Plutarch relates, were scarce out of his mouth, before they were answered with a huge noyse, as it had beene of a multitude, sighing and groaning at this wonderment. If these spirits had beene by nature mortall, as this Philosopher thinkes, the death of their chiefe Captaine could not haue seemed so strange: but that a farre greater than the greatest of them, by whose power the first of them had his being, should die to redeeme his enemies from their thraldome, might well feeme a matter of wonderment and sorrow vnto them. The circumstance of the time will not permit me to doubt, but that vnder the knowne name of Pan was intimated the great Shepheard of our soules, that had then layd downe his life for his flocke; not the fained sonne of Mercurie and Penelope,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Plut. vt supra. as the Wisemen foolishly resolued Tiberius: Albeit euen this base and counterfeit resolution of these Heathens coyning, beares a liuely image (for the exact proportion) of the diuine truth, charactred out vnto vs in Scripture. For it shall appeare by sufficient testimonies, in their due time and place to be produced, that sundry generall, confused, or aenigmaticall tradiditions of our Sauiours conception, birth, and Pastorall office, had beene spread abroad amongst the Nations. Hence, in stead of him, they frame a Pan, the God of Shepheards; in stead of the holy Spirit, by whom he was to be conceiued, they haue a Mercurie (their false God, fained Messenger and Interpreter) for Pans father; in stead of the blessed Virgine, who was to beare our Sauiour, they haue a Penelope for their young Gods mother.
The affinitie of qualitie and offices, in all the parties here paralelled, made this transfiguration of diuine Truth easie vnto the Heathen; and the manner of it cannot seeme improbable to vs, if we consider the wonted vanitie of their imaginations, in transforming the glorie of the immortall Godhead into the similitude of earthly thinges, most dislike to it in nature and qualitie. Thus admitting Plutarchs storie to be most true, it no way proues his intended conclusion, that the wilde goatish Pan was mortall: but the Scriptures set foorth vnto vs the true cause, why both he, and all the rest of that hellish crue should at that time howle and mourne, seeing by the great Shepheards death they were become dead in law; no more to breath in Oracles, but quite to be depriued of all such strange motions, as they had seduced the ignorant world with before. All the anticke trickes of Faunus, the Satyres, and such like creatures, were now put downe; God had resolued to make a translation of his Church; and for this cause the Diuels were enforced to dissolue their old Chappels, and seeke a new forme of their Liturgie or Seruice. Whilest the Israelites were commaunded to consult with Gods Priests, Prophets, or other Oracles, before they vndertooke any difficult warre or matters of moment, Sathan had his Priests and Oracles as much frequented by Heathen Princes vpon the like occasions. So Strabo witnesseth,Lib. citato. That the auncient Heathen, in their chiefe consultations of State, did relye more vpon Oracles than humane policie. If Moses were fortie dayes in the Mount, to receiue Lawes from Gods owne mouth, Minos will be Iupiters Auditor,Plato in Min • e. in his denne or caue, for the same purpose. In emulation of Shiloh, or Kireath-jearim, whilest the Arke of God remained there; the Heathens had Dodona; and for Ierusalem they had Delphi, garnished with rich donatiues of forraine Princes as well as Grecians; so magnified also by Grecian Writers, as if it had beene the intended paralell of the holy Citie.
