Insomuch,Plut. ibid. that Plutarch thinkes the storie, commonly receiued of that Oracles originall, to be lesse probable, because it ascribes the inuention of it to chaunce, and not to the diuine prouidence, or fauour of the Gods: when as it had beene such a direction vnto Greece, in vndertaking
warres, in building Cities, and in time of pestilence and famine. Whether these effects in auncient times had beene alwayes from the information of Diuels (as I said before) I will not dispute. That this Oracle had beene often consulted, it is euident; and that oftentimes the Diuels deluded such as consulted them, is as manifest. But since that saying of the Prophet was fulfilled,Ier. 31.33. I will put my Law in their inward parts, and write it in their hearts; since the knowledge of Truth hath beene so plenteously made knowne and reuealed, and the principles of Religion so much dilated and enlarged by discourse, the Diuell hath chosen prowd hearts and busie braines for his Oracles; seeking by their subtiltie of wit, and plausibilitie of discourse, to counterfeit and corrupt the forme of wholesome Doctrine; as he did of old, the truth of Gods visible Oracles, by his apish imitations.

3 This conclusion then is euident, both from the ioynt authoritie of all auncient Writers, as well prophane, as sacred; That God in former times had spoken vnto the world by Dreames, Visions, Oracles, Priests, and Prophets; and that such reuelations had beene, amongst the Israelites, as the Starres or Night-lampes; amongst the Heathen as Meteors, fierie Apparitions, or wandering Comets, for their direction in the time of darkenesse and ignorance. But when both the sensible experience of our times, and the relations of former ages, most vnpartiall in this case, haue sufficiently declared vnto vs, That all the former twinckling lights are vanished; the reason of this alteration, I see, men might seeke by naturall causes, as Plutarch did. But this doubt is cleared, and the question truely resolued by our Apostle in these wordes: Heb. 1.1. At sundrie times, and in diuerse manners, God spake in the old time to our Fathers by the Prophets; in these last dayes he hath spoken vnto vs by his Sonne, whom he hath made heire of all thinges, by whom also he made the world: who, being (as the Apostle there sayth) the brightnesse of his glorie, hath put the former lights, which shined in darkenesse, to flight. The consideration hereof confirmes that truth of our Apostle to all such as are not blinded in heart, where he sayth, That the night was past, and the day was come: For the suddaine
vanishing of all former lights, about this time assigned by Christians of our Sauiours birth, abundantly euince, That this was the Sunne of Righteousnesse which (as the Prophet had foretold) should arise vnto the world.
Malach. 4.2. It was the Light which had lately appeared in the Coasts of Iurie, then approaching Italie, Greece, and other of these Westerne Countries, which did cause these sonnes of darkenesse (the daemoniacall Spirits) to flit Westward, as Darkenesse it selfe doth from the face of the Sunne, when it beginnes to appeare in the East. And Plutarch tells vs,Plut. ibid. That after they had forsaken the Countrey of Greece, they haunted little desart Islands, neere adjoyning to the coasts of this our Britanie; where they raysed such hideous stormes and tempests, as Nauigators report they haue done of late in that Island, called by their owne name. Both reports had their times of truth; and the like may be yet true, in some places, more remote from commerce of Christians. But the Heathen (as Heathenish minded men doe euen to this day) sought the reasons of such alterations from sensible Agents, or second Causes, which haue small affinitie with those effects: or if they had, yet the disposition of such causes depends wholly vpon his will; who, though most immutable in himselfe, changeth times and seasons at his pleasure. And wheresoeuer the light of his Gospell commeth, it verifieth that saying of our Apostle, Ecce vetera transierunt, & noua facta sunt omnia: And new times yeeld new obseruations; which cannot be taken aright, nor their causes knowne, without especiall directions from this rule of Life. By which it plainely appeareth, that the second maine period of the World, since the Floud (whose beginning wee account from the promulgation of the Law, and the distinction of the Israelites from other people, vntill the time of Grace) yeeldes great alteration and matter of much different obseruation from the former. And in the declining, or later part of this second age, wee haue described vnto vs, as it were, an ebbe or staunch in the affaires of the Kingdome of Israel, going before the generall fullnesse of time: After which wee see the tenure of all thinges in Iurie, and of other Kingdomes of the world, quite changed. But the particulars of this change I intend to handle
hereafter: I now would prosecute my former obseruations of the old world.

4 Continually, whilest we compare ancient Poets or stories with the booke of Genesis, and other volumes of sacred Antiquitie: these sacred bookes giue vs the patterne of the waking thoughts of ancient times; and the Heathen Poems, with other fragments of Ethnike writings (whose entire bodies, though not so aged as the former, being but the workes of men, haue perished) containe the dreames and fancies which succeeding ages by heare-say, and broken reports, had conceiued, concerning the same or like matters: So no doubt had God disposed, that the delight which men tooke in the vncertaine glimpse of truth in the one, should enure their mindes the better to obserue the light which shineth in the other; and that the vnstable varietie of the one should prepare mens hearts more stedfastly to imbrace the truth and stabilitie of the other, when it should be reuealed vnto them. And, as any man almost, if hee bee obseruant of his former actions, cogitations, and occurrents, may finde out the occasion how dreames (though in themselues oftentimes prodigious, absurd, and foolish) come into his braine or fancie: so may any iudicious man, from the continuall and serious obseruation of this Register of truth, finde out the originall, at least, of all the principall heads or common places of Poeticall fictions or ancient Traditions, which cannot be imagined they should euer haue come into any mans fancie, vnlesse from the imitation of some Historicall truth, or the impulsion of reall euents stirring vp admiration. For admiration (as shall afterward appeare) did breede, and imitation spoile, the diuine art of Poetrie.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the apparitions of the Heathen Gods and their Heroicks.
div.p: 1 WEre all the workes of auncient Poets vtterly lost, and no tradition or print of their inuentions left, so as the art of Poetrie were to begin anew, and the Theater to bee raysed from the ground; the most curious wits in this or neere adioyning Countries might for many generations to come beat their braines, and sift their fancies, vntill they had runne ouer all the formes and compositions which the whole Alphabet of their fantasmes could affoord, before they could euer dreame of bringing the gods in visible shape vpon the Stage, or interlacing their Poemes with their often apparitions. And vnlesse ensuing times should yeeld matter of much different obseruations from that which these present doe, this inuention would be accounted dull, and finde but sorrie and vnwelcome entertainement of the auditors or spectators. That the like inuention finds some acceptation now, it is, because mens mindes haue beene possessed with this conceit from the tradition of their forefathers. For many inuentions, which in succession cease to be of like vse and consequence as they were in former times, become yet matters of delight and sport vnto posteritie: as Shooting continues still an Exercise of good recreation to vs of this Land, because it hath beene a practise of admirable vse and consequence vnto our worthie auncestors. But whence came this conceit of the gods appearing in sensible shapes, into Homers and other auncient Poets heads? How became it a common place of Poeticall inuention, whilest Poetrie it selfe was but beginning? Surely, as God had spoken in diuerse manners vnto the old world, so had he appeared in diuerse formes (perhaps) not onely to the Israelites, but vnto other nations also before the distinction of this people from them: howsoeuer, as the diuels had counterfeited Gods manner of speaking to his people, so did they the manner of his, or his Angels apparitions.

2. Such apparitions of God or his Angels, the sacred Storie
tels vs, were frequent, not onely in Abrahams, Isaacks, Iacobs, and the Patriarches times, but in the ages immediatly going before the times that Homer wrote of: so that the traditions of these vndoubted experiments (if Greece or Asia had not the like in Homers time) might then bee fresh and vnquestionable. Exod. 3.2. Numb. 22.22. So God appeared to Moses, in the bush; his Angell to Balaam, to Gedeon, to Manoah and his wife. Iudg. 6.11. Iudg. 13.3. The like apparitions in times following were more rare in Israel; not that the date of Gods, or his Angels extraordinarie presence, was vtterly expired: but their presence was seldome apprehended, by reason of that peoples blindnesse of heart, and want of Prophets eyes. For Elishaes seruant had not seene so much as a glimpse of any Angell, albeit a mightie host of these heauenly souldiers had pitched their tents about him, vnlesse his master, by his prayer to God, had opened his eyes. His master and hee may be a perfect embleme of the heauenly and worldly wise. The seruant did see the host of the Assyrians as clearely, perhaps more clearely, at the least hee descryed it sooner than his master did: And when the seruant of the man of God arose earely to goe out, 2. King. 6.15. & sequent.
behold, an Hoste compassed the Citie with horses and chariots. Then his seruant said vnto him, Alas master, how shall wee doe? And hee answered, Feare not: for they that bee with vs, are moe than they that bee with them. Then Elishah prayed, and said, Lord open his eyes that hee may see. And the Lord opened the eyes of the seruant, and hee looked, and behold, the mountaine was full of horses and chariots round about Elishah. This place, and that other of the Angels appearing to Balaam, may instruct vs that such apparitions might bee conspicuous to some one or few whom they concerned, though not to others present with them: and that the eyes of some, which were open enough to worldly spectacles, might be close shut to these celestiall visions, as the eares of others haue beene in like case. Act. 22.9. For S. Paul onely heard the voice which cryed alowd vnto him: though those that were with him did see the light that shone at his conuersion, and were astonished at it. From the like experience about Greece or Asia, in his owne, or the vsuall tradition of the like in former times, did Homer bring in Pallas appearing thus to Achilles:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 :Iliad. • .
Of all the rest not one but hee
The Goddesse did, though present, see.

3 As the end and purpose which Homer assignes for these apparitions of his gods; so are both these, and many other particular circumstances of his gods assisting the ancient heroickes, such as might iustly breed offence to any serious reader, if a man should auouch them in earnest, or seeke to perswade him to expect more than meere delight in them. Yet I can not thinke, that he would haue fained such an assistance, vnlesse the valour of some men, in former times, had beene extraordinarie, and more than naturall. Which supernaturall excellencie in some, before others, could not proceede but from a supernaturall cause. And thus farre his conceit agrees with Scripture: that there were more heroicall spirits in olde times, than in later, and more immediate directions from God, for managing of most warres. And from the experience hereof, the auncient Poets are more copious in their hyperbolicall praises of their Worthies, than the discreeter sort of later Poets durst be, whilest they wrote of their owne times. Not that the auncient were more licentious, or lesse obseruant of decorum in this kinde of fiction, than the other: but because the manifestation of a Diuine power in many of their victories, was more seen in ancient, than in later times: so that such fictions, as to the ancient people might seem, by reason of these extraordinarie euents, then frequent, very probable; would haue beene censured as ridiculous and apish in succeeding Ages, wherein no like euents were manifested. The like extraordinarie manifestation of Gods power in battell, and of this heroicall valour inspired into men, we see most frequent in the auncient Stories of the Bible, as in the bookes of Moses, Iosuah, Iudges, Samuel: some one man in those times, was worth a thousand others: but in the Histories of the later Kings of Iudah and Israel, such extraordinarie heroical spirits are very rare. One or two miraculous victories Israel had in Elishahs, and Iudah in Ezekiahs time: but by the power, of Angells: no extraordinarie valour of anie man was much seene in them. And, these few excepted, their battels, their victories, and maner of fight, come neere vnto the nature of other nations in the same time. Generally from Rehoboams time, the Histories of Iudah and
Israel fall much more within the compasse of moderne and ordinarie obseruation, than did the euents of former Ages. And if we had any perfect register of such matters as had fallen out in other nations and kingdomes during the time of Moses, Iosuah, and the Iudges: wee should finde them much more consonant to the sacred Stories of these times, than are any Histories of later times, or of former ages, wherein any Historiographer of better account did liue. And albeit I can not excuse Herodotus and Ctesias, either from affecting fabulous narrations, or too great facilitie in admitting the superstitious report or hearesay-traditions of others: yet is mens mistrust of them vsually more vniuersall, than in scholastike discretion and obseruation it neede to be; onely because the like euents haue not beene vsuall in any Age throughout these parts of the world, since the times whereof they wrote. No maruell if many since that time suspect the signes and wonders of the old world, when as the Psalmist, that liued before most heathen Writers that are extant (besides such as relate like strange euents) complaines; Psal. 75.9. We see not our signes, there is not one Prophet more. Generally, after Iudah had beene captiued by the Gentiles, that and other kingdomes lie, as it were, vnder one paralel, and may almost be measured by the same line: the eleuation of the Iew and Gentile is much-what the same, and the same celestiall obseruation may serue for both. The Priests after their returne from captiuitie, were forbidden to eate of the most holy thing, till there arose vp a Priest with Vrim and Thummim, Ezra 2.63. But; either no such did arise at all, from the erection of the second temple vntill Christs time: or, if any did, it was but to giue this people a farewell of Gods extraordinarie speaking vnto them, either by Priests or Prophets.Antiquitatum. lib. 3. cap. 9.
Iosephus confesseth, that reuelations by Vrim and Thummim did finally cease two hundred yeares before his time. But more probable is the opinion of others, that this, as all other kind of Prophecies, and many extraordinary signes of Gods power and presence (sometime most frequent in that nation) did cease with that generation which returned from captiuitie, or immediately after the finishing of the second temple: as if God during all that time, had appoynted a Fast or Vigil, as an introduction to the time of fulnesse, Ioel 2.28. Wherein their sonnes and daughters should prophecie, and their old men dreame dreames, and
their yong men see visions, and his Spirit should be powred out on all flesh; as well vpon the seruant, as the master; as well vpon the Gentile, as the Iew, Malach. 1.11. For this cause. as I said, God had enioyned this long fast in Iudah, to humble the Iew, and • each him, that he was no more his God than the Gentiles; and imposed silence to all his prophets, dis-inuring his chosen Israel from his wonted call: that so, this people might grow more mild, and apt to herd together with his other flocke, now to bee brought into the same fold, wherein both might ioyntly heare the great Shepheards voice. As God, elsewhere, had threatned, so it came to passe, that visions had ceased in Iudah, before the rising of the Romane Empire: and likely it is that presages by dreames, or like meanes, formerly vsuall among the Ancient heathen, did either altogether determine, or much decrease in many Nations about the same time. For which reasons, the Romans of that Age, being the onely wise men of the world (giuen too much by nature vnto secular policie:) did giue lesse credite to the relations of the Ancient Greekes, or the euents registred by their Auncestours in their owne Countrey. The like incredulitie remaineth in most of vs: but may be easily remoued by discouering the root of it.

div.head: CHAP. VI. The reasons of our mistrusting of Antiquities.
div.p:
1 IT is the common practise of men to measure matters of Ancient times, by obseruation of the times and place wherein they liue: as commonly wee passe our censure on other mens actions and intentions, according to our owne resolutions and secret purposes in like cases. And, besides this generall occasion of mistaking other mens actions, and euents of other times, euery particular sort of men seek to assigne causes of things sutable vnto their proper faculties. The naturall Philosopher striueth to reduce all effects to the matter and forme, or some other sensible quality; the Mathematician, to abstract formes or figures
or insensible influences; the Politician thinks no alteration in publike States, or priuate mens affaires, f • lles out, but from some politike cause or purpose of man: and whilest in the Annales of Antiquities hee reades of sundrie euents, surpassing the reach or skill of mans inuention, or contrarie to the ordinary course of nature, hee attributes all vnto the simplicitie or credulitie of their Ancestors. Albeit, if we should search the true cause of their credulitie in yeelding assent vnto such strange reports, it will easily confute the error of posteritie: for this credulitie in such particulars, could not haue beene so great in their Ancestors, vnlesse their mindes had beene first inclined to the generall, from the tradition of their Predecessors. But why their forefathers should either haue inuented such strange reports, or be so inclinable to beleeue them: if we search into the depth or first spring of this perswasion, we cannot imagine any other cause, but the reall and sensible experience of such strange euents as they reported to posterity. This did inforce beliefe vpon the first Progenitors of any Nation: and from the fulnesse of this perswasion, or actuall beliefe in them, was bred this credulitie or aptnesse in posteritie, to beleeue the like, which yet in successe of time did by little and little weare out. It is great simplicitie and vncharitable credulitie in vs, to thinke, that either the most Ancient, or middle Ages of the world, were generally so simple, credulous, or apt to beleeue euery thing, as some would make them. It had beene as hard a matter to haue perswaded men of these times, that there were no Gods, no diuine power or prouidence: as it would be to perswade the moderne Atheists, that there is an Almightie power, which created all things; gouerneth and disposeth all things to his glorie. The most politike Atheist now aliue, is as credulous in his kinde, as the simplest creature in the old world was: and will yeeld his assent vnto the Epicures or other brutish Philosophers conclusions, vpon as light reasons, as they did their beliefe vnto any fable concerning the power or prouidence of the Gods: the reason of both their credulities in two contrarie kinds, is the same. The often manifestation of an extraordinary power in battels, or presence in oracles, and sensible documents of reuenge from heauen, made the one prone to intertain any report of the Gods, though neuer so strange: & the want of like sensible signes or documēts of the same power in our daies
(whilest all mens minds are still set on politike meanes and practises for their owne good,) doth make the other so credulous and apt to assent vnto any politike Discourse, and so auerse from beliefe of the Prophets or sacred Writers, which reduce al effects to the first cause. But this we can not doe so immediately as the ancient did: because God vseth his wisedome more in the managing of this politike world, than he did in times of old; and men naturally are lesse apprehensiue of his wisedome, than of his power; so that his present wayes are not so obuious at the first sight vnto sense as sometimes they were, though more conspicuous to sanctified reason now at this day than before, and the manner of his proceeding more apt to confirme true beliefe in such as follow his prescripts, than euer it was. For the same reason were the auncient Israelites more prone to idolatrie, than their successours were, after the erection of the second Temple; or eyther of them were at any time to serue their GOD. For the sensible signes and bewitching inticements of some extraordinarie powers, mistaken for Diuine, were then most common; and Gods wonders and miracles grew more rare, because they swarued from his commaundements. What Iew was there, almost, in the time of the Machabees, but would haue giuen his body for an Holocaustum, rather than sacrifice to any of the heathen Gods? The vndoubted experience of long woe and miserie for their former idolatrie, made them so auerse from this sinne; and the certaine signes of the Messiahs approach, did support them from falling into Atheisme. Such violence as these later willingly suffered at the hands of heathen Princes, rather than they would consent vnto idolatrie, their forefathers in the wildernesse were as readie to offer vnto Aaron, for not furthering them in their idolatrous imaginations So we reade Exod. 32. when God had but for a while withdrawne his extraordinarie presence from them, & Moses his instrument in working myracles, had bin but a short time out of their sight: they complaine he taried long, and gathered themselues together against Aaron, and said vnto him; Vp, and make vs Gods to goe before vs: for of this Moses, the man that brought vs out of the land of Egypt, we know not what is become of him. There was no danger lest they should turne Atheists, this was a sinne vnknowne in that age. And this people had experience enough of extraordinary
powers in Egypt, which they took for Gods. So far are they from thinking there was no god that guides the world, that they thoght there were many: and if one did withdraw his presence, an other might serue to conduct them: one they must haue, otherwise all help of man was in vaine. As Iannes and Iambres had withstoode Moses miracles with their magick; so had the diuels, their masters, sought to work wonders about the Egyptian idols, which did obstupifie the people. For albeit their wonders were not so great, as gods: yet were they more delightfull to their outward sense; for their seruice for the most part, was sport and play. They were neuer daintie to shew their iugling tricks, for their owne aduantage; alwaies pliable to the humors & lusts of men: whereas the omnipotent maiestie of God would haue all to frame their liues & actions according to his written Laws, which might not be altered or mis-interpreted, at the pleasure of men; nor would he vouchsafe to worke his miracles in all ages, or vnto such as were vnworthie spectators of them. Thus had Satan his oracles and sacrifices oft times better frequented, than God had his; as in these times, such Preachers as will accommodate themselues vnto the peoples humors, are most frequented, but such as hold this sinne as sacrilege and dishonour to their God, are despised and set at naught. And though we may not mitigate Aarons fault, nor diminish these Israelites transgression (as their foolish posterity doth) by transferring the blame of this idolatrous fact vpon the Magicians which followed the host of Israell out of Egypt: yet it is more than probable from the circumstance of the Text (besides the tradition of the ancient Hebrews,) that there was some magicall or daemoniacall skill practised in the sodain moulting of this Egiptiā god, whence this peoples superstition towards it was increased.Plutarch. de defecta oraculor. pag. 742. edit. H. Steph. The heathen princes of those times were no babies; as wary (we may presume) vpon what occasion to forgoe their children, as misers are to part with mony: & yet these were wrested from them, and their blood shed by their owne hands, to pacifie the rage of powers, then manifestly knowne for supernatural. But when both Gods wonders grew rare, and the diuells trickes waxed scant, either by restraint from aboue, or of their owne free choice, as if by their long continuance they had growne out of request: they see it more boote to draw the politike world vnto Atheisme, which neuer did florish
vntill the rising of the Roman monarchie. Vnto this maine inconuenience of the late Romans, and other worldly wise mens distrust of wonders past, this second mischiefe did accrew, That sundry Writers of those times, did hold it a part of their profession, to fill their bookes with such stuffe, as they found in ancient stories; as if their Histories or Poems had not been currant, without as many parts or heads of inuention, as others had in former Ages. And this experience of counterfeit wonders, meeting with the want of experience of anie true wonders of that time, did concurre as the forme and priuation for the producing of infidelitie in mens minds already disposed to this euill by secular policie. And these were enough to carry our mindes below the lowest degree of any credulitie, or suspition of truth, in like reports: vnlesse the Scripture did forewarne vs of this guile and policie of Satan, which we may the better preuent, if we diligently obserue, first, the difference of times and places; secondly, how strange fables and lying wonders receiue being from notable and admirable decayed truths, as baser Creatures doe life, from the dissolution of more noble bodies.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the diuersitie of euents in different Ages.
div.p:
1 THe diuerse Characters of different times rightly taken, giue vs as easie and perfect a crisis between the fictions of later, & the true annalls of former ages: as out of ordinarie discretion men vsually make between foolish trauellers reports of great wonders in Spaine, or France; and the iudicious records of vncouth sights, and strange euents, in the East or West-Indies. And we haue altogether as litle reason to enuy either the generall truth of strange euents recorded by the auncient, or the prototypos of poeticall inuentions in former times, for the want of like experience in later: as we haue to discredit Benzos martyrs, or other late nauigators obseruations of the East or West Indies,
because many, who haue trauelled France, Spaine, and Italy, while they make true relatiōs of their trauels, relate no such euent, as the Indies afford many. And yet Gulles, when they flie abroad, will relate (amongst such as know them not) as strange matters of neare adioyning countries, as he that had compassed the vtmost endes of the world. Now it were a great folly to discredit all late nauigators, for the absurditie of some few Gulles: and as great madnesse it were to disparage all ancient stories, for the absurd & preposterous imitation of later writers, against all experience of later times. For diuersitie of times yeelds as great diuersitie of obseruations, as the diuersitie or distance of place; onely this is the difference; Daily obseruation yeeldes experiments of this diuersitie in place, whereas the word of God alone which indures for euer, giueth vs the sure rules and grounds of alterations in the euents of different ages. And yet in many remote places lately made known vnto the inhabitants of Europe, such strange euents as Antiquity hath told vs, were sometimes frequent in these Countries which wee now inhabite, are not at this day altogether vnusuall. And the face of Time is now there much-what such, as the ancient Registers of Times haue pourtrayed vnto vs: as if the affaires and fashion of this visible world, were framed according to some inuisible patterns or supercoelestiall Characters; which varying their aspect in reuolutions of time, did now (by reflecting that force vpon these remote countries, which they did on these neare adioyning in times past) produce the like shape & fashion of things there, as they haue done here. And those places shal, in time, com to the selfe same temper & disposition which we now enioy: and the posterity of such as now liue there, shal hereafter suspect the vndoubted stories of our times concerning their ancestors, as we do many ancient stories of Iewry, Syria, Asia, or our owne countries, for want of like moderne experiments in our land.

2 For the better rectifying of our assent, which must be by the right balancing of credulity and mistrust, it shall not be amisse to consider, that, besides these general diuersities of times and places, particular kingdomes and nations haue their seueral ages proportionable to infancie, youth, virilitie, and old age in men: nor is the period either of the whole age, or the seuerall parts thereof, one & the same in all, but varies in diuerse kingdomes, as the course of
life, or seuerall ages do in diuerse men. Some kingdoms beare age well vnto a thousand; some to sixe hundred yeares: others breake and decay in halfe that time. Againe, as in the course of mans life diuersity of ages requires diuers manners or conditions: so, in the same people or nation, some euents are vsuall, as best befitting them in that degree of their growth which answeres to youth, or infancie, which seldome or neuer fall out in that part of their age which answeres vnto mature or old age in men, because not conuenient for their constitution then; and yet the want of like experience makes them as distrustfull and incredulous of what formerly had beene, as old men are forgetfull of their own disposition or temper in youth. Generally, when the fulnesse of any nations iniquitie (wherein their decrepit age consisteth,) is come, they grow more and more incredulous: so as they verifie the Latine prouerb concerning the disposition of old men: Nullus senex veneratur Iouem: more true of states;
As they grow old,
Their zeale growes cold.

3 As the world was redeemed by Christ, so doe nations begin a new computation of their ages, from their admission to Christianitie. Some were come to youth, or virilitie in their profession, before others were borne in Christ: as Asia and Africa, for the most part, were Christians before Europe. Againe, the ancient inhabitants in some prouinces had beene Christians, long before other people that afterward subdued them and liued in their countries: as the Britaines in this Iland had beene long partakers of Gods mercy in Christ, before the Saxons; and the ancient Gaulles, before the Franks, which afterward seated themselues in their habitations. Generally, miracles were vsuall in the infancie of Christianitie, as we read in Ecclesiasticall stories: nor can it be certainly gathered when they did generally cease. To say they indured no longer than the Pimitiue Church, can giue no vniuersall satisfaction, saue only to such as thinke it enough for all the world to haue the light of the Gospell lockt vp in the Chancell of some one glorious Church: for some Churches were but in the Prime, or Change, when others were full of Christian knowledge. The vse of miracles at the same instant was befitting the one, not the other. For God vsually speakes to new-borne children in
Christ, by miracles or sensible declarations of his power, mercy, or iustice: as parents deterre their children from euill, in tender yeres, by the rod, or other sensible signes of their displeasure; and assure them to goodnes with apples, or other like visible pledges of their loue: but, when they come to riper yeares, and are capable of discourse, or apprehensiue of wholesome admonitions, they seeke to rule thē by reason. Proportionally to this course of parents doth God speak to his church: in her infancie, (wheresoeuer planted) by sensible documents of his power; in her maturitie, by the ordinarie preaching of his word, which is more apt to ripen & confirm true Christian faith than any miracles are, so men would submit their reason vnto the rules set down in Scripture, and vnpartially examine all euents of time by them, as elsewhere, God willing, we shall shew.

4 These grounds, well considered, will moue any sober spirit at the least to suspend his assent, and not suffer his mind to be hastily ouerswaied with absolute distrust of all such miracles, as either our writers report to haue bin wrought in this our land at the Saxons first comming hither, or the French Historiographers record in the first conuersion of the Franks, or in the prime of that Church.

5 And the Franks and Saxons before their conuersion to Christianity, were much-what of that temper, in respect of their present posteritie, as Greece was of in Homers, or Italy in the daies of Romulus, in respect of Ciceroes, or Plutarchs time: nor would I denie, but that admonitions by dreames were vsuall amongst them, as they had beene amongst the Easterne nations.

And, without preiudice to many noble Patriots and worthie members of Christ this day liuing in that famous Kingdome of France, I should interpret that dreame of Bassina, Queene vnto Childerick the first,Annonius in vita Childerici, lib. 1. of the present state of France: in which the last part of that threefold vision is more truly verified, than it was euer in the lineall succession of Childerick and Bassina, or any of the Merouingian, or Carlouingian families.

6 The vision was of three sorts of beasts; the first, Lyons & Leopards; the second, Beares and wolues; the third, of Dogs or lesser creatures, biting and deuouring one another. The interpretation which Bassina made of it, was registred certaine hundred yeares ago; That these troupes of vermine or lesser creatures, did signifie a
people without feare or reuerence of their Princes, so pliable and deuoutly obsequious to follow the Peeres or Potentates of that Nation in their factious quarrels, that they should inuolue themselues in inextricable tumults to their owne destruction.

7 Had this vision beene painted, onely with this general notification; that it was to be emblematically vnderstood of some state in Europe: who is he that can discerne a picture by the knowne partie whom it represents, but could haue knowne as easily, that this was a mappe of those miseries that lately haue befallen France; whose bowels were almost rent and torne, with ciuill and domesticke broyles? God grant her closed wounds fall not to bleed a fresh againe, and that her people be not so eagerly set to bite and teare one another (like dogs or other testie creatures,) vntill all become a prey to Wolues and Beares, or other great rauenous beasts; which seeke not so much to teare or rent in heat of reuenge, as lie in waite continually to deuoure and swallow with vnsatiate greedinesse, the whole bodies of mightie Kingdomes, and to dye her Robes, that rides as Queene of Monsters vpon that many-headed beast, with streames of bloud that issue from the bodies squezed and crushed betweene their violent teeth; yea, euen with the royall bloud of Kings and Princes. Many such examples of admonitions by dreames and other extraordinary signes of future woe or calamities, both foretold and fulfilled many hundred yeares since Bassina and Childerickes daies, I could bring, which might confirme the historicall truth of the like mentioned in Scriptures to any ciuill heathen, as they haue inforced such as we most suspect for Atheists, to acknowledge a diuine power or prouidence in them. And I know not what reason any professor of truth can haue to denie the like presignifications in later times vpon extraordinarie occasions, or in some transmutations of Kingdomes; if he haue so much Religion as not to doubt of Nabuchadnezers vision. But of such signes, (whether good, or ominous) and of their lawfull vse elsewhere. Of the vse of prophecies amongst the heathen and barbarous people, and of that offence which some take at such as seem to giue any credit to them, as if this were against the truth of scriptures, we may perhaps take occasion to speake, when we come to vnfold the diuers kinds of prophecies amongst the Iewes, with their interpretations.
Thus much may suffice for the remouall of that preiudice, which Atheists, Infidels, and other worldly-wise men haue, of their ancestors credulitie, or fabulositie, which were not incident to primarie antiquitie, but vnto ages in succession nearer to those times wherein wonders had beene plentifull: as commonly the braggadochian humour doth haunt the degenerate race of worthy ancestors, before their posteritie come to be sneaks or peasants, which in the race of priuate persons answeres in proportion to infidelity, the common symptome of decrepit age in kingdomes.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the originall and right vse of Poetrie: with the manner of its corruption by later Poets.
div.p: 1 THe positiue truth, which in the remoual of impedimēts & offences hath bin made more thā probable in the former discourse, may yet be made more euident from more particular obseruations concerning the manner how monstrous fables haue descended from true wonders: which will best appeare by setting downe the original and right vse of Poetry.

2 A Poet being (as his name imports) a maker, according to the Latine prouerb, is not made by art, but framed to this diuine facultie by nature. Not that any amongst the Romans became Poets on a sodaine: but that many very fruitfull wits in all other kinds of learning, could not be forced by any industrie, art, or culture to such a temper, as was befitting this plant of Eden, which groweth not in any moderne breast without more tender care and greater cherishing, than any other slip or branch of the tree of knowledge; and yet when all is done seldome comes to any proofe, vnlesse it borrow grounds from the Ancient: as tender plants can hardly be remoued from a better foile to a worse, without some of the earth wherein they naturally grow. Were arts to begin a-new, Poetrie, which was the first and most common among the Ancient, in all probability, would spring the last, & grow the slowest amongst vs. Their wits of old were not naturally or generally better than ours:
why then was the way to Pernassus, which vnto vs, vsing all help of art and imitation, is laborious and hard to ascend, so plaine and easie to them, without any guide or helpe; all other artificial learning being then either vnknown, or very scant? Such knowledge or obseruatiōs as they had or cared for, they knew not otherwise how to conuey vnto posterity, than by poetical numbers & resemblances. He is a Poet by nature (saith that excellent Poet and diuine Philosopher) That is apt to be rauished with the true and natiue beautie of such obiects as are represented to his senses, & can expresse his conceit by such pleasant resemblances, as oftē as he shal haue occasion to vtter his mind in writing or set speech. This inclination or disposition is as the ground or soile wheron Poetry doth naturally grow, whether in ancient or moderne breasts: but the ancient had this aduantage. The fashion of the world in their times was more apt to rauish their thoughts with admiration: wonderfull euents were then frequent: nor did their frequēcy abate, but rather increase wondermēt, because their varietie was great, & the apprehension of inuisible or supernatural powers in them vsuall. So that admiration was then inforced vpon men, & the breasts of such as diligently obserued these euents, or were any way disposed by nature to the faculty, were inspired with liuely and sublimate affections, apt to vent themselues in such poetical phrase and resemblances, as we cannot reach vnto, vnlesse we raise our inuention by art & imitation, and stirre vp admiration by meditation and studie. And because neither our senses are moued with any extraordinary effects of Gods power, nor our minds bent to obserue the waies of his wisdome, so as we might be stricken with true admiration of them, we haue fewer good sacred poemes, than of any other kind. But as the Ancients chiefe learning did consist of Poetry: so the excellency of their Poetrie was chiefly seene in the power and natiue subiect of this faculty, that is, in matters of sacred vse or obseruation: whence the title of Vates did descend vnto secular or prophane Poets, which retained the number and manner of speech vsed by the former.

3 That such as were Vates indeed, were raught to this sublimity of speech by admiration of extraordinary euents, may be confirmed by the historicall narrations of the sacred story: wherin poeticall hymns or songs are the vsual consequents of strange or wonderful euents. As, Iud. 5. after the victory gotten ouer Sisera, Then sang
