〈1 page duplicate〉
Deborah, and Barach the son of Abinoam, the same day saying; Praise ye the Lord, &c. So likewise Hannah, after the Lord had heard her prayer, and taken away her barrennesse, burst out into the like Poeticall hymne, 1. Sam. 2. So did the blessed Virgin vpon her cosen Elizabeths salutation, and Iohn Baptist springing in her wombe, take vp her song, Luke. 1.46. My soule doth magnifie the Lord, &c. So doth Zacharie, Iohn Baptists father, take vp his prophecie, Luk. 1.68. and Simeon. Luke. 2.28. So likewise after the manifestation of Gods wonders in the red Sea, all his people (as if they had beene baptised in a sacred Helicon) presently turned Poets, Exod. 15.1. And againe, Numb. 21. after they had returned to Beer, the well which Moses had opened out of the hard rocke with his rod, Israel (as if they had washed their mouthes in Hippocrene) had their voyces tuned to an high straine of Poetrie: Then Israel sang this song: rise vp, well, sing ye vnto it, the Princes digged this well, the Captaines of the people digged it, euen with their staues.

4 That the frequent vse of Poetrie among the ancient heathen, did arise from like occasions, may be gathered from Strabo: who from antiquitie,Strabo. init. lib. 1 better knowne to him than vs, auoucheth it as vnquestionable, that all other set speech, whether historicall or rhetoricall, was but the progenie of Poetrie, falling in later times from its wonted state and dignitie; wheras the Ancients knew no other branch of artificial or set speech, but only Poetrie. Albeit to speake properly, it was (in respect of the efficient or impulsiue causes) rather super artificiall, than naturall or artificiall; and Rhetorick and Historie only artificiall. This opinion will not seeme strange, if we consider, that the wiser sort in those times did commend such matters only to writing, as might inflame posteritie with deuotion and loue of vertue. For Poetrie, as the same Author tels vs, was accounted by Antiquitie, prima quaedam Philosophia, a kind of sacred morall Philosophie, appropriated, as it seemes, at the first to the relation or representation of supernaturall euents or diuine matters only: of which the most ancient had best experience, and were impelled to communicate them to posteritie, eleuated (as is obserued before) by the excellency of the obiect to this celestiall kind of speech, which is most apt to rauish yonger wits, as it selfe was bred of admiration. This vse of Poetrie appeares in some fragments of most ancient Poets, in their kind proportionable to the booke of
Psalmes, of Iob, and the songs of Moses, the only patternes of true Poesie: whose subiects, vsually, are the wonderfull works of God manifested vnto mē. Some degenerate footsteps of these holy men the heathen, about Homers time, did obserue: vsing their Poets and Musicians for planting modestie and chastitie amongst other vertues in their auditors. So Agamemnon left the musicall Poet as Gardian to Clytemnestra, who continued chaste and loyall vntill Aegistus got the Poet conueyed into an vninhabited Iland.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . For this reason was PoetrieStrabo ibid. taught children first throughout the Grecian Cities, as Moses had commaunded the Israelites to teach their children his diuine Poeme, Deut. 31.19. & 32.46. And they much wrong that diuinePlat. lib. 10. de Repub. Philosopher,Hom. odys that think he was any farther an enemie vnto the sacred facultie, than only to seek the reformation of it by reducing it to its first naturall vse; which was not meere delight, as Eratosthenes dreamed, rightly taxed by Strabo for this error. That might perhaps be true of the Comicall Latine Poets;
Poeta quum primum animum ad scribendum appulit,
Id sibi negoti credidit solum dari,
Populo vt placerent quas fecisset fabulas.
When first the Poet bent his wits to write,
The onely marke he aym'd at, was delite.

Which not withstanding had neither beene the onely, nor chiefe vse; no end at al, but rather an adiunct of Poetrie amongst the Ancient: by the wiser and better sort of whom nothing was apprehended, at least approued as truly delightfull, which was not also honest and of profitable vse for bettering life and manners. The law of nature being then lesse defaced: they could read it without spelling, comprehend al the three elements of goodnesse, iointly vnder one entire conceit, as we do the product of diuers letters or syllables in one word, without examination of their seueral value apart. But when the vnion of this trinity wherin the nature of complet & perfect goodnes cōsist, was once dissolued in mens harts, & delight had found a peculiar issue without mixture of honesty or vtility: the desire of becomming popular Poets, did breed the bane of true Poesy, & those sacred numbers, which had bin as amulets against vice,
became incentiues vnto lust. Or if we would but search the natiue vse of poetrie by that end which men, not led awry by hopes of applause, or gaine, or other externall respects, but directed rather by the internall impulsion of this facultie and secret working of their soules, do aime at: it principally serues for venting extraordinarie affections. No man almost so dul, but will be poetically affected in the subiect of his strongest passions. As we see by experience, that where the occasiōs either of ioy for the fortunate valour, or sorrow for the mishaps of their countrimen, or alliance, are most rife, this disposition is both most pregnant and most common. And as speech or articulation of voices in generall, was giuen to man for communicating his conceits or meaning vnto others: so Poetrie, the excellēcy of speech, serues for the more liuely expressing of his choicer conceits, for beautifying his darling thoughts or fancies, which almost disdain to go abroad in other than this exactly proportioned attire, the soules wooing suits (if I may so speak) wherby she wins others to sympathize with her in abūdance of griefe, or to cōsent with her in excessiue ioy, or finally to settle their admiratiō or dislike where she doth hers. And the more strange or wonderful the matter conceiued, or to be represented, is, the more pleasant & admirable will the true and natural representation of it be: and the more he that conceiues it, is rauished with delight of its beauty or goodnes; the more will he long to communicate his conceit & liking of it to others. Whence, such as had seen the wonders of God and had bin fed with his hidden Mannah, Psal. 34.8. sought by their liuely and heartie representations to inuite others, as the Psalmist doth, to tast and see the goodnesse of the Lord, as birds and beasts, when they haue found pleasant food, call (on their fashion) vnto others of the same kind, to be partakers with thē in their ioy: vntill Satan, who hunts after the life of man, as man doth after the life of birds, did inuent his counterfaite cals to allure our soules into his snare. For, when men had once taken a delight in the naturall representation of euents, delightfull in themselues: he stirred vp others to inuent the like, albeit there were no reall truth or stability in the things represented, and the manner of representation vsually so light and affected, as could argue no credence giuen by the Authors to their owne report, but rather a desire to please such as had neuer set their minds to any inquisition of solid truth, whose vnsetled
fancies cannot choose but fall in loue with as many faire pictures of others pleasant imaginations as are presented to them. For, as to view the connexion of reall causes with their effects (most of all, if both bee rare, or the concurrents of circumstances vnusuall) doth much affect the iudicious minde or vnderstanding: so the quaint or curious contriuance of imaginarie rarities, set forth in splendent artificiall colours, doth captiuate the fancies of such as are not established in the loue of truth. But (as the Orator said of such as applauded the Tragedie of Pylades and Orestes) how would such mens soules be rauished, could they vpon sure grounds bee perswaded, that these stories were true, albeit deuoid of artificiall colours, or poeticall contriuances, neuer vsed by sacred Antiquitie? in whose expression of wonders, the phrase is vsually most poeticall, as naturally it will alwaies, where the minde is much affected; their inuention lesse artificiall or affected, than our historicall narrations of moderne affaires; the character of their stile (as was intimated before) doth argue that they sought only to set downe the true proportion of matters seene and heard, with such resemblances as were most incident to their kinde of life. And from the efficacie of such extraordinarie effects vpon their soules, is it, that the Prophets so often expresse the same thinges in diuers wordes, as if all they could say, could not equalize the sensible experiments, which did moue their hearts and fancies (as the musitians handes or breath doth his instruments) to sound out such patheticall Ditties. Nor had their Ditties any greater disproportion with their subiect, than our Songs of famous victories, haue with theirs; or other passionate Ditties, with their composers affections: albeit hee that hath experience of loue, or abundant griefe or ioy, will speake in an other dialect, than ordinarily hee vseth, without any touch of affectation.

5 Hence we may clearly discerne, whilest wonders decaied, and men sought as great delight in fained, as their forefathers had done in true representations: how the disproportion betwixt representations, and the reall euents, or experiments of the times, wherein the later Poets liued, became so monstrous and prodigious. This fell out iust so, as if the armorours of this age should not obserue the stature of men now liuing, but fashion their armour by old Guy of Warwicks harnes: or our painters, not looke
vpon the bodies of moderne English-men, but take their proportions from some ancient pictures, which had beene truly taken about some thousand yeares agoe, in some other Countrie, that had yeelded men of more ample stature in that age, than this land of ours did in any. Such an error as this, which we haue mentioned in Poetrie, would quickly haue beene reformed in any other facultie that had concerned mens temporall profit or commodities, or whereof others had been as competent iudges as the professors: for so, when they had begunne to wander, or digresse a litle from their right end, they should presently haue beene called to this accompt; quid adrem? your worke may be pretie, but not to our purpose. But when such admirable euents, as were well worth Poeticall expression, decreased, and worldly cares did multiply, as men increased: the diuine art of Poetrie, which admits not many competent iudges in any age, was counted no better then a matter of meere delight, or recreation; and for this reason the prodigious representations of it, so monstrously disproportionable to the truth represented (because oft times more pleasant to men wearied with other studies or imploiments, than the bare narration of the truth) were neuer reformed. And so at length, that audacious licentiousnesse of fictions, for mouing delight, did in the iudgement of posteritie disparage the very patterns or prototypos of poeticall representations, whereunto later Poems had beene framed. As many tall fellowes in this present age, if they should see the true image or picture of some ancient Giants, would sweare that the painter had plaied the Poet: were it not that the dead bodies or limmes of some ancient people, lately digged out of the ground, did by their vnusuall bignesse teach vs to estimate (as we say) expede Herculem, how great others might haue been, whose big limmes and bones haue not come vnto this ages sight.

6 But most of these strange euents were such, as did continue no longer than while they were a doing, wherefore we must seeke out the true proportion of these heauenly bodies, by their shadowes, represented in the later prophane Poets. The original and manner of whose digression from the patterns of the ancient diuine Poets, or rather from diuine truth, the patterne of ancient poetrie it selfe, was partly as you haue heard, partly as followeth.

7 Gods wonderfull works haue been more plenteous in Asia,
than in other parts of the world; more plentifull in Iudea, and the Regions about it, than in other parts of Asia; most plentifull in them, about the Israelites deliuerance out of Aegypt. In that time and in the ages before, or immediately succeeding it, artificiall learning was very scant; and characters, either not inuented, or their vse very rare in most places. The fresh memorie of such wonders presupposed; the liuely image either of such licentiousnes in coining fables, or confounding true histories with the mixture of false and vnnaturall circumstances, as these wants euery where in all time naturally breed, we may clearely behold in the moderne Turkes: who are as abundant in prodigious fables, as defectiue in good learning; and for want of printing, or neglect of writing, haue no perfect character of the worlds fashion in times past, nor any distinct order of former euents.Nullam habent Turcae temporum neque atatum rationem, mire{que} historias omnes miscent & confundunt: cum ijs in mentem veniet, non verebuntur affirmare Regis Salomonis magistrā curiae fuisse lobum, cius exercitus praefectum Alexandrum Magnum, aut hijs etiam absurdiora. Busbequius, Epist. 1. It is but a pettie soloecisme among them, to affirme that Iob the Hussite was chiefe Iustice; and Alexander the Great, Lieutenant generall vnto King Salomon.

8 The like confusion of times and places might be more incident vnto the Asiatike Nations, before Alexanders time, because their ancestors had beene acquainted with more strange euents, latelier forepast than the moderne Turkes are. Now alwaies the more strange the euents be, the more ready they be to mount vppon the wings of fame; and once so mounted, the more apt to receiue increase in euery circumstance, and varie their shape, whilest they flie only from mouth to mouth in the open aire, not fashioned or limited at their first birth, by some visible character, or permanent stamp set vpon them.

9 From this vicinitie of true wonders in Iurie, or thereabouts, were the Medes, Persians, and Syrians, so much adicted to fabulous narrations, that their delight in such traditions did make their later writers ambitious in the skill of coining wonders; as Strabo tels vs in his 11. Booke. And Greece, as it receiued artificial learning first from Asia, so did it drinke in this humour with it. For the traditions of Gods miracles in Iurie, and the regions about it, hauing beene far spred, when Greece began first to tattle in artificiall learning, the Grecians (alwaies children in true antiquitie, as the Aegyptian Priest told one of their Philosophers) were apt to counterfait the forme of ancient truths, & misapply it to vnseemly
matters, or foolish purposes; as children will bee doing that in homlier stuffe, which they see their elders doe in better. Finally, the same humour which yet raignes amongst men, might possesse most of the Heathen. There is no famous euent that falls out, (though it be but a notable iest) but in a short time, is ascribed to a great many more, than haue any affinitie with it. As many of Diogen▪s conceipts haue beene fathered vpon Tarleton: and what the Christians say of S. George, the Turkes ascribe to Chederley. If it be any storie concerning way-faring men; euery Hostler, Tapster, or Chamberlaine, will tell you that it fell out in their Towne, or in the Countrie thereabouts. And though you heare it in twentie seuerall places, yet shall you haue alwaies some new tricks of addition put vpon it. In like manner did the reports of sundry euents, which either fell out, only in Iurie or vpon occasion of Gods people, flie about the world; sometime with cut and mangled, but most vsually with enlarged, artificiall wings, as if the same had been acted euery where, or the like inuented vpon euery occasion.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of some particular fables resembling some true stories of the Bible.
div.p:
1 TO draw some instances from the first fountaine, the Well of Beer,
Numb. 21. mentioned before, did prefigure Christ, the rocke and fountaine, whence issue streames of waters vnto eternall life. And that sacred Poeticall spirit, which now possessed them, was as a praeludium to those hymnes and songs vttered by Christs Apostles, and his Disciples, when the spirit of God was powred vpon them, after Christs glorification. Neighbour-countries, amongst whom the fame of this euent was spred, might easily hence take occasion to ascribe the effect vnto the Well. And hence had Greece her Helicon, and others (by her) reputed sacred Wells, whose waters drunke did make men Poets on a sodaine; besides, that the opportunitie of such places, as Helicon and Pernassus were, did dispose mens mindes vnto this facultie. The Daemoniacall spirits, which for this reason would frequent the same, might inspire such with poeticall furie as did obserue their
rites and ceremonies; counterfeiting the spirit of Diuine Prophecies, as they had done Gods voice in Oracles. Who can doubt if hee compare both stories, but that the fable of Hyppocrene or Aganippe in Boaetia, so called because digged by an horses foote, as Poets faigne, did take beginning from the storie of this sacred well which Moses digged with his rod: and as the Israelites haue a tradition, the Princes afterwards, with their staues? And the Phaenicians which followed Cadmus into Europe, are made such wanderers by the Poets, as the Israelites were in the wildernesse: and Cadmus himselfe, the founder of Hippocrene or Aganippe, amongst other of his inuentions is said to haue beene the first that taught Greece the vse of letters, or that wrote Histories in prose; and in one word, another Moses. The firie Serpents, which stung the Israelites murmuring for want of water, Numb. 21. v. 5. might grow in short time to be dragons; and hence, as it is most likely,Ouid Met. l. 3. fab. 2. Chap. 10. v. 13. are Cadmus companions said to bee slaine by a dragon, whilest they sought for water. The Sunne, as we read in the storie of Ioshuah, at Ioshuah his prayer once stood still in the vale of Gibeon. The occasion is in the same place specifyed; That Iosuah might haue a day of the Ammorites: such a day as was neuer before it, nor shal be after it. This strange miraculous euent, the heathen people of those times had noted, and deliuered it by tradition vnto their posteritie; who, after the manner of this world, sought to assigne some causes of it. The Poets in ages following, ascribe it (with some additions) vnto that vnnaturall prodigious murther, which Atreus had committed; and for ought we know, besids the reasons specified in sacred writ, God might vse this, partly as a meanes, to make Greece and other countries, that should heare of Atreus bloudie facte, stand amazed at such foule impietie, whereat the heauens did blush, and the sunne stood still. The times of Atreus his fact, and Iosuah his victorie, come neere to one point: if Statius the Poet be not farre out in his Chronologie. For he tels vs, that this horrible fact of Atreus was committed, about the time of the Thebane warre; for which reason the Mycenae amongst other good neighbours, did not aide King Adrastus, and his Argiues against the Thebanes.

l.hi: Funereae dum namque dapes, medijque recursus,
Solis; et hinc alij miscebant proelia fratres.

q.l: Mycene their neighbours onely send no ayde,
Their tragicke cheare had bred such bloudie broyles,
Whose direfull sight the blushing Sunne had staid,
Whilest fierce reuenge in heart of brothers boiles.

div.p: 2 And some Chronologers, whose skil in this facultie, & other good literature, I especially reuerence, refer the siege of Troy to the time of Iudges, or age following Ioshuah; whereas the Thebane warre was in the age before: for Tydeus, father vnto Diomedes (who was one of the greatest sticklers against Troy) was one of the greatest Chieftaines in the Thebane warre.

3 From the fore-mentioned humour of seeking to play the Poets or Painters in adorning true stories; or of vaine curiositie in inuenting the like: wee may easily coniecture, what varietie of reports would in that temper of the world bee extant, of Samsons consecrated haire, wherein his inconquerable strength, as the sacred storie tels vs, did consist: Let Dalilah, Samsons wife, be but mistaken for his daughter, Iud. 16. v. 17.18 (as few reports of forraine or forepast matters, but varie as much in some circumstance or other) and for Samson and Dalilah you haue the famous Legend Nisus and Sylla. This mistake was very easie. For such as had heard of Dalilahs treacherie, without any particular certaintie of that circumstance, whether she were his daughter or wife, might iustly suspect that she was his daughter, one that wanted an husband, doting vpon some forrainer, whom she hoped to winne vnto her loue by this practise. Or perhaps Sylla had betrayed her father Nisus, vpon hope of satisfying her lust; and Ouid (with other Poets) hauing heard of like practize, did Stage-play-like put Samsons haire vpon Nisus his head; as vsually the Graecian Poets haue borrowed their best Stage-attire from the glorious wardrope of Israel. Other circumstances of this storie are verie like; saue onely that Ouid faines Nisus his vnuanquishable fortune, to haue beene seated in one haire,Ouid metamorp. l. 8. fab. 1 which was of the colour of his costly robes.

q.l: —Cai splendidus astro

l.hi: Inter honoratos medio de vertice canos

q.l: One skarlet bright, amids the ranks of white and reuerend haires,
He had, wheron did hang the hope, and hap of his affaires.

div.p:
But Samsons strength was in his lockes, as he told Dalilah;
Iudg. 17. v. 17. There neuer came rasor vpon my head, for I am a Nazarite vnto God from my mothers wombe: therefore if I be shauen, my strength will goe from mee, and I shalbe weake, and be like all other men. For the meanes and opportunities whereby Dalilah did, and Sylla is fained to haue compassed her intended treason, they are the very same. Dalilah, as it is said, made Samson sleepe vpon her knee, and shee called a man, and made him to shaue the seauen lockes of his head; Ʋers. 19. and so Ouid brings in Sylla, taking the like opportunitie of her fathers sleepe;
Prima quies aderat, qua curis fessa diurnis
Pectora somnus habet, thalamos taciturna paternos
Intrat, & (heu facinus) fatali nata parentem
Crine suum spoliat. —
First sleep was come, & wearie limbs were at their sweet repose
When she vnto her fathers bed, in sliest silence goes:
But let no silence cloake her shame, so detestable theft,
Her father of his fatall haire the daughter hath bereft.

4 Not much greater varietie is there betweene the storie of Lots wifes transformation into a pillar of salte,Ouid Met. l. 6. fab. 3. and Niobes into a stone. The Poets faine that Niobe was transformed, vpon her griefe for death of her children: and the Iewes haue a Tradition, that Lots wife was ouertaken with that hydeous showre of fire and brimstone, whilest she stayed behind her husband to see what would become of her friends, & her kinsfolke, which remained in Sodom. And it is probable out of that Chapter, that Lots sonne in Law remained in Sodom, and likely their wiues too, Gen. 19. v. 14. Lots other daughters. For so it is said (not without Emphasis in the Original) Take thy wife and thy two daughters, which are found,
Vers. 15. or (as the Chaldies paraphrase) which are found faithfull with thee, (that is, which are not corrupt by conuersing with others abroad) least thou be destroyed with others in the punishment of this citie. Whether this Tradition of the Iewes bee true or no, it makes little for my present purpose. Verie ancient it is, & whether true or false, might giue occasion to the former fable, as other stories of the Bible do, sometimes the rather, because the sence is mistaken. As the common
opinion is, that Lots wife was transformed into a pillar of Salt, when as no circumstance of the text doth enforce so much, but rather leaues vs free, to thinke, what is more probable; that fearefull showers of Gods vengeance, wherewith Sodom was destroied, were heaped vpon her, so that her bodie was wrapt vp in that congealed matter, which was perhaps in forme like to some thunderstone, or the like, from which it could not be discerned, being as it were canded in it.

5 If such a transformation of Lots wife seeme strange; what wil the Atheist say vnto the destruction of Sodom, Haud procul inde campi, quos ferunt olim vberes magnisque vrbivus habitatos, fulminum iactu arsisse, & manere vestigia, terram{que} specie torridam vim frugiferam perd •
disse; nam cuncta sponte ed • ta, aut manu sata, siue verba tenus aut s • ore, s • u s • litam in speciem adoleuere, atra, et inania velut in cinerem vanescunt. Ego sicut Indaicas quendam vrbes igne coelesti flagrasse concesserim, ita halitu lacus inficiterram, corrumpi superfulum spiritum, eo{que} faetus segetum & autumni p • trescere •• or, sole, coelo{que} iuxta graui. Cornelius Tacitus in Ʋ •• pasi • num sua • um historiarum ab exessu N •• on •• l b. 5. Strabo. l 16. & the fiue cities? or if this seeme more strange and incredulous, because their destruction vanisheth whilest they perished; What can he say to the salt sea? Doubtlesse, vnlesse God had left this as a lasting monument to confute the incredulitie of Philosophers, by an ocular & sensible demonstration, they would haue denyed the truth of this effect, as wel as they doubt of the cause, which the Scriptures assigne of it. Is the violence of that storme, which destroyed the fiue Cities, strange, and aboue the force of nature? so is the qualitie of that sea, and the soile about it, contrarie to the nature of all other seas, or in-land lakes. And let the most curious Philosopher in the world giue any naturall cause of it, and the disproportion betweene the cause, and the knowne effect, will be more prodigious in nature, than the cause, which Moses giues of it, is strange: some cause by their confession it must haue; and though the storme were raised by a supernaturall power, yet admitting the violence of it, to be such as the Sciptures tels vs, and the fall of so much durable matter, no cause can be conceiued, so probable in nature, as Moses giues; as out of the grounds of Philosophie, and diuerse experiments in nature, I could easily proue. But Strabo that great Philosopher, and no credulous antiquarie, hath cased mee of this labour. For albeit he held the Syrians for a fabulous people: yet the euident markes of Gods wrath, that had bin kindled in that place, (as concauities made by fire, distillation of pitch out of the seared rocks the noysome smell of the waters there abouts, with the reliques and ruines of auncient habitations,) made the Tradition of neighbour inhabitants seeme probable vnto him; That there had beene thirteene populous Cities in that soile, of which Sodome was the chiefe, whose circumference then remaining, was
sixtie furlongs. But (as the custome is of secular Philosophers) he seekes to ascribe the cause of this desolation rather vnto Earth than Heauen, and thinkes the Lake was made by an Earthquake, which had caused the bursting out of hot waters, whose course was vpon Sulphure and Brimstone. And it is not vnlikely, that the earth did tremble, whilest the heauens did so terribly frowne, and the Almightie gaue his fearefull voice from out the clouds: and once hauing opened her mouth to swallow vp those wicked inhabitants, the exhalations of whose sinnes had bred these stormes, became afterwards a Panne or Receptacle of moysture, infecting all the waters which fell into it, with the loathsome qualities of those dregges of Gods wrath, which had first setled in it; as bad humors, when they settle in any part, plant (as it were) a new nature in the same, and turne all nutriment into their substance.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Noahs and Deucalions Floud, with other Miscellane obseruations.
div.p:
1 NOt any sonne so like his naturall father, as Deucalions Floud is like Noahs. Euery Schoole-boy, from the similitude of their substance, at the first sight can discerne the one to be the bastard brood of the other; albeit Ouid, from whom wee haue the picture of the one, hath left out, and added, diuerse circumstances at his pleasure; which assures me, that he had neuer read the sacred Storie (as some thinke he did) but tooke vp the confused tradition of it, which had passed through many hands before his time: For other Poets which had come toPlut. lib. Vira animantium plu • radij habeant, terrestriane an aquatica. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Plutarchs reading, though not to ours, make mention of Deucalions Arke, his Doues returning to him againe before the waters fall, his prognostication of the waters decrease, by her perpetuall absence at her last setting out. This tradition was so commonly receiued in Greece, that some Etymologists thinke the famous hill Pernassus did take its name from the Arkes aboade vpon it, as if it had first been
called Larnassus.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which word Plutarch vseth in that place. These are sure testimonies that such a floud had beene: but that in Deucalions time any such had beene, or that the Arke did stay in Greece, hath no shew of truth; Saint Augustine hath shewed the contrarie De ciuit. Dei, Lib. 18. cap. 10.

2 If Trogus Pompeius Works had come entire into our hands, or had they light vpon a more skilfull and sincere Anatomist than Iustin, we should haue found more euident prints of the storie of Noahs Floud, in that controuersie, betweene the Scythians and Egyptians; whether were the most auncient people? As Iustin relates it, Lib. 2. thus it was.

3 The Egyptians thought the heauens ouer them had beene in loue with their soyle, and that from the conjunction of the ones mildnesse with the others fertilitie, the first people of the world had beene brought forth in Egypt. The Scythians alledged, it was most probable, that their countrey was first inhabited, because if fire had shut vp the wombe of their mother earth, this element did forsake theirs first, as being the coldest countrey: or if water had couered the face of nature, and made it vnapt for conception by too much moisture, this veile was first put off in Scythia, as being the highest part of the inhabited land. Vnto these reasons of the Scythians the Egyptians yeelded, as Iustin reports. Both of them erred in the manner of mans Propagation; both againe held a generall truth, in thinking mankind had some late Propagation, and that Kingdomes had not beene so frequented with people in former generations, as now they were. The Scythians agreed herein with Scripture, That the higher parts of the World, which they inhabited, or parts neere vnto them, were first dried vp from the waters; for in the mountaines of Armenia the Arke stayed, and Noah went first on land in that countrey. The storie of whose preseruation in this Deluge, and the propagation of mankind from him, and his children, not being expressely recorded to the Scythians, they imagine that men had growne like Mushromes after raine, because they had beene so few, and now were come vnto such great multitudes. Nor did Noah onely goe first on land in Armenia, but his posteritie had their habitation in the mountainous Countries, vntill their multitude caused them to seeke more roome; as we may gather Gen. 11: vers. 1. & 2. Then the whole earth was of one Language, and one
Speech; and as they went from the East (that is,Tres vero Noae filij Semas, Iaphetus, & Chamas cen • ū annis ante diluvium nati, pr • mi relictis montibus planic • ē habitare coeperunt, & aliis recenti etiā tum cladis memoria pauid • s nec au • d • ntib{us} a cc siore loco descendere idem faciendi autores & exemptum fuc • e. Joseph. l •• . 5. Ant. q. cap. 5. from Armenia) they found a Plaine in the Land of Shinar, and there they abode. Some broken traditions of this Truth might cause the auncient Scythians to stand vpon their pantofles, and plead prioritie of nature from superioritie of place. And this conceit of antiquitie being propagated to posteritie, they seeke to fortifie their title to it (called in question) by such reasons as were alledged before. A • d euen in these their reasons, though false in particular, there appeares a certaine generall glimpse of the diuine Truth: For in that they take it as graunted; that either fire or water had stopped the course of nature, this is an infallible argument, that they had heard of the dominion allotted by fate to those two elements ouer other bodies; albeit they did not rightly apprehend the manner of the worlds destruction by them, nor whethers course was first passed. This tradition of the Worlds destruction by fire and water, and the distinction of their courses (though not so plainely reuealed in the old Testament) had come more distinctly to Ouids hand; who bringeth in Iupiter, Met. 1.1.
• ab. 9. Iom{que} erat in totas sparsurus fulmina terras sed timuit ne sorte sacer tot ab ignibus aether concip • ret flammas totūsque ardesceret axis. resoluing to plague the old World rather by water than fire, because it was to haue a fatall dissolution by fire:
Esse quoque in fatis reminiscitur affore tempus
Quo mare, quo tellus, correptaque regia coeli
Ardeat, & mundi, moles operosa laboret;
He cals to mind the day would come (for Fates had set the same)
When sea and land, heauens, elements, and all this mundane Frame
Should sweat with heat, and melt as wax before the fearefull flame.

4 The Egyptians likewise had many reasons why they might justly thinke themselues a very auncient people, and these not dissonant vnto Scripture; which witnesseth Egypt to haue beene a mightie Kingdome, euery way better replenished than any other Countrey that we can read of in times so auncient; first possest by Mizraim, the sonne of Cham, by whose name it is continually called by all the sacred Writers, as well the Prophets and late Historiographers, as by Moses; and in the Easterne Languages beares that name vntill this day, asCom. in Gen. cap 10. v 6. Vid. & Iosephū, lib. 1. Antiq c. 7.
Mercerus tels vs. This Mizraim also did propagate sundrie particular Nations in short time, as wee finde registred Gen. 10. vers. 13, 14. All which
might make for the Egyptians conceit of their antiquitie. And albeit the old Canaanites were as auncient and populous a Nation (though not so vnited in a Kingdome) as the Egyptians; yet, before these altercations arose, or (at least) before any other people tooke notice of them, their posteritie was rooted out by the Israelites, who though they came in the others place, yet came not into competition with the Egyptians for antiquitie in the judgement of any Heathen Writer; because the Israelit • s were no people, till the time that Egypt was one of the mightiest Nations vpon earth; and the Heathen being ignorant (as making little reckoning of their originall) tooke them for a Colonie of the Egyptians, as appeares by Strabo,
Lib. 16. who in recompence of this his error hath elsewhere acquainted vs, with another experiment, which may confirme the antiquitie of Moses storie concerning Sems posteritie.

Moses tels vs Gen. 10. vers. 22. that Aram, sonne to Shem, and brother to Ashur, had Vz, and Chul, and Mash vnto his sonnes. The Aramites no question had their name and propagation from Aram. Some thinke the Arabians, or other Countries about Idumaea, or both, had their originall from Vz: Others, that the Massiani in Arabia were so called of Mash: Iosephus, that the Armenians were the progenie of Chul. Consonant to all these opinions isSed Scripturam m • tare cum sit ve • ella, non e • t necesse; culpanda potias nominis mutatio quae frequen • est & vsi • ata omnibus gentib • s; & videntur quid im
•• terarum mutationibus •• m • raru • eam essi •• re. Optimè omnium existimo Possidoni • m, hic quo{que} à genti • m cognatione & communitate interpretationem vocum ducere. Nam Armeniorum, Syrorum, & Arabum, multū cognationis pr • e se ferunt nationes, sermone, vita, corporum forma, maximè vb • degunt in vi • i • ia. Id{que} ostendit Mesopotamia ex tribus his constata populis: Maximè enim in his simi •• tudo est ill istri • : quod si quà est varietas pro eo at{que} aliae partes alijs magis ad septentrionē, aut merid • e vergunt, •• t •• medio sunt sitae: nihilominus tamen communis affectio obtinet. Assyrij quoque Ariani & Armenij nter se at{que} isterum s • nt a ••• miles. Est que colligendum harum gentiū nomina esse affinia: Qui enim à nobis Syri, ij ab ipsis Syris Ar • m • i d • c •• tur, bisque cou •• n • unt Armenij & Arabes, & Erembi, Strab. l. 1. This opinion of Strabo confirmes
•• se • hus obseruation concerning the changing of nations names, lib. 1. Antiq. c. 6. Porro gentium quaedam adhuc seruant deriuatam à suis co • ditoribus appellationē, quaedā etiā muta • erunt, nonnullae in familiarem acco •• : & notiorem vo • em sunt verse, Graecis potissimum talis nomenclaturae autoribus. Hi enim posterioribus saeculis •• ter • m lo ••• um • loriam sibi vsurpanerunt, gentes nominibus sibi notis insigninut, dumque tanquam ad suum ius •• t •• erent, ••• es ••• unc prop • io • in illas i •• chunt. Strabo his obseruation of these people; whom the Grecians call Syrians, the Syrians themselues call Aramaeans; and his collection is, That the Armenians, and the Erembi (that is, the auncient Arabians) haue taken their denomination from the same name, a little varied (as the custome is) by continuance of time, and varietie of Dialect. That these three Nations did all proceed from one stocke, he gathers from the similitudes and perfect resemblances of their nature, customes, and manner of life.

5. But for the first habitation or antiquitie of Armenia or Scythia it skils not much. That mankind had a new propagation about the time assigned by Moses of the vniuersall Floud, and that the Nations were propagated from those Regions, which Moses tels vs were allotted to the sonnes of Noah, and inhabited by his nephewes, is apparant, from the suddaine encrease of Arts and Sciences: Which were in a good measure perfect in those Countries, in times as ancient as any prophane Historie can point vnto; yet seated onely in a narrow roome, whence they were deriued, as from a Centre, to more remote parts of the world. The ripenesse of Literature, ciuile discipline, and inuentions, amongst the Assyrians, Chaldaeans, and Egyptians, before the like did so much as bud forth in Greece, Italie, or other Countries, farre distant from the former, doth argue, that these were the stocke, and others but slippes or branches transplanted thence. Againe, the State and Pompe of these Easterne Countries, before Greece, or Italie, or any other Westerne People, did grow into the fashion of a Kingdome or ciuile Nation, demonstrates vnto vs, That the inhabitants of those places were the heires of the world, who had the Court, Kingdome, and Metropolis amongst them, and other Nations but as Colonies of men of meaner sort, not so neere allied vnto the first borne; or (as it were) of a yonger house, and farre ruder education. And it is most likely, or rather euident, that the sonnes of Iaphet did first inhabite Scythia, or the Northerne parts of Asia minor, and other parts neere adjoyning, before they came into Greece, or other Countries of Europe. And these were the sonnes of Noahs meanest posteritie, vntill the fulnesse of Sem and Chams iniquitie were accomplished. For as Gods promise vnto Abraham was not accomplished in his Person, but in his Posteritie, many generations after his death; so neither did his curse vpon Cham take place, till the same time. The execution of Gods curse vpon the one, was the collation of his blessing vpon the other: but the enlarging of Iaphets race came long after both. Thus the Egyptians were the first great Princes; the Assyrians, Medes, and Persians the next; the Grecians and Romanes after them; and in later times the race of Ismael hath beene the mightie People: for of him the Saracens lineally descend, and the Turkes, by adoption heires of the same promise. So truly doth the Scripture
tell vs the truth of all antiquitie,Vid. Fagium in cap. 16 Genes. & Paraeum, ibid. and the true causes of Nations encrease; but of this elsewhere. To conclude this storie of Noah.

6 The former argument drawen from the suddaine increase and propagation of men, the scarcitie of Artes, ciuil discipline and inuentions, with other experiments better knowne to them than vs, enforced certaine of the ancient Philosophers to hold a perpetuall vicissitude, some of generall, some of particular deluges, whereby the workes of antiquitie, once come to perfection, had bin, & continually should be defaced; either generally throughout the world, or in sundrie countries according to the extent of the inundation. This opinion might seeme more safe, because not easie to be disproued in that old world, in which the wisest liuing (besides the people of God) had no distinct knowledge of any thing, that had happened an hundred yeere before his owne birth; much lesse what mutations should follow after his death: but vnto vs their Prognostication is like vnto some late Prophecies of doomes-day, confuted by a world of witnesses, euen by the continuance of euery thing after that time, which, by their prophecies, should haue imposed a fatall end to all things. We may truely vse the mockers wordes of these mockers of truth; since the olde Philosophers dyed, all things continue alike, seede-time and haruest haue beene still distinct, nor hath there beene any floud to destroy either the whole earth, or any entire nation thereof. For assurance of which promise, the Almightie hath set his bow in the cloude: whose naturall causes, though the Philosophers can in some sort assigne, and shew the manner how diuersities of coarise in it; yet the ancient Poets see more, than either they themselues haue left exprest, or later Philosophers sought to conceiue, when they faigned Iris to bee Thaumantis filia, the daughter, or (as wee of this age would say) the mother of wonderment, the messenger of the great God Iupiter and his Goddesse Iuno. The occasions of this fiction (had they bin well acquainted with them) might haue informed Philosophers, that the raine-bow had some better vse, than a bare speculation how it was made; some finall, besides the materiall and efficient cause, vnto whose search the admirable forme or composition of it did incite men naturally. And the auncient Philosophers (who were for the most part
Poets, and endued with more liuely notions of the first, and supreme cause of all things) did vsually assigne a finall cause, (commonly) supernaturall, of such effects as proceeded from efficient and materiall naturall causes.Arist. 2. Poster. As the Pythagoraeans thought the thunder (whose matter, forme, and efficient they well knew) was made to terrifie such as were in hell; not erring in the generall, that it had some such like vse, though mistaken in the particulars, whom it was made to terrifie. Naturall Philosophie giues vs the materiall and sensible efficient causes, the Scripture onely the true and supernaturall end, which leades vs to the immortall, inuisible, and principall efficient cause of all naturall effects, euen of Nature it selfe. And Aristotle acknowledgeth the motions or dispositions of the matter to depend vpon the end or finall cause: albeit he giues no finall cause at all of maine principall, much lesse the supreme or principall finall cause of all naturall effects, but confounds the forme with the end, against his owne principles, and contrarie to the analogie betweene Nature and Art, which is the ground of all his Discourse, about the matter, forme, and efficient. For the artificiall forme is not the end of the Artists worke, but rather incites the spectator to view and admire his skill, from which his gaine or fame may redound. And these (one, or both) are the principall end of all his labours: so is the glorie of the first, and supreme efficient cause, the principall and vtmost end of all the workes of Nature; and Nature it selfe (if I may so speake) the art or skill of the first and supernaturall cause. But as Aristotles Philosophie is imperfect, because it leades vs not, either vnto the first cause, or last end of all things; so is it fully sufficient to confute such Diuines, as thinke there were Rainebowes before the Floud. Which opinion hath no pretence of Scripture to enforce it: and grounds in Nature it can haue none, vnlesse they will auouch this euident vntruth, That euerie disposition of the Aire, or euerie Cloud, is fitly disposed to bring forth the Raine-bow. And if other naturall causes, with their motions and dispositions, depend vpon the finall; such as acknowledge the truth of Scripture haue no reason to thinke, that eyther the Clouds or Aire had that peculiar disposition which is required vnto the production of the Raine-bow, before the Floud,
when this wonderfull effect could haue no such vse or end, as it hath had euer since. Gen. 9. v. 12, 13, 14. For it was ordained, as the Scripture tels vs, to be a signe or witnesse of Gods couenant with the new world, a messenger to secure mankinde from destruction by deluges. Now if it had appeared before; the sight of it, after the floud, could haue beene but a silly comfort to Noahs timorous posteritie; whose mistrust, least the like inundation should happen againe, was greater, than could be taken away by any ordinarie or vsuall signe, if we may beleeue suchIoseph. hist. Noae. testimonies of antiquitie, as we haue no reason to suspect. I omit the discussion ofVid. Ammian. Marcell. lib. 20. Et quoniā indiciū est per mutationis aurae (vt dixim{us}) à sudo aëre nubiū concitans globos, aut contrà ex concreto immutans in serenam laetitiam coelum: ideo apud poëtas legim{us} saepe Irim de coelo mitti, cū praesentiū rerum fit stat{us} mutatio. their opinion, who thinke the Raine-bow doth naturally argue such a temper of the aire, as is vnapt for the present to conceiue any excessiue moisture, either from these reasons in nature, then well knowne, or from the tenour of Gods forementioned couenant, communicated to the ancient Heathen people by Traditions, doth Iupiter in Homer make Iris the messenger of his peremptorie command vnto Neptune, to desist from aiding the Graecians;

From Ioue I come a messenger, to him that Neptune hight,
His pleasure is, that thou henceforth ne come in field or fight:
But hence to Heauen, or to wide Sea addresse thy speedie flight.

7 The true mythologie of which fiction I should, from the circumstance of the Storie, coniecture to be this. The swelling of waters and aboundance of moisture, did aduantage the Graecians, and annoy the Troians, for whom faire weather was best, as hauing greatest vse at that time of seruice by Horse. For this reason is Neptune by Iris commanded to get him into the Sea; which is as much as to say, the ouer-flow of waters and abundance of moisture was now to bee asswaged; and Apollo on the other side sent to encourage Hector, and his Troians; The meaning is, that Iupiter would now haue faire and drie weather.

Goe to, prepare the troupes of horse (for they must do the deed)
And charge thine enemies at their ships, but charge thē with all speed;
Meane time I'le goe before, and smooth the way you follow must,
I'le turne the Graecian Chiefetaines backe, or lay them in the dust.

div.p: Such mysteries of Nature are oft enwrapt in Poeticall fictions, though many of them not so easie to be discerned in such distance of time: this kind of Diuinitie being now worne out of date. But we that haue this supernaturall Commentarie vpon the workes of nature, may see in the mixt colours of the Rain-bow, more cleerly than in any propheticall vision, the old worlds destruction by water: and this presents future consumption by fire, whose brightnes is praedominant in the waterish humour. The resolution of the cloude, by the heate of Sunne-beams reflected vpon it, praefigures vnto vs the melting of the Elements with fire, 2. Peter chapter 3. verse 12.

8 Scarce any thing in the frame of Nature, no not the vntruths of poeticall fables, or lying stories, but beare witnes of the Diuine truth reuealed in Scriptures; so men would not be praeposterous in their obseruations, like Iulian the Apostate: who sought to discredit the sacred storie of • he tower of Babel, by the Poets fictions of the giants warre against heauen; as if there had beene no more probabilitie in the one than in the other. If he could haue shewed vs any Poeme of the same subiect, more auncient than that storie, he might haue had some peece of an excuse for his impietie; some pretence for accusing the Scripture of poeticall imitation: but if the Poets haue beene imitators of Moses, or other Writers of this storie, the blame must lie vpon them, either for wilfull corrupting of the truth, or (which is most likely) for taking the hyperbolicall phrase of Scriptures in a strict sense; as if they had meant to builde a Tower vp to heauen indeede, whenas the Phrase importeth no other intendement in them, than only to build an exceeding high Tower, which might secure them from inundation
(as some thinke;) or else endure as a monument of their fame, or a refuge whereunto they might resott, and continue their combination.

9 But the later Graecians, hauing their consciences conuict with the euidence, not their affections conquered with the loue of truth, were driuen into more desperate impudence, to say that our Sauiour Christ had taken those Diuine Sentences, which they could not but admire, out of their diuine Plato; whereas Plato himselfe (as Saint Ambrose, August. lib. 2. de Doctrina Christ. and Saint Augustine, out of testimonies not now producible, gather) had his best Diuinitie from such as wrote of Christ, although the medley of their Diuinitie and his Philosophie, is but like the mingling of Iordans sweete streames with the salt Sea. That Plato had eyther read, or beene instructed by such as had read the Bookes of Moses, hee will easily beleeue, that shall reade that speech of Aristophanes in the Dialogue of Loue or Banquet-discourse. In the beginning (saieth hee) there were three sortes or sexes of men, Plato in Co • uiu. not these two onely which now are extant, male, and female, but a third common nature composed of these, whose name now onelie remayneth, without anie such reall Nature, as the word Androgyni importes.

10 This opinion (doubtlesse) was conceiued from a misconceit of Moses his meaning, in making diuerse mention of our first parents creation. Genesis 2. He makes first mention of Adams creation, then of Euahs, distinct from it. But Genesis chap. 2. verse 27. Genesis chap. 5. verse 1. and 2. He seemeth to relate both their Creations so ioyntly and briefely, that a man, not acquainted with the Hebrew Dialect, nor the mysteries of Matrimonie represented in that Storie, might thinke, that neyther distinct man or woman had beene there created, but Androgyni. Furthermore God said, Let vs make man in our likenesse according to our Image, and let them rule ouer the fish of the Sea, and ouer the foule of the Heauen, and ouer the beastes, and ouer all the Earth, and ouer euerie thing that creepeth or mooueth on the earth. Thus GOD created man in his Image, in the Image of GOD created hee him; hee created them male and female. And a secular Artist that affecteth artificiall, beeing ignorant of Moses his methode, might think that these were not repetitions of the same, but distinct stories of diuerse creations. From the like ignorance of the Graecians
in the Easterne tongues, or some default in the written copies which they followed, did the riuer Perath enlarge its name by translation from one tongue to an other, as it doth its streames by passing from place to place. For if wee ioyne the Hebrewes Pronoune or Article with the Nowne, whereby this Riuer is named in Scripture, the compound is onely different in termination from the same riuers name in Grecke. Moses Genesis chap. 2. hauing mentioned three riuers of the Garden, addeth, And there was a fourth which is Perath [Which according vnto the Greeke termination is Euphrates, not Euphrathes, as of the Hebrew Beth is the Greeke Beta, not Betha. Hu Perath] or rather [Hu prath] which words conioyned are Huphrath. All these argue, that the sacred Antiquitie of Iewrie was, vnto other Nations, as Nilus to Aegypt, the maine streame or principall riuer, whence they drew most of their inuentions, either of necessitie or delight; albeit these Cuts or petty streames thence deriued, did quite alter their natiue qualitie in the conueyances, receiuing infection from the soyle through which they ranne, or putrifying in the cisterns wherein they setled.

11 For confirmation of all, we may adde this. The Greeke alphabet hath been taken from the Hebrew, as is euident to such as will compare both. The Graecians themselues acknowledge, that they had their very letters from the Phoenicians, who were next neighbors to Iudaea.

12 To re-collect the summe of all that hath bin said throughout this Discourse. As both the first Elements, and sundrie Primitiue wordes of the Greeke and Hebrew, scarce differ so much one from an other, as three from foure, or one digite number from the next vnto it, and yet after many deflections from the first rootes or themes of both, and new frames of wordes by artificiall composition, (a thing as naturall to the Greekes as spreading braunches to the Vine) the Languages themselues, or whole product of both elements, are much different: so are the principall or first heads of the Graecians iuuētions, deriued for the most part from the Hebrews; although by successiue artificiall imitation their varietie grow greater, and their resemblance of diuine truth the lesse. So likewise were Logicall conceits first clothed, like Natures children, in termes not much abhorrent from common and ciuil vse; but after diuers reflections of Artists imaginations, and endlesse reu • lution of conceipt vpon conceipt, the Logicians
dialect is become a distinct language from al others; so that a man may as well speake Greeke vnto a meere Latinist, as Logicke-Latine to a meere Humanitian. Thus much of the heathens digression from the historicall truth of Scriptures. It remaines that we compare the morall vse, and issue of their inuentions with the end, scope, and fruit of these Diuine writings.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of sacred Writers sobrietie and discretion, in relating true miracles; compared especially with later heathens vanitie, in coyning fruitlesse wonders.
div.p:
1 ALbeit the superstition of later Gentiles were most opposite to the most true, most ancient religion of the Israelites: yet if we trace the most ciuill sort of them backwards in their sinister waies, we shal find it, & the right path of the Israelites, like the two opposite branches of Pythagoras his letter iumping as it were in one truncke. Sundry fragments of Orpheus, Linus, Pythagoras, yea of Euripedes, much later than the former, with many sayings of other auncient Poets and Philosophers, doe witnesse that their Authors had many notions of good and euill, not much dissonant from the morall law of God, fully consonant (for their generall truth) vnto the good sentences of Iobs friends: albeit euen these were mingled with many particular errours of the Diuine Prouidence. Much more did the most of the heathen, since the diuision of the Iewes from other people, by their sacred Lawes, goe much euery day more than other awry from those good rules of life, which had beene naturally ingrafted, both in the Iewes and Gentiles hearts. These excellent sayings of the auncient heathen, and their posterities credulitie to beleeue all reports of their Gods, demonstrate that they had obserued many wonderfull Experiments, and euident Documents of a Diuine prouidence; and communicate the same vnto posterity, both in plaine literall morall Discourses and allegorical or mysticall fictiōs. In thus doing, perhaps not intending so much, that their successours should expect the same euents, or course of
things to continue for euer: as that they should learn to reuerence these sacred powers, to glorifie them as diuine, who could alwaies alike effect what they intended, though by meanes most contrary. But vnto the heathen, destitute of Gods written word, the best obseruations of their auncestours became quickely like a Kalendar out of date; they could not discerne the workes of God, nor his inward secret calling, whē once the course of his proceedings, or manner of his speaking to them changed.Plut. de defect • Oraculorum. Thus Planetiades in Plutarch ascribes the defect of oracles vnto the carelesnesse or malignacie of the Gods as if, these once taken away, they had no other meanes left for procuring the welfare of mankinde. But in Iewry the true doctrine of the Diuine power, or Prouidence, was well knowne. For God by Moses had both giuen them his written Oracles as an absolute Ephemerides of all things that had bin since the first moment of Time, by whose rules they were to discerne all other succeeding praedictions; and also continually raised them vp Prophets, like yearely Astronomers, to continue the Ephemerides, which Moses had made for the direction of mans life, and to instruct them as it were in a monthly Kalendar of euerie particular alteration or change, vnto which that great Law-giuer in his generall praedictions could not discend. From this reason it is, that the Pen-men of the sacred story doe not alwayes relate the same, or like euents, but assigne diuers maners of his working and speaking to seuerall ages. Some afford vs liuely monuments of his power; others paterns of his wisedom; some exāples of his iustice; others, of his mercie: yet al of them continually acknowledge him to be the only author of their good, albeit the maner of procuring it be diuers, yea contrary. Thus Ezra, Nehemiah, and other godlie men of that time, ascribe their redemption from Babylonish captiuitie, as immediatly to the wonderfull working of their God, as their fore-elders did their deliuerance from Aegyptian thraldom: although no such miracle of his power were seen in the later. The former deliuerāce had confirmd his omnipotent abilitie of doing what he would, the later, his infinite wisedome in doing what hee could, by what meanes he would: and it was his good pleasure to be glorified in sundry ages, by diuers manifestations of his seuerall attributes.

2 But the heathen wanting his word for their direction, after
they had once begun, knew not how to make an end. If God cease to shew his miracles in any one kind, which they had heard of before, eyther they sought to continue them by faigning the like, (more readie to play vpon former reports, than to obserue the course of Gods proceedings in their owne times:) or else from the varietie of wonderfull euents, whose cause they knew not, for they imagine a pluralitie of Gods. Others, from these mens superstition, and curiositie, were prone to suspect the truth of what had beene; after once such sensible euents, or experiments begunne to cease. This gaue the first occasion vnto Atheisme; which hath most abounded since the propagation of the Gospel, whose glorie hath quite extinguished those pettie lights, which purblinde Heathen onely vsed for their direction, beeing most conspicuous to the flesh or sense, as the Gospel is to the Spirite. For as dimme or weake sights can make some shift with star-light or candles, that shine a farre off, but are quite put out by looking vpon the bright Sunne: So hath the brightnesse of Christs glorie reuealed, put out the eies of corrupted nature, in such as loued darkenesse more than light, and would not seeke for any remedie at his hands, which giueth sight to the blind. Yet might this their disease be sooner cured, if they would compare other Countries vanitie in faigning wonders without occasion, with this religious sobriety of the later writers of the Bible, or other godly men, who haue written of Iews affairs; not one of them since Ezekiahs time relating such wonders, as their fathers had told thē. This sobrietie in them euidently shews, that the former miracles were no fictiōs of humane fancie: otherwise the Iews, liuing betweene Ezekiahs and Christs time, would haue bin copious in their inuentions of the like, as we see by experiēce, that the learned Iews since our Sauiors time haue bin most ridiculously apish in coining, & the illiterate as grosse in beleeuing most absurd and filthy fables. That this people, during the whole time of the second temple, added no bookes to the Canon of the Bible, confirms their forefathers care, of admitting none in former times, but vpon euident & sure experiments of their diuine authority. Again, it was most miraculous, that this people which had Prophets, and sacred Writers in euery age, before the Babylonish captiuity, should after their redemptiō thence lie so quiet, that not the most learned amōg them did euer
challenge the name of Prophets; though they had men of diuine spirits, and excellent obseruation in heauenly matters, as appeares by the Author of Ecclesiasticus, the booke of Wisedome, and other books of good vse amongst all religious men, though not canonicall amongst the Iews themselues. Answerable to this sobrietie of the learned was the disposition of the vnlearned among this people; which during the former period of time, wherin they wanted prophets, were generally most auerse from al idolatry, whereunto they were most prone, while Prophecies were most plentifull amongst them; & yet continued stil as far from Atheisme, as Idolatrie. The reason of all which I haue giuen before. God had inioyned a general silence throughout this land, that all might hearken more attentiuely vnto the Criers voice, appointed to prepare the wayes of the Lord: after whose message once fully accomplished, as it had beene after the ringing of a market-bell, euerie Mounte-banke throughout their coasts, sets to sale the dreames and fancies of his owne braine, for diuine prophecies.

3 Lastly, the Heathen in their most sacred traditions, and matters of greatest consequence, adde circumstances according to the occurrents of their owne Times, which suite no better with the substance, or essence of their auncestors obseruations, than a Pigmeies slipper with a Gyants foote. How shamefully doeth the wanton Poet faigne his Gods to long after such matters, as hee himselfe did most delight in? The best end and vse of his greatest Gods apparitions are oft times to accomplish beastly lust; Diuine truths are vsually transformed into the poets priuat affection. Ouids description of Iupiters comming to Semele, Aethera conscendit vultum{que} sequentia traxit nubila, quei • nimbis immista{que} fulgura 〈◊〉
•• tis addidit, & tonitrus & ineu • tabile fulmen libr. Metam. 2.
