And behold, the Lord went by and a mighty strong wind rent the mountaines & brake the rock before the Lord, and after the wind an earthquake, & after the earthquake fire. Eliah vpon the mount; and therefore not altogether vnbeseeming the Maiestie of the great king, if al circumstances were answerable to the substance of the description: but it is brought to an absurd, profane, & foolish purpose. So likewiseDet pignus amoris si modo verus is est quātus{que} & qualis ab alta lunone excipitur, tantus talis{que} rogato Det tibi complexus sua{que} ante insignia sumat. Oui. Ibi. Semeles petition vnto Iupiter, is butEx 33, 12, 13, & 18. Then Moses said vnto the Lord; See, thou saiest vnto me, Leade this people forth, & thou hast not shewd me whom thou wilt send with me: Thou hast said moreouer, I know thee by name, and thou hast also found grace in my sight: Now therfore I pray thee, if I haue found fauour in thy sight, shew mee now the way that I may know thee, and that I may find grace in thy sight. Againe he said, I beseech thee shew me thy glorie. Moses his request vnto God, effeminate and transformed in sundry circumstances to the Poets humor. Moses Ex. 33.18. desired to see the
glorie of the Lord: and the Lord answered him, Thou canst not see my Face: for there shall no man see my Face, and liue. Yet willing to confirme this his seruants faith, he condiscends thus far to his suite:Exod. 33. verse 20, 21, 22, 24. Whilst my glory passeth by I will put thee in a clift of the rocke & will couer thee with mine hand whilest I passe by, and thou shalt see my back-parts, but my face shal not be seene. Either from some mistaking of this place, or from experience of others sodain death, vpon such apparition of the Diuine maiestie, as Moses and Elias by peculiar dispensation had escaped, did that tradition spring which Manoah conceited so deeply, Iudg. 13.22. And Manoah said vnto his wife; we shall surely die, because we haue seene God; as Gedeon had done likewise, Iudg. 6.22. Alas my Lord God, for because I haue seene the Angell of the Lord face to face,
Hence was that of Homer lib. 1. Odiss. — 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Corpus mortale tumultus non tulit aethereos donis{que} iugalibus arsit. I shall die. This tradition had come to Ouids hands, who makes that maiestie, which hee had described to be so great, so improuident withall, as to grant her foolish request, on whom he doted, to her vtter ruine; and so impotent, that he could not protect her, albeit he stroue to couer her with his hand: and so finally neither the God could inioy his loue, nor his best beloued her life. Such are the consequences of later heathens greatest miracles; but in the sacred story, wherin are specified euents as strāge as Poets relate any, such causes are assigned of them, as are more weighty, and the manner of their relation more graue and serious than the euents are rare; if God at any time appeare, either in vision by night, or corporall shape by day, it is for some extraordinarie purpose. All the miracles or wonders wrought in Israel, were to bring that people vnto the knowledge of the true God, to relie continually vpon his prouidence; A matter more hard, if we consider the frailtie of our owne flesh, than the effecting of any miracles, reported to haue been wrought for the Iewes. Why his wonderfull workes should be most frequent amongst this people, this reason is as plaine as probable from the end. This people was placed as a light vnto all the nations of the world besides: they inioyed extraordinarie prosperitie, that others might be allured to reuerence them, and taste the goodnes of their God: their vnusuall iudgements and strange kind of afflictions were as so many proclamations vnto the world, to beware of like rebellion: seeing all the world was set on wickednesse, and God had appoynted a day, wherein he would iudge the world in righteousnesse, necessary it
was, to set out a paterne of his mercie and iustice in some people; and without wrong to any other, it was his especial fauor, to make choice of Abrahams seed for this purpose, on whom hee showred his mercies in greatest abundance, whilest they were obedient and faithfull in the workes of Abraham; but when they rebelled,
Isa. 63. v. 10. and vexed his holie spirit, then he turned to be their enemie, and he fought against them, making them continuall examples of his vnpartiall iudgements, as shal appeare in the next Section.

div.head: The third Section of the second generall part Lib. 1.
Containing experiments drawne from the reuolution of States, or Gods publique iudgements, but especially of the estate of the Iewes from time to time.
div.p: OF all externall experimentes, the most firme and solide, for assuring the trueth of these diuine oracles vnto our soules, are gathered from the reuolution of states, or Gods iudgements vpon seuerall lands and people. In the obseruation of which, the continuall storie of the Iewish nation doth best direct vs. The intercourse of their particular afflictions, before our Sauiours time; the maner of their recouerie from them, as from so many spices of some grieuous disease growing vpon them; the epidemicall disease, which through euery generation haunts theirs, since they desired our Sauiours bloud to bee vpon them and their children: are so many probata, or tried experiments, that these coelestial precepts containe the onely method of preseruing the publique or priuate welfare of mankind whose obseruations may cure, whose neglect will breed, all the miserie that can befall any people. And this methode I would wish euery Christian to follow; First diligently to consider the state of the Iewes from time to time; for it euidently confutes the Athiest, and confirmes the truth of the old Testament: and the truth of it established, doth most euidently confute the Iewe, and witnesse the truth of the Gospell vnto vs, as shall be proued (God willing) in due place.

div.head: CHAP. I.
Of the state of these Iewes in generall, before our Sauiours time, with Tullies obiection against them.
div.p: Enimuero tanta fuit autoritas Alphonsi, vt etiam victus conditiones dixerit, et victo res victi metu cesserint, quasi victoriam casu non virtute se consecutos arbitrati. Anton. Panormitanus l. 4. de dictis & fact. Alphonsi. August. (ex Seneca) lib. 6. de ciuitat. Dei cap. 11. 1 IT is storied of Alphonsus the great, that being sometime prisoner to his enemies, he did so carie himselfe amongst them, and prescribe them such conditions for his release, as might argue, that they had ouercome him onely by chance. This was not so strange in a Prince, so famous and venerable for the integritie of his whole life, and so amiable in his cariage towards his enemies; a man, as it were, made to ouercome and quell all the spiteful malice, or base intendments, that could be deuised against him, by his heroicall open heart, and bountifull hand towards all, and indefatigable clemencie euen towards such, as sought to outuie it by ingratitude, and iust prouocation of his heauiest displeasure: But that the Iewes, a people whom others praeiudiciall conceipt of their peeuish selfe-conceited singularitie, (raised from their strict obseruation of lawes contrarie to the customs of other people) had made for the most part odious, ere knowne vnto the world, should victi victorib{us} legem dare, being captiues, giue Lawes vnto their Conquerours, euen vnto such as sought to triumph in their disgrace, as birds ouer an owle caught in a snare; did iustly minister occasion of wonderment to sundrie Heathen, and might haue taught the proudest & mightiest of their enemies that they had ouercome them onely by permission or chaunce, or (if these words seeme vnfit) for want of that good hap and fauour in their battels, which they after their ouerthrowes finding, became by it in a sort, conquerours of their enemies, euen whilst they were detained in captiuitie.

2 The full height and amplitude of those fortunes, whereof this people was only capable, would bring the natural man, could he fully comprehend them, within perfect ken of that incomprehensible omnipotent power, which was onely able to effect them. But because these cannot be taken by any ethnique obseruations, which reach not neere those ancient times, wherein their extraordinarie successe was most conspicuous; wee must gather them
from the maner of their states declining, since it hath bin knowne to ethnique or other writers, not liable to suspition of partialitie on their behalfe. God in his prouidence (as Moses prophecies, compared with later, and the succession of their histories, testifie) had ordained, as the fulnesse of time and their iniquitie drew near, his fauours towards them should decrease by such an vniforme proportion, that their contraction in later might notifie their excessiue greatnesse in former times. The manner of their deliuerance from the Babylonish captiuitie (to such as rightly obserue the diuerse maner of Gods proceeding in different ages before specified) will giue the true estimate of wonders wrought for their forefathers: and Cyrus fauour towards them will appeare most credible, from the representation of like extraordinarie kindnesse shewed them in Aegypt by Ptolomaeus Philadelphus; who, though their supreme Lord by right of conquest, set at libertie a hundred thousand of their bodies, captiuated by his father, to submit himselfe vnto their lawes, which he (directed by the Diuine prouidence) caused to be translated into the most knowne tongue then on earth, through which the nation (as it were through a perspectiue glasse) might better discerne the new star of Iacob which was shortly to arise.

3 It is a point without the circumference of politique obseruation plainely arguing such a coelestiall prouidence, as can controll the purposes of greatest Princes, why Ierusalem so often ruinate, should still be repaired againe; or, the Temple continue in such beautie after it had bin so often fallen into the enemies hands; especially seeing the flourishing state of the one was apprehended by their Conquerours, as a great encouragement, and the fortification of the other, as a great opportunitie of this peoples rebellion; vpon which considerationEzra. 4. v. 17 1. Es dr. 2. v. 25. &c. Ios. l. 11. Antiq. cap. 3. Etsi Cambisem pro Artaxerxe habeat. Appianus de bellis Syriacis. Yet here is omitted the reedification by Hircanus in Iulius his time, their demolishing by Sossius. Iose. l. 14. Ant. cap. 16. & l. 15. c. 1. Reedified againe in Caius his time. Tacit. l. 5. Hist. Artaxerxes did inhibit the execution of Cyrus grant for the reedifying of Hierusalem. The Citie wals had beene razed since the time of the Babylonish captiuitie, (which was before any Heathen Historiographer of note,) first by Ptolomie the first; secondly by Pompey the great; and yet repaired before Vespasians time, who ouerthrew their strongest munitions, as Adrian afterwards did the same, once againe repaired.

4 The truth againe of that fauour which they found vnder the Aegyptians, (though otherwise knowne by vnpartiall writers)
is more than credible in it selfe, from the extraordinarie fauour which they found among the nations, about the time of their cōquest by Pompey. Tullie tels vs in his Oration pro Flacco, that their was gold transported out of Italie it selfe, and all the rest of the Romane Prouinces, for garnishing the Temple of Hierusalem. The prohibition of this practise in Asia, enacted by Flaccus Gouernour of that Prouince,Ios. de Bello Iudaico l. 1. c. 5. was afterwards laid to his charge, though the like had beene decreed by the Romane Senate in the time of Tullies Consulship. It was no little preiudice vnto his cause, that Pompey in the conquest of that citie, did think so reuerently of the Iewes religion & Temple, that, albeit he viewed the golden table, candlesticke, & other vessels of like mettal, with many costly ornaments, & two thousand talents of their sacred treasure: yet he did not diminish so much as one iot of it, nor spoile Ierusalems temple of any ornamēts, to beautifie the Temples of his Romane Gods. This abstinence of Pompey Tullie in the forecited place acknowledgeth, albeit (for bettering the cause he had in hand) vnwilling to confesse, that Pompey did abstain for any religious respect of the Iewes or their lawes: for after many shiftes, Cicero pro Flacco. Sua cuique ciuitati religio Laeli est, nostra nobis. Stantibus Ierosolimis, pacatis{que} Iudaeis, tamen istorum religio sacrerum à splendore huius imperij, graui • ate nominis nostri, maiorum institutis abb • rrebat. Nunc verò hoc magis, quod illa gens, quid de imimperio nostró sentiret, ostendit armis, quàm chara dijs immortalibus assetdocuit, quod est victa, quod clocat • , quod seruata? he takes this as the best argumēt to eleuate the Romanes conceipt of the Iewish religion; Whilst Ierusalem flourished & the Iewes were quiet, yet their sacred rites were altogether dissonāt vnto the splendor of the Romain Empire, the grauitie of that nation, & the institution of their Auncestors; much more (as he thought) should the Romains now make lesse account of that nation, which had giuen perfect proofe what good wil they had borne vnto the Romaines, by their late taking armes against them. And what good wil the immortal Gods did beare to them, their late fortunes did witnesse, in that they had beene vanquisht, made tributarie, and (as hee thought) were at the Romains disposition for their preseruation or destruction.

5 If these Iewes late subiection were any disparagement to their religion, much more might Pompeyes & Tullies ouerthrow discredit the Romaine Gods, which Pompeyes faction did reuerence more than Caesars; yea fortune it selfe, on whose fauorl • b. Epist. ad Attic. Epist 1. ad Octau. Tullie relied after he had fallen out with all the rest, could not be excused, if earthly calamitie were any iust presumption of impietie against heauen. But if Tullie would haue sought but the first fountaine of his countries wracke; want of reuerence to the Iewish Temple, and their
religion was cause of Pompeius and Crassus ouerthrow, and their ouerthrow the ruine of the Romaine state.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of Pompey his factions and other Romaines ill successe that had molested or wronged the Iewes.
div.p:
1 I Know the secular Politician can espie many ouer-sights in Pompeys proceeding against Caesar, The originall causes of Pompeys fortunes sudd • ine alteration. & assigne other causes of his disaster: but he that had gone into the temple of the Lord, with more reuerēce than Pompey did, might haue vnderstood that it was his vnhalowed progres into the most holy place, which had set an vntimely period to his greatnes growth. This was the main spring or head of all his other particular error • obserued by secular politicians. Hitherto he had maruailously prospered in al his waies, fortune had bin his guide, & felicitie his attēdant. Althogh his wisdome and experience would not suffer him to ouer-see any thing, that lay within the compasse of warlike skill: yet happie chance delighted to haue a finger in his proceedings, alwaies bringing somewhat to his aide, and furtherance, from beyond the haemisphaere of humane pollicie; so as the issue and product of all his enterprises were still discerned to bee greater, than could amount from the particular meanes forecast by him, or his Counsellers, for their atchieuement. Vide Ciceronem de lege Manilia, of his Affrican expedition: and of his piraticall warre. He had the helpe of winde, and weather, to prosecute his foes by Sea: the fauour of As in his conquest of Mithridate vid Flor de Gest. R • m. lib. 3 cap. 5 Nocturna ea diminutione fuit. etluna in partib. quippe quasi cōmilitans, cum a tergo hostilus, à facie Romanis se praebu • sser, Pontici per errorem longius cadentes umbras suas quasi hos • ium corpora petebant. vid Stadium, comment. in cum locum Moone and Starres to make him conquerour by Land. Thus fates had been his friend, vntill his ascending the holy Mount: but vpon his descent thence, fortune (to vse the Romaines language) beganne to turne her wheele vpon him. His wonted prouidence and forecastƲid. Pl • tar in Pompe • e & Appianum l b 2 de Bello civil, & Dion • m, in initi{us} lib. 42. di. for-sooke him; and hee that in his yonger daies (when his heart was as full of hopes as his bloud of spirits) had vsed greatest vigilancie to preuent all dangers in matters of smaller moment, whose losse might easily haue beene recouered: now in that age, whose vsuall symptomes are timiditie, and too much care, suffers those consultations on which his owne, his friends, his Countries fates, & fortunes wholly depended, on which the whole state of the world did in a manner hang, to passe away as in a dreame; yeelding his irreuocable consent to whatsoeuer any parasite should
propose, in points wherein error and ouer-sight were incorrigible, and their consequence, if bad, remedilesse; with as great speede and little care, as a man would answere, yes, or yea, to some idle question proposed vnto him betwixt sleeping and waking. Answerable to this his sottish demeanour, Victorie, which before had wooed him, once in his last extremitie (like a wanton Minion disposed to flout her blind decrepit doting louer) seemes a little to make toward him,Such was Caesars cēsure of them. either wanting eies to discerne her, or wit to giue her entertainment. But not Victorie her selfe could haue made him victorious, in whose death and ouerthrow the Almightie would haue his iudgements seene. For seeing it could not content him to haue vanquished so many Kings and Kingdomes, but he will prouoke the King of Kings in his owne house, by his vnmannerly intrusion into his most secret closet, reserued alone, of all places of the earth besides, (though all the earth besides were his) for his Holinesse presence and his Priests: it seemed iust to this Lord of heauen and earth, the supreme disposer of all successe, to giue the Kingdomes subdued by Pompey into his fatall enemies hand, not leauing him so much firme ground of all his conquests, as might decently couer his miserable corps. Since the foundations of the Earth and Sea were laid,Hic, post tres consulat • s & totid • m triumphos domitum{que} terra rum orbem, sanctissimi ac praestantissimi viri, in id euecti super quod ascendi non potest, duodesexagesimū annū agentis, pridie natalē ipsius vitae fuit exitus: in tantū in illo viro â se discordante fortuna, vt cui modo ad victoriā terra defucrat, deesset ad sepultucam. Vell • i. Pater. Histor. lib 2. neuer had so high a flow of all good fortunes, so sudden, so strange, so low & naked an ebbe, Vt cui modò defuerat terra ad victoriam, deesset ad sepulturam: that he, who, as the Romaine Orator saith, had conquered more Prouinces than almost any of his Countrie-men had seene; HeeQui mare vniuersum, quod Romanis parebat, pacauerat, in eo ipso perijt, qui olim mille nauibus (tot enim serunt) prefuerat, tunc in nauicula prope Aegyptum occisus est, id{que} ab eo Ptolomaeo quodammodo, cuius patrem ipse in eam regionem ac Regnum reduxerat. Dyon. Hist. Rom. lib. 42. & statim post. Sic Pompeius, inter Romanos habitus antea potentissimus, vt Agamem non etiam cognominaretur, quod mille nauibus & ipse cum Imperio praefuiss • t, tunc quasi vnus de extremae fortis Aegyptijs, ad montem Cassium interijt, ea ipsa d •• , qua qu • ndam de Mithr • date & Piratis triumphum duxerat: vt ne in his quidem extrema cum primis conuenerint. that had commanded a thousand ships, restored the vse of the Sea to the Nations againe, and freed all others from the violence of Pyrates, sole Lord of that element, and the coasts adioyning; should (vpon that very day, which in memorie of thisThe P • raticall was the most honourable Warre that euer any Romane vndertooke, and iustly deserued a glorious triumph: but Pompey triumphed in his sinne, whilest hee included Iuries conquest, as put of that daies glorie, which the Lord for this reason would haue defaced by his miserable death, as he had polluted the solemnitie of Gods Saboath in Ierusalem, for hee tooke it on the Saboath day. Ʋid. Ioseph. lib. 1. de Bello Iudaico, cap. 5. matchlesse victorie hee had celebrated some few yeares before at Rome
with greatest triumph and solemnitie) become a prey to a beggarly Aegyptian boat, and fall into such base hucksters handes, as knew not the worth of so great a Prince, but (as if hee had beene some rauenous Sea-monster, that had liued by publique harmes, of whose death only some pettie commoditie might bee made) present his head to the chiefe Magistrate in hope of reward, leauing that body, whose goodly presence had ouer-charged the greatest Temples, like a pestiferous carrion, or some offensiue garbage, or forlorne spawne, rather hid than buried in a little heape of sand.

2
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Vix caperet tēplum quem parua recondit arena. Epitaph. Pompeij apud Appian. l. 2 de Bello Ciuili. The strange stupiditie, and more strange destinie of this famous Prince, so wise by nature, so well experienced, and alwaies before this time most fortunate, did argue to the Heathens apprehension, that he wasAppian. ibid.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as we would say, taken in the braine by the hand of God, and his hopes blasted from aboue. But such is the preposterous dullnesse of humane sagacitie in diuine matters, that euen where the print of Gods waies is most sensible and perspicuous,The Romās preposterous & impious collections vpon Pompeis ouerthrow. the wisest of vs runne counter still vntill his word direct our foote-steps, and his spirit giue life vnto our senses. For the most religious amongst the Romaines, deeming Pompey such as they held themselues, one that had neuer giuen iust offence to any of their Gods; vpon his miscarriage, either altogither Hence were these and like complaints. Marmoreo Licinus tumulo iacet: at Cato paruo, Pompeius nullo, quis putet esse Deos? disclaime the diuine prouidence, or else exclaime against the ingratitude or malignitie of celestiall powers; as if there had beene no other God or Gods, but such as they and Pompey had well deserued of. Whereas his fatall ouerthrow, whom their gods they thought had most reason to fauour, should haue instructed them, that there was a God of gods in Iurie, which did beare rule ouer the ends of the world, who would not bee worshipped after their fashion, as Pompey dreamed. For the reason of his desire to see the most holy place, was to bee resolued whether the Romaines, which worshipped the gods of euery Nation subdued by them, had not that God alreadie, which the Iewes adored:Romanerum primus Cn. Pomp domuit tēplum{que} iure victoriae ingressus est. Inde vulgatum, Nulla Intus Deum effigie vacuam sedem & Inania Arcana. Tacitus lib. 5 Histor. Vide Florum. l. 3. c. 5. but finding no grauen Image, nor likenesse of any thing in heauen or earth, many Romaines, which till that time had liued in suspence and admiration who this God of these Iewes should be, held their concealed mysteries for meere gulleries, and thought it folly to worship they knew not whom, forIucanus. Incerti
Iudaea Dei; yet were his iudgments vpon this great Peere of Rome, the first among that people that had to doe with the Iewes, most certaine, yet iudgements mixt with mercie and long suffering. Seeing Vzzah and Vzziah King of Iuda, for intermeddling in the Priests office, were smitten, the one with sudden death, the other with continuall leprosie vntill his dying day: who can expect that this aliant should escape vnpunisht for like presumption? Neuerthelesse, because he did approch the most holy place, though with an vnsanctified heart, yet with no sacrilegious handes, hee had a longer time of repentance than his next Peere in might amongst the Romaines, his predecessor in like miserable and disgracefull death, though his successor in like, but more shamefull sacrilegious base prophanenesse.

The causes of Crassus mishaps3 That sacrilege was one especiall cause of Crassus miscarriage in the Parthian Warres, the Heathens of that time had obserued; and it may be, Plutarch, from vnwritten Traditions the nurse of error, did mistake the storie. Sure it was not the Goddesse of
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . &c. Plutarch in Crasso. Hierapolis, but the God of the holy Citie, which made the yong and aged to stumble one against an other. Or if Crassus and his sonne had this first Omen of their ouerthrow at their egresse out of this Goddesse Temple; this doth not argue that it was either soly or principally for his offence therein committed; albeit euen sacrilegious wrongs against the Heathen Gods, did oft redound to the true-Gods dishonour, being not intended by worldly minded men, so much against them in particular, as in contempt of the Deitie or diuine power simply: Nor are such warnings vsually sent immediatelyAs the destruction of Hierusalem did not immediately follow vpon our Sauiours, but vpon his seruants, S. Iames vniust death. vpon the principall fact, but rather after continuance in the like. And the vicinitie of thisThis Hiera-polis was Bambyca or Edessa, where Di • ceto the great Syrian Goddesse was worshipped, as appeares from Strabo, in hs 16. Booke. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . 't was beyond Euphrates: whereas Crassus had ominous signes of his destruction at his first passage ouer that Riuer. Plutarch. places name, (which was a second witnesse of Crassus sinnes) might haue put him in minde of his former misdeedes in Ierusalem, with whose sacred treasure he had dealt iust so, as Plutarch saith hee did with the treasurie of that Goddesse of Hierapolis.
Which makes me suspect that Plutarch did mistake the storie.Vid. Ioseph. l. 12. Antiq. cap. 13. For as Iosephus tels vs, he tooke away the 2000. talents, which Pompey left vntoucht, and 8000. besides. But such was the Heathens preiudice of the Iewes, that the least iniurie offred to their Idol-Gods was more than the most grieuous sacrilege that could be deuised against the God of Israel. The worst that could be done against his Temple, was, in many of their opinions, but as reprochfull words, which can beare no action, because not easily appliable to any determinate person: with many of them it was all one, Non esse Deos, & non apparere, represented in some visible shape or image. Thus Polibius, otherwise an ingenuous writer, imputes the cause of Antiochus Epiphanes suddaine and fearefull death, vnto his intended pillage of the Goddesse Artemis Temple; when as this miscreant was guiltie of that actuall crime before, for ransacking the temple of Ierusalem. But as the plenarie cause of Crassus miserable and shamefull death, was his shamelesly miserable and sacrilegious minde in generall: so in the meanes, or manner of this end, the Almightie would haue his particular offences against his Priest and Temple to be most eminent, and conspicuous.Eleazarus cum videret Crassum totum esse in colligendo auro times omnib{us} Tēpli ornamētis, trabē hāc redemptionē pro omnib{us} ei dedit, cum prius cā iurciurando obstrinxisset, nihil aliud loco moturum, contentum eo quod ipse trader • t, estimatum plurimis aureorū millibus. Haec trabs inserta erat trabi cauae ligneae quod caeteris omnib{us} ignotū, solus scieb • t Eleazar{us} Crassus tame & hanc pro reliquo tēpli auro accepit, & mox violato iureiurando totum quantum intuserat • g • ssit. Ios. l 14. ant. c. 12
Eleazar the high Priest, seeing him wholly bent to make a golden Haruest of the Parthian expedition, feared least hee should rake all the sacred Treasure into his coffers. For preuenting of which mischiefe hee presents him with a golden beame, whereon the hangings of the Temple hung, hoping thereby to redeeme the rest of the sacred Treasure; but hee hauing gotten this into his handes, which otherwise he could not haue found (being couered with wood) contrarie to his oath, most agreeable to his humour, seazed vpon all the residue. Yet gold, which hee thus greedily sought, as (to his seeming) the only sure nerue of warre, by the Almighties disposition, became the indissoluble chaine of his dismall faults. As loue to it had made him periure himselfe to circumuent Gods Priest; so did it expose him to circumuention by a periuredMax mā autē calamitatis partem Angar{us} ipsis Os •• enus attulit. Is Romanis ant • a foedere iunct sub Pomp. barbarorū partes tum poti •
res habuit. Quod idem Alchandonius quo{que} Arabs fecit, semper potent • orise solitus adiūgere: Caeterā hic quia manifesto defecerat à Romanis ca • eri facile p • tiat. Angarus autē, quum Partho studeret, simulauit se Crassi amicū, liberaliter{que} ei pecuniā suā impendēs, et explorauit omnia ei{us} cōsilia, et Partho enūciauit. Dion. lib. 40. villaine; who hauing found out his appetite, prepared a fit bait for his bane. For by feeding this greedie thirst of gold, he insinuated himselfe into the societie of his secrets, which he disclosed vnto the Parthian. Had Crassus wits naturally beene so dull, or had he vsually shewed himselfe so grosse and sottish, as hee
proued in this expedition: he had neuer borne any place amongst the Romaines, much lesse had they euer permitted him to manage any forraine Warres.Vid. Plutarch in Crosso. Dionem l. citato. Appian. de E • ll. Parth. But partly from his prodigious stupiditie, vncapable of any warning by so many ominous signes and tokens, as did obstupifie his whole Armie besides, partly from his more than brutish facilitie, in taking an vncouth way (as hee had beene a tame beast before the drouer) vntill he came to the very stand, where his enemies stood with their bowes bent, and their arrowes of death made readie vpon the string for his destruction, all the Romaine writers agree, that hee was lead awry by sinister fates. Now if they had but once read what God he was, that had blinded Absolon to disclaime2. Sam. c. 17. Achitophels good counsaile, and ratifie Hushars plot for his ouerthrow; they would easily haue granted that the same God, & no other,Tum Cassiani rursum agre ferebat, & om • sso Crosse, qui monitores audi • e gra • abatur, connicijs meessabant Angarum. Appian. l. citato, & Strabon. l. 16 had infatuated Craessus heart to renounce Cassius, & other graue experienced Roman warriors holesome aduise, & betake himselfe wholly to the barbarous fugitiue Abgarus directions, suborned by the Parthian to betray him.

4 But Cassius, much wiser than his Generall in this one particular of mistrusting forainers, was afterwards as farre ouer-seene in the maine chance, and ouer-taken with that sinne which had caused Crassus blindnesse: First, polluted with like So saith S. Austine de Ciuit. Dei l. 18 c. 45. Postea (i. post. Pompeij victoriam de Iudae is) Cassius Templū spoliauit, Of his cruell exactions in Iudea, Vide Ioseph. antiq. l. 14. c. 18. sacrilege, and cruell oppression of these Iewes: then with his owne bloud,Of his grosse error in mistaking his victorious friend for his persecuting enemie. Ʋide Velleum Paterculum l. 2. & reliquos Rom. hist. autores. shed by his seruant at his commandement, vpon as grosse an ouer-sight as Crassus had committed So shall they all, sooner or later, bee infatuate, that robbe God of his honour, and put their
trust in wrong or violence. And thus till this time did they perish all, as many as bare ill will to Sion; for Hierusalems houre was not yet come, because the day spring had not visited her from on high. The glorie of her glorious Temple was not as yet reuealed; vnto whom after her children had offered greater disgrace than the Romaines had done to their Temple, the staffe of her wonted stay begins to breake, the bones of her former peace vntwine, and only one part of her double fates remaine; if then shee fall, shee riseth not againe, shee hath no inclination left but to destruction; the burthen of the Fathers sinnes, and the yoke of captiuitie due thereto, growes heauier and heauier in the descent vpon posteritie, without all hope of recouerie, much lesse of reuenge, vpon such as offer her greatest violence; but rather happy shall that man be thought, and highest earthly honour shall bee the wages of his seruice, that rewards her children, as they had serued their Lord and Sauiour. But these times were not come in Crassus or Cassius daies, in which som reliques of her ancient hopes remained, to see the rods and scourges of her correction consume and wither, after once the Almightie had taken off his punishing hand. And if vnto these three aboue mentioned, we adde the like destinie of Antonie and Scipio; the ill successe of other Romaines, who had ought to do with these Iewes before our Sauiours time: we may conclude, that although the Romaines were then Lords of the earth, yet this people, whom they held as base, retained the priuilege of Gods roiall Priests. Although the soules of all flesh were the Lords, who for this cause reuenged the oppressed in euery Nation: yet, Ierem. 2. v. 3. Leuit. 22. v. 10. Israel only (as the Prophet speakes) was as a thing hallowed vnto the Lord, his first fruits; all such as deuoured them did offend, euill should come vpon them, although inflicted by their owne, or their seruants handes at their appointment. Lastly, if we call to minde the former distinction of Ages, and the diuers manner of Gods dealing with them, before and after the Babylonish captiuitie; the contraction or abridgment of their large priuiledges, in the long suceession of times foretold, by ancient, and acknowledged by their owne latter writers: wee can not mistrust the amplitude of their fundamentall charter, of their historicall narrations of what the Lord had done of old vnto Iabin, Sisera, and Sennacherib, would we (allowing some different condition of times) compare
theirs with Pompeys and his Complices vnusuall Fates.Gods iudgements vpon Pompeys factiō, were most iust, because they had participated of his sinne Gods power was more immediately manifested in the one, his Wisedome more admirable in the other, his Iustice the same in both. Yet a Romaine would reply: If Pompey had so grieuously offended, why should he not haue borne the whole burden of his sins? So he should, had either he alone offended, or the Romains suffered him to haue liued a priuate life; but if they will associate themselues as members to their naturall head, and professe their seruice and alleageance vnto him, that stood as proscribed by the court of heauen: Gods quarrel with the whole faction is most iust, all of them are guiltie of their Generalls sinnes, all liable to the plagues and punishments due thereto. Yet, besides that Pompeys intolerable presumption and prophanenesse, according to the vsual course of Gods iustice, might propagate his destinie vnto such of his adherents, as had beene free from any actuall wrong done to the Iewes, or contempt of their God and religion in particular: a great many of his chief followers had polluted themselues with the like sinne in Ierusalem. For, asIudaeorum quidem 12. millia occubuerunt: Romanorum vero perpauci, sed plures sauciati sunt Nih • l autem grau • us in illa clade Iudoeorum genti visum est, quam sanctum illud arcanum, neq, cuiqu • m pr • us visum alienis esse detectū. Deni{que} Pompeius vna cum suis comitibus in templum ingressus, vbi neminem praeter pontificē adesse fas erat, quae intus erant candelabra cum ly • hnis & mēsis in quibus tibare atque adolere moris est, & vascula ex auro cuncta spectauit. Ioseph. de Bello Iudaico. l. 1. c. 5.
Iosephus tels vs, Pompey went not into the most holy place alone, but accompanied with a multitude. All of them, no doubt, had sinned presumptuously against the admonitions & threatnings of Gods Priests; and this peoples curse (it seemes) did follow them, whither they themselues durst not; for as the same writer testifies, no other calamitie in that war did grieue the Nation so much, as this pollution of their Temple.

5 Whatsoeuer Tullies or other politique Romains conceipt of this people in his time was; many amongst the Romains, as well as in most other Nations, had (without question) either obserued the like fatal mischances of such as vexed them, or else had felt som good in obseruing their lawes, whose persons vnknowne they hated. In one, or both which respects, these Iewes stood vpon better termes with their Conquerors, than any other captiues did. And vnlesse it had been a receiued opinion amongst other Romaines, that this had been a people fauoured of the diuine powers; why should Tullie haue obiected their late conquest by Pompey to proue the contrarie? And (me thinks) it might haue moued him and others, so much deuoted to the Romaine Gods before, to haue thought these Iewes did serue a better God then they knew any, after they had seene their owne state vtterly ruined
without all hope of recouerie, and their Gods either vnwilling, or vnable, (as Tullie doubtfully complaines) to redresse those miseries and calamities, of which they should at least haue giuen them warning, when as Hierusalems wals,Ʋide Ios. l. 14. Antiq. c. 14.15.16. which Pompey had demolished, were (according to this peoples hope, from which no power on earth could deiect them, being supported by the expresse promise of their God) reedified within twentie yeeres, and they graced with great Priuiledges for their good seruice performed to Caesar. For chiefly by their meanes became hee Lord of Aegypt, the first and surest ground of his good successe in Africke; as Iosephus out of the publike Decrees and testimonies of Romain Writers boldly auoucheth, challenging the heathen to disproue him or his testimonies, if they could, though this they easily might haue done, if hee had cited them amisse, because the Originals were then euery where extant.

6 The former testimonies alleaged out of Tullie (whose works we haue) so well agreeing with Iosephus, who it seemes had neuer read them, will not suffer any ingenious man to suspect the truth of that which the same Iosephus cites, out of Strabo the Cappadocian, whose workes are lost.Quatuor erant genera in Cyrenensium vrbe, ciues Agricolae, inquilini, & quarti Judaei, hoc • am in omnes vrbe • subrepsit, necest facile inuenire locum in vrbo habitabili, quem recepta semel non obtineat, nā & Aegyptus & Cyrene, vtpote eisdem solitae parere dominis, aliaeque multae regiones horum
• itus admiserunt: aluni{que} congregationes Iudaeorum maximas, tempore coalitas & vtentes institutis domesticis, per Aegyptum sanè etiam coloniae sunt eius gentis, abs{que} eo quod Alexandrinae vrbis magna pars ei assignata est. Habet etiam proprium magistratum, qui suae gentis res administret, controuersias ex iure dirimat, & contractus atque pacia rata habeat, non aliter quam fit in absoluta republica. Iosephus Antiq. Iud. lib 10. c. 12.
The Iewes (saith he) haue crept into most Cities, nor can a man almost name any place in the inhabited world, where they once get footing, but they hold possession. Aegypt, Cyrene, and many other nations haue admitted their rites, and in lieu of them, nurse huge multitude of Iewes vsing their owne domestique lawe; besides that a great part of Alexandria is assigned to their vse, there be colonies of this nation throughout Aegypt which enioy magistrates of their owne, for determining all controuersies of right and wrong in such sort and forme as is vsed in absolute states. Seneca inter alias ciuilis theologiae superstitiones reprehendit Sacramenta Iudaeorum. Christianos tameniam tunc Iudaeis inimicissimos in neutram partem commemorare ousus est, ne vel laudaret contra suae patriae veterem consuctudinem, vel reprehenderet contra propriam forfitan voluntatem. De illis sanc Iudaeis, cum loqueretur ait, cum interim vsque eo sceleratissimae gentis consuetudo conualuit, vt per omnes iam te • ras recepta sit, victi victoribus legem dederunt. Mirabatur haec dicens, & quid diuinitus ageretur ignorans, subiecit plane sententiam, qua significaret, quid de illorum sacramentorum ratione senti • et. Ait enim: Illi tamen causas ritus sui nouerunt, & maior pars populi facit, quod cur faciat, ignorat August. l. 6. de ciu. D. c 11.4 Sequitur auri illa inuidia Iudaici. Hoc nimirum est illud, quod non longè a gradibus Aurelijs haec causa dicitur, ob hoc crimen hic locus, abs te Laeli at illa turba quaesi ta est. Scis quanta sit manus, quanta concordia, quantum val • t in concionibus &c. Cic. Orat. pro Flacco. Saint Augustine hath the same
obseruation out of Senecaes books concerning superstition which this reuerend father had perused, though, with diuerse others of that famous Phylosophers workes, now lost.

7 What Strabo had obserued of these Iewes in Syllaes, and Seneca in his time, is intimated by Tullie in fewer words. You know well (saith hee vnto his aduersarie) what a great faction it is: how closely they band together, what sway they beare in assemblies. But how great soeuer the number of this people was at Rome, they durst not haue beene so bold in the Mistresse-citie of the world, vnlesse their patrons there had beene many. And it seemes by Tullies conclusion,Aurum in aerario est, furtum non reprehenditur, a iudicibus oratio auertitur, vox in coronam turbam{que} effunditur. Cic. Orat. pro Flacco. in the fore-mentioned place, that the bare vnkindnesse offered by Flaccus to this Nation, was worse taken at Rome, than the wrongs and violence, which he was accused to haue done to sundrie other people. The gold (saith he) for which Flaccus was accused, is in the treasurie: you charge him not with theft, but onely seeke to make him odious: your speech is turned from the iudges and directed to the companie.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Tacitus obiections against the Iewes refuted, by their palpable grosnesse, and more competent testimonie of other Heathen writers.
div.p:
1 VNto this their powerfulnesse in perswading other Nations to renounce their owne, and imbrace their Lawes and religion,Hiritus quoqu • modo inducti, antiquitate defendūtur. Cetera instituta sinistra, foeda prauitate valuere. Nam pessimus quisque spreta relig onib{us} patrijs, tributa & stipes illuc congerebant. Tacit. Histor lib. 5.
Tacitus ascribes the increase of these Iewes estate; albeit hee maliciously attributes this attractiue force vnto the impietie of their Lawes, as if by sympathie they had wrought most vpon wicked and depraued natures. But wherein did their impietie consist?Profana illic omn a, quae apud nos sacra. Rursum concessa apud illos, quae nobis incesta. Tacit. Hist. lib. 5.
What wee Romanes esteeme sacred, they account prophane, what is polluted to vs, is lawfull to them. This argues that either the Romaine religion, or theirs, was superstitious and prophane: and hee, like a true patriot and right Romanist, loath to suspect that Religion wherein his
forefathers had prospered so well, charges the contrarie orthodoxall with superstitious impietie. Most true it was, that the Iewes of his time were a wicked people, but euery way of the loosing hand: their strength, which had been long in gathering, was suddenly broke by Titus, and their wonted means of encrease, by addition of Proselytes, quite cut off. For after the Temples destruction, Nullus ad amissas ibat amicus opes: from the first day of our Sauiours Ministeriall Function, they woon not halfe so many Gentiles to Iudaisme, as our Sauiour and his Disciples did Iewes vnto Christianitie. Tacitus then spake not of such Iewes as liued in his time, when their strength and greatnesse was in the wane; but of their ancestors, during the time of the second Temple. Nor was it that, which was most wicked indeed in this people, or their predecessors (as their particular opposition, or contrarietie vnto diuine truths) but rather what was onely good in them, as their constancie in their Religion, and stedfast profession of Abrahams faith, common to them and the Christians; which was the ground of this Politikes hatefull censure, The grounds of worldly greatnesse hate against resolute professors of truth. Jnterim in ijs, qui ad me tanquam Christiani defer ebantur, hunc sum sequutus modum. Interroga • i ipsos, au essent Christiani: confit • ntes iterum ac tertio rogaui, suppliciū minatus, perseuerantes duci iussi. Neque enim dubitabam, qualecunque esset quod faterentur, peruitaciā certè, & inflexibilem obstinationem debere pun • ri. Plin. Epist. li. 10. Epist. 100. for this reason a-like bitter against them and the Christians. That either should be so resolute in defence of their owne Religion, was, in his opinion, a pernicious superstition, lyable to any punishment that could be proposed, as another Romane Writer of his time was not ashamed to auouch. If wilfulnesse simply deserue punishment, the carnall minded make no scruple in what measure it be inflicted, seeing the more grieuous the torture is, the greater it alwayes argues their wilfulnesse or obstinacie to be, that will vndergoe it rather than obey their superiors, so as the crime seeme alwayes commensurable to the punishment, though it could be increased in infinitum. And Tacitus seemes well to approue of Antiochus sauage crueltie against the Iewes, as a medicine that would in time haue wrought a reformation, if the Parthian had permitted this cruell Surgeon to haue applyed his patients with change of such corroding playsters. So immoderate is the ambitious mens desires, that to be Lords of others bodies doth but whet their appetite, and stirre vp a longing to become Lords of their faith and consciences also. And to refuse absolute obedience in matters spirituall, as well as temporall, vnto such as are
competent Iudges of the one, not of the other, is a sinne as hatefull as rebellion, the foulest crime that can be conceiued or fashioned in the Polititians braine.

2 Besides these generall motiues, which would minister enough of matter for superiours to condemne their inferiours: it did in particular exasperate Tacitus, and other politicks of his temper,Iudei (vt est gēs ea irae, si semelea correpta fuerit, acerbiasimae) multa ac grauia mala quidem ij Romanis intulerant, longè tamen plura passisunt Dion. lib. 49. to see so many naturall Romaines renounce their name and countrie, forsake father and mother, friend and alliance, for maintenance of Iewish religion. And albeit that Nation had sustained incredible calamities by the Romaines, yet it vexed him to remember, that they should bee able to haue done the Romaines so much mischiefe, alwaies stirring when others were quiet; being, to his seeming, a base people in respect of many other subiect to the Romane Empire. Perhaps his hate to Christians was propagate from his inueterate malice against these Iewes, in whose region Christianitie (as he confesseth) did first spring. ButAffirmabant autem hanc esse summam, vel culpae sue erroris, quod essent solitistato die ante lucem conuenire, carmenque Christo quasi Deo dicere sec • m inuicem, seque sacramento non inscelus aliquod obstringere: sed ne furta, ne latrocinia, ne adulteria committ • rent, ne fidem fallerent ne depesitum appellati abnegarent Quo magis necessariū credidi ex duabus ancill • s, quae ministrae dic • bātur, quid esse veri, et per tormenta quaerere Sed nihil aliud inueni, quam superstitionem prauā, & immodicam: ide • que d • lata cognitione ad consulendum te de cucurri. Plin. Epist. 100. l. 10.
Plinies testimonie will sufficiently quit the Christians from those imputations, whichTransgressi in morem eorum idem vsurpant, nec quidquam prius imbauntur, quam contemnere Deos, eruere patriam: parentes, liberos, fratres, vilia habere. Tacit. Hist. l. 5.
Tacitus vniustly layeth vpon them. As for that impietie, wherewith hee chiefly chargeth these Iewes religion, it implies an euident contradiction. Such as conforme themselues (saith he) to their customes are likewise transformed in minde. The fist precept, wherewith they are seasoned, is to contemne the Gods, to put off all naturall affection to their Countrie. If the Iewes did either forsake father, or mother, or other kindred, It was for the loue of their God, religion and Countrie. For, vnlesse the greatnesse of their loue to God drowned the other, no people in the world did euer match them in loue to their kinsfolkes, friends and countrimen. But if they perswaded the Romains to esteem the glorie of Rome as vile, in respect of Hierusalem; and account Romish rites and ceremonies, compared with theirs, as sacrilegious and prophane; they did that but vpon good and warrantable grounds, which any true Romane would haue done vpon farre worse; that is, they sought their countries good, by winning the good will of others to their estate and religion.

3 But what madnesse possessed Tacitus his minde, that hee should thinke, or rather write, for I doe not thinke that hee thought, or cared what he wrote, when he auouched, that the wickednesse of their lawes was a meanes of alluring wicked or lewde companions to their obseruance? I would their greatest enemies were admitted Iudges; whether such as indeed were, or such as any ciuill heathen would so account, not such as it pleased Tacitus only, out of meere pride and splene, to call wicked persons, would not in all likelihood, be more readie to subscribe vnto the rites of Venus or Bacchus, (whose seruice Tacitus so well likes,) or any other of the Romish Gods, than tie themselues vnto Iudaicall ceremonies; which, once subscribed vnto, were to be most strictly obserued by Aliens as well as Iewes; nor could they bee throughly acquainted with their lawes, or admitted to other mysteries, vntill they had communicate with them in that Sacrament of Circumcision, alwaies most loathsome and grieuous to flesh and bloud. What pleasures of the flesh, what dissolutenes or luxurie, or what, that can be properly called sinne or enormitie, did their lawes maintaine or nourish, or their rites or ceremonies any way insinuate? All that Tacitus (comparing their rites with those of Bacchus) could in conclusion say against them, was; That Tiber Jestos loetosque ritus pos • t: Judocor ••
mos absurdus sord • dusque. Tacit. Hist. lib. 5. Bacchus his rites were merrie and pleasant, theirs absurd and base.

4 Vnto these politicall surmises of Tacitus, altogether ignorant of forraine antiquities, I will oppose the iudgement of a lesse partiall Strabos testimonie of the Iewes religion Lib. 16. writer, and a professed antiquarie, liuing about our Sauiours time: from whom amongst o • hers we may gather, that the famous and conspicuous hill of Sion stood as a probleme to oppose the nations; and from admiration of her strange and vnobseruable fortunes and change, were so many opinions blazed abroad of those Iewes originall and state. Of all that were extant in his time, capable of any credit, this following went best for currant, and did sway the most, to wit; That these Iewes (as you heard before of his errour in this particular) were descended from the Egyptians: the cause of their departure out of Egypt, was to seeke a place, where they might worship God aright, perswaded hereunto by Moses, whom he takes for an Egyptian Priest, but one that condemned the Egyptians for painting beastes, the
Africans and Grecians for vsing pictures of men to represent God; deeming it a madnesse to imagine, that he that contained all things, could be represented by any visible or sensible creature. Chastitie & holinesse were the dispositions of such as sought him, or could hope to know-his will: and for this purpose ordained sacrifice, neither chargeable to such as should vse them, nor otherwise offensiue by their vndecencie, lewdnesse or absurditie.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . With these perswasions (saith he) Moses preuailed with the better sort, and such as feared God, to forsake Egypt: and seated once about Ierusalem, neighbour countries did associate themselues vnto them, allured by the equitie of their lawes, and the puritie of the religion which they professed, whence he erected a new kingdome, and that no meane one. And his successors for a time continued in his institutions, iust and rightly religious. But after they had (as Tacitus obserueth) ioyned the Priesthood to support their Kingdome, they grew more Yet was Strabo somewhat offended with Circumcision and their Sabboths, as being ignorant of their caus • s, as their Sabboths indeed were then superstitious. superstitious, tyrannicall to their owne, and noisome neighbours to other countries. d Yet was their Hold or Fort still had in honour: not detested as a nest of thieues or seat of tyrants, but reuerenced as a temple. Thus farre Strabo. Who, although he were mistaken in sundrie particulars of this peoples antiquitie, (as all beside themselues of necessitie were, by reason this sacred volumne was kept secret from all such as did not obserue their rites) yet from tradition he had learned as much, as could be knowne of them in generall: That Moses their first Law-giuer was a Prophet, and one that relyed not vpon pollicie, but the diuine Oracles; that this people in ancient times had bene much better, and had prospered accordingly.

13 With this Strabo the Geographer, that noble Historian Dion Cassius well accords, but more fully with Strabo the Cappadocian, whose works, now lost, Iosephus cited. This people (saith he) differ from others, as in many other points and daily practise of life, so especially in this that they worship no other Gods, but onely one of their owne, whom they hold to be inuisible and ineffable,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Strabo lib. 16 D • o ••
acquitall of these Iewes from Tacitus imputations. Diuersum à reliquis hominibus obtinent cum a •• s in veb •• , vsuque vitae quotidiano, tum eo praesertim quòd n • llum ex coeteris diis colunt, vnum autem quendam s • mr •• s •• dio venerantur. Nec vllum simulac • rum. Hierosolymis vnqu • m habuerunt; nimirum suum illum Deum 〈◊〉
• ilem & formae expertent, relig • oso eius cultu coeteros mortales superant. Dion. lib. 37. and for this cause admit
not any Image of him: yet doe they worship him more deuoutly & religiously then any other people do their Gods. But who this god of theirs was, or bow he came at first to be thus worshipped, how greatly he was feared of this people, were points he listed not meddle withall, many other had written thereof before him.Regioipsa, Iudaea gens, Iudaei appellantur. Id cognomēti vnde initium coeperit haud scio. Quin{us} & alii homines qui secundum eorum statuta viuant, id gerunt, quanquam alieniginoe Est • d genus hominum apud Romanos etiam, atque tametfi soepe in minutum sicerit, ita tamen auctum est, vt etiam condendi leges licentiam sibi vinâicarit. Or as some read, vt legum qucq • e potestatem vicerit. Dion. ibid. It seemes he gaue but little credence vnto Tacitus discourse of their originall, for he ingeniously professeth: That he knew not whence they had this name of Iewes, but others that followed their rites, although Aliens by birth and progenie, did brooke the same name or title, euen amongst the Romans themselues there were of this profession. Hee addeth; Although this people had beene often crushed and diminished: yet did they rise and increase againe aboue the controll of all other lawes, onely subiect to their owne. Thus hee spake of the Iewes liuing in Pompeys time, after which they had beene often crushed before Tacitus wrote, yet recouered strength againe.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
The meanes of these Iewes thriuing in captiuitie. In what they exceeded other people, or were exceeded by them.
div.p:
1 THese allegations, and many other, which out of Heathen writers I could bring, sufficiently proue, that albeit these Iewes tasted of as bitter calamities as any other did: yet had they this strange aduantage of all; that whereas all other were forsaken of their friendes in their aduersitie, and their Lawes vsually changed by their conquerours, oft-times abrogated or neglected by themselues vpon their ill successe: these Iewes still found most friends, and their lawes (neuer forsaken by them) most earnest fauourers, in the time of their captiuitie and distresse. This was quite contrarie to nature, politike obseruation, or custome of the world. Wherefore seeing nature and policie can affoord vs none, we must seeke resolution from their lawes. The reasons subordinate to the cause of causes (Gods
prouidence) were these. In the time of their distresse, they did more faithfully practise their lawes themselues, and had better opportunitie, or greater necessitie of communicating them vnto others: they being of themselues alwaies most potent to allure sober and discreet mindes to their obseruance, made knowne and not preiudiced by the foolish or sinister practise of their professors. So their great Law-giuer had foretold, Deut 4. vers. 4.5.6. Behold I haue taught you ordinances and lawes, as the Lord my God commanded me, that ye should do euen so in the land, whither ye goe to possesse it. Keepe them therefore and doe them; for that is your wisedome and vnderstanding in the sight of the people, which shall heare of all these ordinances, and shall say; Onely this people is wise and of vnderstanding, and a great Nation. For what Nation is so great vnto whom the Gods come so neare vnto them, as the Lord our God is neare vnto vs in all that wee come vnto him for? And what Nation is so great that hath Ordinances and Lawes so righteous, God was more sauourable to these Iewes than to any other people. as all this law which I set before you this day? That they had not in later times so great prosperitie, as others had, was no argument that their God was not more neare to them, than the Gods of other Nations to their worshippers; for he was a God of Gods, and Lord of Lords, which did good to euery Nation; yea he made the Romanes so great a Nation, albeit they knew it not. That these Iewes were now in subiection, and the Romanes Lords, was no argument, that he was better to the Romanes than to them, or that they were a lesse Nation, if we make an equall comparison. For if God should often recouer a man from dangerous diseases, and propagate his life vnto two hundred yeares, in health and strength competent for old age; this were no argument to proue that he were not more fauourable to him, than to men of yonger yeares or middle age, whose strength is greater for the present, but they vnlikely to recouer health often impaired, or to renue life once lost in humane estimation, or to account halfe so many yeares.In what sense the Iews might truly be thoght a mightie na
•••• . In like sort was this peoples often recouerie from so many ouerthrowes and captiuities; their long continuance a distinct nation from others: more extraordinarie than the Romanes present strength or greatnesse. And albeit many other Empires and States were larger, than the Kingdome of Israel was at any time, yet no other people could be said so great a Nation
as this. For others continued the same rather by identitie of soyle, or like forme of gouernment, then by any reall or materiall vnitie or identitie of people: their increase was meerely politicall, and their greatnesse rose by way of addition or accumulation; that is, by admitting such mixture of others, that from the first erection of the Kingdome, ere it came to its full greatnesse, the number of Aliens might ouerspreade and hide the naturall inhabitants, or progenies of such as laid the fundamentall Lawes thereof, which were seldome so continuate by direct succession, as they might be rightly distinguished from others. And as Theseus his ship was accounted one and the same, because it retayned the same forme, though not so much of the same Timber, whereof it was first built, as did goe to the making of halfe the keele: so the greatest States amongst the Heathens, retayned perhappes some few fundamentall lawes, or relikes of Ancient Families descending from their first founders, in which respect alone they might be taken for one Kingdome, but not so properly termed one People or Nation, to whom greatnesse could be truly attributed, seeing a great many of seuerall people were to share in this title. But these Iewes (besides the perpetuall vnitie, their particular, as well as fundamentall lawes, lesse varied eyther by change, addition or abrogation, than the Lawes of any other Nation) continued still one and the same people by a strict Vnion of succession, their grouth was naturall, after the manner of vitall augmentation. For albeit they admitted some mixture of strangers, they could notwithstanding alwaies distinguish the progenie of forraine stockes from their naturall branches, which they could still deriue from their seuerall stemmes, and these all from one and the same roote: so that after so many changes, and alterations of their State from better to worse, and backe againe; after so many glorious victories, as Scriptures mention gotten by them ouer others; and so many captiuities of their persons and desolations of their countries, as others had wrought, they remained still one and the same people, by such a kinde of vnitie, as a great Oake is said one and the same tree, from its first spring to its last fall, whether naked and bereft of leaues by blastes of Autumne or Winters frost, or spoyled of boughes by the
loppers axe, or beautified with pleasant leafe, or farspreading branches. If the glorie of other kingdomes were more splendent for a flash, presently to bee extinguished, (as being greater than their corruptible nature was capable of:) this no way impeacheth Gods promise for making Abrahams seede a mightie Nation; seeing it was not at any time so great a people as at al times it might haue beene, had they obserued the meanes appointed for their grouth. How incomparable the height of Sions roofe, aboue other nations, might haue bin, we may gesse from the capacitie of her foundations. The known altitude and continuance of her wals, though neuer finished to her founders desire,The strength and cont • nuance of these Iewes diseased estate, argues how incomparable their strength might haue beene had they followed their Lawgiuers precepts for the preseruation of their health. yet such, as who so shall looke vpon with vnpartiall eye, must acknowledge ordained for extraordinarie strength and greatnesse. For take wee this Kingdome with it defectes; what wonder can reuolutions of time affoorde like to this late mentioned? That by such an vnitie of naturall propagation from one roote, (almost perished before it sprouted,) and distinct lineall succession neuer interrupted, Abrahams seede should continue one and the same Nation for two thousand yeares: sometimes the mightiest amongest coeuall Kingdomes, a scourge and terrour to all neighbour countries; and after many grieuous wounds and deadly, in their estimation that gaue them, receiued from others, still preserued aliue, to see the successiue rise and fall of three great and potent Monarchies, yet able in decrepit daies, to hold play with the fourth, the mightiest that euer was on earth, euen whilest it was in it best age, full strength and perfect health, free from any intestine broyles, secure of all externall assaultes. Much better were these Iewes able to encounter the Romane Empyre, in Tacitus his life time, than it, within three hundred yeares after his death, to defend the imperiall seate against barbarous, seelie, and foolish nations, vnhatched when the Romane Eagle winges were spread ouer the most famous Kingdomes of the earth. Suppose the Romane Empyre had receiued,The Romane Empyre had neuer the like push before it fell, as it had by the Iewes in Adrians time. at the same time, but halfe so terrible a blow in Italy, as these Iewes had done in Iurie and Hierusalem vnder Vespasian, and his sonne: how easily had the commotions of their relickes, in Traeians and Adrians times, shaken the Romane yoake from off the Nations neckes? Or if the other tenne Tribes returne had beene but halfe so entire and
complete, as Iudahes and Beniamins were, the Romane Eagles had neuer come to prey vpon their carkases in the territories of Iudea. But it was their strong God, which before had scattered Israel amongst the nations, and at the time appointed shut these Iewes vp in Hierusalem, as in a prison.

2 Againe, other Kingdomes gained little by their greatnesse, saue onely magnificent names or swelling titles. No other people euioied so great prosperitie, so good cheape, as this sometimes did, and all times might haue done. No other had so good assurance or securitie of that prosperitie or peace they enioyed, as this people had, vnlesse themselues had made a wilfull forfeiture: nor was the publike health or welfare of any other state or Kingdome so fully communicated to euery particular and inferiour member. For vsually the titularie or abstract brightnesse of that glorie, wherewith other great states outwardly seemed most to shine, was maintained with the perpetuall harmes and internall secret mischiefes of many priuate persons, as great flames are not nourished without great store of fuell: whereas the prosperitie of Dauids throne, as in other points so in this, was established like the Moone: that whilest they turned vnto their God, their state was capable of greatest splendour, without consumption of their naturall partes or substance. And euen whilest other States did for their sinnes preuaile against theirs, yet such Peeres as had beene principall instruments of their woe, and tooke occasion to disgrace their Lawes or Religion, in their captiuitie and distresse, had for the most part, (as was obserued before) fearefull and disastrous ends: and might more iustly haue taken vp that complaint, after their spoyles of Iewrie, which Diomedes did after the destruction of Troy,
Quicunque Iliacos ferro violauimus agros,
— nefanda per orbem
Supplicia scelerum poenas expendimus omnes.
What did Troies fall, or Phrygian spoyles, the Graecians state aduance?
Whom fearfull plagues haunt through the world: such was the victors chance.

Many of them (no doubt) before their dying day, had obserued as he did, that they had foughten against some God, whilest they wrong'd this people: and would haue beene as vnwilling to beare armes against them againe as hee was against the relickes of the Troians:
Nec mihi cum Teueris vllum post eruta bellum
Pergama: nec veterum memini loetoruc malorum.
What Troy my splene to Troiās ceas • t, her flames quench th'heat of war
I little ioy of what is past. Rub not a bleeding scar.

3 For these and many like consequentes, this people in the issue and vpshot of their greatest calamities, had both reason to reioyce, and
Psal. 126.6. the Heathens iust cause to say: The Lord had done great things for them, albeit hee often suffered them to bee conquered. For euen this sicklinesse of their State was a meanes of its long life, their scourges and phlebotomies a signe of Gods tender care ouer their health, vntill they grew proud of his fauour, and waxed obdurate by his often fatherly corrections, as one of their owne writers well obserues. The Lord doth not long waite for vs, 2. Mott. 6.14. as for other Nations whom hee punisheth, when they are come to the fulnesse of their sinnes. But thus he dealeth with vs, that our sinnes should not be heaped vp to the full, so that afterward he should punish vs, and therefore he neuer withdrawes his mercie from vs, and though he punish with aduersitie, yet doth he neuer forsake his people.

4 Finally, their decay and increase was such as could not bee measured by the rules of policie. Hence was it that Tacitus was not tacitus, but a tatler, transported from himselfe, his wonted sagacitie and ingenuitie, as being quite out of his naturall element, while hee medled with their affayres. That contrarietie, which he obserues betwixt theirs & the Romans Religion, was as great betwixt their policies. What was good in the one, was nought in the other: that which Rome did thinke might preserue her in helth, was apprehēded, by the wisest amongst this people, as readie poison for their state. Those plots which would haue
crushed any other people once brought vnder, did oft worke their aduancement, and their enemies fall. Whence both their rising and falling, and consequently, the successe of such as opposed themselues against them, were, in other Nations apprehension, sometime in their owne, meerely fatall, altogether incorrigible by worldly policie, especially in more auncient times. Hence did the wise men of Chaldee, vpon the first notice of the windes turning for them, read Haamans destinie, but too late: Esther 6.13. If Mordecai be of the seed of the Iewes, before whom thou hast begun to fall, thou shalt not preuaile against him, but shalt surely fall before him. Achion the Ammonites speech to Holofernes, whether truly vttered by him, or fained by the pen-man of that storie, was framed (no doubt) according to the knowne experience of those times, and containes such aduise, as a faithfull counsellor, well acquainted with their estate, vpon like occasion should haue giuen vnto his Lord, not so well acquainted with it. This hee was bound vnto by the rules of Poetrie,Vnto what time this Historie is to be referred, Vide Sulpit. Seuerum. which the author of that booke (vnlesse perhaps his memorie faile him in the circumstance of time, an escape incident to fictions, for their affinitie with lyes) very well obserues, if his worke be rather to be censured for a Poeme than an Historie; his aduise was this: Iudith 5.21. And whiles they sinned not before their God, they prospered, because the God that hated iniquitie was with them. But when they departed from the way which he appointed them, they were destroyed in many battailes after a wonderfull sort, and were led captiue into a land that was not theirs: and the Temple of their God was cast to the ground, and their Cities were taken by the enemies. But now they are turned to their God, and are come vp from the scattering wherein they were scattered, and haue possessed Hierusalem, where their Temple is, and dwell in the mountaines which were desolate. Now therefore my Lord and Gouernour, if there be any fault in this people, so that they haue sinned against their God, let vs consider that this shall be their ruine, and let vs goe vp, that we may ouercome them. But if there be none iniquitie in this people, let my Lord passe by, least their Lord defend them, and their God be for them, and we become a reproach before all the world. The first root of all such effects or knowne experiments, as in auncient time, yeelded matter to their neighbours of this or like obseruation, was Gods first promise vnto Abraham:
Gen. 12.2, 3. And I will make of thee a great Nation, and will blesse thee, and make thy name great, and
thou shalt be a blessing. I will also blesse them that blesse thee, and curse them that curse thee, and in thee shall all the families of the earth be blessed. The causes and gr • unds of the heath • ns insulting ouer the Iewes in their distresse. Which promise, as it doth concerne the temporall state of the Iewes, was to be limited according to the tenor of Achiors speech, and did then onely take effect, when they followed Abrahams footsteps, and liued in faithfull obedience to Gods Lawes, or hauing transgressed them, did turne againe with their whole heart to seeke the God of their Fathers. From experience of their good successe in such cases, partly (I thinke) were their neighbour countries so sauage and mercilesse towards them in their greatest distresse, alwayes crying, vpon like occasion, as the Edomites did in the day of Hierusalem, Downe with it, downe with it euen to the ground; because they could not hope for any reuenge, but by waiting the turning of their fates, and taking them in the ebbing of their fortunes: for when they begun to rise, they knew there was no meanes to stay them. TheIudea terra quali nunquam ante mo • u cōcussa, magnam, per totam • am re ••
nem iacturam fecit pecud • m: q un & haminū oppr • ssa sunt rui
• s aediū circ • ter de • e millia, militaris tamen multitudo nihil detrimenti accepit, vtpote sub d • oagu • s. H ec • lades etiā in maius aucta rum •• ibus, quos • u • cij ge • tilium od o i • non ignari dabant aurib{us} Arabum, im •• ane quanin extulit host • um animos, quasi subuersi • Iudaeorum vrbibus & extinctis hominabus, nulli iam superessent. Legatos ita{que} gentis, quir • bus afflictis pacem patuuri venerant comprehensos necauerunt, moxque magna alacritate preperauerūt ad hosti ē exercitum. Joseph. Antiq. Iud. l. 15. c. 7. Arabians immane and sauage practises vpon their Embassadors, seeking compassion to their lamentable estate, torne and ruinate by the mightie hand of their God, in a fearefull and prodigious Earthquake, doe argue a deepe rooted memorie of their ancestors strange ouerthrowes (mentioned in Scripture) by this peoples forefathers; and these later Arabians, long lying in wait to do these Iewes a mischiefe, if they had not beene restrained by the mightie hand of God; who now, as they suppose, being turned their enemie, they apprehend this opportunitie of working a full reuenge. Nor are their hard hearts mollified with their publike miseries, nor their inueterate malice so quenched with their embassadors bloud, shed in the 7. yeare of Herods raigne, but it burst out againe in Vespasians time. For these Arabians, though neuer (as aAmmia. Marcel. lib. 84. Romane Writer notes) any true friends, or well-willers to the Romane state, were the forwardest men to assist Titus in Hierusalems last and fatall siege; for the same reasons were the Nations round about them as earnestly bent to hinder the reedifying of Hierusalem, after the returne from captiuitie, as these were now to pull it downe, as fearing least this peoples good fortunes should rise againe with their Citie wals. But as Nehemia notes, Nehem. 6.16. after the enemies had heard that the wall was finished, they were afraid, and their courage fayled them, for they knew that this worke was wrought by God.

5 These and like obseruations make me thinke, it was neither skill in Astrologie, or profession of such Arts as the Magi vsed, (whereunto this of all people was least addicted) which first hatched that opinion of the Iewes descent from the Magi: Refert Diog laertius, in Prooemio. rather the later Heathen, ignorant of their originall, and not able to deriue that strange successe which did haunt them, or their demeanour answerable thereto, from ordinarie or naturall causes, referred all to Magicke spels, or some secret Art of diuination. So vnwilling is flesh and bloud to acknowledge such as they hate, for the beloued of the Lord; and so powerfull is the Prince of darkenesse, either to blind the hearts of the worldly wise, or to auert their eyes from beholding an vnpleasant truth, that if at any time the finger of God appeare in the deliuerance or good successe of his people, the infidell or naturall man ascribes such effects as Magicians (vnlesse vpon presumption of trauellers priuiledge amongst the ignorant) durst not arrogate to themselues, vnto Magicall or some other like Arts; because the corruption of their nature is more capable of such practises, than of true beleefe in God, and they more prone in distresse to flye vnto Sorceries or Magick charmes,
• ege Xiphilinum in libro Dionis 71. than with true faith and firme constancie to expect the deliuerance of the Lord by such meanes as the faithfull Israelites did. So when the Christian Legion had, by their prayers, relieued Antonius armie, readie to swound for thirst, with plentie of water, in as miraculous sort as Elias did sometime the hoast of Israel; the Heathens, acknowledging the effect for supernaturall, ascribed it to Arnuphis, the Egyptian Sorcerer, his acquaintance with Mercurie, and other supposed Gods of the ayre. In like sort the moderne Iew, acknowledging many wonders wrought by our Sauiour, takes it for a sufficient argument,Vide Munsterum in secundum caput Matth. Heb. That all of them were wrought by Magicke skill, onely because the Euangelist sayth, he had beene in Egypt; so is he blinded with wilfull malice, that he cannot see how, by this obiection hee layes all the wonders which Moses wrought, open to the like exception of Atheists, Infidels, and Heathen. For both Moses, in whom he trusts, and Abraham in whom he glories, and all the Patriarches, from whome the Iewes descended, had beene in Egypt, in ripe age, where our Sauiour came not, but in his infancie. As for his myracles, the testimonie of Moses,
and other Prophets, whose diuine authoritie is acknowledged by the Iew, shall euince them, wrought by the finger of God. In the meane time the estate of the Iewes since their death, sufficiently knowne to all the world, and foretold by them, shall manifest against the Atheist, that they all wrote by the spirit of God.

div.head: CHAP. V.
That all the Heathens obiections against, or doubts concerning the Iewes estate, are preuented or resolued by Iewish Writers.
div.p:
1 OVt of that which hath beene hitherto premised, this conclusion stands firme, supported both by forraine Writers obseruation, and these Iewes owne confession, That they were a people remarkable, for their vnusuall prosperitie and calamitie. I am fully persuaded it would haue giuen full satisfaction to any ingenuous Roman or later Heathen, that this was a people beloued of God, had they knowne as much as we doe: that all they could obiect in contempt of the Iewes, or their Religion, had beene conceiued before by the Assyrian and Babylonian, but falsified in the euent, fully answered by Iudaicall Writers, and plainely foretold by their Prophets; least such euents as occasioned others to contemne them, might haue proued temptations to the godly amongst this people, as if they had beene forsaken of their God. The dayes had beene, wherein the Babylonians had taken themselues for men, and their Idols for gods, as good as Rome had any; and these Iewes for as base a people as the world yeelded: They had gathered captiuitie as the sand,
Abac. 1.10. mocked the Kings, and made a scorne of the Princes, deriding euery strong Hold: and hence (as the Prophet foresaw) they were as readie as the Romanes to take a courage in transgressing and doing wickedly, imputing this their power vnto their God. But the Prophet is not herewith dismayed, nor tempted to thinke his Gods power was lesse than theirs; albeit, to shew himselfe a true Patriot of Israel, hee complaines of their intolerable presumption, which in due time he wel foresees should be abated. Art not thou of old, my Lord my God, mine holy one? We shall not die:
O Lord, thou hast ordained them for iudgement, and O God thou hast established them for correction. Thou art of pure eyes, and canst not see euill, thou canst not behold wickednesse: wherefore doest thou looke vpon the transgressors, and holdest thy tongue when the wicked deuoureth the man, that is more righteous than he? and makest men as the fishes of the sea, and as the creeping things, that haue no ruler ouer them? They take vp all with the angle, they catch it in their net, and gather it in their yarne, whereof they reioyce and are glad. Therefore they sacrifice vnto their net, and burne incense vnto their yarne, because by them their portion is fat, and their meat plenteous. Shall they therefore stretch out their net, and not spare continually to slay the Nations? No: he knew their time was limited, and other Nations, as Ieremie saith, When his time was come, were to serue themselues of him; though God at that time had exposed the Princes of Iudah to his violence, for their violent oppression of their brethren, as Habacuc expressely notes in the beginning of his fore-mentioned Prophecie. These Iewes, before the euent did proue the contrarie, were as incredulous they should bee brought into captiuitie by the Babylonian, or such foolish Idolaters, as the Romans were of their great prosperitie vnder Dauid or Salomon.
