And for to beat downe this proud humor in them, the Prophet Ezechiel foretels, That for their extreame crueltie the Lord would punish them by the most wicked of the Heathen: Make a chaine: for the land is full of the iudgement of bloud,
Ezech. 7.23. and the Citie is full of crueltie. Wherefore I will bring the most wicked of the Heathen, and they shall possesse their houses: I will also make the pompe of the mightie to cease, and their holy places shall be defiled. When destruction commeth, they shall seeke peace, and shall not haue it: Calamitie shall come vpon calamitie, and rumor shall be vpon rumor: then shall they seeke a vision of the Prophet, but the Law shall perish from the Priest, and counsell from the Ancient. And least any should maruaile, why God would so vse his chosen people, he giues the reason in the words immediatly following, because he was a God of iustice. The King shall mourne, and the Princes shall be clothed with desolation, and the hands of the people in the land shal be troubled: I will doe vnto them according to their wayes, and according to their iudgements will I iudge them, and they shall know that I am the Lord.

2 More particularly both Tullies obiection, concerning their ouerthrow and conquest, is directly answered; Strabo and Senecaes
doubt, concerning their thriuing in captiuitie, fully resolued; and Tacitus false imputations of their increase, sufficiently cleared by the Psalmist: Psal. 106.39. They were stained with their owne workes, and went a whoring with their owne inuentions: therefore was the wrath of the Lord kindled against his people, and he abhorred his owne inheritance, and he gaue them into the hand of the Heathen: and they that hated them were Lords ouer them. Their enemies also oppressed them, and they were humbled vnder their hand. Many a time did he deliuer them, but they prouoked him by their counsels, therefore they were brought downe by their iniquities. Had Tullie read thus much, he might haue bin fully satisfied, that it was not loue or hate of his immortall gods, which made the Romanes conquerors, the Iewes captiuate: but it was their loue to sinne, onely hatefull to their God, which brought them in subjection vnto the Romanes; and made Caesar, whom Tullie and other Romans hated, Lord ouer them, as they had bin ouer the Iewes. And if Strabo, Seneca, Tacitus, or others, that either enuied or maruelled at these Iewes prosperitie, had read what followes in the same Psalme, they had rested better satisfied with the reason that the Psalmist there giues, than with such as blundering Politicians guesse at: vers. 44. For although they had bin brought downe by their iniquitie, yet their God, who had giuen them into their enemies hand, saw when they were in affliction, and heard their cry. And he remembred his couenant towards them, and repented according to the multitude of his mercies, and gaue them fauour in the sight of all them that led them away captiues. The Psalmist had better vnderstanding of Gods dealing with these people, than Tullie and Strabo had; and in confidence of Gods mercies, which they had often tasted, he concludes with this prayer: vers 47. Saue vs, O Lord, our God, and gather vs from among the Heathen, that we may praise thy holy name, and glorie in thy praises. Though this godly Psalmist saw this people in greater distresse than they were in Tullies time, yet hee attributes not their captiuitie and oppression vnto any want of good will in their God towards them, but vnto their ingratitude towards him: for if they had beene thankfull vnto him, the blowes that light on them should haue beene spent vpon their enemies. But as another Psalmist complaines in the person of his God, Psal. 81.11. But my people would not heare my voice,
Psal. 81.11. vers. 12, 13, 14, 15, 16. and Israel would haue none of me. So I gaue them ouer vnto the hardnesse of their hearts, and they haue walked
in their owne counsels. O that my people would haue hearkened vnto me, and Israel had walked in my wayes, I would soone haue humbled their enemies, and turned my hand against their aduersaries: The haters of the Lord should haue beene subiect to them, and their time should haue endured for euer. I would haue fed them (saith the Lord) with the finest wheat, and with the honey out of the rocke would I haue satisfied thee.

3 This one place, to omit many other,Gods especiall fauors towards the Iewes, no way impeach his vnpartiall iudgements. abundantly proues the former assertion, That if this people had continued in well doing, all the Nations should continually haue wondered at their extraordinarie prosperitie. But here a Christian may as well doubt, as the Heathen wonder, Why Israel after so many transgressions, as the Author of the hundred and sixt Psalme complaines of, was not destroyed at once, as other great and mightie Nations had bin. For the more abundant fauours their fore-fathers had found, and the greater Gods blessings (layd vp for their posteritie) were, the greater was their ingratitude in rebelling, their rebellion it selfe so much more wilfully hainous; and alwaies the more wilfull or hainous any sinne is, the more grieuous, certaine, & more speedie punishment it deserues. How could that most just & holy one, which so often protesteth he respecteth no mens persons, spare this most vngratefull, stubborne, & rebellious people, longer than any other?

4 The full and necessarie consequence of these collections is thus much, and no more: The finall extirpation of these Iewes had bin accomplished many generations before it came to passe, had the Lord bin only iust, or respected onely their deserts, whom he so often preserued, when iustly he might haue destroyed them. But if wee looke farther into the waies of Gods prouidence, the true end and reason of destroying others, and preseruing them, wil appeare one & the same. For that suddaine execution of his justice vpon others, which did so much aduance his glorie, equally practised vpon them, had as greatly impeached it amongst the nations. This cause of their long preseruation the Lord himselfe assignes, Deut. 32.26.27. I haue said I would scatter them abroad, I would make their remembrance to cease from among men; saue that I feared the furie of the enemie, least their aduersaries should wax proud, & least they should say, Our high hand, and not the Lord, hath done all this. Againe, as the Lord was most iust, so was he most kind & mercifull towards all, euen towards the Gentiles, in these Iewes: for by their strange deliuerance & restauration
the other might haue learned, that their God was a God of Gods, and Lord of Lords, most worthie to be honored of all the world, as he himselfe addeth in the fore-cited place: Vers. 36, 37, 38, & 39. For the Lord shall iudge his people, and repent towards his seruants, when he seeth that their power is gone, and none shut vp in Hold, nor left abroad: when men shall say, Where are their Gods, their mightie God in whom they trusted, which did eat the fat of their sacrifices, and did drinke the wine of their drinke-offering? Let them rise vp and helpe you; let him be your refuge: Behold now, for I, I am he, and there is no gods with me. Thus, since these Iewes began first to be a Nation, as well the wane as the encrease of their estate; or (to vse our Apostles words) as well their diminution as abundance might haue yeelded the docile and well disposed greater riches, than the spoyles of their Cities and Countrey did the proud and mightie amongst the Gentiles. And albeit they oft times sinned more grieuously than others did, yet were there alwayes left some godly amongst this people, which in their distresse knew themselues, and could teach others the right way to repentance; of which the Heathen, one and other, were altogether ignorant. And this was an especiall cause, though subordinate to the former, of their long preseruation. For when they were not so extreame bad, as to continue in former sinnes, but vnfainedly called vpon the Lord in their distresse, he heard their prayers; and being once receiued to his, they found fauour at their enemies hands. So Salomon had obserued, When the wayes of a man please the Lord, he will make also his enemies at peace with him. The truth whereof we haue seene continually experienced in these Iewes, before our Sauiours time, though much degenerate from their auncestors. But their posteritie, as much degenerate from them as they from the other, goe as farre beyond the middle sort in punishment, as they came short of their first fore-fathers in all graces and fauours bestowed vpon them by their God. Though these (such I meane as liued since our Sauiours time) cry vnto the Lord, yet doth he not heare them, although their distresses haue beene more and more grieuous, many hundred yeares together, than their fore-fathers. P • o. 28. What is the reason? Because they haue turned their eares continually from hearing the Law, therefore their prayers are continually turned into sinne.

5 Thus though the alteration of the Iewish state be such, as all the world might wonder, and stand amazed at; such as would make the wisest heathen giddie, that should seeke to compasse the true causes thereof by politique search; yet vnto vs Christians, that haue the Oracles of our God, their estate cannot seeme strange; seeing nothing, good or bad, that hath befallen this people, from their first beginning to this present day, but is foretolde in the sacred storie, which hath continually proued it selfe as infallible a Prognostication for what is to come, as it is an authentike register of all things past.

6 The particular kalendars, wherin their good or dismall daies are distinguished, according to the diuersity of their ways, we may find Leuit. 26. and Deut. 28. After Moses had proposed extraordinary blessings, if they would walke in the Lawes which he had giuen them, hee threatneth them with plagues and calamities in their owne Land; as with bodily sickenesse, incursion of enemies, oppressions and spoyle of goods, strange ouerthrowes in battell, and fearefulnesse of heart. And if these would not reclaime them, then hee threatneth to punish them seauen times more according to their sinnes: as with barrennesse of soyle, prodigious famine, and scarcity of fruit. And yet if they hold on stil to work stubbornly against him, he threatneth to multiply the former plagues seuen times; by sending wild beasts among them, which should spoile them & destroy their cattell, and make them few in number, and your high-waies shal be desolate. The like multiplying of his plagues, for the increase of their stubbornenesse, hee reiterates twice againe ver. 23. to the 27. Yet, if by those you will not be reformed &c. hee increaseth all the former plagues seauen times againe, verse 28, 29, 31, 32, 33, and 36, 37, 38. The first and second degrees of the plagues threatned, were in part fulfilled in the dayes of Gedeon, Samson, Samuel, and Saul: The third likewise (by wilde beastes) wee see fulfilled in the dayes of Iehoram King of Israel, 2. Kings chap. 17. verse 25, 26. The fourth and fift likewise wee see in part fulfilled in the captiuitie of Israel in Iudah, in the dayes of Manasseh, Iehoiachim, and Tzedechiah; and in the time of Ptolomie the first, vnder Antiochus Epiphanes. Both their owne and other Stories, giue vs full Experiments of this Prophecie. As their stubbornenesse did increase, so Gods plagues here threatned did wax more grieuous:
these later calamities being, at the least, seuen times greater (both for extent and duraunce) than the former persecutions, which they suffered by the Philistims, Moabites, Aramites, and Ammonites. But the fifth and last plague, which containeth all the rest more than seuen times, was not accomplished till after our Sauiours death: after which time, all the rest (in part fulfilled before) are more than seuen times multiplied vppon them. In their former ouerthrowes or captiuities, they suffered the violence of warre, and oftentimes felt the extremitie of hostile lawes: but after these storms were past, so they would submit themselues vnto their conquerors, they vsually found (as was shewed before) more than ordinary fauour at their hands. But since our Sauiors death, the memory of their former plagues hath bin but an inuitation of the like, or worse; their continuall bad vsage prescribing the lawfulnesse of their abuse. In the 28. of Deuteronomy, the extraordinary blessings, and plagues which were to ouertake this people, either in their life or death, are more exactly calculated. And albeit their blessings might haue beene more, and more admirable, than the curses that haue befallen them: yet Moses (it seemes) foreseeing, or fearing what would be, rather than hoping the best that might be, is almost foure times as long in calculating their plagues, as their blessings. So haue the miseries of these later Iewes beene foure times as long, as the prosperitie of their worthy auncestours; if wee would take an exact measure of the one, from the sacred histories before the Babylonish captiuity, of the later from experience and relation of Iewish or Heathen writers. And yet no plague, either knowne by experience, or related by any Writers, but is euidently foretold by Moses. His particular praedictions shall be inserted, as the euents shall giue the occasion throughout this Discourse. To beginne with that most horrible plague, Deut. 28.53. &c. And thou shalt eate the fruit of thy body, euen the flesh of thy sonnes and thy daughters, which the Lord thy God hath giuen thee, during the siege and straitnesse, wherein thy enemy shall inclose thee. So that the man that is tender and exceeding daintie among you, shall be grieued at his brother, and at his wife that lieth in his bosome, and at the remnant of his children, which he hath yet left. For feare of giuing vnto any of them of the flesh of his children, whome he shall eate, because he hath nothing left him in that siege and straitnes,
wherein the enemy shall besiege thee in all thy Citties. The tender and dainty woman among you, which neuer could venture to set the soale of her foote on the ground (for her softnesse and tendernesse) shall be grieued at her husband that lieth in her bosome, and at her sonne, and at her daughter, and at her after birth, that shall come out from betweene her feet; and at her children which she shall beare. For when all things lacke she shall eate them secretly, during the siege and straitnes, wherein thine enemy shall besiege thee in thy Cities. This prophecie we see fulfilled, to an haires breadth, in Vespasians time.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
The fulfilling of Moses and others Prophecies touching the desolation of Iewry, and destruction of Ierusalem: and the signes of the time, witnessing Gods wonderfull hand therein.
div.p:
1 SEeing that part of Tacitus is lost, whence we might haue knowne more, concerning their calamitie, than we can find now in heathen writers, we must take the conclusions, answerable to Moses praedictions, from Iosephus a Iew by birth, no way partiall for Christians. And his conclusions (to omit Moses his authority or other inducements) can not seeme improbable, from such premisses, as the Romane writers haue confirmed; though little intending such inferences, as we now make from them. Doe the calamities of those Iewes, related by Iosephus and Eusebius, seeme strange? They iustly may, if wee consider this people as naturall or ordinary men, not as paternes of GODS extraordinarie iudgements. Straunge might theyr iudgements seeme, and incredible to the Romanes or worldly-wise, vnlesse other circumstances of that Time, witnessed by the Romanes themselues, were as rare. But if, by the Romanes opinion, euerie vnusuall effect in Nature did portend some such strange euent in humane affaires: why should not the wisest of them in that Age, expect some extraordinary or miraculous matters of
Vespasians time? yet, excepting what he did vnto those stubborne Iewes, his other acts were but ordinarie, and required no pompous or magnificent prologues: whereas many signes, either foreshewing his exaltation to the Empire, or confirming his right vnto it, or authority in managing it, were such as no heathen, I think, hath euer heard of before, but most consonant vnto Gods wonted signes in Israel, whilest their Kings did prosper. Seeing the wisedome of the wise, and vnderstanding of the prudent amongst this people, had beene long hid, as the Lord had threatned by his Prophet Esay chap. 29. and they themselues had complained, We see not our tokens, we haue not one Prophet more: Whence was it that Iosephus the Iew should become a prophet for Vespasians good, who had alreadie brought much, likely to bring more harme vpon his Country and him, now captiued, and imprisoned by him? So Et vnus ex nobilibus captiuis Josephus, cum conijceretur in vincula, constantissimè asseuerauit sore, vt ab eodem breui solueretur, veram iam imperatore. Sueton. in Vesp. It is not probable that eyther Suetonius, Tacitus, or Dion should take this testimony from Iosephus (though he relate it) but frō the Romanes that were eare witnesses of it: It is lesse probable againe that Ioseph should learne this from any prophecies concerning Christ, for he knew Vespasian was no Iew • rather God made him as a mouth to those other dumbe signes which Roman writers relate, by his appoyntment foreshewing Ʋespasians exaltation; as Dion notes. For speaking of other signes he saith: S • d h • c quidem omnia egebat interpretatione. At Iosephus, natione Iudaeus ante abeo captus constrictus{que} vinculis rideus ait; Nunc quidem me vincies, post annum autem sol • es, quum fueris imperator factus. Igitur Vespasianus vt alij quid • m, ad principatum natus erat. Dion. hist. Rom. lib. 66. Ʋid. Josephum ipsum.
Suetonius and Tacitus (no factious friends for Iews or Christians) tell vs, Iosephus did solace himselfe at his Commission with this; that Vespasian the Emperour should shortly release him. Though Vespasian at that that time was farre enough from such hopes, in the iudgement of the Romane state, which had appoynted him Generall in the Iewish warres, becauseSuetonius in Vespasia • , verba citantur prox. sequ. pag. his meane birth, and obscure familie, did minister least suspition of affecting the splendour and Dignitie of the Romane Empire, if hee should proue Conquerour. Did the rest of his vnruely Countrey-men, conceit any such matter of Vespasian, as Iosephus did; Then had they not continued stubborne as they did. But although Israell knew him not, and his people had no vnderstanding, yet the dumbePrandente eo quendam, tanis extrarius triclinio manum humanam intulit coenante ru • sus, bos arator d • cuss • iugo, triclinium • rup • t, ac sugatis ministris, quasi defessus, procidit ad ipsos accumb • ns ped • s ceruicem{que} submisit. Apud Iudaeam Carmeli oraculum consulentem, ita confirmauere sortes, vt quicquid cogitaret animo volueret{que} quantumlibet magnum, id esse prouenturum pollicerentur. Sueton. in Vesp • siano. Oxe knew him to be his owner, and appoynted Lord of the earth, and in signe of his submission to him, hauing cast off his yoake, ranne furiously into the roome where hee sate at supper;
where affrighting his attendances from him, he strait prostrates himselfe before his feet (as if he had bin wearie) offring his necke to his clemencie. Oracles had ceased in Iewry (at least from speaking any good vnto the Iewes) yet the Oracles of Carmel assure Vespasian of good successe in all that he should set his hand vnto.

2 As these, and many other praesignifications were more than naturall, so the means of his aduancement (if we respect only the purpose of men) were meerely casuall nor is it possible for the Atheist to imagine their concurrence contriued by policie.

3 But herein wee may cleerely see Gods couenant of exalting this people, and humbling their foes, quite inuerted; all the plagues threatned to such as bare ill will to Sion, lights on her friends and inhabitants, all the blessings promised to such as prayed for Ierusalems Peace, are heaped vpon them that worke her ruine. More particularly do they verifie that Prophecy of Moses, Deut. 28. v. 43. The stranger that is amongst you shall climbe vp on high, and thou shalt come downe beneath alow. For these children of the kingdom, taking violent but false hold vpon Gods truest promises, doe, by their vnseasonable desire of exalting themselues aboue the nations, hoise him vp to highest dignitie, that was ordaind to pluck them downe from their seate, and bring them below all other people. The maner of it was thus.

4Percrebiter at orient • toto vetus & constans opinio: esse in satis, vt co •• mpore Judaeâ profectirerum p • tirentur. Id de Imperatore Romano, quantuus cuentu p • stea patuit, praedictum, Iudaei ad se trahentes, rebella • unt: coesoq •• Pr • posito, legatum insuper S •• tae consularem suppetias serentem rapta aquilâ sugauerunt. Ad hunc motum comprimendum cum exerc ••• aux •• ar • , & non instrenuo duce, cui tamen • uto tanta res committeretur opus esset, ips • potis • imum dilectus est, vt indu •••• expertae, nec metuendus vllo modo ob numilitatem generis ac nominis. Suetonius • n Vespasiano. There was a constant opinion through the East, that Iewry about this time should bring forth the monarch of the world. In confidence of which prophecie, the Iews (as the Roman Writers obserue) did rebell. Vespasian (otherwise likely to haue liued in danger, died in obscuritie and disgrace, whereunto Nero had designed him) appointed, for reasons afore alleadged, to manage these wars, gets renowne f • r his good seruice, among the Romans, good wil of the Esterne nations; & vpon Neroes death and ciuil broiles thence insuing; partly by promise of assistance from the Parthian, partly by other vnexpected occurrents; had the Empire thrust vpō him, otherwiseNec tamen • q •• dquam ante tentauit; promptiss • mis atque etiam instantibus suis, qu • m solicitatus quorundam & igroto • um & absentium fortuito fauore. Suet. ibidem. backward of himselfe to entertaine hopes, suggested to him from heauen by many wonderfull signes and tokens.

Yet after all this, being made Emperor on a suddaine, before hee could bethink himselfe what belonged to so high a place, he wanted (Sueton. paulo posteae. Antoritas & quasimaeiest • s quaedam, vt sc •••• t inopinato & adhuc nouo principi decrat: h • c quoq • e acces • it. as the Historian notes) Authority and Maiesty to countenance his proceedings: and these againe are confirmed vnto him, at his first entrance into the Empire, by meanes more miraculous than the former. Since Rome beganne was it not heard, that any Romane had opened the eyes of the blinde; vnlesse this man had beene from God, he could haue done nothing. Why then do the Heathen rage, & the people murmure a vaine thing against God, and his annointed the Christ, as if hee had not healed him which was borne blind, with spittle? when as Vespasian, late elected Emperour, did cure one desperately blinde, by spitting vpon his eies; or whence came that vertue into this new Emperors feet, that he should heale a lame and witherd thigh, by treading vpon it?Ae • timari à medius iubet Ʋ • spasianus an ta • is coecitas ac d • bi • tas ope humani superabiles foret. Medici variè disserere. Hinc nō exosam vim luminis & redituram sip • llerentur obstantiat illi elapsos in prauum artus, si salubris vis adhibeatur posse integrari Id fortasse corde Deis, & diuino ministerio principem electum: deni{que} patrati remedij gloriam penes Caesarem; irriti ludibrium penes miseros sore Igitur Vespasianus cuncta fortunae suae parêreratus, nec quid quam vltrà incredibile, laeto ipse vultu, erectâ quae astabat multitudine, iusta exequitor. Statim conuersa ad vsum manus, ac caeco reluxit dies. Vtrum{que} qui interfuere nunc quoque memorant, postquam nullum mendacio pretium. Tacitus h stor. lib. 4. Suetonius hath the same story with the same circumstances. Both these effects were well knowne vnto the most iudicious Romane Writers of those times, so constantly auouched by them, as can leaue no place for suspition in ages following.

5 What shall we Christians say to these things? Only this; In both these Cures there was the finger of God, pointing out Vespasian to the world, as Seeing they had reiected the true Son and heire of Dauid, the Lord raised vp Vespasian (as it were an adopted sonne and liuely patterne of olde Dauid both in meanenesse, manner of exaltation and humility) to rule them with an yron rodde, and feed them with the sword. Suetonius Character of his patience and disposition, hath a perfect pelish of Dauids Spirite. Mediocritatem pristinam ne{que} dissimulauit vnquam ac frequenter etiam prae se tulit. Quin & conantem quosdum originem F aui • generis ad Conditores Reat • ns cumitem{que} Herculis cuius monumentum exstat via Salaria referre irrisit vltro. Adeo{que} nihil ornamentorum ext ••• se • us cupi • è appetiuit, vt triumph die fatigatus tarditate & toedio pompae non reticuerit: merito se plecti, qui triumphum quasi aut debitum maioribus suis ant speratum vnquam sibi, tam ineptè senex concupisset. Sueton. in Vespasian. Christs right hand appoynted for some extraordinary & peculiar seruice, euen to inflict the plagues foretold by him, vpon these Iewes, which had reuiled, traduced, and crucified the Lord of glory for the like, and infinite other farre greater miracles wrought amongst them. These strange calamities, had they befallen in Neroes, or other like Emperours time, might haue beene attributed to their cruell disposition: but that Vespasian for his naturallNeque cade cuiusquam vnquam laetatus, quam iustis supplicijs illa chryma uit etiam & ingem •• t. Suetonius in Vespasiano. inclination an other Moses, scarce prouocable
to reuenge practize of treason against his person in priuate men, should worke that strange desolation vppon a whole Land, hath this signification, that hee was Gods instrument onely in this businesse; what hee did, hee did impelled by him, not of his owne motion or inclination. And because hee hadConuenit inter omnes tam certum eum de suá suorumque genitura semper suisse: vt post assiduas in se coniurationes ausus sit affirmare Senatat, aut filios sibi successuros, aut neminem. Dicitur etiam vid • sse q • ndam per quietem stateram in m • dia parte vest • buli palatinae domus positam examine aequo: cum in alterâ parte • la • d us & Nero starent: in alterâ ipse ac filij. Nec res fefell • t: quando totidem annis, pari{que} temporis spatio vbique imperauervnt. Suetonius in fine Vespasian. diligētly executed that which was right in Gods eies, and had done vnto these Iewes, according to all things that were in Gods heart, he had (by what reuelation God best knoweth) Iehues blessing sealed vnto him, That his sonne should sit vpon his throne: so confident was hee in this perswasion, as after the discouerie of many, to scorne all Conspiracies, though daily intended against him; auouching still, either his sonnes, or none, must succeede him in the Empire, as both of them did. Though the later (much degenerate from so worthy a Father, most dislike vnto his noble brother) was most vnworthie, and vncapable of so high a place, but onelie from his Fathers deserts, which GOD had ordayned, should be rewarded with this honour. Had either of his sonnes rendered according to the reward bestowed vppon them, more Scepters had sprung from the Flauian stocke: but as it grew apace, so did it quickly fade; Titus, the fairest branch to all mens seeming, beeing plucked off, to his great hearts griefe, in the Blossome, for what secret sinne, GOD knoweth best, this one was grieuous enough, to haue deserued a more grieuous death, that apprehending his Fates approach, hee durst so confidently looke Heauen in the face, and expostulate his vntimely death as vniust, seeing hee neuer had offended the sacred Powers thereof but onelie once. The Signes of those Times were extraordinarie, could the Romanes haue rightly obserued them: but these great Conquerours were taken with their captiues errour in not discerning, or mis-applying them. As the Spring Sunne, which naturally reuiueth all other liuing Creatures, often times prepareth such humane bodies as are fullest of life and bloud, but most neglectiue of the opportunitie of taking Physicke, or vsing diet conuenient for that season, to
hote and desperate diseases, neuer perceiued in their Summers growth, vntill they be ripe of death in the Autumne: so albeit the Sunne of Righteousnesse, whose comming into the world, was to giue life vnto it, did first arise in Iewrie; yet by her childrens confidence in their wonted temper, so whole and sound vnto their seeming, that of all other people, they onlie needed no Physition, the verie Beames of sauing Health did secretly dispose their euill disposed hearts to violent death, which burst out in the latter end or Autumne of that Age, wherein hee appeared. For that Generation with whome our Sauiour Christ Iesus conuersed on earth, was not fully past, vntill this people beganne to swell with insolent and prowde hopes of soueraignetie ouer others, and by their vntimely prouocation of the Romanes bring suddayne destruction vppon themselues; as stowt and full bodies, by violent and vnseasonable exercises, are soonest brought downe from the height of their strength, vnto the graue. The Romanes agayne, seeing these Iewes defeated, and themselues possessed of their hopes, (Vespasian beeing called to the Empire during these warres, which Titus his sonne did gloriously finish, to the vtter ruine of that Nation) thinke sure their Gods had beene more potent than the GOD of the Iewes, and apply the Prophecie,Suetonius in Vespasiano & Tacitus, hist. li. 5. Vid annot. ex Tacito infra paragr: 7. & ex Sueton. supra 4. meant of Christ, vnto Vespasian, as if hee had beene that Monarch of the World, which, according to the common receiued opinion throughout the East, was at this time to arise in Iewrie. So doeth the God of this World still blinde the eyes of the worldly-wise with faire shewes or earthly shadowes of heauenly things, that they can not, or care not to looke into the bodie or substance of Diuine mysteries, for whose representation onely those are giuen; otherwise vncapable of any cause eyther in Nature, Reason, or Policie. Vespasian the Emperour (indeede) was the second type or shadow of the Messiah, that great Monarch and Prince of Peace, whose endlesse Kingdome shall put downe all warres for euer. For seeing by the fall of these Iewes, as the Apostle Saint Paul saieth, Saluation is come vnto the Gentiles, it pleased the wisedome of our GOD, to haue their destruction solempnized with the selfe-same signes, that his birth had beene, which brought foorth life vnto the world.

For immediatly after their fatall ouerthrow by Titus, Ianus had his Temple shut, and Peace a Temple erected by Vespasian. Thus Diuine suggestions effect no more in most mens thoughts, than diurnall intention of minde doth in hard students broken sleepes; which vsually set the soule a working, seldome finding any distinct representation of what shee seekes, though contenting her selfe oft-times for that season with some pleasant phantasme, as much different from the true nature of that shee hunts after, as the cloudes, which Ixion imbraced, were from Iuno. Vespasians secret instinct in this deuotion did aime no doubt (as it was directed by all signes of the time) at the true Prince of peace, but was choaked and stifled in the issue or passage, and his intent blinded in the apprehension, by the palpable and grosse conceipts of Romish Idolatrie, wherein hee had beene nuzled; as mens in-bredde desire of true happinesse is vsually taken vp and blind-folded by such pleasant sensible obiectes, as they most accustome themselues vnto. And yet, God knowes, whether this vertuous Emperours last hopes were inwardly rooted in pride and presumption of heart; or rightly conceiued there, were onely brought foorth amisse. As if a man should first apprehend the state of blessednesse or regeneration in a dreame, the representation of it would bee grosse, though the apprehension sound. Quite contrarie to his sonnes disposition, when hee himselfe apprehends death comming vppon him, which the Physitians and Astronomers could not perswade him to beware of, hee solaced himselfe with this saying; Now shall I be a God: his inward hopes of a celestiall state after this life might (for ought that any man knowes) be true and sound, and the representation onely tainted with the Romanes grosse conceipt.

6 But whatsoeuer became of him in that other world; his entrance into this his continuance herein, and departure hence, were in all the worlds sight of vnusuall and extraordinarie obseruation. The disposition of the times, by the most irreligious amongst the Romanes, were referred to Fates or diuine powers, who had not graced the birth, life and death, or long flourishing raigne of Augustus with halfe so many tokens of their presence on earth, or prouidence ouer humane affaires. What effect,
or issue, can the Romane assigne answerable vnto them? Rome could not inuite the nations to come and see, whether any prosperitie were like hers: for hers had beene farre greater and of longer continuance, than now vnder Vespasian; who was suddenly called away by aDion. comet from Heauen, and Augustus his Sepulchre opening of it own accord to welcome him to his graue. Wherat then did all these signes point? They should haue bin as a new starre to lead the wise-men of the West vnto Hierusalem; now crying out of the dust vnto the carelesse Romane; Haue yee no regard all yee that passe by?
Lamen. 1. v. 12. Behold and see if there be any sorrow like vnto my sorrow which is done vnto me, wherewith the Lord hath afflicted me in the day of his fierce wrath. It was not Titus and Vespasian that had afflicted her, they were but his deputies, that was Lord of Sion, who had decreed what they effected.His de causis vter{que} imperatoris •• ment obtinuit, neute • tamen Iudaicus co nominatus est, licet alia mulla, vt par erat tam magna parta victoria, atque imprimis arcus triumphales eis decreti sunt. Dion li. 66. For this cause did neither the father nor the sonne take the name of Iudaicus, albeit the difficultie of the warre, begun by the father, and the famousnesse of the victorie atchieued by the sonne (according to the custome of the Romans obserued by them in their triumphs and other solemnities) did solicite them hereunto. For what victorie gotten by any Roman was like vnto this either for the multitude of the slaine, or the captiues? Nothing in this kinde could seeme strange vnto the politician, if it had proceeded from Tacitus pen. But Satan, it seemes, by Gods permission, hath called in that part of Tacitus as a booke too dangerous for his schollers to read; least; giuing credence vnto it, they might beleeue him lesse, and Christians, more in many other points; and yet praised bee the name of our gracious God, who enuies no man the truth, and hath left vs abundant records of this storie; all answerable to his sacred word, and prophecies of old concerning Hierusalem. From that part of Tacitus, which is left, wee may gather, how consonant his conclusions would haue beene vnto that faithfull, and most ingenious Historian Iosephus, with whom hee iumps in these particulars; That this people were of bodiesSo are they not now. healthfull and able, their CitieFons perennis aquae, cauati sub terra montes: et piscinae seruandis imbribus, praeuiderant conditores ex diuersitate morum, crebra bella, inde cuncta, quamuis aduersus longum obsidium; et a Pompeio expugnatis, metus at{que} vsus pleraque monstrauere. Atque per auaritiam Claudianorum temporum, empto iure muniendi, struxere muros in pace tanquam ad bellum: magna collunie, & caterarum v • bium clade aucti. Tacit. Hist lib. 5. The writers of the Sacred storie complaine of defect of water in Hierusalem since that time. Vid. Strab. lib. 16. Est •••• s saxosus aquis ipse quidem abundans. This barrennesse was onely about Hierusalem, for Tacitus acknowledgeth the fertilitie of Iudaea. exceeding strong, euery way well prouided against long siege
Which assertion would haue ministred suspition to such as measure all Stories by rules of policie, vnlesse some Romane writer had auouched it, seeing Pompey had razed the Citie-walles, and Sossius had taken it by force in Augustus time; since continuing in subiection vnto the Romanes vntill the last and fatall rebellion. But Tacitus telleth vs, that these Iewes made their benefite of Claudius his couetousnesse, and purchased licence to fortifie the Citie in time of peace against warre: during which it grew more populous than before, by the reliques of other ruinated Cities resorting vnto it. And albeit hee differ from Iosephus in the number of the besieged; yet hee acknowledgeth sixe hundred thousand of all sorts; the women as resolute as the men; armour and munition enough for as many as could; and yet more in this people that durst vse and manage them, than could bee expected in such a number. Their seditious, and factious, their stubborne and desperate mindes against God and man, and their owne soules, neglectiue of fearefull signes from Heauen, and other prodigious tokens foretelling their desolation, are pathetically described by the same writer. The preparations likewise on Titus his part wee may gather from him, to bee as great as any Romane euer vsed. His armie, at the first approach into the Citie, thought skorne to expect the helpe of famine to make the besieged yeelde; and yet after one or two assaults made to like purpose, enforced to desist, vntill all the engines of batterie, either of auncient or moderne inuention, were made readie. All these circumstances wee haue fully set downe in this fragment of Tacitus which is left.

7 Were that register of Hierusalems tragicall funerals (to vse his words) now extant as entire, as hee intended it, what other conclusion from the former premises could wee expect, than such woe and miseries as Moses and Ieremie had foretold, and others haue related to vs? Iosephus (as if Ieremiahs spirit had directed his penne) saith their miserie did farre surpasse all plagues inflicted vpon any Nation, either by God or man. The multitude of Iurie dead in the warres, was equall to the number of liuing men in Israell vnder King Dauid,
when Iacobs posteritie florished most, besides fiftie thousand taken captiues. The number (albeit he maketh it eleuen hundred thousand) cannot seeme strange, if wee consider the confluence of this people from all Nations almost vnder heauen vnto Hierusalem at their Passeouer. Dion telleth vs, that besides the naturall inhabitans of Iewrie, strangers, not onely of Iewish progenie, but such as obserued their rites and customes, did flock to the Cities defence, both from those parts of the Romane Empire, through which they were scattered, and from the Countries beyond Euphrates not subiect to the Romanes: consonant herein to Iosephus, where hee telleth vs that the greatest part of the slaine were strangers, but most of Iewish progenie. The whole Nation (to vse his words) was shut vp by fates, as in a prison, or to speake more significantly, foyled by the Romanes in the field: they were driuen into the Citie as into a slaughter house. And heere the Psalmists curse beginneth to seize vpon the nation, that which should haue beene for their good proues the occasion of their fall: the effect of Gods blessing vpon Abraham proues a plague to his seede: the huge number, wherewith God had multiplied them, which had late made them swell with hopes of victorie in the open field, brings grieuous famine suddenly vpon them once inclosed in the Citie: and famine no sooner got within the walles, but lets in her fellow-messengers of Gods wrath; first breeding the pestilence by the carkases of the famished, then disposing the bodies of the liuing to receiue this and such other loathsome infectious diseases, as hunger and the huge multitude of the besieged in such a strait place would quickly breed; and yet they so desperatly set to increase these miseries, as euen in their greatest penurie to receiue fugitiues from Titus Campe. For, as Dion storieth, diuerse of his souldiers fled to the besieged, being partly wearied of the difficult siege, partly animated thereto, by a rumour bruted throughout the Romane armie, that this citie could not be taken.

7 Thus all occasions conspire to worke them woe whom God will plague. The generall perswasion of the East, that Iewrie, about this time, should bring foorth the Monarch of the world, ministers matter for their false prophets to worke vpon: and from their trust in their Prophets, it was that neither the present
aduersitie which they felt, nor prodigious signes from heauen could disswade or terrifie the seditious from their enterprise vnhappily vndertaken. God (no doubt) had so disposed, that the Romaine Souldiers should dispaire of victorie, to giue countenance to these false Prophets, and make these cast-a-waies, who still delighted most in lies, more confident in the waies of death. Though the signes, recorded byTacitus concurring with Iosephus in relation of those horrible signes addeth: Pauci in metum trahebant: pluribus • e suasio inerat, antiquis Sacerdotum literis cōtin • ri, co • pso tempore fore, vt valesceret orient profecti{que} Iudaea rerum potirentur, quae anibages Ʋespasianū ac Titū praedixerant. Sed vulgo Ier. 10.2. More humana capidinis, sibi tantam fatorum magnitudinem interpretati, ne aduersis quidem ad vera mutabantur. Tacit. Hist. lib. 5. Vnto all the former mischiefes these did accrew: Praelia, dolus, incendia inter ipsos, & magna vis frumenti ambusta. Tacit. Hist. lib. 5. Cum{que} vicina quaedam aedeficia succendissent, velut hac quoque via Romanos, etiamsi maxime circulo illo potirentur, ab vlteriori progressu reiecturi: simul & ipsum destruxere murū & inuiti munitionem, qua templum includebatur, exusserunt. Ita Romanis aditus ad Templum patefactus suit. Tacitus and Iosephus, might seeme fearefull, yet their interpretation was ambiguous: they might as well menace their enemies harme, as their destruction; howsoeuer to regard them much might argue Heathenish superstition; and in discreet auoidance of superstition, makes hypocriticall Professors of true religion preposterously stubborne in imitation of true confidence. They could pretend the Prophets admonition: Learne not the waies of the Heathen, and be not afraide for the signes of heauen, though the Heathen be afraide of such. For the customes of the people are vaine; and hence assume his resolution to themselues paueant illi, ne autem paueas tu; Let the idolatrous Heathen tremble and quake, but why should Israell bee afraid at these apparitions of their God? Or if a man would haue measured all by politike obseruations, it was more likely the Romaines should haue forsaken the siege, than the besieged haue fallen into their handes. But God was against them, and they could not be for themselues. For, as Dion notes, (which I thinke Iosephus omitteth) they themselues, by making way for their more commodious defence, did (against their will) demolish the chiefe muniment of the Temple; at which breach the Romaines entred, but not without some stay, amated only with reuerence of the place. Nor did the successe answere to their resolution in the assault (albeit they were farre more in number than the defendants) vntill Titus commanded part of the Temple to be set on fire. But then, as the same Author witnesseth, some offered their bodies for sheaths vnto the Romaines swords; some killed their fellowes, requited instantly with like kindnesse from them againe; some lept into the fire; all accompted it their happinesse to perish with the Temple.

8 The Lord had often professed his dislike vnto their solemne feasts, and his loathing of their sacrifices; both fully manifested
in this their last calamitie, such as the stench of their dead was now to their polluted senses, such had the abhomination of their sweetest incense long beene to his holinesse, now to bee purged with the Priests owne bloud, sacrificed in the flames and ruines of the Temple: the Citie, as oft before, was now taken vpon the Sabaoth day. Other particular miseries, described by Iosephus and Eusebius, I leaue for this time to the Readers priuate meditations: desirous only in these generalities, to iustifie theirs or other Ecclesiasticall writers reports, against all suspitions cast vpon them by Atheists or Infidels, from the testimonie of such as Infidelitie it selfe cannot suspect for partiall. Both sorts afforde vs euident documents of the diuine truth of Scripture; and might afford vs more than we are a-ware off, were we better acquainted with the ancient manner of interpreting Scriptures amongst the Iewes, in our Sauiours and his Apostles time: of which hereafter. If now vpon occasions of these relations concerning Ierusalems last day, and the signes of the times ensuing, I interpret one or two places otherwise, than such as are most followed in our times doe, the Christian Reader, I hope, will grant me pardon, vpon promise of such satisfaction as shall befit one ingenuous Christian to expect of an other to be made; when I shall come to explicate the diuers kinds of prophecies amongst Gods people, with the right manner of their interpretations.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
The fulfilling of our Sauiours prophecie, Mat. 24. with others, concerning the times ensuing Ierusalems destruction.
div.p:
1 REading Iosephus, I cannot but acknowledge Hieremiahs lamentation, as well for a prophecie of these late times vnder Vespasian, and Titus, as an historie or elegie of the miseries that had befallen Ierusalem by Nebuchadnezzar. The Lord, I know, had then done that which he had purposed: but now more properly he hath fulfilled his word that he had determined of old time; Lament. 2.17. & sequ. he hath throwne downe and not spared, he hath caused thine enemies to reioyce ouer thee, and set vp the horne of thine aduersaries. Arise, crie
in the night in the beginning of the watches: powre out thine heart like vnto water before the face of the Lord, lift vp thine hand towards him for the life of thy yong children, that famish for hunger in all the corners of the streets. These wordes perhaps were meant, in diuers measures, of both calamities; but the complaint following, of the later only vnder Titus: Behold, O Lord,
Lament. 2. and consider to whom thou hast done thus. Shall the women eate their fruit, and children of a span long: shall the Priest and the Prophet be slaine in the Sanctuarie of the Lord; the yong and the old lie on the ground? My Virgins, and my yong-men are fallen by the sword: thou hast slaine them in the day of thy wrath: thou hast hilled and not spared. Thou hast called as in a solemne day my terrors round about; so that in the day of the Lords wrath none escaped or remained. Those that I haue nourished and brought vp hath mine enemie consumed.

2 Many particulars, here set downe by Ieremie, are not so much as once intimated by the sacred storie, which describes the siege by Nebuchadnezzar. But no calamitie either intimated by any historicall relations of those times, or prefigured in Ieremies cōplaint, but in this later siege by Titus, is most exactly fulfilled: as if the Lord had but sowne the seedes of destruction and desolation by Nebuchadnezzar; which now come to their ful growth & ripenesse, this people must reape according to the full measure of their iniquitie. They are as drie stubble, and the Romans as a consuming fire. Nebuchadnezzars Host perhaps slew some, but had no occasion to make a generall massacre in the Temple, destitute of defendants ere it was taken the King and his greatest Commanders being first fled into the wildernesse; nor was it destroied vntill the heate of warre was past, and most of the people led into captiuitie. But whilest in this later destruction by Titus, it fell by the furious heate and brunt of Warre, the number of such, as were either willing or forced to end their daies with it, was of all sorts exceeding great: and which was most miserable, many who had taken their farewell of life & had bid death welcome, reuiued againe to renew their more than deadly sorrowes, & to reiterate their bitter complaints, which this lamentable accidēt could only teach them to act aright, and vtter with such tragicall and hideous accent, as was be fitting a calamitie so strange and fearefull as neuer had been knowne before. Euen such as famine had caused to faint, hauing
their vocall instruments clung together, and their eies more than halfe closed vp with death, vpon sight or noise of the Temples crackling in its last and fatall fire, rowsed vp their spirits and resumed their wonted strength, to proclaime vnto all neighbour-Regions in shrill and lowdest out-cries; That there was neuer any sorrow like vnto this sorrow wherewith the Lord had afflicted them in the day of his fierce wrath, and yet they blow the fire which it had kindled, ventilating and inlarging the deuouring flame (whose extinction the abundance of their bloud did otherwise seeme to threaten) by violent breathing out their last breath vnto it. The gastly confusion of this fearefull spectacle and hideous noise are so liuely expressed by Iosephus, and others, that they may well serue the Christian Reader, as a mappe of hellish miserie. I only prosecute the fullfilling of Ieremies prophecie,Joseph. lib. 7. c. 8. De bello Iudaic. in particulars related by Iosephus: as of the womans eating her child, a thingSo the circumstance of his relation plainly showes neuer heard of in that or any Nation before: of the Priests slaughter both in the Temple, and after the destruction of it. For Titus, otherwise inclined to mercie, seeing it consumed by fire, which he sought by all meanes to saue, commanded such of the Priests, as had escaped the flame, in a by-roome adioyning, to be executed, telling them, it was fit they should perish with the Temple, for whose sake, might it haue stood, hee willingly would haue saued their liues. Againe, the massacre of the promiscuous multitude of women and children, vnfit for Warre, are particularly described with all the circumstances by Iosephus in the eleuenth Chapter of his seuenth Booke: Cap. 11. lib. 7. of sixe thousand perswaded by a false Prophet to repaire vnto the Temple, there to expect signes from God of their deliuerance, not one Man, Woman, or Child escaped.

3 Thus Moses fore-showes the grieuous plagues, which hung ouer this Nations head, but then a-farre off: Ieremie after points out the very place where they shall fall; our Sauiour Christ only knew the distinct period of time, Mat. 24. Luke 21. wherein both the former prophecies should be accomplished. I will not trouble the Reader with rehearsall of particular calamities fore-told by him; their obseruation is alreadie made vnto his hand by Eusebius, and will apply themselues, being compared with Iosephus; so perhaps will not some places of Scripture following, though
as much concerning the same times. For the better vnderstanding of which we must call to mind, what was obserued before; That Hierusalem was the Lords owne seate, and the Iewes a people set a-part by him, and distinguished of purpose from others, to exemplifie his mercie and iustice in their prosperitie and distresse. Consequent hereunto his pleasure was, that in the desolation of Iurie, and destruction of the Temple, other Nations should bee put in minde of their mortalitie, and not thinke in their hearts that these were greater sinners than any other Nation; but rather that he who plagued them was Lord of the whole earth, as well as Iewrie; that the like and more fearefull iudgements did hang ouer their heads, vnlesse they would learne by the knowne calamities of this people, to auoide them. So saith the Lord to all the earth without exception: Iere 25.29. For loe I beginne to plague the Citie where my name is called vpon, and should you goe free? yee shall not goe quit: for I will call for a sword vpon all the inhabitants of the earth, saith the Lord of Hosts. Therefore prophecie thou against them all these wordes, and say vnto them; The Lord shall roare from aboue, and thrust out his voice from his holy habitation: he shall roare vpon his habitation, and crie aloude, as they that presse the grapes, against all the inhabitants of the earth. The sound shall come to the ends of the earth: for the Lord hath a controuersie with the Nations, and will enter into iudgement with all flesh, and he will giue them, that are wicked, to the sword. And thus saith the Lord God of Hosts; behold a plague shall goe forth from Nation to Nation, and a great whirle-winde shall bee raised from the coasts of the earth, and the flame of the Lord shall be at that day, from one end of the earth euen vnto the other end of the earth; they shall not be mourned, neither gathered nor buried, but shall bee as the dung vpon the ground. Howle yee sheep-heards and crie, and wallow your selues in the ashes, yee principall of the flocke: for your daies of slaughter are accomplished, and of your dispersion, and yee shall fall like precious vessels. And the flight shall faile from the sheep-heards, and the escaping from the principall of the flocke. Thus when the Citie and Temple was first destroied by Nebuchadnezzar, all the Nations round about them were enforced to taste of the same cup. Babylon herselfe that begunne the carouse, which shee meant not to pledge; hoping to make her selfe sport to see others drunke with the
bloud of their slaine, was compelled at length to drinke so deepe of the dregges, till (as my Prophet speaketh) all her strongmen did fall, and her Princes slept their euerlasting sleepe. This prophecie notwithstanding concernes the second destruction of Hierusalem, as literally as the former: and sundrie plagues here mentioned, for ought that can bee gathered from any Historie sacred or prophane, were not in any degree verified of the Nations, in the daies of Nebuchadnezzer, or his Sonne. But scarce any Nation was free from such calamities as are here described in the time of Titus and his Successors; as shall bee declared anon. Rome her selfe, which had reioyced at Iudas miserie, and triumphed in Israels woe, troden Hierusalem vnder her feete, and giuen her dust and ashes for a couering to her nakednesse, was shortly after pinched at the heart with like sorrowes; howsoeuer her outward robes of maiestie did couer her secret wounds from their eies that liued after, or beheld her estate only a-farre off, not acquainted with her inward gripes or smothered out-cries. All is not sound within that is faire without, nor they furthest from danger who feele least paine for the present: such as since haue liued securest, neither regardfull of Hierusalems miserie, nor the calamities of other Nations that ensued them, altogether vnacquainted with any like sorrowes of their owne times, shall haue their deepest share in the horrors of that dreadfull day, whereof these were but shadowes and maps, to represent vnto vs in some proportion the inconceiueable affrightments that shall then appeare. But as no man knowes of that day and houre, so neither did the Prophets themselues distinctly conceiue the manner of it: they did see it only in these adumbrations, which in processe of time grew still more liuely. The second destruction of Hierusalem, and the signes following it, exceeds the former in the distinct prefiguration of the later day, as much as the map of a particular Countrie taken at large, doth the representation of the same in a generall map of the whole earth of like quantitie. And as maps haue a distinct quantitie of their owne, easie to bee knowne by sense, but which no man measures so much for it selfe, as for to know the capacitie of the Countrie which it represents: so haue most prophecies of the
old Testam • nt a distinct, peculiar, naturall, or literall sense verified in the time • f the law, which is not so much to bee expected as the mysteri • of the Gospell; or matters of the world to come prefigured b • these euents past: euen the most secret of these mysteries, af ••• some one or few circumstances be reuealed, may bee distinc •• y knowne. For the proportion of one circumstance or euent with an other, is all one in the later, and in the former; so that by the distinct knowledge of the former, wee may discerne the later, after it bee parallelled in any one part: as by the measure of a map, wee finde out the quantitie of the ground represented. For this reason hath our Sauiour Christ pictured vs out the last day by the calamities of Hierusalem only. For, vnder correction, I should thinke, that no one part of his prophecie, Matth. 24. from the fifteenth to the thirtie-sixth Verse, but is litterally meant, and hath beene verified of Hierusalems fatall day, and the times ensuing. For so our Sauiour concludes; Verily I say vnto you, this generation shall not passe, till all these thinges be done. All what? All he had spoken of before. What, did the signe of the Sonne of man appeare? did he send his Angels with a great sound of a trumpet, to gather the Elect from the foure winds? No. Christ is not yet come: the Elect are not thus gathered. Yet vpon Hierusalems destruction they had the watch-word giuen: the Nations had then a glimpse of his last comming in glorie: then it sounded the first time vnto iudgement; and the Sunne and Moone were seene in tragicall attire, that all the whole world might take notice of such a wofull Tragedie towardes, as wee expect: wherein the whole frame of nature, euen the earth it selfe, this stage of mortalitie, shall be actors; and all mankinde were then set to learne their parts. Our Sauiours comming with power and great glorie, mentioned in the ninth Verse, must bee vnderstood in such a sense, as hee is said to haue come in his Kingdome, or with power, at his Transfiguration. And that first Verse of the ninth of Marke will best interpret the place aboue cited, Matthew 24.34. Sundrie learned Interpreters, I know, expound both places otherwise.Some interpret these wordes of the Gospels promulgation, which is called the power of God: but it is vsuall in prophecies, to attribute that vnto the Type of Pledge which is proper to the substance. And CHRITS Transfiguration was both a liuely type and pledge of his future appearance in power & great glorie. But, to omit the former for this present, the continuation of our Sauiours speech doth enforce
this my interpretation of S. Matthew. For ha • ing spoken of the calamities that were shortly to fall out in Iudah • n • Hierusalem, (as all agree) in the former verses he addeth, Vers. 2 • . And immediately after the tribulations of those daies, shall the Sunn • be darkened, and the Moone shall not giue her light, & the Stars shall fall ••• m heauen, and the powers of heauen shall be shaken. And then shall app •• e the signe of the Sonne of man in heauen; and then shall all the kinreds of the earth mourne; and they shall see the Sonne of man come in the cloudes of heauen, with power and great glorie: and he shall send his Angels with a great sound of a trumpet, and they shall gather together his elect from the foure windes, and from the one end of the heauen to the other. Now learne the parable of the fig-tree; when her bough is yet tender, and it bringeth forth leaues, yee know that Sommer is neare: so likewise when yee see all these thinges, know that the Kingdome of God is neare, euen at the dores. Verily I say vnto you, this generation shall not passe, till all these thinges be done. Some referre these wordes [immediatly after] to the troubles of the Church; as if their meaning were this: And immediately after God hath made an end of the troubles of his Church, these signes shall follow. But who knowes when that shall be? whereas our Sauiours wordes must be referred to those daies whereof he had spoken, which were comprised within determinate and set bounds, and would shortly manifest themselues; so as all men might be certaine when to expect those signes, which he promised to all the world for the confirmation of his doctrine and their faith. The full and naturall meaning of the place is, as if he had said: When you haue seene Hierusalems fatall day, then looke for such signes in the Sun and Moone as I haue told, for the one doth prognosticate the others approch, as certainly, as the budding of the fig-tree doth Sommer. The like connexion of these fearefull signes with Hierusalems desolation we haue in S. Luke cap. 21.24. Hauing spoken before only of the tribulation of Hierusalem, hee continueth his speech: Then there shall be signes in the Sunne, and in the Moone, and in the Starres, and vpon the earth, trouble amongst the Nations with perplexitie, the Sea and the Waters shall roare, and mens hearts shall faile them for feare, and for looking after those thinges which shall come on the world. For the powers of heauen shall be shaken; and then shall they see the Sonne of man come in a cloude with power and great glorie. And
when these thinges beginne to come passe, then looke vp and lift vp your heads, for your redemption draweth neere. And hee spake to them a parable; Behold the figge tree and all trees, when they now shoot forth, yee seeing them, know of your owne selues that Summer is then neere: so likewise ye, when yee see these thinges come to passe, know yee that the Kingdome of God is neere. Verily I say vnto you; this generation shall not passe, till all these things be done. As wee are bound by Christian faith to beleeue that this prophecie is not yet, but shall bee fully accomplished at the last day: so in trueth I should suspect my heart of infidelitie, if I did not acknowledge it truely verified (in such a sense as I haue intimated) immediatly after the destruction of Hierusalem. The former distinction of our Sauiours comming in power, or to present the terrors of the last day, and his last comming vnto iudgment indeede, hee himselfe hath intimated: for hee gaue his Disciples infallible signes, when they might certainly expect the former, verse 33. Heauen and earth shall passe &c. but of that day and houre (to wit the last of iudgment) no man, no not the Angels of Heauen, but my father onely knoweth. As if he had said; This last day shal not come with such obseruation, as the former will: the signes here described shall not prognosticate, but accompanie it: In the former, there were signes in the Sunne and Moone; but in the later both Sunne and Moone shall cease to bee: In the former, the powers of Heauen were shaken, the earth did tremble, and the Sea did roare; in the later, The Heauens shall be gathered like a scrole, and passe away with a noyse, the 2. Pet. 3 12.13. elements shall melt with heat, and the earth with the workes that are therein shall bee burnt,
Reuel. 21.1. the Sea shall be no more: the whole frame of Nature shall bee dissolued on a sodaine, and such as vntill that time minde earthly matters, confining their thoughts within this spheare of mortalitie, shall bee intrapped in the ruines of it, and prest downe to Hell with the weight; onely such as being in this world, are not of it, but haue their conuersation in Heauen, where their Redeemer sits at the right hand of GOD, shall escape these suddaine and fearefull daungers, as birds that are without the compasse of the trappe when it begins to fall. Seeing it will bee too late for men to b gin their beliefe then: too late to flye from death, when destruction hath surprised them; or to cry for mercie first, when Gods iudgements beginne to seize vpon the
world: the Atheist or carelesse worldling may gather both the terrors and calamitie of that day, from the often-mentioned liuely representation of it vnder Titus: for euen in his time the Heauens and the earth did threaten to passe away, that all the world might know Christs wordes should not passe away. The fire of Gods wrath, which Moses had foretold should eate the foundations of the mountaines in Iewrie; and such as Iosephus tels vs had beene kindled in the holy mount, did deuoure the foundations of the mountVid Plin. lib. 6. Epist. 15. Vesuuius in Campania. The consequences thereof, with other prodigious concomitants, were so strange and fearefull, that if we compare the ingenious Heathen Historiographers description of them, with the fore cited place of S. Luke, his relation doth as fully answere our Sauiours prediction, as the historicall narrations of euents past, contained in Scripture, doe the prophecies that had gone of them before.

Repente ita graues terraemotus facti, vt & omnis ea planieres seruida esset, & culmina montium subsiderent. Ad haec, so • itus tum subterranci tanquam •• nitrua, tum super terram mugitibus similes extiterunt, Dein ma
• e simul fremere, omne coelum vnà sonere, ingensque & repentinus fragor quasi mōtes conciderent exa • diri: Tum exilire primum immensi lapides & ad summos vertiees peruenire, deinde m • gnatepia ignis fumique ita vt omnem, acrem obscuraret, occultauitque solem non aliter quam fi defecisset: Igitur ex 〈◊〉 nox, & tenebrae ex luce factae erant, putantibus nonnullis Gigantes seditionem inter se facere, quod multae •• agines corum in fumo conspie erentur, quodque ciangor tubarum audiretur. Alij estistimabant aut mundum in • hao •• digi aut igni consumi, ob camque causam properabant alij ex aedibus in vias, alij de vijs in aedes consugere, 〈…〉 continentem & ex continenti in mare se recipere.4 The sodaine earthquakes were so grieuous, that all that valley was sultring hotte, and the tops of the mountaines sunke downe; vnder the ground were noyses like thunder, answered with like bellowings aboue. The Sea roared, and the Heauens resounded like noyse; huge and great crashings were heard as if the mountaines had fallen together: great stones leaped out of their places, as high as tops of hils; and after them issued abundance of fire and smoke, in so much that it darkned the ayre and obscured the Sun, as if it had beene eclypsed, so that night was turned into day, and day into night. Many were perswaded, that the Giants had raysed some ciuill broyles amongst themselues, because they did see their shapes in the smoke, and heard a noyse of trumpets: others thought the world should be resolued into old Chaos, or consumed with fire; some ran out of their houses into the streets; others from the streets or highwaies into their houses; others from Sea to Land; some againe from the Land to the Sea.

5. These questionlesse were the signes of the sonne of man, that made all the kinreds of the earth thus mourne. For the calamitie was publike: the abundance of ashes and dust was such that
it ouer spread Egypt, Africke and Syria, choaking not onely men, but beastes and birds, poysoning fishes, and spoyling the grounds where it came. The inhabitants of Rome (whither this infection came a few daies after the fire kindled in Campania) thought that the frame of the world had beene out of ioynt: that the Sun did fall down to the earth, & the earth ascend vp to heauen. And albeit the ashes & dust did not such present harme there,Ios. l. 7. de bol. Iudaico lib. Dion. as it had done euery where else: yet it bred a most grieuous pestilence, breaking out not long after: and in the yeare following, whilest Titus went to view the calamities of Campania, a great part of Rome was burnt by fire issuing out of the ground. Amongst other harmes, these following were most remarkable: It consumed the Temple of Serapis, of Isis, of Neptune, the Pantheon, the Diribitorium, the Temple of Iupiter Capitolinus, vnto which the Iewes were not long before enioyned to pay that tribute, which they formerly had done to the Temple of Hierusalem. Thus though the Arke be taken, yet will it be the downfall of Dagon their chiefe God that tooke it: and though Hierusalem lay buried in her ruines, for her peoples grieuous sinnes; yet shall hers, as all sacred pensions sacrilegiously employed, deuoure the seates of their possessors. But what can we more say, than this noble Historiographer hath said of this euent: Id malum diuinum potius quam humanum fuit: this was a calamitie more than humane, in which the finger of God was euidently seene. And as it was a type of the last day: so may it, and the like following, confirme the truth of Sodomes destruction. Nor did God speake onely once in this language to the Romane (to omit other wonderful works of God in these times, to be recounted in their proper place,) the like fearfull earthquakes, with other prodigious concomitants, fell out in Traians time at Antiochia: but the harmes not terminate within her territories, or the Cities about her herewith destroyed. For abundance of soldiers and multitudes of other people did repaire from all quarters to the Emperour wintring there; some in Embassages, some for suites, some vpon other businesses, some to see Playes and Pageants. Whence the dammage, as this Author saith, did redounde to all that were subiect to the Romane Empyre. This out of question was the Lords doing,
that all the world might heare and feare his wondrous workes; and wondring enquire after the true causes and meaning of them. Thus Antioch, as well as Edom and Babylon, is ouertaken with the Psalmists curse, for reioycing in the day of Hierusalem. Besides the massacres of the Iewes there committed when Titus came vnto that citie: the inhabitants after their insinuating gratulations,Ios. lib. 7. de bel. Iud. c. 21. petitioned with all humilitie and pollicie, that the reliques of this people (for whom there was no place left in their owne land) might be extirpate thence, comprising the Christians, no doubt, vnder this name.

6 Many particulars, then known, are not registred by such heathen writers as now are extant; and many signes of those times not regarded by any heathen: all which might witnes the truth of our Sauiours predictions, and expound their meaning, were they as well knowne to vs as to the faithfull then liuing; whose meditations, it seemes, were so wholly taken vp with these contemplations, that they had no leysure to leaue their comments in writing to posteritie. That dreadfull woe directed against the women of Hierusalem, with child and giuing sucke, did take these Antiochians at the rebound. Women in such cases could not die, but a double death, and yet how many such were slaine none can tell. Of an infinite companie of all sorts, starued by their close imprisonment in houses, whose foundations were shrunke, the roofe remaining, onely one woman was found aliue, which had sustained herselfe and her childe by her milke; another childe found in the like concauitie aliue, sucking his deceased mothers dugges. In fine (saith the Author) there was no kinde of violent disaster, which did not at this time befall men. For the earthquakes being caused by the Diuine power, mens wits were not their owne, nor knewe they what medicine to seeke for these mishappes. Such as were on the house-tops had not list to descend to fetch any thing out; such as were in the field, had no minde to returne backe to fetch their clothes; Traiane himselfe was drawne out at a window by no mortall creature (as this writer thinkes) so astonished with this disastrous sight, that for many daies after the earthquake had ceased, he durst not come in any house.

7 Neither of these strange signes of the sonne of man fell out in any corner of the world, but the one in the chiefe, the other in the second Citie of the Empire, at that time the Emperors court: so as the whole world representatiue (as we may so speake) was in danger, and all men, at least, men of all sorts, at their wits end; and by their terrors all mankind had publike warning to prepare themselues against that terrible and dreadfull day: These being such types of it, as the first destruction of the holy Citie and Temple by Nabuchadnezzar, was of the second by Titus; so as that which is truly said of the one, may in an higher degree be rruly auouched of the other.

8 Of these times againe was that of the Prophet meant; I will poure out my spirit vpon all flesh,
Ioel 2.28. Ʋide Zach. 14. v. 7. and your sonnes and your daughters shall prophecie. And I will shew wonders in the heauens and in the earth, bloud and fire, and pillars of smoake: the Sunne shall be turned into darkenesse, and the Moone into bloud, before the great and terrible day of the Lord come. But whosoeuer shall call on the name of the Lord shall be saued. If we rightly obserue the Prophets methode in this place, it will both justifie and illustrate the former interpretations of Ieremie, and our Sauiors prophecie. First he speakes (none can denie) of Christs comming in the flesh, and effusion of the holy Ghost vpon all people; I will poure out my Spirit vpon all flesh. By the spirit the Gospell was to be communicate to all Nations: and this (as the Euangelist witnesseth) at the first descending of the holy Ghost vpon the Apostles, Act. 2.5. there were resident at Hierusalem men that feared God of euerie Nation vnder heauen: and all these at their Baptisme receiued the gift of the holy Ghost,
Act. 2.38. whereby they might manifest the power and vertue of the Gospell vnto the Countries where they liued. If wee compare the generalitie of Saint Lukes speech in that fifth verse, with our Sauiours Matth. 24. vers. 14. And this Gospell of the Kingdome shall be preached throughout the whole world, for a witnesse vnto all Nations, and then shall the end come: Wee cannot doubt but our Sauiors prophecie was verified before the destruction of Hierusalem, which was the end he meant should come. But why should the Prophet Ioel, immediately after his description of the time of Grace, adde in the second place; I will shew wonders in the Heauens, and in the Earth; bloud and fire, and pillars of smoake? Doth he call the
people of God againe vnto Mount Sinai, vnto burning fire, to blacknesse and darknesse, and tempest, vnto the sound of Trumpets, the voice of words, which they that once had heard, should not desire to heare any more? No: but he would haue the world vnderstand, That after the Gospell was once proclaimed throughout it, the Lord would shew himselfe as terrible a Iudge to all such as did not embrace the glad tidings thereof, as he had done before to the Israelites at the promulgation of the Law. Both that fearefull sight in Mount Sinai, and those other prodigious apparitions in Italie and Syria, were types and representations of that dreadfull day. The former was seene and testified by the Israelites onely, because the Law was onely reuealed to them: the horrors of the later are registred by Heathen Writers, knowne and felt by the principall Nations of the world, and from them diffused to all others (as Earthquakes, which begin at the centre, leaue their effects vpon the whole surface of the Earth) because the Gospell was at that time communicate to all the inhabited or frequented parts of the world. Those prodigious signes then which the Prophet Ioel describes, and the Heathen witnesse to haue beene so frequent among the Nations, presently after Ierusalems destruction, and the extirpation of the Iewes, were added as so many seales, to assure the truth of the Prophets and Gospell; and to testifie both to Iew and Gentile, That if either the one did follow his Iewish sacrifice, or the other his wonted Iolatrie, after the truth of Gods new couenant with mankind was sealed and proclaimed, there remained no more sacrifice for sinnes, but a fearefull looking of iudgement and violent fire: that there was no other name vnder heauen able to saue them from such euerlasting flames, as they now had seene some flashes of, but onely the name of Iesus, whom the Iew had crucified. So the Prophet Ioel concludes, Whosoeuer shall call on the Name of the Lord, that is, of Iesus (for now all Israel might know for a suretie, that God had made that Iesus whom they had crucified, both Lord and Christ) he shall be saued. The fruits of calling vpon the name of the Lord, and that distinction betwixt the state of the elect and reprobate, intimated by the Prophet in the last verse of that Chapter, shall be most fully manifested in the day of judgement: For such as haue watched and prayed continually, alwayes expecting their masters comming, shall vpon
the first apprehension of his approach, lift vp their heads, as knowing that their redemption draweth neere. But for the riotous or carelesse liuer, he shall not be able to stand before the sonne of man: in stead of calling vpon his name, he shall crie vnto the hils, Couer me, and to the mountaines, Fall yee vpon me. Yet was the same distinction, betweene the reprobate and the elect, truely notified by the confident carriage of the Christians, in those fearefull times lately mentioned (which did so much affright the Heathen) as wee may gather from Antoninus the Emperours Decree, inhibiting the Christians persecution by the Commons of Asia. It seemes the other had accused the Christians as hurtfull persons, and offensiue to the Gods; vnto which the Emperour makes reply in this manner:Euseb. l. 4. c. 13.
I know the Gods are carefull to disclose hurtfull persons; for they punish such as will not worship them more grieuously than you doe those whom you bring in trouble, confirming that opinion which they conceiue of you, to be wicked and vngodly men. It shall seeme requisite to admonish you of the Earthquakes, which haue and doe happen amongst vs; that being therewith moued, yee may compare our estate with theirs: they haue more confidence to Godwards than you haue. I will shut vp this discourse for the present with that saying of our Sauiour; Remember Lots wife: and his exhortation, Luk. 21.34. Take heede to your selues, least at any time your hearts be oppressed with surfetting and drunkennesse, and cares of this life; and least that day come on you at vnawares: for as a snare shall it come on all them that dwell on the face of the whole earth. So did the former calamities in Titus and Traians time, which were as the day of Noah; They ate and they drunke, and rose vp to play: and when they said, Pax & tuta omnia, suddaine destruction came as an vnexpected actor vpon the stage. For, as you heard before, one cause of the great concourse vnto Antiochia at that direfull season, was to see Playes and Prizes: and in the former vnder Titus, Duas integras vrbes, Herculaneum & Pompeios, populo sedente in Theatro, penitus obruit. Dion. li. 66. two whole Cities were ouerwhelmed with the tempest of Gods wrath, whilest the Citizens were sitting in the Theatre. So must all such fruitlesse spectacles, or pleasant (but vnseasonable) Comedies, be concluded with their spectators Tragedie in the catastrophe of this great and spacious Amphitheatre.

9 Thus much of the Prophecies concerning Hierusalems destruction, and the signes of those times. Ere we returne to suruey the Iewes estate since, it shall not be amisse to note, how vpon the expiration of their interest in Gods promises, confirmed vnto their father Isaack, the seed of Ismael began to enter vpon the other moitie of his promise made to Abraham.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
That the Saracens are the true sonnes of Ismael: Of their conditions and manners answerable to Moses Prophecie.
