div.p: 1 THat the sonnes of Isaack and Ismael (for more than three thousand yeares after their fathers death, in Countries almost as many miles distant from their originall Seat, whither scarce any other Asiatickes come) should kithe each other with as little scruple as if they were full cousin germanes, to me hath seemed an argument, That the Lord had appointed both for continuall signes vnto the Nations: the more, whiles I consider with what difficultie of search, varietie of conjectures, and vncertaintie of resolution the best Antiquaries amongst the naturall inhabitants of those Countries assigne either their first planters there, or the Regions whence they came.

2 But howsoeuer such as wee call Saracens, are best knowne to the moderne Iewes of Spaine by the name of Ismaelites; yet in these later dayes (disposed to quarrell with former ages) some beginne to suspect, others to contradict the common receiued opinion, as well concerning the Saracens naturall descent from Hagar and Ismael, as their pretended originall from Sarah, Abrahams lawfull wife. Vnto which bold assertion, or needlesse scruple, though vtterly deuoid of all ground, either of reason or authoritie, we are thus farre beholden; it hath occasioned vs to seeke the ground of the contrarie out of antiquitie, as well Secular as Ecclesiastique: Whose pregnant consonancie with the sacred Oracles is pertinent to this present, necessarie for subsequent
discourse, in it selfe neither vnpleasant, nor vnprofitable to the judicious Christian Reader.

3 Of Abrahams base seede, some (in Scripture) are denominate from their mother, knowne by the name of Hagarens; others from her sonne, their father, are calledSo these two are distinguished 1. Chro 27. v 30. & 31. Ismaelites: some take their names from his sonnes, as Kedar, Duma, Naphish, 1. Chro. 5. v. 19. Ietur, &c. Not any people in Scripture (to my remembrance) take their name from Nabaioth their eldest sonne: Which addes probabilitie toGoropius Becanus in Hispanicis their opinion, who thinke such as the Heathen called Nabathaei, were in Scriptures tearmed Ismaelites, as sole heires to their first progenitors name: Their seat was in the best part of Arabia Petraea, neere vnto the Midianites, as is probable from the storie of Ioseph; who in one place is said to be sold vnto the Ismaelites, and in another to the Midianites, these being neere neighbours, as it seemes, and copartners in traffique. As the Nabathaeans are not mentioned in Scripture, so neyther doe I finde the name of Ismael in any auncient Heathen Writer: All of them I thinke being of Strabo his minde,Strabo, lib. 16. who professeth, That he omits the auncient name of the Arabians, partly because in his time they were out of vse, partly for the harshnesse of their pronunciation; vnto which exception the name of Ismael was most obnoxious.

4 The Seat of such as the Scripture calls Hagarens, was in the desart Arabia, betwixt Gilead and Euphrates, as wee may gather from the first of Chronicles, the fift chapter, the ninth and tenth verses. This people was called by the Heathen
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Agraei, (a name more consonant to their name in
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Hebrew, than the Latine Hagareni) rightly placed by Ptolomie in the Desart Arabia, and by Lib. 16. Strabo in thatTo wit, next vnto the Chaulotaeans, or inhabitants of Hauilah. verie place which the Scripture makes the Easterne bounds of Ismaels posteritie; their Metropolis or chiefe Citie in later times wasThis name of [Atraeni] it seemes was peculiar to the inhabitants of Atra, the chief Citie of the Aagrens or Agraeans: as Petrae was the Metropolis of the Nabathaeans, so that the Atreni and Agareni differ as the Petraeni and Nabathaei. Atra, or Atrae, and the inhabitants thereof Atraeni, vnlesse both Dion and Herodian either mistooke, or haue beene mistaken to haue written Atraeni for Agreni. But to omit the particular denomination of Ismaels seede, they were best knowne to auncient Heathens from the manner of their inhabitation in tents: and Scenitae Arabes was a name generall, and (I thinke) equiualent to his race, vnlesse
perhaps the Midianites or Idumaeans might share with them in this name, as they were partakers of their qualitie: which is not so to be appropriated vnto either, as if they had neyther house or towne; for the Tents of Kedar are most famous in Scripture, yet sayth the Prophet, Let the Wildernesse and the Cities thereof lift vp their voice, the Townes that Kedar doth inhabite:
Jsay 42. v. 11. Nor did hee meane as many Tents as would make a Towne; for euen in Moses time they had their places of defence, as appeares from the fiue and twentieth of Genesis, the sixteenth verse, These bee the sonnes of Ismael, and these be their names, by their Townes and by their Castles, twelue Princes of their Nations, or rather twelue heads of so many seuerall Houses, Tribes, or Clans; which kinde of Regiment they continued, till foure hundred yeares after Christ. And the Heathen Writers, both Greeke and Latine, better expresse Moses wordes in the fore-cited place, [ 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ] than sundry moderne Interpreters doe; who call them Dukes or Princes, being to theStrab. lib. 16. in descriptione Syriae, & lib. 2. Grecians 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to the Latines Phylarchi Arabum, or to the later Writers Saracenorum, albeitAmmian. Marcell. lib. 23. vide annotat. ad Num. 5. cap. 9. some Latine Writers call them Reguli Saracenorum.

5 The proofe of our intended conclusion depends vpon these two premisses; the first, That the Saraceni were the same people whom the Auncients call the Scenitae Arabes; as is expressely auouched byLib. 22. & 23. Scenitae Arabes quos Saracenos posteritas appellauit. Ammianus Marcellinus in sundrie places, and euerie one will acknowledge, that compares theWhom the auncient Writers call Phylarchi Arabum, the later call Phylarchi Saracenorum, as appeares by Sextus Rufus and Jornandes, Montes Armeniae, primum per Lucullum Romana arma videruut; per quem & Osroene & Saracenorum Phylarchi devicti Romanis se dediderunt. Jornandes lib. 1. So he calles them by anticipation as in Scripture; places are oft times called by those names which were best knowne in the Writers time; not by the names which they bare in those auncient times of which they write. So likewise, Sextus Rufus in his Breuiarie of the Romane storie, speaking of the Consuls time, mentioneth the Saracens; albeit no mention is made of them or their Phylarchi, by any Romane that liued within two hundred yeares of Pompeyes Conquests. auncient and later Romaines, writing the same stories. The second, That the Scenitae Arabes were the seede of Ismael; which doth appeare by the identitie of their habitation, condition, and qualitie.

6 First, it is euident out of Plinie andLib. 2.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Et lib. 10. ••• a orientem versus te • minatur E • phrate & Arabibus Scenitis. Strabo, That the Scenitae Arabes were seated Eastward about the riuer Euphrates, noysome neighbours to Chaldaea and Mesopotamia; some part whereof in Strabo his time they inhabited: on the West part they bordered vpon Aegypt and Aethiopia: So Ammianus Marcellinus in his two and twentieth booke describing the situation of Aegypt, sayth,Aegyptia Gens, qua crientem è regione prospicit, Elephantinam & Meroen vrbes Aethiopum, & cata-dupos rubrumque Pelagus & Scenitus praetenditur Arabas, quos Saracenos nunc appellamus. Amm. Marcell. lib. 22.
it bordered on the East vpon the Cataracts of Nilus, and the Scenitae Arabes, whom now wee call Saracens. And in his fourteenth booke, describing the situation of the Saracens, he makes Assyria their border on the East, and the confines of Blemmiae and the Cataracts of Nylus on the West. And Moses in the twentie fiue of Genesis sayth, The sonnes of Ismaels dwelling was from Shur, which is towards Aegypt vnto Hauilah, which is toward Ashur, in the way from Aegypt thither. This land of Hauilah, or (according to the orthographie of the Hebrew) Chauilah, famous in Scripture for gold, retained the same name inLib. 16. initio descr •• Arabiae. Strabo his time; the inhabitants called by him Chaulotaeans, next neighbours to the Hagarens, or Agraei, whose countrey Seuerus suspected to haue had good store of gold.

7 The description of the Saracenes situation and conditions out of Ammianus Marcellinus, in his foureteenth booke, compared with Moses characters of Ismael, and his prophecie of his posteritie, Genesis 25. v. 18. and Genes. 16. v 6. & 12. Saraceni nec amici nobis vnquam nec habendi [alij legunt: nec Hostes optandi] vltro citroque discursantes, quicquid inueniri poterat, momento temporis parui vastabant, miluorum rapaci vitae similes: qui si praedam despexerint celsius volatu rapiunt celeri, aut si impetrarint non immorantur. Super quorum moribus licet in actibus principis Marci, & postea aliquotios meminerim retulisse, tamen nunc quo{que} pauca de ijsdem expediam carptim. Apud has gentes, quarum exordiens initium ab Assyrijs ad Nili cataractas porrigitur & confinia Blemyarum, omnes pari sorte sunt bellatores, seminudi, coloratis Sagulis pube tenus amicti, equorum adiumento pernicium, gracilium que camelorum per diuersa reptantes in tranquillis vel turbidis rebus: Nec eorum quisquam aliquando stiuam apprehendit, vel arborem colit, aut arua subigendo quaeritant victum, sed errant semper per spatia longè latcque distenta, sine lare, fine sedibus fixis aut legibus, perferunt diutius coelum. Haud trectus vnius soli illis vnquam placet, vita est illis semper in fugâ, vxoresque Mercenariae conductae ad tempus ex pacto: atque vt sit species matrimonij, dotis nomine futura coniunx traetam & tabernaculum offert marito, post statum diem s • id el • gerit d • scessura: & incredibile est, quo ardore apud eos in venerem vterque sexus soluitur. Ita autem quoad vixerint, latè palantur, it alibi mulier nubat, in loco pariat alio, liberosque procul deducat, nulla cop • à quiescendi permissa. Ʋictus vniuersis caro ferina est, lactisque abundans copia, quâ sustentantur, & herbae multiplices, & si quae alites capi per aucupium possunt. Et plerosque nos vidimus frumenti vsum & vini penitus ignorantes. If Amm. Marcellinus had but knowne how fully Moses had preuented him in his obseruations of these Saracenes,
gathered from his experience of their behauiour, many hundred yeares before the Romanes had heard of such a people; nay ere they themselues were any Nation; it would perhaps haue moued him to haue thought better of Moses writings, and worse of his master Iulian for oppugning them. And if neither loue, nor feare of God, or true Religion, mee thinkes, naturall ciuile modestie should enforce men to beleeue his report of thinges past, that can so clearely point out the nature of men many hundred yeares before they come into the world. For so wee must esteeme Moses words of Ismael and Hagar, though historically verified in their persons, yet withall a typicall prophecie of their posterities conditions.As that prophecie Gen. 25. v. 23. And it is a demonstratiue Argument, That their wildnesse was foretold by his spirit, that onely can commaund Nature, and prescribe limits to the free thoughts of man, in that this Progenie (throughout so many hundred generations) varie no more from their first Progenitors agrest and fierce qualities, than the wilde Plants of the Forest, neuer accustomed to humane culture, doe from the Trees whence they are propagate.

8 Ismael, as Moses tels vs, was begotten of Hagar an Egyptian hyreling: The matrimonie of Saracens women in Ammianus his time was mercenarie, and vpon compact for a time. Hagar conceiued Ismael in Abrahams house, but readie to bring him forth in the Wildernesse, whither he and she were sent againe, after her returne vnto her mistresse: The Saracene women of Ammianus his time marrie in one place, beare children in another, and bring them vp in a third farre distant; neuer permitted to liue in rest: and in shew of matrimonie, they bring a Speare and a Tent for their dowrie, being indeed a perfect Embleme of their mercenarie rouing life: for these they may by couenant take with them at the end of their seruice, and be packing from their masters to seeke their food in the Wildernesse, as their mother Hagar taught them. Who would thinke, but that it were more likely one should die rather of hunger than thirst in the Wildernesse? Or who could imagine, that Abraham (vnlesse directed by some secret instinct, praesaging that rude and sharking life, whereunto, this wilde slippes progenie was ordained) could suffer Ismael and Hagar to goe to the Wildernesse out of his house,
which God had blest with all manner of store, onely furnished with a little bread, and a bottle of water, so quickly spent, that the child had almost died for thirst, before God did prouide him more. This did portend, that his Posteritie should be pinched with like penurie, scant of water (their best drinke) straitned their territories (as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Strabo lib. 16. in desc. Syriae. Strabo telles vs) in Arabia; and after they had enlarged the bounds which Moses let them,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Id. lib. 10. euen in Mesopotamia it selfe, they are confined to drie and barren places; nor could the Isaiah. 13. vers. 20. From which place we may gath • r that such as the ancient w ••• ers of sacred storie would haue termed Hagarines or Ismaelites were called by later, Arabians: not • s it vsuall after Iehosophats time (if at all) to mention the Ismaelites or Hagarens, the name of the Arabians being then equiualent to the Ismaelite if wee take them generally, as may be gathered l • kewise from Iosephus in sundrie places amongst others from his 13. chapter of his f • rst booke of Antiquities. Tumultuantibus ijs qui à Saracenis victi fuerunt, & d centibus, •• num non ce • imus, cr ••••• te inquit, illi qui vos vincunt aquam bibunt. Ʋide Aelium Spartian. in Pessemnio N • gro. The Sa • acens which haue beene famous for their Artillerie throughout all their generations. Prophet better expresse the future barrennesse of Babylon, & the regions about, then by by intimating it such, as the sonnes of desolation, which sought their foode out of flint, should not be able to inhabite. That water, many yeares after Straboes time, was the Scenite Arabians best, or onely drinke, appeares from Pessemnius Nigers replie vnto his Souldiers, pretending lacke of wine as cause of their lacke of courage, or faint seruice, you may be ashamed, (saith he) of this excuse, whereas they that foyle you are but water-drinkers. And Ammianus saith, he knew very many of them in his time, that neyther knew vse of wine nor corne. Moses describing the manner of Ismaels life, said he was an archer in the wildernesse. None of the Saracens, if we may beleeue Ammianus, did euer set his hand to the plough, but got their liuing for the most part by their bow. For as were they, such was their meate, wilde flesh or venison, hearbes or milke, or such wilde foule as the wildernesse did affoord, and they could catch. For their owne wildenesse hee compares them to Kites, readie to spie a prey, but so vntame withall, that they would not stay by it, as Crowes or other rauenous birds doe by carion, but presently fled with what they caught vnto their nestes. So notoriously was their wildenesse incorporated into their nature, that the
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
more tame they grew, the lesse right they seemed to haue vnto their names, as Strabo intimates.

9 Yet did they not more fully resemble Ismael and Hagars conditi • ns, then preposterously imitate Abrahams Rites, or Religion. Their Father Ismael, was about thirteene yeare old when God established his couenant with Abraham: and for this reason notI • a • tum 8. m ••

Vid La • Iouic. circumcised vntill that age: the SaracensVide Ludouicum Viuam de vert. till this day circumcise not their children before that time; when as they might with as good reason deferre it till about the hundreth yeare of their age, because Abraham, was thereabouts when hee first receiued this seale of Gods couenant. div.head: CHAP. IX.
The beginning and progresse of Ismaels greatnesse.
div.p: 1 THe chiefe strength of Ismaels sonnes in ancient time did consist in artillerie, as we may gather from the Prophet Esay. Yet a yeare according to the yeares of an hireling, and all the glory of Kedar shall faile, and the residue of the number of the strong Archers of the sonnes of Kedar shall be few: for the Lord God of Israel hath spoken it. Though the plague heere threatned by the Assyrians, did ouertake them: yet as Saint Ierome notes, they escaped the rod of Gods wrath, better then most of their neighbours, by reason of their speedie remouall from place to place, most of them such as were neuer out of their dwelling, whilest they had tents, and Cammels, and wastes to range in. Afterwards they continued troublesome neighbours vnto Syria, vntill it was annext to the Romane Empyre,Strabo. lib. 16. by whose valour the strength of their Archers, was againe diminished, and the raigne of their Phylarchi cut shorr. But their countrey first brought into the forme of a Prouince by Traiane, in whose time the Hagarens, (so soone are thy wearie of ciuill subiection,) begunne to reuolt, and for ought I finde, neuer brought againe to performe perfect obedience vnto the Romane or any other people.

2 Their Citie, saithPerlege historia apud Dion. l. c • . Dion, was neither great nor rich, yet had it Zoars priuiledge. Hee that preserued the one from the stormes of fire and brimstone, which deuoured farre greater neighbour-Cities, did guard the other against the violence of
two most potent Emperours, who had ouer-runne the mightiest Kingdomes of the earth. The Heathens thought the Sunne, to whom their Citie was consecrated, did protect it. But can they shew vs any prophecie of old, giuen by Phoebus for this peoples good? we can shew them the expresse promise of Abrahams God, more than two thousand yeeres before, for making them and their brethren a mightie Nation. Let the Atheist iudge, whether their Gods arme were shortned, or whether his miracles, which the Scripture tels vs were wrought for the sonnes of the free-woman, whilest they followed their fathers steps, can seeme incredible, being compared with the wonderfull deliuerance of the Agarens, the sonnes of the bond-woman, from Traiane and Seuerus, both besieging them in person. The soyle about their Citie was barren, and when Traiane besieged it verie hote; so that the violence of the siege could not bee long. These signes the politicians could assigne of Traianes ill successe. But whence was it, that as oft as the Citie was assaulted, the soldiers were annoyed with lightnings, thunders, whirlewindes, and hayle? affrighted or dezcled with the apparition of rainebowes? whence was it that flyes should corrupt and spoile their meate, whilest they eate it? by these and the like meanes, wonderfull euen in the Heathens sight, was Traiane forced to giue ouer the siege; which hee had followed, not without great daunger of his life, by comming within these strong Archers shot in viewing the Citie, shortly after, (as if hee had fought before with men, but now against God) falling into a disease, whereof he died.

3 About some fourescore yeeres after, the EmperourDion. lib. 71.
Seuerus, disdaining (as Traiane had done) that these Hagarens should stand out still against the Romanes, when all the rest about them had yeelded, beeing once repulsed with losse of men and munition, made great preparation for the second assault, in which (after great losse of his souldiers) hauing ouerthrowne part of the Citie-wall, he caused the retreite to bee sounded in policie, hoping the besieged would haue come to intreat for peace and libertie, which he was not minded to graunt, but vpon condition they would bewray the hidden treasure supposed to bee consecrated
to the Sunne. But they continued resolute a whole day, giuing no intimation of any treatie for peace. The souldiers in the meane time were so discontented, that on the morrow following the Europaeans, before most resolute, would not enter at the breach: and the Syrians, enforced to vndertake the seruice, had a grieuous repulse. So, saith Dion, God deliuered the Citie, recalling the Souldiers by Seuerus, when they might haue entered, and restraining Seuerus the second day by the Souldiers backewardnesse. This conquest after this breach, was in martiall esteeme so easie, that one of his companions confidently vndertooke to effect it, without the hazard of any other mans life besides, so he might haue but fiue hundred and fif • ie Europaean Souldiers assigned him. To which faire proffer the Emperour (as perish as they had beene peeuish,) in a distracted chafe replied: But where shall I finde so many Souldiers? and so departed into Palestina. Thus are the proud assaults of greatest Monarches, in their height of strength, but like the billowes of a swelling tide, which breake ouer the bankes, and immediately fall againe. The Almightie hath set bounds to both, which they must not passe; and vnder his protection may Ismael rest, as secure from the Romane forces, to whom hee had giuen all the R • gions round about them, as Edom did from the Israelites, when they slew mighty Kings, and cast out farre greater neighbour-nations. It is probable that these Hagarens, after their good successe against Traiane and Seuerus, did propagate their name to all the sonnes of Ismael; as whole nations in like cases take new denominations from the ring-leaders vnto reuolt. Lib. 6. c • p.
• 8. Sozomen and SaintCommost. in 21. Isa. Hierome, both liuing shortly after this people was generally knowne by the name of Saracens, auouch without question, (what they could haue giuen reason for, had they fore-seene posterities in credulitie) that vsurped the name of Sarah, in hope to extinguish that note of bastardie, imported in their former name of Hagarens: as great mens bastardes in few descents, will attempt the changing of their ignominious coate. And in all Ecclesiasticke writers, the names of Saracens or Hagarens, are vsed promiscuously as equiualent; which argues that the name of Hagarens had somtimes beene common to all the race of Ismael,
not appropriate to the Agraei or such as the Scripture calles Hagarites.

4 It is euident out of Ammianus, that the name of Saracens was not ancient. The first certaine mention of it is in Ptolomie: who describes a Region called Saracene in the West part of Ismaels territories, as they are described by Moses, and a people, called Saraceni in the wealthie Arabia, neere vnto the mountaines, which the Scenitae inhabite. Whether the fertilitie of the soyle, might make them scorne their former name, as it would cause them loath their aunciente seat: or whether giuen, or taken vpon other occasions: the whole progenie aswell in the desert Arabia as elsewhere, was willing to make the benefite of it, as an argument to perswade the world they were free borne, and true heires of that promise whence the Iewes were fallen. For Mahomet, as all writers agree, vsed this plausible Etymologie as a faire colour to countenance his foule blasphemies: and aIbi ab saracenenis coepta est Orati • quae commiserat • onem e • slagitaret commun • m esse Deum quem vtr • que • olerent, ritum di • er • um. Ill s Ab • aham esse ge •• eris principium, quod à Sara ge •• t • Saraceni •• cantur, fratres esse comm • ni praeditos b ma • itate, sub vn • pat • e Deo, •• mamarum rerum varietate iam se victos saepe ante victores. Albert. Krantzij rer. Germ. hist. d. Reg. aquil. Dan. Suec Noru Chro. Saxon. l. 7. c. 12. graue relator of truth, not accustomed to make speeeches for dead men to vtter, brings in the later Saracens in the siege of Torutum (which was a mile from Tyre) vsing their name deriued from Sarah, as an argument to perswade their true descent from Abraham, for whose sake they hoped for fauour at Christians hands. But they could not so easily change their nature, as their name: the greater they grow in might, the more exactly they fulfill that prophecie of Ismael, and he shall be a wild man, his hand shall be against euerie man, and euery mans hands against him, For a long time they continued, like forward but poore gamesters, not able to set at more then one at once, and that for no great stake, without some to beare their part; vntill at length by their treacherous shuffling from side to side, and banding somtimes with one, somtimes another against some third, they grow so flush, that they dare set at all, and take Asia, Europe, and Affricke to taske at once.

5 Sometimes they tooke part with Mithridate, and other Easterne nations, against Lucullus and Pompey, and yet readie to ioyne with Pompey against the Iewes. Some of them againe were for the Parthians against the Romanes, others for the Romanes against the Parthians, some now for the one, then for the other as Achlaudonius andOs • oenus Dio: m a • Ar abs qu • nquam & Osroen • Ar • b s ori • ine, M •• opotamiae incolae. for Pesseninus Niger against Seuerus, others against Pesseninus, afterwards one whi • e for Persian, & another while for the Romanes, as in the times of Constantiu •

Saraceros id • o pat • ebamur infestos, q • od salaria inunetaque plurima tul • an • ad similitudinem praeteriti temporis accipere vetit • , quaest que apud eum, solum and erat Imperatorem bell •• o • um & vigilantem, ferrum habere non auram. Amm. an lib 25. reuolting from him. Afterwards, they serue vnder the Romans againstVide facimus po • tento • um Saracem cu • u • dam contra Got • os apud Ammianū sub finem lib. v •••• st. the Gothe • : and yet while the Gothes and other barbarous people, claspe with the Romane Eagle in the West; These foule Harpies plucke off her traine in the East; and not therewith content take their fl ght toward the West to snatch the mea • e out of the other ba • tards mouth, and beate them one after another from the prey which they had seized on in Spayne and Affricke; attempting the like in France, Greece, and Germanie; dis-pluming the breastes, and ofttimes readie to deuoure the verie heart, euen Italie and Rome it selfe.

6 Finally, as Ismael began first to giue proofe of his might, when Isaacs strength begun to fayle, so can wee scarce name any place where Isaacs seede haue beene scattered, whither the the dread of Ismaels ha • h not followed them: that such Christians, as would not suffer the miserable estate of the one to sinke into their soules, nor learne to feare Gods iudgements shewed vpon them, might apprehend the other, as present executioners of like woe and vengeance vpon themselues. It is well obserued by the Author of the triparti • e worke, touching the sacred warre (annexed to the Councell of Lateran) that the persecution of Christians by the Saracen, hath beene euerie way greater and more grieuous without interruption, then all the persecutions vnder the Roman Emperours, or any forraine enemies. These prouocations by this foolish Nation, witnesse the truth of Gods threatninges to the ancient Iewes, and that our pride of heart hath beene like the • rs: for the asswaging whereof his pleasure hath beene, To bring the most wicked of the heathen to possesse our houses, and to d fi • e the holy places. A • cording to their iudgement hath he iudged the most part of Christendome: such seruilitie as the Iewes suffered vnder the Greeks & Asiaticks haue they endured vnder the Saracen: and the Turke who is but a Prosylite of Ismael, & heire by adoptiō of that promise. Gen. 17.20. I will
multiplie him exceedingly, and I will make a great nation of him Besides his participation with him in the couenant of Circumcision, the best pledge and ground of Ismaels gteatnesse, the manners and conditions of the Turkes and Saracens haue great affinitie; the Turke also is a wild man, yea this is the signification of his name (as Ʋterque in limine suae historiae. Arabs likewise is as much as homo agrestis, or incultus. And Arabia, as much as terra agrestis & inculta: in which all things grow promiscuously. And if I mistake not, only the desolate barren parts of that countrie, which we call Arabia, is so called in sacred storie. Chalcocondilus and Louicer expound it.) But though both Turkes and Saracens by Christians continuance in their fathers sinnes haue beene perpetuall scourges of Christendome; yet hath God at sundrie times giuen vs manifest signes of helpe laid vp in store, so that wee would turne to him with our whole heartes. The strange and almost incredible, though most vndoubted victories, which Christians sometimes had ouer them, doe liuely represent the miraculous victories of the Iewes ouer the Heathen, related in Scriptures. To omit others, It might be remembred as an irrefragable witnesse as well of the multitude of Gods mercies towards vs, as of Ismaels posteritie, that three hundred and eighty thousand of them should be slaine all in one day by one Christian Generall. Vnlesse the Lord had raised vs vp a Gedeon then, hee onely knowes how quickly these parts of Christendome might haue beene rebaptized in their bloud, and borne the name of Saracens euer after. And, as a Germane writer well obserues, the French Kings might well brooke that title of Christianissimi, from that admirable exploit of Carolus Martellus, the next meanes vnder Gods prouidence, that other parts of Europe had not Saracen tyrants in steed of Christian Princes. Of such particular experiments, as the Histories of Turkes and Saracens affoorde, answerable to the Prophecies in Scripture concerning them, wee shall haue fitter occasion to speake heereafter.

div.head: CHAP. X.
The persecutions of the Iewes by Traian: and the desolation of their countrie by Adrian: their scattering through other nations, fore-told by Moses.
div.p: 1 THough the greatnesse of their former plagues vnder Vespasiā had made their nūber lesse throughout their owne land: yet Aegypt, Cyrene, & Cyprus, had too many of these snakes within their bowels, vntill their deadly stings, procuring others, did prouoke their own destructiō. In the later end of Traians reigne, the manner of their outragious massacres, practised vpon both Greeks and Romans in the foremētioned countries, was as hainous, as the facts thēselues; though these hainous beyond all credence, if not related by most credible, most vnpartial writers.Dion lib. 6 • . Besides the particular butcheries cōmitted throughout Aegypt, about Cyrene were slaine by them two hundred thousand, in Cyprus two hundred and fiftie thousand. The Lord (no doubt) had smittē them, as he had threatned Deu. 28. v. 28. with this madnesse and blindnesse of heart, that they might hereby prouoke this puisant Emperors indignation; which otherwise would haue slept, but now pursues them throughout his dominions, not as enemies, or rebels of the Empire, but as noxious creatures to humane societie, with reuēge suting to their former outrages.Dion ibidem. Partly for the Cyprians better securitie in time to come, partly in memorie of their former miserie, & these Iewes infamie: It is publickly inacted, that no Iew, though driuen by tempest thither, should presume to set foot within their coast, vpon paine of present execution, as alreadie condemned by his verie appearance on that soile, which had bin tainted with the deadly venome of his countrimen.

2 But least posteritie, litle respectiue of Iewish affaires (through negligence of the Romane writers) should forget, or, from the inconsiderate frailty of humane nature, lesse obserue these two most grieuous persecutions of the Iewes than was behouefull for testification of Moses, or Christes prophecies, and confirmation of Christian faith: In Adrians time, (like traitours that had fainted vpon the racke before their full confession taken) they are recouered to greater torture. And least the Nations in that,
or ages following, should not acknowledge them to haue beene such a mightie people, as the sacred storie makes them: they are made a spectacle to the world againe, to showe their naturall strength by their grieuous lingring paines in dying. This was that which Moses had said Deut. 28. vers. 59. The Lord will make thy plagues wonderfull, and the plagues of thy seede great plagues, and of long continuance, and sore diseases, and of long durance. Yet their destruction now, as at both times (alwaies) before, was from their owne procurement. For Adrian, causing new AElia built by him where Hierusalem stood, to bee inhabited by others, Christians as well as Iewes, and permitting the vse of their countrie-religion to all: the Iewes began first to repine while Adrian was neere, afterwardes to mutinie vpon his departure out of these Easterne Prouinces.

3 The fresh memorie of their former desolation made their strength seeme litle, and the apprehension of their weaknes made the Romanes care for preuenting new dangers, lesse than otherwise it might, and in reason should haue beene. But as men enuironed with darknesse, haue great aduantage of such as stand in the light; and presumption of good-casting in the beginning bring such, as intend the after-game well, to better possibilitie of winning the stake: so these Iewes, partly through the Romanes confidence of their strength, partly through their own secrecie in meeting, securitie of harbour in caues and dens purposely digged in the earth, and diligent prouiding necessaries for war; from litle & contemptible beginnings gather such strength and resolution, that they can be content to set the whole stocke vpon it, offring battel vnto the choysest warriours of the empire, toHadrianus optimos quosque duces aduersum eos mittit, quorum primus fuit Iulius Seuerus qui ex Britannia cui praeerat, contra Iudaeos missus est, &c. Dion Hist. Rom. li. 69.
Iulius Seuerus that noble General himselfe, called to this seruice (such was the daunger) out of this Iland of Britaine. And albeit the Romaines in the end had the victorie without controuersie,Periere quo • ex Romanis complures in eo bello. Quamobrem Hadrianus, cum scriberet ad senatum, non est vsus illo exord o, quo vti Jmperatores consueuerunt: Si vos liberique vestri valetis bene est, ego quidem et exercitus valemus. Dion ibidem. yet would they not haue wished many triumphes at the same price. This peoples last conflict with death, and destruction now seazing vpon them, may witnesse to the world, that they had beene a principall part of it now so generally and deepely affected
with their last pangs. For as this iudicious and vnpartiall writer saith; The whole world, in a manner, was shaken with this commotion of the Iewes.

4 But as the Preacher obserueth, that riehes are oftentimes reserued to the owners for their euill. So these Iewes extraordinarie strength was giuen them for like destruction. The greater danger their mutinie had occasioned to the Empire, the greater was the Emperours seueritie in punishing their rebellion past, the greater, his care to preuent the like in time to come. In battels and skirmishes was slaine of this people fiftie thousand, beside an infinite number, consumed with famine and diseases, during the time of this lingring war, protracted of purpose by the Romanes, not willing to trie it out in open field with such a forlorne desperate multitude. Now as Deut. 28. v. 62 Moses had expresly foretold, andIulius Seuerus nulla ex parte ausus est aperte cum hostibus cōgredi, multitudine ipsorum atque desperatione cognita, sed eos singulatim militum legatorum que numero aliquo adoriens, & commeatis prohibens, atque includens serius quidem, sed minore cū periculo, ita & adterere & exhaurire, & exscindere potuit vt pauci adm •
dū euaserint, & quinquaginta eorū arces munitissimae, vici{que} celeberrimi atque nobilissimi non ginti octoginta quinque funditus euersi sint. Caesa sunt in excursionibus praelijsque hominum quingenta octoginta millia: eorū autē qui fame, morbo, & igni interierunt, iudagari multitudo non potuit, ita vt omnis poenè Iudaea deserta relicta fuerit. Dion Hist. Rom. lib 69.
Dion (liuing not long after this time) emphatically notes, they were left fewe in number, their land laid waste, fiue hundred of their strongest munitions vtterly razed, nine hundred of their chiefe and most populous townes sackt and consumed by fire.

5 This mightie destruction of these Iewes, had generall desolation of their countrie by Romans, and their tributaries of these western countries, Adrian and Traian were both Spaniards by birth, Iulius Seuerus was called to their destruction out of this Island, wherein Vespasian had giuen best proofe of his good seruices. Their ensignes (being Eagles) were as emblemes of their swiftnesse to execute Gods wrath vpon this people: and Moses in this place by diuine inspiration, alludes vnto the Romane eagles. a people strange & perhaps vnheard of to their ancestors: are euerlasting monuments of the truth of Moses his prophecie, Deut. 28. v. 49. The Lord shall bring a nation vpon thee from far, euen from the end of the world, flying swift as an eagle; a nation whose tongue thou shalt not vnderstand: a nation of a fierce countenance, which will not regard the person of the old, nor haue compassion of the young. The same shall eate the fruit of thy cattell, and the fruite of thy land, vntill thou bee destroyed; and hee shall leaue thee neither wheate, wine, or oyle, neither the increase of thy kine, nor the flockes of thy sheepe, vntill hee haue brought thee to naught. And hee shall besiege thee in all thy Cities, vntill thy high and strong walles fall downe, wherein thou trustest, in all the land: and hee shall besiege thee in all thy cities throughout thy land, which the Lord thy God, hath giuen thee. Thus at length Iudah as wel as Israel, hath ceased to bee a
Nation not without manifest signesSignes foreshowing Iuries desolation by Adrian, recorded by Dion and others. foreshewing their fatall expiration. Salomons sepulchre, which they held in greatest honor a litle before this warre, did fall asunder of its owne accord; as if it would haue signified vnto them, that Gods couenant, made with Salomon for Iudahs peace and restauration, was now vtterly void, and finally cancelled by its rupture and fall. Wolues & Hyenaes did howle throughout their streets, & deuoure this people in the fields: these are the Lords messengers of woe & vengeance to this vngratious seed, whose fathers had kild and stoned his prophets, sent vnto them for their good. Yet is not the wrath of the Lord ceased, but his hand is stretched out against them still. For Adrian, after this strange desolation, by publique decree ratified with the Senates consent,Iernandes. prohibits any Iew to come within the view of Iurie. This he did only in a publique respect, least the sight of their natiue soyle might inspire this people with some fresh desperate resolutions, but herein made, though vnwillingly, Gods Angel to keepe, by his powerfull sword, this wicked progenie of those rebellious and vngratious husbandmen,Euseb. 4. c. 6. ex Aristone Pe
••• . that had kild their Lords first borne, out of that paradice, which he had set them to dresse and keepe. The same mightie Lord, hauing now (as it were) disparked the place which he had walled & fenced about, and graced with many charters of greatest priuiledges, doth by his arme, stretched out against them stil, scatter the reliques of this rascall heard throughout all the Nations vnder heauen. Deut. 28. v. 62. So as this remnant (left by Adrian) and their race, haue beene as the game, which Gods iudgements haue held in perpetual chace for this fifteene hundred yeeres.

6 Thus are Gods iudgements executed vpon this people; according to the order and course of Moses his sentence, pronounced against them almost two thousand yeeres before. For after he had foretold that paucitie, wherunto this last war had brought them; he ads immediatly v. 63. As the Lord hath reioyced ouer you to do you good, and to multiply you; so he will reioyce ouer you to destroy, and bring you to naught: and ye shalbe rooted out of the land, whither thou goest to possesse it: and the Lord shall scatter thee amongst all people, from the one end of the world vnto the other. Quos verò Hadrianus in eo bello Iudaeos cepit, in Hispaniā exulatum misit, p • rrò ex eo tempore, ad foelicissima vs{que} tempora Catholicorū regum Ferdinandi & Isabelle, at{que} etiam Emanuelis inuicti Portugaliae regis publica in Hispania Iudae eorum Synagogae fuere. Io. Vasaeus Chr. His. pā. 137. vide Pet. Ant. Beut. l. 10. c. 19. Such as were captiuate in this warre, were transplanted by Adrian into Spaine, his natiue countrie: where they had their Synagogues since his, vntill Ferdinando
and Isabels time. Of their ill rest there, and in other of these Westerne Nations, (foretold by Moses in the very next wordes) wee are now to entreate: but first to aduertise the Reader, So the continuer of the Historie of the sacred Warre complaines. Nulli mirum erat, nos rerum per Judaeam gestarum notitia destitui, ob Romanorum tum in Iudaeos inuidiam, quorum quidem te • pore, & deuotionem & pietatem superstitiosam quandam persuasionem credebant. Nulla igitur eorum ratione habita, nec mentionem de bis habere dignati sunt. Adde quod qui Syria praefectus erat, hanc quoque viribus, opibus, armis, militibus, exutam regebat. Cum{que} Christiana res pace quā bello magis accresceret, tumultis nunquam inclaruit Iudaea, neminem Imperatorum seditione. Iohan. Herold lib. 1. de contin. bel. sacri. cap. 15. Why Romaine Writers make no mention of our Sauiour Christ or his acts. That the state of these Iewes, from this time vntill the expiration of the Romaine Empire, can not easily be gathered from any Romaine Writers; who seldome vouchsafe the Iewes or Christians any mention, vnlesse enforced thereunto by some such famous Warre or mutinie, as fell out in Vespasians, Traians, or Adrians time; or by some other euent redounding to the Romaines glorie; whereas Iurie after this time, was not famous for any tumult, till Romes captiuitie; the Iewes wanted strength, and Christians willing mindes, to erect any Emperours praise by their seditions. So that, whatsoeuer calamitie, either suffered by the Romaines, was past ouer by Romaine Writers, as priuate wrongs not worthy of registring in their Annalls.

7 No meruaile then, if they tooke no notice of our Sauiour, or his acts, all tending to peace and loialtie. For as Tacitus notes,Tacit. lib 5. Histor. Ergo abolendo rumori Nero subdidit reos, & quae stissimis paenis affecit, quos per flagitia inuisos, vulgus Christianos appellabat. Auctor nominis eius Christus, qui, Tiberi • imperante, per procuratorem Pontium Pilatum supplicio affectus erat. Tacit. Annal. lib. 15. Iudaea was most quiet in Tiberius time; which was the best newes the Romaines cared to heare thence: only Tacitus spleene to Christians (it seemes) had made him inquisitiue of their first originall, whose Author hee acknowledgeth to haue beene one Christ, put to death by Pontius Pilate, in the raigne of Tiberius.

8 The estate of these Iewes in generall, betweene Adrians and Honorius time, may be gathered out of the reuerend Fathers of the Primitiue Church; who vsually stopt the Heathens or blasphemous Atheists mouthes, by proposing their condition, then knowne vnto all the world, for such as our Sauiour had foretold. But these reuerend Fathers obseruations, and such scattered testimonies of their estate and qualitie, as can bee gathered out of Romaine writers, during that flourishing age of Fathers, and continuance of the Romaine Empire, will come in more fitly in the article of our Sauiours passion.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of the Iewes estate after the dissolution of the Romane Empire, generally throughout Europe, vntill their comming into England.
div.p:
AFter the dissolution of the Romane Empire, they had some hopes of taking roote vnder the shelter ofTunc temporis Galliarum Episcopi, sacros ordines non nisi pretio, & quaestu conserebant; vti ne hodie quidem faciunt: & Iudaei genus homiuum coelo quoque ipsi inuisum Christiana mancipia possidebant Gregorio vtcunque non placebat, &c. Papirius Masson. lib. 1. Annal. Francorum. Theodebart and Theodorick, Kings of a great part of France, and other Prouinces, then annexed to that Kingdome. And whilest the Bishops of those Countries made merchandice of sacred Orders, these Iewes purchased Christians for their bond-slaues; vntill Gregorie the Great, hy his fatherly admonitions and reproofe, wrought a reformation of these two foule enormities, and open scandalls of Christianitie. Their number after was much increased throughout most parts in France, by their suddaine decrease in Spaine, caused by Sisibutus King of the Gothes, andƲide Crantzium, lib. 4. Sueciae, cap. 13. Lord of that Countrie; who had vrged them to profession of Christian Religion, or perpetuall exile from his Dominions. Such as made choise of banishment, before Baptisme, fled in troupes into France: where in short time, they and their Countrimen, there residing before, had as hard entertainement vnder Dagobert, though peaceably admitted at the first.Paul. Aemil. in Dagoberto. Some thinke the fame, and honour, which the Goth had purchased amongst Christians by his late fact, did enflame the Franck with a zealous desire of like glorie: others from more particular information of ancient Writers, aswellHeraclius cum literis abunde esset instructus, ad vltimum Astr • logus • fficitur: Agno • cens ita{que} in si • nis syderum imp • rium • uum a circumcisa g • nte vastandum, & autumans id de Iudaeis fuisse praemonstratum, per inter-nuntios Dagebertum ro •• u • t, Regem • ranco • um, vt cu • ct • s Iudaicae stirpis qui in Prouincijs illi subiectis manebant Christianos fieri prae •••• ret, eos vero qu •
• ollent aut exilio aut morte damnari. Quod Dagobertus volens effecit, omnes qui noluer • nt ba • t • sma suscipere procul a finibus elim • nant Franciae. Porro Heraclio non de Iudaeis sed de Saracenis fuerat praeostensum. Auoinus si • e Annonius, lib 4. cap. 22. French asVide Hispan. histor. in Sisibuto. Spanish, referre the originall of both persecutions vnto Heraclius the Emperour; who seeking his fates in the Starres, pulls downe Gods iudgements from heauen vpon these Iewes, scattered from the East to West. By this meanes, he had learned (whether by meere skill in Astrologie, or otherwise, is not now to be disputed) that the winges of his Empire should bee clipped by a circumcised people. This fore-knowledge,
howsoeuer gotten, was not giuen him for his good (for his feares came vpon him, when hee least suspected;) but for these Iewes mischiefe, whom he deeming as the likeliest, or only men that could bring his fates vpon him, inserts the former persecution as a condition of peace, then concluded betweene him and Sisibutus; afterwards preuailes with Dagobert, for enforcing all the Iewes throughout his Dominions, either to renounce circumcision, France, or their liues. And no doubt, but hee, that could preuaile thus farre with these westerne Kings, did also deale effectually with other Soueraignties of Europe, nearer vnto his Imperiall seate, for disinabling of this Nation from effecting what he feared: much more would hee seeke their extirpation, or conuersion, throughout his owne proper Dominions. And so I finde his persecution of the Iewes recorded, by such as wrote his life,Judaeos etiam inuitos ad baptismum compulit • , matheseos studijs operam d • d • t, haraspicijs & praestig js daemonum fidem adhibuit. Append Aur. Vict. as one of the chiefe memorables in his raigne: which confirmes their report, though otherwise authentique, who referre the two former persecutions, vnder the Goth and Franck, vnto the occasions aboue mentioned.

2 Shortly after, the progenie of such as had beene enforced to baptisme byHoc tempore Iudaei perfidi non solum tunicam sacri baptismatis, quam susceperant, macularunt: Sed etiam contra Regem regnum{que} conso rare ausi sunt, in quos haec poena statuta, vt omnibus suis rebus nudati, tam • psi perfi • ii, quam vxores eorum & filij, ac reliqua posteritas per cunctas Hispaniarum Prouincias, seruituti s •
•••• erent perpetuae, manerent{que} vsquequa{que} dispersa. Praeterea quicunque eosdem Iudaeos in seruitutem reci •• re •• , in nullo eos permitterent rituum suorum ceremonias celebrare aut colere. Filij vero eorum a 7. aetat • s • n •• , nullam cum parentibus suis habitationem, aut societatem habere permitterentur, sed fidelissimis C 〈9 letters〉 s nutriendi traderentur, & fil • ae eorum ac filij Christianis in matrimontum darentur, ne insidelium patrum s • o •• m semitas quibuslibet occasionibus itera • e possent. Vasoeus in Chron. anno 694.
Sisibutus, for their reuolt from Christ, and conspiracie against Aegica (his anointed) and his Kingdome, were adiudged to perpetuall seruitude, throughout all the Prouinces belonging to Spaine: prohibited the vse of their rites and ceremonies, not permitted to inhabite together; but, as if the Lord had vsed the Land of Iurie as a marle-pit, to fat the soile of this Nation where his vine was planted; after hee had lead forth the Iewes thither in heapes, hee scatters their heapes ouer the whole sur-face of the Land. All Parents not suffered to commerce with their children at all, after the seuenth yeare of their age, committed by publique decree to the education of Christians, appointed in riper yeares to bee giuen in marriage vnto their Sonnes and Daughters; that so the succession of infidelitie might bee abolished.
But Christian Princes consultations preuaile as little for their good, as Pharaohs policie for their forefathers harme: they must multiply, that Gods plagues may be multiplied vpon them. This last here mentioned, in their estimation not the least, though otherwise intended by the state of Spaine, was by the disposition of the diuine prouidence brought to passe, that another prophecie of Moses might bee fulfilled: Thy Sonnes and thy Daughters shall bee giuen vnto an other people; and thine eies shall still looke for them, euen till they fall out; and there shall bee no power in thy hand.

3 Of their estate from this accident, till three hundred yeares after, nothing memorable hath come vnto my reading: dishonourable it was, in that their name, throughout this time, seemes quite put out; miserable wee may presume it, in that their wonted curse is not expired, but rather increased in ages following, in which we haue expresse, distinct, vndoubted, records.

4 About the yeare one thousand, they were so vexed throughout most parts of Europe, that, as Moses had foretold, andJudaei ea tempestate in pluribus Europiae locis grauiter vexati, quid agerent, aut quo se verterent nesciebant. &c. Rapir. Masson. ex Glabre. my Author (little thinking of Moses speeches) expresly notes, they could finde no rest. A companie of them, seated about Orleans, out of their Diuelish policie, addresse an embassage to the Prince of Babylon, aduertising him, that the Christians in these Westerne parts were ioyning forces to assault him, hoping hereby to make him inuade Christendome, by whose broiles they expected, either better securitie from wonted dangers, or fitter opportunitie of fishing for gaine in troubled streames. But the tenour of their embassage being either knowne, or suspected by the Christians, the Embassadour vpon his returne was called in question, conuict, and sentenced to the fagot. Nor could the hainousnesse of the fact be expiated by his death; the rest of his Countrie-men (generally presumed to bee as treacherous, when occasion serued) were made away, without any formall course of law, by Fire, Water, Sword, or what instrument of death came next to hand; This furie of Christians raging against them, as farre as the same of their villanie was spred, which was quickly blazed throughout Europe.

5 Ere this time Ismael was come to his ful growth, & his posteritie hauing prosecuted their old broken title to the Land of Promise, through their diuision had left the possession of it to the Turke: and so far is Isaacs seed from all hope of possessing the good things thereof, that the very loue which Christians, the true seede of Abraham, bare vnto these louely dwellings of Iacob, breedes his vngratious posterities wo, vnto whom the inheritance belonged. For no expedition, either made, or intended by Christians for recouering Iewry from the Turke and Saracens, but bringeth one plague or other vpon the Iew; so prouident is this people, to procure their owne mischiefe, & as it were to anticipate Gods iudgements vpon themselues, by such deuises as their former embassage, whose effect was to hasten the sacred war: which in the Age following, vndertaken vpon other occasions, more than doubles all their wonted miseries. For it beeing intended against the Turke and Saracen, these other Infidels were apprehended as a fit subiect for such souldiers, as were indeede bent for Asia and the Holy Land, to practize licentious hostile outrages vppon by the way. Others againe made a shew of setting forward against the Turkes or Saracens of Asia, intending indeed onely to spoile the Iewes of Europe; Vnto which purpose that worthy Edict of the Claremont Councell ministred this occasion.

6 Auentinus Boiorum Annalium libro quin. Ex Germanis caelitus voce edita ita praedicant Deus vult, Gallijs, Hispanijs, Britanijs, Italia, Sicilia, innumerablis hominum vis duces praefecti, Tetrarchae Dinastae, episcopi sacrificuli, Monachi, foeminae sacratae, ciues, opisices, agricolae, viri, mulierculae cum cunis, pastores cum pecore, relictis regno, vrbibus, castellis, sacerdotijs t • mplo, contubernijs, vxonibus, liberis, p •• di • s, aratro, in Asiam gregatim migrant, sub specie religionis (itasunt humano) • efanda scel • ra impune perp • trant. Anscr • m praeferunt spiritum sanctum esse. Carolum Magnum reuixisse praedi • ant. The ioynt consent of Bishops, and others there assembled, testified aloude in these tearmes, Deus vult, Deus vult, hauing found (as it seemes) some lauish commendations, as if it had beene the voyce of God, and not of men, brought forth a rumor of a voyce from heauen, calling Europaeans into Asia: The report was not so vaine, as the people of those times credulous. For beside such as were appointed, or would haue beene approoued by the Councell, huge multitudes of all sorts, conditions & sexes, runne like hounds to the false hallow; some pretending the Holie ghosts presence in visible shape. Amongst the rest oneEmicho quoque Dinasta cum Rh • nta colis, vnde oriundus erat, ad Pannoniam pro • essit, Ii{que} omnes •• daeos sub i • go reli • ion •• no • trae m • ttere ••• n •• , p • losophiam nostram recipere recusantes compell • t, bonis on nil •• sp • li • nt, exto • r • s vrbibus agu • i, •• m • u • eliminant •• que contrucidant. Duodecim tum millia Iudaeorum in nostra regione coesa fuisse in annales relatum est. Henr. Muscus. Emicho,
with a great band of his Country men gathered from the bankes of Rheine, hauing ranged as farre as Hungarie, and there either despairing of his hoped prey in Asia, or onely vsing this expedition, generally countenanced by Christian Princes, as a faire pretence to catch some bootie nearer home, falleth vppon the Iewes about that Countrey, compelling them either to liue Christians, or die. Besides the spoile of their goods, twelue thousand of their persons were slaine by Emicho, and his complices, as the Annales of these Countries doe testifie. The like had beene practized a little before by one Godes Culus a Dutch Priest; who had perswaded the King of Hungarie, that it was a charitable deede to kill these vncharitable Iewes, vntill his beastly life did discredite his doctrine, and Christians begunne to feele the harmes of such licentious Pilgrimages, after the Iewes being exhausted, could not satisfie his, and hss followers greedie appetites.

7 About the same Age,Per id tempus Iudaei in Gallia & Germania rerum suarum sedem ac domicilium non pauci habebant; Petrus Cluniacensis literas ad Ludouicum scripsit quae extant; ijs laudat consilium regis de bello pro Ch • istianis aduersus Arabes Persas{que} suscipiende, deinde exposita Judaeorum perfidia atque improbitate. Auferatur ait vel maxiusa ex parte imminuatur Iudaicorum diu • tiarum maleparta pi • guedo: & Christianus exercitus, qui vt Saracenos expugnet, pecunijs, vel terris proprijs Christi domini sui amore non pare • t, Iudaerum thesauris tam pessimè acquisitis non parcat, reseruetur eis vita, auferatur pecunia. Seruiant populis Christianis etiam ipsis inuitis diuitijs Indaeorum. Crudelior in eos Rudolphus V • tis Monachus fuit &c. Papirius Massonius libro tertio in Ludouico c. 7.
Why the Lord would not haue the Iewes vtterly destroyed. Petrus Cluniacensis directeth a paraeneticall discourse vnto Lewes the French King, for furtherance of his intended expedition against the Saracens; shewing him withall a readie meanes of maintaining his army, making the perfidious Iewes purchase their liues with losse of their goods. But more vehement, if not more Iewish, was Rodulphus Vilis the Germaine Monke, deliuering it in Sermons as found Doctrine, throughout both Germanies, that for the better supplie of the sacred warre, (which Christians he thought were bound in conscience to vndertake,) the Iewes, being as great enemies to Christianitie as the Saracens were, might not onelie bee robbed of all their goodes, but ought to bee put to death by Christians; as a good Omen to their future successe against the Saracens. And vnlesse Saint Bernard, with other graue Diuines of that Age, had sounded a counter-blast to this furious doctrine, both by mouth and pen; this Monkes prescript had beene practized generally throughout Germanie, readie enough to holde on as shee had begunne to euacuate her selfe of Iewish bloud, alwayes apprehended by that people as the worst humour in their
body politike: Many such generall massacres haue been intended against them in diuers Countries; but God still raised vp one or other to sollicite their cause, because hee hath an eare continually vnto the Psalmists petition, not so much for theirs as Christians good; Slay them not lest my people forget it, but scatter them abroad by thy power. Psal. 59.11. Vnlesse God had giuen them such trembling hearts, and sorrowfull mindes (as Moses had fore-tolde) through Germany, France, and other Countries, they had not beene scattered so soone through this Iland; whither they were first brought from Fraunce, by him that brought many grieuances thence vnto this Nation. But the euill which hee intended, hath God turned to our good. For Gods Israel planted here vntil this day, may heare and feare his heauy iudgement, manifested vpon these Iewes in the time of our forefathers; albeit at their first comming they found some breathing from their wonted persecutions. But so prodigious is all appearance of prosperitie, in such as God hath cursed, that these Iewes hopes of ease and welfare, are an infallible symptome of great distemper in the publike state wherein they liue. Twice only I find in all the Legend of their wandering, they had obtained some freedome, and hopes of flourishing in the Landes where they were scattered: once in France, in the time of Theodebarte and Theodericke, when sacred orders (as you heard before) were set to sale; Once in England, vnder William Rufus, whose conditions were such, that whosoeuer would giue enough, might haue whatsoeuer lay in his power to grant. Their estate in England, during other three kings raigne vntill Richard the first,Nulli Iudaei intra vrbem habitant, exclusi enim ab illis sunt brachio aquarum, atque inter illud & Sophiae m • ris brachium aliud con • lusi, neque in vrbemire pepmittuntur nisi nauigio, id{que} negotij & commercij causa: sunt{que} Iudaei circiter bis mille, qui cum magistris congregantur, hoc est sapientum discipulis, inter quos primas obtinent Abtalion magnus & Abdias & Aaron Cuspus, & Josephus Sarginus, & Eliak m gubernator ex vno quidam sunt artifices vestium sericarium quam plurimum quin{que} mercatores sunt, ij{que} dit • ssimi. Nulli{que} Iudaeo illum equo vehi licet, praeter Salomonem Aegyptium Medicum regium, cuius officio Iudaei recreantur, suamque captiuitatem solantur, quam grauem sentiunt: oppido enim inuisi sunt Gsaecis Iudaei omnes nullo bonorum ac malorum discrimine; propter cortarios quidem pelles conficiunt, impuram aquam in plateas ante suas ipsorum portas effundunt: ideo{que} omnes graui iugo pariter premuntur atque in plataeis vapulant & coguntur violenter inse • u • re. Verum Iudaei ipsi divites vt dixi, sunt viri{que} boni ac misericordes, praeceptorumque obseruatores: qui captiuitatis miseriam aequo serunt animo. yeelds little matter of obseruation: this peoples hate had not as yet broken out against them, but was all this time in gathering; and after their first planting here they were to haue a time to bring forth fruite for others to eate, a time to gather wealth for others to spend, as Moses had foretolde.

8 Most miserable in the meane time was their estate throughout the Easterne Empire, as one of their owne Writers, (who went on pilgrimage to visite his Country-men, wheresoeuer dispersed throughout the world) complaineth of their generall hard vsage amongst the Graecians, instancing in such as were seated about Constantinople, within whose walls they might not come, but vpon occasion of publique commerce or businesse; in which case they were allowed passage, onelie by boate, hauing theyr habitation, as it were, in an Iland. Amongest two thousand of this seruile Congregation there residing, not one permitted to come on horse-backe, saue onelie Salomon the Emperours Physition; whose exaltation (perhappes not foureteene handfulles aboue ground) was held as a publique grace of the whole Nation, the chiefe solace of that miserable and seruile vsage, which all the rest, without difference, good or bad, did sustaine, daiely beat and scourged in the open streetes. Yet must wee beleeue this Relator; That these Iewes were wealthie, good and mercifull men, obseruant of the Lawe, such as could patiently endure this miserable captiuitie. But patience perforce, according to the Prouerbe, is no patience. If GOD had graunted them abilitie, or opportunitie, they had quickely shewed theyr Iewish mindes by Iewish actions. And why, hee keepeth them continually vnder, vnwilling to heare theyr crie, though they can not,The fulfilling of Samuels prophecie in the Iewes liuing vntill our Sauiours death. 1 Samu 8.18. wee Christians may easily perceiue the cause. For so his Prophet Samuel had fore-tolde; And yee shall crie out at that day, because of your King whome yee haue chosen you; and the Lord will not heare you at that day. Which wordes,Iohan. Baptista de confut. Jud. parte tertia. as a learned conuert Iew rightly obserueth, were not fulfilled in Samuels time; whose opinion may be fortified by these reasons.

9 Samuels authoritie ouer that people, was not so strictly lincked with GODS, but that they might reiect the one for their present Iudge, still retayning the other for their supreame Lord: and who can deny, that the God of their Fathers did rule ouer them in Dauids, Salomons, Iehosaphats and Ezekiahs times? Sinne no doubt they did in abandoning Gods Priest and Prophet, to follow the fashions of other Nations, in submitting themselues vnto a King. And Samuel, like a good Physitian, forewarneth them of that incurable disease which this new-s ••
〈…〉
temperate act did euen then prognosticate: whose fatall Crisis notwithstanding did not insue, vntill they (ouergrowne with desperate, wilfull, and intemperate malice) had reiected him with open mouth, who was both Priest and Prophet, and their lawfull King; whose kingdome was not of this world, whose soueraigntie was so vnited with the diuine Maiestie, thatGods wordes in that seuenth verse are as if he had said. Let it not grieue thy righteous Spirite, that they grow weary of thee, but let them haue their wil, for so wil they serue thy Lord and thy Remer. Sunt verba proculdubio opinor, filij Dei seu secund. personae trinitatis. 1. Sam. 8.7. in casting him away they could not but cast off God, that he should not raigne ouer them.

10 Againe, before that time, God alwayes heard their crie, and redeemed them from all forraine bondage; and such as Samuel there describeth, was neither generall, nor perpetuall vnder their owne Kings: neyther did the best of such vse anie, nor the worst all, or most part of the naturall Israelites, in such sort as he there threatneth; yet all the miseries there threatned, 1. Sam. chap. 8. verse 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17. haue beene since accomplished in full measure, if I may so speake, in length, breadth, and profunditie. First, this seruilitie hath beene extended ouer all the Nation, without exception. Secondly, the continuance of it hath beene exceeding long and perpetuall without interruption; and so must continue vntill they confesse their forefathers rebellion, and acknowledge him for their King, whom reiecting, they reiected God; for hee that will not so honour the Sonne cannot honour the Father as King. Lastly, those markes of seruilitie, set forth by Samuel, haue beene so deepely imprinted in this generation reiect of GOD, that his Prophecie, compared with moderne Histories concerning them, will seeme but as painted wounded men in a cloth of Arrasse, to the bleeding relickes of a scattered, vanquished armie. For neyther vnder anie Caesar, (though they made choice of Caesar for theyr King) nor vnder anie other Kings or States, haue they liued as Free-dennizens, capable of publique office or honour: the best of them are but as slaues, prohibited to vse the meanest of Christians so: The most of them, as Samuel fore-told, are admitted in Common-wealths, for manuall seruices or other handie-crafts imployments; Captaines I thinke none of them haue beene; vnlesse perhappes in some desperate seruices: many of them in greater Cities are suffered to follow Ma • chandize, that they may serue the State as Spu • ges; alw • y •• surer to be sq ••• z • d for the moysture th • y
haue sucked, than to bee nourished by it: Sundrie of them are curious Artificers, and professe ingenious Trades; like seelie Silke wormes, permitted to exercise their skill in precious stuffe, to fill Princes Coffers, and finde their Courtiers cloathing.Ex Narbonae proficiscitur lex in omnes nationes; vbi sapientes sunt & magni & suspiciendi Theodori bonae memoriae ex semine Dauid recta genealogia, qui praedia & sundos habet à principibus regionis nullius hominis vim aut imp • tum metuentia. Beniamin: fil. Ionae in itin. 1. Sam. 8.14, 15 16. Est vrbs enim ipsa Th • mia magna & frequens. Horum regio inter montes qui septentrionales dicuntur, sedecim dierum itinere protenditur, vrbibus magnis & munitissimis exculta nullo{que} externe gentis iugo subdita. Vnde prodeuntes incolae finit • mas & remotiores etiam gentes dirip • unt omnes quotquot sunt vs{que} ad Ara • es qui cum ipsis fidem habent Idem.

11 The possession of fields and Vineyards, hath not beene so vsuall amongst this people, as their spoile amongst such as possessed any: so this Iew relateth it as a speciall prerogatiue of Calinomus, the sonne of Theodorus (both in their life-times) chiefe of the Synagogue in Narbona, and lineally descended (as hee pretendeth) from Dauid, that hee might quietly possesse the fruits of his grounds. The Princes, it seemeth, of that and like places, did take other Iewes fields and vineyardes, and best Oliue trees, and gaue them vnto their seruants, rather tything than taking the tenth of their seede and Vineyards; for that vsually was the Iewes part, the other nine (as Samuel fore-tolde) fell vnto Princes Officers lot.

12 But the greater these dispersed sonnes of Isaac seruilitie was, the more it commendeth the fidelitie of Gods word concerning the sonnes of Rechab, who, as this Author relateth, liue vnited in forme of a Kingdome or Nation, not subiect to any forraine yoake; rather able to offend their neighbours, than likely to receiue harmes from them. Their estate to this Authors dayes continued such, as they themselues acknowledged vnto Ieremie; Only experience (it seemeth) had taught them to build Citties, for their better securitie against the incursion of forrainers, which was not against their oath, in case of necessitie, as appeareth from the eleuenth verse of the fiue and thirtieth of Ieremie; Because in other points, they haue obeyed the commaundement of Ionadab their Father, and kept his precepts, and done according to all that hee had commaunded them; therefore Ionadab hath not wanted a man to stand before him vntill this day; that is, their estate hath continued, such as their Father left them, much better than the estate of Abrahams Sonnes by Sarah; Though this Iew at his returne to Paris, then flourishing with all maner of Arts and Sciences, found his Countrey-men maruellous great Students in Diuinitie, and in much better state than might be expected to continue anie long time.Iere. 35 9, 10.

13 Lewes the seuenth, The persecution of the Iews in France vnder Ph lppus Augustus Papyrius Massouius lib. 3. Annalium Franc in mitio Phil. Aug. albeit instigated thereto (as was said before) had not shorne them so neare vpon his expedition to the Holie Land, but that they might beare fleece againe for his sonne to plucke off. Their Synagogues had remayned still beautified; and their priuate wealth, either before his death much increased, or in his time not much impayred. But Almightie GOD, who in testimony of his reioycing to doe them good, had raised vp Cyrus to Balthazars Throne, to release their Nation from that Captiuitie, which Nabuchad-nezzar had brought vppon them; to giue the world as perfect a proofeDeut 28.63. of his reioycing ouer them to destroy them, and bring them to nought,An. 1179. Kalen. Octob. Ludouici patris consensu Philippus apud Rhemos regium ornatum nomen{que} sumpsit, praesente Hen • ico regis Angliae filio, & caeteris regni proceribus. Quamprimum honorem illum adeptus est, Iudaeorum Synagogas donarijs omni{que} suppellectili spoliari mādauit: cum{que} eos audisset christianis molestos esse, pr mum debita omnibus remisit, deinde fundos eorum & res • nan mouentes, fisco addixit, Loco citato. Pap. Mas. did aduaunce Philippus Augustus, sonne vnto the former Lewes, vnto the Crowne of France, to defeate the Iewes throughout that Kingdome, in an instant, of all their former hopes; no sooner was enthroned King, but presently hee giueth forth his Edict; That their Synagogues should bee spoyled of all donatiues and ornaments belonging to them: and, enformed of the grieuances which Christians sustained by them, graunteth a generall release of all debts due vnto them from Christians, confiscating all their lands and immoueable goods. This was done that Moses his prophecie might be fulfilled in part, Deuteronomie chap. 28. vers. 30, 31, 33. Thou shalt builde an house, and not dwell therein; thou shalt plant a Vineyard, but shalt not eate the fruite thereof. Thine Oxe shall bee flaine before thine eyes, but thou shalt not eate thereof: Thine Asie shall bee violently taken away before thy face, and shall not bee restored vnto thee: Thy sheepe shall bee giuen vnto thine enemies, and no man shall rescue them for thee: the fruite of thy Land, and and all thy labours shall a people which thou knowest not, eate; And thou shalt neuer but suffer wrong and violence alwayes.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of the fulfilling of other particular Prophecies of Moses in the Iewes persecutions, in England, Germanie, France and Spaine.
div.p: 1 THat they should not once or twice, in this or that Age, in some one or few Kingdomes onely, but alwayes, in euery place, where they haue come since their rooting out of their owne Land, suffer such wrong and violence; must needes bee thought to haue proceeded, rather from diuine Iustice, than mans iniustice, which could not but haue varied with the diuersitie of times and places, and the seuerall dispositions of parties, amongst whom in this their long pilgrimage they haue liued. And yet this briefe enumeration (following) of their particular spoyles, and hard vsages, since Philippus Augustus time, throughout the most ciuil and b • st gouerned States of Europe, will aboundantly confirme the truth of Moses generall Induction, in the place now cited. Thou shalt neuer but suffer wrong and violence alwayes. To beginne with their persecutions in this Land.

2 Had Henry (the eldest sonne of Henry the second) (who was Papyrius Massonius: loco citato. The lamentaable massacre of these vpon K. Richard the first his Coronation day. present at the fore-named French Kings Coronation, acquainted with these seuere Edicts against the Iewes) liued to enioy the Crowne of England after his Father, as hee was entituled King with him: the grieuous wrongs and violence, immediately after befalling these Iewes throughout this kingdome, had beene ascribed to this politicke imitation of the French King his brother; at the least men would haue thought, they had been done by his subiects, by his sufferance and conniuence. But God had taken him away, and yet these Iewes intreatie continues much worse vnder Richard the first, who neuer intended them like harme; only vpon his Coronation day, (with his raigne beginnes their woe, which ends not till their finall extirpation hence) not willing to be beholden vnto them for their presents, or (as some thinke) partly afraid lest admitted to his presence, they might practize some sorcerie
vpon his bodie, he gaue command that no Iew should come either within the Church, where he was crowned, or the Palace where hee was to dine. But they desirous to present him with some gift in hope to haue their Charters, and other Priuiledges, granted by other Kings, confirmed by him, presse in at the Palace gate amongst others, making (perhaps) more hast but worse speed, one of them receiuing a blow for his forwardnesse by one of the Kinges seruants, who might well iustifie the fact by the Kinges command to keepe them out. The people about the gate apprehend the matter so, as if this Iew had beene beat by the Kings commandement, and so they thought might all the rest of that crew: and hence fall vpon them with such weapons as they could finde, as it was easie to finde bats to beate these doggish Iewes, come to their kennells; where they found but silly shelter: For albeit their houses were strong, yet the rage of the people was too great against them. With the multitude the former rumour was enlarged, that it was the Kings pleasure to haue all the Iewes destroyed: And, as the axiome is, mens owne desires are quickly beleeued. So farre more apt they were to apprehend this rumour as true, than to examine whether it were true or no, that the Lord chiefe Iustice and other Officers, sent from the King to appease the tumult, were more likely to catch harme themselues, than to free these Iewes from present danger: some of whose houses now flaming gaue the people light to spoile & rifle others in the darke. For so violently were they set to wrong them, and eate their labours, that they could not bee satisfied from dinner time on the one day, to two a clock on the other: many of these Iewes in the meane time being rosted, or smouldred with their goods; others leaping out of the fire fell vpon their enemies weapons. Although the outrage was such, as in a peaceable state might seeme intollerable; yet was the hainousnesse of the offence quite swallowed vp by the multitude of the offenders. But as the English escapt vnpunished: so the Iewes were not amended, by their correction. Their stubbornnesse, as the Scripture tells mee, did first procure their blindnesse, and their blindnesse becomming hereditarie hath confirmed their stubbornnesse to posteritie.

3 The former violence which they suffered,The bruitish stupiditie of the Iewes. would haue beene a sufficient caueat to any people in the world besides, to
haue carried themselues with more moderation in a strange land: but not the flies so stupid and senselesse indiscerning the causes of their smart, as this people is. Their perfidiousnesse and daily sucking of Christians bloud, had made them most odious in this, as in other Landes; and though a number of them be massacred to day for like attempts; yet the rest are as ready againe to morrow to seaze vpon euery sore, either to exhaust the reliques of life from such as are shrunke in their estate, by cruell exactions, and damned vsurie; or else to intrude themselues, as wedges or instruments of diuisions, into euery breach that shall appeare amongst Christians, or betweene them and others. In which practize they haue beene continually crusht. Finally, their generall carriage is so odious and preposterous, that albeit the CHRISTIAN Magistrates conspire together for their good, they themselues will certainly prouoke their owne miserie.

Their massacre in Linne.4 The lamentable death of those Iewes in London had purchased pitie, and compassion towards the rest, (as the Kings Proclamation for their peace and securitie did witnesse) but their Bretheren of Linne can not abstaine from offering that violence, from which the King had priuiledged them, to one of their owne linage, for becomming a Christian; attempting forcible entrance into the Church, whither hee had fled for Sanctuarie. Vnlesse they had thus riotously violated the Kings peace, the Christians had not assembled together, and the Inhabitants were afraide at all to meddle with them. But so God had prouided, that a great companie of forraigne Marriners should repaire vnto this mutinie; who, moued with indignitie of the attempt, could not content themselues with the rescue of the Conuert (at the first perhaps onely intended) but assault these mutinous Iewes, through feare repairing to their houses; which the other first rifle, then burne together with their owners, departing vnpunished with spoile.

5 The end of the Kings Proclamation being once frustrate, by this strange accident, though not purposely or directly violated by the inhabitants of this place; his subiects elsewhere are willing enough to imitate the fact, without any occasion of like wrongs, offered by the Iewes, only vpon opportunitie of doing
violence by the Kings absence, and the present mustering of Souldiers for the holy Land; vpon whom, transported hence, their partners, in euill here at home remaining, might post ouer the whole blame of the fact, of part whereof no doubt his Souldiers had beene guiltie. The like massacres of these Iewes ensued at Stamford, at Lincolne, and S. Edmundsburie shortly after; but of all others, most memorable and lamentable was that, which in the same Lent befell them at Yorke.

6 The Iewes there dwelling had heard by this time, what had beene done vnto their bretheren in London, and Linne; and see now the like or greater violence intended against themselues: so that as Moses in the fore-cited place, Deut. 28. vers. 33. addeth; They became madde for the sight of their wrongs and violence, The horrible conspiracie of the Iewes against their owne soules in Yorke. which their eies did see. One of their learned Rabbines perswades foure hundred of his companie, besieged with him in a strong Tower by a furious multitude, to proue themselues (such as the world had long taken them, and were now persecuted for) right cut-throats indeede, rather then fall into their enemies handes; himselfe confirming his doctrine by his example, in cutting his wifes throat first, then his childrens, and lastly by killing himselfe.
