The residue of the foure hundred, which hee had perswaded vnto this vnnaturall and Iewish act, not only willing to imitate him herein, would before their death haue enforced many others, that would not yeeld vnto this Rabbines aduice, to a more violent death, had they not conueied themselues into a strong Turret, within the manie Tower, which defended them from the flames that consumed their goods. And yet these poore soules, that had scaped their fellowes violence, were borne to suffer the like of their Christian enemies; to their shame, who had promised them life, vpon condition they would yeeld themselues, and become Christians; which whether they meant in heart or no, as they promised, hee that trieth the secrets of all hearts doth know. Sure I am, their professed Christian enemies did turne Iewes in heart, that treacherously killed them before any triall made of their sinceritie towards Christ.

7 All these wrongs and violences were committed only by the people, much against the Magistrates mindes; but hereafter the supreme Magistrates, Kings themselues (as if they had learned
wit of their subiects) tooke the monopolie of wronging the Iewes into their owne handes. To omit what Richard the first had done vnto them, their hard vsage vnder King Iohn, Henrie the third, and Edward the first,Yet were it worth enquirie Whether such as haue beene transported out of Spaine or other Coūtries of Europe w • re not sent into Aegypt; or what entertainment they find there. They came out of Aegypt without Ships for the Sea gaue them passage. Deut 28 v 68. The report of their persecutions about this time in Spaine made them more readie to redeeme their peace. Vide Matthew. Paris. makes me thinke, that Moses, in the last words of his often mentioned prophecie Deut. 28. spake in his language that said, Patria est vbicunque bene est: so as England, and euery place in Europe, wherein their condition of life hath beene more hard and burdensome, than their forefathers had been in Aegypt, may bee said to bee that Aegypt, whereunto the Lord had threatned to bring them againe by ships. King Iohns exactions were so grieuous, that they had rather suffer than doe what he commanded, many of them being imprisoned and tortured before they would yeeld what hee demanded. What an intollerable thing was it, for a priuate man in those times to pay tenne thousand markes,Mat. Paris. Vide orationem Pontifici Iudeorum, suorum calamitates deplorantes apud Mat. Paris. The French King persecuted them at the same time as miserably, as M • tth • w Paris intimates. Matth. Paris. for refusall of which that poore Iew of Bristow was so pittifully vsed? But with God it was iust, to punish him by his owne greedinesse of gaine; for vnlesse his money had beene as deare to him, as meate to such as make their belly their God, he would haue let his hold goe, before he had lost seuen teeth of nine.

8 King Henrie the third, first demands the third part of all their moueables for his supplies; then punisht them grieuously by the purse, for a murther secretly committed by them; and thirdly makes them buy their miserable peace by the third part of what was left: Finally, hee brought them to such extreme pouertie, that his brother, to whom he let them out to farme, could (it seemes) make nothing of them; and so they were freed from this brutish seruitude (as Moses in the fore-cited place had foretold) for want of a buier. The King surely did not so much pittie them, as he did himselfe and his posteritie, who should haue gotten nothing of them, if the bargaine with his brother had gone forward: whereas his Successor, Edward the first, accounted their goods as his owne, and for Non-paiment of what hee demanded, the whole generation scattered throughout this Land, were shut vp in one night, where they enioyed no day, vntill they had fined at the Kings pleasure; who yet perhaps did recouer but as much as he and his subiects were endamaged, by two hundred and odde of their Countrimen, all condemned some eight yeares before for
circumcising, counterfeiting, and washing his coyne. This King, albeit their wealth vnder him was much diminished, had this aduantage of his praedecessours; The English, desirous to haue them banished, and they, as willing to spite the English by their staying here, were both forward to purchase their contrarie desires by large offers to the King, vntill the English at last did outuie them, by a fifteenth, which the Parliament granted for their vtter auoidance of this land; so much welcommer was their roome than companie.

9 All their immoueable goods, with their Obligations and Bils of debt were confiscated: Thus (as Moses sayth) they had builded houses, but could not dwell therein, Vineyards they had planted which they could not carrie with them, neuer to returne hither againe, they nor their seede to eat of their fruit: yea, euen the gold and coyne, with other riches which they were permitted to transport, were reserued to many of their owners euill. The sea which gaue their forefathers passage from Aegypt, did swallow vp a great number of those wealthiest Iewes at their departure out of this Land. And, howsoeuer both his fact that exposed them to danger was most impious, and his speeches scurrilous, in turning them off to pray to Moses, when he might haue saued them, yet if wee consider the concourse of circumstances, and opportunitie tempting him, otherwise ill disposed vnto this fact, his prophane jeasting at their miserable death was a sensible document of the Almighties reioycing to destroy them and bring them to naught.

10 During this time of their abode here (which was two hundred and odde yeares) their generall persecutions throughout Germanie (that haue come vnto my reading) were not so rife, as in the ages following.Of these Iewes massacres in Germanie after their banishment out England or about that time. Auent. Boior. Annalium. lib. 7. In the yeare 1286 (in which they had beene generally imprisoned throughout this land) they had stabbed a child, throughout his whole bodie, with needles, at Munchen in Bauere, taking his bloud in a bason; to vse it, as the suspition was then, in sacrifice, for stanching that issue of bloud, wherewith this people (Christians know why) is continually pestered. These butchers were detected by the • rouer, an olde Hagge taken in the verse manner, while she was stealing a second for the same purpose. The bodie of the former being found out
by her directions, the fresh print of infinit wounds filled with gore, imploring vengeance, as it were with so manie watrie and blubberd eyes, did so enrage the multitude, that they could not expect the Iudges sentence, but fall immediatly vpon these Iewes, notwithstanding the Princes seruants, and their chiefe Magistrates earnest endeauours to appease the tumult, conueying as manie Iewes as they could into their Synagogue, which the people burning with furie, set on fire, and with it burned an hundred and eightie Iewes.

11. Yet this was but as a little flash in the fire-panne to that generall furie, which the people of this and other Countries of Germanie did discharge vpon this cursed seede about ten yeares after.Auentinus lib. 7. Boior. Annalium. The alarum to this bloudie fact was a rumour, true or false, by Gods disposition a meanes to bring destruction vpon them whom hee reioyced to destroy; as soone condemned by the multitude, as accused for stealing away the consecrated hoast, as they tearme it, and amongst other indignities for braying it in a Mortar, vntill it bled againe. One Rindeflaish, of what spirit God knowes, by profession a Husbandman (whether one of the raisers of this rumour, or onely taking opportunitie vpon it blazed abroad by others) proclaimes that he was sent from heauen to destroy the Iewes, wheresoeuer scattered vpon the face of the earth: and with that coniuring acclamation, as many as bare any loue to Christ, or wished the safetie and welfare of Christendome, let them follow him, gets so manie followers, that through eight or nine Cities, named by mine Authour, and manie others omitted, they robbe, spoile and kill these Iewes, now become as obstinate and stubborne as the others were violent. For after they had gathered their goods and house-hold stuffe together, least the Christians should be any better by it, or they themselues by Christians, that would haue enforced them to baptisme, the men with their Wiues and Children cast themselues into the fire, and so perish with their ill gotten goods. The signes of the time with which in particular wee are not acquainted, did fully perswade both Priest and People, that all was done by Gods speciall appointment: and Auentinus himselfe saith, Iram diuinam fuisse necesse est; because the Emperour, most desirous to reuenge their wrongs, was enforced to giue place to
this persuasion, and dissemble his griefe. The magistrates of Regineburgh (the auncient Metropolis of Bevere) with much adoe persuaded their people to forbeare execution of their wrath, and expect more certaine warrants from heauen for their proceedings.

12.Superest vltimus Philippi annus: illo leprosos, Iudaeos{que} in Gallia vexatos constat, propter suspicionem veneni in puteos sparsi, Autores sceleris Judaei a morosis & miseris hominibus esse dicebantur; quare in vtros{que} saeuitum, plebe nulla expectatâ Iudicij formâ igni illos cremante. Papyrius Massouius l. 3. Fran. A • rel in Philippo longo. Not manie yeares after this their generall calamitie throughout Bevere, and olde Fraunce, they and the Leapers conspire to poyson the Fountaines throughout the French Kingdome, and are both made away on heapes by the people, dying for the most part by the contrarie element, without any conuiction or arraignement, which fortie of themIdem Ibidem. imprisoned at Vitree in Champaine, did wisely preuent, by killing themselues all in one Gaole. So cunningly doth the Almightie plot their ouerthrow, euer since hee became their enemie, that it is oft times hard to say, Whether mans purposes for their good, or euill, bring greater plagues vpon them. Not fifteene yeares before this time,Vno die Iudaei • ota Francia cap • i, bonis e • rū fisco addictis, regni finib{us} excedere iussisunt. Papyrius Masson. lib. 3. Annalium Franco • um. Philip the Faire had apprehended all the Iewes throughout his dominions in one day, robbed them of their goods, and rid his Land of them. About tenne yeares after this their banishment by publike Edict (not fiue yeares before the late mentioned persecution)Ide Papyr. in vita Ludouici • uztini. Lewes the tenth, sonne to this Philip, intending their good, reuokes his fathers Edict for their perpetuall banishment, and brought them backe againe into Fraunce; where these malefactours were, by the appointment of God, to suffer just punishment for their villanies there committed by their fathers and them, and their bodies seruing for fuell to the flame, prepared by God to purge the ayre, which their blasphemous mouthes had polluted.

13.Auentinus lib. septimo Annal ū Boior. The like plagues, but farre more generall, from like prouocation, did befall them, about the yeare one thousand three hundred thirtie seuen, and the times ensuing, till one thousand three hundred fortie eight.The like plague befell them at Prage: about the year 1389 for the like contumely offered by their children to the hoast (as they tearme it) Incensis domibus, foeminae cum p • ruul s se sua sponte iniecerūt incendio, ne probris Christianorū exposi • ae ad extremū necarētur. Krantius Wandalorū hist. 9. c. 23. They hoped Christian religion should haue died in the warres betweene the Emperour and the Pope; the state of Christendome, they saw deepely endangered in these ciuile broyles: and they, according to their Iewish
policie, seeke to thrust it ouer head and eares in bloud, poysoning the Fountaines throughout Germanie, offering like violence to the Sacraments as they had done before; and by this just prouocation were so dealt withall by one Hartmannus and his complices, as they had beene vsed some fortie yeares agoe by Rindeflaish. The rehearsall of all particular outrages committed against them, during the time of the Pope and Emperours variance, would take vp more roome in this Discourse, than all the rest hitherto reckoned.Ʋide Mutium & Bertulsium Constantiensem. Most memorable is that of the Iewes, inhabiting Wormes; who, persecuted by the people, implore the Bishops intercession for their safetie: the conditions of their peace, procured by him, were to bee washed from their sinnes; and hauing respite giuen to deliberate vpon the point, they pollute themselues with their owne bloud, without returning any further answere to the Bishop that had interceded for them.

14. This and the like barbarous impietie, committed by others of this cursed race at Vitrie, almost fortie, at Yorke, aboue an hundred yeares before cannot be ascribed to the reuolutions of the Heauens, or successiue reigne of some vnruly starres; all of them were from his will, in whom there is no shadow of change. In these last massacres, as in the former, the Magistrates in many places had mindes willing ynough to saue them, but durst not venture their bodily presence for their rescue. Albeit the manner of the Christians proceeding against them be vsually such, as none but Iewes would justifie; yet this is an euident Argument, that the Lord of Lords, and King of Kings hath ordained them to suffer wrong, whome the greatest powers, in such ciuile States as Germanie, Fraunce, and England are, cannot right. For although the Palsgraue, with some others inclining vnto them, had taken their protection vpon them in these last Persecutions; yet euen this pitie, whether true or pretended, did cause their further wrongs, by grieuous exactions for maintaining the warre begun in their defence. So strangely doth the wisedome of God bring that to passe, which his seruant Moses had foretold, Deut. 28. verse 29. Thou shalt not prosper in thy wayes, thou shalt neuer but bee oppressed with wrong, and bee polled euermore, and no man shall
succour thee. Euen succour it selfe by their distempered appetites is turned into sorrow. Though all Christan Kings and States should conspire together for their weale; yet (as I said before) they will conceiue mischiefe, and bring forth their owne destruction, by bursting out into such shamefull actes, as deserue grieuous punishment in sight of God and man. So in theKrantzius. lib. 10 Wandal. cap 18. yeare one thousand foure hundred and ten, they go about their wonted practise of crucifying a Christian childe in contumelie of our Sauiour Christ; but their intent being known before they had opportunitie of acting it, the Marquesse of Misna, & Land-graue of Turing find roome enough for their coyne in their coffers, but leaue none for them, stript naked of all they had within any part of their dominions. Or if they doe sometimes that which in it selfe is good, they doe it with such malitious mindes, that God giues them but the reward of wickednesse:Krantzius. lib. 11. Saxo. cap. 7. So in the yeare one thousand foure hundred twentie one, for furnishing the poore Christians of Bohemia with monie and munition against their Antichristian persecutors, they were generally emprisoned throughout Beuere, quite bereft of all their monie and coyne, and lastly banished all the dominions belonging to Fredericke Duke of that Prouince. Nor doth their in-bred spight to Christians, or their plagues due therunto weare out in that age. For, in the yeare one thousand, foure hundred ninetie seuen, they were burnt at
Krantzius Wand. lib. 14. cap. 17. The like facts and like massacres of the Iewes, at Ch • raco, and related by the same Krantz • us li. 8. Wandaliae cap. 8. a. 133.
Of these Iewes estate in Spain and Portugall about the year one thousand fiue hundred.
Osorius lib 10. d • gefl • s Emanuelis. Stenneberge in the Prouince of Stargardia, for there wonted violence, and indignities offered to the blessed Eucharist.

15 Thus much of their estate in England, France, and Germanie, vntill the yeare one thousand fiue hundred. Of their estate in Germanie since, if God permit elsewhere, because it yeelds matter of distinct obseruation from the former. Now briefly to acquaint the Reader with so much of their affaires in Spaine, as may testifie some other parts of Moses his prophecie in the forementioned place. In the yeare one thousand foure hundred eightie two, the measure of their iniquitie was growne so full, that this land could not beare it: and they themselues become so abhominable to Ferdinand, and Isabel his Queene, that none of this seede must stay within their dominions, vnlesse they will become Christians, as sundrie of larger possessions amongst them in outward profession did, the rest were scattered thence into other countries
most into Portugall, welcome for their monie to soiourne there a certaine time: after which as many as were found in Portugall, were there to remaine as slaues vnto the King, such as would were to be transported at his costes and charges. The King himselfe (vnlesse Orosius be partiall for him) was carefull to performe his promise, to secure them of peace during their abode, and of safe passage at the time appointed. But the Marriners hauing once gotten them aboard, did make their ships as so many prisons, or houses of torture, to wrest their wealth out of their hands, lengthning the time by circular and vnnecessarie turnings, backe and forth, vntill the Iewes had quite spent all their prouision, afterwards enforced to buy their foode, and other necessaries of the Marriners, at what rate they pleased. And, not content with spoyle of their goods, they abuse the bodies of their wiues and daughters to their lust, not pleasant enough, vnlesse sauced with other contumelies, and indignities practized vpon their Fathers, and husbands. Finally by these marriners, too much thinking that their passengers were Iewes, and might be vsed accordingly, they forget that they themselues were Christians, and staine that sacred profession with all manner base villanie and impieties. Partly through this delay in shipping ouer the first companie, partly, through the abuses done vnto them, so shamefull, that the fame thereof was brought vnto their fellowes eares by the wind, which serued the Marriners backe to Portugall: the later sort remayning in expectation of safe passage, eyther could not, or would not be transported at the day appointed, and so by their staying become captiues to Iohn then King of Portugall. But Emanuel his successour, not long after sets them free, vsing all other faire meanes to bring them vnto Christ, vntill Ferdinand and Isabel his confederates, solicite these ill-thriuing plants eiection out of Portugall,The Iewes eiected out of Portugall and their miserable vsage vnder Emanuel Ʋide Osorium. lib. 1. de gestis Emanuelis. as vnfit to settle in any Christian soyle. After long debatement with his counsellers for their exile or stay, the fresh examples of their expulsion by so many other Christian Kinges and Princes did moue Emanuel to their imitation. So that eyther they must auoide his dominions by a certaine day, or else remaine there eyther free-men in Christ, or slaues and Captiues vnto him: as many of them did against their willes, not able to prouide themselues of shipping, hauing but one port at last allowed
them for their passage: whereas at the first promulgation of the Kings edict against them, they had choyce of three. The greatnesse of their number, best appearing by their confluence about the day appointed for their passage, moued the good King with compassion, to see so many thousand soules should desperately runne the waies of death; and seeing no hope of diseasoning the old and withered stockes, fit fewell for euerlasting flames, he was the more desirous to recouer some of their young and tender graftes, by watering them with the water of grace: and for this purpose giues strict commaundement, that all their children vnder foureteene yeares of age should bee taken from their Iewish parentes, and trayned vp in the Schoole of Christ. This sodaine and vnexpected diuorce, though intended in compassion of the children, brought greater miserie on the Parents, than if their owne flesh had beene torne from their bones. There a man (so his heart would haue serued him) might haue seene silly infants haled from their mothers breasts, more willing to embrace death, than part with them; And yet for pitie, (least their hands by holding fast, might proue their childrens rackes) suffering them to bee drawne out of their tender embracements, with farre more griefe and sorrow of heart, than they had beene brought out of the wombe; Fathers enclasping their sonnes and daughters, willing to die in their armes, had these beat off, (as hoopes from vessels which they enuiron) from their childrens bodies, and eyther broken or benummed with blowes. A voyce was heard through Portugall, surpassing that in Ramah, nothing but mourning, and weeping, and lamentation, many a Leah blearing her eyes with weeping for her children, and would not be comforted; Men and women filling the heauens with more hideous outcries than the Egyptians did at their forefathers departure out of Egypt: when the first borne of euery family, throughout the land, was slaine at midnight. But these were bereft at once of all their louing children, in the open Sunne. Many of them, not able eyther to rescue or dispatch their owne bowels, become madde with the sight that their eyes had seene, and killed themselues: Others, hauing better opportunitie, account it a part of their happinesse, to be able to preuent
their childrens washing in the sacred font, by drowning them in draw-welles and ditches. In both these calamities, at the two fore-mentioned transportations, we may see those Prophecies of Moses exactly fulfilled, Deut. 28. vers. 30. Thou shalt betroth a wife, and an other man shall lie with her. And again, vers. 32. Thy sons and thy daughters shall be giuen vnto an other people, and thine eyes shall faile at the sight euery day, and there shall be no power in thy hand. Many Moores, professing Mahometisme, were transported from Portugall the same time, but had no such violence offered them: what was the reason? God would haue a manifest distinction betweene this and other people. The barbarous Moores had some power in their hands, and the Portugals abstaine from like vsage of them: least the report comming to the African Mahumetans eares, might haue moued them to auenge their wrongs vpon poore Christians, liuing amongst them. But these Iewes no where had any Nation, none to auenge their grieuous wrong, which the Lord God of their forefathers had ordained they should suffer, at all times, in all places wheresoeuer they haue come, without redresse.

The lamētable massacre of these Iewes at Lisbon: and the naturall consequence of monkish deuotiō towards Christs image therein represented. Osor. lib. 4. de rebus gestis Emanuelis.16 Nor doe their fates change their name or profession. For what violence was euer offered to any of this race like to that which these late conuerts christned Hebrewes, (but still Iewes in misfortunes) suffered in Lisbon, in the yeare one thousand fiue hundred and sixe. Two thousand massacred in three daies space, many not suffered to die of deadly wounds, were dragged by their mangled limmes into the market-place, where the bodies of the liuing and slaine, with others halfe aliue halfe dead, were burnt together on heapes. The spectaclē was so horrible, that it quite astonied the rest of this miserable progenie, at other times as desperately set to suffer as Monkes furiously to inflicte any torture. Parentes durst not mourne for children, nor children sigh for their parents, though each halled in others sight at the place of torments, least these significations of their griefe and sorrow might bewray them to bee of the tormented kinred, with whom the least suspicion of alliance, was sufficient to make them inherite like plagues, ere the breath was out of their predecessors bodies.
Jngens eoiam die s • upor adeo mis • rrimae gen
• is sensus oppresserat, vt ne lamentari quidem cladem illam, & deplorare mseriam suam possent, qui se occultabant, quamuis filios aeut parentes sues ad supplicium abripi viderent, ne lugubri gemitu prodi • etur, vocem emittere non audebant. Sic. a, eos metus exanimauerat vt viui non multum à mortuorum s militudine d • starent. Osorius de rebus gest. Emanuelis lib. 4.
Osorius description of these distressed soules perplexitie, shewed their gesture and cariage during this massacre, may serue, albeit he meant nothing lesse, as a paraphrase vpon the last words of Moses often-mentioned prophecie. There (that is in the vtmost parts of the earth,) the Lord shall giue thee a trembling heart, and a sorrowfull mind, and thy life shall hang before thee. The disposition of the diuine prouidence in affording opportunity to this licentious outrage was much what like to that, described before in Linne. A great part of these tragicall actors were Germane and French marriners, which had repaired to Lisbon for other trafficke, but returned home vnpunished, burdened with the spoile of these Hebrewes goods, but more heauily laden with guilt of their bloud: albeit their soules were not so deepely died therewith as the Lisbone monks, who had instigated them and others to this butcherie, inflamed themselues with this furious zeale only by an vnseasonable speech of one poore Hebrew apprehended by the other as derogatorie to our Sauiour. For whilest the others, by long gazing vpon the picture of his wounded side, through a glasse, cast the reflexe of light, thence cast vpon their dazeled eyes, for a miracle, the sillie Hebrew, whether openly to contradict, or vnawares vttering to some by-standers what hee thought, bewrayed his incredulitie, how a piece of drie wood should worke miracles.

17 Whilest I reade so many christned soules, thus butchered like beastes for ones deniall of diuine honour to a liuelesse Image, I could not but pause with my selfe; and now I must commend it to the Christian Readers consideration, whether that part of Moses prophecie, and there thou shalt serue other Gods, which thou hast not knowne, nor thy Fathers, wood and stone,
Deut. 28. vers. 64 v. 36. may not be vnderstood of the conuert Iewes throughout the Popes dominions, thus oft times vrged to commit Idolatrie with stockes and stones, vpon more tyrannicall tearmes, if they gainesay, than their forefathers were eyther by the Assyrian, Chaldaean, Egyptian, Romaine, or any whosoeuer had led them captiue out of their land. If the monkish Apologizer replie: There is a great difference betweene the Heathen Idoll, and their Image worship: I grant the Idolatrie is of a diuers kinde: and
so it seemes Moses meant when he threatned this people, that after their finall transplantation by Adrian, and their scattering through Spaine, and these Westerne countries, they should serue such Gods as their fathers had not knowne. For this peoples forefathers, before Moses time and after, had knowne the Heathen Gods too well. If the Romanist yet reioyne, that in worshipping Christs Image they worship Christ: I will not denie, but he may thinke so: for so the Iewes thought they honoured Moses, be cause they honoured the letter of his law. But, to omit other reasons, this and other like outragious facts, committed vpon as light occasions, shall conuince their nice schoole-distinctions of foule errour, and turne their lies with such violence into their throat, that (as Saint Augustine interpretes the Psalmist of these Iewes) It shall euen breake their teeth in their mouthes.
Psalm. 58. v. 6. For if the zeale these monkes of Lisbone bare vnto this Image, had beene directed vnto Christ, they had in some good measure beene transformed into the similitude of his gentle, meeke, and mercifull disposition. It was wood-worship doubtlesse which had made them so madde and furious: It was their continuall adoring of stones, which had turned their hearts of flesh into hearts more full of fire than the flint, and harder than the hardest Adamant. But of the effects of monkish pitie towards Christ or the Crucifixe, as also of the Iesuites doctrine concerning Image-worship, elsewhere if God permit. Thus much of these Iewes estate from time to time, may suffice for our intended purpose, to be further collected in the Chapter following.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Generall collections out of the particular histories before mentioned: the strange dispositions of the Iewes: and Gods iudgements vpon them.
div.p:
1 I Cannot but approueLibro vndecimo, Saxon. cap. 7.
Crantzius his iudgement of these Iews, That they are a perfidious & wicked people, worthie to be spewed out of the confines of Christendome, as many Princes haue expelled them their dominions. But as the same author
obserueth, howsoeuer Christian gouernours (as the world now counts Christians) are most opposite in outward shew to the Religion which they professe: yet they agree too well with them in their loue vnto this worlds God, by whose meanes these Iewes, after they haue beene expelled one countrey, finde admission into some other, or else into the same againe; as they did into France whence they were expelled by the father, and brought in againe by the sonne; and intoAbierunt hoc anno ex hac parte Iudaei, Pij 5. secundi Pontificis max. iussu, qui acerrimo diplomate exterminari illos ex ecclesiasticae ditionis Ciuitatibus mandauerat. Quanquam enim ill • s tolerabat Ecclesia miserata illorum vic • m vt Christianis frequenti illorum aspectu, Christi Dei mors, versaretur ob oculos, & Iudaei Christianorum exemplis, ac doctrinae, ad amplectendam Christianae fidei veritatem, quam reliquias Israel iuxta diuini vatis oraculum, accepturas constat, incitar • ntur • à qua si ablegarentur ad alienos longius multò abessent. Tamen cum & vsuris grauibus exigendis & latronibus furibusque etiam rerum Ecclesiasticarum recipiendis, magicis artibus ac l • nocinij • mulierum exercendis illorum impietas iam eo processisset, vt pro communi omnium incolumitate expediret, tanti vim morbi celeri remedio coercere, omnino eos reijciendos ex ciuitatibus decreuit Hieronnius Rubeus. lib. 11. hist. Rauen. Rauenna, whence banished (for their combination with thieues and robbers, and sacrilegious persons, for sorceries or magicall charmes, in winning women to their owne or others lust) by Pius Quintus in the yeare one thousand fiue hundred sixtie eight, they were recalled by Sixtus Quintus in the yeare one thousand fiue hundred eightie seuen. As if the former of these Kings and Popes had cast their hookes into another mans liberties, and their successors had drawne them, when they had caught the prey. For so in truth these Iewes are like rouing hounds or spaniels, which catch a prey wheresoeuer they come, and carrie it vnto any Prince, or Potentate, that will giue them harbour. They neuer stand vpon better tearmes with any Prince or people, than notorious or cunning malefactors do with graue Iudges, or great States-men. Who oft times winke at such villanies as they hate, for some further purpose. Nor could these Iewes euer hitherto purchase their ease and quiet, as they haue often done their admission into diuers countries. Since their rooting out of their owne land, they haue continued as hares hunted from their seate; no sooner finde they any place of habitation in these ends of the world, but the crie of Gods iudgements streight pursues them. If for a time they may seeme to gather strength, or to recouer themselues from that faintnesse of heart: it is but to take their feeze with greater force to their breake-necke. In the pittes, which they digge for Christians, are their owne feete alwaies taken. The best aduantages which they can espie and entertaine with greediness for their good, are but baites, laide by the Almighties handeJdem. ibid.
to entrappe them: and whilest his iudgements huntes them one way, and they take another to escape, that in the verie places, wherunto they flie for refuge, as Foxes chaced doe to their holes, is the fatall ginne set for their soules; as appeares out of the Histories heere set downe, which are but so many experiments of Moses his rule. Deut. 28. vers. 65.66.67. Also among these Nations, thou shalt finde no rest, neyther shall the sole of thy foote haue rest: for the Lord shall giue thee there a trembling heart, sinking eyes, and a sorrowfull minde. And thy life shalt hang before thee, and thou shalt feare both day and night, and shall haue no assurance of thy life. In the morning thou shalt say, would God it were euening, and at euening thou shalt say would God it were morning. For the feare of thine heart which thou shalt feare, and for the sight of thine eyes which thou shalt see.

Of the loathsome conceit which most nations haue of the Iewes foretold by Moses and the Prophets.29 But as no monie could hitherto purchase their peace, and securitie from calamities: so neither could their calamities, though continually most grieuous, redeeme their estimatiō in the world, nor all the bloud of their slain (though their massacres haue bin number-lesse) til these times, allay, much lesse extinguish that hateful & loathsom conceit, which most men haue entertained of them. To ascribe all this to their forefathers sinnes against our Sauiour is true, but too generall to giue satisfaction in all particular doubts which their estate might minister. For why the children should inherit their fathers curse, without cōtinuance in like sins, is a point which admits no resolution. Againe, why this people aboue all other creatures should continue their diuellish temper stil, hauing tried such change of aire, diuersity of soiles, conuersing among so many seuerally-disposed people, seems yet more strange. I haue read of trees, leauing their poyson with their natiue soyle, by transplantation bringing forth edible and wholsome fruite, Wolues in few generations wil become as kinde as dogs; Lions and Beares by often presence of men, grow more tame; generally beasts of most wild nature by often housing will come neere the nature of domesticke creatures, rude idiots by frequent entercourse with men of better fashion, in time will take some tincture of ciuilitie and discretion. Of all sensible creatures onely the Iewe, in so many descentes, after so many grieuous corrections, for his owne, and his forefathers sinnes, can wee
no more leaue his Iewish disposition, than the Leopard can his spots. It further encreased my admiration, why the whole Progenie being vtterly banished this Land aboue three hundred yeares agoe, their memorie should still remaine for a paterne of mischieuous mindes, eyther apt to doe, or fit to suffer anie violence: The verie name of a Iew seruing this people as a perfect measure, eyther to notifie the height of impietie in the Agent, or to sound the depth and bottome of an abject, worthlesse, forlorne condition in any patient. Better wee cannot expresse most cut-throat dealing than thus, None but a Iew would haue done so: Lower we cannot prize any abject condition, than by comparing him to a Iew. For so in common speech wee exaggerate enormious wrongs, done to the most odious or despised amongst vs, This had beene ynough for a Iew to suffer, or I would not haue done so to a Iew. All these plagues are come vpon them, for continuing in their fore-fathers steppes; and to make their Creator the author of their villanous mindes, were impietie: His word endures for euer, Perditio tua ex te, O Israel. Yet, is it possible that any people, endued with the light of reason, should continue so obstinate and obdurate, as willingly to deserue all mens hate they haue to deale with? I know not better how to resolue this doubt, than our Apostle did his, of their fore-fathers vnbeleefe, after so manie miracles wrought amongst them:Such speeches do not import an absolute cause of the thing, but of our instruction or persuasion concerning it. Therefore (sayth he) could they not beleeue, because Esayas sayth, He hath blinded their eyes, &c. Iohn 12. vers. 39. & 40. Therefore must I say, they could not but continue hatefull and opprobrious amongst all people with whome they haue conuersed, because Moses had said, Deuteronomie 28. vers. 37. Thou shalt be a wonder, a prouerbe, and a common talke among all people, whither the Lord shall carrie thee. So likewise had Hieremie 24. vers. 9. I will giue them for a terrible plague to all the Kingdomes of the earth; for a reproach, and for a prouerbe, for a common talke, and for a curse, in all places where I shall cast them. If anie man then further aske, Why Israel is cut off from the Land which God had giuen him, and made a prouerbe, and a common talke among all people; God himselfe hath taught vs how to answere, Because they haue
forsaken the Lord their God, which brought their fathers out of the Land of Aegypt &c. This the Lord himselfe foretold, and gaue them warning of, euen when hee specified the articles of his Couenant, made with Salomon for their peace, 1. Kings, cap. 9. vers. 69. These authorities may suffice, to stay all such doubts as might arise from curious inquiring after the causes of these peoples incessant miserie; which cannot seeme strange, because fore-told; nor vnjust, in that they were borne to more extraordinarie prosperitie: from which being fallen, by following their owne vngracious wayes, they are now reserued, as Pharoah after manie admonitions was, for Markes or Buttes, against whom the arrowes of Gods wrath and vengeance must bee shot, to the terrour of others, and manifestation of his power.

3. These grounds supposed, the consideration of their manie and cruell massacres, their often spoyling and robbing, and other outrages, which, according to the fore-cited Prophecies of them, they continually suffer, would the Atheist but lay it to his heart, would wring thence, what the Diuine Oracles haue vttered; that this had beene a people appointed to destruction, neuer suffered to multiplie vnto a Nation; as if God had vsed them as men doe wilde beasts, nursing onely so manie of them, as may make sporte by their destruction. So likewise their continuall wandring vp and downe in the world, without any rest, doth aboundantly witnesse; that albeit they beare the shape and nature of men, yet are they no naturall part of the World; but haue the same proportion in the ciuill bodie, or societie of mankind, that bad humours haue in our naturall and materiall bodies; Which by course of nature should bee expelled her confines, but, being retained, runne from ioint to ioint, and lastly breede some grieuous swellings in the extreame parts. And, amongst other most tried and demonstratiue experiments of Moses often-mentioned Prophecie, this is not the least; that Spaine and Portugall, for these later yeares, haue bin the chiefe receptacle of these Iewes: as if Hercules pillars, accounted by the Ancients the vtmosts ends of the World, were not the full period of their peregrination West-ward, whome the Lord had threatned,
Deutronomie 28. verse 64. to scatter amongst all people, from the one end of the World vnto the other. There they haue beene in greatest abundance, for manie yeares, as it were expecting a wind for their passage to some place more distant from their natiue Countrie. And who knowes whether that Prophecie, Deutronomie 28. verse 41. Thou shalt beget Sonnes and Daughters, but shalt not haue them; for they shall goe into captiuitie: hath not beene fulfilled, in the Iewes inhabiting that Kingdome? Whether manie of their Stocke, whome Emanuel detained in Portugall, haue not beene transported since into America? or whether manie of the Spanish Colonies, haue not a mixture of Iewish Progenie in them? Nay, who knowes, whether the West Indies were not discouered, partly, or especially for this purpose, that the sound of these Preachers, vnto whome God hath appointed no set Diocesse, might goe out into all Lands with the Sunne, and their wordes vnto the ends of the world, vntill they returne vnto the place whence they were scattered? But these conjectures I leaue to be confuted or confirmed by future times, desirous to prosecute briefely some obseruations of their fore-passed miseries, not yet ended.

4. As Gods judgements vpon this people haue had no end, so neyther haue the grounds or motiues of Christian beleefe any limits; euerie degree of their fall is a steppe vnto our rising: ynough it were to condemne the whole Christian world of infidelitie, if it should not bee rapt with admiration of Gods mercie towards vs, as it is manifested onely in his seueritie towards them. But if, vnto their perpetuall grieuous calamities here recounted, wee adde their like continuall stubbornenesse of heart, wee shall proue our selues more stiffe-necked than this people it selfe, vnlesse wee take vp Christs yoake and follow him; vnder which onely wee shall finde that ease and rest vnto our Soules, which they haue wanted euer since his death, and without repentance, must want euerlastingly. Angels, Men, and Diuels, yea all the world may clearely see, that the God of their Fathers hath cast them off; that they haue borne no Signes or Badges of his auncient wonted fauours,
whilest innumerable grieuous markes and skares of his fearefull indignation against their fathers still remaine vnhealed in the children, after more generations, than their auncestors Seat of prosperitie had beene in the promised Land: and yet euen these later, as all the former, since their scattering thence, continue their boastings of their prerogatiues, as if they were his onely chosen people. A grieuous distemper of bodie and minde hath runne in their bloud for almost sixteene hundred yeares; the children still infected with their fathers disease; all rauing and talking, like men in a phrenzie, as if they were Wisedomes first borne, and heires of happinesse. Thus their vnrelenting stubbornenesse is an irrefragable Argument,A comparison of the modern Iewes stubbornenesse with the stedfastnesse of Abrahams faith That they are the degenerate seede of faithfull Abraham; for stubbornenesse is but a strong hope malignified, or (as we say) growne wilde and out of kinde. If the Scripture had not described his nature and qualitie with his name, wee might haue knowne by these moderne Iewes, that their first progenitour had beene a man of strong hopes, against all hopes in the sight of men: for these goe further, continuing stiffe in their persuasions of Gods fauour towards them, contrarie vnto the grounds of hopes, eyther in the sight of God or man, insolent in confidence, euen whilest they are at the verie brinke of deepest despaire. Abraham looked for a Sonne after the chiefest strength of his bodie was decayed, and Sarah his wife by course of Nature past all possibilitie of conceiuing: but his hopes were assuredly grounded vpon his faithfulnesse which had promised the same: These hope for a Messiah, after the fulnesse of time is past and gone, and their Countrey, being the Land of his Natiuitie, couered with barrennesse and desolation; without all grounds of hope, quite contrarie to the praedictions of GODS Prophets, whome they beleeue in grosse; after whose meaning they groape as palpably now in the Sunne-shine of their Messiahs glorie, alreadie reuealed, as if it were in Aegyptian darkenesse: Yet euen the fulnesse of that joy, which most of them doe looke for in the dayes of their Messiah (were their hopes of his comming as probable as they are impossible) could
not in reason support any other mens nature, to sustaine that perpetuall violence, disgrace, and torture, which they indure throughout so many successions, in this wearisome time of their expectation. Abraham was approued of God, for his readinesse to sacrifice his sonne Isaac at his command: These his degenerate Sonnes haue crucified the sonne of Abrahams God; and for their infidelitie and disobedience, haue beene cast out of that good Land, which was giuen to Abraham and his righteous seede; and for their stubbornnesse in like practizes, their posteritie continue exiles, and Vagabonds from the same, not to this day willing to offer vp the Sacrifice of a contrite heart, for their disobedience past, Deut. 29. vers. 19. but rather (adding thirst to drunkennesse) blesse themselues, when they heare the wordes of that curse, promising peace vnto themselues, although they walke on according to the stubbornnesse of their fore-fathers hearts. Their owne desires they will not breake: butvide Socratem lib. 7. cap. 16. Krantzium lib. 10. Wandalorum c. 18. Papyrium Masson. lib. 3. ex Ʋillaneo. Vide Hollinsheed anno 20. Hen. 3. & alibi. At Prage in the yeare 1240. (or thereabout) they crucified a Christian by Sacra Parasceu. Krantius lib 7. Wandalorū c. 40. Ioh. 8. v. 44. Christian children they can bee well content to Sacrifice, kill, and mangle, throughout all ages, wheresoeuer they come, as their often practizes in England, France, and Germanie witnesse; and the Iewes of Lincolne, executed at London for this crime, did confesse to bee a solemne practize, as oft as they could conueniently come by their prey. Thus out of the mouthes of Infants and Children, will God haue his praise erected still: their bloud hath sealed, and their cries proclaimed the truth of our Sauiours wordes, that these Iewes are of their Father the Diuell, and the lusts of their Father they will doe. He was a murtherer from the beginning, and alwaies delighted much in such sacrifices, as were most displeasing vnto God.

5 If Christian sobrietie did not teach vs to acknowledge Gods iudgements alwaies iust; although the manner of his iustice can not be apprehended, much lesse exemplified to ordinarie capacities, by the wisest of the Sonnes of men: the consideration of these Iewes perpetuall temper would halfe perswade vs, that the soules of such, as had either procured, consented vnto, or approued our Sauiours and his Apostles death, had beene sent from hell by course, into the bodies of these Iewes here scattered in these Westerne parts, as so many Messengers from
the dead, to shew the malignant heate of those euerlasting flames, by their vnquenchable thirst of innocent bloud. But neither doth Scripture warrant, nor naturall reason enforce such suppositions, either for acquiting Gods seueritie vpon this people from iniustice, or his goodnesse from suspition of being the Authour of their villainous mindes, though hee bee the sole Creatour, as well of theirs as their godly forefathers soules. For these their wicked posterities plagues are iust, because their soules, which hee hath made, will not receiue correction by their owne, or their fathers plagues, continually inflicted vpon them since our Sauiours death; but still, as it were, hunt out Gods iudgements, which lie perpetually in wait for them, by treading in their vngratious predecessours steps. In one word, though the God of their Fathers haue made their soules; yet they make pride of heart, inueterate custome, examples of their progenitors, their God. For vs Christians, let vs admire the wisedome of our gratious God, that so disposeth our enemies mischieuous mindes vnto our good; rather then enquire, how their villanies can stand with his iustice. This their vnsatiable desire of crucifying them, vnto whom the Kingdome of heauen belongs, doth confirme our faith, in that maine article of their Fathers crucifying the Lord of glorie. And (no doubt) but God, in his all-seeing wisedome, hath permitted the like hellish temper to remaine in all generations of these Iewes, that the former most horrible, and otherwise almost incredible act, with the actors Diuelish spite and malice, might bee more liuely and sensibly represented to all posterities, which had not seene or knowne them by experience. And Gods iudgements vpon these moderne Iewes, for their forefathers sinnes, hereby may appeare most iust, in that they make them their owne by imitation; plainely testifying vnto the world, that they would doe as their forefathers had done, if the same Tragedie of Christs Passion were to bee acted againe; yea, in as much as they practize the like vpon his liuing members, they are guiltie, aswell as their forefathers, of his death.

6 Generally, the outward carriage, and inward temper of these moderne Iewes are such, as all that haue any experience of them, may perceiue the excellent qualities of their worthie Progenitours, and the extraordinarie prerogatiues whence they are fallen, as sensibly and vndoubtedly, as wee can know by the lees, or corrupt remainder of any liquor, what the vertue and strength thereof was in it prime. The present depression of this people, below all others amongst whom they li • e, rightly taken, doth giue vs the true excesse of their exaltation, in former times aboue the Nations, as perfectly as the eleuation of the pole which wee see, doth giue vs the degrees of the others occultation. Finally, if wee compare the estate of such as liued in Tullies times, with these moderne Iewes estate lately mentioned; the great prosperitie of their Ancestors vnder Iosuah, Iudges, Dauid, and Salomon, may bee gathered from these differences as exactly, and as clearely, as the third proportionable number out of two others alreadie knowne. This is that golden rule, whose practize I would commend to all yong Students. For, from the knowne differences of their estate from time to time, wee may bee ledde vnto the perfect knowledge of Gods power, and prouidence, of his mercie and bountie to such as loue him, of his iudgements vpon such as hate him, and transgresse his Lawes. Finally, nothing in Scripture can seeme incredible, if men would consider the wonderfull exaltation, and depression of this people.

7 This admirable difference betweene the true Israelites of old, and these moderne perfidious Iewes,Vide Ezech. 6. is most liuely represented vnto vs in that parable of diuers Figges, which Ieremiah saw, Ierem. 24. vers. 1.2. The Lord shewed mee, and behold two baskets of Figges were set before the Temple of the Lord: one basket very good Figges, like the Figges that are first ripe, and the other very naughtie Figges, which could not bee eaten, they were so euill. No man, I hope, will challenge mee, for extending this Text beyond it litterall sense. One part of which, by the Prophets owne exposition, is to be vnderstood of such as were ledde captiue by Nebuchadnezzar, signified by the good figges: the other of Zedechiah, with the residue of Hierusalem, and them that dwelt
in the Land of Aegypt, represented by the badde figges. My Prophet indeede applies it only vnto them of his owne time; of whom I confesse it was litterally meant: but not only of them; but more principally, more fully and directly, of the Iewes, about, or since our Sauiours time, and his Apostles, or their followers. The parable, with the consequence thereof, is true of both; in as much as both are particulars, contained vnder that generall diuision, whichVide supra cap. 5. paraph. 6.
Moses had made of Blessings and Cursings to befall this people in diuers measures, according to their constancie in good, or stubbornnesse in euill. Vnto this generall prediction the Prophets doe still frame their prophecies, as corollaries or appendices; and so must they be applied by vs, not only to the present times wherein they wrote, but to the times of the Messiah, in which both Moses his generall, and the Prophets particular prophecies were more fully accomplished, than in any age before. That which Ieremie in the third Verse of that same Chapter said of the figges, was true of this people in all ages: The good amongst them were very good, the naughtie alwaies very naughtie: but the difference greater betwixt the better sort of the ancient, and the worse of later, than betwixt the best and worst of such as liued in the middle age; greatest of all betwixt the good and badde, in our Sauiours time, or immediately after. These wordes againe of the Prophet, verse 6. & 7. are altogether as litterally, more peculiarly meant of Christs Apostles, and Disciples, than of Nehemiah and Zerubbabel, and the rest which returned from the captiuitie of Babylon: For I will set mine eies vpon them for good, and I will bring them againe to this Land, and I will build them, and I will plant them, and not roote them out, and I will giue them a heart to know mee, that I am the Lord, and they shall bee my people: And I will bee their God; for they shall returne vnto mee with their whole heart. So is that curse, Verse 9.10. more fully verified of the Iewes, about, or after our Sauiour Christs time, than of Zedechiah, and his complices: I will euen giue them for a terrible plague to all the Kingdomes of the Earth, and for a reproch, and for a prouerbe, for a common talke, and for a curse in all places, where I shall cast them. And I will send the sword, the famine, and the pestilence among them, till
till they be consumed out of the Land that I gaue vnto them and to their Fathers. In like sort I must needes with all orthodoxall antiquitie, not contradicted for more than a thousand yeares, acknowledge the Psalmists prayer, Psalme 59. to haue beene more directly meant, at least more notably fulfilled, in the Iewes of later times, than of his enemies amongest whome hee liued; Slay them not, O God, lest my people forget it; but scatter them abroad by thy power, and put them downe O Lord our shield, for the sinne of their mouth, and the words of their lippes; and let them be taken in their pride, euen for their periury and lies which they speake. The infallible grounds of thus interpreting these two places, and the like, shall be fortified, (GOD willing) when I come vnto the prophecies concerning Christs incarnation, passion, or exaltation; My warrant at this time for the later heere alleadged, shall be the end of the Psalmists wish, verse 13. Consume them in thy wrath, consume them, that they be no more: and let them know that God ruleth in Iacob vnto the ends of the world. Their strange massacres in these ends of the world, whither they haue beene scattered, doth better confirme our faith of Gods prouidence, and mercie towards vs, then Dauids enemies exile, and scattering, did his people, of Gods fauour towards him and them. And it is to bee obserued, that he saith not, Let them know in Iacob, that God ruleth vnto the ends of the world. For we the adopted sonnes of Abraham, though liuing in these extreame parts of the world, which he neuer knew, are the true Iacob; and the naturall sonnes of Abraham according to the flesh, though liuing in the Promised Land, haue no inheritance in Iacob; all are Iewes. So doth he, which sits vpon the circles of the heauens, weigh all the Kingdomes of the earth as in a ballance, debasing some, and aduauncing others at his pleasure:Gods fauours to the ancient Israelites paralelled by like blessings vpon the Gentiles. and so doth the light of his gratious countenance towards any Land or People, change or set, in reuolution of times, as the aspect of starres doth vnto such as compasse the earth. And yet, as the same obseruation of the Sunnes motion from contrary tropicks to the Line, serueth our English in Summer, and the Nauigators of opposite Climes in Winter: So is the same light of Gods countenance, which shone vpon the Iews, before, turned to the Gentiles, after the fulnes of time. Abraham had the Promise of Canaan often renewed vnto him; but neyther hee, nor his posteritie possessed
it, vntill the fulnesse of the Canaanites iniquitie were accomplished: wee Gentiles had the promises of being engrafted into Israel, as it were, conueighed vnto vs in the building of the second Temple, and afterwards renewed in the translation of these sacred writings (the instruments of our inheritance) into the Greek tongue, but were not partakers of the blessings of Iacob, vntill the iniquitie of Abrahams posteritie, according to the flesh, was full. Againe, as the Canaanites were not vtterly destroyed, albeit the Israelites were commaunded so to doe: but some relickes were reserued in the promised Land to a good purpose, by the wisedome of God: so neyther were these Iewes vtterly extinguished, but a remnant was scattered abroad amongst the Gentiles, that they might know Gods mercie towards them by his iudgements vppon the other: and though Christian Princes haue oft receiued them, vpon as vniust respects, as the Israelites did permit the Canaanites to dwell amongst them, yet God hath still rectified their errour, and turned their euill imaginations to the great good of his chosen. Gods fauours towards them of olde, and vs of late, might bee thus paralelled in many points: and, as Moses made nothing about the Arke,Exod 25 40. Heb. 8.5. but according to the fashion that was shewed him in the mountaine: so is there no euent or alteration of moment vnder the Gospel, but had a patterne in the Lawe and Prophets. The celestiall obseruations which were taken for these Israelites good, might continually serue for the direction of the Gentile, if hee would obserue the seuerall signes of diuerse Ages, as Mariners vse diuers Constellations in diuers latitudes, and gaze not alwayes vpon the same pole. TheMatth. 16.3. Luke 12.54. ignorance in discerning the signes of Times, was a Symptome of the Iewes hypocrisie, and cause of his continuall ship-wracke in faith. For suffering the fulnesse of time (where hee and the Gentiles should haue met as at the Aequator) to passe away without correction of his course or due obseruation of the sodaine change of heauens aspect; hee lost the sight of his wonted signes, and since wanders vp and downe, as Marriners destitute of theyr Carde,The Iewes blindnes is an especi • ll light v ••• the Gentile. depriued of all sight, either of Sunne, Moone, or Stars: or rather, like blinde men groaping their way without any ocular direction: yet euen this their blindenesse, is, or may be a better light, and direction vnto vs, than their wonted sight and skill in
Scriptures could afford vs. First, this might teach the wisest amongest vs, not to be high minded, but feare; seeing wisedome hath perished from the wisest of mankind, euen from Gods owne chosen people. Secondly, this palpable blind obstinacie, which hath befallen Israel, might persuade vs Christians (were not we blind also) to vse that methode, which God himselfe did think most fit, for planting true faith in tender hearts: Christian parents, whether bodily or spirituall, should be as carefull to instruct their children what the Lord had done vnto these Iewes, as the Israelites should haue b • ene, to tell their sonnes, what God had done vnto Pharaoh. His hardnesse of heart, was nothing to their stubbornenesse, Aegyptian darknesse was as noone-tide to their blindnesse; all the plagues and soares of Egypt, were but flea-bitings to Gods fearefull marks vpon these Iews: yet is al this come vpon them, that the fulnes of the Gentiles might come in.Rom. 11.25. With a more mightie hand hath God brought vs out of the shadow of death, and dominions of Sathan; than he brought the Israelites out of Egypt, out of the house of bondage: with a more powerfull, and harder stretched out arme, hath he scattered these Iewes among all people, from the one end of the world to the other, than he brought the frogs, flies, and caterpillers into Egypt.Ex. 13.9, 14, 1 • . And it should be as a token in our hands, and as frontlets between our childrens eies, that the Lord hath redeemed vs through a mightie hand. When Israel departed out of Egypt, the Egyptian did not furnish him with weapons for his defence, or Apologies for his departure. These Iewes scattered abroad, are made such Messengers as Vriah was of their owne destruction, bearing records against themselues, but sealed vp from their sight; holding Moses their chiefe accuser, in greatest honour; or to follow that faithfull follower of Christ, S. August. in his similitude to this purpose: although these Iewes be desperately blinde themselues, yet they carry those looking glasses before them, which long since put out their eyes by their too much gazing on them, so as now they can hold them onely in their hands, or turne their faces towards them, not able to discerne their misshapen visages in them; but we Gentiles which come after them, do herein go before them, that we may cleerly see their deformitie, and hideous blindnes, first caused by the glorious beames of the diuine maiestie shining in these sacred fountaines, whilest they
vsed them (as Narcissus did his Well, or little Babes doe Bookes with faire Pictures) onely to solace themselues with representation of their godly forefathers beautie, set out in them in freshest colours; not as looking glasses to discouer, much lesse to reforme what was amisse in themselues, whom they in the pride of their hearts still presumed to be in all points like their worthie Auncestours.

8 If vnto all their miseries throughout so many Ages, wee adde their perpetuall stupiditie and deadnesse of heart to all works of the Spirite; if to this againe wee adde their incomparable zeale and courage, in preseruing the letter of the Law; and lay all vnto our hearts: what is it we can imagine, the Lord could haue done vnto his vineyard,Esay 5.46. that he hath not done to it? He hath commanded the cloudes not to raine vpon the naturall branches, that the aboundant fatnesse of the roote might be wholly communicate to vs Gentiles, by nature wilde grafts. He hath laied his Vineyard in Israel waste, and left the hill of Sion his wonted ioy, more desolate then the mountaines of Gilboah, that the deaw of all his heauenly blessings might descend vpon the valleis of the Nations. Let vs not therefore tempt the Lord our God, in asking further signes for confirmation of our faith: for no signe can be giuen vs, aequiualent to this desolation of the Iewes. Such as the dayes of Ierusalem were in her distresse, such we know (but how farre more grieuous, wee can not conceiue) the day of iudgement shall be; euen a day of wrath, and a day of vengeance; an end of dayes, and an end of comfort; a beginning of an endlesse night of sorrow, troubles, woe, and miseries to the wicked.The desolation of the Iews the most effectuall signe for confirming christian faith. Leuit. 26.44. Such as the condition of these Iewes hath beene, for more than fifteene hundred yeares; such shall the state of vnbeleeuers bee without end, without all rest or securitie from daunger, disgrace, and torture, tenne thousand times more dreadfull and insufferable, than what the others at any times haue feared or felt. What else hath beene verified of them, as in the type; must bee fulfilled in vnbeleeuers, as in the bodie or substance. These shall feare both night and day, and shall haue no assurance of their life; but in steade thereof, an ineuitable perpetuitie of most grieuous death. In the morning they shall say, Would God it were euening; and at euening they shall say, Would GOD it were
morning, and wish that Time might bee no more, or that no dayes of ioy had euer beene; that all their mirth had beene exchanged for sorrow, euen whilest it was first conceiued within their breast, that so no memorie of sweete delights or pleasures past, might adde gall vnto the bitternesse of their present griefe, nor minister oyle vnto that vnquencheable flame wherein they frie. Thus much of Gods extraordinarie mercies and iudgements towards these Iewes, and of the experiments which their estate from time to time hath afforded for the establishing of our assent to Scriptures.

9 Particular iudgements vpon any Land or People, as remarkeable and perspicuous to common sense, as heeretofore haue beene, wee are not in this Age to expect. The approach of this generall and fearefull iudgement, wee may iustly thinke, doth swallow vp the most of them, as great plagues vsually drinke vp all other diseases. The conuersion of these Iewes wee may probably expect, as the chiefe signe of later times; onely this last part of Moses prophecie, Leuiticus chapter 26. verse 44. hath not beene as yet fulfilled, but must bee in due time, for so he saith, Yet notwithstanding this (euen all the plagues and curses which hee had threatned, and wee haue seene fulfilled in these Iewes) when they shall be in the land of their enemies, I will not cast them away, neyther will I abhorre them, to destroy them vtterly, and to breake my couenant with them: For I am the Lord their GOD: But I will remember for them, the couenant of old when I brought them out of the land of Egypt, that I might be their God: I am the Lord. And the continuation of their former plagues seemeth much interrupted, the plagues themselues much mitigated, in this last Age (since the Gospel hath beene againe reuealed) as if their miserie were almost expired, and the day of their redemption drawing nigh. Yet would I request such as with me holde their generall conuersion, before the end of all things, as a truth probably grounded on GODS word; not to put that euill day farre from them, as if it could not take them vnawares, vntill GODS promise to this people bee accomplished. For, (were that the point now in hand) I could (mee thinkes) as probably gather out of scriptures, that their conuersion shalbe sodaine,
as at all, and such as many parts of the world shall not so soone heare of, by authenticke r • ports or vncontroulable relation, as sensibly see at our generall meeting before our Iudge.

10 Like experiments might bee drawne from the reuolutions or alterations of other states, oft times wrought by such causes, as are without the reach of policie, but most cōsonant to the rules of scriptures; or from the verification of such rules, in Gods iudgements vpon priuate persons. But these obseruations can not bee made so euident to ordinary Readers, before the doctrine of Gods prouidence be vnfolded. Wherefore I must referre them partly to that place, partly to others of my Labours, which haue been most plentifull in this Argument. Onely that mutation in our deliuerance from the seruitude of the Romish church, may not be omitted.A paralell of the Israelites deliuerance from Egyptian and ours from Babylonish thraldome. For, if we compare it with the Israelites departure out of Egypt: the maner of Gods prouidence exemplified at large by Moses in the former, is as a perfect rule to discerne the same power in the later; and the fresh experiment of the later confirmes vnto our consciences the truth of the Historie concerning the former. God from the spoyles of the Egyptians furnished the Israelites with all things necessary for their iourney; the same God had reuiued the study of tongues, and reuealed the Arte of Printing, alittle before our fore-fathers departed out of Babylon, that they should not come away empty, but well furnished to wage warre with their enemies, whom they had robbed of their chiefe iewels, leauing small store of polite literature, or skill in Scriptures amongst them; though they haue increased their faculties that way since. If wee diligently view the disposition of Gods prouidence before those times, we can not but acknowledge, that it was the same power that first caused light to shine out of darkenes, which then renewed the face of the earth againe, and brought the light of ingenious and sacred literature, foorth of the chaos of barbaritie, obscuritie, and fruitlesse curiositie, wherein it had beene long inclosed. It is (me thinks) a pleasant contemplation to obserue how the Worthies of the age praecedent did bestirre themselues in gathering and dressing armour, not vsed for many hundred yeares before, no man knowing for what purpose, vntil the great Commander of heauen and earth giues out his commission to the captaines
of his hoste, for inuading his enemy, the man of sinne. Little did that noble, religious, and learned King Alphonsus, or Laurentius de Medicis, with such like, thinke of Luther, Zuinglius, Caluin, Bucer, Melancthon, or other champions departure from the Romish Church, when they gaue such countenance to polite learning and learned men, from whom these had their skill: yea these men themselues, and their fellowes did little thinke of such proiects, as God by them after effected, when they first beganne to vse those weapons, by which they finally foiled their mightie aduersaries. Againe, wee haue as it were, a fresh print of Gods dealing with Pharaoh in his like proceedings against the Pope. Pharaoh being deliuered ouer to the stubbornenesse of his owne heart, had it so hardened at last, that hee desperately looseth both life and kingdome, whilest hee wrangles with the Israelites for their cattell. The Popes heart likewise was so farre hardened for his former pride, and so strangely besotted with the sweetnesse of his owne Cup, that he cannot forgoe the very dregges, but will haue all swallowed downe, euen Indulgences themselues; that so the Lords name might be glorified in his shameful ouerthrow. Vnlesse it had bin for such a notorious and palpable blindnesse of heart, in retayning that more than heathenish and idolatrous abhomination; the iust causes of Luthers reuolt had not bin so manifest to the world, nor others departure from the Romish church so generall. All this, as it was the Lords doing, so ought it to seem wonderfull in our eyes. For in this our deliuerance was manifested the selfe same power, wisedome, and prouidence, for the stedfast acknowledgement of which, all the former miracles in Egypt had bin wrought: then necessarie to the Israelites, but not to our forefathers, who had belieued the truth of Moses miracles; instructed by the rules of Gods prouidence in them manifested, to discerne the same infinite power and wisedome in their owne deliuerance: the maner of which was truely miraculous, as theInterim si pontificij omnino cū Judaeis signum habere velint, acci • iant hoc, quod nos summi miraculi loco habemus, va • cū vir • m • u •• ue mise • um Mona

Lutherane wel answered the Papist Iewish like requiring signes or miracles for Luthers doctrine, which had the same signes to confirme it, that Christianitie it selfe first had.

l.hi: Vir sine vi ferri, vi verbi, & inermibus armis;
Vir sine re, sine spe, contulit orbis opes.

q.l: Sans dint of sword, by strength of word,
And armelesse harmelesse paines;
A wealthlesse wight, hopelesse in sight,
Hath crash'd Romes golden vaines.

div.p:
11 Luthers successe was apprehended by the worldly wisemen of those times as impossible, as the praedictions of Pharaohs ouerthrow by Moses, would haue beene to such in that Age, as knew not the will or power of God. And Albertus Dolebat sanctissimo viro non solum vitam eorum, quibus religionis confessio mandata erat, nefarijs sceleribus inquinari, sed serpere etiam in religionē maximos errores. Ideò de illis euer
• endis plurimum laborabat: Sed quod tandem videret papae authoritatem, quousque processisset, & diffideret, ne vnus homo tanto negotio par esset, de seipso spem abiecit, & optauit, vt omnes docti viri couiunctis studijs papam in ordinē redigerent. Idem dixit, quam paulo ante mortem, infirmus, Lutheri propositiones de indulgentijs vidisset, Lutheram in bonam causam ingressum esse, sed vnius homuncionis vires nihil valere ad tantam pontificis potentiam infringendam, quae nimium inualuisset. Et l • cti • & approbatis propositionibus Lutheri, exclamasse fertur, Trater &c. Iohan. Wolf. in praefat. ad Krantzij opera. Krantius, a man, as of an excellent Spirit, so of farre greater place and authoritie in Germanie than Luther was, and one, that from as earnest detestation of the Romish Churches pride and insolencies, notified as great a desire of reformation, as Luther had; yet thought he should but haue lost his labour in oppugning that greatnesse whereto it was growne. The same Bishop, a little before his death, beeing made acquainted with Luthers purpose; after approbation of his good intents to reforme the abuse of Indulgences, burst out into these despairing speeches of his good successe: Frater, frater, abi in cellam, & dic; Miserere mei, Deus. Brother, brother, get into thy cell, and take vp a Psalme of mercie.

12 Would God the incredulitie and carelesse carriage of the Israelites after their mightie deliuerance, had not been too liuely represented by the like in most reformed Churches. When that generationIudg. 2.10. Rom. 2.22, 23. was gathered to their fathers, would God another had not risen after them, which neither knew the Lord nor the workes which he had done for Israel: A generation as much addicted vnto sacrilege, as abhorring Idoles: dishonouring GOD by polluting that law of Libertie, wherein they gloried.

div.head: Lib. 1. SECT. 4. Pars. 2.
Of experiments in our selues, and the right framing of beleefe, as well vnto the seuerall parts as vnto the whole Canon of Scriptures.
div.p: THough these we now treat of be the surest pledges of diuine truths, without which all obseruations of former experiments, are but like assurances well drawne, but neuer sealed: yet are they least of all communicable vnto others. Hee that hath tried them may reioyce in them, as of that good treasure hid in the field, which he that hath found, can be content to sell all that hee hath, and buy the field wherein it is: that is, (to moralize that parable for good Students vse) he can be content to addict himselfe wholly or principally vnto this studie, suffering others to discourse of such matters as they most delight and glorie in, sealing his owne mouth with that Hebrew prouerbe, secretum meum mihi. It shall suffice then, to set downe some generall admonitions, for the finding of this hidden Mannah: albeit thus much can not bee so well performed in this place, seeing the search hereof is not so easie or certaine without the doctrine of Gods prouidence; and the matter or subiect of the most or best experiments in this kinde, belong vnto particular articles of this Creede, to bee prosecuted in their proper place, according to the methode vsed in these generall introductions, by comparing diuine Oracles with the experiments answerable vnto them.

div.head: CHAP. I.
Shewing the facilitie and vse of the proposed methode by instance in some, whose beleefe vnto diuine Oracles hath beene confirmed by experiments answerable vnto them.
div.p:
1 THe methode is such as the simplest Christian may easily learne, S. Peters beleef of knowne Oracles confirmed by experiment. and the greatest professors need not to contemne. For St. Peter himselfe, that great Doctor of the circumcision, did profit much by this practize. He had often heard, that God was
no accepter of persons. This truth was acknowledged by Elihu, who had neuer heard, Iob. 34. vers. 19. nor read the written law of God: He accepteth not the person of Princes, and regardeth not the rich more than the poore: for they bee all the worke of his handes. The like hath the Wise man from the same reason: Wisd. 6. vers. 7. He that is Lord ouer all, will spare no person, neither shall he feare any greatnesse: for he hath made the small and great, and careth for all a-like. The same in substance is often repeated in the booke of life: and no man could denie it, that had heard it but once proposed, if hee did acknowledge God for the Creatour of all. Notwithstanding, the fresh experiment of Gods calling Cornelius to Christian faith, confirmed St. Peter in the right beleefe of diuine oracles to this effect: and as it seemes, taught him the true meaning of that place, Deut. 10. vers. 16. Circumcise therefore the fore-skin of your heart (as if he had said, Glorie not in the circumcision of the flesh) and harden your necks no more: for the Lord your God is God of Gods, and Lord of Lords, a great God, mightie, and terrible, which accepteth no persons. From this place alone, the proude Iewes might haue learned, that the Lord was God of the Gentiles as well as of them: and, from the abundance of his inward faith, enlarged by the forementioned experiment, St. Peter burst out into these speeches: Act. 10. v. 34.35 Of a truth, I perceiue that God is no accepter of persons: but in euery Nation, he that feareth him, is accepted with him.

2 The same methode the Lord himselfe hath commended vnto vs in many places of Scripture, wondering oft times at the dulnesse of his peoples hearts, that could not from the experiments of his power, might, and maiestie, shewed in them, or for them, acknowledge those principles of faith which Moses commended vnto them in writing: O (saith he) that they were wise, then would they vnderstand this; they would consider their later end: how should one chase a thousand, and two put ten thousand to flight; except their strong God had sold them, and the Lord had shut them vp. And againe, Deut 32. v. 39. Behold now, for I am he, and there is no Gods with mee. Why should they beleeue this? They were to take none for gods, but such as could doe the works of God. What were these? Such as God auoucheth of himselfe in the next wordes: I kill, and I giue life; I wound, and I make whole; neither is there any that can deliuer out of my hand. These, and like effects, specified in the former
place, often manifested amongst this people, might haue taught them the truth of the former Oracle, albeit Moses had beene silent. For so the finger of God, Naaman without the written word by experiment confirmed in the truth of what was written in the word. 2. Kings 5.14.15 manifested in Naamans the Syrian Generalls cure (which was but one part of the former effects appropriated vnto God,) did write this diuine Oracle as distinctly in his heart, as Moses had done it in the booke of the Law. For after he was cleansed (from his leprosie,) hee turned againe to the man of God, hee and all his companie, and came and stood before him, and said; Behold, now I know there is no God in all the world, but in Israel: And againe, thy seruant will henceforth offer neither burnt sacrifice, nor offering, vnto any other God, saue vnto the Lord. This was as much, as if hee had said: Behold now, for the Lord is hee,
Vers. 17. and there is no other Gods with him: hee woundeth, and hee maketh whole.

3 If the cure of leprosie, contrarie to humane expectation, could so distinctly write this diuine Oracle in an vncircumcised Aramites heart, without any patterne or written copie, whence to take it out: how much more may the Lord expect, that the like experiments in our selues should imprint his Oracles alreadie written, by Moses and other his seruants of old, in our hearts and consciences, that haue these patternes of Naaman and others registred to our handes, admonishing vs to bee obseruant in this kinde? But alas, wee are all by nature sicke of a more dangerous leprosie, than Naaman knew: and yet the most of vs farre sicker of Naamans pride, than of his leprosie. If Gods Ministers shall admonish the curious Artists, or Athenian wits of our times, as Elishah his Prophet did Naaman: they reply with Naaman in their hearts: Wee looked they should haue called vpon the name of the Lord, their God, and made vs new men in an instant: and now they bidde vs wash our selues againe and againe in the water of life, and be cleane. Are not the ancient Fountaines of Greece (that nurse of Arts, and Mother of eloquence) and the pleasant Riuers of Italie (the Schoole of delicate moderne witts) better than all the waters of Israel? Are not Tullie and Aristotle as learned as Moses, and the Prophets? Thus they depart from vs in displeasure.

4 But if the Lord should command vs greater thinges for
our temporall preferment, or for the auoidance of corporall death or torture: would wee not doe them?
