How much rather then, when he saith vnto vs, Wash your selues often in the holy fountaine, the Well of life, and yee shall bee cleane, euen from those sores, which otherwise will torment both body and soule eternally? Yea, but many reade the Scriptures againe and againe, and daily heare the word Preached publikely, and yet proue no purer in life and action than their Neighbours. The reason is, because they heare or reade them negligently; not comparing their rules with experiments daily incident to their course of life: their preparation and resolution are not proportionable to the waight and consequence of this sacred businesse; their industrie and alacritie in obseruing and practizing the prescripts commended to their Meditations by their Pastors, doe in no wise so farre exceede their care and diligence in worldly matters, as the dignitie of these heauenly mysteries surpasseth the pleasures or commodities of this brittle earthly life: and not thus prepared to heare, or reade the Scriptures, to heare is to contemne, to reade is to prophane them: euen the often repetition of the wordes of life, without due reuerence and attention, breedes an insensibilitie or deadnesse in mens soules. Yet should not such mens want of sense breede infidelitie in others: rather this experience of so much hearing, and little doing Gods will, may confirme the truth of his word, concerning such Teachers and Hearers. Many in our times, not Monkes and Friars only, but of their sterne opposites,2. Tim. 3. v. 5.6.7 not a Iew, Hauing a shew of godlinesse, but denying the power thereof, crept into houses, and lead captiue simple Women, laden with sinnes, and leade with diuers lusts, euer hearing, and neuer able to come to the knowledge of the truth. And as the Philosopher said of his morall Auditors indocilitie, that it skilled not whether hee were yong or of youthfull affections: so is it not the difference of sexe but resolution, that makes a good Scholler or non proficient in the Schoole of our Sauiour IESVS CHRIST. Many men haue weake and womanish, and many women, manly, and heroick resolutions, towards God and godlinesse.Better effects of experiments lesse wonderfull in Anna.

5. The infirmitie which vexed the religious Hanna, was not so
grieuous as that of Naamans: she was, in our corrupt language, as many honest women at this day are, by nature barren; or, if wee would speake as the Prophet did in the right language of Canaan, the Lord had made her barren: wearie shee was of her owne; and, according to the ordinarie course of nature, shee saw no hope of being the author of life to others. Yet in this her distresse shee prayed vnto the Lord her God, and he graunted her desire. From this experiment of Gods power, though not altogether so remarkable in ordinarie estimation as Naamans cure, she fully conceiues not onely the truth of the former Oracle, acknowledged by Naaman (but more emphatically expressed by her,1. Sam. 2. v. 2. There is none holy as the Lord; yea, there is none besides thee, and there is no God like our God;) nor that other attribute of wounding, or making whole (so liuely vttered, vers. 6. The Lord killeth, and maketh aliue; bringeth downe to the graue, and rayseth vp:) but Gods Word, planted in her heart by her fresh experience, growes vp like a graine of Mustard-seede, and brauncheth it selfe into a faithfull acknowledgement of most of his attributes: The Lord is a God of knowledge, and by him enterprises are established; the bow and the mightie men are broken, and the weake haue girded themselues with strength: they that were full, are hired forth for bread, and the hungrie are no more hired, so that the barren hath borne seuen, and shee that hath borne many children, is feeble: the Lord maketh poore, and maketh rich; bringeth low, and exalteth: he raiseth vp the poore out of the dust, and lifteth vp the beggar from the dunghill, to set them among Princes, and to make them inherite the seat of glorie: for the pillars of the earth are the Lords, and he hath set the world vpon them; he will keepe the feet of his Saints, and the wicked shall keepe silence in darknesse; for in his owne might shall no man be strong. Nor doth it containe it selfe within the bounds of ordinarie beleefe, but workes in her heart like new wine, filling it not onely with Songs of joy and triumph ouer her enuious enemies, Mine heart reioyceth in the Lord, my mouth is enlarged ouer my enemies, because I reioyce in thy saluation; De Prophetiâ Hannae vide Augustinum, lib. 17. de Ciu. Dei, c. 4. Vers. 10. but also with the diuine spirit of * Prophecie: The Lords aduersaries shall be destroyed, and out of Heauen shall he thunder vpon them; the Lord shall iudge the ends of the world, and shall giue power vnto his King, and exalt the horne of his annointed.

Different operations of like experiments in diuerse parties, with their causes.6 The like docilitie was in the blessed Virgine, of whom perhaps Annah was the type: both of them verified that saying, Verbum sapienti sat est, One experiment taught them more than fiue hundred would doe most of vs: The reason was, because their hearts were so much better prepared. For, as heat in some bodies, by reason of the indisposition of the matter, causeth heat and nothing else; in some scarce that; in others brings forth life, and fashioneth all the organes and instruments thereof: so experiments of Gods power, in some mens hearts, breedes onely a persuasion of his might or operation in that particular, as in those foolish2. King. 20. vers. 23. Aramites, who, vanquished in battell by the Israelites whom he fauoured, question whether he were a God, aswell of the valleyes as of the mountaines; in others, the same or lesse apprehension of his power or presence, begetteth life, and fashioneth this image in their hearts, which thence will shew it selfe vnto others in such ample and entire confession of his attributes, as Hannah and the blessed Virgine vttered. Some againe are so ill disposed and indocile, that the whole Morall Law of God might sooner be engrauen in hardest Marble or Flint, than any one precept imprinted in their hearts by such wonderfull documents of his power, as would teach the godly in an instant both the Law and Prophets. Imagine some men in our dayes had beene cured by like meanes of such a maladie as Naaman was; or some woman blessed from aboue with fruit of their wombes, after so long sterilitie, as Hannah endured. Who could expect, that one of tenne in eyther sex should returne to giue like thankes to God in the presence of his Priests or Prophets? Were Elishah now liuing, he must be warie to worke his cure by his bare word (and so perhaps he should be censured for a Sorcerer) in any case, hee might not vse the waters of Iordan, or other like second causes: otherwise curious wits would finde out some hidden or secret vertue caused in them (at least for the time being) by some vnusuall, but benigne aspect of some Planet or Constellation, in whose right they should be entitled either full owners, or coparteners of that glorie, which Naaman ascribed wholly vnto God. And poore H • nnah, in this politique age, should not be so much praysed for her deuotion or good skill in diuine Poesie, as pitied for a good honest well-meaning sillie soule, that did attribute more to
God than was his due, vpon ignorance of alterations wrought in her bodie by naturall causes. For it is not the custome of our Times to marke so much the ordering or disposition, as the particular or present operation of such Agents. If any thing fall out amisse, wee bid a plague vpon ill fortune, or curse mischance: if ought aright, wee applaud our owne or others wits that haue beene employed in the businesse, or perhaps thanke God for fashion sake, that we had good lucke. He is to vs, in our good successe, as a friend that liues farre off; who, wee presume, wisheth well to such projects as he knowes in generall we are about, being vnacquainted with the particular meanes that must effect them, or no principall Agent in their contriuance. Hence doe not I maruell (though many doe) if such men in our times as reape the fruits of the fields which God hath blest, in greatest abundance, make no conscience of returning the tenth part to him that gaue the whole; when as not one of a thousand, eyther in heart or deede, or out of any distinct or cleare apprehension of his power or efficacie, or true resolution of all effects into the first fountaine whence they flow, doth attribute so much as the tenth, nay as the hundreth part to Gods doing in any euent, wherein the industrie of man or operation of second causes are apparant. We speake like Christians of matters past, recorded in Scripture; but in our discourses of moderne affaires, our Paganismes and more than Heathenish Solaecismes bewray the infidelitie of our thoughts and resolutions. And albeit wee all disclaime Manes heresie, that held one Creator of the matter, and another of more pure and better substances; yet are we infected, for the most part, with a spice of his madnesse, in making materiall Agents the authors of some effects; and the diuine power, of others. Nor can I herein excuse the Schoole-diuines themselues, auncient or moderne, domestique or foraine; the best of them (in my judgement) either greatly erred in assigning the subordination of second causes to the first; or else are much defectiue, in deriuing their actions or operations immediatly from him, who is the first and last in euerie action that is not euill, the onely cause of all good vnto men: as shall appeare (God willing) in the Article of his prouidence, and some other Treatises pertinent vnto it, wherein I shall, by his assistance, make good these two assertions: The
one, that moderne euents, and dispositions of present times, are as apt to confirme mens faith now liuing, as the miracles of former would be, were they now in vse, or as they were to instruct that age wherein they were wrought; the second, that the infidelitie of such in this age, as are strongly persuaded they loue Christ with their heart, and yet giue no more than most men doe vnto his fathers prouidence, may be greater than theirs that neuer heard of either, or equall vnto the Iewes that did persecute him.

Generall directions for the right taking of experiments in our selues.7. Vntill the Article of the diuine Prouidence, and that other of the Godhead be vnfolded, these generall directions for experiments in this kinde must suffice. First, that euerie man diligently obserue his course of life, and suruey the circumstances praecedent or consequent to euerie action of greater importance that hee vndertakes, or euents of moment that befall him. Secondly, that he search whether the whole frame or composition of occurrents be not such, as cannot be attributed to any naturall, but vnto some secret and inuisible cause; or whether some cause or occasions praecedent be not such, as the Scripture hath alreadie allotted the like euents vnto. Would men apply their mindes vnto this studie, experience would teach them (what from enumeration of particulars may be prooued by discourse) That there is no estate on earth, nor businesse in Christendome this day on foot, but haue a ruled case in Scripture for their issue and successe. Nor is there anie praescript of our Sauiours, his Euangelists, or Apostles, but his people might haue a Probatum of it, eyther in themselues or others; so they would referre themselues wholly into his hands, and relye as fully vpon his praescripts, as becomes such distressed Patients vpon so admirable a Physitian.

The causes why so many in our dayes haue little or no experience of the truth of diuine Oracles8. But manie who like well of Christ for their Physitian, loath his medicines for the Ministers his Apothecaries sake, and say of vs as Nathaniel said of him; Can there any good thing come from these sillie Galilaens? They will not with Nathaniel come neere and see, but keepe aloofe. And what maruell, if spirituall diseases abound, where there bee spirituall medicines plentie, when the flocke, be they neuer so soule-sicke, come onely in such sort to their Pastours, as if a sicke man should goe to a Physicke
Lecture for the recouerie of his health, where the Professour, it may be, reades learnedly of the nature of Consumptions, when the Patient is desperately sicke of a Pleurisie; or discourses accurately of the Plethaera or Athleticall constitution, when his Auditor (poore soule) languisheth of an Atrophie? Most are ashamed to consult vs (as good patients in bodily maladies alwayes doe their Physitians) in any particulars, concerning the nature of their peculiar griefes: so as we can apply no medicine to any but what may as well be fit euery disease. Whereas, were we throughly acquainted with their seuerall maladies, or the dispositions of their mindes, the praescript might be such, or so applyed, as euerie man might thinke the medicine had beene made of purpose for his soule; and, finding his secret thought with the originall causes of his maladie discouered, the Crisis truely prognosticated, hee could not but acknowledge, that hee who gaue this praescript, and taught this art, did search the verie secrets of mens hearts and reines, and knew the inward temper of his soule better than Hippocrates or Galene did the constitution of mens bodies. Finally, would men learne to be true patients, that is, would they take vp Christs yoake, and become humble and meeke, and obserue but for a while such a gentle and moderate diet, as from our Sauiours practise and doctrine might be praescribed by their spirituall Physitions vpon better notice of their seuerall dispositions, they would in short time, out of their inward experience of that vncouth rest and ease, which by thus doing their soules should finde, beleeue with their hearts, and with their mouthes confesse, that these were rules of life, which could not possibly haue come from any other, but from that Diuine Aesculapius himselfe, the onely Sonne, yea the wisedome of the onely wise, inuisible, and immortall God. The more vnlikely the meanes of recouering spirituall health may seeme to naturall reason, before men trie them, the more forcible would their good successe and issue be, for establishing true and liuely faith. But such as can, from these or like experiments, subscribe vnto maine particular truthes contained in Scripture, and acknowledge them as diuine, may be vncertaine of their number, or extent; doubt they may of the number of bookes wherein the like are to bee sought: and againe, in those bookes which are acknowledged to
containe many diuine Reuelations and Dictates of the holy Spirit, they may doubt whether many other praescripts, neyther of like vse, nor authoritie, haue not beene inserted by men.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Containing a briefe resolution of doubts concerning the extent of the generall Canon, or the number of it integrall parts.
div.p: 1 THe full resolution of the former doubt or rather controuersie, concerning the number of Canonicall bookes, exceedes the limits of this present Treatise, and depends as much as anie question this day controuersed, vpon the testimonies of Antiquitie. The order of Iesuits shalbe confounded, and Reynoldes raised to life againe, ere his learned Workes, lately come foorth vpon this Argument (albeit vnfinished to his minde, whilest hee was liuing) be confuted by the Romanists: Or, if any of the Iesuitish Societie, or that other late vpstart Congregation, will be so desperate as to aduenture their honour in Bellarmine, or other of their foyled Champions rescue, they shall be expected in the Lists before they be prepared to entertaine the Challenge, by one of that deceased Worthies Shield-bearers in his life time: whose judgement in all good learning I know for sound; his obseruation in this kind, choise; his industrie great; his resolution to encounter all Antagonists, such as will not relent. For satisfaction of the ordinarie Reader I briefely answere.

2. First, that this is no controuersie of Faith, nor need it to trouble anie Christian mans conscience, that we and the Papists differ about the authoritie of some bookes; it rather ought to confirme his faith, that men disagreeing so much in many opinions, so opposite in their affections, should so well agree about the number of no fewer than two and twentie Canonicall Bookes of the olde Testament. Had their authoritie onely beene humane, or left to the choice of men, whether they should be allowed or rejected, manie that now admit them, would re
• ect them, because opposite Religions did embrace them. That
all sorts of Protestants, Papists, andThe testimonies of the antient Israelites and moderne Iewes for the canon of the old Testament is most authentike. For euen those ancient Fathers which our aduersaries alleadge to acknowlege some more bookes for canonicall than our Church doth; did it only vpon this errour that they thought there had bin more in the canon of the Hebrews, vpon whose testimonies they relied; as will be made cleare against the Papists. Iewes do receiue them, is an infallible Argument, that hee who is Lord of all, did commend them to all. Nor doth our Church so disclaime all which the Romanes aboue these two and twenty admit, as if it were a point of faith to holde there were no more: it onely admits no more into the same rancke and order with the former, because wee haue no such warrant of faith, or sure experiments so to doe. Many of them discouer themselues to be apocryphall: and albeit some of them can very hardly, or not at all, be discerned for such by their stile, character, or dissonancie to Canonicall Scriptures; yet, that none of them indeede are, or can be admitted for Canonicall, without manifest tempting of God, is euident from what hath beene obserued before, concerning Gods vnspeakeable prouidence in making the blinded and perfidious Iewes, his sonnes, and our bitterest enemies, such trusty feoffees for making ouer the assurances of life vnto vs. For, seeing by them he commended vnto vs, onely so many Bookes of the Olde Testament, as our Church acknowledgeth: this is an infallible Argument, that his will was, wee should admit no more; Had any more beene written, before the reedifying of the Temple by Zerubbabel, no doubt the Iewes would haue admitted them into their canon. For all such as should be written after; the Prophet Malachie, who is the last of their Canon, had left this caueat in the last words of his prophecie for not admitting them; Remember the lawe of Moses my seruant, which I commaunded to him in Horeb, in all Israel, with the statutes and iudgements: as if hee had saide, You must content your selues with his writings, and such as you haue already, consonant to his; for any others of equall authoritie you may not expect, vntill the expectation of the Gentiles come. For no Prophet shall ariseVerse 5.6. Consonant hereto is that, Matth. 11.13. Lex est propheta ad Iohannem &c. That is, their writings were the compleate rule of faith and infallible meanes of saluation vntill Iohn. Yet can it not be proued that any booke held by our Church for Apocryphall is contained either vnder the law or prophets as the historicall bookes of the Hebrew canon are. Euident it is that the books of Judith and Machabees were writ since Malachies time: from whom till Iohn no Prophet was to be expected, but Moses law (illlustrated by euents recorded in histories and propheticall commentaries til Malachies time inclusiuè) was to be the immediate medium for discerning the great prophet, Vide libr. 2. sect. 2. cap. 6. num. 3. & 4. lib. 1. part. 2. sect. 2. cap. vlt. vntill that time, as he intimates in the last words, Behold, I will send you Eliah the Prophet, before the comming of the great and fearefull day of the Lord: and he shall turne the hearts of the fathers vnto the children, and the hearts of the children to their fathers,
lest I come & smite the earth with cursing. The ministery of others for conuerting soules, he supposed should be but ordinarie, by the exposition of the law & prophets: and the authority of such (writ they asmuch as they listed) could not be authentike or canonicall.

3 Some others againe of reformed churches in these our times, haue from the example of antiquity, doubted of the authority of some bookes in the new Testament: as ofThe diuine authoritie of some Books in the Testamēt, especially the Apocalypse, doubted of by the Ancient, brought to light in latet times, Iude, of Iames, the second of Peter, and some others. Which doubt is now diminished by their continuance in the sacred Canon so long time, without manifest documents of GODS prouidence in preseruing them, whose pleasure (it may seeme) was to haue these Bookes, of whom the Ancients most doubted, fenced & guarded on the one side, by Saint Pauls Epistles, and other canonicall Scriptures (neuer called in question by any, but absurd and foolish heretiques, whose humorous opinions herein died with themselues;) and on the other, by the booke of the Apocalypse: of whose authoritie though many of the Ancient for the time being, doubted; yet He that was before all times did fore-see, that it should in latter times manifest it selfe to be his worke, by euents answerable to the prophecies contained in it. And, albeit many Apocryphall bookes haue beene stamped with diuine titles, and obtruded vpon the Church as Canonicall, whilest shee was in her infancie, and the sacred Canon newly constitute: yet the diuine Spirite, by which it was written, hath wrought them out, as new wine doth such filth or grossenesse as mingle with it whilest the grapes are troden. S. Iohns adiuration in the conclusion of that booke hath not only terrified all for adding vnto, or diminishing it selfe: but hath beene as it were a Seale vnto the rest of this sacred volume of the new Testament, as Malachies prophecie was to the olde; the whole canon it selfe, consisting both of the old & new, continues still as the Arke of God, and all other counterfeits as Dagon.

4 Were not our Roman aduersaries doctrine concerning the general principles of faith, an inuention deuised of purpose by Sathan to obliterate all print or impression of Gods prouidence in gouerning his church, out of mens harts: how were it possible for any man endued with reason, to be so far ouer-growne with frensie, as not to conceiue their owne follie and madnes, in auouching we cannot know what books are canonicall, what not, but by the
infallible testimony of the present Romish Church. But of these impieties at large hereafter. I will now only inferre part of their conclusion, which they stil labor, but neuer shalbe able to proue, from premises which they neuer dreamt of.Wherein the testimony of the Romish Church in discerning some Canonicall bookes is most auaileable. For I professe among others, this is not the least reason I haue to hold the Apocalypse for canonical scripture, because the Romish church doth so esteem it. Nor could reformed churches belief of its authoritie be so strong, vnles that church had not denied, but openly acknowledged it for canonical scripture. As the same beams of the Sun reach frō heauen to earth, and from one end of the world to another; so do the same raies of Gods power extend themselues from generation to generation, alwaies alike conspicuous to such as are illuminate by his spirit: for who, thus illuminate, can acknowledge his prouidēce in making the Iews so careful to preserue the old testament; & not as clearly discerne the same in constraining the Romish church to giue her supposed infallible testimony of the Apocal. Doubtlesse, if that book had bin the work of man, it had bin more violently vsed by that church of late, than euer the new testament hath bin by the Iewish synagogue, or any heretike by the Romanists, seeing it hath said far more against them, than any whom they account for such, euer did. But God, who made Pharaohs daughter a secōd mother vnto Moses, whom he had appointed to bring destruction afterwards vpon her fathers house & kingdome, hath made the Romish church of old, a dry nurse to preserue this book (whose meaning she knew not) that it might bring desolation vpon her selfe and her children, in time to come. For by the breath of the Lord shal she be destroied; her doom is already read by S. Iohn; and the Lord of late hath intangled her in her owne snare, whilest she was drawing it to catch others. Her childrens brags of their mothers infallibilitie, wherewith they hale most seely soules to them, were too far spread before the Trent councel, too cōmodious to be called in on a sodaine. Had they then begun to deny the authority of this book (thogh thē pronoūcing their mothers wo more openly than any prophecies of olde had done the ensuing desolations of the Iewes) euery child could haue caught hold on this string, that this Church (as they suppose) alwayes the same, neuer obnoxious to any errour, had in former time acknowledged it for authentike & diuine: albeit (no question,) but many of them since haue wish'd
from their hearts that their forefathers had vsed the same, as Sheraiah did Ieremiahs bookes which he wrote against Babylon, that both it, and all memorie of it, had bin drowned in the bottome of the deepest sea, and a milstone throwne vpon it by Gods Angel, that it neuer might rise vp again to interrupt their whorish mothers beastly pleasures, by discouering her filthy nakednesse daily more and more. For conclusion of this point for this present. That this and other canonicall books had bin long preserued, or rather imprisoned by the Romish church in darkenes and ignorance, vntill the Almightie gaue his voyce, and caused them to speake in euery tongue, throughout these parts of the world; doth no more argue her to haue bin the true & Catholike church, than Moses educatiō in Pharaohs Court, during the time of his infancie or nonage, doth argue the Aegyptian Courtiers to haue bin Gods chosen people.

div.head: CHAP. III.
A briefe direction for preuenting scruples and resoluing doubts, concerning particular sentences or passages in the Canon of Scripture.
div.p:
1 VNto the second demand, [How we know this or that sentence in any booke of Canonicall Scripture, to haue beene from God, not inserted by man,] some perhaps would say this must bee knowne by the spirit. Which indeede is the briefest answere that can be giuen: but such as would require a long Apologie for its truth, or at least a large explication in what sense it were true, if any man durst be so bold as to reply vpon it.How our firme assent to some principal matters reuealed in Scriptures, tieth our faith vnto their whole Canon. Consequently, to our former principles, we may answere, that our full and vndoubted assent vnto some principall parts, doth binde vs vnto the whole frame of Scriptures. But you will say, wee beleeue such speciall parts, from vndoubted experience of their truth in our hearts, and without these our beleefe of them could not bee so stedfast: how then shall we stedfastly beleeue those parts, of whose diuine truth we haue no such experiments; for of euery sentence in Scripture, we suppose few or none can haue any? yet euen vnto those parts whereof we haue no experiments in particular, we doe adhere by our former faith, because our soules and consciences are as it were
tied and fastned vnto other parts wherewith they are conioyned, as the pinning and nailing of two plaine bodies in some few parts, doth make them stick close together in all, so as the one can not be pulled from the other in any part, whilest their fastning holds. It will bee replied, that this similitude would hold together, if one part of Canonicall Scripture were so firmly or naturally vnited to another, as the diuers portions of one and the same continuate or solid body are: but seeing it is euident that so they are not, who can warrant the contrarie, but that a sentence or period, perhaps a whole page, might haue beene foisted into the Canon by some Scribe or other? Here we must retire vnto our first hold or principles of faith. For if we stedfastly beleeue from experiments or otherwise, that some principall parts of Scripture haue come from God, and that the same are sure pledges for mans good, the only meanes of his saluation: this doctrine or experience of Gods prouidence once fully established, will establish our faith and assent vnto other parts of his word, whereof (should we take them alone) we could haue no such experiments. For he that knoweth God, or his prouidence a-right; knowes this withall, that hee will not suffer vs to be tempted aboue our strength. And once hauing had experience of his mercies past, we can not, without iniurie to his diuine Maiestie, but in confidence of it, beleeue and hope, that his all-seeing wisdome & almightie power will still (maugre the spite of Death, Hell, and Sathan, and their Agents) preserue his sacred word sincere without admixture of any prophane, false, or humane inuentions that might ouerthrow, or peruert our faith begun. Hereto we may referre all former documents of his care and prouidence in preseruing the Canon of our faith from the tyrannie of such, as sought vtterly to deface it; and the treacherie of others, who sought to corrupt it. And it ought to be no little motiue vnto vs, thus to thinke: when we see Austine, Gregorie, and other of the ancient writers, either maimed, or mangled, or purged of their best bloud, where they make against the Romish Church; or else her vntruths fathered vpon them, by her shamelesse sonnes, in places where they are silent for her: & yet this sacred volume vntouched and vncorrupt, by any violence offered to it by that Church; only it hath lost it naturall beautie and complexion, by long durance in that homely and vulgar prison, wherunto they haue confined it.

2 But as from these and like documents of Gods care and prouidence in preseruing it, and of his loue and fauour towards vs, we conceiue faith and sure hope, that he will not suffer vs to bee tempted with doubts of this nature, aboue our strength: so must we be as farre from tempting him, by these or like vnnecessarie, vnseasonable curious demands. How should we know this or that clause or sentence (if we should find them alone) to be Gods word? Why might not an Heretike of malice haue forged, or a Scribe through negligence altered them? It should suffice that they haue beene commended to vs not alone, but accompanied with such Oracles as we haue already entertained for diuine. And if any doubt shall happen to arise, we must relie vpon that Oracle, of whose truth euery true Christian hath, and all that would be such, may haue sure triall. Deus cum tentatione simul vires dabit: God with the temptation will giue issue; yea ioyfull issue to such temptations as he suffers to be suggested by others, not vnto such as we thrust our selues into by our needlesse curiositie. When we are called vnto the search of truth by Sathan or his instruments obiections against it, the Lord will giue vs better reasons for our owne or others satisfactions, than yet we know of, or should be able to find: but by the conduct of his vntempted prouidence.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
Concluding the first booke with some briefe admonition to the Reader.
div.p:
1 TO conclude this Treatise, as it was begun. The greater the reward proposed to the faithfull practise, or the punishmēt threatned to the neglect of these diuine Oracles: the greater is the madnesse of many men in our time, who in contēplatiue studies whose principall end is delight, can vndergo long toyle, and great paines, neuer attaining to exact knowledge, but by beleeuing their instructors and taking many theoremes and conclusions vpon trust, before they can make infallible triall of their truth: and yet in matters of their saluation, which cannot be exactly knowne, but onely beleeued in this life, and whose beliefe must be got by
practise, not by discourse, demand euidence of truth, and infallible demonstration, before they will vouchsafe to beleeue or aduenture their paines on their practise, and finally, so demeane themselues in speech and resolution, as if God Almightie should thinke himselfe highly graced, and our Sauiour, his sonne, much beholden to them, that they would deigne to be his schollers, sooner than Mahomets, or Machiauels. But we that are his messengers must not debase his word, nor disparage our calling by wooing them vpon such termes, or professing to shew thē the truth before they be willing to learne it: One first principle whereof is this, That such as will seeke, may finde starting holes enough to runne out of Christs fold, and escape his mercies profered in his Church. And as many reasons are daily brought, sufficient to perswade a right disposed vnderstanding of the truth of Scriptures: so no argument can be found of force enough to conuince a froward will, or perswade peruerse affection. These are they which make a many altogether vncapable of any moral, most of all of any diuine truth, and must be laid aside at the first entrance into the schole of Christ, and continually kept vnder by the rod of his iudgements and terrours of that dreadfull day. Vnto such as account these consequents lesse dreadfull or their dread lesse probable, than that they should (for a time at least) lay aside all peruersitie of will, or humour of contradiction, to make sure triall of those diuine Oracles for their good; we can apply no other medicine, but that of Saint Iohn: He that is filthie, let him be filthie still.

2 Thus much of generall inducements to beliefe. In the obseruation and vse of all these and others of what kinde soeuer, we must implore the assistance of Gods Spirit, who onely worketh true and liuely faith, but (ordinarily) by these or like meanes. These Scriptures are as the rule or methode prescribing vs our diet and order of life: these experiments ioyned with it are as nutriment: and the Spirit of God digesteth all to our health and strength. Without it all other means or matters, of best obseruation, are but as good meate to weake or corrupt stomacks: With it, euery experiment of our owne or others estate, taken according to the rules of Scriptures, doth nourish and strengthen faith, and preserue our spirituall health. Many in our daies vncessantly blame their brethrens backwardnesse to entertaine the spirit, or relie vpon it only, more blame-worthie themselues for being too forward in beleeuing
euery spirit, and seeking toThis is that circle which the Aduersarie opposeth as a countermine to vs whilest we seeke to ouerthrow their circular beliefe. The obiection may iustly be retorted vpon the En • husiast, but not on our Church as shal appeare in the second Section of the fourth booke. discerne Canonicall from Apocryphall Scriptures by the spirit, and againe to trie true from false spirits by the Scriptures, without serious obseruation & setled examination of experimēts answerable vnto sacred rules. Such mens feruent zeale vnto the letter of the Gospel is like an hot stomach accustomed to sleight meats, which increase appetite more than strength, & fil the body rather with bad humors than good bloud.

3 The spirit no doubt speaks often vnto vs when we attend not, but we must not presume to vnderstand his suggestions by his immediat voice or presence; only by his fruits, & the inward testimony of an appeased conscience (which he alone can work) must we know him. He that seeks (asProsicientibus (vt admonet P. noster Ignat. in L. exercit. de dignos. spir.) Spiritus malus se dure, implacide & violenter, quasi cum srepitu quodam, vt imber in saxa decidens, in fundit, bonus vero ijsdem leniter, pl • cide & suau tor, sicut a qua irrorat spongiam. Ill • s vero qui • n deterius proficiunt, exper entia docet, contrarium euenire. Delrius disqu • si. Magic. lib. 4. cap. 1. q. 3. sect. 6.
Ignatius Loyola taught his sons) to discerne him without more ado by his manner of breathing, may in steed of him be troubled with an vnwelcome guest alwaies readie to inuite himself where he sees preparation made for his better, & one (I am persuaded) that hath learned more kindes of salutations than Loyola knew of, able to fil empty breasts or shallow heads vnsetled in truth, with such pleasant, mild and gentle blasts, as are apt to breed strong perswasions of more than Angelical inspirations.

4 God grant the carriage of ensuing times may argue these admonitiōs needlesse which further to prosecure, in respect of times late past & now present, could not be vnseasonable; but thus much by the way must now suffice me, purposed hereafter (if god permit) to intreat of the triall of spirits, & certain apprehension of inherent faith: about the generall means of whose production, & establishment, the question, most controuersed in these daies, is; Whether beside the testification of Gods spirit, which (as all agree) must (by these late mentioned or other means) work faith in our harts: the testimonie or authority of others besides our selues be necessarie, either for ascertaining our apprehensiō of the spirit thus working, or for assuring the truth of experimēts wrought by it in our souls? or if no other besides the testimony of Gods spirit and our owne conscience be necessary, either after their sentence giuen, or whilst they giue it? How farre the authority or ministerie of men are necessarie or behoueful, eyther for bringing vs acquainted with the spirit of God, or for the assistance & direction of our conscience in giving right sentence of the truth or true meaning of Gods word? Of these questions and others subordinate to them, we are to dispute at large in the bookes following.

div.head: HOW FARRE THE MINISTERIE OF MEN IS NECESSARIE FOR PLANTING TRVE CHRISTIAN faith, and retaining the Vnitie of it PLANTED. THE SECOND BOOKE.
div.p: AS in the first intention, so after some prosecution of this long worke, my purpose was to referre the full examination of the Romish Churches pretended authoritie in matters spirituall, vnto the Article of the Catholicke Church: Which (with those three others of the Holy Ghost, Communion of Saints, and forgiuenesse of Sinnes,) for more exact methodes sake, and continuation of matters, in nature and sacred writ, most vnited, I haue reserued for the last place in this frame of Christian beliefe: annexing the Articles of the bodies resurrection, and euerlasting life, vnto that of finall iudgement, whereon these two haue most immediate, most direct dependance.

2 But after the platforme was cast, and matter for structure prepared: vpon euident discouerie of the Iesuites treacherie, in setting vp the Pope as a secret competitour with the blessed Trinitie,
for absolute soueraigntie ouer mens soules; (and for this purpose continually plotting, to haue the doctrine of their Churches infallibilitie planted as low and deepe as the verie first and fundamentall principles of beliefe:) albeit in laying the former foundations, I had come to ground firme enough (if free from vndermining) to beare all I meant to build vpon it: I was, notwithstanding, in this place constrained to bare the whole foundation, and all about it, vnto the verie rocke, on whose strength it stands; least this late dismall inuention (concerning the Popes infallibilitie) might proue as a powder-plot to blow vp the whole edifice of Christian faith; as it certainly will, if men suffer it to be once planted in their hearts and consciences. The Iesuites speculatiue positions of their Churches transcendent authoritie, are as the traine, the Popes Thunderbolts as the match, to set the whole world on combustion, vnlesse his Lordly designes, (though in matters of faith, and greatest moment) be put in execution, without question or demurre: as shal (God prospering these proceedings) most clearely appeare in the sequele of this discourse: Wherein are to be discussed
1 Their obiections against vs; the points of difference betwixt vs; with the positiue grounds of truth maintained by vs.
2 The inconueniences of their positions: Erection of triple blasphemie by the ouerthrow of Christianitie.
3 The original causes of their error in this; and such erroneous perswasions, as held by them in other points, not descried by vs, proue secret temptations for others to follow them, or serue as praeu • all dispositions, for their Agents to work vpon.
4 The possible meanes and particular manner, how Orthodoxall may be distinguished from hereticall doctrine, or the life-working sense of Scriptures from artificiall glosses.

These points discussed, and the positiue grounds of Christian faith cleared, as wel against the open assaults of professed Atheists, as the secret attempts of vndermining Papists: wee may with better securitie proceed to raise the foundation, laid in the first generall part of the first booke, to the height intended.

div.head: SECT. I.
What obedience is due to Gods word, what to his Messengers.
div.p: THE whole Scripture (saith the Apostle) is giuen by inspiration of God, and is profitable to teach, 2. Tim. 3.16.17 to improue to correct, and to instruct in righteousnes, that the man of God may be absolute, being made perfect vnto al good works. What, or whom, he meanes by the Man of God, is not agreed vpon by all that acknowledge his words in the sense he meant them, most infallible and authenticke. Some hereby vnderstand onely such men as Timothie was, Ministers of Gods word, or Prophets of the new Testament; and so briefly elude all arguments hence drawne to proue the sufficiency of Scriptures, for being the absolute rule of faith, at least to all, as well vnlearned as learned. Yet should they in all reason (might Gods word rule their reason) grant them to be such, vnto all such as Timothie was, publike teachers, men conuersant in, or consecrated vnto, sacred studies; but euen this they denie as well as the former, though the former in their opinion be more absurd for vs to affirme, especially holding the Hebrew text onely authenticke. Briefly, they charge vs with debasing Peter for aduancing Paul, or rather for colouring or adorning our pretended sense of Paules words, that is, for giuing too little to Peters successors, or the Church: too much to Scriptures: too little to spirituall, too much to lay-men.

2 These are plausible pretences, and sweet baites to stop the mouths, & muffle the pens of Clergy-men in reformed Churches, vnto most of whom, (as they obiect) besides the spirituall sword, litle or nothing is left for their iust defence against the insolēcies of rude, illiterate, prophane Laicks. And yet, who more earnest than they in this cause, against the Church, against themselues? yet certaine it is, that no man can be truly for himselfe, vnlesse he be first of all for truth it selfe, of which he that gaines the greatest share, (what other detriment or disparagement soeuer in the meane time he sustain) in the end speeds alwaies best And seeing to lie or teach amisse, is a matter altogether impossible to omnipotēcy it selfe: to
be able and willing withal to defend a falshood, or set faire colours on foule causes, is rather impotencie then abilitie: Hence was that quicquid possumus pro veritate possumus. Seeing by truth we liue our spirituall life: to weaken it for strengthening our temporall hopes, can neuer rightly bee accounted any true effect of power, but an infallible argument of great and desperate imbecillitie.

3 For these reasons; since I consecrate my labours to the search of diuine truth, my minde hath beene most set to finde it out in this present controuersie: whereon most others of moment chiefly depend. And, as vnto the Romanist it is (though falsely) termed the Catholicke, so should it be vnto vs, to all that loue the name of Christ, the very Christian cause: a cause, with which the aduersaries fortunes, our faith: their temporall, our spirituall estate and hopes must stand or fall: a cause whose truth and strength on our part, will euidently appeare. We first examine what the Antichristian aduersarie can oppose against it.

div.head: CHAP. I.
The summe of the Romanists exceptions against the Scriptures.
div.p: 1 THeir obiections against Scriptures spring from this double roote: The one, that they are no sufficient rule of faith, but many things are to be beleeued which are not taught in them. The second, that albeit they were the compleat rule of faith; yet could they not be knowne of vs, but by the authoritie of the Church, so that all the former directions for establishing our assent vnto the Scriptures, as vnto the words of God himselfe, were vaine, seeing this cannot be attained vnto but by relying vpon Christs visible Church.

The former of these two fountaines, or roots of errour, I am not here to meddle with: elsewhere we shal. That the Scriptures teach all points of faith set downe in this Creede, they cannot denie, or if they would it shall appeare in their seuerall explications: so that the Scripture, rightly vnderstood, is a competent rule for the Articles heerein contained. Let vs then see whether the sense or meaning
of these Scriptures, which both they and we hold for Canonicall, may not be knowne, vnderstood, and fully assented vnto, immediately, and in themselues, without relying vpon any visible Church or Congregation of men, from whose doctrine we must frame our beliefe without distrust of errour, or examination of their decrees, with any intention to reforme them, or swarue from them.

2 That the Scripture is not the rule whereon priuate men, especially vnlearned, ought to relie in matters of faith; from these generall reasons, or Topicks, they seeke to perswade vs. First, admitting the Scriptures to be infallible in themselues, and so consequently to all such as can pe • fectly vnderstand them in the language wherein they were written: yet to such as vnderstand not that language, they can be no infallible rule, because they are to them a rule onely as they are translated: but no vnlearned man can be sure that they are translated aright, according to the true intent and meaning of the holy Ghost for if any man do infallibly beleeue this, & build his faith hereupon, then is his faith grounded vpon the infallibility of this or that mans skil in translating, wherof he that is vnlearned can haue no sufficient argument, neither out of Scripture, nor from reason. Nay reason teacheth vs that in matters of ordinarie capacitie most men are obnoxious to errour: and the most skilfull may haue his escapes in a long worke, for, In opere longo fas est obrepere somnum, Aliquando bonus dormitat Homerus: A man may sometimes take Homer napping euen in that Art whereof he was Master and Prince: much more may the greatest Linguist liuing in a worke of so great difficultie as the translation of the Bible, not another mans (though that more easie to erre in than a mans owne) but the worke or dictates of the holy Ghost, proue an Homers, but a blinde guide vnto the blind: many things he cannot see, and many things he may ouersee. And how then can any man assure himselfe, that in those places whereon wee should build our faith, he hath not gone besides the line: vnlesse we will admit an infallible authoritie in the Church, to assure vs that such a translation doth not erre.

3 Againe, in those very translations wherein they agree; Luther gathers one sense, Caluin another;Answ. sect. 3. euerie heretique may pretend a secret meaning of his priuate spirit. Who shall either secure
the people distracted by dissensions amongst the learned, or the learned thus dissenting, vnlesse the infallible authoritie of the Church.Retorted and answ. sect. 4. Finally, without such an infallible authoritie, controuersies will daily grow: and vnlesse it be established, they can neuer be composed, seeing euery man will draw in the Scriptures, as a party, to countenance or abet his opinion, how bad soeuer.Answ. sect. 2. The ground of all which inconueniences, though the sectaries cannot see it, is the naturall obscuritie and difficultie of the Scriptures. These are the maine springs, or first fountaines, whence the aduersaries eloquence in this argument flowes. And it will be but one labour to stop vp these, and his mouth. Or granting them passage, we may draw his inuention against vs drie, by turning their course vpon himselfe.

div.head: CHAP. II.
The former Obiection, as farre as it concernes illiterate and Lay men retorted and answered.
div.p: 1 IF to suppose such an authoritie, were sufficient to confirme any translation, or secure the world of sincere translations, or to allay all controuersies arising about the true sense and meaning of Scriptures: we were verie impious to denie it. But, if we haue iust cause to suspect, that such as contend for it, haue but put this infallible authoritie, as the Astronomers haue supposed; some, Epicycles & Eccentricks; some, the motion of the earth; to salue their Phoenomena which otherwise might seeme irregular: we may, I trust, examine: first, whether the supposall of this infallible authoritie, in the Church, doe salue the former inconueniences: secondly, whether greater inconueniences wil not follow vpon the putting of it,That the illiterate may as well know the true sense of Scriptures, as the right meaning of the Popes decrees. than are the supposed mischiefes, for the auoydance of which this infallible principle was inuented, and is by the fauourites of this art, sought to be established and perswaded.

2 a That this supposed infallible authority of the Church visible doth no way salue the inconueniences obiected against our positions, is hence euident. As the Scriptures themselues were written
in a tongue not common, nor vnderstood of all nations, but of some few: so likewise the decrees of this visible Church, concerning the authoritie of translations, are written in a tongue neither common to all, nor proper at this day to any vnlearned multitude, but to the learned onely. Sometime they were written in Greeke: but, in later yeares, all in Latine, or some other tongue (at the least) not common to all Christians: for no such can this day be found. Nor is the Pope, (or his Ca • d nals,) able to speake properly and truly euery language in the Christian world, of which he challengeth the supremacie. He would be the vniuersall head indeed: but he hath not, nor dare he professe he hath, an vniuersall tongue,Tot verò translationes, mutationes, sine graeuissimo pericul • & incommodo non fierent. Nam non semper inueniuntur idonei interpretes: atque ita multi errores committerentur qui non possint postea facilè tolli. Cum neque pontifices, ne{que} concilia de tot linguis iudicare possint. Bellarm. lib. 2. de verbo Dei. cap. 15. whereby he may fully instruct euery person throughout the Christian world, in his owne naturall, knowne mother tongue. For Bellarmine brings this as an argument why the Bible should not be translated into moderne tongues, because if into one, why not into another: and the Pope (as he confesseth) cannot vnderstand all.

3 Tell me then, you that seeke to bring the vnlearned lay sort of men to seeke a shelter vnder the infallible authoritie of the Romish Church: how can you assure them what is the verie true meaning of that Church? They vnderstand not the language wherein her decisions were written. What then? must they infallibly, and vnder paine of damnation, beleeue that you do not erre in your translations of them? or must they stedfastly beleeue, that you interprete their decrees aright? Nay euen those decrees, which you hold infallible, condemne all priuate interpretation of them: and your greatest Clearks daily dissent about the meaning of the Trent-Councell in sundrie points. Yet, vnlesse the Lay people can stedfastly beleeue, that you interprete the Churches sentence aright: your supposed rule of the Churches infallibilitie in confirming translations or senses of Scripture can neither be a rule infallible, nor any way profitable vnto them. For it hath no other effect vpon their soules, saue onely beleefe:Were thei • obiections against vs pertinent: not the Popes infallibilitie, but the Priests and Iesuites honestia or fidelitie, should be the rule of most lay Papis • faith. and they haue no other meanes to know that this which they must beleeue is the Churches sentence, but your report: then can they not be any more certaine of the Churches minde in this or that point, than they are of your skill or fidelitie; neither of which can be to them the infallible rule of faith. For, if they should be thus infallibly
perswaded of your skil or fidelity: then were their good perswasion of you, the ground and rule of their faith; and so they must beleeue that you neither d • d, nor could erre in this relation; Whereas your owne doctrine is, That euen the learnedst among you may erre: and you cannot denie, but that it is possible for the honestest Iesuite, either to lie, or equiuocate. Otherwise, your infallibilitie in not erring, were greater than your Popes or Churches: for they both may erre vnlesse they speake ex Cathedra. Now, whether the Pope speak this or that ex Cathedra, or whether he speake or write at all or no, is not known to any of the cōmon people in these Northern countries, but onely by your report: which if it be not infallible, and as free from errour as the Pope himselfe, the people must still stagger in faith. Nor doe I see any possible remedie: vnlesse euery man should take a pilgrimage to Rome, or vnlesse you would bring the Pope throughout these countries, as men vse monsters or strange sightes. Yet, how should they be certaine that this is the Pope, rather than some counterfeit? or how should they know Rome, but by others? Or can you hope to salue this inconuenience by an implicite or hypotheticall faith? as, that it were enough for the lay people to beleeue absolutely and stedfastly, that the Pope, or Church cannot erre: but to beleeue your report or informations of his sentence in doubtfull cases, onely conditionally; if it be the Popes minde: if otherwise, we will be free to recall our present beliefe. This is all which I can imagine any of you can say for your selues. And may not we, I pray you, say as much, if thus much would serue for vs? Might not we by the selfe same reason teach the people to admit of translations, but onely conditionally, as farre forth as they shall be perswaded that this was the meaning of the Scripture or the word of God? For questionlesse, it is more certaine that God cannot erre, than that the Pope cannot. And it is more necessarie vnto Christian beliefe to hold, that God the Father, Sonne, and holy Ghost neither can, nor will speake a lie: than that the Pope cannot, or will not teach vs amisse. That the Pope and his Cardinals doe arrogate thus much vnto themselues, is more than the lay and vnlearned people can tell, but onely by yours and others relation: But that the God of heauen neither can, nor will teach amisse, is a principle not controuersed by any that thinkes there is a God.

4 Let it then first be granted, That God is freer from errour, from deceiuing, or being deceiued in points of faith, or matters of mans saluation, than the Pope is, although he speake ex Cathedra. From this position it followes most directly, and most immediately, that if the lay vnlearned people of this land haue as good means and better, to know that these bookes of Scripture are Gods owne words, than they can haue to know that this or that Canon in any Councel was confirmed by the Popes teaching ex Cathedra: then must the same people beleeue the one more stedfastly than the other; to wit, Gods word, as it is read vnto them in our Church, more stedfastly than the Popes interpretations, iniunctions, or decrees. Let vs compare the meanes of knowing both. First, if the Popes decrees be a certaine meanes of knowing any truth: they are as certaine a meanes of knowing those Scriptures which our Church admits, to be Gods word, as of any thing else; for the Pope and his CouncellConcil. Trident. sessione quarta. haue auoucht them for such, although they adde some more than we acknowledge.

5 If the worst then should fall out that can be imagined; as if we had reason to despaire of all other translations saue only of the Vulgar, yet that it were the word of God we might know, if by no other meanes, yet by consent of the Romish Church; and all the people of this land might be as certaine of this decree, as of any the Pope can giue. But take the same Scripture as it is translated into our English, the people may be as certaine that it is the word of God, as they can be that the Trent-Councell was lawfully called, or by the Pope confirmed, yea much more certaine. The Iesuites may tell them, that these very words (being first englished) were spoken in the Trent-Councell, and confirmed by the Pope. Why should they beleeue it? because they auouch it seriously whom they thinke able to vnderstand Latine? Suppose not onely one, or two, or three, but the whole assembly of our Cleargie tels the same people, that these (reciting the points of our saluation) are the verie words of God himselfe; and are for substance all one in the Hebrew, Greeke, Latine, and English. What difference can you heere imagine? That the Trent-Councell decreed thus, the moderne Iesuites haue it but from tradition of this age: That God spake thus, we haue the consent of all ages. Yea, but it is easier to render the Trent-Councels meaning out of Latine,
than the meaning of Gods word out of Hebrew or Greeke? Whether it be so or no, the vnlearned people cannot tell, but by hearesay: yet, if we would take the vulgar Latine, this foolish obiection were none: for it is as easie to be rendred, as the Trent-Councell; and if the Trent Councell be true, it is the word of God. All then is equall concerning the difficulties, that may arise from the skill, or ignorance of the translators of the one or other; the Popes decrees, or scripture. Our ministers know to render the meaning of Scripture as well as yours doe the meaning of the Councels. Let vs now see whether it be as likely, that our ministers fidelitie in telling them as they are perswaded, and as they beleeue themselues, be not to be presumed as great. To call this in question were extreme impudencie & vnciuilitie, especially seeing we teach, that the people should be throughly instructed in the truth: where as you hold it for good Christian pollicie, to hold thē in ignorance. Our permitting the free vse of Scriptures to all doth free vs from all suspition of imposture or guile: of which in the Iesuite or learned Papist the deniall of like libertie, is a foule presumption. Further, let vs examine, whether from the matter or manner of the Popes decrees, there can be any argument drawne to perswade the people that these are his decrees and no other mans: more then can be gathered from the matter and manner of Scripture phrase, to perswade a man that these are Gods, & can be no mans words.Granting the Pope to be as infallible as God himselfe: yet were not his decr • es related by his messengers to be so much beleeued, as Gods written word, receiued by vs and thē, because it is freer from suspition of forgerie, then they can be, harder to be counterfeit then they are. And heere certainly we haue infinite aduantage of you. For no man of sense or reason, but must needs suffer himselfe to be perswaded, that it is a farre easier matter to counterfaite the Decrees of the Laterane or Trent-councell, or the Popes writs, interpretations, or determinations: than artificial y to imitate the inuincible and maiesticall word of God, either for the matter or the manner.

6 The sequele is this, that if the Scriptures receiued by vs be obnoxious to any the least suspition of being forged: then from the same reasons, much more lyable to the same suspition are those which we account the Popes decrees, and therefore in respect of vs, much lesse to be beleeued; although otherwise we should grant the Popes decrees (which without controuersie were his decrees indeed) to be as infallible as the eternall and immutable decrees of the Almightie. Gods word oft-times vnto
Atheists hath discouerd it selfe by the maiestie of stile and sublimitie of matter, to be more than humane, and therefore diuine, not able to be imitated by any lying Spirit. If any Iesuite will denie this: let him make triall of imitation in the prophecie of Isaias, the beginning of S. Iohns Gospell, the relation of Ioseph and his brethrens dialogues, the booke of Iob, &c. The maiestie of speech and other excellencies which appeares in them (especially if we consider the time, wherein most of them were written,) doth argue a diuine spirit: in whose imitation the most accurate writers of later ages, (albeit no man writes excellently but from some beame of diuine illumination in the facultie) are▪ but apish, if we read the same Scriptures in the tongue wherein they were written, or in sundrie moderne tongues capable of the diuine splendor which shines in the originall; with which the Latine (especially in prose) hath greatest disproportion of all learned or copious tongues. As for the Popes Decrees they bewray themselues both for the matter and manner, to be onely humane, and therefore easie to be imitated by the Spirit of man, subiect to many errors. Nor doth the Pope challenge to himselfe the gift of prophecie, but onely of legall decisions: which are no otherwise written, than many write, and containe no deeper nor more supernaturall matter, than many may inuent: most of them vsually penned in a base and barbarous Logicke phrase: his stile at the best is not peculiar, his character easie to be counterfaite by any man that can pen a proclamation, or frame an instrument in ciuill Courts.

7 To recollect what hath beene said. First, seeing God is more to be beleeued than men; secondly, seeing we haue better arguments to perswade the people that these Scriptures daily read in our Church, are Gods owne words, than the Priests and Iesuits haue; that the tidings which they bring from beyond Sea are the Popes or Churches decrees or sentence: we may and ought teach them to relie immediately vpon Gods word preached or read vnto them, as the surest and most infallible rule of faith, the most liuely, most effectuall, and most forcible meanes of their saluation. Or if the Iesuites will teach them to beleeue the Popes decrees giuen ex Cathedra; or the Churches opinion indefinitely taken, fide diuina, by infallible faith; but the Iesuites, or Priests expositions or
translations of them, only conditionally, and with this limitation, [If so they be the Pope or Churches decrees]: we may in like sort with farre greater reason, teach the people to beleeue the Scriptures or the word of God absolutely, and our translations or expositions of it, but conditionally or with limitation, so farre as they are consonant to the word of God. Seeing it is as probable, that we may expound Gods word as rightly and sincerely, as the other can the Church or Popes edicts: we haue better reason to exact this conditionall obedience & assent, in the vertue and authoritie of Gods word, which we make the rule of faith; than they can haue to exact the like obedience by vertue of the Pope or Churches edicts, which is to them the mistresse of faith. For it is more certaine to any man liuing, that Gods word is most infallibly true, than that the Pope cannot erre. Wherefore, if the absolute beleefe of the Popes infallibilitie, and conditionall beliefe of the Iesuites or Priests his messengers fidelitie or skill, be sufficient to saluation: much more may the absolute beliefe or assent vnto the infallibilitie of Gods word, and such conditionall and limited beliefe of his ministers fidelitie, be sufficient for the saluation of his people: who as hath bin proued, cannot be more certaine that the Romish Church saith this or that, than we can be of Gods word. For they neuer heare the Church or Pope speak, but in Iesuits or Priests mouthes. And although they knew he said iust so as those say: yet may a man doubt in modestie, whether the Popes words be alwaies infallible; but of the infallibilitie of Gods word, can no man doubt.

8 And heere I cannot but much wonder at the preposterous courses of these Romanists, who holding an implicite faith of beleeuing as the Church beleeues, (in many points,) to be sufficient vnto saluation: will yet fasten this implicite faith vpon the present Church of Rome, and not referre it rather vnto that Church as it was vnder S. Peters iurisdiction and gouernment. For if vniuersalitie be (as they contend) a sure note of vndoubted truth: then must it needs be more vndoubtedly true, that S. Peter could not erre in matters of faith, than that this present Romish Pope & his Cardinals cannot so erre. For all Papists hold this as true of S. Peter, as of this present Pope: and all Protestants hold it true of S. Peter, not in the present Pope: and so did all the fathers without controuersie hold it most true, that S. Peter did not teach amisse in his Apostolicall
writings. So that vniuersalitie is much greater for Saint Peter, then for this Pope that now is, or the next that shall be.

9 For these reasons (fully consonant to their owne positions) all Papists me thinkes, in reason, should make the same difference in their estimate of S. Peter and later Popes, which a French Cardinall (as the tradition is at Durham) once made betwixt Saint Cuthbert and venerable Bede. Albeit S. Cuthbert was accounted the greater Saint amongst them, whose greater benefactour he had beene, (in which respect they brought the Cardinall first vnto Saint Cuthberts tombe:) yet, because he knew him not so well, but onely by their report, he praies very warily; Sancte Cuthberte, si Sanctus es, ora pro me. But, afterwards brought vnto Bedes tombe then in the consistorie; because he had beene famous in forraine Nations, from the commendations of lesse partiall antiquity: he fell to his praiers without ifs or ands; Venerabilis Beda, qui à tu Sanctus es, ora pro me.

10 Proportionall to this caution in this French mans prayer, should euery moderne Papist limit his beleefe of the present Popes infallibilitie in respect of S. Peters; And say thus in his heart: As for S. Peter, I know he beleeued and taught aright; and I beseech God I may beleeue as he beleeued, and that my soule may come whither his is gone: as for this present Pope, if he beleeue as S. Peter did, & be likely to follow him in life & death, I pray God I may beleeue as he beleeues, and do as he teacheth; but otherwise (beleeue me) I would be very loth to pin my beliefe vpon his sleeue, least happily he runne headlong to hell with that which should haue drawne me vp to heauen: for in this life I walke by faith, and by faith I must ascend thither, if euer I come there, and therefore I dare not fasten my beleefe vpon any man, whom I would be loath to follow in his course of life. But most surely might this implicite faith be fastned vpon Gods written word, contained in the writings of Moses, the Prophets, Apostles & Euangelists. We know, O Lord, that thou hast taught them all truth that is necessarie for thy Church to know. And our aduersaries confesse, that thy word vttered by them, (righly vnderstood) is the most sure rule of faith: for by this they seeke to establish the infallibilitie of the Church and Pope. They themselues speake aright, by their owne confession, where they speake consonantly vnto it. Wherefore the safest course for vs must be, to search out the true sense and meaning
of it: which is as easie for vs, as them to finde, as in the processe of these meditations, God willing, shall appeare.

11
A briefe answere to the obiection concerning the illiterate. In what sense the Scripture or writtē word may be said to be the rule of their faith see the last chapter of this Section. Parag. 3. & 4.
How farre such are to relie vpon their instructors authoritie, see the eight chapter of this sect. Vnto the maine obiection, concerning the meanes of knowing Scripture to be Scripture, we haue partly answered (or rather preuented it) in the first treatise: and throughout this whole intended discourse we shal (God willing) explicate the former generall meanes or motiues, as also bring other peculiar inducements for the establishing of true faith, vnto the particular articles in this Creede contained. For the present difficultie, concerning the rule of illiterate lay mens faith, as such as vnderstand not those languages in which the holy Ghost did write: we answere briefly, That the language, tongue, or dialect, is but the vesture of truth; the truth it selfe for substance, is one and the same in all languages. And the holy Sect. 2. cap. 5. parag. 4. Spirit, who instructed the first messengers of the Gospell with the true sense and knowledge of the truthes therein reuealed, and furnished them with diuersitie of tongues to vtter them to the capacitie of diuers nations: can, and doth, throughout all succeeding ages, continue his gifts, whether of tongues or others whatsoeuer are necessarie, for conueying the true sense and meaning of sauing truth alreadie taught, immediatly to the hearts of all such, in euery nation, as are not,The want of skill in sacred tongues in former ages was for their ingratitude towards God, and louing of darknes more then light. For the like reasons were the Scrip • ures to the Iewes (as to our forefathers they had for a long time beene) as a sealed booke. Vid. sect. 2. cap. 2. parag. 3. 4. 5. for their sinne, iudged vnworthie of his societie: of all such as resist not his motions, to follow the lusts of the flesh. And as for men altogether illiterate, that cannot read the Scriptures in any tongue, we doe not hold them bound (nor indeed are any) to beleeue absolutely or expresly, euery clause or sentence in the sacred Canon, to be the infallible Oracle of Gods Spirit, otherwise than Lib. 1. par. 2. sect. 4. cap. 4. is before expressed: but vnto the seuerall matters or substance of truth, conteyned in the principle parts thereof, their soules and spirits are so surely tied and fastned, that they can say to their owne consciences; Wheresoeuer these men that teach vs these good lessons, learned the same themselues, most certaine it is that originally they came from God, and by the gracious prouidence of that God (whose goodnesse they so often mention) are they now come to vs. Such are, the rules or testimonies of Gods prouidence, the doctrines or reall truthes of originall sinne, of our miserie by nature, and freedome by grace: Such are, the articles of Christs passion, and the effectes thereof; of the resurrection, and life euerlas • ing.
Vnto these, and other points of like nature and consequence, euerie true Christian soule, indued with reason and discourse, giues a full, a firme, and absolute assent, directly and immediately fastned vpon these truthes themselues, not tied or held vnto them by any authoritie of man. For albeit true and stedfast beliefe vnto these fundamentall points might be as scant, as the true worship of God seemed to be vnto Elias in his daies: yet euery faithfull soule must thus resolue:Thus much C • n • s grant • th de loc. • h • ol. cap 8. re • p •• d 4. Consequently h • reunto he proueth the last resolution of faith not to be in • o the veracitie or infallibil tie of the Church, taxing Scotus, Gabriel, and Durand, as the margine telleth vs: but his reason holdeth good against all such as make the Churches infa libilitie the rul • of fai h: as sha l bee shewed • od wil ing in the thi • d s • ct 3

Though the world besides my selfe should worship Baal, and follow after other Gods: yet will I follow the God of Heauen, in whom our fathers trusted, and on whose prouidence who so relies shall neuer fall. So likewise must euery Christian, both in he • rt resolue, and outwardly professe with Peter, (but with vnfained prayers for better successe, and diligent indeauours by his example to beware of all presumption:) * Though the world beside my selfe shou • d abiure Christ, and admit of Mahomet for their mediator: yet would not I follow so great a multitude to so great an euill, but alwaies cleaue vnto the crucified Christ, my onely Sauiour and Redeemer, who I know, is both able and willing to saue all such as follow him, both in life and death. So againe, though all the subtiltie and wisdome of hell, the world, and flesh, should ioyntly bend their force, and stretch inuention to ouerthrow the glorious hope of our resurrection from the dead: yet euery faithfull Christian must here resolue with Iob, and out of his beleeuing heart professe,
• ob.
• 9. v. 25. I am sure that my Redeemer liueth, and he shall stand the last on the earth: and though after my skin this body be destroyed, yet sh • ll I see God in my fl sh, whom I my selfe shall see, and mine eyes shall behold, and none other for me. As we hope to see Christ with our owne eyes immediately and directly in his person, not by any other mens eies: so must we in this life stedfastly beleeue, and fasten our faith vpon those points and articles, which are nec • ssarie for the atta • ning of this sight of Christ, in and for themselues, not from any authoritie or testimonie of men, vpon which we must relie; for this were to see with the eyes of others faith, not with our owne.

12 Many other points there be, not of like necessitie or consequence, which vnto men, specia • ly altogeth • r vnlearned, or otherwise of lesse capacitie, may be proposed as the infallible Oracles of God: vnto some of which it is not lawfull for them to giue so
absolute, and firme irreuocable assent, as they must doe vnto the former, because they cannot discerne the truth of them in it se • fe, or for it selfe, or with their owne eyes, as (it is supposed) they did the truth of the former.

div.head: CHAP. III.
The generall heads of agreements, or differences, betwixt vs and the Papists in this Argument.
div.p: 1 ALL the d • fficulties in this Argument may be reduced to these three heads. First, How we can know, whether God hath spoken any thing or no vnto his Church. Secondly, What the extent of his word or speeches is; as whether all he hath spoken be written, or some vnwritten; or how we may know amongst bookes written, which are written by him, which not. Likewise of vnwritten verities, which are diuine, which counterfect. Thirdly, How we know the sense and meaning of Gods word, whether written or vnwritten.

2 These difficulties are common to the Iewes, Turks, Christians, and all heretiques whatsoeuer: all which agree in this maine principle, That whatsoeuer God hath said or shall say at any time, is most vndoubtedly and infallibly true.

3 But for this present, we must dismisse all questions about the number or sufficiencie of canonicall bookes, or necessitie of traditions. For these are without the listes of our proposed methode. All • he professours, eyther of reformed, or Romish Religion, agree in this Principle: That certaine books, (which both acknowledge) doe containe in them, the vndoubted, and infallible word of God.

The first breach betwixt vs.4 The first point of breach or difference betwixt vs and the Papist is, concerning the meanes how a Christian man may be in conscience perswaded, as stedfastly and infallibly as is necessarie vnto saluation, that these bookes, whose authorititie none of them denie, but both outwardly acknowledge, are indeed Gods words.

5 The secondThe second. point of difference (admitting the stedfast and infallible beliefe of the former) is, concerning the meanes, how euery Christian man may be in conscience perswaded, as infallibly
as is necessarie to his saluation, of the true sense and meaning of these bookes ioyntly acknowledged, and stedfastly beleeued of both.

6Our agreement concerning the nec • s • itie of minist riall function, for the planting of faith. In the meanes or manner, how we come to beleeue both these points stedfastly and infallibly, we agree againe in this Principle: That neyther of the former points, can (ordinarily) be fully and stedfastly belieued, without the ministery, asseueration, proposall, or instructions of men appointed by God, for the begetting of faith and beliefe in others hearts; both of vs agree, that this faith must come by hearing of the diuine word.
7 Concerning the authoritie of Preachers, or men thus appointed for the begetting of faith the question againe is twofold.

8 First, whether this authoritie be primarily,The points of differen • e betwixt vs, about the prerogatiue of Pastors, and the manner of their begetting faith in others. or in some peculiar sort, annexed to any p • culiar men or company of men distinct from others by prerogatiue of place, preheminence of succ • ssion, and from him or them to be deriued vnto all others set apart for this ministerie; or whether the m • nisterie of any men, of what place or societie soeuer, whom God hath called to this function, and enabled for the same, be sufficient for the begetting of true faith, without any others confirmation, or approbation of their doctrine.

9 Secondly, it is questioned, how this ministerie of man, which is necessarily supposed (ordinarily) both for knowing the word of God, and the true meaning of it, becomes auaileable for the begetting of true beliefe in eyther point. In whomsoeuer the authoritie of this ministeriall function be, the question is; whether it performe thus much, onely by proposing or expounding the wo • d, which is infallible, or by their infallible proposall or exposition of it, that is: whether for the attaining of true beliefe in both points mentioned, we must relie infallibly vpon the infallible word of God onely; or partly vpon it, and partly vpon the infallibilitie of such as expound it vnto vs. Or in other words thus: whether the authoritie or infallibilitie of any mans doctrine or asseueration concerning these Scriptu • es, or their true sense, be as infallibly to bee beleeued as those Scriptures themselues are, or that sense of them, which the spirit of God hath wrought in our hearts, by sure and vndoubted experience.

10 These are the principall rootes and fountaines of difference
betweene vs, concerning our present controuersie, whence issue and spring these following.O • her branches of the former differences. First, Whether Christ (whose authoritie both acknowledge for infallible) hath left any publique Iudge of these Scriptures which both receiue, or of their right sense and meaning, from whose sentence we may not appeale; or whether all, to whom this ministerie of faith is committed, be but expositors of diuine Scriptures, so as their expositions may by all faithfull Christians be examined. Hence ariseth that other question, whether the Scriptures be the infallible rule of faith. If Scripture admit any Iudge then is it no rule of faith: If all doctrines are to be examined by Scripture, then is it a perfect rule.

The Romanists assertions.11 Our aduersaries, especially later Iesuites, positions are these. The infallible authoritie of the present Church, that is of some visible companie of liuing men, must be as absolutely beleeued of all Christians as any Oracle of God: and hence would they binde all such as professe the Catholicke faith, in all causes concerning the Oracles or word of God, to yeeld the same obedience vnto decrees and constitutions of the Church, which is due vnto these Oracles themselues, euen to such of them as all faithfull hearts doe vndoubtedly know to be Gods written word.

12 The reasons pretended for this absolute obedience, to bee performed vnto the Church or visible company of men, are drawn from the insufficiencie of Scripture; eyther for notifying it selfe to be the word of God, or the true sense and meaning of it selfe.
