Consequently to these obiections, they stifly maintaine, That the infallible authoritie of the present Church, is the most sure, most safe vndoubted rule in all doubts or controuersies of faith, or in all points concerning these Oracles of God: by which we may certain • y know both, without which we cannot possibly know either; which are the Oracles of God which not, or what is the true sense and meaning of such as are receiued for his Oracles: one of the especiall consequents of these assertions is that this Churches decisions or decrees may not be examined by Scriptures.

Our Churches assertions contradictorie to the former.13 Our Churches assertions concerning the knowledge of Gods word in generall is thus. As Gods word is in it selfe infallible, so may it be infallibly apprehended, and beleeued by euery Christian, vnto whom he vouchsafeth to speake, after what manner soeuer he speake vnto him. Yea whatsoeuer is necessarie for
any man to beleeue, the same must be infallibly written in his hart: and on it once written there he must immediatly relie, not vpon any other authoritie concerning it.
14 Or if we speake of Gods written word, our former generall assertion may be restrained thus.

15 We are not bound to beleeue the authoritie of the Church, or visible companie of any liuing men, either concerning the truth or true sense of diuine Oracles written, so stedfastly and absolutely, as wee are bound to beleeue the diuine written Oracles themselues. Consequently to this assertion we affirme.

16 That the infallible rule whereupon euery Christian, in matters of written verities absolutely and finally, (without all appeale, condition, or reseruation) is to relie, must be the diuine written Oracles themselues; some of which euery Christian hath written in his heart by the finger of Gods Spirit, and beleeues immediately in and for themselues, not for any authoritie of men; and these to him must be the rule for examining all other doctrines, and trying any matters of faith.

But because most in our daies, in matters of faith, and Christian obedience, misse the celestiall meane, and fall into one of the two extreames: It shall not be amisse, while we seeke to diuert their course from Sylla, to admonish least they make shipwracke in Charybdis.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
Shewing the meane betwixt the two extremities; the one in excesse, proper to the Papists; the other in defect, proper to the Anti-papist.
div.p:
1 IT is a rule in Logicke, that two contrary propositions, for their forme, may be both false; And hence it is, that many Controuersers of our times, (eyther in loue to the cause they defend, or heat of contention) not content onely to contradict, but desirous to be most contrarie to their aduersaries, fall into errour with them. No controuersie (almost) of greater moment this day extant, but yeelds experiments
of this obseruation, though none more plentifull than this in hand, concerning the visible Churches authoritie, or obedience due to spirituall Pastours.

2The first extremitie held by the Papist. The Papists on the one side demaund infallible assent, and illimited obedience vnto whatsoeuer the Church shall propose, without examination of her doctrine, or appeale; which is indeed (as we shall afterwards proue) to take away all the authoritie of Gods word, and to erect the present Churches Consistorie aboue Moses, and Saint Peters Chaire.The second held by the Antipapist. On the other side, sundrie by profession Protestants, in eagernesse of opposition to the Papists, affirme, that the Church, or spirituall Pastors must then only be beleeued, then onely be obeyed, when they giue sentence according to the euident, and expresse law of God, made euident to the hearts, and consciences of such, as must beleeue and obey them. And this, in one word, is to take away all authoritie of spirituall Pastors, and to depriue them of all obedience, vnto whom (doubtlesse) God, by his written word, hath giuen some speciall authoritie and right, to exact some peculiar obedience of their flocke.

Now if the Pastor be then onely to be obeyed, when he brings euident commission out of Scripture, for those particulars, vnto which he demaunds beliefe or obedience; what obedience doe men performe vnto him, more than to any other man whomsoeuer? For whosoeuer hee bee that can shew vs the expresse vndoubted command of God, it must be obeyed of all: but whilest it is thus obeyed, it onely, not he that sheweth it vnto vs, is obeyed. And if this were all the obedience which I owe vnto others, I were no more bound to beleeue, or obey any other man, than he is bound to obey or beleeue mee: the flocke no more bound to obey their Pastors, than their Pastors them. Yet certainly God, who hath set Kingdomes in order, is not the Author of such confusion in the spirituall regiment of his Church.

3 Seeing then, it is most certaine that the Romanistes doe fouly erre, let vs see how their errour may bee fully contradicted, not striue to bee most contrarie vnto them, but rather to seeke out the meane betweene these two erroneous extreames.

4 Infallible assent, and illimited, vnreserued obedience we may not performe to the present Church, or any visible companie of men; but to the Scripture onely, made knowne, and euident to our consciences. This assertion is directly, and fully contradictorie vnto the Papists.

5 Conditionall assent, and cautionarie obedience we may and must performe to our spirituall Pastors, Ouerseers, & Gouernors,The third or middle assertion contradictory to the two former extreames, & • onely consonant to the truth. albeit we see not expresse commission out of Scripture, to warrant these particulars, whereunto they demaund assent or obedience. It is sufficient that they haue their generall commission for obedience, expr • sly cont • ined in Scripture. This assertion directly contradicts the other extreame, or contrarie assertion, and of all the three onely doth not contradict the word of God, which expresly teacheth, that some peculiar obedience is due vnto spirituall Gouernours. Vnlesse we hold, that when Christ ascended on high, and led captiuitie captiue, his donation of spirituall authoritie, was but a donation of bare titles, without Realities answering vnto them. Ephes. 4▪ vers. 11. To some he gaue to be Apostles, to some Prophets, some Euangelists, some Pastors and teachers. That some peculiar obedience, though not so great, as the Romish Church doth challenge, is due to spirituall gouernor • . Though prophecying in some degree hath ceast, and the eminencie of Apostleship bee dead with the Apostles; yet Pastors remaine, and Teachers must continue in Christs Church vnto the worlds end. If Pastors we be, then must we haue our shepheards staffe: if teachers, a rod to keepe our schollers in awe. The same Apostle from these grounds thus exhorteth the flock. Heb. 13. vers. 17. Obey them that haue the ouersight of you, and submit your selues: for they watch for your soules, as they that must giue account, that they may doe it with ioy, and not with griefe, for that is vnprofitable for you. What manner of submission, or what kind of obedience doth he heere exact? only spirituall will the carnall gospeller replie. But what manner of obedience is this spirituall? the least of all others? It is doubtlesse in their esteeme, which feare no losse, but what is sensible for the present, nor know not the vertue of any thing, but what is palpable: vnto all such, to be spiritual, is all one as to be inuisible, and to be inuisible is all one as not to be at all. This is the last resolution of most mens conceit of all spirituall authoritie in our times. But such as dread the Maiestie of that inuisible God, & feare to grieue his holy Spirit, will be most affraid of contemning spirituall authoritie. Disobedience to it,
though in a prince, is as hateful to the King of Kings as the sinne of witchcraft: for no subiect is more bound to obey his Prince in ciuil actions, than his Pastors in spirituall. He that said, touch not mine annointed, said also, do my Prophets no harme. Of Princes it is said by the Apostle Rom. 13. He that resisteth them, resisteth God. To Pastors it was said, (by the wisdom of God by whom Princes raigne) Luc. 10. v. 16. He that heareth you, heareth me, he that despiseth you, despiseth me, and he that despiseth me, despiseth him that sent me, and elsewhere Iohn. 20. v. 23. Whose sins ye remit, th • y are remitted, whose sinnes ye retaine, they are retained. These are prerogatiues of Priests, and were not esteemed as words of course, or formalitie, in the ancient and Primitiue Church. It was the iust feare of disobedience in the flocke, which first gaue occasion to Pastors, to vsurpe this tyrannie ouer them, which now they practise. For as Idolatrie and superstition could not haue increased so much in the old world,Vid. li. 1. 2. part. sect. 2. cap. 6. pag. 60. vnlesse there had beene euident documents of a diuine power in ages praecedent: So neither could this extreme tyrannie ouer Christs flocke haue beene eyther vsurped in the middle, or continued to the later ages of the Christian world, vnlesse the flocke had made it a maine matter of conscience to disobey their Pastors, and Ouerseers, whose authoritie they knew from those places of Scripture, then well expounded by the practise of holy men, to be exceeding great.

6 Saint Peter foresaw, that this Antichristian authoritie was likely to spring from the peoples reuerend conceit of their Pastors authoritie▪ and because the flocke was bound most strictly to obey them, he willeth the Pastors not to be too Lordly in their commands.1. Pet. 5. v. 3. Feede the flocke of God, which dependeth vpon you, caring for it not by constraint, but willingly: not for filthie lucre▪ but of a readie minde: Not as though ye were Lords ouer Gods heritage, but that ye may be ensamples to the flocke. So doth S. Paul,
Act. 20. vers. 28.29. Take heede therefore vnto your selues, and to all the flocke, whereof the holy Ghost hath made you ouerseers. to feed the Church of God, which he hath purchased with his owne bloud: for I know this, that after my departing shall grieuous Wolues enter in among you, not sparing the flocke. Vnlesse the flocke, for their parts, had beene bound to strict obedience, vsurpation of Lordship ouer them had not beene so easie, especially when there was no power beside the pastoral staffe to keepe them vnder: nor could their Pastors haue had any such oportunity to attempt it, as
might iustly occasion these caueats from these two Apostles, which by their moderate carriage had prescribed a contrarie example to their successors. Easie it had beene for the flocke to haue spared themselues, or kept aloofe from such mercilesse ouerseers: whose designes, though they could not with safe consciences contemne, auoid they might, by circumspect and carefull attending to other true shepheards voices, who by their skill in Scriptures, and true knowledge of the Apostles rules, knew how to limite the former large commission, directed to Pastors, after they begun to degenerate into Wolues. For this cause neither of these Apostles direct these admonitions to their flocke, as if it were permitted them to limite their obedience at their pleasure, but vnto their Pastors. And Saint Peter, in the words immediately following this admonition vnto Pastors, exhorts the flocke vnto obedience,1. Pet. 5. v. 5. Likewise ye younger submit your selues vnto the Elders; without any the least intimation, that they might disobey, as soone as the other began to dominiere. Not that the flocke may not refuse to obey their ouerseers, in some cases; but our Apostle did foresee, that the people would be alwaies most prone to disobedience, vpon lesse occasions than was requisite: and yet disobedience, vnlesse vpon euident, and iust occasions, he knew to be as dangerous, as blinde obedience in matters vnlawfull; the one vsually is the forerunner of superstition and idolatrie, the other the mother of carnall securitie, schisme, and infidelitie. And, according to our Apostles feare, did it fall out in the Church of God. The first mischiefe, which befell her in her prime, was from the want of due reuerence, and awfull regard of Ecclesiasticke iniunctions, and constitutions. Hence did heresies spring in such abundance; Sathan had sowne their seeds in proud hearts; and the ciuill Magistrates facilitie to countenāce euery prating Discontent, or forthputting Vocalist, in preaching what he list, though contrarie to his gouernours constitutions, was as the spring sunne to cherish and bring them forth. And as the Romish Church, vpon the depression of such rebellious spirits, did raise her selfe aboue all that is called God: So in truth it cannot be denied, but that many in reformed congregations, by seeking to cure her diseases, haue cast the Church of GOD into a relapse of her former sicknesse: which was the vsurpation of too much libertie in her
children. For the auoidance whereof, we are now, as God hath enabled vs, to aduise.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of the diuersitie of humane actions: the originall of their lawfulnesse, vnlawfulnesse, or indifferencie: which without question belong to the proper subiect of obedience, which not.
div.p: 1 OF the subordination of spirituall Gouernours amongst themselues, we shall haue fitter occasion elsewhere to entreate: Now we are to enquire the limits and bounds of spirituall authoritie in generall, onely so farre forth as it concernes the rectifying of their beliefe, who are bound to obey.

2 Out of the places before alleaged, these truthes necessarily and immediately flow. There is some peculiar authoritie in the Priesthood, or ministerie, which is not to be found in other men. This authoritie in them is as essentially subordinate to Christ, as the authoritie of any other magistrates is, vnto the principalitie, or soueraigntie, of that nation wherein they liue. Disobedience vnto spirituall gouernours, doth redound as directly and fully vnto Christs, as disobedience to inferiour Magistrates doth vnto the Princes or supreme gouernours dishonour: For he that heareth Christs messengers heareth him, he that despiseth them despiseth him: and yet it is as euident againe in some cases they may bee disobeyed. The difficultie is in which they are to be obeyed, in which not; or in one word, what is the proper subiect of obedience due vnto them.

3The generall or remote subiect of obedience. All obedience is seene, eyther in doing what is commanded, or abstaining from what is forbidden; all disobedience in refusing to doe what is commanded, and doing that which is forbidden by superiours, or men in authoritie. Things commanded or forbidden are of three sorts, eyther good in themselues, and required, or else simply bad and prohibited by the law of God or nature; or finally indifferent, neither commanded, nor forbidden by eyther of the former lawes. Againe, of good things, some are better,
some lesse good, and so of euill, some are more, some lesse euill: things indifferent onely admit no degrees; but our perswasion of their indifferencie, as al • o of the two other kindes, may be stronger or weaker.Perswasions pure or mixt. Our perswasion in all three kinds may be pure or mixt. Our perswasion of any kind, is then pure, when there is no surmise or perswasion of any contrarie qualitie in the action to be vndertaken; then mixt, when we are partly perswaded, that it is of this or that nature, but not without some surmise or probability, that it may be of another quality.Of the various mixture of perswasions, whence the varietie of actions▪ or of doubts concerning their lawfulnesse or vnlawfulnesse doth arise. The mixture of our perswasion likewise may be diuers. Somtimes we may be strongly perswaded, that the matter enioyned is good, & yet haue some weake perswasion or surmise, that it is euil, or contrariwise. Sometimes we may haue an equal perswasion both waies, & thinke it as probably good as euil. Somtimes we may haue a strong perswasion, that it is indifferent; and a weake, that it is good or euill, or contrariwise. Sometimes we may haue a we • k perswasion or coniecture, that it may be a great good, and a strong perswasion that it is but a little euill, or contrariwise. Sometimes a strong perswasion that it is a thing indifferent, & yet some surmise, that it is a great euill, or great good. Finally, as the good or euill apprehended by vs, so our apprehension or perswasion of their truth, or the truth of that indifferencie, which is found in some actions, may be diuided into as many degrees as we please: from the multiplicity of whose different combination, the varietie of humane actions (if we would descend to Mathematicall mensurations of our conceits, or calculate euery scruple, which curiositie of speculation might breed in ma • ters of practise) may be in a manner infinite. But because most men measure matters of conscience, as they doe commodities of little worth, onely grosso modo •
for our present purpose, it will suffice to suppose three degrees of good, and three of euill, and as many of our perswasions concerning the lawfulnesse, vnlawfulnesse, or indifferency of our actions.

4 Of things good in themselues, or so apprehended by vs, without any suspition or scruple of euill in them, there is no question. Euery mans conscience hath authoritie sufficient to enioyne their practise, and other authoritie is scarce seene in the substance of such actions. For seeing the good it selfe is to be done, one time or other, in some measure, onely the alacritie of doing it being
enioyned; in what time or measure it is to be done, or other like circumstances, doe properly come within the subiect of obedience.

5 Concerning pure perswasion of things indifferent likewise, there is no difficultie of moment. For no man that vnderstands what he saith, wil once denie, that euery lawfull gouernour is to be obeyed, in things acknowledged for meerely indifferent. Only this question may be made, Whether indifferent in the general, or vnto many, or most men at ordinarie times, be indifferent in the indiuiduall, to this or that particular man, at some peculiar seasons? Eyther he makes no conscience of his waies, or else he is besides himselfe, that denies obedience vnto any lawfull Magistrate: saue only in such matters as at that time seeme vnlawfull for him to doe, though indifferent in the generall, or at other seasons, or to other men. Hence ariseth the first degree of difference betwixt gouernours and priuate persons, that in things acknowledged for indifferent vnto vs, at this very instant, we are not bound to follow priuate mens aduice; but a magistrates or gouernours commaund we are in conscience to obey, and to make choice of whether part he shall appoint.

The rule of piuate resolutions in matters apprehended as meerely euill.6 If we speake of priuate resolutions concerning things euill: This rule in generall is most certaine; Whilest we are perswaded, that any action is euill, without any conceit or perswasion of good in the same, the aduenturing vpon it is desperate, and the performance of it vnlawfull. And yet, as he that exchangeth a commoditie worth eleuen shillings, for another not worth fiue, sustaines greater losse, than he that hath a Crowne taken from him,In what case some matters apprehended as m • erely euill may be vnder • aken with l • sse dange • , thē o hers which re partly apprehended as eui • l, partly as good. without any thing in liew thereof: so may a man oft-times wrong his owne soule and conscience more, by vndertaking actions which haue some shew or probabilitie of goodnesse in them, than in vndertaking others, which haue none, but are onely apprehended as euill. This falles out onely and alwaies then, when the difference betweene the greatnesse or probabilities of the euill feared in the one, and the goodnesse hoped in the other action, is greater than the quantitie or probabilitie of the former euil, which admitted no mixt apprehension of good. The reason is plaine, because the mixture of good doth onely recompense so many degrees of euill as it selfe containes of good. Now if in the actions
of equally mixt perswasions, the proportion betweene the euill and good be such, as is betweene eleuen and fiue; the ouerplus of the euill will be as sixe; and so shall it make the action, wherein it is, worse, than that which hath but fiue degrees or partes of euill, albeit without all mixture of any contrarie perswasion, or conceit of good. But alwaies where the euills feared are equall, and the probabilities of their ensuing likewise equall: any mixt apprehension of some good probably incident to the one, not to the other, doth make that action wherto it is incident, lesse euill, according to the degrees, eyther of the good apprehended, or of our probabilities that it may be accomplisht: and yet shall the action still be euill, as long as the euill which we feare is greater than the good which we can hope for; or, (these being equall) the probabilities greater, that the euill should fal out, than the good. For if to preferre a lesse good before a greater, be euill, much more to aduenture vpon a great euill, in hope of a lesser good; most of all to aduenture vpon any great or probable euill, without probabilitie of any good to counteruaile it in the choice.

7 Concerning mixt perswasions of good and euill,The rule of priuate resolutions, in matters, as probably good as euill. this rule is generall for priuate resolutions. Wheresoeuer the probabilities or perswasions of the goodnesse of any action, are as great, as the perswasions and probabilities of the euill that may ensue, and the measure of the goodnesse apprehended, as great as the quantity of the euill feared: a man of his owne priuate accord may as safely aduenture vpon the action, as the omission of it, referring the euēt to Gods prouidence, which fauoureth positiue actions, more than priuations; works rather than idlenesse; and the following of that which is good, more than abstinence from euill. A lawfull gouernours command, whether spirituall or temporall, must in this case rule all priuate choyse, eyther for doing or omitting it: the case is all one, as in things meerely indifferent; for heere is an indifferencie of perswasions. These rules are euident in priuate resolutions.

8 All the difficultie concerning the subiect of obedience vnto gouernours, is, eyther in pure perswasions of the euil,The chiefe points of difficultie concerning the subiect of obedience. that may be in matters commanded, without any probabilitie of good, or else where the mixture of perswasions is vnequall, in respect of the euill
feared, or lastly, where (supposing the probabilities of good and euill are equall) the quantitie of the euill which men feare, is greater than the quantitie of the good which they hope: The points of difficultie are especially two.

9 First, whether iniunction of publike authoritie may ouersway any degree of our priuate perswasions, concerning the vnlawfulnesse of any opinion or action; as, whether we may safely aduenture vpon such actions, or embrace such opinions, as we our selues iudge euill, without any shew or conceit of good: or such as we are more strongly perswaded, that they are euill than good: or such, wherein the euill which wee feare, seemes greater, than it can bee recompenced with the good, which wee can hope for; though it were as likely to ensue.
10 Secondly, if publike authoritie may ouer-sway any at all, what kinde of priuate perswasions these be, or how farre they may be ouerswayed by it.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
That sincere obedience vnto lawfull authoritie makes sundrie actions lawfull and good, which, without it, would be altogether vnlawfull and euill.
div.p: 1 MAny in our daies are perswaded, that no iniunction of authoritie ought to moue vs to any thing, which priuately we deeme euill, eyther absolutely, or vnto vs. Obedience, in matters lawfull, they acknowledge to be good, and acceptable in the sight of God: but the goodnesse of it not so great as may warrant our vndertaking actions, eyther suspected for vnlawfull, or alreadie condemned for such, in the consistorie of our priuate conscience: for this, in their opinion, were to do euill that good migh • ensue.

2 But heere men should consider, that many actions may be euill, whilest vndertaken by priuate men, vpon priuate motions, which are not euill, once allowed or enioyned by authoritie; not that any authoritie can make that which is euill, good: but that it may adde some circumstance or motiue, whereby the same action which, barely considered, was euill before, may now by this addition
or alteration, become not euill, because not altogether the same. For Abraham, vpon priuate instigation or secular motiues, to haue killed his sonne, had beene hideous and monstrous crueltie, one of the greatest breaches imaginable of the law of nature: but being appointed by God so to doe, to haue killed his sonne had been no man-slaughter. Not that God in this particular did (as some speake) dispense with the law of nature: for dispensation had made his action or purpose, only not vnlawfull; whereas Gods commaundement did, not onelyAbraham non solum non 〈◊〉 culpatus crud •
litatis 〈◊〉 , verum e •
• am laudatu • est • omine piet ••• quod v •••• t 〈◊〉 n • quaquam • celerate, • e • ob •
dienter occidere. Aug. de ciu. Dei. lib. cap. 21. exempt his resolution from that precept, Thou shalt not kill, but placed it in the highest ranke of goodnesse. For he had done better in killing his sonne, vpon this motiue, than in sauing of his enemies life, out of his priuate resolution, or goodnesse of nature. Most true it is (for a Prophet said it) of the generall Abrahams obedience made that action which without it had beene worse than mur • her, to be better than s •
crifice. Obedience is better than sacrifice: the truth whereof was most vndoubtedly most perspicuous, in this particular, by which that verie action, which otherwise had beene most cruell murther, became more acceptable in the sight of God, than any sacrifice that euer was offred, saue onely That, wherein greater obedience, than Abraham heere intended, was actually performed.

3 But some (perhaps) will heere demaund, what argument can be drawne, from obedience vnto diuine supreme authoritie,How farre the former instāce serueth to inferre the conclusion proposed. for iustifying obedience vnto subordinate powers, in matters, which in our priuate estimation we deeme vnlawfull? Shall wee equalize man wi • h God, or humane authoritie with diuine? No, but we should know, that all lawfull powers are from God, and he that resisteth them, resisteth the authoritie of diuine power. Abrahams warrant for killing his sonne, was more authenticke and expresse, than we can haue for any particular act • on, which we priuately conceiue as euill: but not more authenticke and expresse, than many diuine precepts for obedience vnto lawful gouernours are. As his warrāt was better, so had his action without it bin more desperate, than such as superiour powers vsually impose vpon inferiours. The former instance then was brought, principally, to mitigate the rigour of their precisenesse, who stifly maintaine, That no obedience can legitimate such actions, as, without i • , would be euill; but all must be performed, onely in matters presupposed good and lawfull, or, at least acknowledged for indifferent
vnto priuate men, before inioyned by publike authoritie. The contradictorie to which vniuersall negatiue appeares most true, in this particular affirmatiue of Abrahams resolution and obedience: from which we may further argue thus. As the immediate interposition of diuine authoritie made that action holy & religious, which otherwise had beene barbarously impious: so may the interposition of authoritie, deriued from God, make some actions, which, barely considered, would be apparantly euill, desperate, or doubtfull to be honest, good, and lawfull. To beate one that is sui iuris, at his owne disposition, and in his right minde, against; or one that is not such, with his consent; were insolent wrong: Because, we haue no power ouer the one; the other none ouer himse • fe, to authorize such vsage of his bodie. What would it be then, in priuate men, to beate such as they know for Gods Embassadours, though requested by them so to doe; when as the verie request might seeme to argue some present distemper, or distraction of minde? No doubt, but he that refused to smite his neighbour Prophet (whether Elisa or some other: the storie is in the first of Kings,)1. King. chap. 20. vers. 35.36.37. did not onely pretend, but truly had some scruple of conscience, least he should offend, eyther that generall law of not doing wrong vnto his neighbour, or that peculiar precept, Do my Prophets no harme: and yet for his disobedience to the Prophets command became a sacrifice to the Lion. But he that took the Prophets authoritie for his warrant, though he smote, and in smiting wounded him, yet did he not hurt his owne conscience a whit but rather by thus doing, preserued it whole, notwithstanding the former precept of doing Gods Prophets no harme. Miles cum obediens potestati sub q • a legitime co • stitutus est bominem occidit, nulla ciuitatis suae lege reus est h • mi •• dij: imo nisi fecerit, reus est • mperii deserti atque contempti. Quod si sua spon • e atque authoritate fecisset, in crimen effusi hum • ni sanguinis incid •• set. • taque vnde punitur si fecerit iniussas, inde punietur nisi fecerit iussus. Aug de ciu. Dei. lib. c. 26. To rifle a Spanish ship, vpon priuate quarrels, were piracie in an English Nauigator, to kill a Spaniard murther; but suppose the Kings Maiestie, vpon wrong done, by that nation to our state, not satisfied, should grant his letters of Mart: to rob them of their goods were no piracie, to take away their liues no murther: yet were the outward action in both cases the same, but the circumstances diuerse, and the partie that now vndertakes it, hath better motiues than before he had.

4 Many instances might be brought vnto this purpose, all euidently euincing thus much in general, That sundrie actions, which vndertaken out of priuate choice, would be wicked, (because we
conceiue in them some euil, without any conceit of possible good to set against it) may by iniunction of publike authoritie become lawfull to vs; because we haue new motiues and better warrants for to doe them; nor can our aduenture vpon such actions be censured for desperate, as before it might well haue beene. For first, whilest men of skill and iudgement, appointed by God to aduise in such matters, are otherwise perswaded than we in priuate are: the rule of Christian modestie bindes vs to suspect our owne perswasion, and consequently, to thinke there may be some good euen in that action wherein heretofore we thought was not; wherein as yet we our selues see none, yet may safely perswade our selues that others see, eyther more good or lesse euill. And vnto thi • perswasion we must adde this consideration also: That performance of obedience it selfe is a good and acceptable action in the sight of God. Or to come nearer the point.
He that doth that which in his priuate opinion he suspecteth for euili, because inioyned by lawfull authoritie, in this respect, doth not euill that good may ensue, seeing the goodnesse of obedience is no consequent of the action, but a motiue precedent.
The same reason holds in auoidance of scand • ll or bad example.

5 The goodnesse of sincere obedience alone is not a consequent onely of the action, but either an essentiall part, or such a circumstance, or motiue precedent, as brings a new essence for it concomitant: whereby the euill which we, out of priuate perswasions, feare may be counteruailed, as well as if we did conceiue some good probably included in the verie obiect of the action it selfe, which might be equiualent to the euill feared. At the least then, some actions, which priuately we would auoid as altogether euill, may vpon the former motiues be as lawfully vndertaken, as those which we h • ld, as probably good, as euill.

6 But, as euerie conceit of any good is not sufficient to counteruaile all conceit of eui • l, which may appeare in the same matter: so neither may all authoritie counteruaile euery priuate perswasion, in any man; but the greater, or more publike, the authoritie is, the more should it preuaile with all priuate persons, for the vndertaking of such actions, as otherwise would seeme vnlawfull. The like may be said of the danger, or sc • ndall, which might arise from the example of our disobedience, or non performance of obedience. The greater the harme is, likely to ensue such neglect of obedience, the more we are bound to be lesse scrupulous in obeying, for these are not more consequents of the action. The reason why men often mistake
them for such, is, because they distinguish not betweene the reall harmes themselues, or scandalous euents, which follow the action and the serious forecast of their danger. For as the meanes are precedent to the reall assequution of the end, and yet the intention of the end doth alwaies goe before the right choice of meanes, and as it were, seasons them for the production of what we intend: so albeit the reall euents or harmes be meere consequents, yet the mature and prudent forecast of danger, likely to follow any action or resolution, must be admitted into the consultation precedent, and ought to sway our consciences, according to euery degree of their probabilities vnpartially conceiued, as well as if we were as probably perswaded of so many degrees of inherent goodnesse in the action it selfe, or it essentiall obiect For the auoydance of any euill equally probable, is as good as the attaining of an equall good. If the danger, which we iustly feare may follow our neglect of obedience, whether in things forbidden or commanded, be as great as the euill, which (vpon like probabilitie) we conceiue in the verie action it selfe; it should make vs as willing to do what we are commaunded, as to refuse: albeit wee set apart the goodnesse, which may arise from the meere act of obedience it selfe.

7 That both the goodnesse of meere obedience, as obedience, and also the danger of euill likely to ensue our deniall thereof, are eyther essentiall parts of the obiect, or such internall motiues precedent, as may raise a new forme in the action: may be gathered from what hath beene said afore of things indifferent.Some obedience may alter that euil which appeares in some • ctions: because any obedience (though in the lowest degree) doth make acti • ns which without it were indifferent, to be truy good. For the iniunction of authoritie, as none (I thinke) will denie, makes things which to haue done, or not to haue done, was before indifferent, now not to be such, but necessarie & good. So as, not onely the obedience is to be thought good, but the very action wherein obedience is seene, though before indifferent, is now inherently good, and the omission of it would be in it selfe euill, and not by consequent onely. For obedience eyther is, or causeth, a new forme or essentiall diff • rence, which doth as it were sublimate the outward action, to an higher nature and qu • litie than it was capable of before. For the same reason may this goodnesse of obedience, and the due consideration of harmes, which may follow its refusall, make such actions, as before had beene euill for
vs out of priuate resolutions to haue vndertaken, not to be any more euill, but good. The difficultie onely is,To giue precise • ules what actions may of euill become good by obedience, is very difficult. what priuate doubts or disl • kes may be counteruailed by publike authoritie: or what certaine rule may bee giuen when they may, and when they may not.

8 Generall rules in this case are verie hard to be giuen, because the circumstances may be many & diuers. The authoritie may be greater or lesse: so may their dislike that are to performe obedience be of the things enioyned. The iniunction likewise may be more or lesse peremptorie. Sometimes it may seeme to resemble rather an aduice, than absolute command: somtimes rather to adiure, than command: Sometimes the parties in authoritie may be of lesse, & the parties of whom obedience is exacted, of greater reach, and deeper insight in those matters, whereunto obediēce, is enioyned, according to the diuersity of the subiect of obedience, which somtime may be such, wherin men of experience or practize are to be most beleeued, wherein occurrence of iudgements and multitude of voices may argue more truth: Sometimes the subiect of obedience may be matters of abstruse speculation, wherein one man of profound iudgement is more to be belieued, than fiue hundred but of ordinarie capacitie. For as things visible, but farre distant, for matters of abstruse speculation, cannot be discerned by multitude of eyes, but by clearenesse of sight; and as he that could discerne ships in the Carthaginian, from the Lilibae an hauen, saw more than all Xerxes Armie could in like distance: so doth it oft fall out, that some one profound iudicious contemplator sees clearely that truth, which all the wits of the same age had not been able without him to discouer. Such men may sinne in obeying authoritie, whereunto others in yeelding obedience, sin not; because they can discerne the vnlawfulnesse of the commaund it selfe better than others. But vnlesse a man can iustly plead this, or some other like peculiar reason or priuiledge, it is a very suspitious and dangerous case to disobey lawfull authoritie, (whether spirituall or temporall) in such matters as he thinkes others of his owne ranke may with safe conscience obey, or in such matters, whereunto he sees many men, by his owne confession of great iudgement and integritie of life, yeelding obedience with alacrity. For if thus he thinke of them, he cannot but suspect himselfe and
his perswasions of error; nay he cannot be otherwise perswaded, but that the commandement, or publike iniunction of authoritie, is not absolutely against Gods commaundement; for so it could not be obeyed, with safe conscience, by men of skill and integritie.A certaine rule when authoritie may be disobeyed, without whose obseruation disobedience is alwaies more suspicious than safe. And this I take to be the safest generall rule that can be giuen in this case: Not to consider the particular matters inioyned, with such of their circumstances or consequences as we out of our priuate imaginations conceiue, or feare; so much, as the general forme of publike iniunction, as it indistinctly concerns all. If we can truly discerne the law or publike act it selfe to be against Gods law, and such as will lay a necessitie vpon vs of transgressing Gods commandements, if we yeeld obediēce to particulars inioined by it: Act. 4. vers. 19. Our Apostles haue alreadie answered for vs, It is better to obey God than men. Christ had commanded them to preach the Gospel: The Priests & other Gouernors forbid them to preach Christ. Heere was a contradiction in the lawes themselues. But God commands vs to obey the powers ordained by him; & their cōmandements are particular branches of Gods generall commandements for this purpose: and he that disobeyeth them, disobeyeth God, vnlesse their commandements be contrarie to some other of Gods commandements. And it is a course as preposterous as dangerous, to disobey authoritie, because wee dislike the things commanded by it, in respect of our selues, or vpon some perswasion peculiar to vs, not common to all. For seeing obedience is Gods expresse commandement; yea seeing we can no more obey, than loue God, whom we haue not seene, but by obeying our superiours whom we haue seene: true spirituall obedience, were it rightly planted in our hearts,Such as disobey publike iniunctions, vpon s • spicion or feare least their practise might occasion euill, are vsually taken in their owne feare, and fall into that verie sinne which they seeke to auoid. would binde vs, rather to like well of the things commanded for authorities sake, than to disobey authoritie for the priuate disl ke of them. Both our disobedience to the one, and dislike of the other, are vnwarrantable, vnlesse wee can truly deriue them from some formall contradiction or opposition, betwixt the publike or generall iniunction of superiours, and expresse law of the most high.

9 It will be replied, That albeit the generall forme of publike iniunction be not absolutely vnlawfull, nor the things inioyned (for this reason) essentially or necessarily euill: yet are these most vnexpedient, and may be grand occasions of great euill.

He that is thus perswaded, might as farre as became his place, disswade any publike act concerning such matters; and yet withall were bound to cōsider, whether the want of such an act might not occasion as great euils, as he feares may follow the practise of such obedience as it commands: or whether other might not as probably foresee some equiualent good, which he sees not. But after such acts are publikely made, and obedience duly demanded,
Jn vitium ducit cu • pae fuga si caret arte.
As we may not do euill that good may ensue, so may we not omit any good, lest euill might happen thereon, and yet obedience by all mens consent is good. Thus from an vnnecessarie feare of the former men fall into the later, (which is but a sister sinne) by denying obedience which in it selfe is good, for feare lest they should giue occasion of euill. he that denies it vpon feare onely of some euill that may follow, doth giue great occasion to others of committing that euill, which hee himselfe by this refusall certainly commits, he opens the gappe to that capita • l mischiefe of publike societies anarchie and disobedience. In doubts of this nature, it will abundantly suffice to make sincere protestation in the sight of God, or if need require, before men, that we vndertake not such actions vpon any priuate liking of the things enioyned, but onely vpon sincere respect of performing obedience to • uperiours, whom God hath appointed to make lawes for vs, but not vs to appoint them what lawes they should make, not to iudge of their equitie being made, saue only where the forme of the commandement is contrarie to some of Gods commandements, so as the particulars enioined become therby essentially and necessarily euil. In such case, the lawes of superiours are alreadie iudged and condemned by Gods law, by which whilest they stand vncondemned, they shall condemne vs for disobedience both to Gods lawes and them, albeit we stand in doubt, whether that which they enioin, would not be most vnlawfull for vs to doe, if we were left vnto our priuate choyce. For seeing the case stands in controuersie betwixt vs and our superiours: we should doe as we are commanded by them, and referre the finall decision to the supreame Iudge, whether they do well or ill in making such lawes, as to vs may seeme to be occasions of euill, but whether they shall proue so or no, he best knowes, that onely can preuent the danger. We, as I said before, might aduise if we were thereunto called, for the mitig • tion or abrogating of such lawes, but iudge or condemne them, by the probabilities or feares of their consequents, we may not, but onely where they are alreadie iudged by the law of God. What priuate man is there, that knowes the secret intents or purposes of the state, in most actions of publike seruice? Can any man doubt but that a great many oft
feare some dangerous consequentes of those seruices wherein they are imployed? why then doe most men thinke themselues bound to obey the state, against their priuate doubtes or feares?
Thus much Saint Austea taketh as granted by all. For he bringeth in these words following to inferre a conclusion denied by his aduersarie.
Vir iustus, si fortè sub rege homine etiam sacrilego militet, rectè potest illo iubente bellare, ciuicae pacis ord • n m seruans. Cuiquod iubetur, vel non esse contra Dei praeceptum certum est vel, vtru • sit, certum non est. vt fortasse reum regem faciat iniquitas imperandi, innocentem autem militem ostendat ordo serviendi. Aug. l. 22 contra Faustum Manichaeum. cap. 15.
It is enough that we know such businesses (as for example warres with forrainers) not to be vnlawfull in the generall, and the determinations of warres, or like businesse, to be referred to the King, and his Councell: but whether this or that warre bee iustly vndertaken by them or no; common souldiers, nay captaines are not to iudge, nor to detract obedience, albeit they suspect the lawfulnesse of the quarrell, or could wish for peace if they were in place to determine of such matters. But if the whole state should commaund promiscuous vse of women, adulterie, murther of our brethren vncondemned by law, blasphemie, or the like: such commandements were not to be obeyed, but we are rather bound to suffer death our selues, than to be their instruments in such actions: for heere is a direct contradiction, betwixt the forme of such lawes and the law of God.

10What hath beene spoken of authoritie in generall, applied to spirituall authoritie. From what hath hitherto beene deliuered, we may collect, That superiours or men in authoritie are to be obeyed in such points, as their inferiours are not at leisure to examine, or not of capacitie to discerne, or not of power, or place, to determine whether they be lawfull or no. Thus much at the least is common to all absolute authoritie, of what kinde soeuer. And from the former places alledged, containing the commission of Priests or ministers, it is most euident, That the lawfull Pastor or spirituall Ouerseer, hath as absolute authoritie to demaund beliefe or obedience in Christs, as any ciuill Magistrate hath to demaund temporall obedience in the State or Princes name: And if any of Christs fold denie obedience, or appeale from his Pastor, without iust and euident reason, he doth thereby denie Christ, and endanger his own soule, as much as he doth his bodie that resists a lawfull Magistrate, when he is charged by him in his Princes name to obey. And as in temporall causes, if a man appeale without iust occasions, from an inferiour court to a higher, he is not thereby freed, but rather to be returned to the inferiour court from which he appealed, or to be censured (besides his other facts,) for his vnlawfull appeale: so likewise such as vpon pretence of ignorance in Gods word, or libertie of conscience, appeal • from ordinarie Ministers to Christ
the chiefe shepheard, are not thereby presently acquitted, but stand still liable to the censure of their Pastors, eyther to bind them if they continue obstinate, as well for this their disobedience in appealing from them, as for their other sinnes; or to loose and remit their sinnes if they repent. For God hath appointed his ministers to gouerne his Church, and Gouernours are to be obeyed in that they are gouernours, vnl • sse such as are to performe obedience, do perfectly know, or haue reasons (such as they would not be affraid to render to Christ in that dreadfull day,) to suspect, that their Pastors in their commaunds, goe beyond their commission, or the expresse lawes and ordinances of Christ Iesus, the supreme Gouernour and Commaunder both of Pastor and People.

11 But many men are oft-times strongly perswaded, that the verie forme of the law, or their superiours iniunctions,Vnto what a man stands bound being strongly perswaded that the lawes of superiors are against Gods lawes, and wherein his sin consisteth, if he disobey vpon such strong, but ill grounded perswasions. are opposit vnto Gods lawes, when in truth they are not. And hence they thinke they denie obedience vpon sinceritie and conscience, when indeed they do not, but in both cases are meerly blinded by affection. The questiō is, whether denying obedience vpon such perswasi • ns, they doe well or ill? That the perswasion is euill, is without contr • uersie. The difficultie is, whether (the perswasion remaining in full strength, without any mixture of suspition, or apprehension of their errour,) they adde a new sinne of disobedience, besides the sinfulnesse of their erroneous perswasion, or that habituall aff • ction whence it springs: that is, whether they should doe better in obeying against the full strength of their perswasion, or in disobeying, whilest it remaines? If they obey, they sinne ag • inst their consciences, and preferre the lawes of man before Gods: If they doe better in disobeying, it may seeme an happie errour, which exempts thē from the yoke of obedience, wherunto the orthodoxe are subiect. The answere is easie; Whosoeuer shal denie obediēce vpon such perswasions, doth commit disobedience actually; Not that it were better for him to obey, (supposing the strength of his perswasion to the contrarie,) but he actually sinnes in that he suffers not the strength of his perswasion to be broken by the stroke of authoritie, but rather suffers it to confront authoritie: So that his sinne (if we will speake precisely) consists onely in the exercise of his former perswasion, or in the motion of his
habituall affection: not in any proper act of that peculiarIt may iustly be questioned whether there be any such peculiar vice distinct from all vntoward affection, or whether all disobedience consist, onely in the formall opposition betweene some one or other affection, and the law, seeking to restreine it. habite or vice, which we call disobedience. That whereunto he stands bound by authoritie, is to abiure his former perswasion, that hee may with safe conscience obey: or (to speake more distinctly,) he is not bound immediatly to obey in the particulars now enioyned, nor to renounce his perswasion without more adoe, but to enter into his owne soule and conscience, to examine the grounds or motiues of his perswasion, to rate his owne wit and iudgement at its due worth and no higher, to renounce all selfe-conceit, or iealousies of disparagement, in yeelding to that he had formerly impugned, that so he may sincerely and vncorruptedly iudge of the truth proposed, and esteeme aright of authoritie, and others worth that yeeld vnto it. If we would sincerely obey in these pointes, which are the immediate and first principles of true Christian obedience, the grounds of erroneous perswasions would quickly faile: so as wee should be alwaies readie to obey in the particulars, whereunto obedience was iustly demaunded. But of the grounds, occasions of erroneous perswasions, and their remedies, by Gods assistance, more at large in the article of the Godhead, and some other Treatises of Christian faith.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
What actions are properly said to be not of faith in the Apostles sense: What manner of doubt it is which makes them such.
div.p:
1 AGainst all that hath beene hitherto deliuered concerning this point, that happily may be yet obiected, which hath alwaies bred greatest scruple for yeelding obedience in doubtfull cases. For our Apostle saith: Rom. 14. v. 23 Whatsoeuer is not of faith, is sinne: But whilest men obey spirituall Gouernours, in those particulars for which they shew no Scripture, this obedience is not of faith, (for faith is alwaies ruled by the word:) Ergo his obedience is sinfull, euen in this respect alone, that it hath not the word for it w • rrant, but much more
if we doubt whether the things enioyned bee good or bad: for doubting breedes condemnation as our Apostle in the same place gathereth. He that doubteth is condemned if he eate, because he eateth not of faith.

2 Vnto the former part of this obiection, the answere is easie and briefe: Seeing Gods word commands obedience in generall vnto spiritual Pastors, and that in most expresse termes; it doth warrant our obedience in particulars, which are not forbidden by the same word. But for clearing of the later obiection, because this place of Saint Paul is as often vrged to as little purpose, as any other in the whole booke of God besides, it shall not be amisse to consider. First in what sense it is true; Whatsoeuer is not of faith is sinne. Secondly, what manner of doubt it is, that makes a thing to be not of faith, in that sense which our Apostle meanes.

3
Three diuers meanings of this phrase, not of faith.
The first meaning. A thing may bee said to bee of faith three waies. First, strictly and properly, That is said to bee ex fide, of faith, which is an act or exercise of the habite or vertue of faith, as to beleeue in GOD, in Christ, or to assent vnto any article in this Creede. In this sense no man I thinke doth vrge this place of our Apostle: Whatsoeuer is not of faith is sinne. For then all deeds of charitie should be sinfull, seeing they are no actes or exercises of the habite of faith, but of charitie, which is a distinct habite from faith, according to best Diuines: nor can we properly say, that such works flow from faith, as the fruit doth from the roote, seeing charitie is no branch of faith, but a coaeuall stemme of infused sanctifying grace, the common roote to both. Such acts then may be said to bee of faith, onely because the doctrine of faith enioynes them, and the habite or vertue of faith inclines the soule vnto them, & moues charitie vnto the exercise of them. And this is the second sense or meaning of the speech, ex fide, of faith: that is, those things are said to be of faith, or to proceed from faith, which are commanded by the doctrine of faith▪ or vnto which we are inclined or moued by the habite or vertue of faith. But neither is it alwaies true, Whatsoeuer is not of faith, in this sense, is sinne. For so no recreation, no meriment,The second. not eating and drinking, with many other works both of reason and nature, generally nothing meerely indifferent could be truly of faith: at the least
at this or that time. How then are not all these sinfull, seeing they are not of faith, in none of the former senses, being neither acts of faith, nor enioyned by the doctrine of faith? This necessarily enforceth vs to seeke a third significatiō of the former words.

4 Thirdly then, that is said to be not of faith, whatsoeuer is not warrātable by the doctrine of faith,The third meaning onely meant by our Apostle. whatsoeuer conscience, or the vertue of faith, being consulted, cannot countenance or allow, but rather disswade. And in this sense, all that may be said to be ex fide, of faith, whatsoeuer is warrantable by the doctrine of faith, whatsoeuer faith, conscience, or the law of reason and nature can approue or allow of, either absolutely, or at that present whilest they are vndertaken, albeit they do not enioyne them, or impell vs vnto them (at the least) for that season. As for example; If a man, free from necessarie imployments of his calling, should ride halfe a score of miles to be merrie with his honest friend: This were neither an act of faith, nor an exercise enioyned by faith, and yet truly of faith in our Apostles sense, and no way sinfull, because warrantable by the doctrine of faith: Neyther faith, nor conscience, nor lawe of nature would condemne him for so doing. But if his dearest friend lay on his death bed, and did expect some comfort by his presence: his absence vpon such light occasions would be sinfull, because it could not be of faith. Neyther the doctrine of faith, nor the law of reason, could countenance such an action. Such resolutions may properly be said Not of faith, because they cannot proceed but from some inclination, or disposition, opposite to the habite of true faith, and the dictates of naturall well disposed, much more of sanctified conscience. Suppose some mans conscience were so scrupulous, as to doubt whether he might ride so farre to be merrie with his friend, when he had no vrgent occasions to withdraw him; and another so confident, and fully perswaded in his mind, as to make no question whether he should meete his friend in a plaguie house, or when his owne father lay a dying. The question is, whether of these two doth sinne the more? or if both doe not sin, whether of them is freed from sinne, and by what meanes? The former, as is supposed, doubts of the action, and yet doth it: the other doth the like, but worse, and doubteth not. If that iourney
which in it selfe is lawfull, (supposing the former case) becomes vnlawfull to the one, because hee doubts it is vnlawfull: then may the others confident perswasion make his expedition lawfull vnto him, although in it selfe (supposing the case aboue mentioned) it were vnlawfull. For who can giue any reason, why confidence of perswasion may not as well legitimate what otherwise is vnlawfull, as doubt or scruple illegitimate that which otherwile were lawfull and warrantable. So that, according to these grounds, the former partie aboue mentioned should sinne, not the later. And our Apostles speeches (vnlesse they admit some restraint,) will inferre thus much. Rom. 14. v. 14, I know and am perswaded through the Lord Iesus, that there is nothing vnclean of it selfe: but vnto him that iudgeth Our Apostles words, vnlesse the vniuersalitie of their forme be restrained by the matter or subiect, inferre • as forcibly, that confident perswasion might acquit vs, as doubting condemne vs in any action. Yet confidence of perswasion doth neuer acquit vs: But in matters presupposed indifferent; no more can doubting condemn vs without some inequalitie in the matter. any thing to be vncleane, to him it is vncleane, And againe; This man • st • emeth one day aboue another day, another man counteth euery day alike▪ let euery man be fully perswaded in his mind: as if he added, and then there is no danger. And yet if we should but consult natural • reason; who could denie, that he that made an idle iourney whereby he might endanger his owne, or neglect his fathers life, did sinne most grieuously; albeit he were most fully perswaded to the conscience: yea the stronger his perswasion were, the greater his sinne. On the contrarie hee that should vndertake the like iourney, hauing no serious occasions to withdraw him, if the truth bee rightly scanned, did not sinne at all: vnlesse perhaps in doubting whether he sinned or no. For euerie doubt of what we doe, doth not make our action sinfull, or not of faith: which is now to be discussed.

5 If that speech of our Apostle, He that doubteth is condemned if he eate, were to be vniuersally vnderstood of all doubts, or all actions: we should neuer haue an end of doubting, nor any beginning of many good and most necessarie works.The effects of such scrupulosities as our Apostles rule vniuersally vnderstood, would necessarily breed, are contrary to the Analogie of faith. This very perswasion, were it throughly and generally planted in all mens hearts, were enough to bring all states to vtter anarchie, and to set the whole world in combustion. For what enterprise is there of greater moment, but diuers men will be of diuers minds, concerning the lawfulnesse or vnlawfulnes of it? Who could not by this exception excuse himselfe from performance of necessarie allegeance or seruice? If the Kings Maiestie should wage warre against the Spaniard, he that were addicted to their religion might reply,
I should be as willing as another to doe my King and Countrey any seruice, but I doubt whether I may afford him my goods to the hurt and dammage of Romane Catholikes: the cause I am affraid is most vnlawfull, and will bring Gods plague vpon this land, theref • re I may not hazard my life in it, nor aduenture to shed the innocent bloud of our holy mother the Churches children. The like might a Lutheran say, if warre should fall out betwixt our state and the Saxons; or if with some other reformed Churches, the like might be said by most in our land: Finally there would be continuall distraction in the mannaging of all publike affaires. But such scrupulous demurres in ciuill matters, are eyther seldome made, or quickly answered by the temporall sword. And are they lesse dangerous in cases as little doubtfull, (wherein the consequents feared are of lesse moment) when they are giuen to the chiefe mannagers of our spirituall warfare, in times wherein disobedience threatens dissolution of Christs armie, that must fight his battels against Sathan and the man of sinne? Is the authoritie of binding and loosing, opening and shutting the Kingdome of heauen, lesse than the authoritie of life and death, or the disposing powers of temporall goods? What should be the reason then that euery scruple should be held sufficient to denie obedience (in matters of greatest consequence) vnto spirituall, more than temporall authoritie?Deniall of obedience vpō scruple, yea eu n the scruple or doubt it sel • e, may be not of faith, as we • l as the positiue action of whose lawfulnesse they doubt, whence the obiection, which many draw from the Apostles rule is most • orcibl • against th • mselues. Out of doubt, that rule of Saint Paul doth no more warrant the one than the other. The true reason is: most men feare temporall censures, more than eyther Gods or his, an ordinarie Gaile, more than hell: and had rather bee doore-kepers in great mens houses, than glorified Saintes in heauen; but of this hereafter. To proceede then with our Apostles rule. Were it vniuersally to be vnderstood, it would bring all Christian soules into such perpetuall, miserable, inextricable perplexities, as they should alwaies liue in suspence, and scarce resolue vpon any thing. For his rule holds as true in the omission of what should be done, as in the commission of what we thinke should not be done. Suppose then thy Pastor commaunds thee to obey in this or that particular, which he verily thinkes, eyther necessarie to be vndertaken by all Christians, at all or most times; or else most expedient for thy soules health, the setting forth of Gods glorie, or the good of others, at this present. But thou art contrarie-minded, and doubtest
whether thou maist doe it lawfully or no. Why? because thou hast no warrant for it out of Scripture, or because he brings no necessary reasons why thou shouldest do it, but bare probabilities, which cannot ouersway that doubt, which thou hast framed vnto thy conscience. But he can shew thee expr • sse commandement out of Scripture, that thou shouldest obey him. Thou wilt say; in things lawfull onely. This he auoucheth to be such; Thou deniest it. He can shew thee againe expresse words of Scripture, that thou shouldest not be wise in thine owne conceit, but be willing to learne of thy Pastor, Who is the messenger of the Lord of hostes, at whose mouth thou should • st seeke the law, and on whom, as our Apostle saith, thou dost depend. Tell me then, first, by what place of Scripture thy disobedience in this particular can be warranted? How canst thou chuse but doubt, whether thy deniall of obedience be of faith or no, seeing Gods word commands thee, in generall termes, to obey, and no where willes thee to disobey in this particular. Or if thou thinkest thou hast some generall warrant for disobedience, because thou supposest this particular to be vnlawfull: yet how canst thou but doubt, whether thou hast learned the precepts of Christian modestie as thou shouldest? Whether thou hast learned to denie thy selfe, and thy affections? whether thou hast learned to reuerence thy Pastor as Gods messenger, not taking any offence at his person? Finally, whether thou hast abandoned all such delights and desires, as vsually are the grounds of false perswasion, and impediments of sincere obedience? If thou canst not be fully and truly resolued in these, then must thou doubt, (whether thou wilt or no) whether thy doubt or scruple it selfe be of faith or conscience, or of humour onely. And if thou canst not but doubt herein, then maist thou assure thy selfe, that thy deniall of obedience is not of faith, and therefore sinfull: if the Apostles rule (as thou supposest) were vniuersally true; that whosoeuer doth any thing, of whose lawfulnesse he doubts, doth sinne, because he doth it not of faith. A man in •• some cases may eyther obey or disobey authoritie, not without doubt, and yet without sinne. But I dare not denie, but that sundrie of Christs flocke may sometimes eyther denie, or performe obedience vnto their Pastors, not without doubt or scruple whether they should doe so or no, and yet not sinne in eyther. In performing obedience they sinne not, vnlesse the doubt be verie great or probable, and the euill which they conceiue in the action
extraordinarie. Againe, in denying obedience they sinne not, albeit they doubt whether they should doe so or no: if the euill, which vpon mature deliberation and serious forecast they much suspect, be extraordinarie, such as cannot be recompensed by the goodnesse, which appeares in the act of obedience, nor in the fruits of the action it selfe, which their Pastor proposeth, as a motiue to vndertake it. According to those grounds must our Apostles speech be limited. He that doubteth is cond • mned if he eate, because he eateth not of faith.

6 What then? Is euery man that eateth any thing, which hee doubts whether it were better for him not to eate, straight condemned? God forbid. He that hath such a tender infants squemish conscience, as to thinke thus, had need to haue a verie ancient, graue, wise, and moderate stomacke: and it were fit he neuer came at any feast, or table, furnished with varietie of dishes.

7 But for a direct answere to our Apostles speech. It must be granted,It was not the doubt or scruple, but the qualitie of the things doubted of, which made their actions, of whom our Apostle speaketh, so grieuously sinfull. For the euill which vpon great probabilities they feared, was incomparably greater, than any good possible to ensue vpon their eating. that they of whom he speakes, did sinne in eating when they doubted. For if they had beene as fully perswaded in their mindes, as the Apostle himselfe, and sundrie others of their brethren were, they had not sinned in eating the selfe same meat: yet for all this they sinned not in eating (simply) when they doubted, but in eating such meates when they doubted: Other meats they might haue eaten with little or no offence; albeit with more vncertaintie, whether it had been better for them to eate or no. Nor was it so much a positiue doubt, as rather a rashnesse, or want of setled resolution, in many of thē, which made them sin; as may appeare from the circumstance of the place: yet was this eating not only a sin, but a most grieuous sin, in all that did eate such meats, without a constant and well-grounded resolution. Both the sin, & the extraordinarie grieuousnesse of it did hence, arise: they had eatē of things sacrificed to Idols, or other meats, (in their iudgement) accursed by the law, which they suspected not onely to be vnlawfull to be eaten, but doubted whether in eating them they should not be partakers of the table of Diuels, initiate to the Sacraments of idolatrie, or separated from the Israel of God, or finally become Apostata's from faith, and the holy doctrine. As on the one side, the euill which they feared was extraordinarily grieuous, and the reasons of their feare such as could not easily be cast off, but
would be alwaies likely to breed despaire after the action were past, albeit many of them did shake off all doubt for the present: so on the other part, there was not quid pro quo, not the least possible surmise of performing any degree of any good or acceptable seruice in the sight of God, by their eating. For, as Saint Paul in the same place notes: The Kingdome of God is not meate or drinke, but righteousnesse and peace; whosoeuer in these, (as if he had said, not in eating and drinking) serueth Christ, is acceptable vnto God, and is approued of men. Those then of whom he there spake, accounting it a chiefe part of their righteousnesse to abstaine from all vncleane things, their danger in eating was in quantitie exceeding great, and for the qualitie spirituall: their losse in abstaining from such meates (being prouided of others) was in quantitie as nothing, and for the qualitie meerely corporall. Wherefore thus to haue eaten, with the least scruple of such grieuous danger, was worse than Esau's alienating of his birth-right for a messe of pottage. And albeit they had doubted to day, and growne resolute to morrow, vpon no better motiues than the bare examples of others; or in an humour or brauerie, because they would not doubt any longer, but vse their libertie as others did: yet had such resolutions beene deadly. For opinions of this nature may not bee cast off in a moment, nor may a man aduenture vpon a doubt of such fearefull consequence, but vpon great motiues of some spirituall good; the probabilities of attaining which may counteruaile the euill feared: or vpon serious deliberation, and perspicuous discouerie of their former errour, and causelesse scruple. From these grounds did our Apostle inferre that exhortation. Let euery man be fully perswaded in his mind.
Vers. 5. He exacteth not this fulnesse of perswasion in matters of ordinarie consequence; too much curiositie in them alwaies occasioneth lesse diligence or circumspection, than were requisite for establishing our minds with true faith, in pointes of greatest moment: nor did he meane such fulnesse of perswasion, as hot spirits vsually enforce vpon themselues, without mature and sober deliberation. For such resolutions, albeit they may seeme most strong, as indeed they are for the time exceeding stiffe: yet are they easily to be vnderminded by Sathan; the inward temptations of the flesh; or other occurrents; and after once they begin to faile, such as leane
most vnto them, fall so much the more headlong into deepest despaire, by how much they haue beene stronger or higher pitcht; as it seems some of these, to whom he writes, had beene too bold in eatng, and were afterwards tortured by the sting of conscience. The end of our Apostles exhortation was this: Seeing their perswasions, concerning the vnlawfulnesse of such meates, had beene (as it were) bred vp with the parties doubting, they should in no case aduenture vpon the contrarie practise, but vpon long and well-setled resolution, grounded vpon a sincere and cleere manifestation of their former errour. For as the Phisitions of our bodies do not alwaies apply such medicines, as they know most forcible to expell the present disease, if the same be contrarie to our former long accustomed diet, (for vitiosae consuetudini indulgendum est, there must a care be had that a custome, though depraued, be not too violently thwarted, or too sodainly broken off:) so likewise must skilfull Physitions, of the soule, not seeke so much to expell inueterate opinions, (though erroneous,) by present force of strongest arguments, or eager exhortations; but rather suffer them to weare out their strength by little and little, neuer infusing contrarie perswasions, but mitigated and qualified, and that sparingly, as opportunitie shall serue. Otherwise, what one saith of Nature her selfe,
Expellas furca licet, vsque recurret:
Though with strong hand she be out-throwne,
She still repaires vnto her owne:
will proue true of that altera natura, inueterate custome. It, sodainly expulsed, will one time or other retire as violently: and so shall the relapse be much worse than the disease it selfe.

8 For these reasons did they also offend most grieuously, who by their example or instigation, did cause their weake brethren to eate such meates as they made this conscience of: Vide. 1. Cor. 11.8 for so they caused them, for whom Christ Iesus died to perish for their meats sake, as it is vers. 15. Whereas the losse of meate, or life it selfe, should, by the rule of charitie, be accounted gaine in respect of our brethrens inestimable da • ger, which may ensue vpon such actions. Better it were we should suffer our selues to starue for meate, and so procure our owne corporall, than occasion their eternall death
by our example; so saith our Apostle: If meate offend my brother, I will eate no meate while the world standeth that I may not offend my brother. It were better for me to die, 1. Cor. 8. v. 13. 1. Cor. 9.15. than that any man should make my reioycing vaine. Nor did our Apostle in this place speake hyperbolically, or more than hee meant to haue performed, if hee had beene called to such a triall of his resolution, as some of his forefathers had beene. So we read, when Antiochus officers, out of great loue (as they esteemed it) vnto the good old man, had permitted Eleazar one of the principall Scribes to make choyse of of such flesh as he would, and might safely eate by his countrey lawes; only requesting him to dissemble by his silence,2. Machab. 6. vers. 21.22.23.24. &c.
As though he had eaten the things appointed by the King, euen the flesh of his Idols sacrifices: Albeit he might haue had life vpon this condition: yet he confidently answered: and willed them straightwaies to send him to the graue. For it becommeth not our age (said he) to dissemble, whereby many young persons might thinke, that Eleazar being fourescore yeares old and ten, were now gone to another religion: and so through mine hypocrisie (for a little time of a transitorie life) they might be deceiued by me, and I should procure malediction, and reproach to mine old age. This eating, which hee refused, could neuer haue beene of faith, that is, no way warrantable, by the doctrine or principles of faith, which had taught him the contrarie: as he well exprest in the next words following: for though I were now deliuered from the torments of men, yet could I not escape the hand of the Almightie, neither aliue nor dead. Wherefore I will now change this life manfully, and will shew my selfe such as mine age requireth.

9 And it should bee considered, that the parties of whom ourTwo principall circumstances to be considered, peculiar to those of whom our Apostle speaketh▪ Apostle speakes in the fore • entioned place, were neuer inioyned by any lawfull superiours, eyther ciuill or Ecclesiastique, to eate such meates as they made scruple of: yea the verie original or fountaine of their scruple, was from the expresse law of God, denouncing fearefull iudgements against all such, as polluted themselues with vncleane meates: so that their eating, albeit solemnly inioyned by the greatest powers on earth, could not fall within the subiect of true obedience, because the lawes inioyning it (as they conceiued) stood actually condemned, by the expresse law of God to the contrarie, in defence whereof, many of their ancestors
had exposed their bodies to most grieuous tortures, and the refusall of such meates, as they made scruple of, had beene alwaies accounted the iustest title of glorious martyrdome amongst the Iewes. And albeit these lawes concerning vncleane meates were indeed antiquated at the alteration of the Priesthood; yet should we not meruaile, if at the first planting of the Gospell, many good Christians did make great conscience of eating such meates as were forbidden by them, when Saint Peter himselfe, long after our Sauiours ascension, durst scarce take Gods owne word against his written law, then not abrogated (as he supposed) in this case. For when there came a voice vnto him (as it is) Act. 10. v. 13. saying, Arise Peter, kill and eate, Peter said, Not so Lord, for I haue neuer eaten any thing that is polluted, or vncleane. And the voice came vnto him againe the second time, saying, the things that God hath purified doe not thou account polluted. Nor was Peter, as it seemes, yet fully satisfied, for it is added in the next words: This was so done thrice, and the vess • ll was drawne vp againe into heauen. All these circumstances abundantly euince, that it was not the bare doubt or scruple, but the qualitie of the things doubted of, and the inueterate opinion, or abhominable conceite, which the Iewes, or other of their instruction, had of the meates themselues, that made their eating to beeThis phrase includeth a contrarietie or opposition vnto faith as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 & many like phrases, as vsuall in the Hebrew Dialect, as the Latine compounds immitis, immisericors, &c.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , so fa • re from being of faith, that it rather seemed to ouerthrow it. Had the excesse of the daunger they feared beene lesse, or had there beene any ordinarie possibilitie of any proportionable good to set against it: their sinne in eating had beene lesse, albeit the grounds of their scruple had beene greater, or their perswasions one way or other lesse setled.

10 Albeit this exposition of our Apostle, may seeme strange and new to many honest and well disposed minds in our Church: yet in truth, the manner of the deduction only is new, the doctrine it selfe is generally held by all Diuines, though not expresly in conclusion, yet in the premises, wherein it is essentially contained, and may be most euidently deduced; thus.

11The former interpretation necessarily follow • th from grounds of diuinitie acknowledged by all. All sinne consists, either in preferring none before some, the lesse before a greater, or a corporall before a spirituall good: the hainousnesse of sinne, in the excesse of difference, betwixt the true good neglected, and the seeming good embraced, which is
eyther absolutely euill, or else a farre lesse good, which in competition with the greater good is likewise to bee accounted euill. Now, if whatsoeuer be not of faith be a sinne, then by the former rules it is a sinne, because a lesse good is preferred before a greater, or some euill chosen without any proportionable good, that might serue as a sufficient recompence. But if the nature of all actuall sinne consist in one of these two: It is questionable, how or in what case, doubting or scruple of what we do, doth make our actions sinfull.How scruples or doubt of what we doe, concurre to make our actions sinfull. Briefely, it is an externall cause, or circumstance, concurring to the making of a sinfull action, not any essentiall part, or internall circumstance of the sinne it selfe once caused. And it thus concurres onely, when that which in it selfe is euill, or proues so in the euent, would not be euill vnto vs, vnlesse we had some doubt or scruple, that is, some notice or apprehension of it as euill: In such cases indeed we should not sinne, vnlesse we had formerly doubted: but to speake exactly, we doe not sin, because we doe what we doubt of, but because in doingAs when the euill feared, is greater than any good that can be hoped. some actions, when we doubt, we actually preferre euill before good; which otherwise we should not, albeit we did the selfe same action. For it could not be euill to vs, without the apprehension of its nature, so as the apprehension of it concurres to the making of it euill. And because in all doubts or scruples, there is some apprehension of euill: therefore when we doubt, in cases aboue mentioned our actions are not of faith, but sinfull. But if eyther we could be fully perswaded to the contrarie; that is, if we could out of sinceritie of conscience, & setled iudgement, discerne that very thing which eyther we ourselues sometimes did, or others yet, apprehend as euill, not to be truly euill: the same action, which before had beene, shall not be now sinfull vnto vs: because we now preferre not euill before good.
