Or againe, albeit the thing were in it selfe euill, (as being prohibited by some positiue law,) but we vpon inuincible or vnculpable ignorance, did not apprehend it for such: wee should not actually sin in doing it, because in this case, wee could not truly be censured for preferring euill before good (seeing the apprehension maketh it euill to vs) albeit we did prefer that which was euill, before that which was good. As for example: If a Proselite should haue eaten swines flesh, being altogether ignorant (not by his owne, but the Priests negligence) of the Israelites law to the
contrarie: he had done that which was euill, because forbidden by the law, but notMalum non malè. ill, because he had no apprehension of it as euill, but did eate it without all scruple, as well as the strong in faith did in Saint Pauls time. As doubting, in those cases wherein wee haue an apprehension of some excesse of euill, makes mens actions not to be of faith; and want of doubt, (so all other circumstance be obserued) makes them to be according vnto faith:The same action though simply euill in both, may be lesse of faith in him that doth it confidently, then in another that doth it not without scruple. so it oft-times falles out, that such as nothing doubt whether they do ill or no, do sinne farre more than such, as not without great scruple of conscience make the same sinister choyce. For, oft-times the causes why men make no scruple, or why they apprehend not the euill which they doe, are such, as will necessarily make their actions worse, than if they had doubted, and yet had done the same. This rule holds alwaies true, when the cause, why men doubt not of their actions, is some inordinate desire of gaine, pleasure, or other like corrupt affection, or some strong humour of contradiction: not stedfast or well-grounded resolution, not pure simplicitie, or inuincible ignorance, not occasioned by default or negligence in our vocation. If scruple eyther hath not beene conceiued, or else expelled vpon these later motiues, our actions are thereby iustifiable or excusable: but where strength of inordinate affection or desire • , either expelles or impaires a scruple (of some excessiue euill,) which hath beene conceiued (though amisse,) or hinders the conceiuing of some such doubt or scruple, in matters whose vnlawfulnesse might well be doubted of, or rather might clearely bee discerned, and ought with resolution to be auoyded: there the action is so much the more sinfull, as the scruple is lesse, or their confidence or boldnesse that vndertake it greater. The difference betwixt him that in this case doubteth, and him that doubteth not. is altogether such as Moralistes acknowledge betwixt the actions of intemperate and incontinent men.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Who most transgresse our Apostles former rule: with directions for squaring our actions vnto it or other rules of faith.
div.p: 1 FRom what hath beene said in this point we may safely gather, that none in our daies so much transgresse, as those that perswade themselues, they most precisely keepe this rule of our Apostle, which indeed was the rule of conscience, and of nature. They of all others transgresse it most, that make no scruple of denying obediēce, but confidently aduenture vpon any course of life, against their Pastors serious admonitions, for their spirituall good. For whosoeuer doth any thing for his owne priuate commoditie, or bodily good, which (though he doubt not) might vpon due examination, and attention to his Pastor, seeme doubtfull whether it may not endanger his soule, or impaire his spirituall estate, doth in so doing, sinne against his owne soule, and wound his conscience: because there is no proportion betweene the good which he seekes,Hoc itaque de vno sibi genere non edendo, vbi aleorum tanta copia subiacebat, tam leue praeceptum ad obseruandum, tam breue ad memoria retinendum, vbi praesertim nondum voluntati cupiditas resistebat quod de poena transgressionis postea subsccutum est, tanto maiore in • u • lit • a violatum • st, quanto faciliore possit obseruantia custodiri. Aug. 4. de Ciu. Dei lib. 41. cap. 12. and the euill which he might iustly feare. Such actions too well resemble our first parents sinne, who preferred the momentarie pleasures of their licorish tast, before the perpetuitie of their estate in Paradise, wherein did grow much better fruit than that they so greedily longed for. And we may as truly say, that our first parents were condemned for eating, as those that doubted of the lawfulnesse of what they eate. They did not eate of faith more than the others but lesse: although they were perswaded, that God rather had dealt hardly with them in forbidding them to eate, than that they should giue iust offence to God in eating. But the bolder they were, the greater was their sinne, and lesse of faith, nay most against faith: because their incontinent desires had expelled all feare, and made them co • fident.

2 The best methode to square our actions to the rule of faith, would be this. First, to be rightly instructed and perswaded in what order, or ranke of goodnesse, obedience to spirituall gouernours ought to be placed. Secondly, (hauing found out the true
nature and qualitie, and due estimation of obedience in generall,) to accou • t the degrees of goodnesse, which appeare in this or that particular act of obedience. And these are to be taken, according to the generalitie, or soueraigntie of the authoritie commanding, or according to the manner, and tenour of the command, or charge it selfe; as, those commands are to be obeyed with more alacritie, (although they proceed from the same, or equall authoritie,) in which obedience is demanded vpon stricter, or more adiuring termes, or wherein the zealous desires of men in authoritie are eyther more fully and significantly expressed to all, or more liuely intimated vnto vs in particular.

3 Thirdly, to calculate the inconuenience, or scandales that may arise from our disobedience. For albeit we might denie obedience in sundrie particulars, with farre safer consciences than others could, yea, although it were indifferent for vs (as perhaps in diuers cases it is to some men) to performe or denie obedience:This is a point, which I am perswaded, many haue lesse regarded than had been requisite, as not considering that our Apostles rule might be violated, as well by the omission of some actions as by the commission of others. or that the same offence might be giuen to weake and tender consciences, by emboldening them to denie obedience, as was giuen in our Apostles time, by emboldening them to eate of things suspected for vnlawfull Nor can we doubt but many in our time haue made scruple of matters inioyned by lawfull account, onely from the example of others whom they reuerenced. yet we should alwaies haue an especiall care, that we embolden not others, (who haue not the like motiues, or cannot be so well perswaded) to doe the like, by our example. For so we may commit the selfe same sinne, which they that were strong in faith did, by causing others to eate such meates, as they eyther made scruple of before they eate, or else were vpbraided by their consciences after they had eaten: And (as I intimated before) vnlesse disobedience be vpon euident, and well grounded resolutions, it is as dangerous a si • ne as a man can practise, and of all sinnes that are, it is most properly said to be 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 not of faith, seeing faith and obedience (amongst all other vertues,) are of most strict alliance. Neyther is there any breach or defect of faith, but in some disobedience or other; no sinne, but in disobedience to the rule of faith. Which l • ter (God willing) shall afterwards more plainely appeare.
4 Lastly, we are diligently to consider the hopes, or probabilities of goodnesse eyther inherent, or consequent to the actions themselues, which are to be vndertaken.

5 All these considerations must be put in opposite ballance to our doubts, or feares of euill, whether inherent or consequent to the same actions, or matters inioyned, if we were left to our owne choice; or to the probabilities, or iealousies, which we may haue,
that the forme of publike commaund is contrarie to Gods law. Although for doubts or scruples conceiued out of priuate dislike to the things inioyned, onely because we see no expresse warrant for them out of Scripture, or because they goe against our consciences: we need not so much to oppose former considerations, to ouersway thē, as seeke to extirpate thē. For after the interpositiō of authority, we may rather suspect that these doubts are not of faith, but of humour, vnlesse we can deriue them from some opposition, betwixt the publike edicts inioyning obedience, and the law of God, which must be presumed to countenance, as long as it doth not contradict, superiours actions, because it giues authoritie and commission to make them. Euery doubt, or scruple, that such edicts are formally or directly contrarie to Gods law, is not sufficient to denie obedience vnto them: nor doe spiritual Gouernours, in demanding obedience to such as their inferiours suspect to bee against Gods law, oppose humane authoritie to diuine, or desire men to obey them rather than God, as some friuolously haue obiected. Indeed the least probabilitie or suspition of disobeying God, should make vs refuse to obey man, in case our disobedience vnto man redounded onely to man, and not to God. But in as much as Christ hath said, He that heareth you, heareth mee, disobedience vnto spirituall gouernours is disobedience vnto Christ, yea vnto God. And therefore obedience may not be denied vnto such, but vpon great and waightie motiues, and serious examination of such reasons, as moue vs to thinke, that their edicts are contrarie, or opposite to Gods lawes. Otherwise we should preferre a coniecturall conceit, or surmise of obeying God rather than man, before a greater probabilitie of obeying God by obeying man. For it is certaine in general, that men in spirituall authoritie should be obeyed, and that in obeying them we obey God: but vncertaine and coniecturall, (according to our supposition) whether in this particular they should be disobeyed, and therefore vncertaine, whether God, by our deniall of obedience, should bee disobeyed or obeyed.

6By obeying humane authoritie deriued f • om diuine (in the generall) we may in some particulars inioyned by it, diso • ey diuine autho itie it selfe directly and immediately. Albeit I must confesse, there must a difference be put betwixt the immediate and direct disobeying of Gods expresse lawes, resulting from ob • dience vnto mans lawes that are opposite vnto them; and the disobeying of Gods lawes immediately or by consequence:
that is, by disobeying mens lawes, whose authoritie is deriued from them. As if a priuate man should obey a publike Magistrate commanding him, or his Pastor perswading him, vnder some faire pretence to tell a lie, or preiudice his neighbour by false reports, he doth immediately and directly disobey the ninth commandement by thus obeying man. And this sin may iustly seeme greater, than his that should denie obedience to publike authoritie in such matters, as are by it commend d vnto him for good, and as much tending vnto Gods glorie as the former did to his dishonour: but yet such as the partie denying obedience is not so perswad • d of, nor hath any such particular, expresse, or immediate law of God for doing this, as the other had for not doing the former. This later then disobeyes Gods law, which commaunds obedience to authoritie in lawfull matters; but not so directly, and immediatly as the former did the ninth commandement. Wherefore the former sins are worse in their kind; the worst of thē is worse than the worst of the later; the least of the former, worse than the least of the later kind:Hard to determine what degrees of feare, least we shou • d, by obeying mans lawes, disobey Gods lawes immediatly, ough • to expel all feare of disobeying mans lawes, whose authoritie in generall is from Gods. but in what degree or proportion they are worse is hard to define, & therefore a verie d • fficult point to determine, what degrees of probabilities, or what measure of feare, least they should disobey Gods lawes immediately, & directly, by obeying mans that seem opposit vnto them, should ouersway our generall certainty, that Gods deputies on earth are to be obeied, or our habitual inclination to Christiā obedience grounded hereon. Most certaine we are, that they must be obeyed in all lawfull cases, or where their lawes are not opposite vnto Gods: and if wee were certaine, that theirs were contrarie to Gods lawes, we are as certaine, by the doctrine of faith, that they should bee disobeyed. But when we doubt whether their degrees be against Gods lawes, we cannot but doubt, and doubting feare, least we should disobey God directly in obeying them. And by the former reasons, it is euident, that if the doubt were equall on both sides; that is, were it as probable that their cōmands are against Gods as not▪ we were bound in conscience not to obey thē; because we shold commit a greater sin in obeying them, if they were indeed opposite, than we should in disobeying them, supposing they were not opposite or contrarie to Gods lawes. For in the one case we should disobey Gods lawes directly and immediately: in the other only mediately,
and by consequence. Now of two euils equally probable, the lesse must be aduentured vpon, and the g • eater more eschewed.

7 YetSometimes by disobeying mens iniunctions we may disobey Gods lawes both mediately and immediately. oft-times againe it may fall out, that the things commaunded by publike authoritie, may bee in themselues verie good, and commaunded, at least in their vniuersall, by some particular Lawe of God. As if a spirituall Gouernour, should in the name of Christ commaund, or adiure a man (otherwise backward, and fearing the face of great men) to witnesse the truth for his poore neighbours good: If obedience in this case were denied, both Gods particular commaundement should bee immediately and directly transgressed, and that generall Lawe also bee transgressed by consequence, which commaundes obedience to Gods Ministers, or Embassadours. And it is all one, whether the matter inioyned be actually knowne for such as I haue said, vnto the partie denying obedience: or might haue beene knowne vpon due exmination, and supposall of his former obedience to his Pastor in other points. The further prosecution of these matters I leaue vnto the learned, th • t purposely write of iurisdiction; Whereof by Gods assistance, according to the talent which God hath giuen v • , in the Article of the Catholicke Church. It may suffice, for our present purpose, to haue shewed, that it is not euerie doubt, or scruple of the vnlawfulnesse of Superiours comma •• ds, that can warrant deniall of obedience to them: and that all inferiours are bound to a sober, diligent, and vnpartiall examination of their owne hearts, and consciences: to a resolute deniall, or abandoning of their owne affections, or desires, that they may be more fit to discerne the t • uth it selfe, & more sincerly waigh the consequence of their Superiours admonitions, before they can pleade the libertie of con • cience, for reiecting them, or appealing from them.

8 Whether any such opposition as I haue spoken of, can probably be found between any expresse law of God, & our Churches publike iniunctions of such rites and ceremonies, as many painefull labourers in Gods haruest haue made scruple of, or whether such scruples haue beene first conceiued vpon probable discouerie of such opposition, after such serious and due examination, I leaue it to their consciences that haue made,
or doe make them: beseeching God, for the good of his Church, and his glories sake, to inspire many of their harts but with this cogitation; Whether were more likely, That they themselues should commit any act of infidelitie or Poperie, by continuance in their pastorall charge, vpon such termes as many of their religious and learned brethren doe: or whether Atheisme and Infidelitie should increase abundantly throughout this land by their silence. Many of them I know haue held the things inioyned not absolutely euil, but suspicions, or occasions of euill. And could we in such cases vsually take but halfe that paines, in seeking to preuent the particular euils, which publike acts, (we feare) may occasion, as we doe in censuring them for inconsiderate, or occasions of euill, or finally, as we doe in breeding iealousies of their vnlawfulnesse: the euils which we feare, would not fall out halfe so fast, as by this meanes they doe; besides that the vnitie of faith should alwaies be faster kept, in the stricter bond of loue; and true obedience in things essentially good, and necessarie for the preseruation of Gods Church, would be more plentifull and cherefull.

9 But my purpose in this place was, onely to search out the limits of true obedience vnto spirituall authoritie in generall, so farre as it concernes the rectifying of their faith, or edification in manners,That the goodnesse of obedience, by our Apostles rule, (whatsoeuer is not of faith is sinne) ought to moue men vnto such conditional assent and obedience vnto their Pastors as hath beene mentioned. who are to be gouerned and instructed by it. None of them can iustly pretend, (ordinarily) any scruple of such consequence as inferiour Ministers may. If they could but duly consider, and vnpartially esteeme the goodnesse which accompanies obedience (which is better than sacrifice,) & the euill of disobedience, (which is as the sinne of witchcraft) these two laid together would be more then equiualent to any euill that lay-men, or inferiours, vsually conceiue in such actions, as they denie obedience in vnto their Pastors. Nay in this vnbeleeuing age, wherein it is more to be complementall than religious, it is thought an answere good enough, so it be complementally performed vnto their Pastors: We will doe as you aduise, or inioyne vs, in Christs name, if we certainly knew that it were Christs will, or agreeable to Gods word. Whereas in truth, in giuing such answeres, when neither they certainely know, nor are carefull to learne, whether their aduise be contrarie to Gods word or no, they sinne directly against Christian faith, aduancing their owne humors aboue Gods
word, which commands obedience vnto Pastors, preferring the liberty of their vnruly willes before the safetie of their consciences. And it is preposterous to plead ignorance of Gods wil before thē, whose instructions therein they are bound duly to heare, and hearing to obey, vntill they can light on better, or finde them false, vpon serious and due examination: that is, They must obey them not absolutely and irreuocably, but wi • h limitation and caution. And questionlesse if men did infallibly beleeue, or absolutely from their hearts obey, that which they vndoubtedly know to be Gods will: they would neuer make question, but that, for which they haue presumptions that it is part of Gods will, or that, which is commended vnto them for his will, by such as he hath appointed to be messengers of the same, should be conditionally beleeued, and with caution obeyed, especially when it is deliuered solemnly vpon deliberation, & premeditatiō or out of that place whence he hath appointed thē to learne his wil. Did not Priests (as the Prouerb is) forget that euer they were Clearkes, or such as take themselues for great proficients, that they were sometimes Nouices in the schole of Christ: they might remember how they came vnto that absolute and infallible beliefe of those Christian principles, by which they hope for saluation, by entertaining this conditional beliefe, which we speake of, and by yeelding like obedience vnto diuine truthes, now fully, but at the first imperfectly, knowne for such. And albeit such generall articles of Christian faith, as are necessarie for all to beleeue, neither increase, nor diminish their number: yet if we descend vnto the diuersitie of mens estates and callings, and difference of time and place: Christian faith receiueth perpetuall increase, not onely in it proper strength, or as we say by way of intention, but in extent also vnto many particulars, eyther directly contained (though not so easie to be discerned) as essentiall parts vnder the former generall principles, or else annexed vnto them collaterally as limmes or borders. Besides, all Christian duties, or matters of practise, are not promiscuously fit for euery time or place, but must be seuerally proportioned to their diuersitie. Againe, the same duties, (I meane of the same kinde) must be performed in different measure, according to the different exigence of time, place, persons, or other occurrents. In all these and many more respects is this conditionall assent, and obedience vnto Pastors
most necessarie. And ere men can retaine stedfastly that which is best, they must make triall of all, or many things of different kinds: and yet triall of spirituall medicines without spirituall Physitiōs prescripts, is so much more dangerous to ordinary mens soules, than like triall of Phisicke-conclusions is to their bodies, by how much such men are more ignorant of the state of their soules, than of their bodies. The necessitie and vse of what hath beene deliuered concerning obedience in generall, will appeare in sundrie points to be discust hereafter. In respect of which (especially of that point concerning the manner, how wee may know the sense of Scriptures, and that concerning the nature of Christian faith,) some further vnfolding of this conditionall assent and obedience will be likewise necessarie.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of the nature, vse, conditions, or Properties of conditionall assent or obedience.
div.p:
1 THE first step in the way to life, is from this infallible ground of nature; Whatsoeuer God hath reuealed concerning matters of mans saluation, is most true, and by all meanes to be obeyed. This Principle all men absolutely capable of reason, acknowledging a God, doe beleeue: and from their absolute beliefe hereof they yeeeld a conditionall obedience, and reuerence vnto those bookes which we call Scripture. From the triall of whose truth, we rise a steppe or degree higher, and vndoubtedly acknowledge certaine generall Principles contained in Scripture, (without whose beliefe no man ordinarily can be saued) for the Oracles of God, or diuine Reuelations: and vnto them we yeeld absolute obedience. This second steppe brings men within the listes, or borders of Christianitie, where no Christian man is to set vp his rest. Euen the meanest that beares that name, once come to yeares of discretion, or capable of instruction, must hold on his progresse still, thus resoluing with himselfe: Though I must be as a child for innocencie,
yet not in knowledge of Gods will. A shame it were I should alwaies be a babe in that profession, which of all is onely necessarie; a shame I should accustome my selfe to milke, for this were to nourish vnexpert babishnesse in the word of righteousnesse. A Christian I was from my cradle, and now as old a Christian as a man: butHeb. chap. 4, vers. 13. strong meate is fit for them that are of age which haue (or should haue) their wits exercised through long custome, to discerne good from euill: Phil. 3. v. 10.14.15. Let therefore as many as be perfect (or would be) be thus minded. not the fundamentall principles of Christian religion onely, without which none can be saued: not he that hath professed Christianitie but an houre, These are grounds which once surely laid, must (as the Apostle speaketh) be Heb. 6. v. 1.2. left that we may be led on to perfection, not alwaies hammering vpon the foundation of repentance from dead workes, of faith towards God, or of Baptisme, of laying on of hands, of the resurrection from the dead, and of eternall iudgement, but seeking to build vpon these, whatsoeuer is befitting present times or seasons, whatsoeuer may make our election sure. And they, who laid the former foundations in my heart, seeke yet my farther edification in many points, of whose truth my consciēce as yet hath no such firme perswasion or liuely taste, as it now hath of the former: but is so affected towards these later, as it was to the other before better acquaintance with them Should I for this reason, forthwith denie obedience to my instructors? or withdraw assent from matters proposed by them? God forbid: For he hath commanded all, not excepting me, to obey their ouerseers in the Lord. Must we obey them whilest they plant, and may we disobey them whilst they water? how then can I expect, that God should giue increase vnto that faith which they haue planted in my heart? heretofore I trusted them, and I found their sayings true, euen the Oracles of the liuing God: all which I so esteeme, as I had rather abiure this present world than vtterly disclaime any, which vpon like triall, might proue such. What if I know not this particular to be such? I may in good time, be as well perswaded of it, as of the former; if so I will vouchsafe to make like triall of it, by sincere religious obedience.

2 Nor doth the greater stedfastnesse, or infallibilitie of the point beleeued necessarily, exact either obedience of an higher nature, or more intention, or alacritie in the act, than may without offence
be performed, vnto some other points of doctrine lesse infallible, or lesse euident to their consciences, who must obey. Infallibilitie of it selfe exactes only a more full and absolute title ouer our obedience, than probabilities or presumptions can expect. For that which is infallible, and absolutely beleeued for a diuine truth, exacts such obedience, (both for qualitie and degree,) as is conformable to the nature of the thing proposed, without all limitation, condition, or reseruation: that is, perpetuall and absolute allegeance. That which is but probably, or conditionally assented vnto as diuine truth, (Whatsoeuer the nature of the thing propoposed, the end or consequence pretended, or exigences of other circumstances be,) can exact onely conditionall, or cautionarie obedience: yet obedience, for the qualitie, sutable to the nature of the thing proposed, and for the alacritie, or intention of the act, proportionable to the end or consequence pretended, and auouched by Gods Embassadors. So that if they commend it vnto vs, as fit to be entertained in some higher rancke of goodnesse, or as most necessarie for the present time, albeit we our selues doe not apprehend the same as expresly commaunded by God: yet may we performe obedience, both as sincere for the qualitie, and entire for degree, as we doe vnto some other things, which we stedfastly beleeue to be commanded in Gods word. But wee must not tender our obedience vnder the same stile or title. Absolute obedience, of what kinde soeuer, we may not yeeld vnto it, vntill it be absolutely knowne for Gods will. When it is once knowne for such, we must absolutely yeeld vp the same obedience, which before was but conditionally yeelded: as a man may pay the same summe vpon caution, before hee be throughly perswaded of the demaunders right vnto it, which after his right be fully knowne, he paies absolutely. In this case these foure things must be considered.

Foure points to be considered for the rectifying or right framing of our assent vnto truthes proposed.3 First, the assurance or probabilitie which we can haue, that the thing proposed is Gods word. Which sometimes may bee grounded vpon reasons, (eyther communicate vnto vs by our Pastor or others, or conceiued by our selues,) as well as vpon authoritie: sometimes all the assurance, which men of lesse capacitie can haue, is only from the Pastors authoritie. Secondly, the title, or pretended nature of the truth proposed. Thirdly, the act or qualitie
of obedience. Fourthly, the manner or limitatiō of our obedience.

4 The act or qualitie of our obedience, (so we be more probably perswaded that it is Gods word, than otherwise, or know nothing to the contrarie) must be proportioned to the title, or nature of the thing proposed, which is commended vnto vs as a spirituall good. So that our obedience must be religious and spirituall, not meerely ciuil: although our best motiue, why we hold it to be a diuine Oracle, or spirituall good, be the authoritie of our teacher, which is but humaine; but now he exacts not obedience to his owne authoritie, but vnto Gods word, (as he affirmes:) which because we know is diuine, therefore we must yeeld religious, obedience to it; and therefore religious, albeit conditionall obedience vnto this precept, which we probably know to be diuine, and assent vnto conditionally as such. The act of our obedience in this particular, must proceed from the same habite, from which our actes of obedience vnto such truthes, as we infallibly beleeue for diuine, doe: for euen this verie act, is performed primarily and absolutely to Gods word in generall, vnto which we owe religious and spirituall obedience: and vnto this particular (inioyned by our Pastor) onely secondarily, and vpon supposition that it is part of Gods word. So as if the particular by him inioyned, should in the euent proue no part of Gods word: yet obeying it onely vpon the former motiues, it might be truly said, we had obeyed Gods word, not it; as he that shewes kindnesse to a stranger, vpon presumption that he is a brother or alliance of his deare and familiar friend, albeit he were mistaken herein, may be said to haue done a friendly office rather to his knowne acquaintance, for whose sake he vsed the stranger kindly, than vnto the stranger himselfe thus kindly vsed vpon a mistake. But albeit the qualitie be such, as Gods word absolutely knowne requires: yet the manner of our obedience must be limited by the degrees of probabilitie, or morall certaintie, which we haue of this particular, that it is Gods Oracle. Where the probabilities are lesse, and the inducements for beliefe of this particular weaker, there the condition of our assent, and reseruation of our obedience must bee more expresse: that is, we must stand further off from yeelding absolute, and be more inclined to renounce this present conditioniall obedience (which we yet performe,) vpon lesser motiues
to the contrarie, then we would, if our probabilities for beleeuing it were greater. Where the probabilities, or inducements for beleefe of this particular, are greater and stronger, there wee must the more incline vnto absolute and irreuocable obedience, or assent vnto the same particular: and be more vnreadie, or vnwilling to recall our assent, or renounce our obedience, but vpon greater and more euident reasons. Onely there we are to fixe our beliefe absolutely; onely there we may safely, vndoubtedly, and fully passe ouer our full and absolute obedience vnto it, without all condition, limitation of time, or reseruation: when the truth of it shall be as fully confirmed, and manifested to our consciences, as the others are, vnto which we haue formerly yeelded absolute obedience, without appeale or reseruation: or when wee can as clearely discerne, and as stedfastly beleeue, the consonancie of this particular with the formers, as wee can the formers with Gods word.

5 And whereas we said before, that the onely motiues which some men haue to beleeue the sense and meaning of sundrie doctrines, (necessarie perhaps vnto them in particular at some seasons, when God shall call them to some extraordinarie point of obedience) might be the authoritie of their teachers: this authothoritie may bee greater or lesse, according to the qualitie of the Minister or spirituall Gouernour. As the world goes now a daies, this function is committed to some, in whose mouth the word of God, or any good doctrine, may rather seeme to lose its vertue and power, than his any way binde men to obedience, vnlesse besides his commendation of what hee proposeth, they haue other motiues to perswade them, that it is Gods word, or wholesome doctrine. If the minister, who should carrie Gods message, be such a one as Sir Thomas Moore iested vpon, That he would not for any good heare him say the Creed, lest he should take it for a lie comming out of his mouth: It is doubtfull what the people should do in such a case, albeit he exact obedience vpon their vow in Baptisme, if they haue no other motiue but his authoritie. Yet for all this, it is not best to be too bold in contemning his admonitions, or adiurations, vnlesse they be apparantly false. In this case others more sincere and skilfull, or such as haue authoritie to examine his doctrine, should be consulted, his may not be neglected in all
particulars, vpon a generall preiudice of his lewdnesse or simplicitie. For though his life be bad, yet may his meditations for that present, wherein he publikely speakes, be good and fruitfull vnto them, so they will yeeld due obedience to his doctrine. And although a man should know a Constable, or some greater Officer, that pretends commission from the King, to be a notorious lying knaue, or treacherous companion: yet were it not the safest way to tell him he lied, when he charged him to obey him in the Kings name, nor to make a scoffe of his authoritie, or replie he would not beleeue he had any, because he might abuse himselfe, and it at other times: If so he doe at this time, he may answere it before his betters hereafter: but in the meane while, it were best for the partie commanded to obey him, vntill he be certaine, that he did eyther faine authoritie, where he had none, or else abuse it in this particular. He that should yeeld obedience, being thus (perhaps wrongfully) charged in the Kings name, (so hee yeeld it for this reason, & vpon this condition:) shal not be thought guiltie of disloyaltie, albeit he be hereby brought to commit some fact, distastefull to his Maiestie, or publike peace. For the fault in this case, must be returned vpon the Author: if so the partie obeying did not know it to bee simply vnlawful, and against the Kings peace, or had no opportunity of consulting other publike Officers, but hath beene abused, by the craft and cunning of the other, who hath concealed his end, intention, or other circumstance which made the fact vnlawfull. It is enough to disclaime his former obedience when he knowes the truth. And if Officers should not be obeyed in the Kings name, vntill men sought the truth, whether they had a lawfull commission, or but a counterfait, or whether they did not goe beyond their commission: the Kings Maiestie should want a great deale of necessarie seruice, and the Common-weale bee at an ill passe for continuance of publike peace. Did most men feare God, as much as men, or the sonne of man, the Iudge of quicke and dead, as much as earthly Iudges: they would not so often withdraw their necke from the yoake of Christian obedience, (being charged to vndertake it in Christs name, and as they would answere it at that dreadfull day,) vpon such sillie exceptions against the meanenesse, basenesse, or lewdnesse of the Ministers person. Bee hee as they list to make
him for his life, it hath pleased God to make him his messenger, his officer to demaund obedience of them. And shall it serue their turne to say, we will not beleeue that God sent him with this message, or sure he goes beyond his commission: when they know nothing to the contrarie; but onely will take occasion from his person, to discredite his doctrine, if it controll them in the pursuit of worldly affaires? And God knowes for whose sake it is: wee all may feare, it is especially for the infidelity & disloialty of this people towards him, & their disobedience to his messengers, that he sends them such idle, foolish, or lewd Pastors, as they haue in many places. Because the Laitie of this land are so prone and headstrong to cast off Christes yoake, and to denie due obedience to his faithfull Ministers: he therefore sets such watchmen ouer them in many places, as they shall haue no lust to obey in any thing that they shall propose vnto them, but harden their hearts in infidelitie and disobedience. Albeit I should prosecute this point a great deale further, I should not much digresse from my maine purpose and drift, which God he knowes is no other, but to bring home sillie soules from yeelding this blinde obedience to the Romaine forraine yoke. For the diuerting of which from this lands & peoples neckes, I know no better meanes, than to take vp Christs yoake vpon vs. For questionlesse, this open malapert scoffing disobedience to all Ecclesiasticke power now openly professed by the meanest, and countenanced by many great ones of the Laitie, is the sinne, which to all that know Gods iudgements, or haue beene obseruant to looke into the daies of our visitation, cries lowdest in the Almghties eares, (more lowd by much than Fryars, Monkes, and Iesuites prayers doe,) for Gods vengeance vpon this land: for vengeance to be executed by no other than our sworne, inueterate, malitious enemies; by no other grieuances, than by the doubled grieuances of the long enraged Romanistes iron-yoake, which is now prepared for vs ten times more heauie and irksome, than was that which our forefathers haue borne. It were hard to determine, whether Atheisme & Infidelitie amongst professed Prorestants, or superstition and Idolatrie amongst the Papists, haue more increased throughout this land in later yeares: or, whether the Romish Priests and Iesuites haue beene mo • e industrious, and earnest to sow the seeds of the one, than sundrie
which oppose themselues most eagerly against them, haue been to foster and cherish the other: both perhaps (vnto their seeming) for a good intent: neither intending either mischief expresly & directly: For so the reluctation of conscience would haue abated their indeuours: nor could Idolatrie, or Infidelitie haue growene so fast, had their fosterfathers seene them in their proper shape. But both haue masked in sheeps clothing, both had their faces couered with zeale.

6 Sure, if there be degrees of malignancie in hellish Ghostes, the most potent factions of most malignant spirits, throughout the infernall Anarchie, the one vpon emulation of the others might or abilities in doing euill, striue for glorie by doing greatest mischiefe in this land. The one part hath made choice of their fairest meanes, by solliciting, partly desperate discontents, partly, sillie soules (vnder pretence of ancient Catholike Religion) to superstition, and Idolatrie: the other, by driuing proud and disobedient mindes, vpon their deadly dislike of popish tyrannie, to cast off the yoake of Christian obedience, and vnder pretence of Christian libertie, to rush headlong into hypocrisie, Atheisme, or Infidelitie. For euen where the best and most industrious Ministers are, throughout this land, how scarce is this Christian obedience to bee found? Let the Pastors skill and sinceritie bee neuer so great, let him tell his flock, for whose soules he must answer, that they must doe thus and thus, if they will be saued: they can be diligent perhaps to heare him, and say he spake exceeding well. [1] Verie ill of others (as they coniecture) but not of them or their adherents: If for his good lessons in the Pulpit he haue good words returned at table, he seeth the best fruits of his labour. For if one of his flock shall haue an aduantage against his neighbour, or haue picked a quarrell with his Lease; or let a Gentleman bee disposed to put off his tenants, or inhance their rents to their vtter vndoing, let any, gentle or meane, haue but good hope to make his owne great gaine by some others losse: Heere if we trie him, and charge him vpon his allegiance vnto Christ to remit his hold, to let go all aduantage, and be good vnto his fellow-seruant, or poore brother, these are matters the Minister must meddle no more with than another man, the law can determine whether he he doe right, or wrong, and this case belongs properly vnto the Lawyer. As if the power of Gods Spirit, or authoritie of his Misters
did consist onely in words, and required no other obedience, than a formall speculatiue assent vnto their generall doctrine, not a full resignation of mens willes, or heartie submission of affections, vnto such rules as they shal prescribe, for the preseruation of a good and vpright conscience in particular actions, or entercourse of humane affaires. Or if one of a thousand will be so good as to grant that he is to obey the precepts of Christ, before the customes of our common law, or other ciuill courts: yet euen the best of such, when it comes to points of priuate commoditie, will dispense with his Pastor, and replie: I would doe as you admonish me, if I saw any expresse commaund for it in Gods word, or any euidēt necessity that should bind me to renounce that right which law doth giue me: but for ought I can perceiue, I may prosecute my right in this present case, with a safe conscience, and you doe not know all particular circumstances, which belong vnto this matter; if you did, or were in my case, I am perswaded you would be of my mind. This although it be the only shelter, vnder which the infidelitie of later ages takes its rest, the onely dorture wherein hypocrisie sleepes profoundly, & neuer dreames of further danger: yet is it a most sillie excuse, and shamelesse Apologie, in the iudgement of any that knowes, or knowing rightly esteemes, the principles of Christianitie. For, suppose thou see no euidence, that Christ hath commanded thee to confesse his name in this particular, doth the law lay any necessitie vpon thee, to make thee prosecute thy supposed right? If it did charge thee vpon paine of death so to doe, thou hast some pretence to obey it; albeit thou shouldest feare him more, that could condemne thee, and the interpreters of it, to euerlasting death: but the law doth leaue it to thy choise, whether thou wilt vse the benefit of it, or no: and thy Pastour vpon penaltie of incurring Christs displeasure, commaunds thee, that thou vse it not. Thou repliest, thou seest no euidence that Christ commands thee. But doest thou absolutely and infallibly know, that he doth not call thee at this time, to trie thine obedience in this particular? If thou canst out of sinceritie of heart, and euidence of truth, fully informe thy conscience in this negatiue (so the end of thy proceedings be good,) thou maist be the bolder to disclaime thy Pastors summons. If thou canst not, how wilt thou answere thy Iudge, when thou shalt appeare before him, why
thou out of the stubbornesse of thy heart, didst more respect thy priuate gaine, than his heauiest displeasure? For suppose thy hope of gaine were great, (as it is vsually to such as thou art more great than certaine) yet cannot the greatnesse, and certaintie of it, counteruaile the least danger of incurring his wrath, nor could the certaintie of worldly gaine coūterpoise, much lesse ouersway, the least surmise or probabilitie of incurring thy soules destruction, vnlesse thy minde had beene set more on gold, than vpon thy God, more inclined to priuate commoditie and selfe-loue, than vnto Christ thy Redeemer. Or shall thy answere stand for good in his sight, when thou shalt say vnto his messenger: It is more then I know, that Christ commands mee? Then should the damned be iustified at the day of iudgement, when they shall truly replie, they knew not that euer Christ did supplicate vnto them sub forma pauperis? Most of them we may safely sweare, had lesse probabilities to beleeue this in their life time, than thou hast now to perswade thee of this particular: although thy Pastors authoritie, and frequent admonitions were set aside; which make thee so much the more inexcusable. For thou mightest haue knowne by him, that God had commanded thee as much, vnlesse thy bad desires had made thee blinde. But neither shal theirs, or thy ignorance herein helpe. For ignorance which is bred of bad desires, corrupt affections, or greedy appetites, brings forth hardnesse of heart, & infidelitie: so that seeing thou shalt not see, & hearing thou shalt not heare, nor vnderstand the warnings for thy peace; because thou hast formerly shut thine eares at thy Pastors admonitions, or raged at his iust reproofe. And the law of God binds thy soule, vpon greater penaltie, & better hopes, than all lawes in the world besides could binde thy bodie, euen vpon hope of euerlasting life, and penaltie of euerlasting death, to lay aside all selfe-loue, all worldly desire, for the finding out of the true sense and meaning of it, as well as to obey it, when thou knowest it. And when any point of doctrine or practise, either in generall or particular, is commended to thee by thy Pastor, Gods word doth binde thee to search, with all sobrietie and modestie, the truth and force of all motiues, inducements, or probabilities which he shall suggest vnto thee; all priuate respect laid aside, least thou become a partiall Iudge of euill thoughts: and if thou
canst not finde better resolution, it bindes thee to relie vpon his authoritie. And euen in this againe, Gods word (so perfect a rule is it) doth rule thy thoughts, to discerne the fidelitie, sinceritie, or authoritie of thy teacher.

Vnto such as approue themselues, as Saint Paul did2. Cor. 4. v. 2. to euery mans conscience in the sight of God, or to such as make not a marchandize of the word of God, but speake in Christ as of sinceritie, and as of God in the sight of God: 2. Cor. 2. v. 17 Christian people are bound to yeeld greater obedience. Generally, vnto such as, in their liues, expresse those characterrs of faithfull dispensers, set downe by Saint Paul, and other Pen-men of Gods word, euery Auditor is bound to yeeld greater obedience, than vnto others, in points wherein he hath no other motiues to beleeue, beside his Pastors authoritie. For this is a dictate of common reason, and cannot but commaund the assent of euerie sanctified mind; That such men are most likely to haue the meaning of Gods Spirit, which walke according to Gods Spirit, and seeke not their owne gaine, glorie, or pleasure, but Christs glory, his will, and peoples good: and such againe are most likely to vse greatest sinceritie in deliuering the truth, which they know, without partialitie or respect of persons. Againe, men are bound (caeteris paribus) to beleeue them best, and obey them most, of whose skill, and sinceritie in dispensing the mysteries of faith, they haue had most comfortable, and spirituall experience. For the article of Gods prouidence binds vs hereto, and willes vs to reuerence our fathers in Christ, eyther such as (by his word) first begot faith, or nourished it in vs, more than others.

Thus much concerning this point, I haue thought good to insert in this place, because the true and sincere practise of obedidience, according to that measure of truth, or beliefe which men haue, though but imperfect, is the excellentest meanes, for attaining the cleare sight of diuine truth, and that perfect measure of sanctifying beliefe, which in this life can bee looked for, as shall (God willing) afterwards appeare.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Wherein this conditionall beliefe differeth from the Romanes implicite faith. That the one is the other, not subordinate to Gods word, or Rule of faith.
div.p:
1 AS this opinion of conditionall assent vnto diuine truthes, not absolutely knowne for such, holdes the meane betwixt the two extreames, or contrarie errours aboue mentioned: So is this conditionall assent it selfe a meane, betwixt that absolute beleefe, which all acknowledge to be necessary in some principall points of Christian faith, and that implicite beliefe, which the Romish Church exactes in all points whatsoeuer. Our assent vnto many articles of faith, is actually,What implicite faith is. and expresly absolute. The implicite beliefe of the Romanists is but potentially, or rather vertually, and implicitely absolute: This conditionall beliefe, hitherto mentioned, not so much as potentially, much lesse implicitely, or virtually absolute. That properly is beleeued by an implicite faith, which is not actually, and expresly assented vnto in the particular: but yet is so essentially and immediately contained in some generall article, or point of faith absolutely or expresly beleeued, that this particular likewise is assented vnto in grosse, whilest we assent to it, and may be as absolutely as expresly, and distinctly assented vnto, as the generall, when it is once explicated and vnfolded. In this sense we say, the conclusion is implicitely contained in the premisses, the corallarie in the Thaeoreme, or the immediate consequent in his necessarie antecedent. For he that grants one of these absolutely, must vpon the same termes grant the other, at the first proposall of it vnto him. But this conditionall, or reseruatiue beliefe may be of such points, as are not certainly, & infallibly cōtained in any principle of faith, absolutely, expresly, actually, or infallibly acknowledged; much lesse so essentially, and immediately contained in any, that a man cannot absolutely grant it, but he must absolutely beleeue them. And albeit oft-times, they may be infallibly deduced from known vndoubted principles of faith, yet is not the deduction so immemediate,
as can be made cleare, and euident to all capacities, at least not at the first sight, without any further increase of knowledge in spirituall matters. And before the deduction be made as euident, and apprehended as infallible, as are the generall articles whence they are deduced, the particulars deduced from them may not be so infallibly and absolutely beleeued, as the generals are. The Papists, besides their explicite beleefe of some few maine points, demaund an implicite beliefe of as many particulars as the Church shall propose: so as whatsoeuer the Church shall propose, with them once proposed, admits no cōditional beliefe: all must be absolute, albeit the parties beleeuing cannot discerne any necessarie, or probable deduction of the particulars, from generall points absolutely & expresly beleeued. It is enough that they know them to be proposed by the Church. For once beleeuing, Whatsoeuer the Church saith is most infallible, (which is the maine article of Romane faith,) no man can denie any particular proposed by it to bee infallible, more than he can denie the conclusion for certaine, after he hath granted the premisses for such. Consequently to these positions, they make the visible Church the rule andA speech well beseeming the seruants of the great whore. mistresse of mens faith, as they speake. For albeit a man at this present thinke otherwise of many points of greatest moment, than the Church or Pope doth, or though he thinke not at all of many things, which they in time may propose vnto him: yet after they haue proposed, either a contrary opinion to that which his conscience tels him is Gods word, or a new & strange position, which he neuer thought of, he must without more adoe, beleeue both absolutely and expresly, and so finally, retract, extend, enlarge, a bridge direct and frame his faith, according to that rule or standard, which they shall set him.That the faith of moderne Papists cannot be resolued into the Scriptures or the first truth. Hence (God willing) shall appeare the madnesse of some great schollers among them, who holding the Church to be such a rule of faith, would perswade vs, (if we would be so simple,) that their last resolution of faith is, not into the Churches authoritie, but into the Scripture. For nothing can be resolued beyond it rule, & to make the Churches authoritie such an absolute, authenticke, vnquestionable rule of faith, as the Papists do, and withall to seeke the resolution of any point of faith further then it, or to deriue it from Scripture, doth argue such a medley of folly and impietie, as if some gullish Gentleman, desirous
to proue the antiquitie of his house, should draw his pedigree from Adams great grandfather, and yet hold the records of Moses for most vndoubted and true, which affirme Adam to haue beene the first progenitour of all mankinde. Whether they seeke to resolue their faith into the Scriptures acknowledged by vs and them, or into other vnwrittē reuelatiōs, pretended for diuine truthes, their folly will still appeare the same, so long as they hold that impious and blasphemous opinion, making the Churches authoritie such a rule of faith, as hath beene said. Their iniuries and contumelies vnto Gods written Oracles (as hath heretofore been intimated) are especially two. First, they denie them to be any entire rule, for the number of precepts. Secondly, they make those verie precepts, which are acknowledged for diuine, insufficient for the establishment of true faith vnto themselues, without the Churches authoritie. We acknowledge them, euery way sufficient for the edification of Christs Church in faith and maners: and consequently both to our positions, & the truth, we teach, that all matters of faith, must be finally resolued into these diuine written verities, which for this reason we acknowledge the only infallible rule of faith: The meaning of which assertion is here to be further explicated, that so the truth may be maintained against their obiections.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
In what sense we hold the Scriptures to be the rule of faith.
div.p:
1 WHen we affirme, that the Scriptures are the only infallible rule in matters of faith and Christian obedience, we vnderstand such a rule in those matters, as Aristotles Organon may be said of Logick: supposing it were sound, & free from all suspicion of error in euery point, and contained in it all the generall & vndoubted principles, from which all true forme of argumentation must be deduced, and into which all must be finally resolued. To illustrate this truth, by a known practise. Our yonger students are bound to yeeld their absolute assent vnto Aristotles authoritie, in matters of Logicke: but not vnto any interpreter, that shall pretend it, saue onely when he shall make euident vnto them, that this was Aristotles
meaning. And while they so onely, and no otherwise yeeld their assent, they yeeld it wholy and immediately vnto Aristotle, not to the interpreter, although by his meanes they came to know Aristotles meaning; which once knowne, without any further confirmation of other testimonie or authoritie, commands their obedience and assent. But ere they can fully assent vnto this great Master, or throughly perceiue his meaning, they must conditionally assent vnto their priuate Tutors, or other expositors, and take his sense and meaning vpon their trust, and credite. In like manner (say we) in all matters, doctrines, or controuersies of faith, and Christian obedience, we are bound to yeeld our assent, directly, absolutely, and finally vnto the authoritie of Scriptures onely: not vnto any Doctor, Expositor, or other whosoeuer he be, that shall pretend authoritie out of Scripture ouer our faith, saue onely when he shall make it cleare, and euident vnto vs, that his opinion is the true meaning of the Scripture. And thus yeelding our absolute assent vnto the truth explained by him, wee yeeld it not to him, but vnto the Author of truth, whose words we hold to bee infallible in whose mouthes soeuer; and once knowne to be his words, they neede not the testimonie or authoritie of him, that did bring vs to the true knowledge of them. And before wee be brought to see their truth with our owne eyes, and feele it by our sense, (by the effects or experiments of it vpon our owne soules,) we are to limite our assent and obedience, (as it is set downe before) according to the probabilities, or vnpartiall inducements, which we haue of the Expositors skill, and sinceritie, in dispensing diuine mysteries. And these motiues or inducements, which we haue of his skill and sinceritie, must be framed according to the rules or precepts of Scripture, not according to our affections, or humours: we may not thinke him most to be belieued, that is in highest place, or hath the greatest stroke in other affaires. For as the faith of Christ, so must our perswasion of the faithfull dispensers, or skilfull seedes-men of faith, bee had without respect of persons.

2 If we yeeld assent or obedience vnto any Expositor, or other, otherwise than vpon these conditions and limitations, then, as we said before, whilst wee yeelded absolute obedience vnto his doctrine that perswaded vs to true beliefe, because wee perceiued
that which he spake to be the word of God, we did not yeeld it vnto him, but vnto Gods word, deliuered and made knowne vnto vs by him: so heere againe by the same reason (onely inuerted) it will euidently follow, that if we beleeue any mans doctrines or decisions, to be the word of God, because he speakes it, or because we hold his words to be infallible, we doe not truly and properly beleeue the word of God, (suppose his doctrine were the word of God,) but his words and infallibilitie onely. Hence againe it followes, that if we yeeld the same absolute and vndoubted assent vnto his authoritie, which we would doe vnto Gods word immediately knowne in it selfe, and for it selfe; or relie vpon his infallibilitie in expounding Gods word, as fully as he doth vpon the word, (which it is supposed he knowes immediately in it selfe, and for it selfe:) by doing thus we rob God of his honour, giuing that vnto man, which is only due to him. For the infallibility of this teacher hath the same proportion to all that thus absolutely beleeue him, as the infallibilitie of the Godhead hath vnto him; his words the same proportion, to all other mens faith, that Gods word hath vnto his. Gods word is the rule of his, and his words must bee the rule of all other mens faith. Or, to speake more properly, God must bee a God onely to him, and he a God to all other men.

3 Heere it will be demaunded, how men, altogether illiterate, can examine any doctrine by Scriptures?In what sense the Scriptures may be said the rule of mens faith altogether illiterate. If they cannot read them, how shall they examine any thing by them? not examining the points of faith by them, how can they be said to be the rule of your faith? In such a sense as Aristotles workes (supposing them only authentick, & all his opposites counterfaits or new-fangles) may be said to be the rule of blind-mens Logicke; for albeit they cannot read his works, yet are they capable of his generall and vndoubted rules, seeing they haue (as well as other men) a naturall facultie of discerning truth from falshood, and can distinguish betwixt rules deriued from the pure fountaine of truth in that kinde, and precepts drawne from coniecturall, erroneous, and corrupt surmises of shallow braines; if both be distinctly proposed vnto them. And the rules of truth once fully apprehended and embraced, serue as a touchstone to discerne all consequences and conclusions, which shall be suggested vnto them by others:
so as they wil admit of nothing for sound & true Logick, but what may be resolued into the former, or some other principles, which they can perspicuously and immediately discerne, to haue beene drawne from the fountaine of truth, by the same naturall facultie or abilitie, by which they did discerne the former: for the facultie will still be like affected with all principles, of like nature, vse and perspicuitie. In like sort must the first and generall principles of faith be deriued from Scriptures, (the onely pure fountaine of supernatural truthes) vnto all illiterate hearts, by the ministerie of the learned. For hearts, though illiterate, once illuminated by Gods Spirit, are as apt to discerne spirituall principles, from falshood or carnal cōiectures, as the naturall man is to discerne natural truths, from errours of the same kinde. And these generall and fundamentall principles of faith, engrafted in their hearts, serue as infallible rules, for discerning the consonancy or dissonancie of such particulars, as shall be suggested vnto them; as shall (God willing) hereafter be declared: nor may they without iniurie to Gods Spirit or inward grace, admit any other precepts into the same ranke or societie with these, but eyther vpon euident and distinct deduction from them, or sure experiments of their like spirituall fruite and vse, for the amendment of life, and procuring that peace of conscience, which no naturall man can conceiue, much lesse can it be caused by meere naturall precepts. For wee suppose (what afterwards will manifest it selfe) that all truthes necessarie for men to beleeue, haue a distinct relish from all falshood, or other vnnecessarie or superfluous truthes: and may be knowne by their fruit, so men will be carefull to preserue the sinceritie of their spirituall taste.

4 Gods written word then, is the onely pure fountaine and rule of faith: yet not such immediately vnto all as it is written, but the learned,Quâ scriptum. or spirituall instructors, onely, whose hearts and consciences must be ruled by it, as in all other spirituall duties, so especially (as they are instructors) in this; That they may not commend any truthes, or principles of faith, vnto the illiterate, but such as are expresly contained in Gods written word, or (at least) are in substance the selfe same with these written truthes. If the vnlearned, through Gods iust iudgement, absolutely admit of other principles, and equalize them with these: such shall lead them into
errour, and peruert their faith. If they doubt of any mans doctrine, whether it be truly spirituall, or consonant to the foundation of faith, they may appeale to Scriptures, as they shall be expounded o them by others. Finally, they are tied to no visible companie of men, whom they must vnder paine of damnation follow: but for their soules health, they may trie euery spirituall Physition. If they will be humorous, they may, but at their owne perill, both for temporall punishment in this life, and for eternall in the life to come.

5 For conclusion; the Scripture according to our doctrine, and the generall consent of reformed Churches, is the onely infallible rule of faith, in both respects or conditions of a perfect rule. First, in that it containes all the principles of faith, and pointes of saluation: So that no visible Church on earth may commend any doctrine to others, as a doctrine of faith, vnlesse it bee commended to them for such by the Scriptures, by which euerie ones doctrine, that acknowledgeth God for his Lord, must be examined, as by a law vncontrollable. Secondly, in that these principles of faith, are plainely, perspicuously and distinctly, set downe to the capacities of all that faithfully follow their practicall rules most plaine, most perspicuous, and easie, to all capable of any rule or reason: So that this sacred Canon needs no associate, no addition of any authoritie as equally infallible, nor more perspicuous than it selfe, to supply what it wants; onely the ministerie of men skilfull, and industrious in the search, or exposition of it, is to be supposed. And all these (be they neuer so excellent & wel conuersant in them) are vnto Scriptures, but as the ordinary expositors of classique and authenticke bookes are vnto the chiefe Authors or Inuentors of the science contained in them: Supposing that the first authors were men of extraordinarie and infallible skill, and their expositors (as they vsually are) but of ordinarie capacitie, or experience in those faculties.

6 Finally,The prerogatiue of Scriptures, in respect of faith,, aboue all other rules, in respect of arts or sciences. the bookes of Scriptures are to be reputed a more absolute rule for all matters of faith and diuine mysteries, than any bookes or writings of men are, for naturall sciences or secular professions, as in sundrie other respects, so in this, that they giue as more facile, so more infallible directions, for finding out their true sense and meaning, than any other writings
doe, or writers could haue done, who, though present, could not be so fully assistant, but cannot so much as affoord their presence, to their expositours in the search of truthes, rather professed than fully conceiued, much lesse infallibly taught by them: whereas the Spirit of truth which first did dictate, is euery where present, alwaies assistant to such as seriously & sincerely seeke the truth contained in these diuine Oracles, conducting them from knowledge to knowledge, both by al such means as Artists haue for increasing their skill, and by other meanes extraordinarie, such as none in any other facultie can haue, nor any may hope for in the search of Scriptures, but onely such as delight in, and meditate vpon them day and night.

div.head: SECT. II.
That the pretended obscuritie of Scriptures is no iust exception, why they should not be acknowledged the absolute Rule of faith, which is the mother-obiection of the Romanist.
CHAP. I.
How farre it may be granted the Scriptures are obscure; with some premunitions for the right state of the question.
div.p:
1 IT is first to be supposed, that these Scriptures, for whose soueraigntie ouer our soules we plead against the pretended authoritie of the Romish Church, were giuen by God, for the instruction of all succeeding ages, for all sorts of men in euery age, for all degrees, or diuers measures of his other gifts in all seuerall sorts or conditions of men. This diuersitie of ages, and conditions of men in seuerall callings, who so well considers, may at the first sight easily discouer our aduersaries willingnesse to wrangle in this point: whose vsuall practise, (as if they meant to cast a mist before the weake-sighted Readers eyes) is, to picke out heere and there some places
of Scriptures, more hard and difficult, than necessary or requisite to be vnderstood of euery man, perhaps, of any man in this age. The knowledge of all, or any of which, notwithstanding, those that liue after vs, (though otherwise, peraduenture, men of farre meaner gifts, than many in this present age) shall not therefore need to giue for lost or desperate, when they shall be called vnto this search. For God hath appointed, as for euery thing else, so for the reuelation of his word, certaine and peculiar times and seasons. Daniel, though full of the spirit of prophecie, and one that during the raigne of Nabuchadnezzar, and Balthasar his sonne, had (as it were) continually trauelled of reuelations concerning the estate of Gods Church, and the affaires of forraine kingdomes for many generations to come: yet knew not the approaching time of his peoples deliuerance from captiuitie, vntill the first yeare of Darius, sonne of Ahashuerosh. And this he learned by bookes. Dan. 9. vers. 2. Euen in the first yeare of his raigne, I Daniel vnderstood by bookes the number of the yeares, whereof the Lord had spoken vnto Ieremiah the Prophet, that he would accomplish seuentie yeares in the desolation of Ierusalem. And of his owne Reuelation he saith: Dan. 12. v. 4. And Daniel was commanded to shut vp his words, and seale vp his booke vnto the end of the time, or as some read (vnto the appointed time:) and then many shall runne to and fro, and knowledge shall be increased. For at the time appointed, as he intimates in the words following, others though no Prophets were to know more of this prophecie than the Prophet did himselfe. Then I heard it, but I vnderstood it not: then said I, O my Lord what shall be the end of these things? And he said, Go thy way Daniel: for the words are closed vp and sealed till the end of the time.

2 The Prophets of later ages did see Reuelations of matters, which had beene hid from the ancient Seers. And as it fared with them in the succession of visions, immediately inspired from God, not framed in imitation of any precedent written word, but to be then first written for posterities instruction: some saw one vision, some another, alwaies such were seene by the present Prophet,All Scriptures not alike perspicuous to all ages. as most concerned the present times. So fares it still with the Ministers of Gods Church, and Christian people throughout all succeeding ages, wherein visions haue sailed, and onely the written stories of former visions are reserued for perpetuall direction:
Some part of Gods will contained in Scripture is reuealed in one age, some in another; alwaies that which is most necessarie for the present time is most easie to be vnderstood by the faithfull then liuing, so they seeke the meaning of it as they should, not vpon curiositie of knownig mysteries for the raritie of that skill, but for the edifying of Christs Church, which is sometimes out of reparations in one point, sometimes in another: for which cause God suffereth the knowledge of sundrie places to grow and increase, according to the necessitie of the present times, nourishing (as it were) a continuall spring, for repairing or beautifying of his Temple.

3 For this reason, those places which seeme most plaine and easie vnto vs, might bee more hard and difficult to such in former times, as should haue sought their meaning too curiously; yea it might haue beene curiositie in that age, to haue sought halfe so much knowledge in them as wee now see at the first sight, because the time of their Reuelation, now is, was not then come.

Latter ages more to be beleeued in the exposition of the Apocalyps then former.4 It is but a silly shift for our aduersaries to say, that some of the ancient Fathers did otherwise interprete the Apocalyps, than our men doe: the perfect interpretation and knowledge of which booke, more peculiarly concernes this latter, than that flourishing age of ancient Fathers, most of all these daies wherein wee liue, in which the true and perfect meaning of it, were most likely to be reuealed, as (God be praised) in good measure it hath beene, and daily shall be more and more, vnlesse the daily increase of our sinnes deserue the contrarie. Many godly men, yea disciples in our Sauiours time, were ignorant of sundrie mysteries, which since his glorification haue beene communicated to the meanest of his flocke by the holy Spirit, who neuer failes to reueale Gods will, either by extraordinarie or ordinarie meanes, so men be not negligent to inquire after it by lawfull meanes. For God is as farre from partiall respect of ages as of persons; so the persons of seuerall ages respect his word alike,All Scriptures not alike perspicuous, because not alike necessarie to all nations in the same age. and as they should.

5 The like obseruation wee may take, from the diuersitie of place or nations. As the knowledge of Ieremies Prophecies did more concerne the state of Iudah vnder Iehoiachim and Zedekiah,
then the prophecie of Isaias, or some more ancient Prophet did: so in this our age, the knowledge of some one part of either their prophecies, and the manner of Iuda his progresse (in their times) to her ouerthrow, may more concerne this our land, than the knowledge of some other parts of the same or other Prophets. And yet those other whose knowledge concernes vs lesse, may at this instant concerne some other land or people more. Alwaies, the gracious prouidence of our God directs the studie and industry of all that loue him to the search of those points, which most concerne thē; but suffers the endeuors of such, as by their transgressions haue procured his wrath, to run at randō, neuer seeking after those things which belong vnto their peace, vntil his iudgments ouertake them.

6 These Collections are no paradoxes, but truthes, probable enough of themselues to win the assent of sober and vnpartiall mindes, so capable of externall fortification, as they may easily be made euident and strong enough to conuince the froward mindes of such as delight most in contradiction. From their truth supposed (which we are readie to make good against all gainsayers) it necessarily followes, that this question about the Scriptures obscuritie, or perspicuitie, cannot be vniuersally meant of all,The question concerning the obscuritie or difficultie of Scriptures, cannot bee ment of all Scriptures, in respect of all ages, or all men. and euery part of Scripture, in respect of all persons and ages: as whether no part be obscure or difficult to all, or any this day liuing. For, from this diuersitie of ages, we may easily discerne some things kept secret from the ancient Patriarches, by the wisedome of God made manifest vnto vs: and some things againe, by the disposition of the diuine prouidence, become obscure and difficult vnto vs, which were more manifest vnto them; as the particulars concerning the mysterie of mans redemption, were more obscure to them than vs; although the mysterie it selfe was, in some sort, revealed to them, in the Propheticall and Mosaicall writings. So likewise all the Propheticall predictions or prelusions vnto the time of Grace, are better and more distinctly knowne of vs than them; because the expresse knowledge of these particulars more concernes vs that haue liued since, than those that liued before the fulnesse of time. So the Israelites Iudaical constitutions, their types and ceremonies, were much more plaine and easie vnto them, than vs: because the knowledge of these matters, if we speak of their iudiciall law, more concerned theirs than any other state, as their
types and ceremonies, did their persons, vnto whom the Messias was to bee pourtraied or shadowed out, more than any in this present or other precedent age, since he was manifested in our flesh and substance. The knowledge of the moral law, the end and scope thereof (the obseruation of Gods commandements and doctrine of repentance after their transgression,) was equally perspicuous to both, because equally necessarie, most necessarie to both for their saluation.

Diuers degrees of Scriptures perspicuitie, arising from the diuersitie of mens conditions or callings:7 Againe, from the diuers conditions of men liuing in the same age, this resolution is most euident, and most certaine. The same portion of Scripture may be difficult vnto some sort of men, and easie vnto others, without any preiudice to their sufficiencie, for being the perfect and infallible rule of faith to all. For, what we said before of diuers ages, we may conclude againe of diuers sorts or conditions of men. Sundrie places are more necessarie, and requisite to be vnderstood of this or that sort, and other places of others: nor are all places necessarie for the one to know, requisite for men of another condition or calling to search into. Thus the knowledge of many places is necessarie for him that is a publike Reader, Teacher, Instructer, or generall Ouerseer of Gods flocke: which to search into, or laboriously to examine, would be curiositie in him that had no such calling, especially if engaged to any other, which might iustly challenge the greatest portion in his best endeauours, or take vp the most part of his choicer houres for studie.

8 In this assertion we auouch no more than our aduersaries must of necessitie grant, and expresly doe acknowledge in their supposed infallible rule; which they doe not suppose should be alike plaine and easie, to all sorts or conditions of men, in all points. They would iudge it damnable presumption for the most learned amongst their Laitie, to professe as great skill in the Canons of their Church, as their Cardinals, Bishops, Abbats, or other principall members of it, either haue or make shew of; a great presumption of heresie in any of their flocke, to discusse the meaning of their decretals, as acccurately as their Canonists, or sift other mysteries of their religion, as narrowly as the Casualists doe. Should one of their greatest Philosophers, that were no Cleargie-man, or profest Diuine, professe he knew the meaning of that
Canon in the Trent-Councell: Sessione 2. Canone. 6. Sacramenta conferunt gratiam ex opere operato, as well as Soto, Valentian, or Vasques did, Suarez or other their greatest schoolemen in Spaine or Italy now liuing do it would breed as dangerous a quarrell in their inquisition, as if he had entred comparison with a Rabbin in a Iewish Synagogue, for skill in expounding Moses law.

9 That the Scriptures therefore may be said a sufficient rule of faith and Christian carriage, to all sorts or conditions of men, it is sufficient that euery Christian man of what sort or condition soeuer, may haue the general and necessary points of Catholike faith, and such particulars as belong vnto a Christian and religious carriage in his owne vocation, perspicuously and plainely set down in them. And no doubt but it was Gods will, to haue them in matters concerning one calling not so facile vnto such as were of another profession: that euery man might hence learne sobrietie, and be occasioned to seeke, if not only yet principally, after the true sense and meaning of those Scriptures, which either necessarily concerne all, or must direct him in that Christian course of life whereunto his God hath called him. But shall this difficultie of some parts (which ariseth from the diuersitie of vocations) be thought any hindrance, why the whole Canon of Scriptures should not be a perfect rule to all in their seuerall vocations? Suppose some vniuersall Artist, or complete Cyclopedian, should set out an absolute systeme, or rule for all secular sciences: it would be a ridiculous exception to say, his works could be no perfect rule for yong Grammarians, Rhetoriciās, Logicians, or Moralists, because he had some difficult Mathematicall questions, or abstruse Metaphysical discourses, which would require a grounded scholers serious paines, & long search, to vnderstand them throughly: and if he should admonish yong students, to begin first with those common and easie arts, & not to meddle with the other, vntil they had made good triall of their wit and industrie in the former: this would be a good token of a perfect teacher, and one fit to rule our course in all those studies which he professeth. And yet the Scriptures (which the Iesuits would not haue acknowledged for the rule of Christian life) besides all the infallible rules of life, and saluation (common to all) admonish euery man to seek after the knowledge of such things as are most for edifying, or most befitting his particular calling.

Of the pretended difficulties in S. Pauls Epistles.10 And euen in Saint Pauls Epistles, (which are the common places of our aduersaries inuention in this argument) after he comes to direct his speeches, (as in the latter end of them vsually he doth) vnto maisters of families, seruants or the like, or generally, where he speaks of any Christian dutie, (either priuate or publike) his rules are as plaine and easie to all men in this age, as they were to those housholders, or seruants, or the like, vnto whom they were first directed. So plaine and easie they are vnto all ages, and so familiar, especially to men of meaner place, that I much doubt whether the Pope himselfe, and all his Cardinals, were able in this present age to speake so plainly vnto the capacitie, or so familiarly to the experience of men of their qualitie vnto whom he wrote. For, setting aside the absolute truth & infallibility of his doctrines; his manner of deliuering them is so familiar, so lowly, so heartily humble, so naturall and so well befitting such mens disposition in their sober thoughts, as were impossible for the Pope to attaine vnto or imitate, vnlesse he would abiure his triple Crowne, and abstract himselfe from all Court-state or solace, vnlesse he would, for seuen yeares, addict himselfe vnto familiaritie, with such men in a pastorall charge.
