It was an excellent admonition of one of their Cardinals (if I mistake not, and would to God our Church would herein be admonished by him,) to begin alwaies with the latter end of Saint Pauls Epistles. For once well experienced in them, we should easily attaine vnto the true sense and meaning of the former parts, which vsually are doctrinall, and therefore more difficult than the latter. Yet the true reason of those difficulties in the former parts containing doctrine, is, because he wrote them against the disputers of that age, especially the Iewes. Euen in this age they are onely seene in matters concerning the learned expositors of Scriptures, not necessarie for priuate and vnlearned persons to know. And the especiall reason, why his doctrine in some Epistles (as in the Epistle to the Romanes) seemes obscure, difficult, and intricate, is, because learned men of later times haue too much followed the authorities of men in former ages, who had examined. Saint Pauls doctrine, according to the rule or phrase of those arts or faculties, with which they were best acquainted, or else had measured his controuersie with the Iewes, by the oppositions or contentions of the age wherein they liued. Where this
partialitie vnto some famous mens authoritie (which indeed is made a chiefe rule in expounding Scriptures, euen by many such, as in words, are most earnest to haue Scriptures the onely rule of faith) once laid aside, and the rules of faith, elsewhere most perspicuously and plainly set downe by Saint Paul, vnpartially scanned: his doctrine in that Epistle would become so perspicuous and easie vnto the learned, as it might by them bee made plaine enough and vnoffensiue to the vnlearned. For the light of truth, elsewhere deliuered by this lampe of the Gentiles (might it be admitted as a rule, against some expositions of that Epistle) would direct mens steps to auoid those stumbling blocks, which many haue fallen vpon. But to conclude this assertion; their difficultie (take them as they are) is no iust exception against this part of Scripture: because it remaines difficult still, euen for this reason, that it is held generally for difficult, and is not made a rule, indeed for our directions; but other mens opinions or coniectures concerning it are taken for an authenticke Rubricke, by whose leuell only we must aime at our Apostles meaning from which we may not, without imputations of irregularitie, swerue in the decision of pointes (to say no worse) as now they are made hard and knottie.

11 Thirdly from the diuersitie of capacities,Scripture more or lesse difficult, to men of the same profession, from the different measure of their naturall capacities or Gods gifts bestowed vpon them. or different measure of Gods gifts, in men of the same profession, we may safely conclude, that the difficultie of the same portion of Scriptures vnto some, and facilitie and perspicuitie vnto others of like profession, cannot iustly impeach them of greater obscuritie than befits the infallible rule aswell of theirs as of all other mens faith, in their seuerall vocations. For as mens callings are diuers, and Gods gifts to men in their diuers callings in nature and qualitie different: so likewise is the measure of his like gifts, to men in the same calling not one and the same. To some he giues more knowledge, to others lesse: yet all he commands, not to presume aboue that which is written, & euery man to limit his desires of knowing that which is written, by the distinct measure of Gods giftes in himselfe, not to affect or presume of such skill as they haue vnto whom God hath giuen a greater talent. And besides this, that the Scripture is the inexhaustible storehouse, whence all men haue their seuerall measures of diuine knowledge, as well he that
hath most as he that hath least: euen in this againe it is a perfect rule, that it commands all sapere, idque ad sobrietatem, to be wise according to that measure of knowledge which God hath giuen them, and not to seeke to know, at least, not to say, why should I not know as much as any other of any profession? For this were pride and arrogancie (the fatall enemies of all true Christian knowledge) if so his gifts be lesse than others. And for the auoidance of these maine obstacles of Christian knowledge, or true interpretation of Scriptures, the Scripture hath commanded euery man to thinke better of others, than of himselfe, and not to be wise in hi • owne conceit.

12All Scriptures not alike perspicuous to all ministers of the Gospell or men of God. From the former generall will follow this particular Albeit some parts of Scripture bee verie obscure vnto some; the same perspicuous vnto other Ministers, or Preachers of the word • yet may the whole Canon be the infallible rule of faith vnto both, according to the diuerse measure of their gifts, rightly and vnpartially taken. If the one either faile in the exposition of sundrie places, which the other rightly expounds, or cannot apprehend so much in them, as the other doth: he is in sobrietie of spirit bound to acknowledge his owne infirmitie, and content himselfe with that knowledge, which is contained within the measure of Gods giftes bestowed vpon himselfe: and this againe he is to take by the same rule. So that the Scriptures are a perfect rule to both, to all; for direction in the search of diuine knowledge, for limitation of mens desires whiles they seeke it, or conceit of what they haue gotten. That they doe not so throughly instruct or furnish some, as others, (though all men of God) for exact performance of their ministeriall function; can be no argument of their insufficiencie • a make all such in their place and order competently wise vnto saluation, more than it would be to proue Euclides elements (or other more absolute Mathematicall worke) an insufficient and imperfect rule for instructing Surueyours or other practicall Mathematitians, whose skill lies onely in measuring triangles, circles or other plaine or solid bodies, because containing many questions of higher nature, and greater difficultie, (as of the circles quadrature, of lines or numbers surd, or asymmetrall) well befitting the exercise of speculatorie, learned Mathematicall wits.

div.head: CHAP. II.
The true state of the question about the Scriptures obscuritie or perspicuitie: vnto what men, and for what causes they are obscure.
div.p: 1 THE question then must be; whether the Scriptures be an absolute rule of Christian faith and maners to euery man in his vocation & order, according to the measure of Gods gifts bestowed vpon him? We affirme, it is such to all. None are so cunning, none so excellent or expert in diuine mysteries, but must take it for a rule, beyond whose bounds they may not passe, from which they daily may learne more, none so silly, but may thence learne enough for their saluation, so they will be ruled by it. And yet euen of those points which are perspicuously set downe to the diuers capacities of men in the same or seuerall professions, the question is not; Whether any can fully comprehend their intire meaning? certaine it is, in this life they cannot. But neither will our aduersaries, (I hope) auouch, that the infallible authoritie of their Church can make vs so comprehend the full meaning of mysteries contained, either in Scriptures, or her pretended vnwritten traditions. Of Scriptures the best learned Christian may say with the heathen Socrates: Hoc vnum scio, me nihil scire, I know this one thing, that I know nothing; nothing as I should, or as fully as I then shall, when I shall know as I am knowne: for in this life, we know but in part, 1. Cor. cap. 13. vers. 12. & 9. and we prophecie in part.

2 Lastly, euen in respect of places (though containing points of saluation) onely thus imperfectly knowne (though as perspicuous and cleare as can be required the rule of faith should be) the question is not, whether they be very obscure, and difficult vnto some, or vnto the maior part of mankinde: if we consider them as they are, or may be, not as they should or might be, that is, if wee consider them as disobedient to the truth knowne, or carelesse to amend their liues by this light of Scripture. For vnto all such as hate it, this very light it selfe proues an occasion of falling. Nor
could any thing be more plainly or perspicuously set downe in any other rule of faith imaginable, than this very point we now handle, is in Scriptures, to wit, that such parts of them, as containe matters necessarie to saluation, are most easie to some, most hard to others. And albeit they might, through the iniquitie of mankinde, proue difficult to all, or impossible to be vnderstood of most now liuing (liuing as for the most part we do) yet were this difficulty or impossibilitie of vnderstanding them aright (vpon these suppositions) no hindrance to all, why they should not be a complet rule of faith at all, no iust reason for admitting any infallible authority besides theirs.

This is a point to be obserued, because the weaknesse and impertinencies of all our aduersaries arguments will best appeare, if they be hereto reduced, as shall appeare by the particulars in this, and the next section.3 For of such as admit any authority equiualent to theirs, it must be further demanded; whether the infallibilitie of it, can take away that blindnesse of heart, which by Gods iust iudgement, lights vpon all such as detaine the knowledge of God or his sacred word in vnrighteousnesse? If, for their sinnes, God punish them with this spirituall darknesse, in discerning his will reuealed in his written word: no other infallible authoritie (as we suppose) can take away those scales from their eyes, which hinder their sight in the meanes of their saluation. If men haue beene called to this light, and preferre darknesse before it: either they must receiue sight and direction from it againe, or continue still in ignorance and the shadow of death; but doth God locke vp all or most mens eyes in such darknesse? No, for this blindnes (by our doctrine) befals only such, as haue deserued it by the fore-mentioned sinnes, which once remoued by repentance, the rule of life shal inlighten thē; vnrepented of; no other rule or authority shall teach them the way to life.

4 Since we thus grant, that the Scriptures may be obscure to most men by their owne default, but perspicuous to others free from like fault or demerit: it remaines, we further inquire whether the same Scriptures do not most plainly set downe: First, the causes why they are so obscure to some, and perspicuous to others: Secondly, the remedie or meanes how their obscuritie or difficultie may be preuented. If they plainly teach these two points, this is a sure argument that they are, if not, that they cannot be, so excellent a rule of faith as wee acknowledge them. For this very point, [That the Scriptures in respect of diuers persons are obscure and perspicuous, though obscure to none but through their
owne default] is a principle of Christian faith, and therefore must be plainly set downe in the absolute complete rule of faith. And (to omit others in their due place to bee inserted) what can be more perspicuously taught, either by Scriptures or other writings than this truth, God giueth grace to the humble, and resisteth the proud? or this, He will confound the wisedome of the wise, or such as glorie in their wisedome? These and like rules of Gods iustice in punishing the proud and disobedient, hold as true in the search of Scripture, as in any other matter, yea especially herein. Thus were the Scribes and Pharisees (men of extraordinarie skill in Scriptures) blinded in the most necessarie pointes of their saluation, though most plainly set downe in Scriptures. For what could be more plainly set downe then many testimonies of their Messias? Many places of farre greater difficultie they could with dexteritie vnfold: how chanced it then they are so blinded in the other? They were scattered in the proud imagination of their hearts, and glorious conceits of their prerogatiues in being Moses successours: and in their stead, simple and illiterate, but humble and meeke spirited men, raised vp, to be infallible teachers of the Gentiles, to vnfold those mysteries of mans redemption, (which the Scribes and Pharisees could not see) with euidence of truth to inlighten the silly and ignorant, and conuince the consciences of their learned proud oppugners. By their ministerie, Propheticall and Mosaicall mysteries became a light vnto the Gentile, whose life had beene in the shadow of death: whilest a veile was laid before the hearts of the most learned Iewes, so that euen whilst the Sunne of righteousnesse, which inlightens euery man that comes into the world, did arise in their coast, and ascend vnto their Zenith, they groape their way, as men that walke in dangerous pathes by darke night.

5 Was the Scripture therefore no rule of faith vnto these Iewes, to whom it was so difficult and obscure? Or is it not most euident, that this blindnesse did therefore come vpon Israel, because they hated this light, carried away with lowd cries of Templum Domini, Templum Domini, as the Papists now are with The Church, The Church: And for words of supposed disgrace offered to it (only vpon a surmise that Christ had said hee would destroy and build it vp again) brought to seek the destruction of the glory of it,
euen of the Lord of glorie. Thou that wouldest make others beleeue the Pope is such, dost thou beleeue the Scriptures to be infallible? How is it then, whilest thou readest Gods iudgements vpon thy brother Iew, thou doest not tremble and quake, least the Lord smite thee also (thou painted wall) with like blindnesse? seeing thou hast iustified thy brother Pharisees stubborne pride, wilfull arrogancie and witting blasphemie in oppugning Scriptures. And as for all such, whose hearts can be touched with the terrour of Gods iudgements vpon others, in feare and reuerence I request them to consider well; whether one of the greatest Romane Doctors, Disce ex vno omnes. Gather how mad Baals other Priests are in this argument from Ʋalentians Iewish phrensie in vrging Scriptures against vs which make most plainly for vs. were not taken with more than Iewish madnesse in mistaking Scripture in it selfe most plaine and easie, who to proue the Scriptures obscurity to be such as in this respect it could not be the rule of faith, alledgeth for his proofe that place of theIsa. cap. 29. vers. 11. Prophet. And the vision of them all is become vnto you, as the word of a booke that is sealed vp, which they diliuer to one that can read saying, Reade this I pray thee, then shall he say, I cannot for it is sealed.

6 The Prophet relates it as a wonder, that they should not be able to discerne the truth. What truth? an obscure or hidden truth, impossible to be vnderstood? This had beene a wonderfull wonder indeed, that men should not bee able to vnderstand that, which was impossible to be vnderstood. Wherein then was the true wonder seene? In this, that they, whose eyes had formerly beene illuminated, by the euidence and clearenesse of the diuine truth, reuealed by Gods messengerr, should not be able to discerne the same, still alike cleare and perspicuous; but now to bee shut vp from their eyes, as appeareth by the similitude of the sealed booke, whose character was legible enough, but yet not able to be read whilst sealed? A man might as well proue the Sunne to be darke, because Polyphemus, after Vlisses had put out his eye, could not see it; as the Scriptures by this place to bee obscure. The Prophets words entire are these. Ʋers. 9 10. &c. Vers. 13. Stay your selues and wonder, they are blinde and make you blinde, they are drunken, but not with wine, they stagger, but not with drinke. For the Lord hath couered you with a spirit of slumber, and hath shut vp your eyes: The Prophets and your chiefe seers hath he couered. And the vision of them all is become vnto you, &c. And more plainly. Therefore the Lord said, because
this people come neare me with their mouth, and honour mee with their lips, but haue remoued their heart from me: and their feare towards me was taught by the precepts of men (doth hee not meane the blinde obedience of moderne Papists, as well as ancient Iewes?) Therefore behold I will doe a maruellous worke in this people, euen a maruellous worke and a wonder. For the wisedome of the wise men shall perish, and the vnderstanding of the prudent man shall be hid. The Lord himselfe foretelles it as a wonder, that this people should be so ignorant in the word of God: and yet will the Iesuite make vs beleeue, the word of God is so obscure that it cannot be vnto vs the rule of faith, when as without the knowledge and light of it, (not which it hath in it selfe, but which it communicates to vs,) there is no vision no knowledge in the visible Church, but such wonderfull darknesse as the Prophet heere describes.

7 Let the Reader heere giue sentence with mee, whether it were not wonderfull Iewish blindnesse, or wilfull blasphemie inVelamen quod ipse Paulus (2. Cor. 30 15.) affirmat vsque in hodiernum diem, cum legitur Moses, esse positum supra cor Iudaeorum: profecto textum (vt ita dicam) bona ex parte est ex difficultate scripturarum illarum. Valent. tom. 3.
• n Aquin. disp. 1. quaest. 1. punct 7. parag 4. He addeth immediately. Hoc enim (vt ant ••• monuimus) o • scripturam esse difficilem, em •
modi eam esse, & tam mutae vt illa int ••• gatur, requ ••• practiue fuerit Iudaeis, & sit alijs omnibus non percipere veram eius sententiam: quod quia dare nobis coguntur vel •• t, nol • m sect 〈◊〉 , r • ct • ac necessarie inde concludimus, commune illam r • gulā & magi tram fidei, quam recesse est esse propos •• am delibus omnibus, non esse scriptura, cum non sit cognita fa • il s ips • s hom • nibus. Huc & in ••
Isai •• 29. pertinit. Valentia, so confidently to auouch, that the veile which Saint Paul saith is laid before the Iewes hearts, was wouen (a great part) out of the difficultie of Scriptures, such Scriptures, as the sectaries (so he termes vs) contend about: and for proofe of this blasphemous assertion to bring the forecited place. Ere their allegations of this or like places, brought to proue the Scriptures difficultie or obscuritie, can be pertinent, they must (according to the state of the question alreadie proposed) first proue this obscuritie or difficultie to be perpetuall and ordinarie, nor inflicted as a punishment vpon hypocrites, or such as loue darknesse more than light, And this they neuer shall be able; this one place alledged by Valentian most euidently proues the contrarie. For this was an extraordinarie and miraculous iudgement vppon these Iewes, for their hypocrisie, as appeares, verses the thirteene and fourteene. And vnto such as they were, wee acknowledge the Scriptures, by the iust iudgement of God, to bee most difficult 〈◊〉 ; but denie such difficulties to be any barre, why they should not be the complete rule of faith. If the Iesuites will auouch the contrarie: Let them tell vs whether any other rule could in this
case supplie their defect, be it vnwritten tradition, or viua vox infallibilis authoritatis, the infallible teaching or preaching of the visible Church or Pope. This (I presume) they will be ashamed to affirme.So our Sauiour expoundeth it Mat. 15 vers 18.9. O hypocrites Esa as prophesied well of you saying, This people, &c. vsing the words before cited out of the 13. verse of Esay, cap. 29. Out of both places it appeares that their hypocrisie and disobedience to the truth knowne caused this blindnesse: and what the Prophet threatned v. 14. Our Sauior ratifieth Mat 15. v. 12.13.14. For when his disciples said vnto him, perceiuest thou not that the Pharises are offended in hearing this saying? He answered, Euery plant which my heauenly Father hath not planted. shall be rooted vp, let thē alone, they be blinde leaders of the blinde, and if the blinde lead the blinde, both shall fall into the ditch. So the prophet had said in the 14. verse. The wisedome of their wise men (to wit the Pharises) shall perish, and the vnderstanding of the prudent shall be hid, and in the 9. verse. They are blinde and make you blinde. For this cause our Sauiour in the fore-mentioned place calleth not them as he did the multitude to heare and vnderstand. vers. 10. Nor expoounds the parable vnto them as he did to his disciples. vers. 15. For this prophecie was fulfilled of the Pharisees which liued in our Sauiours time, & heard him preach the doctrine of saluation, as plainly as the Pope can doe: yet neither could his doctrine, nor miracles win them to his father. Why could they not? Because they had, as the Papists now haue (though not so openly) disclaimed the Scriptures for the rule of their faith, & did follow the precepts or traditions of men; and God (as we said before) hath so decreed that such as neglect the truth knowne, or loue darknesse more than light, should bee giuen ouer to this reprobate sense; that the more euident the truth is, the more hatefull it should be to them: as the hate of these Scribes & Pharises to our Sauiour was greater then their fore-elders had beene to the Prophets, because the light of his doctrine was greater, his reprehensions more sharpe, and their deeds and hypocrisie worse than their Fathers. No maruaile then, if it be so hard a matter to recouer a learned Papist, or make a Iesuite recant his error in this point, seeing they are farther gone in this Iewish disease of contemning Gods word, following traditions, and precepts of men, for the rule of their faith, than these Iewes themselues were; not likely therefore they would haue yeelded to our Sauiour himselfe, if they had liued in his time. Nor should the ingenious Reader thinke we hyperbolize or ouer-lash, when we charge them with deeper blasphemie in this point, than these Iewes were guiltie of: as if this were strange, seeing they are such great schollers, and professe that they loue Christ as well as we: for so would these Iewes boast of their antiquitie, and skill in Scriptures, and thought that they loued God, and his seruant Moses, as well as Christ and his Apostles did. But it was Gods purpose to confound the wisedome of the worldly-wise: of the Scribes & Pharisees then, and of the learned Priests & Iesuits now.

div.head: CHAP. III.
How men must be qualified, ere they can vnderstand Scriptures aright: that the Pope is not so qualified.
div.p:
1 OVT of the fore-mentioned places it is euident, that Gods word (otherwise plaine & perspicuous) was hidden from this peoples eies for their hypocrisie; and the same blindnesse continues still in their posteritie for continuing in like sin. But can it be proued as euidently, by any other place of Scripture, that vnto such as doe the will of God, and practise according to his precepts, the same word shall be plaine and easie so farre as is necessarie for their saluation? Yes, infinite places may bee brought to this purpose. And least any man should except against the extent of such bountifull promises, as if they included some condition of learning, great dexteritie of wit, or the like, whereof many men are not capable: Our Sauiour Christ addes the vniuersall note; Iohn. 7. v. 17. If any man will doe his will, hee shall know of the doctrine, whether it bee of God, or whether I speake of my selfe. If any man will doe his will: Not if any man will learne the learned tongues, or studie the Scribes and Pharisees comments, which this people supposed to haue beene the onely, as they were good, meanes, for vnderstanding Scriptures aright, whilest subordinate to this principall condition heere mentioned by our Sauiour. The occasion of the multitudes admiring his doctrine, was that hee, who had neuer beene Scholler to their Rabbins, should be so expert in Scriptures [as it is verse the fifteene.] Our Sauiours replie to this their doubt conceiued by way of admiration, [in the sixteenth verse] is, that hee had his learning from God, and not from man: My doctrine is not mine, but his that sent mee. And as hee was taught by his father, to deliuer and teach the heauenly doctrine, so might the simplest, and most vnlearned amongst them, be likewise taught of God to discerne whether his doctrine were of God, or whether he spake of himself; If they would doe the will of God and seeke his glory, not their owne, as Christ did not seeke his own glory, but his that sent him.
Yet might these Iewes haue brought the same exceptions against our Sauiours rule for discerning doctrines, which the Papists now bring against the Scriptures, why they should not be the infallible rule of faith; as shall appeare hereafter. In the meane time whom shall we beleeue, the moderne Iesuite, who will sweare one thing sitting, and the contrarie standing, or Christ Iesus, whose word (as he himselfe) remaines, yesterday, to day, the same for euer? Our Sauiour fully confirm • th this truth vnto vs, which the Psalmist had before in effect del • uered, Psalm. 25. vers. 14 The se • ret of the Lord is reuealed vnto them that feare him: and his couenant to giue them vnderstanding, and vers. 9. Them that be meeke will he guide in iudgement, and teach the humble his way, vide etiā vers 10 & 12. This euidently confuteth their folly, who thinke or rather say, our Sauiour spake in this place of his owne peculiar doctrine and authoritie. Albeit Canus (amongst others) might be excused (by such as would salue his credit) by the common answere, non locutus est ex sua sententia, as appeareth by the manner of his reply. Lib. 2. de Coc. Theol. cap. 8. Euen at this day, (as well as at that time, when he spake this Oracle) if any man will doe the will of God, (which sent him:) he, amidst the varietie of mens opinions concerning matters of faith, shall know of the doctrine, whether it be of God, or whether men speake of themselues, without recourse vnto the infallible authoritie of such as sit in Peters chaire: who are to Peter, but as vnto Moses the Scribes and Pharisees were, vnto whom Gods Church in Iewrie, about our Sauiours time, was not much beholden for doctrines of faith, or decisions of doubts, concerning the truth of Scriptures, or principall mysteries taught by Moses.

2 Will you heare what Bellarmine (the onely champion that euer Rome had, for eluding euident authorities of Scripture) could answere vnto this place? Non haec dixit dominus vt ostendat omnes viros bonos per se intelligere posse omnia loca scripturarum: sed vt doceat viros probos carere quib • sdam impedimentis, propter quae alij quidem nec per se, nec per alios, fidei veritatē intell g • re possun • , vt Ioh in 5.44. Luk 16.14. Bellarm. Tom. 1. lib 3. cap 1. Canus in his first answere to th s place seemes willing to assent vnto the truth Concedimus inquit, liberaliter doctrinam cui{que} in sua vita & statu necessariam, illi sore perspectam & cognitam, qui fecerit voluntatem Dei. S • cut enim gustus bene aff • ctus diff • rent • as saporum facile disceruit, sic animi optima affectio facit, vt homo doctrinam Dei ad salutem necessariam discernat ab errore contrario qui ex Deo non est. Que verò Ecclesiae sunt communia, nec ad iudicia nec ad fidem s • ectant singularum, ea non à quonis discerni & iudicari possunt, quatumcunque is Dei faciat voluntatem. In h • s second answere he bewraies a willingnesse to dissent from vs, or perhaps a feare, not to say somewhat against vs: and therefore, to su • h as will not be satisfied with the former, he giues a second a • swe • e, in effect, the same with Bellarmines. We may admit both their conclusions, without harme to our cause. From that which Canus granteth of priuate men (both in his answere to the second and third argument,) we may conclude against h • m thus As God giueth them the spirit of discerning true from false doctrine, in points necessarie to saluation, without all respect of persons: so likewise will he, by h • s prou • d nce, direct the learned or spirituall ouerseers in euerie nation (without respecting person place, or other prerogatiue) for discerning Apochryphall from Canonicall bookes. Nor is there any more reason to appropriate their discretion to the Pope, or Cleargie of Rome, more then to appropriate the gift of d • scerning truth from falshood in points necessarie to saluation, to their seruants. V. Can. l • b. 2. de Loc. Theol. c. 8. Responsione ad secundum & tertium.
Our Lord and Sauiour did not intend in this speech to shew vs that all honest-minded men might vnderstand euery place of Scripture by themselues: but to teach vs that good
men are free from diuers such impediments, as dis-enable others for vnderstanding the true doctrine of faith either by themselues, or by others helpe. For some became vncapable of true faith by pride and desire of worldly honour, others by couetousnesse. All these things heard the Pharisees also which were couetous, and they mocked him.

3 That all honest-minded men should bee able to vnderstand all places of Scriptures, wee neuer affirmed; that without the ministerie or helpe of others they should (ordinarily) vnderstand any aright, we neuer taught. This notwithstanding we constantly auouch. Without this condition of doing Gods will, not men otherwise furnished with the best gifts of Art and nature, can euer be competently qualified for spiritual instructors: By performing it, the simple and illiterate shall be made capable of good instructions, and enabled to discerue true doctrine from false. By our Sauiours rule in the verie next words (more infallible than any other pretended infallibilitie can bee) wee may discerne the Pope, of all others to bee no true, much lesse any infallible teacher, vnlesse of lies and Antichristian deceit. For he that seeketh his owne glorie (as what Pope is there doth not so? many seeke the Popedome by their predecessors bloud) he speakes of himselfe; not the word of him, whose Vicar he boasts himselfe to be.

4 To place the Apostle Saint Pauls authoritie next in file vnto our Sauiours.Rom. 12. v. 2. Vpon which place hee whom Bellarmine commendes as one of the most excellent interpreters of later-yeaers iere to lansenius, saith thus. Per renouationem me • ti • quam iam per fidem in Christum accepistis, transformemini in nouos aff ctus, vt sic reddamini apei ad intelligendum, quid à vob • s iustificat • s per totam vitam requirat Deus. Quid gratum sit beneplacitum & acc • ptum Deo. Simile quiddam •• pe et Apost Eph. 5. Propantes qu • d sit bene pla • itum Deo. Nisi enim mactanerimus cupiditates tarnis no •• rae, non possumus esse idonei, vt in act onibus nostris int lli, imus, quae sit voluntas Dei: sed quod nostro s nsui vehemen • er arr d • t, interp • etamur • d esse voluntatem Dei. Sasbout in hunc locum. Vide annotat. ex Beda ad paragraph. 5.
Fashion not your selues (saith hee vnto his beloued Romanes) like vnto this present world: but be ye changed by the renewing of your minde, that ye may proue what is the good will of God, and acceptable and perfect. Being fashioned like vnto the present world, they were altogether disproportionable vnto the kingdome of heauen, vncapable of heauenly mysteries; but being renued in their minds; they might proue, taste, and relish aright the meaning of Gods word reuealed. Of such as disanull the Scriptures for being the rule of saith, and transferre this Canonicall dignitie vpon the Pope, I would gladly be resolued,
whether this his Holinesse infallibilitie, can take away the veile, which is laid before the Iewes hearts, or this desire which raignes in most men, of fashioning themselues vnto this present world; whether he can in all such, as professe Christianitie, roote out those lustes and concupiscences, those (corneae fibrae) stiffe and stubborne heart-strings, as are the verie threeds whereof this veile is made, which makes the Scriptures so difficult, and so eclypseth their light in respect of men. If he cannot, well may he make them vnderstand or beleeue his owne decrees; but neuer rightly apprehend, or stedfastly embrace the spirituall mysteries of their saluation: That rule of Saint Pauls is still most infallible. The naturall or carnall man is altogether vncapable of the things of Gods Spirit; of those things, which are in themselues most euident: Neither can he know them. If you will not beleeue his authoritie as infallible, he giues you a reason for the truth of the conclusion, for they are spiritually discerned. Is it then the Popes infallibilitie, or the framing of our liues according to Gods holy word, that must purge the errours of our young and wanton daies, and make vs cease to be homines
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 naturall or carnall men; and become spirituall? If the Popes infallibilitie cannot performe this, to what vse doth it serue? The Scriptures will be difficult still, and their sense insipide to such as haue not their hearts thus clensed. If without his infallibilitie, (by the industrie of faithfull Pastours, attentiue hearing, and serious meditation of his sacred word,) our liues may be amended, and we of carnall men become spirituall: we shall discerne the things of God, what is his will and mercy towards vs in Christ: wee shall know of euerie doctrine necessarie vnto our saluation, whether it bee of God or no: much better than the Pope, and his Cardinals can doe, if they be carnals. For our Apostle addes,Apostolus. 1. Cor. 2. comparando temporalem facultatem ad spiritualem ait, quod animalis homo non percipit ea quae sunt spiritus Dei sed spiritualis dijudicat omnia & ipse a nemine iudic • tur. Soto in 4 Sentent. dist. 25. & 2. Art. 1. Con 5. No marua • le if Val •• tian grosly mistake this place, wherein this graue Diuine as Bellarmin •
in-stiles him is so sottish.
The spirituall man iudgeth or discerneth all things, and is iudged of none. The sense of which words some of your schoole-men much mistake, when they hence gather, that the Pope may iudge Princes: but the Spiritualitie (so in common talke wee call the Cleargie) may not bee iudged by any temporall or lay power. Our Apostle meanes, (nor will a learned interpreter though a Papist denie it) that in matters of faith, and in the truth of diuine mysteries, the truly spirituall, (that is, such as are
renewed in the inner man, not such as beare the name or title of spirituall men in their corrupt language, see and vnderstand those things, which the wisedome of God hath hidden from the wisest, and most glorious teachers of the world, from all carnall men, of what gifts soeuer they may be in other matters; as appeares by our Apostles discourse in that place. Which doctrine of our Apostle how truly it is verified in the wise men of Rome, the Iesuites I meane, (to giue them what by our prouerbe we are bound to giue their masters, their due) men of famous indudustrie and excellent reach, in all subtile and profound artes: but how ignorant and besotted in matters of faith, and mysteries of mans saluation, their doctrine in this present controuersie, being compared with this Axiome of our Apostle, m • y abundantly witnesse, to the astonishment of all sober-minded Christian Readers.

5 They cannot denie that matters of faith and Christian life, the mysteries of mans saluation, are matters belonging to the Spirit of God; and that a lewde, naughtie, ambitious, luxurious man, an heretique, is homo
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a carnall man; they will not offer to call in question. Againe, that many of their Popes be such, as I haue said (naughtie, wicked, luxurious men,) they openly confesse. Some of them grant thatDenique quòd Honorius & nonnulli alij Pontifices in errorem lapsi fuisse dicuntur (quanquam de nullo prors • s satis compertum est, pertinaciter errauiss • ) id quidem vtcunque res habeat, non nisi ad priuatum attinet personarum vitium: atque adeo nihil nobis obstare potest, vt qui tam non ipsas personas, quàm authoritatem illam Apostolicae sedis in definiendo defendimus, sicut supra, Augustini etiam exemplo, respondebamus. Ʋalent. Tom. 3. in August. Disp. lib. 9 1. punct. 7. Paragraph. 10. cas. 11.
Honorius was an heretique.Valentianus loco citato. Ad fidel tatem erga Ecclesiam sp ctat, vt impediret in eo casu, quo minus per Pontificem illum controuersia falso definiretur. Id quod facere Deus possit aut Pontificem de medio tollendo, ne ipse, sed successur pot • us, rem decerneret; aut interna mentis illustratione, vel alio aliquo modo Pontificem an errore reuocando. Neque vero huiusmodi prou • dentia Dei in similibus casibus miraculosa esset censenda, sed esset potius quidam effectus eius l gis ordinarie qua Deus per promissiones de veritate factas, sese obstriaxit Ecclesie. Ac sane huius rei exemplum illud proferri pot • st, quòd cum Ioannes xxij. existimaret, sanctorum animas ante diem Iudicij diuinam essentiam non v • dere, idque eo tempore, quo in Ecclesia (sicut Canus etiam lib. 6 de locis Theologicis. cap. vlt. ad 1. argument. notauit) nondum erat satis explicata hec controuersia, & ad rem defiarendam sese compararet, priusquam id faceret, è vita excessit. Et Benedictus successor contrariam sententiam definiuit. Valentian will not dispute this particular de facto, whether he were one or no, but that the Pope or Popes may hold hereticall opinions he granteth: albeit thus tainted with heresie they cannot propose their heresies ex Cathedra, to be beleeued by others; (beleeue Valentian herein who list:) for God by his prouidence would preuent this mischife. But howsoeuer;
the Pope and his Cardinals may (by their owne confession) be carnall men with a witnesse. Homines Animales cum ad dita • ento. 1. Cor. ca. 2. v 14 Now Saint Paul saith plainly,
• omo animalis non potest cognoscere ea quae sunt spiritus Dei, Quis autem carnalis & animalis homo non per phanta • m • ta sui co • dis euagetur, & constituat sibi Deum, qualis ei pro suo carnali sensu placuerit, atque ita cred • t tantum longè aliter quam Deus est, quantum à veritate vanitas d ffert. Verissimam quippe sententiam dixit Apostolus, plenus lumine veritatis. Animalis, inquit, homo, non percipit quae sunt spiritus Dei. Et tamen de ijs haec dicebat, quos iam fuisse baptizatos ipse manifestat. Beda in hunc locum ex Augustino. l. 3. de Baptismo. This opposition betwixt the spirit and the flesh, is (as wee say in schooles) formall, or directly contrarie: so as this rule and that other late mentioned (Rom. 12.) hold as true in the Pope as in any. If hee fashion himselfe as much to this, hee is as disproportioned to the world to come, as any other: If hee bee as carnall as other men, hee is altogether as incompetent a Iudge of things belonging to the Spirit of God, as others are, whosoeuer. Beda in the same place addeth: Ad animales pertinet vetus Test • mentum, ad spiritales nouum: veteris autem Sacramenta cessârunt, sed concup • scentiae tal • s non cessauerunt. In illis enim sunt quos Apostolus iam per Sacramentum noui Testamenti natos, adhuc tamen dicit animales non posse percipere quae sunt Spiritus Dei. no carnall or naturall man can conceiue the things of the spirit of God, (for this indefinite proposition in materia necessaria may haue thi • vniuersa l note, homo animalis non po est cognoscere, no carnall man can perceiue.) The Iesuites affirme the contradictorie vnto Saint Pauls doctrine, as an vndoubted Ar icle of faith. The Pope (say they) albeit homo animalis though a most wicked man, though oth • rwise an heretique, the worst of carnall men,) cannot but discerne the things that belong vnto the spirit, all the mysteries of mans redemption, all points whatsoeuer necessarie to mans saluation. For he cannot erre in deciding such matters if he speake ex Cathedra. More vnhappie man Honorius, more fooles haue the whole generation beene, that euer would shut their mouthes, or cease to speake ex Cathedra euen to the last gaspe.

6 That sundrie lewde and wicked men may learnedly discourse of spirituall matters, and deduce necessarie consequents out of truthes supposed, or commonly receiued for diuine, in such pointsNo carnall affection, or desire habituate, but harbour some one or other heresie, if the soule bee well searched, or the predominant desire or affection directly crossed; as shall (God willing) heereafter appeare; so that men of lewde life or vitious, onely conceiue well, eyther of such spirituall matters as are not directly opposite to their peculiar vices, or else of such generalities, as may bee prosecuted without p •• iudice to their affections. as contradict not their affections, or tempt them not to become partiall Iudges of euill thoughts: that we are to reuerence & obey Gods word, manifested to our consciences, though by their ministerie, we denie not. But that such wicked monsters of mankind, as many of their Popes haue beene, and may be, should so conceiue and discerne all the principles and grounds of faith, be so familiarly intimate with the holy Spirit, that their decrees, (in matters which concerne their owne pompe and glorie, in matters whose losse would breed their temporall ruine,) should be held for the
infallible Oracles of God, the onely rule of faith, for all other Christians to relie vpon continually: thus to denie the infallible presence, or illumination of Gods Spirit, to all faithfull and godly men throughout the world, & to appropriate it to a succession of such sons of Belial as their owne writers picture out vnto vs in their Legends of Popes liues, is a blasphemy against the Godhead, (I pray God it proue not soThe matter of the Iewes blasphemie against the holy Ghost, was their charging Christ, in whom he rested, with an vncleane spirit, as appeareth in Mark. cha. 3. vers. 29. and 38. The former soule (if I may so speake) of that sinne in them, was their intertainment of that conceit, against the euidence of their owne consciences, Christs life and actions bearing witnesse of his sanctification by the blessed spirit. The matter of this sinne in the Iew, and moderne Iesuite, is allowe: for it is the selfe-same impiety, only inuerted, to say or thinke the diuell is author of goodnes, or the holy Ghost of mischiefe, to make the diuell a familiar of the son of God, and the son of Sathan an associate of the holy spirit. Whether the Popes works do not of • - • imes as truly test • fie hi • impurity, as Christ did his sanctity. The aduersary will scarce question. I wil not conclude, but God grant the Iesuites parasiticall encomions of their Popes sacred authority, be not wilfull, as were the Iewes detractings of our Sauiour. against the holy Ghost) of such huge and vgly shape, that I much maruaile, how it could possibly creepe into any Iesuites pen, being scarce able (I thinke) to get out of the wide, vast, gaping mouth of hell it self, in whose intrails it was conceiued. Was it more in heate of passion (perhaps,) to say that theThat the Pope hath no such ab • olute authority as he pretends from Saint Peter, proued by Saint Peters peremptory deniall of the like to Simon Mag • s. Diuell was a familiar of the sonne of God, than to teach it as an article of faith, that the holy and eternall spirit is a perpetuall associate, an infallible assistant, or familiar companion of Satans first-borne of Coniurers, Inchanters or incarnate Diuels? was it so horrible and infamous a crime in Simon Magus, to offer to buy the gifts of the holy Ghost? and is it lesse sinne in such as hee was, Coniurers, Sorcerers, to seeke after as great, or greater spirituall prerogatiues, (as great as Saint Peter had) by the same meanes that he did? Is it no sinne for the Iesuites, to begge this as a Postulatum, or maine Axiome of faith, that whatsoeuer the Pope (such a Pope as hath gotten his triple crowne, and spirituall power by Simonie) shall decree ex Cathedra, should be esteemed and reuerenced as the dictates of the holy Ghost? Did that old Magus want wit to insert this condition to his request, that whomsoeuer he should lay his hands vpon [ex Cathedra] he might receiue the holy Ghost? Might not S. Peter haue conferred this extraordinarie gift as well vpon him, as he did his infallibilitie vpon the Pope? Simon did not desire the Monopolie of bestowing the holy Ghost, but could haue beene content to haue shared with others in this prerogatiue: Act. 8. vers. 19. Giue me also this power, but his brother in wickednesse, the Romish Leui, of what spirit soeuer he be, must haue this prerogatiue alone, that whatsoeuer he shall speake, must be the Oracle of the holy Spirit. Is it more
to haue the holy Ghost attend on Simon Magus hands, but not on them alone, than to haue him tied only vnto the Popes tongue or pen? The spirituall prerogatiue which he sought, and that which the Pope vsurpes, are (on the Popes part at least) equa • l. The manner or meanes of seeking them, in both alike, the same. For we heare in the corner of the world, wherein we liue, that your elections of men into Peters chaire, doe not goe gratis. I confesse I doe not beleeue the corruption of your Cleargy so firmely, as I doe the articles of my Creede, because I haue not expresse warrant for it out of this sacred Canon, which I make the rule of my faith: but ere you can make vs beleeue the Popes infallibility, as an article of faith, you must make euident proofe to the contrarie: you must make it cleare by testimonie from aboue, that neither any State of Italy, or forraine Prince, doth make request or suite vnto your Cardinals, that his kinsman, his countryman, or fauorite may be elected Pope before another. We haue farre greater reason to beleeue, that such offers are both made and taken, then to thinke that, if a forraine Prince or domesticke Potentate should offer a Cardinall some thousands of Ducates for his voyce, hee would answere, (like one that would bee Peters successour in synceritie,) Act. 3. vers. 20 Thy money perish with thee, that thinkest the gift of the holy Ghost can be bought with money.

7 Yet if the Cardinall take any gift vpon this condition, or respect any Princes fauour in such election; his and the parties sinne solliciting him hereto, is altogether as great as Simons was. For the request is in effect thus much: Let such a man haue this prerogatiue, that on whomsoeuer he shall lay his curse, to whomsoeuer he shall impart his blessing, the one shall be accursed, the other blessed from aboue; whatsoeuer he shall determine in any controuersie shall be the dictate of the holy Ghost. And he that yeelds his voyce vpon such conditions; doth take vpon him, to bestow that vpon the Pope, which S. Peter denied to Simon Magus: The Pope thus chosen, doth vsurpe that, as bestowed vpon him, which Simon Magus did seeke; his practise and profession is continually as villanous as Simons desires were, when he sought after this; his blessings are no better than Simons charmes.

8 It is no maruaile if the Iesuites be so eager in this argument; or the polticke Papists so forward to disclaime the Scriptures, for
the rule of Christian faith. For if men should so esteeme of them in heart and deed, those few rules out of them alreadie alledged, would quickly descrie the Pope and Cleargie of Rome, (I meane their Cardinals and States-men,) to be of all others the most incompetent Iudges, eyther of Scripture-sense, or controuersies in religion thence depending: Or were the vse of Scriptures freely permitted to their Laicks, without the glosses and false representations of the Iesuites, Priests or Fryars, they might quickly see, that the silliest soule among them, might sooner bee partaker of their life-working sense, than their great States-men can be, if so they would frame their liues, according to the knowne rules thereof, better than such great ones doe. For sillinesse or simplicitie of wit or vnderstanding, doth not so much hinder, as singlenesse of heart, or sinceritie of conscience further men, in the search of truth necessarie to their owne saluation. That promise of our Sauiour, (Habenti dabitur) Mark. 4. v. 24 & 25. And he said vnto them, take heed what ye heare, with what measure you mete, it shal be measured vnto you, & vnto you that heare more shall be giuen. For vnto him that hath shall be giuen, and from him that hath not shall be taken away, euen that he hath. Ie • em. 31. v. 34. hath its proper place, and peculiar force in this point. Whosoeuer he be that yeelds sincere obedience vnto the least part of Gods word knowne, to him shall bee giuen greater knowledge. And of such is the Prophets speech most true, They shall be all taught of God, from the greatest to the least. As well the meane schollers and silliest soules, as the greatest and wisest Doctors.Apostolus autem spiritu sancto locutus ait. Scientia inflat, charitas vero aed • ficat. Quod recte aliter non intelligitur, nisi scientiam tunc prod • sse: cum charitas inest: sine hac atuem inflare, id est, in supe • biam inaniss • mae quasi ventositatis extollere. Augustin. lib. 9. de ciuit Dei. cap. 20. The like affection in the Pope or Cleargie of Rome maketh them arrogate so much vnto th • mselues in this businesse of establishing beleefe. That which Saint Austen addeth in the same place seemeth in proportion true of them Est ergo in daemonidus scientia sine charitate: & ideo tam inflati, id est, tam superbi sunt, vt h • nores diuinos, & religionis seruitutem, quam vero Deo deberi sciunt, sibi sategerin • exhiberi, & quantum possunt, & apud quos possunt, adhuc agunt. And againe. Contra superbiam porro Daemonum, qua pro meritis possidebant g • nus humanum, Dei humilitas quae in forma serui apparuit, q • antam virtutem habeat, animae hominum nesciunt, immunditia elationis inflatae, daemonibus similes, superbia non scientia. For with great worldly wisedome there is alwaies great pride, the greatest aduersarie to true and sanctified Christian knowledge: and the best sort of secular learning puffeth vp. All the skill which men so minded can attaine vnto in heauenly matters, is but like lessons got by rote. It must be quite forgotten, at least vtterly renounced and laid aside, before we can be admitted into the schoole of Christ, in which a • l in this life are but paruuli, petties, or children, for their simplicitie and harmelesse mindes, for lowlinesse and nullitie of selfe-conceit. Hence saith our Apostle,The first of the Corintb. vers. 18. vid. Iob. 37, vers. 24. If any man thinke himselfe wise, let him become a
foole, that he may learne wisedome aright: And our Sauiour Christ saith vnto his disciples, Matth. 18. vers. 3. except ye be conuerted and become like little children, yee shall not enter into the kingdome of heauen, that is, they cannot be capable of this heauenly doctrine. For true and sanctifying grace must be ingrafted in this harmelesse simplicitie, and child-like disposition.

Ingenuous simplicitie (such as the Orator ment when he said Omne officium simplex est) and plane dealing are qualities best symbolizing with the internall proprietie of Scriptures. Pae. 19.7.9 It is the nature and propertie of Gods word to be plaine and facile vnto such as are of disposition semblable to it; as to the sincere of heart, single in life, and plaine in dealing: but obscure and difficult vnto the worldly-wise. The simplicitie of it, and the subtiltie of the polititian, or secular Artists, parallele as ill, as a straight rule or square with a distorted crooked sticke: The testimonie of the Lord saith the Psalmist is sure, and giueth wisedome to the simple. The word
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
in the originall sillie or credulous, such as in worldly affaires are more easie to bee deceiued, then apt to deceiue: and is rendred by the Septuagint 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
paruuli, which word it pleased our Sauiour to vse, when he intimates this perspicuitie of Gods word vnto such little ones, Matth. 11. vers. 25. I thanke thee O father, Lord of heauen and earth, because thou hast hid these things from the wise, and men of vnderstanding, and hast opened them vnto babes. It is so, O father, because thy good pleasure was such. Such as in this whole discourse we haue supposed, (and this place doth proue:) that is, such as had decreed that the doctrine of life should be most difficult and hard to proud, disobedient, or craftily-minded men, but most perspicuous (because to be reuealed by God) vnto such little ones. And againe, (least any man should presume vpon his wisedome, or dexteritie of wit) he telles vs expresly, no man knoweth the father,
Vers. 27. but the sonne, and he to whom the sonne will reueale him. And his will is, to reueale himselfe, and his word vnto all, and only such as we haue said, to little ones, or such as become little children, casting off the burthen of age, which hath brought such faintnesse and wearinesse vpon their soules, that they cannot hope for any good successe in the course which tends to euerlasting life, vntill they be disburthened of all former cares. And hence in the next verse his words are generall, [Come vnto me all yee that are wearie and heauie laden.] So they will take vp his yoake, which is easie, and his burthen which is light, he will free them from all the g • i • u •• ces & discommodities of their former yoake, learning but
this one lesson of humilitie and meeknesse of him, it will teach them all the rest; for by it they shall finde rest vnto their soules: which Christ will refresh, not as the Pope doth with Anathemaes binding vnto negatiues, but with the true taste of this water of life.

10 Nor willOr if they will, we shall meete with their exceptions in the Article of the Godhead, and other treatises hereafter. any of our aduersaries (I hope) be so peruerse, as to say, our Sauiours doctrine in this place did hold true onely for that time, wherein the knowledge of Christ, and doctrine of his Gospell was to be first published. For such peruersitie would bewray so great ignorance in scriptures and little experience in the course of Christianitie, as they would be ashamed to be suspected of. For who sees not this opposition betweene worldly wisedome, and heauenly knowledge to continue still in their seuerall professors throughout all ages. Nor can any man be sure, his faith is not humorous or hypocriticall, vnlesse he be transformed into such a little one, as Christ heere speakes of, and haue true humilitie surely planted in his heart. This is the fundamentall or first principle, whereinto faith must be resolued: euen all those graces or pledges of Gods fauour whereon most relie in triall of their spirituall estate, must be apparantly seated in this lowlinesse, and simplicitie, or else euerie man through the multiplicitie, and subtiltie of his owne heart, shall be ouerseene in his perswasions.

11 A liuely experiment of our Sauiors doctrine, & our assertion in this point, we haue in SaintInstitui (inquit) animum intendere in scripturas sacras, vt viderem quales essent. Et ecce vid eo rem non compertam superbis, neque nudatam pueris, sed incessu humilem, successu excelsam & velatam mysterijs: & non eram ego talis vt intrare ad eam possem. Nam illa erat quae crescebat cum paruulis; sed ego indignabar esse paruulus, & fastu grauidus mihi grandis esse videbar. Aug. lib. 3. Confess. cap. 5.
Austen, as himselfe witnesseth: I purposed to looke into the sacred Scriptures, that I might see what manner of writings they were. And loe I light on a matter altogether hid from the proud, and yet not laid open vnto children, in progresse lowly, in processe or issue stately, and wrapped in myster • es: Finally such as my qualitie made me vncapable of entrance vnto it. For the property of it was to grow vp with little ones, but I disdained to be a little one, and swolne with fastuous conceit, in mine owne eyes I seemed a great one. HeereAn vero null us difficultatis res est, ab hoc tumore vitiorum vaeuum esse, eorumque fuligine velatum cor, instar Iudaeorum, non habere, sed humilem fieri ac docilem discipulum ad huiusmodi Spiritus sancti disciplinam caepessendam? Ʋalentian. Tom. 3. disp. 1. quaest. 1. §. 4.
Valentian (sucking poyson out of this reuerend fathers honie) demaunds importunately, whether it be a matter of no difficultie, to procure our freedome from this tumour of viciousnesse.
To haue our hearts purged from that soote which is as the Iewish veile vnto them. Saint Austen supporteth the Scriptures to containe in thē the words of life, but intimateth no other meanes by which either the Scripture should become more plaine, or the sauing truth which he taught be otherwise manifested to his soule then only by practising such rules as the Scriptures prescribe, for their right vnderstanding, whence the madnesse of this Romish Doctor may againe appeare. See the second part of this last folly, in the annotations vnto the third pa • ag. of the fifth chapter. Matth. 11. Matth. 11. v. 30 And finally, whether it be so easie a matter, (as we, to his seeming, make it,) to become humble and meeke, without which vertues the Scriptures were obscure and difficult vnto Austen himselfe, otherwise a man of excellent wit.

12 Me thinks this cumbersome Iesuites cholericke straine, and foole-hardie passionate carriage in this whole controuersie, doth liuely resemble a strong sturdie lubber, that had thrust himselfe vnawares into a quarrell, which hee is no way able to make good; yet so stubborne, that hee will not giue ouer, but fightes, and winkes, and cries, (and hit he misse he) layes about him. For can any man thinke, hee see where these fierce blowes would light? As much as wee haue said, is most cleere out of this verie place of Austen, which hee would throw vpon vs. Most cleere it is that vnto such as follow our Sauiours methode, set downe before, that is, vnto such as will become like little children, and beginne (as it were) a new againe; the Scripture (which for the present seemes hard to all farre entered into the worlds schoole) is perspicuous, cleere, and easie to bee learned. But whether it bee hard to become such a one, or whether it be a difficult matter to lay aside all pride, and selfe-conceit, is no part of the point now in question, nothing at all to this intended purpose. To man, no doubt, it is most hard, or rather altogether impossible. But what it is to man once made partaker of the grace of God, and power of his Spirit, let Christ Iesus the fountaine of grace be Iudge. Hee hath tolde vs that a his yoake is easie, and his burthen light. Or will they replie, that his yoake is easie indeede to beare,His yoak and burden is the practise of patience and humilitie which Valentia saith is so hard. when it is taken vp, but hard to take vp. Our Sauiours next wordes imply the contrarie: but of this question wee shall take occasion hereafter. Onely now I say the Iesuites of all other are most vncapable of this plea. For they hold free will in men, wherby they may assent vnto grace offered: and if men haue free will, and Christ offer his grace vnto such, as vse it well, the learning of humilitie, and taking vp his yoake will be easie through grace, though impossible to nature. But let this question concerning grace and free will, stand still, as it doth, in controuersie, betwixt vs and them, and the Lutheranes. This is
granted by all; that if Christ grant his grace to all that will endeauour to follow his precepts, then is it easie to all, to learne this first lesson of Christianitie, lowlinesse, and meekenesse, the rudiments of true knowledge in Scripture, without which all other learning in them is but verball. As this is confessed by all, so would I be resolued by any Iesuite, whether, if it be Christs pleasuse to denie his grace to any, it be not altogether impossible for him to learne this lesson perfectly, or to become a good proficient in the schoole of Christ, although the Pope, their supposed infallible teacher, should vouchsafe to catechise him ex Cathedra. What hath this Iesuite got then, by his fierce obiecting this difficultie of learning humilitie, for to make the Scriptures seeme obscure? If the same obscuritie, the same impossibilitie of vnderstanding them aright, still remaine, albeit the Pope himself, should stretch his plenarie power, to illustrate them with his infallible authoritie.

13 Or wil it not be more hard for the Pope (being so highly placed in secular honor and dignitie as he is) to stoop so low as a little child for lowlinesse of mind, than it will be for vs poore and sillie men. If it be more hard for him, than vs so to do, wee are more likely to become better schollers in Christs schoole, than his infallible Holines: more likely to be more certaine of the true sense or meaning of Scriptures then he can be, much more certaine (in all necessarie points) hereof, than he can be of his infallibilitie. For this lesson of true humilitie must of necessitie be learned, ere we can proceed in the true knowledge of these mysteries. Suppose this be a verie hard lesson to learne, yet (caeteris paribus) it will be harder as mens places are higher, or their dignities greater: hardest of all to men of highest place and greatest dignities, specially if their aduancements, to such preeminencies be (as many Popes and Cardinals haue beene) per saltum, or ab extremo in extremum sine medio, like lazie beggers sodainly mounted on stately steedes: shall then this dfficultie late obiected depriue these Scriptures of this dignitie, which wee pleade for? Shall this debarre them from being the infallible rule of faith? or rather doe they not, in giuing this verie rule of learning humilitie, and thus forewarning of their impossibility to be vnderstood without it, approue themselues to be an excellent rule of faith; a more excellent rule for these super-excellent diuine mysteries, than any other rules
are for ordinarie, pettie, or triuiall arts? For suppose Bellarmine, or any other more exquisite, though he an excellent teacher of the Hebrew tongue, should in his Grammer haue giuen this caueat (easie to be confirmed by sound reason and experience) that whosoeuer would become perfect in that language, should begin his studie in his younger daies, before he were engaged to subtile or profounder studies, or giuen to deepe meditations of realities, otherwise it would be verie hard for him, to descend againe vnto Grammer rules, and beginne like a schoole-boy to cunne declensions, coniugations, without which, and many other pettie rules about altering of vowels, he could neuer hope to be an absolute Hebrician: Had Bellarmine set downe these or like caueats more at large, should this admonition be accounted any iust exception, why his Grammer (otherwise supposed authenticke,) should not be a perfect rule for learning Hebrew? or must we for this reason haue stretched our wits to inuent some infallible teacher of Hebrew for such men? I am sure he that should haue found the truth of his admonitions by experience in himselfe, or obseruation in others, would commend his iudgement herein, and thinke so much better of his Grammer, or wish that he himselfe had known, or others would obserue these admonitions, whiles they were young, and rather vse Bellarmine than experience, for their Schoolemaster in this point.

14 Doubtlesse it is for want of acquainting youth, and childhood with the former rules of Scripture, which make the Scripture generally either seeme obscure or difficult, or causeth men mistake thm seeming euident. For when they are growne to mans estate, or be embarked in worldly affaires, or inuested in secular dignities, before they haue studied Scriptures, or practised the former precepts: this seeming difficultie, either moueth them to seek for other rules, more easie to their capacitie, or not to care for any rule of faith at all, or else to transforme this which God hath giuen for reforming his image in them, into the nature of their corrupt affections. Were this lesson of becomming like little children, throughly planted in our hearts, when we were children: true knowledge in other parts of Scriptures would grow with vs, and faith (once planted in humilitie, while our hearts were tender, and easie to be wrought vpon by this plaine and easie precept) albeit at
the first but like a graine of mustard seed, yet hauing got the start of pride, and desire of secular glory in the Spring, should afterwards florish in all heauenly knowledge, and fructifie in euery good and acceptable worke, without the husbandrie, lopping, or pruning of an infallible teacher. But if we, either through our owne wilfulnesse, or parents negligence, haue peruerted the waies of our • outh, that they will not parallele this straight and easie rule, shall Gods righteousnesse be preiudiced by our iniquitie? shall not his waies (this way of life) be equall, because our waies be vnequall? Must we become like Senecaes blinde woman, who accused euery place, wherein she could not see, for being too darke: must the Scriptures for our blindnesse of heart, be thought obscure? not in themselues (saith the Iesuit) but vnto vs: how vnto vs? or vnto which of vs? onely to such as are therefore become blind, because they haue not in time, been made acquainted with this light. For otherwise the Scriptures were written to enlightē vs, not themselues, or such as wrote them. And vnto such, as are blinded in their owne desires, difficult they are and obscure, without any respect of persons: to the Pope, as well as to any meaner man, not more proud, or carnall than He. Thus wee see our aduersaries cannot offer one blow against vs in this point, but we can make it fall more heauie vpon themselues. And well were it, if their obiections did light heauie onely vpon the obiecters themselues, for they haue deserued it. But heere I must intreate the Christian Reader to consider well vpon whom their vsuall obiections of scriptures obscuritie are most likely to fall: Vpon vs for whose good they were giuen; Or vpon God the Father who gaue them; his sonne that partly spake them; his holy Spirit who onely taught them; his Prophets, Apostles, Euangelistes, or other his blessed ministers which wrote them.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
The Romanists obiections against the Scriptures for being obscure do more directly impeach their first Author and his messengers their pen-men, then vs, or the cause in hand.
div.p: 1 THat these Scriptures (which our Church holds canonicall, and we now maintaine to bee the rule of faith.) were giuen for the good of Christs Church, or multitude of faithfull men throughout the world, our aduersaries will not denie: or if they would, the Scriptures, which expresly to denie they dare not, beare euident testimonie hereof. Infinite places are brought to this purpose, by such as handle that question, Whether the written word containe all points necessarie to saluation.

2 Saint Iohn saith he wrote his Gospel that we might beleeue. By what authoritie did he vndertake,The perspicuitie of Scriptures (to such as obserue the formall rules) proued from the end why they were written, and the Euangelists carefull endeuours to make them plaine. by whose assistance did he performe this worke? Vndertaken it was by Gods appointment, effected by the assistance of his eternall spirit, to the end we might beleeue the truth: what truth? That which he wrote concerning the mysteries of mans saluation. But how farre did he intend, this our beliefe of such mysteries should be set forward by his pen: Vnto the first rudiments onely, or vnto the midway of our course to heauen? Questionlesse vnto the vtmost period of all our hopes: for he wrote these things, that we might beleeue;
Iohn. 20. v. 31 yea so beleeue in Christ as by beleeuing we might haue life through his name. Was he assisted by the eternall Spirit, who then perfectly knew the seuerall tempers, and capacities of euery age? And did he by his direction aime at the perfect beleefe of succeeding ages, as the end & scope of all his writings? And yet did he write so obscurely, that he could not be vnderstood of thē, for whose good he wrote? Out of controuersie his desire was to be vnderstood of all, for he enuied no man knowledge, nor taught he the faith of our glorious Lord Iesus Christ with respect of persons He wished that not the great Agrippaes,
Iames. 2. v. 1. or some few choise ones only, but all that should heare or read his writings to the worlds end, might be, not almost, but altogether such as he was, faithfull beleeuers. From his feruent desire of so
happy an end as the saluation of all, he so earnestly sought the only correspondent meanes, to wit, posterities full instruction in the mysteries thereto belonging. And for better symbolizing with the ignorant, or men (as most of vs are) of duller capacitie in such profound mysteries: his paraphrase vpon our Sauiours speeches, is oft-times so copious, as would be censured for prolixity or tautologie in an Artist. But seeing the common saluation of others, not his owne applause, was the thing he sought, he disdaines not to repeat the same thing, sometimes in the same, otherwhiles in different words, becomming in speech as his fellow1. Cor. 9. v. 22 Apostle was in carriage, all vnto all, that he might at leastwise, of euery sort gaine some: oft-timesIohn. cap. 21. vers. 23. & 2. vers. 21. sollicitous to preuent all occasion of mistaking our Sauiours meaning, though in matters wherein ignorance could not be deadly, nor errour so easie or dangerous, as in those other profundities of greatest moment, which hee so dilates and workes vpon, as if he would haue them transparent to all Christian eyes.

3 Do not all the Euangelists aime at the same end? do they not in as plaine tearms as they could deuise, or we would wish, diuulge to all the world the true sense and meaning of our Sauiours parables, which neither the promiscuous multitude, to whom hee spake, nor his select Disciples or Apostles themselues (vntill they were priuately instructed) vnderstood aright, as they themselues testifie: so little ashamed are they to confesse their owne, so they may hereby expell or preuent like, ignorance, in others. Tell me: were not our Sauiours parables expounded by his blessed mouth, as plaine rules of life as may (without preiudice to his all sufficiencie) be expected from any other mans? Are not his similitudes (wherein notwithstanding are wrapt the greatest mysteries of the Kingdome) drawne from such matters of common vse, as cannot change whilest nature remaines the same? for the most part so plaine and easie, as will apply themselues to the attentiue, or well-exercised in moralities? Strange it seemed vnto our Sauiour that his disciples should not at the first proposall vnderstand them. Mar. 4. v. 13 Matth. 15. v. 16. Perceiue ye not this parable? how should you then vnderstand all other parables? Yet happie were they, that they were not ashamed to bewray their ignorance, by asking when they doubted, though in a point of little difficultie. This good desire of progresse in
their course begunne, brought them within the hemispheare of that glorious light, whereby they were enabled afterward to discerne the greatest mysteries of the kingdome. And vnto their question concerning the meaning of that great parable of the Sower, which is one of the fundamentall rules of li • e; Our Sauiour immediatly replies Mark. 4. v. 11 These words confirme the truth of the state of the question proposed by vs. To you it is giuen to know the mysteries of the kingdome of God: but vnto them that are without, all things are done in parables, that they hearing may heare, and not vnderstand, least at any time they should turne, and their sinnes should be forgiuen them.

4 Had our Euangelists onely set out the Text and concealed the Comment, it might haue ministred matter of suspicion, whether all Christians throughout all generations, whilest this Gospel shall endure, should be taught of God from the greatest to the least of them; or, whether Christ had not appointed some great infallible teacher as his Vicar generall to supply the same place successiuely in the Church, that he himselfe had borne amongst his disdiples; one, on whose liuing voice all the flocke, besides, were in all doubts or difficulties to relie as the Apostles did on Christs in the vnfolding of this parable. But seeing they haue plainly reuealed to vs in writing, what was reuealed to them (concerning the meaning of this and other parables of greatest vse) from our blessed Sauiours mouth; Their written relations of these mysteries with their expositions must be of the same vse & authority vnto vs, as Christs liuing words were vnto them. And as they were not to repaire vnto any other but their master aloneIohn. vers. 68.
for the word of eternall life; not to admit any other infallible teacher for declaration of his meaning: so may not any Christian to this day infallibly relie vpon any mans expositions of his wordes, alreadie expounded by himselfe, and related by his Apostles; these laid vp like precious seede in our hearts, the diligent labours of Gods ordinarie ministers onely supposed, would bring forth the true and perfect knowledge of other precepts of life, in abundance, competent to euery man in his ranke and order.

6 Shall either the world, diuell, or flesh, be able to breede the least suspition in any Christian heart; whether God who enabled the Apostles and Euangelists to speake so plainly to the capacitie of all sorts of men, in euerie nation, cannot either by increasing internall docilitie in succeeding ages, or subleuating their dull capacitie by facilitie and plentie of externall meanes, repaire whatsoeuer the iniuries of time might detract from the perspicuitie of writings Apostolicall or Euangelicall. So that although the decay of Dialects, absolutenesse of phrase, or alteracions of customes, (whereunto they allude as wel knowne then, because in vse) might breed some difficultie vnto posteritie: yet (vnlesse true faith be decayed with them, or all characters of Gods prouidence worn out of our hearts) how can we distrust, whether, He, by whose wisedome, as well diuine mysteries vnheard before,
as skill to vtter them in euerie language, were extraordinarily and immediately infused into illiterate soules, without the helpe or ministerie of man; cannot or will not, by his good blessing vpon our endeauours in the ordinarie course of attaining skill in sacred tongues, continue the vse of tongues and all other good meanes whatsoeuer, necessarie or expedient, either for our right vnderstanding, or communicating, the infallible truth alreadie taught, without any others infallible assistance besides his, who can teach vs as infallibly by meanes in themselues not infallible, as hee hath done others without any meanes at all. To doubt of Gods prouidence in this point, were to doubt whether he were the same God still: and if the same, he will (albeit by other meanes) performe the same effects still; vnlesse the sinnes of the Christian world deserue the contrarie, and pull that blndnesse, which (in our Sauiours time,) raigned in those Iewes, vpon themselues, by like hardnesse of heart, pride or hypocrisie. And if so they doe, what shall this supposed infallibilitie of the Pope auaile? Is his teaching more infallible than Christes was? shall he loose, where God hath bound? shall he disanull what the Almightie hath ratified: shall hee make the Scriptures cleare to them, before whose heartes the Lord hath laid a veile? Or shall hee giue light, where he that made the eye hath called for blindnesse? Oh that they could remember this who haue forgotten their God and cannot see, that whosoeuer accuseth the Scriptures of difficultie or obscuritie, doth indict the Omnipotent of impotencie, in not being able to performe what by his Apostles he intended.

div.head: CHAP. V.
That all the pretences of Scriptures obscuritie are but mistes and vapours arising from the corruption of the flesh, and may by the pure light of Scriptures rightly applied, easily be dispelled.
div.p:
1 VNto this and all demaunds of like nature [if the Scriptures be not obscure, how chanceth it, that so many finde such difficulties in them, euen in those places, wh • ch seeme to containe in them matt • rs of faith?] The answere is alreadie giuen:
It was the Almighties good pleasure to decree, that the Scriptures should be plaine and easie to such as faithfu • ly practise their most plaine and easie precepts, but hard and difficult to be vnderstood aright of such as wilfully transgresse them, or knowing them to bee Gods word doe not glorifie them as his word: Most difficult, most impo • sible to bee vnde • stood of such as acknowledging by what Spirit they were written, yet renounce their authoritie, or disclaime them for the rule of their faith. All such, though for the cleerenesse of their vnderstanding in other speculations they may seeme to haue angelicall heads, yet for diuine mysteries haue but Iewish or obscure hearts: and being blinded in their mindes they imagine the Scripture wheron they looke to bee obscure. This answere notwithstanding, though most true, will not satisfie all For seeing this blindnesse in most men is not voluntarie, at the least, not wilfull or affected, the captious will yet demand; How shall they helpe it? The Scriptures plainely teach, how, they may bee holpen. What can be more plaine then that rule: Iam. 1.5. If any man want wisedome, let him aske of God: Yea, many doe so, and yet goe without it. So they must as the Scripture telleth vs, if they aske amisse. Doth the Scripture then serue as a streight rule to direct them, how they should a • ke aright? Yes. For what rule can be more plaine then that of Saint Iohn. 1. Iohn. chap. 3. vers. 22. Whatsoeuer wee aske, wee receiue of him, because wee keepe his commaundements, and doe those things which are pleasing in his sight. The promise indeede is plaine, but the condition hard: for the first thing wee would aske of God is grace to keepe his commaundements. But what hope haue sinners to receiue this, seeing hee heareth onely such as keepe his commaundements? wil this, or any other rule of Scripture helpe vs out of this Labyrinth? It will not faile vs, nor forsake vs. For if we haue but a desire to amend our liues, Christes words are as plaine, as forcible, Matth. 12.20. Hee quencheth not smoaking flaxe, a bruised reede hee will not breake. And this is his commaundement, that wee trie the truth of this and other like sayings of comfort by relying vpon his mercie; or, if wee doe but seeke after repentance, we do that which is pleasing in his sight; For hee is not pleased in the death of a sinner, but reioyceth at his repentance. If wee bee wanting to our selues in
the practise of these rules, the Popes infallible authoritie shall neuer be able to supply our negligence; his blessing, where God hath laid his curse, shall do as little good, as Balaams indeuour to curse the Israelites did them harme, whom God, had blessed. Obseruing the former precepts well, the word of God, which these men (belike out of their owne experience) challenge of obscuritie, should be Psal. 119.105 a lanterne vnto our feete, and a light vnto our pathes, as it was vnto Dauids.

2 For the Readers further satisfaction, may it please him but vnpartially to consider what two of the most learned Iesuites, in matters of moderne controuersies, could answere vnto this last place of the Psalmist. Bellarmine would haue two strings to his deceitfull and broken bow. First, saith hee, it may be answered, that the Psalmist speakes not of all Scriptures, but of the commandements onely. If this answere of his could stand for good, it would serue as a new supporter to our former assertion grounded on our Sauiours words in the seuenth of Iohn. For thus the commaundements shall not be obscure, but a lanterne vnto our feete, and if we follow them, they will be (as I haue shewed before) a perfect light vnto vs, to discerne true doctrine from false.
