And in this respect, all good commandements (not the decalogue, or these ten onely) are properly a light, whereby we may cleerely know as to auoide euill, so to discern that which is good. And by this light was Dauid conducted vnto that true wisdome which his enemies wanted. Psal. 119.98. By the commandements thou hast made me wiseser than mine enemies. But what reason had Bellarmine to thinke, that Dauid in the forementioned verse should meane the commandements onely. For there he saith plainly, thy word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is much more generall then 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 commandements or testimonies: yet Dauid saith, That he had more vnderstanding then all his teachers, not the infallible teacher that sate (if any such there were) in Moses chaire excepted. So that his commandements are a light, his testimonies a light, and his word a light. And the best interpreters, as wellSynonymous autem vsurpat, et si Hilarius neget, pro diuina lege & sapientia haec vtroque numero, legem, Mandata, statuta, viam, • udicia, testimonium, praecepta, Iustitiam, Aequitatem, Iustificationes, Sermones, Verbum, Elo quium, Veritatē. Nam vel non diffe • unt, vel cum re id • m fint, eandem{que} Dei legem doctrinamque significēt, • atione & notatione duntaxat distinguuntur, quatenus legis diuinae qualitates, notae, perfectiones, proprietates, variae sunt ac multiplices. Genebrard. com. in primā partem Psal secundū nos. 119. Vide Mollerū in eundē Psalmū. theirs, asVerbum Propheticū Lucernae comparans Apostolus Petrus, habemus, inquit, certiorē Propheticum sermonem, • ui bene facit • , intendentes veluti lucernae lucenti in obscuro loco. Quod itaque hic ait, lucerna pedibus meis verbum tuum & lun e semitis me • s verbū est quod scripturis sanctis omnibus continetur. Aug. in versum Psalmi citatum, Lucernā pedib. &c. ours, take these words, Testimonies,
Precepts, Commaundements, Words, promiscuously throughout this whole Psalme. Any one of these (most of all the most generall of all words) signifie at least all Scripture which serues for mans direction, in the way of life.

3 None can be restrained to the Decalogue onely. This Bellarmine saw well enough. Wherefore his second answere is; It may (it must) be granted, that he speakes of all, or rather of the whole Scripture. But the Scriptures, saith he, are called a lanterne and a light, non quia facilè intelligantur, not because they are perspicuous and easie to be vnderstood, sed quia intellectae cum fuerint illustrant mentem, but because when they are vnderstood, they illuminate the minde or vnderstanding. Thus much wee haue said before, and still doe grant, that the Scriptures are not plaine, & easie vnto all, liue they as they list: nor do they shine vnto such, as are blinded in the pride, vanitie, or corruption of their hearts: yet a light in themselues, and a light to all that loue not darknesse more than light. A light, not after they are vnderstood, for The enterance into thy w • rds sheweth light, and giueth vnderstanding vnto the simple. Psalm. 119. vers. 130. & vers. 104. By thy precepts I haue gotten vnderstanding: therefore I hate all the wayes of falshoode. From which words Saint Augustine gathers this doctrine. A mandatis tuis intellexi. Aliud est mandata tua intellexi, aliud està mandatis tuis intellexi. Nescio ergo quid aliud se significet intel lexisse a mandatis Dei, quod est, quantum mihi videtur, faciendo mandata Dei, peruenisse se dicit ad carum rerum intelligentiam quas concupiuerit scire: propter quod scriptum est, concupisti sapientiam, serua mandata, & Dominus praebet eam tibi, ne qui quam praeposterus antequam habeat humilitatem obedientiae, velit ad altitudinem sapientiae peruenire, quam capere non p • test, n si ordine venerit. Audiat ergo • tiora te ne quaesieris, & fortiora te ne scrutatus fueris, sed quae pracipit tibi Dominus, ill • cogita semper. Sic homo ad occultorum sapientiam peruenit per obedientiam mandatorum. Cum autem dixisset, quae bi praecipit dominus ill • cog ta: ideo addidit, semper, quia & custodienda est obedientia, vt percipiatur sapientia, & percepta sapientia, non est deserenda obedientia. Dauid got true vnderstanding by their light: whose propertie is as well to shew the way how to auoid that blindnesse, which causeth them seeme obscure, as to illuminate the cleare sighted. For as by the Sunne we see what bodies are not transparent or penetrable by its light: so by Scriptures we discerne what bee the obstacles that hinder the intromission of their splendour, (in it selfe, and for it selfe most apparent,) into our hearts. And the glimpse of their scattered beames, appearing through the chinkes and ruptures of that veile of corruption, which nature hath wouen about the eie-sight of our soules, doth enlighten vs so farre as we beginne to desire the veiles remoueall, that we way haue a full fruition of their maruellous and comfortable light: as men in the morning after long and irksome darknesse (vnlesse desirous with the sluggard in the Prouerbe to haue a little more sleepe) are occasioned to open their windowes, when they see the Sunne-beames appeare in at the chinkes. My meaning is, those precepts
whereof I spake before [to learne hum litie and me • knesse, G • ds threatnings to sinners, his sweete promises to the penitent, to pray for wis • dome from aboue, and infinite other like] are so perspicuous and cleare, that they cannot but finde entrance into enueiled, if not withall malitiously wilfull or sluggish heartes: and finding entrance, can • ot but suggest considerations Rom. 13. vers. 11 12.13. what their former life hath beene, and whereunto their now professed hopes doe call them, that now it is time they should arise from sle • pe, seeing saluation draweth nearer then when they first beleeued, that the night is p • st, and the day at hand, therefore time to cast away the workes of darknesse, and put on the armour of light, to wa • ke honestly as in the day, not in gluttony and drunkennesse, neither in chambering and wantonn • sse, nor in strife and enuie. Vnto hearts thus prepared the Scriptures neede no other commendation then their owne, no infallible proposers authoritie to illustrate or confirme their truth, more then the Sun doth a more glorious starre to manifest his brightnesse vnto men indued with perfect sight. For vnto such as walke like children of the Gospels light, nothing necessarie to their soules health can be hid in darknesse; not the day of destruction, which shall come as a snare vpon other inhabitants of the earth, can1. Thes. 5.23. steale vpon them as a theefe in the night.

4 But vnto infidels, haughtie and proud-minded men, vnto such as delight in sinne, and loue to sleepe in sinfull pleasures, vnto such as scorne to be controlled in their courses, the light of Gods word, if it once shine, or send some scattered raies into their hearts, it shines not so againe, f • r they draw a curtaine, and spread the veile, least further intromission of such beames might interrupt their pleasant sleepe. This did Luther well teach (had hee beene as well vnderstood) that the Scripture was only obscure or difficult vnto infidels or proud mindes. But Bellarmine Bel lib. de verbo dei. cap. 1. replies, At certè Dauid non erat superbus aut infidelis: Surely Dauid was neither a proud man, nor an infidell, and yet the Scripture was obscure and difficult to him. Let him bee accounted both, that thinkes Dauid was either, a proud man or an infidell. But the question is not whether he were, but what was the cause hee was not such: was it not
• salm. 19. vers. 7. the perfection of Gods law which did conuert his soule? was it not the certaintie of Gods testimonies
that gaue wisedome vnto his simplicitie? Yes, by these precepts hee had gotten vnderstanding to hate all the waies of falshood.
Psal. 119. v. 104
Vers. 92. And except that law had beene his delight, he had perished in his affliction. Videbat Lutherus posse obijci, vnde sint tot controuersiae, si scriptura est tam • lara: duo eff • gia excogitauit, vnum, quod scriptura, etiamsi alicubi sit obscura, tamen illud idem alibi clarè proponit. Alterum, quod scriptura, licet per se clarissima, tamen superbis & infid • libus sit obscura ob eorum coecitatem, & prauum afctum. Add • t Brentius in proleg. Contra Petrum à Soto tertium effugium, quod etiam in terdum sit obscura, p • opter phrases al enae linguae, id est, Hebraicae & Graecae, tamen sensus eius clarissimus sit. Quae sententia manifeste falsa est: nam scriptura ipsa de sua difficultate atque obscuritate testimonium perhibet. Psal. 118. Dae mihi intellectum, & scrutabor legenit • am. Ibid. Reuela oculos meos, & considerabo mirabilia de lege tua. Ibid. Faciem tuam illumina super seruum tuum, & doce me iustificationes tuas. Et certè Dauid nouerat totam scripturā, quae tunc erat, & nouerat phrases linguae Hebraicae, nec erat superbus aut infid • lis. Bellarm. lib. 3. de verbo Dei cap. 1. Bellarmine would proue the S • riptures to be obscure, because Dauid praies to God for the right vnderstanding of them. And Valentian would perswade vs to relie vpon the Churches infallible authoritie, because it is a hard matter to pray vnto God (as Saint Augustine did) for the gift of interpretation His words are these: Quid autem precatio ad Deum pro sapientiae interpretationis{que} scripturae deno? An exigua difficultas est & piè & perseueranter illud cum eodem Augustino lib. 11. Confess. cap 2 orare: Domine attende &c Valent tom. 3. disp. 1. quaest. 1. § 4. These words of Valentian immediatly follow his former obseruation vpon S. Austen, noted Paragraph. 11. chap. 3. l. F. How then doth Bellarmine proue that law was obscure to him, which as hee himselfe confesseth Psal. 19. v 8 had giuen light vnto his eyes. If it were not, why did he pray to God to vnderstand it? Then I perceiue the Iesuites drift in this present controuersie is to establish a rule of faith so easie and infallible as might direct in all the waies of truth without prayer to God, or any helpe from heauen. Such a one, it seemes, they desire as all might vnderstand at the first sight, though liuing as luxuriously as their Popes, or minding worldly matters as much as their Cardinalles: Nisi v • lint nimium esse caeci, vnlesse they would, as Valentian speakes, desire to bee blinde.

5 Surely more blinde then beetles must they be that can suffer themselues to be perswaded, that euer God or Christ would haue a rule for mans direction, in the mysteries of saluation, so plaine & easie, as he should not need to be beholden to his maker and redeemer, for the true and perfect vnderstanding of it. This is a wisedome and gift, which commeth onely from aboue, and must be daily and earnestly sought for at the hands of God: who (we may rest assured) wil be alwaies more readie to grant our petitions herein with lesse charges, then the Pope to giue his decisions in a doubtfull case. Had Dauid asked this wisedome of him that sate in Moses chaire, we might suspect the Pope might be sued vnto. But Dauids God is our God, his Lord, our Christ, our Redeemer, and hath spoken more plainly vnto vs then vnto Dauid, who yet by his meditations on Gods written lawes, added light to Moses writings, as later Prophets haue done to his. All which in respect of the Gospels brightnesse are but as lights shining
in darke places: yet euen the least conspicuous amongest them, such as will giue manifest euidence against vs to our eternall condemnation, if wee seeke this wisedome from any others then Christs, his Prophets and Apostles doctrine, by any other meanes or mediatourship, then Dauid did his, From Gods lawe written by Moses.

6 Let vs now see what Valentian can say vnto the fore cited Psal. 119. vers. 105. testimonie, and to that Pet. 1. v. 19. other like vnto it. [Wee haue also a most sure word of the Prophets, to the which yee doe well that yee take heede, as vnto a Yet might the Prophets writings, if any place of Scripture seeme obscure. light that shineth in a darke place, vntill the day dawne, and the day-Starre ariseth in your hearts.] Concedimus igitur pari modo, sacras literas, quae diuinae doctrinae cōtinent lumen, tanquam lucernam esse per se ipsam splendidissimam semper, atque fulgentissimam. Sed nobis tamen considerandum est, quomodo sit hoc lumen non in se modo lucidum, verùm etiam (vt regiu • Propheta Psal. 18. d • cit) illuminans ocul • s. Nunquid q • a ratione vnusqu • s{que} ingenij proprij atque industriae suae finib. illud tanquam modo quodam ex guo camprehendit? M nimè ve • ò, sed quatenus est diuinitus in Ecclesiae Catholicae authoritate tanquam in candelabro positum, vt luceat ombus qui in domo sunt, Mat. 5. Hanc enim Ecclesiae authoritatem docebimus postea suo loco, esse in vniuersum iudicem atque magistram fidei viuam: idcirco necesse est, vt lumen illud fidei, quod in diuinis literis splendet, praeferat ipsa atque ostendat omnibus, qui ad eam aggregantur, in eaque manent, licet incruditi sint al • oqui, nec valea • t • psi per se aspicere lumen illud, vt in ipsis literis sanctis tanquam in lucerna continetur. Valent. Tom. 3. disp. 1. punct. 7. §. 4.
It is true (saith the Doctor) the word of God is a light, and this light is cleare and illuminates the eyes. But it must bee considered, how it comes to enlighten our eyes: Doe you suppose that it effects this, in as much as euery man doth comprehend it, within the bounds of his priuate wit, or industrie, as it were in a little bushell? Nothing lesse. But it effects it, as it is placed in the authoritie of the Catholicke Church, as in a d Candlesticke, where it may giue light to all that are in the house. For we shall shew (saith he) in due place, that this authoritie of the Church is the liuing iudge and mistresse of faith. And therefore is it necessarie, that shee should carie this light, which is contained in holy writ, and shew it vnto all, that associate themselues to her, and remaine in her bosome; although they be vnlearned men, and such as are not able by themselues to behold this light, as it is contained in the Scriptures as in a lanthorne.

7 Hee that could find in his heart to spend his groate, or goe a mile to see a Camel daunce a ligge; let him but lay his finger on his mouth, that hee spoyle not the Pageant with immoderate laughing, and he may (without any further cost, or paines) bee partaker of as prettie a sport, to see a grande demure Schoole Diuine, laying aside his wonted habit of metaphysicall proofe, turned Doctor Similitude on a suddaine, and swaggering it in the metaphoricall cut. For what one ioynt, or straine is there, in this long labourious vaste similitude, that doth any way incline
vnto the least semblance of truth: or can be drawne, to illustrate any such meaning, as this man intended; or any way to breake the force of our writers arguments, drawne from the forecited places? For, first, what semblance is there betweene a priuate mans interpretation, or comprehension of Scripture-sence, and the putting of a light or candle vnder a bushell? For what though some one, some fewe, or more such men, will apprehend this or that to be the full meaning of some controuersed place in Scripture? I am (by our Churches doctrine) no more bound to beleeue them, then I am to beleeue the Pope of Rome, whom I neuer saw, nor knew. I am bound to beleeue neither of them more, then if they should tell me, that the whole light of that candle which shines alike to all, were o • ely comprehended in their eyes. For by our doctrine I may behold the same light of Scriptures, which they doe, as freely as they; iudge of it by mine owne eyes and sence as well as they; not onely submit my sence and iudgement vnto theirs. But if we should (as this Iesuite would haue vs) permit the iudgement of all Scripture-sence, wholly and irreuocably vnto the Pope and his Cardinals; as if their Consistorie were the compleate Hemisphere, or rather the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
spheare, the whole Spheare wherein this heauenly Lampe doth shine: then indeede we should see no more of it light then we could of a Candle put vnder a bushell, or locked vp in some close roome; In which case we might beleeue others, that it did shine there still, but whether it did so or no, we could not iudge by our owne eyes. And in like manner would this Doctor perswade vs, that we should iudge of this light of Scriptures, onely by the testimonie or authoritie of such, as see it shine in the Consistorie at Rome, not with our own eies. Had the Lord permitted but one graine of good wit to haue remained in this bushell of branne, not impudency in graine could without blushing haue offered to accuse our Church for hiding the light of Scriptures vnder a bushell; when as we contend, the free vse of it should be permitted to the whole congregation. But he disputeth of the light, as blinde men may of colours. He liued at Ingolstade, and the light of Gods word was at Rome lockt vp within the compasse of the Consistorie, for that he could not see to make his comparison of it. Secondly, what proportion is there betweene the Churches authoritie, (such authoritie as hee
claimes for his Church) and a Candlesticke? Let the Consistory be supposed the Candlesticke, wherein the word of God doth shine as a light or candle. Doth it indeed shine there? vnto whom? To all that will associate themselues to that Church? Come then, let euery man exhort his neighbour to repaire to the mountaine of the Lord. Shall we there immediatly see the truth of Scriptures, clearely and distinctly with our owne eyes, because the Pope, or Trent-Councel holds out vnto vs the books of Canonical Scripture? May priuate spirits discerne their true sense in matters of faith, as clearely as if they were a light indeed to thee? Oh no, you quite mistake his meaning, in making such collections? Let Valentian explicate himselfe in the ende of this fourth paragraph.

8Posteaquā Ecclesia sententiā aliquam ex scriptura colligit, scripturamque prouide, vt est à se secundum Apostolicam tradition • m intellecta, contrarijs erroribus opponit: summa improbitas est, al • quid praeterea desiderare in eiusmodi scripturae vel authoritate, vel interpretatione, quocunque id fiat siue diffcultatis siue obscuritatis praetextu. Quae enim scriptura per authoritatē Ecclesiae commendatur, explicaturque, ea iam hoc ipso & maximè est authentica, & splendidissimè clar • ssime{que} lucet, tanquam lucerna, videlicet (vt supra exponebamus) pofita super candelabrū. Tom. 3. disp. 1. quaest. 1. punct. 7. §. 4.
After the Church hath once gathered any opinion out of Scriptures, and thereupon opposeth the Scripture (thus vnderstood by it, according to the Apostolicall traditions,) vnto contrarie errors: It is extreme impietie and wickednesse to desire any more, (eyther concerning the authoritie or interpretation of that parcell of Scripture,) vnder what pretence soeuer, of difficultie, obscuritie, or the like. For that Scripture (I pray marke his words well) which is commended and expounded vnto vs by the authoritie of the Church, that Scripture now (ea iam) euen for this reason (hoc ipso) is most authenticke, and shines most splendently, most clearly, like a light, videlicet, as wee haue formerly expounded, put vpon a Candlesticke: Nay in good sooth, iust like a Candlesticke put vpon a light or candle. For in this countrey wherein we liue, we see the Candlesticke by vertue of the light, not the light by meanes or vertue of the Candlesticke. And yet if your Church be the Candlesticke, as you suppose, and the Scripture the light (as you expresly acknowledge:) we must by your doctrine discerne the light of Scriptures, onely by the commendation, explication, or illumination of your Church, the Candlesticke. And this illumination is onely her bare asseueration, for Scriptures she seldome expounds, but onely by negatiues or Anathemees. The best correction that can be made of this vntoward, crooked, vnwieldy similitude, would be this: wheras this Doctor supposeth the Pope to be the Church, and saith further, necesse est vt lumen illud fidei quod in diuinis literis splendet praeferat Ecclesia: Let him put lucem for lumen, and so the Pope
(being by his assertion the Church) may be truly called Lucifer. And then, as, when cloth shrinkes in the wetting, men shape their garments accordingly, making sometimes a Ierkin of that which was intended for a Iacket: so out of this vnhandsome ill-spunne similitude, which was marred in the making, we may frame a shorter, which will hold exceeding well, on this fashion: Euen as Sathan, being the Prince of darknesse, doth to mens seeming transforme himselfe into an Angell of light: Iust so doth the Roman Lucifer, being (by Valentians confession) but the Candlesticke, labour to transforme himselfe into the light it selfe; and would be taken for such a light or Candle, as should make the very light of heauen it selfe (Gods word) to shine most splendently and clearly by the glorious beames of his maiesticall infallibilitie once cast vpon it. For otherwise, vnlesse the supernaturall glory of his infallibilitie do infuse light, or adde fresh lustre to this light, or lanterne of truth, the Candlesticke naturally giues no increase of perspicuitie to the light or candle, Which wil shine as cleare in a priuate mans hands, (so he wil take the paines to hold it,) as in a publike Candlesticke. But that which I would haue the serious reader to obserue especial y, is this speech of his, Scripture,Quae scripturae per aut • oritatē Ecclesiae commendatur explicaturque, ea iam hoc ipso, & maximè auth • ntica est, & splendidiss • mè clarissime{que} lucet. as once commended vnto vs, or expounded by the Churches authoritie becomes therby most authenticke, & shines most clearly, & most splendently. For this same Doctor, (if a Doctor may be said the same, affirming and denying the same,) in the beginning of that dispute would gladly shuffle so, as he should not bee taken with that tricke, which will discredite their cause for euer, and descrie their villanous blasphemie in this doctrine of their Churches authoritie. There he would perswade vs, that he doth not allow of this speech [I beleeue this or that to be a diuine reuelation, because the Church doth tell me so:] or of this; [the Church is the cause, why I beleeue the diuine reuelations:] whereas this speech of his, (Quae Scriptura per authoritatē,) doth inferre the authoritie of the Church to be the verie principall, and immediate cause of our assents vnto Scriptures.

9 Secondly I would haue the sober Christian Reader to obserue, what an vnhallowed and vnchristian conceit it is, to admit the Scriptures for a lanterne and yet to affirme that Christians cannot behold the light therin contained, but only as the Church
of Rome doth hold it out, what is this else, but to call the people from the maruailous lightYet haue the the Papists in times of darknesse borne the people in hand that the Bible was the holy mount which no man might approch but the Priest. of the Gospell, vnto the feareful lightnings of the law? And to make the Pope that mediator, which the people implicitely did request Exod. 20. v. 19 when they desired that Moses might speake to them, not God. If we be in Christ, then are we not called into Mount Sinai, to burning fire, blindnesse, darknesse, and tempests; this light of the Gospell is not enuironed with a fearefull cloud, or smoake, threatning destruction if wee should go vp into the mount to heare the Lord himselfe speake: we haue an aduocate with the Father, and need not looke for a Moses to go vp for vs, while we stand trembling a farre off. For as our Apostle tels vs, Heb. 12. v. 22 We are come vnto the Mount Sion, and to the Citie of the liuing God, the celestiall Ierusalem, and to the company of innumerable Angels, and to the congregation of the first-borne, which are written in heauen, and to God the Iudge of all, and to the spirits of iust and perfect men, and to Iesus the Mediator of the new Testament, and to the bloud of sprinkling, that speaketh better things then that of Abel. What is the consequence, or effect of this our challenge? Our Vers. 28. Apostle makes this inference, See therefore that yee despise not him that speaketh. Whom did he meane? The Pope, or Cardinals? But they would be but of like authority as Moses was? but he that speaketh vnto vs, is of farre greater. For so our Apostle collects, See that yee despise not him that speaketh: for if they escape not, which refused him, that spake on earth, much more shall we not escape, if we turne away from him which speaketh from heauen. The Israelites I suppose had despised Moses, if they had admitted any other infallible teacher besides him, whilst he was aliue, or belieued any other, as well as his writings, after his death, but only so farre forth, as they could discerne their words to bee consonant vnto his. If Moses writings were to these Iewes a plaine rule of faith, then much more must Christs word, registred by his Apostles and Euangelists, be the rule of faith vnto vs. That Moses doctrine was their rule of faith, a rule most plaine and easie, these places following abundantly testifie.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
That the Mosaicall writings were a most perfect rule, plaine and easie to the ancient Israelites.
div.p:
1 SO perfect directions had Moses left for posterities perpetuall instruction, that a greatThe author of the the 78. Psalme. Ʋers. 3. & 4. Prophet in later ages, desirous to bring Gods people into the right pathes which their fathers had forsaken, and for this purpose Sasbout vpon those words of S. Paul. 2. Tim. 3. Thou hast knowne the holy Scriptures of a child. professing to impart to them whatsoeuer he had heard or learned, from his godly ancestors: doth but trace out the Prints of Moses footsteps, almost obliterate & ouergrown by the sloth and negligence of former times wherein euery man had trod what way he liked best. And though the same Prophet descend to later ages as low as Dauids; Yet he proceeds still by the same rule, relating nothing but such historicall euents or experiments as confirme the truth of Moses diuine predictions, such as are yet extant in Canonicall Scriptures. So perfect and absolute in his iudgement, was that part of the old Testament which then was written, Deut. 6. v. 6.7.8. to instruct not onely the men such as hee was, but euery child of God, that he presumes not to know or teach more then in it was written. And thus much this people should haue done by Moses precept, without a Prophet for their remembrancer. And these words which I commaund thee this day, shall be in thine heart. And thou shalt rehearse them continually vnto thy children, and shalt talke of them when thou tarriest in thine house, and as thou walkest by the way, and when thou liest downe, and when thou risest vp. And thou shalt bind thē for a signe vpon thine hand, and they shall be as f • ontlets betweene thine eyes. Also thou shalt write them vpon the postes of thine house, and vpon thy gates.
Deut. 32. v. 46. And againe, Set your hearts vnto all the words, which I command you this day, that you may command them vnto your children, that they may obserue, and doe all the words of this law. For it is no vaine word concerning you, but it is in your life: and by this word you shall prolonge your daies.

2 Questionlesse they that were bound to obserue, and doe this law, were bound to know it; and yet Moses referres them not
to his successor, as if it were so obscure, that it could not possibly be knowne without his infallibility; but on the contrarie, he supposeth it so plaine and easie, that euery Father might instruct his sonne in it, and euery Mother her daughter. It was their owne daily experience of the fruits and benefits in obeying, of their harmes & plagues in disobeying his precepts, which was to seale their truth vnto their consciences. For without such obseruation, without squaring their liues, and comparing their thoughts, and actions vnto this straight and plaine rule, all other testimonies of men, or authorities of their most infallible teachers were in vaine. The miracles which they had seene to day, were quite forgotten ere nine daies after. Nor could their perswasions, or conceit of Moses infallibilitie, serue them for any rule, when they had shaken off these inward cogitations, and measured not the truth of his predictions by experiments. In their temptations they were as readie to disclaime Moses, as alwaies they were to distrust God whose mightie wonders they had seene. To what vse then did the sight of al Gods wonders, or of miracles wrought by Moses serue? Motiues they were necessarie and excellent to incline their stubborne hearts to vse this law of God for their rule, in all their actions and proceedings: and to cause them set their hearts vnto it, as Moses in his Deut. 32. v. 46 last words commaunds them. For this lawe, as hee had tolde them Deut.
• 0. before, was in their hearts.

3 Would any man that doth feare the Lord, or reuerence his word, but set his heart to read ouer this booke of Deuteronomie, or the one hundred & nineteene, with sundry other Psalmes, but with ordinarie obseruation or attention, (that so the character of Gods Spirit, so liuely imprinted in them, might be as an amulet to preuent the Iesuites inchantments:) It would be impossible for all the wit of man or Angels, euer to fasten the least suspicion on his thoughts, whether the ancient faithfull Israelites did take this law of Moses for their infallible rule in all their proceedings. For nothing can bee made more euident, then this truth is in it selfe; That the Israelites swaruing from this rule was the cause of their departure from their God; and the occasion, or cause of their swaruing from it, was this diuellish perswasion, which Sathan suggested to them then, (as the Iesuites doe vnto the Christian people now:) As, that this law was too obscure, too hard,
too di • ficult to be vn • erstood: nor compleat rule for their actions, without traditions, or There priests authority was neuer more stood vpon, then in those times wherein Moses was in least request, & their skill in his writings as little. So in Iehoiakims daies these oppose their Pri • sts & other state-Prophets vnto Ieremy. Ier. 18. vers. 18. Then said they, Come, and let vs imagine some deuise against Ieremiah: for the law shall not perish from the Priest, nor counsell from t • e w se, nor the word from the Prophet: come let vs smite him with the tongue, and let vs not g • ue heed to any of his words. relying vpon their Priests or men in chiefe authoritie. This hypocrisie Moses did well foresee would be the beginning of all their miseries, the verie watch word to Apostasie. For which cau • e he labours so seriously to preuent it. Deut. 30. v. 11 For this commandement which I set before • hee t • is day, is not hid from thee, neither farre of, but the word is very neare vnto thee, euen in thy mouth, and in thy heart, to doe it. How was it in their mouthes and in their hearts, when it was so obscure, & difficu • t vnto them, after Moses death? It was in their hearts, and in their posteritie too, had they set their hearts to it. But as it is true, pars sanitatis est velle sanari. It is a part of health to be willing to be healed; so was it heere pars morbi, nolle s • nari, more then a part of this their grieuous d sease, (their blindnesse of heart,) was their pronenesse to be perswaded, that this word or doctrine, which Moses heere taught was too obscure, and difficult for them to follow. They fi • st beganne (as the Iesuites doe) to picke quarrels with God: for which their stubbornnesse he gaue them ouer to their hearts desire. And this his sacred word, which should haue beene a lanterne vnto their feete, and a light vnto their pathes, as it was to Dauids, became a1. Cor. 1. v. 23 stumbling blocke, and a stone of offence; what was the reason? By their swaruing f • om this plaine & straight rule their waies became crooked, and their actions vniust. And it is the obs • ruation of the wise sonne of Strach.
Eccles. 39, vers. 54 As Gods waies are right, and plaine vnto the iust, so are th • y stumbling b • ockes vnto the wicked. Not Moses himselfe, had hee beene then aliue, could haue made this, or any other true rule of faith, plaine vnto these Iewes, whilest they remained peruerse and stubborne. And had they (without Moses, or any infallible teachers helpe) cast off this crookednesse of heart, Moses his infallible doctrine had still remained easie, straight and plaine vnto them. For it was in their hearts, though hid and smothered in the wrinkles of their crooked hearts. In our Sauiours time, they will not assent vnto the word written, nor vnto the eternall word, vnto which all the writings of the Prophets gaue testimonie, vnlesse they may see a Iohn. 6 v. 30.31. 1.
• or 1. v 22. signe; What was the cause? They had not laide Moses commaund • mentes to their hearts. For Iohn 5. v. 46. had they (from their hearts)

• crimen: simul etiam vt discant legem spiritualiter intelligere, & inueniant in ea Christum, per quem iudicem facienda est inter bonos & malos ipsa ducretio. Non enim frustra idem Dominus ait Iudaeis, si crederetis Moisi, crederetis & mi • i. De me enim ille sc ipsit. Carnaliter quippe accip • nda legem, & eius promissa terrena rerum coe • estium figuras esse •• scientes in illa • urmura co • ruerunt, vt dicere aude
• e • t: Vanus es • qui seruit Deo. Et qu • d amplius quia custodiuimus mandata eius, & quia ambulauimus simplices ante fati • n T •… mini omnipotentis. August. de ciuitate Dei. l b 20. cap. 28.
beleeued Moses, they had beleeued Christ. For all whose miracles, wrought for their good, in their sight and presence, they cannot or will not see, that his words were the words of eternal life, as Iohn. 6. vers. 68. Peter confesseth. Nor would any Iesuite haue acknowledged as much, had hee beene in their place. For why should he? Any other might say, he had the spirit of God, and that he was the Messia; and what if Peter one of his fellowes, late a fisherman, did confesse him? The Scribes and Pharisees, principall members of the visible Church, denie him to be their Messias. And how should they know his words to be the word of God, vnlesse the Church had confirmed them? If Christ himselfe should haue said in their hearing as he did to the Matth. 22. v •
2. Iewes. Moses wrote of me, consider his d •
ctrine, and lay it to your hearts: A Iesuite would haue replied, you say Moses wrote of you; But how shall we know that he meant you? Moses is dead, and saies nothing, and they that sit in his chaire say otherwise. And verily the Scribes and Pharisees had farre greater probabilities to plead for the infallibility of that chaire, then the Iesuites can haue for their Popes: who, had they beene in the others place, could haue coyned more matter out of that one saying of our Sauiour, Iohn. 7. vers. 48.49. Sedent in Cathedra Mosis, for the Scribes and Pharisees infallible authority, then all the Papists in the world haue beene able to extract out of all the Scriptures that are or can bee vrged, for the Pope, or Church of Romes infallibilitie.

4 The Scribes and Pharisees (though no way comparable to the Iesuites, for cunning in painting rotten, or subtiltie in oppugning causes true and sound) could vrge for themselues, agai •• t such as confessed Christ, that none of the rulers, nor of t • e Pharisees did beleeue in him; but only a cursed crew of Iohn. 7. vers. 48.49. such as knew not the law. They could obiect the lawe was obscure, and the interpretation of it did belong to them. But could these pretences excuse the people for not obeying Christs doctrine? You will say (perhaps) they could not be •… excused, because Christs miracles were so many and manifest. These were somewhat indeed, if Christ had beene their accuser.
But ourOur Sauiours miracles & maner of life, so fully su able to Mosaical types & predictiō • of him, condēned the Iewes of wilful malice & affected blindnesse for not laying Moses law vnto their hearts, whose spirituall sense would haue brought forth the light of the Gospell therin contained as the branch in the roote. So that Moses condemns thē immediatly because he was their s • holmaster, and would haue • aught thē Christ, so they wold haue practised his rul • s which they acknowledged Christs miracles condemne them mediatly, and leaues them without excuse for n • t looking more narrowly into the spirituall sense of Moses writings which would haue inlightned thē to ha • e discerned the gl • ry of Christ & hi • Gospel in his works So as there is no contradiction but subordination betwixt those places which tell vs Christs works d d condemn thē, & others wherin Mo • es o • the Prophet •
〈◊〉 said to condemne or leaue thē without excuse. Sauiour saith plainly, that he would not accuse them to his Father. And for this cause he would not worke many miracles amongst such as were not moued with the like alreadie wrought, least he should increase their sins. If Christ did not, who then had reason to accuse them? Moses, as it is in the same place, did: Moses, in whom they trusted, and on whom they fastened their implicite faith: Moses, of whom they thought and said, we wil beleeue as he beleeued: Moses, whose doctrine they (to their seeming) stood as stifly for, against Christs new doctrine, (as they supposed) as the Iesuits do for the Catholike Church (as they thinke) against heretikes & sectaries, as they terme vs. Why then is Moses, whom thus they honored, become their chiefe accuser? because while they did beleeue on him only for tradition, or from pretence of succession, or for the dignity of their temple, Church, or Nation, they did not indeed beleeue him, nor his doctrine. For had they beleeued his doctrine they had beleeued Christ. For he wrote of Christ. So he might (thinks the Iesuite) and yet write so obscurely of him as his writings could bee no rule of faith to the Iewes without the visible Churches authority Yea rather they should & might haue beene a rule vnto them for their good, against the visible Churches authority, and now remaine a rule or law against both, to their iust condemnation, because the doctrine of Christ was so plainly and clee • ly set downe in these writings, had they set their hearts vnto them. Euen the knowledge of Christ, the word of life it selfe, was in their mouthes & in their hearts. For that commandement which Moses there gaue them, was that word of faith, which S. Paul the infallible teacher of the Gentiles did preach, as he himself b testifies. If any man aske how this place was so easie to bee vnderstood of Christ, or how by the doctrine of Moses law the doctrine of the Gospell might haue beene manifested to their consciences: my answere is already set downe in our Sauiours words; had they done Gods wil (reuealed vnto them in that law) they should haue knowne Christs doctrine to haue beene of God.

5 Had they, according to the prescript of Moses law, repented them of their sins from the bottome of their hearts, the Lord had blotted all their wickednesse out of his remembrance. And th • ir hearts once purged of wickednes, would haue exulted in his presence
that had made them whole; faith would haue fastened vpon his person though neuer seene be • ore. Malach. cap. 4. vers. 2.3.4. But vnto you that feare my name shall the sonne of righteousnes arise, & health shall be vnder his wings, and ye shall go forth and grow vp as fat calues. 2. And ye shal tread downe the wicked: for they shall be dust vnder the soles of your feete in the day that I shall doe this, saith the Lord of Hostes. 3. Remember the lawe of Moses my seruant, which I commaunded vnto him in Horeb in all Israell, with the statutes and iudgements. Not the Moone more apt to receiue the sun beams cast vpon it, then these Iewes hea • ts to haue shined with the glorie of Christ, had they cast aw • y al •… pride, and self-conceit, or the glory of their nation: but vnto t •… (as now they are, & long time haue been) swollen with pride, a 〈◊〉 full of hypocrisie, Christs glory is but as cleare light to sore • r dimme-sighted eyes: They winke with their eyes, least 〈◊〉 should bee offended with the splendour of it. This doct • i • e • f Christ, and knowledge of Scriptures in points of faith, shall bee most obscure to vs, if we follow them in their foolish pre • en •• s of their visible Church: most cleare, perspicuous, and easie, if we lay Moses commaundements to our hearts. For truth inherent must bee as the eye-sight, to discerne all other things of like nature.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Concluding this controuersie according to the state proposed, with the testimonie of Saint Paul.
div.p:
1 WE may conclude this point with our2. Cor. 4 vers. 3.4. Apostle; Si Euangelium nostrum tectum est, ijs qui p • reunt tectum est: in quibus Deus huius saeculi excaecau • t mentes, id est, infidelibus, ne irradiat eos lumen Euangelij gloriae Christi, qui est imago Dei. If the Gospell be obscure, or rather hid, (For it is a light, obscure it cannot be, God forgiue me if I vsed that speech, saue onely in our aduersaries persons) It is hid onely to such as haue the eyes of their mind •… blinded by Sathan, the God of this world. Of which number, may we not (without breach of charitie) thinke hee was one, who seeing the light and euidence of this place, would not see it; but thought it a suff • cient answere to say Bell • rm. lib 3. de verb. Dei cap. 2. Resp ad 5 arg. The reason why
• ellarmine with his f • llowes and many oth • r g • eat schollers besides, make such hypocriticall gl • sses of Scriptures p • a • nl • teaching what th • y denie, is their not consid • ring that the same inord • nate affections w • i • h made the Iewes to reiect the very hist •• i •
〈◊〉 truth or letter of the Gospel, mak • s such as admit it content thēselues with it onely, neuer looking in • o the m • aning of the spiri • , • f it once contradict their desires. Of this fallacy in the 3. sect. of the 4. boo •• . Apostolus non loquitur
de intelligentia scripturarum, sed de cognitione & fide in Christum; The Apostle speakes not of vnderstanding Scriptures, but of knowing and beleeuing in Christ. It is well the Iesuite had so much modestie in him as to grant this later, that he spake at the least of knowing Christ. For if the knowledge of Christ be so cleere to the godly and elect then are the Scriptures cleare too, so farre as concernes their faith. For Saint Paul wrote this, and all his Epistles, onely to this end, that men might truly come to the knowledge of Christ. But hee meant of a perfect and true knowledge, not such as Bellarmine (when hee gaue this answere) dreamed of; vt neque sit puer, neque anus Christiana, quae non sciat Christum natum, & incarnatum fuisse. Saint Pauls Gospell was sufficiently knowne (in this mans sense of his wordes) because there is neyther Christian childe, nor old wife, but knowes that Christ was incarnate and borne. Too many I feare of his, and his fellowes catechizing, know Christ no otherwise, then olde wiues, or little children know ordinarie matters or stories past, that is, onely by olde wiues tales, lying Legends, or tradition. And on this fashion, and better, did the Iewes know Moses, and beleeued on him; yet did they neyther know him, nor his doctrine, as they should haue done, nor in such a sense, as the Scripture vseth this word Knowledge. Such as hee would haue vs content our selues withall is rather blindnesse then knowledge, and makes a man neuer a whit the better Christian, but a grea er hypocrite.

2 Let Bellarmines answere stand thus farre for true, that the knowing of Christ, and beliefe of the Gospell, are manifest to all, that are not giuen ouer to Iewish blindnesse. And what it is to know Christ, or beleeue the Gospell, in Saint Pauls phrase, (by Gods assistance) wee shall further explicate in the Articles following. To know Christ, was all Saint Paul desired, because it contayned all knowledge of Scriptures: and whether Saint Paul did not desire to know Scriptures, or whether he had not his desire herein, let Christian consciences iudge.

3 And because I must conclude this poynt, (as I promised) with this testimonie of Saint Paul: Beloued Christian whosoeuer thou art, that shalt reade these meditations, aske counsell of
thine owne heart, consult with thy conscience, consider well, and giue sentence betwixt mee and this Romish Doctor, what kinde of knowledge Saint Paul heere meant: whether an implicite or here-say knowledge of Christ and his Kingdome in grosse, or an expresse, distinct, true knowledge (raised from Moses and the Prophets consonancie with the Gospel) of Scriptures necessarie to mens saluation in their seuerall courses of life. I will not wrong thy iudgement so much, as to seeke argumentes, or authorities of Expositors, for thy information in this plaine vndoubted case. It shall suffi • e to rehearse the wordes of that law, about whose sense wee now contend, and by which wee must bee tried; from the twelfth verse of the third, to the sixth verse of the fourth Chapter of the second to the Corinthians.

4 Seeng then wee haue such trust, wee vse great boldnesse of speech, and wee are not as Moses, which put a veile vpon his face, that the children of Israel should not looke vnto the end of that which should be abolished. Therefore their mindes are hardened. For vntill this day remaineth the same couering vntaken away in the rea • ing of the old Testament. Yet was the old Testament the onely Scripture in those times easie to bee vnderstood, but for his veile. And this veile (as the Apostle addes, verse the fourteenth) put away, these Scriptures then which were so difficult to the Iew, are easie to all that are in Christ, by whose death the veile was rent, and that light which shone on Mos • s face as the Sunne vppon the Easterne skie in the dawning, was fully manifested to the inhabitants of the earth since the Sunne of righteousnesse d • d appeare. For the publishing of the Gospell is the putting away of the former veile. But for the Iewes euen vntill this day, (saith the Apostle,) When Moses is reade, the veile is laid ouer their heartes.
Vers. 1 • . Vers. 30 vers. 8. Neuerthelesse when their hearts shall bee turned vnto the Lord, the veile shall bee taken away. For this doctrine of Saint Paul (as often hath beene said) was in their hearts, Deut. 30. ver. 11 and in their mouthes.

The Apostle concludes, Now the Lord is the Spirit, and where the Spirit of the Lord is,
Iohn. 15. v. 15 there is libertie: Libertie indeed in respect of that seruitude which was vnder the lawe; then they
were Vers. 18. seruants because they knew not their Masters will; but since the ministerie of the new Testament, Wee all behold as in a mirrour, the g • o • ie of the Lord w th open face. Out of our Apostles d • scourse, this is most euident, that it was the glorie of his ministerie. and eui • ence of doctrine which made him so confident, in the execution of this function. God (saith hee) hath made vs able Min • sters of the new Testament, not of the letter,
Chap. 3. v. 6. but of the spirit: And this, compared with the ministerie of the old, did farre exceede it in glorie and perspicuitie, as he proues from the sixt verse to the eighteene.

5 The iudicious Reader, though not admonished,Cum enim scriptu • am obscuram esse dicimus, non vitium aliquod in doctrinâ ipsâ diuinitus, tradita inesse sentimus, sed maiestatem atque altitudinem potius eiusmodi sapientiae & scientiae Dei, & imbecillitatem ingenij nostri profitemur. Valent. tom. 3. dup. 1. quaest. 1. punct. 7. §. 4. Chap. 4. vers. 1. Ʋers. 2. would of his owne accord obserue how the Apostle takes clearenesse and perspicuitie as an adiunct of the new Testamentes glorie; the Iesuites quite contrarie would make the Scriptures dignitie and maiestie mother of difficultie and obscuritie. But because it was so much more glorious and perspicuous then the ministerie of the old Testament was, The Apostle inferres: Therefore, seeing wee haue this ministerie of the new Testament, (so glorious and perspicuous) as wee haue receiued mercie, wee faint not; but haue cast • ff the cloake of shame, and walke not in craftinesse, neyther handle wee the word of God deceitfully (for why should any when it will approoue it selfe) but in declaration of the truth approoue our selues to euery mans conscience in the sight of God. What proofe could hee make to their consciences, but onely from the euidence of that truth which hee taught, and his sinceritie in teaching it? These two would binde all such as made any conscience of their waies to admit his doctrine. Whence hee inferres in the verie next words. If then our Gospell be hid, &c:
Vers. 3. Briefely refuting all the Romanistes obiections in this argument, before they we • e conceiued, punctim, euen to an haires breadth. For this would haue beene their common place, had they liued in Saint Pauls time. You may boast and say your doctrine of the newe Testament is euident and manifest, but what wise man will beleeue you, when a great many, as good schollers as your selfe, thinke the contrarie most true. Vnto this obiection of the Ie • es then, of the Iesuites now, of Sathan both now and then, and alwaies frequent in the mouth of Hell, our Apostle answeres
directly, as from his doctrine wee haue done all the Iesuites arguments.) If the Gospell bee hid, (as in deede to some (too many) it is) Yet is it hid onely to them that perish, whose mindes the God of this world hath blinded, that the glorious Gospell of Christ, which is the image of God, should not shine vnto them.

6 The Gospell then did shine, yet not to blinded eyes; to whome then? onely to such as were indued with the spirit of libertie: seeing the new Testament, as hee said, was the ministerie of the spirit, of which these Iewes were not partakers, because they followed the letter or outside of the law, and had Moses writings, (as children, lessons they vnderstand not) at their tongues end, not in their hearts.

div.head: SECT. III.

That the continuall practise of Heretikes in vrging Scriptures for to establish heresie, and the diuersitie of opinions amongst the learned about the sense of them, is no iust exception, why they should not be acknowledged as the sole, entire, and compleat rule of faith.
div.p: OVT of the former discourse their other obiections are almost answered alreadie: and they bee especially two. The first, If the Scriptures be plaine and easie, how comes it to passe, that there should be such contentions amongst the learned about them? Or whence is it, that euery Heretike is so forward to vrge Scriptures for his opinion euen to the death? The second lies (as it were) in the wombe of this, (as this did in the formers) and drawne out in it proper shape, is thus. There can be no certaine meanes of taking vp controuersies or contentions in the Church, but onely by admitting an infallible authority for deciding all controuersies viua uoce seeing the Scripture is alwaies made a partie on all sides, in such contentions.

2 In the former obiection they endite the Scripture as the principall: in the latter, our Church, as an abetter of such quarrels and contentions as it breedes. For our Church wee shall answere in the next: for Gods word in this present Section.

div.head: CHAP. I.
Containing the true state of the question, with the aduersaries generall obiections against the truth.
div.p:
1 IT cannot bee denied, that alwaies there haue beene, and alwaies will continue, contentions amongst learned men in points of faith, or doctrine, or about the true sense or meaning of Scriptures, in these and other cases. For thus much these Scriptures themselues doe plainly witnesse, oportet
esse haereses. 1. Cor. 11.19. 2. Pet. 2.1. For there must be heresies euen among you, that they which are approued among you, might be knowne. But the question is not whether there haue beene, now are, or alwaies shall continue many contentions about the sense of Scripture: but first, whether the Scriptures haue not plainly set downe the original causes and nurses of such contentions, and the meanes how to auoid them, so men will be ruled by them, most plaine for this purpose: or, secondly, whether, not submitting their wils, desires and affections vnto these plaine and perspicuous rules of life, this supposed infallible rule of the Romish Church can preuent, remoue, or compose all such contentions, according to the truth, and cause men stedfastly hold the vnitie of faith in the bond of peace.

3 The causes of contentions about the sense of Scriptures, are So Beda gathers out of Augustine. Ex ipso animali sensu (quia homo animalis non percipit quae sunt spiritus Dei) omnes dissensiones et schismata generantur. Beda in 2. Iam. 4.12. the very same with the fore-mentioned, which made the Scriptures vnto sundrie seeme obscure; or the same, which make men to mistake their true sense and meaning. For euen these warres and contentions whereof we speake (specially these) arise from lustes, which fight in our members: we lust and haue not, we enuie and haue indignation, and cannot obtaine: we fight and warre, and get nothing, (not the truth which we seeke) because we aske it not. Do not such as contend most about the true sense, aske it most? doth not euery heretike, the earnester he is, professe that he praies for the truth so much the more feruently? yea, but such men receiue not that which they so earnestly aske,
Vers. 3. because they aske it amisse. They desire skill in Scripture to aduance their owne conceits, and maintaine their foolish & carnal affections, otherwise asking they should haue, and seeking they should finde,
Matth. 7.7. especially the true sense and meaning of Gods word, which must instruct vs, how to frame all our other petitions vnto God aright.

4 These and infinite like places we acknowledge, plainly declaring thē causes of contentions, and as many more, (some of which shall be heere and there inserted) directing vs how to auoid all occasions of strife and debate. Both which if we obserue, contentions will quickly cease: Which, those not obserued, must increase, as a iust punishment of truth neglected, contradicted or low esteemed, notwithstanding the best indeuours of any authority vpon earth imaginable to the contrarie.

5 But some perhaps will demand, Is there no vse of humane
authoritie in this case? yes; As for the begetting of true and liuely faith, we suppose the liue-voice of an ordinary ministery as the Organe, whereby the written word must be conuaied to our spirits: so for retaining the vnitie of this faith in the bond of peace; for suppressing or preuenting all occasions of schismes, heresies, or contentions; we acknowledge the necessary vse of a lawfull Magistracie, yet no infallibility in eyther.The true vse of the magistracy and ministry for auoiding schismes and contentions. The proper end and vse of both is to espouse mens soules with an indissolub • e knot of loue and loyalty vnto the written word, the only infallible rule of that faith whereby they liue: the one, by vnfolding the g • nerall points or Maximes of Christian faith: the other, by constraining them, at least, to a ciuill practise of vndoubted principles acknowledged by all; and inhibiting such courses as the morall precepts of this Canon haue detected for causes & nurses of contention. Our aduersaries, whether out of wilfull malice or ouersight, or out of both, (according to the diuersities of their tempers) haue taken occasiō to traduce our Churches doctrine, as if it admitted no meanes for preuenting or composing contentions, but only the bare letter of Scripture: Whereas we all teach that the written word is the only meanes infallible, not the onely meanes simply, for effecting both. Nor doth it skill how necessary either ministeriall expositions, or iuridicall decisions bee, for bringing vs vnto, or retaining vs in, the vnitie of the truth professed: for not necessity is meanes, but infallibility of direction is the proper, vnseparable condition of the rule of faith. And seeing Gods word onely endures for euer, and therefore onely is infallible: it must be the sole rule of faith, how many or how necessary soeuer the means be, that must bring vs to the true knowledge of it.

6 Valentian and Sacro-boscus thinke it all one,The grosnesse of our aduersaries exceptions being a branch of their generall extremitie mentioned. cap. 4. sect. 1. further to be prosecuted. sect. 3. lib. 3. to acknowledge no Ecclesiasticall authority or vse of Ministerie, and not to acknowledge an infallibility in both. But this is a position deuoid both of sense & reason. For as our senses, though of themselues only capable of particular & m • terial obiects, subiect to change & contingencie, are the necessarie & only ordinary means whereby our intellectiue faculty is brought to apprehend vniuersal & immaterial principles, whose truth is necessary, euerlasting and immutable▪ so may the ministerie and magistracie, though both in themselues fallible and obnoxious to errors, be the necessary and onely ordinarie
meanes, whereby we are brought (as it were by a sensible induction) to the infallible acknowledgement of the supernaturall, diuine, eternall truthes, which are the proper obiect of the illuminated or spirituall, as immateriall and vniuersall principles are of the naturall vnderstanding; which shall (God willing) be declared hereafter. In this place I onely thought good to forewarne the Reader of this hiatus in our aduersaries collections: whereinto the blinde and ignorant English Papist, led by such blinded forraine guides as Valentian and Sacro-boscus, who eyther did not or would not know what our Church in this point doth hold, fall headlong in the very first entrance of this dispute.

7 But in this, as in the former question, it shall not be amisse to propose our aduersaries principall arguments and exceptions against our Churches doctrine, in admitting the Scripture for the rule of faith. And I would request any man, that is able to iudge of the force and strength of an argument, to read the best learned, and most esteemed of our aduersaries, for the further confirmation of this truth which we teach. Against which, some (who haue not sought into their writings) may happily imagine, that much more hath or might be said by any of them, then can bee found in all their writings. Whereas Bellarmine and Valentia two excellent schollers, and most iudicious diuines, (where their wits were their owne) and all other good writers of their side, whom I could hitherto meete with, by reason of the barrennesse of their matter, and shallow vnsetled foundation of their infallible Church, haue performed as good seruice to our cause in this present controue • sie, as that Romane Orator, famous for his vnskilfulnesse in Augustus his time, did to the parties whom he accused; I would to God (said the Emperour) this foolish fellow had accused my gallerie, (which had beene long in building,) for then it had beene absolued, that is, according to the vse of this word in Latine, finished long ere this. In this case we haue his wish. And for the edification of mine owne faith in this point, I must (out of the synceritie of a good conscience,) professe, I would not for any good on earth, but Bellarmine, Valentian, and other grand patrones or plausible aduocates of the Popes cause, (especially Valentian) had taken such earnest paines in accusing our Churches doctrine; for they haue most clearly acquitted it, in that we may iustly presume
there can be no more said against it. And whether all they haue said or can say be aught, I leaue it to the iudicious readers iudgement: I will set downe some of their obiections, and then prosecute their generall topicke, or formes of their arguments, whence all particulars, which in this case they can bring, must receiue their whole strength.

8Omnes haeretici qui scripturas in authoritate recipiunt, ipsas sibi videntur sectari, cum suos potius sectentur errores. Aug. Epist. 222. ad Consentinum. All heretikes, (saith Saint Augustine) which admit the authoritie of Scriptures (for some reiected all or most parts of the sacred Canon) seeme to themselues to follow the Scriptures, when as indeed they follow their owne errors. Neque enim natae sunt haereses & quaedam dogmata perue • sitatis illaqueantia animas nisi dum scripturae bonae intelligantur non bene: & quod in ijs non bene intelligitur, etiam temere & audacter asseritur. Tract. 18 in Iohan. Non modo locos scripturae obscuros, sed etiam alios qui sunt aperti & clari corrumpi ab hoereticis. lib. 2. de nuptijs & cap. 31.
Nor doe heresies (saith the same father in another place) and other naughtie opinions, which ensnare mens soules, spring from any other root then this, That the right sense of Scripture cōceiued amisse, & yet so cōceiued, is boldly & rashly auouched.

9 And in another booke of Augustine, it is said (Valentian would haue the saying well obserued, as it shall be to his shame,) c That heretikes do not corrupt onely the obscure and difficult, but euen the plaine and easie places of Scriptures; and Christus etiam facilimè ab haereticis doctrinā corrumpi subindicauit, cum admonuit vt ab ijs tanquam à falsis prophetis caueremus. Ʋidentur prophetae, quoniam scripturae verba proferunt, quae diuinae doctrinae sunt character & quasi externa species sed prophetae non sunt, quoniam sub ea verborum diuinorum externa specie non ostendunt nobis genuinam S. S. sententiam, sed adulter • nas suas perue • sasque opin • ones sacrilege in verbis sacris à se collocatas, tanquam abominationem (vt eleganter Origines Homil. 29. in Matt. notauit) st • ntem in loco sancto. Eadem de causa vocantur lupirapaces, qui vestimentis induti sunt ouium. Val • nt. tom. 3. in Aquinatem. punct. 7. quaest. 1 §. 6. Haec ideo recitaui, vt quoniam vniuersi haeretici facilime scripturas omnes in suam perditionem si • ut D. Petrus inquit d • prau • nt. (2. Pet. 3.) Jntelligamus certe non in scripturis solis con • titutam esse vniuersalem illam, & ad salutem hominum accommodatissimam authoritatem, totius fidei iudicem, quam inquirimus. Valent. loc. citat. parag. 7.
our Sauiour Christ (as this writer addeth) did intimate how obnoxious the euāgelical doctrine was to this corruption by heretikes, when he forewarned vs, to beware of false Prophets. Heretikes, saith he, seeme to be Prophets because they make a faire shew of Scripture-phrases, which are as the character or externall shape of heauenly doctrine. But Prophets they are not, because vnder the outward shew of heauenly words they manifest not the natiue sense and meaning of the holy Ghost, but their owne adulterate, corrupt opinions, sacrilegiously inuested by them in sacred phrase, as it were the abomination of desolation standing in the holy place, as Origen elegantly notes, Hom. 29. in Math. By the same analogie are they called rauening wolues, being arayed in sheeps cloathing, &c.

10 These and like places are brought by Valentian (as the title and conclusion of that Paragraph shew) to this purpose: That e seeing all heretiks may and do easily peruert the Scriptures, as S. Peter saith to their own destructiō: we should hence be instructed, that this vniuersall.
authoritie, and most behoouefull for the saluation of all, which wee seeke as the common iudge in all pointes of faith, cannot be seated in the Scripture alone.

11 Another marke whereat these fierie darts doe vsually aime, is; to fasten the conceipt of heresie vpon our Church, seeing it hath alwayes beene the practise of Heretikes, to couer their wicked imaginations with sacred phrase, and, as Lyrinensis saith, to inter-sperse or straw their depraued opinions with the sweet and fragrant sentences of Scripture, as with some precious spice, least the exhalation of their natiue smell might bewray their corruption to the reader. This is a common place trodden almost bare by the English pamphleting Papist, who learnes the Articles of his Roman Creede, and generall heads of controuersies betwixt vs, with their vsuall arguments or exceptions against our doctrine, no otherwise then the Fidler doth his Song; holding it sufficient for his part, to affoord a Mimickes face, scurrilous stile, or Apish gesture, vnto the inuentions of Bellarmine, Valentian or some forraine Iesuites braine. And as it is hard for vs to speake, though in generall termes, against any sinne in a Countrie-Parish, but one or other will perswade himselfe, that wee aime at his ouerthwart neighbour, vnto whome, perhappes, our reproofes are lesse applyable, then vnto him that thus applyes them: so is it very easie for this Mimicall crue to perswade the ignorant or discontented people, that euery Minister, whose person or behauiour, vpon what respect soeuer, they dislike, is the very man meant by the Auncient Father and our Sauiour in the former generall allegations; if hee vse but the phrase of Scripture, not the Character of that forraine beast; Whereas their obiections duly examined can hurt none but the obiectors.

div.head: CHAP. II.

That the former obiections and all of like kind, drawne from the cunning practise of Heretiques, in colouring false opinions by Scripture, are most forcible to confirme ours, and confound the aduersaries doctrine.
div.p: 1 MVster they as many authorities or experiments of this ranke, as they list, wee know the strength and nature of their weapons. They are dangerous indeede to such as haue not put on the breast-plate of righteousnesse, or shield of faith: but yet (God be praysed) as sharpe at the one end as at the other, and they had neede to be wary, how, and against whome they vse them. For beaten backe directly by the defendants, they may be as faire to kill the thrower, at the rebound, as them against whom they were first intended. For proofe hereof, looke how easily we can retort all they haue throwne at vs, vpon themselues. It hath beene the practise of Heretiques, (say they) to misinterprete Scriptures, and pretend their authoritie for countenancing errours. This wounds not vs, except wee were naked of all syllogisticall armour of proofe. For they should prooue (if they will conclude ought to our preiudice) that none but Heretiques haue v • ed Scriptures authoritie to confirme their opinions. For if orthodox and truly religious writers, in the best and flourishing ages of the Church, haue beene as copious and industrious, in citing authorities of Scriptures for their opinions, as Heretiques: this argument prooues nothing against vs, why we may not bee Orthodoxes and true Catholikes, as well as Heretiques. That this hath beene the practise of Heretiques we acknowledge; and hauing receiued this their blow, wee can returne their owne weapons vpon them, with greater probabilitie of better speede.

2Our appealing to Scriptures alone, is no such presumption of heresie in vs, as the refusal • of triall by them, is of Antichristianisme in the aduersa y. It hath beene the practise of sundrie Heretiques, neuer of any Orthodoxe, to refuse their triall by Scripture, and flie vnto traditions. It hath b • ene the continuall practise of most monstrous and blasphemous impostors, of false Messiahs, and such as
oppose themselues against Christ, of Mahomet, and such like, to pleade the infallible assistance of the Holy Ghost, and a Supreame authoritie ouer others, without subiection to any triall, either by Scripture or other meanes. If most of them haue failed in getting so many stedfast followers, as the Pope now hath, and for many yeares hath had; it is most likely this was either because their heresies were more open, and more easie to be descried; or they lesse cunning in countenancing them by Scriptures, antiquitie, or other plausible showes of custome, tradition, or the like. For we all know, that Antichrists greatnesse must grow by the multitude of his resolute followers,2. Thess. 2.11. that God shall send them (be they neuer so many) strong delusions, that they should beleeue lyes; that his comming is by the working of Sathan (who can vrge Scripture as cunningly to maintaine falshood as any Heretique,) and by all power, and signes, and lying wonders. So that it will bee hard to discouer or preuent his comming, vnlesse men bee very cunning and expert in these Scriptures, the rule of truth, the onely light, whereby all falshood must bee discouered.

3 That they may once for all know, how little wee feare their force, we will set our bodies so as they shall not misse them, and prepare our selues to take the full strength and dint of all their strokes. The Heretiques of olde time (say they) haue vrged Scriptures for their doctrine vehemently and copiously: we will giue them better hold, and helpe them to presse this point a little harder; They did vrge Scriptures most cunningly, most subtily, and hereby deceiued many, yea almost staggered the very elect. What if they did? so would Pharaohs enchaunters haue obstupified most of the Israelites beside Moses and Aaron: but did their cunning iugling preiudice the truth of Moses miracles? or did he neglect to manifest the power of God, for feare least hee should bee censured for such a one, as they were, onely more cunning in his craft? Their wicked cunning serued as a foyle so to set forth his heauenly skill, as the Enchaunters themselues could not but see the finger of God in his working: herein more ingenuous then the moderne Iesuites; who in so cleare a point as this, we now dispute, after so many foyles as they haue taken, will not acknowledge the force of that Scripture in themselues; Magna est veritas & praeualet. The reason is; because they will not come
vnto the open Court, to trie their skill before vnpartiall Iudges.

4 The Diuel, wee all know did vrge the Scripture to our Sauiour, with great • kill and dexteritie. Had he beene the onely follower or first founder of this practise, or the first of all wee had read of, we should haue beene (vntill we had found some better example and warrant for it) as much afraid to haue imitated him herein, as that scrupulous Monke was to weare his hood; because he thought the Diuel had been the first that euer had worne one, being vsually painted in that habite, when he came to tempt our Sauiour Christ, and that Story hee thought in all likeli-hood, to be as Auncient as the first hood. But with what weapon did our Sauiour vanquish Sathan, that had set vpon him with Scripture? did hee charge him sub poena anathematis to bee silent? or did hee craue the Churches peace vnder paine of greater penalties? or did he appeale vnto the infallible authoritie, or Supreame Tribunall of the Iewish Church? did hee except against him for vsing an vnlawful, Heretical weapon? can you deny that he foyled him with these very weapons, wherewith wee now contend, that all Heretikes (Sathans followers) are to bee assaulted and repulsed, ere they can be lawfully foyled and quite ouerthrowne? And here I would beseech all sober-minded Christians, euen as they loue our Sauiour Christ, (the chiefe C ptaine of the Lords Host, the authour and finisher of our faith) and as they hate Sathan himselfe (the head and Prince of all Gods, Christs, and our enemies) to consider these subsequent reasons well, and waigh this instance in the quiet, calme, and setled motions of their hearts.

5 If Sathan can thus teach Heretikes,What aduātage the orthodoxes haue of heretiques in trial of controuersies by scriptures. and other his like wicked instruments, such great skill and cunning in Scriptures, as they can thereby countenance errours, and deceiue others with a shew of godlinesse: why should wee not hold it as a principall article of our faith, that Christ Iesus is able to instruct his chosen, immediately, in the true sense and meaning of the same Scriptures, so as they may • ereby grow skillfull enough, to retaine such as loue the truth in the knowledge of truth; and defend themselues and others against the oppositions of Heretikes, although they bring their arguments out of Scripture. For first we know, and beleeue that Christ is stronger then Sathan; for he hath bound
that strong man; Secondly that hee is better skilled in Scripture: for after his first enterance into his Propheticall or Sacerdotall function, he Mat. 4. put him hereby to flight, and at his passion Ioh. 22 vers. 13. Now shall the Prince of this world bee cast out. threw him out of his hold. Sathans strength since that time hath beene lesse, and Christs power greater; so that in his strength wee may be stronger then all Sathans followers. Thirdly wee know that the Scripture is in it selfe much more fauourable vnto truth, then vnto falshood; and (caeteris paribus) farre more apt to confirme true Religion, and instruct in points of faith, then to establish heresie, or fill the world with errours? onely the sonnes of darknes haue beene wiser in their generation, then such as should bee, or (in some measure) are the sonnes of light. And if Heretiques may seeme to haue had the better sometimes of the Orthodoxe, in trying controuersies by Scripture; this doubtlesse was for no other reason but only this: Their alacritie and industrie in searching Scriptures for maintenance of errours, was greater then the others for establishment and confirmation of the truth; otherwise, as wee said before, the truth is more consonant to the puritie and integritie of Sacred Writ, then any falshood (though neuer so faire in shew) can be: And Christ Iesus is more powerful, & more skilfull, more able & more willing to assist and strengthen such as follow him, The argumēts proposed in the last chapter can haue no ground, to proue ought against vs, but this: Sathan is more powerfull or skilfull in Scriptures then Christ; o • more readie to helpe his instruments then Christ to assist his Chosen. then Sathan is to enable his wicked instruments Seeing then by these Scriptures hee hath crushed Sathans head, and put him to flight; why should his faithfull followers despaire, by the same weapons, to foyle and sley Sathans seruants, so they will bee as industrious to vse them, as the others are to abuse them. Nor will you (I hope) deny that Christ is present perpetually to his true Church, as well as Sathan is to Heretiques. Say then what you can or dare, why yee should thinke it strange or impossible, that hee should teach all faithfull soules the true sense and meaning of his word, immediately by his blessed spirit, working with the Ministerie of Saints, (without a Vicar general on earth,) as well as Sathan doth Heretikes the counterfeit sense or false but faire seeming meaning of it immediately by himselfe, or his wicked spirits. For we neuer heard that Sathan had any Vicar generall, by whome he teacheth Heretiques all their cunning; vnlesse this be the Pope: which if he bee, then is he not Vicar generall vnto Christ.

6 Seeing, (beloued Christians) we are compassed about with such a cloud of witnesses, whereof not one, without open infidelitie can bee impeached: let vs not disdaine to take the practise of Christ Iesus, the Authour and finisher of our faith, as a patterne well befitting our imitation. Not to bee as industrious in searching the inward sense and secret meaning, as Heretiques, in vrging the outward letter of the Law; were not to follow the footsteps of a victorious Lord, most good and gratious to his followers, with as great alacritie, as vanquished Sathans, wicked instruments doe his: both (if not detested by vs, as the foulest shame, that in this life can befall vs) will breed our euerlasting confusion, in the life to come.

7 That I may dispute with such as make a ieast of Scriptures, according to their childish folly; if by this meanes, I might possibly cure their impietie: Tell vs I pray, yee Doctors of Rome, many of whom I know to be men of learning wit and spirit, and for this reason (as I should thinke) more vnwilling to make your selues palpably ridiculous, to euery child or nouice in arts, howsoeuer, vnto all sorts you striue to make Christs practise such: Tell vs what is your counsell in this choice? shall wee forsake Christ, our, yea Saint Peters best master, to become Schollers vnto your Staphilus, or Hosius Coalier? who (if their reports bee true) did sooner put the Diuell to silence with this doctrine of your Churches infallibilitie, then Christ did for all his Scripture; for the Diuell, as the Mat. 4. vers. 47.10. Euangelist tels vs; departed not from our Sauiour before the third blowe, Auoide Sathan, able to abide the Coalier, but two or rather one a little doubled, I beleeue as the Church beleeues, and the Church beleeues as I beleeue, So much by your doctrine, doth the Diuell feare the very name of your Church though in a Coaliers mouth, more then the word of God, albeit vttered by the sonne of God himselfe.

8 But wee know the Prouerbe too well, Like to like, Children and ignorant people are not ignorant, that the Diuell will bee commaunded, by such as studie the blacke Art: no maruaile if he suffer himselfe vpon good termes to bee put downe by a Coalier. And as I will not peremptorily denie, but the story might bee true: so questionlesse such as most beleeue it, mightily mistake the true cause of Sathans sudden silence, for the truer the story were,
the liklier were it, he should hold his peace, as soone as hee heard the Coalier beleeue as hee would haue him. This is Catechisme in it kind so perfect and absolute, so well suiting to the olde Serpents purpose; that if Hell might haue a generall vacancy from all other imployments for time as long as hath beene since Lucifers fall; not all the powers therein could deuise what one word might be added, what detracted; vnlesse perhaps they would expresse what the Coalier happily vnderstood, [I beleeue as the Church Romish beleeues, and the Church Romish as I beleeue.] whose consequence is, both shall beleeue whatsoeuer Hell would haue them. The vse of such rustique weapons, as those, was perhaps on your part not vnnecessary in that rude world; wherein Lindan's Panopley went for approoued harnesse, or Ecchius bolts for good artillery; but should you vse the like now, euery punie in our Schooles that knows but how to manage an argument, (of which God bee praised we haue enough for a whole Army) shall match your great Golias, whilest they thus keepe aloofe, and lay your stoutest Champions in the dust, by returning their owne or like shot vpon them.

div.head: CHAP. III.

The pretended excellencie of the supposed Romaine rule, for composing controuersies, impeached by the frequencie of Heresies in the Primitiue Church, and the imperfection of that vnion, whereof since that time they so much boast.
div.p:
1 BVt let vs leaue off skirmishing a far off and come a little nearer to the point. You are content to ioyne with vs in this, That it hath beene the practise of Heretiques from time to time, to stand much vpon the authoritie of Scriptures, Then were not Luther and Caluine, the first, that euer made this odious comparison betwixt Gods word and the Popes, Nay you will not deny but this practise of vrging Scripture was most frequent, and the truth most troubled hereby in the Primitiue Church. If
a man might aske you, where was this your supposed infallibilitie then? in the swadling clouts or vnborne?
