If then vnborne, it is too yong to make yonger brethren of al Congregations else; too yong to cause Christian Kings and Emperours subiect their Crownes vnto your vpstart Mitre: If then borne, albeit but in its infancie: yet such an Herculean power, as you professe yours to bee, which puts an 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to all Christian mens thoughts in pointes of faith, (for to this purpose your controuersors cite that place of Scripture, as your vulgar reades it, verba sapientum sunt tanquam claui in altum fixi per magistrorum consilium, conscripta & à pastore vno data; viz. the Pope, istis amplius fili mi ne requiras) might in all congruitie haue taken Hercules Motto for its word, Cunarum labor est angues superasse mearum: though it had laine then sleeping in the cradle, yet might it, (were it such as you would make it) easily haue crusht this seede of Serpents in the very nest, wherein they bred, and not haue suffered them to growe vp to flying Dragons, to pester the world farre and neare with their deadly poyson.

2 I would haue you here to consider this incongruitie well, which I must farther prosecute in the next dispute. You plead the necessitie of your Churches infallibilitie for composing all contentions and varietie of opinions about Scripture-sense, and yet we euidently see (which you cannot deny) that such bitter contentions, & dangerous varieties of opinions about Scripture-sence, were most rife, most eagerly prosecuted, and maintained, when this title of your Churches infallibilitie (if it were iust) might haue beene best knowne, and soonest assented vnto. ForThat the Fathers, if wee take the litterall plain Gramaticall sense of their words, attribute as much to Scriptures as we do, our aduersaries cannot deny. May wee not then safely thinke, they meant what their words naturally import? No, Valentian hath found out a mystical interpretation of them. Quēadmodum quando vni personae diuinae aliquae perfectio diuinitatis absoluta tribuitur, intelligunt Theologi, ab eius perfectionis communione creaturas tantum excludi, non autem personas alias diuinas quae sunt eiusdē naturae: Jta Sancti patres sicubi Scripturae authoritatem solam ad fidei quaestiones finiendas valere significant: Ecclesiae certè authoritatem pro diuina habēt, & quam ipsa nobis commendat Scriptura, minimè excludunt, sed alia siue testimonia, siue argumenta. quae sint tātū humana. Nam si non ita intelligerent, profecto nūquā illi in controuersijs fidei ipsa per se authoritate Ecclesiasticae traditionis ad probandum vterentur. At vtuntur ea ipsi frequentissimè & vtendum esse docēt. As the non cōsequence of this collection, so how far the Fathers did vrge the Churches authority, how the most pregnant speeches that cā be found in any of their writings must be limited, will easily appeare, if we consider the two former distinctions: the one betweene the infallible rule of faith, and the meanes or motiues inducing vs to beleeue: the other betweene that conditionall assent, which in cases doubtfull we must giue to the visible Church, and that absolute beleefe, which is onely due vnto Scriptures: The Fathers vsed the Churches authoritie against Heretiques, as we doe theirs against Nouelists, not as a rule whereby finally to examine or determine diuine truths, but as a curbe to b • idle presumptuous gainsaying opinions generally receiued or supposed for true, by men of sincerity and skill in diuine mysteries: sure, the Auncient Fathers who had learned Christian obedience,
alwayes ready to giue honour, where honour was due, would most willingly haue acknowledged, so absolute a Soueraigntie, and could haue beene glad to haue vsed the benefits of it, to haue spared themselues a great deale of trouble and paines, if it could haue beene prooued then to haue beene such an excellent meane, for allaying all contentions amongst the learned. The Pope was much to blame, to let Athanasius suffer such paines, exile and abuse by the Arian faction, in the defence of the truth, if his infallibilitie could haue composed the quarrell. Austin hath beene famous throughout all Generations since, for his learned labours against the Pelagian Heresie; Cyril for his accurate confutation of Nestorius, and yet the Scripture was the best weapon they knew. Neither of them did euer appeale to the Popes infallibilitie, nor the Popes themselues which then liued would haue vsed any other rule but Scripture, for their own defence.

3 Your vsuall argument is, that vnlesse God had left such an infallible authoritie as might take vp all controuersies; hee had not sufficiently prouided for his Church. Then, by your consent, he left such an authoritie, as was sufficient to performe this good seruice to it. To whome then did hee commit it? To the Sea of Rome say you. How chanceth it your fore elders did not put it in practise, and make the power of it better knowne? This blame you cannot lay vpon the Almightie; for hee, for his part, (by your confession) prouided abundantly for the peace and quiet of his Church. And yet it seemes the Church was ill prouided for, when Schismes and Heresies sprung so fast. This therefore was your Churches fault, that bore this spirituall sword in vaine, and would not vse it; when the Christian world stood most in neede of it, for the finall decision of controuersies. So then although wee should grant you, that your Church had sometimes the birthright, amongst all the Israel of God: yet might we iustly say of it, as olde Israel said of Reuben his eldest sonne, Thy dignitie is gone; and we were to seeke this Supreame authoritie, (if God had giuen any such Supremacie to any) in some other tribe which were likely to vse it better.

4The more excellent prerogatiues the Iesuites bestow vpon their Church, the greater they make her disgrace, for not vsing her authoritie better, whē the Christian world stood most in need of it. If you reply, your Churches authoritie in composing controuersies amongst the learned hath beene better knowne since
that flourishing age of learned and religious Fathers; and since it hath beene so well knowne and acknowledged, Heresies haue beene more thinne sowne, then before; (few or none till Luther arose daring to confront the Church or Popes authoritie, with Scripture:) You giue vs hereby iust cause to suspect, that Heresie had got the vpper hand of truth, for the multitude of followers; that there had beene a generall combination in falshood till Luther brake it. For if sundrie of the Auncient Heretiques, with whose doctrine the Primitiue Church was pestered, could vnder pretence of Scripture, haue got into Supreame authority; or haue established their propositions, framed (as they thought out of Gods word) with strength of temporall sword, as Mahomet did his: It were great simplicitie to thinke, that they could not haue beene content, to haue let the Scriptures sleepe, or haue threatned all with death and destruction, that should haue vrged them to the preiudice of their opinions, especially of such opinions as did concerne their dignitie. For all falshood and spirituall blindnesse hates this light, and could either wish it put out, or them vtterly extinct that obiect it to them. As hee that hath wound himselfe into an others inheritance by some quirke in Law or Captious clause not well vnderstood, would not bee much offended to haue all euidences or primarie coppies either burnt or buried, euen that by which hee got it, if it, vpon better consideration or more indifferent hearing, were likely to ouerthrow his title.

5 And if wee may ghesse at the course of Sathans policie, in watching his opportunities to effect his purpose by the customary fashion of secular Politicians (his Schollers) in like cases; most probable it is, that after these broiles of dissention about the Gospell of peace so frequent in the Primitiue Church, the great calamities, and bodily affliction which followed thereon; most men grew weary of their spirituall warfare, and became slouthfull in the search of Scriptures, the only Armorie for all munition, in this kind of warre. Euery man afterwardes, in the fresh memorie of the Church their mothers bleeding wounds, and the desolation which had ensued these furious broyles, became more tractable to entertaine conditions of peace: and Sathan himselfe, who had sowne the seedes of all the former dissention, after hee
see all or most wearie of warre, was content to turne Peace-maker for his owne aduantage. These were as the first preparations for laying the foundations of the mysticall Roma Babel rediuiua, the mysticall Babel raised by compounding those Elemēts wherevnto olde Babel was resolued. The dissolution of the one, and the erection of the other differing but as the resolutiō of quicksiluer into fume and the cōuersion of it again, into quicksiluer. • he Citie of Babylon likewise (as shall God willing else-where appeare) was the true type. Babell, in whose erection, the manner, methode, and circumstances of the formers dissolution are all inuerted. The building of the first was hindered by the confusion of tongues, or the diuision of one language into many; whence insued the scattering of the people throughout the earth: the second was finished by the concourse of diuerse people, and the composition or confusion of different languages. For (as Gen. 11.7. of Rome; the one as Saint Austin compareth thē, being the mother, the other the daughter, each euidently paralleling the other in most abhominations: which is the reason (as I take it) why the holy Ghost instiles Rome with the name of Babylon, whose abhominations were well knowne to the faithfull, and might serue as a light, to discouer Romish filthines. Goropius acutely obserues) the present temper of moderne Italian, Spanish, French (we may adde of our English) Dialects, was from the mixture of the Romane and barbarous tongues, whilest the naturall inhabitants of these Countries, (before accustomed to the Romane language,) and the Barbarians which at that time ouerranne them, were inforced to imitate each other in their words and manner of speech, that they might be the better vnderstood in matters ofIn the beginning of his Hermathena. necessarie commerce or ordinary contracts. And this is the true reason why our Auncient English Latinismes are not as the Latine Graecismes, which were deriued by art and imitationThe reason why our old English participates most of Butterie-hatch-Latine. from cleare Helicon extracted from the purest Romane; but from Latine of the base and vulgar stamp. This confusion of the Latine and other barbarous tongues, was but a type or picture of confounding the Auncient true Romane Religion with barbarous Heresies, Heathenish rites, and seuerall kindes of Paganisme; whilest theThat such was the disposition of the Romanes at that time, as would easily condescend to admit a mixture of Paganisme, may appeare out of Saint Austins first bookes de Ciuitate Dei, and Saluianus de prouidentia. Romanes, who had already begun to distast the truth,As may appeare out of some workes going vnder the name of Gregory the great, and Gregory of Towers Historie. sought by lying legends and false wonders, to please the grosse palate of the Goths, Vandals, Hunnes, Alans, Franks and Saxons: and they againe herewith delighted were content to imitate the other in sundry sacred and religious rites; so as neither kept their Auncient religion, but all imbraced this mixture or new confused Masse. And, to speake properly, that vnity whereof the Aduersarie so much
boasts, since that flourishing age of Fathers, wherein contentions were so rife, and the Romane Church no better esteemed then some of her sisters, was not a positiue consent in the sincere truth, wrought by the Spirit of God, (as a perfect Homogeneall mixture by true and liuely heat) but rather a bare negation of actuall dissention, caused by a dull confusion of the dregges of errour, coagulate and congeled together by ignorance, carelesnesse, slouth, negligence, and want of zeale to the truth.

6 And after this composall was once so wrought, that men had felt some intermission of publique dissention which they feared most: such as were industrious in the search, or would haue beene expert in the knowledge of Scriptures, were esteemed of but as Souldiers in the time of peace and ease, alwayes suspected least they should raise new broiles; And for this reason, debarred of free accesse vnto his Armorie. But howsoeuer the practise of examining the Churches authoritie by Scripture, was for many generations rare, till Luther arose; yet during all this time, that of our Apostle was in this case most true Acts. 14 17 Our Church was in the Romish Synagogue as a little portion of fine gold, in a great masse of drosse, vntill the flames of persecution seuered it and made it conspicuous.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
GOD did not leaue himselfe without a witnesse. In all these ages hee had his Martyrs who in the feruencie of their zeale earnestly sought the dissolution of the coagulated Masse and extraction of Celestiall quintecensses therein buried; offering their bodies as fuell to the flames of persecutions that were to effect it.

7 Nor can you in reason demaund wee should giue particular instancies of such Martyrs in euery age.The miserable and shamefull persecution of sundry, for professing most points of our Religion in Saint Bernards time. For no man of sense but will easily conceiue that your Church should seeke by all meanes possible to obliterate their fame and memorie vpon whose bodies shee had exercised such extreme tyrannie, least their example might encourage Posteritie to like resolutions. Vnlesse DRIEDO had (vnawares I thinke) acquainted mee with the Prouost of STENELDAS Epistle to Saint BERNARD I had not knowne either your crueltie against the Albigenses or Picardy, as I suppose, or their constancie, in suffering tortures in themselues most greiuous, yet attended with vsages as disgracefull; both for the mnner or forme of proceeding, as iniuriously, afflicted in
as the ground or matter of accusations brought against them were vniust and impious. The Prouosts Epistle was to this effect.

8 I would gladly bee resolued (Holy Father) might I enioye your presence, whence it is that in Heretiques, the Diuels members, there should be so great resolution for defence of their Heresies, as the like can scarce bee found in very religious and faithfull Christians. There are (saith he) amongest vs, Heretiques which put no confidence in the suffrages of men deceased, Iam olim aute annos 400. Praepositus quidam venerandus Steneldensis interrogabatbeatum Bernardū; vell m inquit, scire, Sancte pater, si praesens essem, vnde in haereticis diaboli membris tanta fortitudo in sua haeresi, quanta vix reperitur etiam in valdè religiosis Christi fidelibus. Sunt, inquit, apud nos h retici, qui insuffragijs mortuorum & in o • ationibus sanctorum non confidunt: (marke the word non cōfidunt) ieiunia caeteras{que} afflictiones q • ae pro peccatis fiunt, aiunt iustis non esse necessaria: purgatorium ignem post mortem non concedunt: in altari Corpus Christi sicrinegant: Ecclesiam apud se esse dicunt, non habentes neque agros neque possessiones. Nouimus etiam ex istis nunnullos esse raptos a populis • imio zelo permotis, & nobis inuitis in ignem positos cremato • ; qui tormentum ignis non solum in patientia, Sed & cum laetitia introierunt. Vellem igitur scire, Sa • cte pater, vne in Diaboli membris tanta for • tudo Driedo lib 4 de Ecclesiast. dog. & scrip • ap 5. part 1.
or prayers of Saints: fastings and other afflictions of the bodie vsually vndertaken for sinne, are not in their opinion necessarie to the righteous: Purgatorie after death they acknowledge none, Denying the making of our Lords bodie in the Sacrament of the Altar; the Church they affirme to be amongest them, hauing neither fieldes nor possessions. Of such we haue knowne diuerse, by the multitude, misled with too much zeale, violently haled against our will vnto the flame; whose torments they not only indured with patience, but entertained with ioy. I would therefore bee resolued by you, (Holy Father) whence so great resolution, in the Diuels members, should spring.

9 No question but this Prouost which esteemed no better of them, then as of Heretiques or Sathans members, did relate the worst opinions then knowne to bee helde by them: and yet, Hee (as I would haue the Reader note) liuing in their time, layes no such odious tenents to their charge, as those that liued long after, or were imployed by the Romish State, to write against Wicklife, Husse or Ierome of Prage, haue charged them and their followers with. Driedo tels vs, he finds no direct answere by way of Epistle or writing vnto this venerable mans demaund in particular. But out of Saint Bernards doctrine else-where deliuered concerning like Heretiques, he findes this resolution,Nihil simile habet constantia Martyrum, & pertinacia h • reticurum, quia in illis pietas, in istis duritia cordis contemptum mortis operatur. B • rnardus Hom. 66. in Canticum Canticorum. The constancie of Martyrs hath no affinitie with the stubbornnesse of Heretiques; pietie breedes contempt of death in the one, hardnesse of heart in the other. Such good minded men as Saint Bernard, I thinke had least to doe
in the examination of such men, most obnoxious to mis-information in the particulars of their carriage: with which the Ciuill Magistrates of France, though Romish Catholiques, better acquainted, haue giuen them laudable testimonies for their honest and religious liues: and whether these mentioned by that Prouost were such, as Saint Bernard spake against, in the place late cited, is more then Driedo knew. Howsoeuer, in matters of this nature it is most true, Bernardus non vidit omnia, as easie in his life time to be abused by crafty Polititians, as his authoritie is now by moderne Iesuites. He that will beleeue these men were such Heretiques as Driedo would make them, only because Driedo sayes so, may easily bee perswaded that their resolution did not spring so much from true and liuely faith, as from humorous obstinacy or stubborne pride. But while wee consider all circumstances well, (though many wee take from your relation, who in this case relate nothing so well, and truely as you should) we haue iust cause to thinke they were not Heretiques, but men rightly religious, fearing God more then men, and more obseruant of his lawes then of humane traditions. For at this time, as the glory, so the temporall power and authoritie of your Church was exceeding great, the lesse these poore soules hopes, either of purchasing glorie by contradicting, or priuate gaines by disobeying your decrees. To attempt the one was the readiest way to procure their vtter disgrace; the other, an infallible prouocation of greatest danger. Your Church had the whole multitude of Nations as readie at her becke to applaude your cruell designes against them, as the High-Priestes and Elders had the Iewish people to approue our Sauiours condemnation. The manner of their tortures, accompanied with such certaintie of ignominie and disgrace, were dreadfull to the setled and deliberate cogitations of flesh and bloud; their memorie (for ought they could in humane probabilitie foresee) was either to sleepe with their bodies, and lie buried in their ashes, or (if suruiuing them) to be perpetually scourged by the scurrilous pens and tongues of their bitter aduersaries. No hope they had of being Canonized for Saints: in the vehement desire whereof some in your Chruch haue solicited the procurement of their owne violent death, by others hands.

10 All these and many other like circumstances, whiles wee
consider yee may brag of the multtude and vniuersality as an no • e of the true Church, and we will easily grant you to haue beene at that time farre more in number, then these silly sheep; whose admirable constancy neuerthelesse in the heat of such extreme tyrannie, and alwayes matcht with such harmelesse simplicitie, doth make vs thinke, that albeit you were the greater, yet these were that little flocke vnto whose hearts, our Sauiour, by his holy Spirit of comfort had said, Feare not, for it is your fathers will to giue you a Kingdome, lands and possessions (as your aduersaries truly obiect) here on earth, yee haue had none. But the losse is little, or rather your gaine exceeding great. For these, because these you haue forsaken for the Gospels sake and mine, you shall receiue lands and possessions an hundred fold with life euerlasting in the world to come. These Heretiques, some of you (I imagine) would say, albeit they might pretend Scriptures for the rule of faith, yet would not be ruled by Scriptures when they were euidently brought against them. For your euidence of Scripture, to proue these points there mentioned, wee know them well enough; for some of them you professe tradition onely.

div.head: CHAP. III.
That our aduersaries obiections do not so much infring, as their practise confirmes the sufficiency of Scriptures for composing the greatest controuersies in religion.
div.p: 1 BVt suppose many Heretikes (your selues for exāple) wil not submit their minds vnto the euidence of Scripture? what remedie? who can helpe it? Their condemnation is iust, and vengeance is Gods, he will repay. Man it behooueth to see euidently, that they contemne or abuse Scripture, before he aduenture to infl • ct punishment vpon them for it, least otherwise he become an intruder into the Almighties Tribunall. But if the euidence of Scripture will not, what else shal recal such from errour?

2 Besides the former generall allegations, let vs see what more can bee said, why the Scriptures may not bee the most effectuall, and infallible rule, that can bee imagined to guide men in the way of truth.Authoritas quae ad iucādas omnes fidei quaestiones diuinitas est instituta, proculd • bio est accommodatissima ad ignoscēdos & cauendos errores omnes fidei contrarios. Scriptura sacra sic compusita est, vt experientia etiam doceat, eā per se solā, non tā regulam acōmodatā esse ad declinandos omnes errores, quā arcano Dei iudicio esse velut lap de offensionis, & in tētationem pedib{us} insipientiā, vt qui velint ea sola niti facile impingāt & errent, Valēt. tom. 3. disp. 1. quaest. in punct. 7. 8. 6. The authoritie (saith Valentian) ordained by
God for determining all questions of faith, is without all question most apt to discerne and preuent all errours contrarie to faith.The like blasphemous speeches he iteates, in the very next parag • aph. Why may not the authoritie of Scripture bee accounted such? The Scripture, saith he, is so framed, (yet was it God that framed it,) as experience may also teach vs;It seemes his meaning is that the Scripture by Gods iust iudgement, is a snare to all such as relie infallibly vpon it alone, euen because they relie vpon it alone. that of it selfe alone it is so farre from being a fit rule for auoyding all errors, that by the secret iudgement of God it is a stumbling blocke, and as a snare to the feete of the vnwise, so that such as will relie vpon it alone, may soone trippe or tread awrie.

3 The Reader must lay the blame where it is due, if these indefatigable mouthes of blasphemies reiterating the like absurd impieties so oft, enforce me often to oppose the same or like answers to them: Such an occasion as Gods creatures were of Idolatrie, the Scriptures we grant may be of heresie. For of Gods good creatures, wherewith th idolatrous heathen polluted themselues, the wise man speakes in that place whereto Valentian alludes. And such an occasion should this infallible way of the Romish Church pretended for auoiding bee of beeding heresies, were it any of Gods waies, of which the wise sonne of Syrach saith indefinitely. They are stumbling blockes to the wicked: so was the way of life, the Gospell it selfe euen whilest proposed and auouched by Saint Peter and Saint Paul. The question then must be,The place cited by him is Wisd. 14. v. 10. for what cause the Scriptures are a snare to some mens feete: because they admit and embrace them, for their rule of life? If thus eyther Valentians ghost, or any Iesuite now aliue, dare auouch, I say no more then the Archangell said to Sathan, The Lord rebuke thee. Onely vnto the vnwise, and wilfully wicked because such; the Mediator and Sauiour of the world, Salus ipsa, Saluation it selfe, was a stone of offence: and vnto all such nor Scripture, nor any of Gods waies serues as a rule to saue, but to condemne them.

4 This is the Article then, vpon which the Iesuite must once againe be examined, whether vnto such, as are by Gods iust iudgements decreed to destruction, and giuen ouer by his holy spirit to beleeue lies, and follow lying traditions, or fables of mans inuention, the Popes infallible authoritie can be a rule of life, or sauing faith? If it can, then we will grant it, to be a more infallible rule then Scripture; because able to controule Gods immutable decree: if it cannot (as none without open & presumptuous blasphemie
will say it can) then is it no more effectuall for to reclaime men from errors, then the Scriptures are, nor doth it any waies supplie their want. If they will not beleeue Moses and the Prophets, Luke. 16. saith our Sauiour, neither will they bee perswaded though one were raised from the dead: why so? Because God hath decreed this word, as the only meanes of saluation to such, as haue beene partakers of it: and such as refuse this, are giuen ouer by his spirit, to the stubbornesse of their owne hearts: shall then the Popes infallibility make such beleeue? By what meanes? Are his words more effectuall then the words of life? Are his bulles able to withstand the decrees of the Almightie? Or are his curses to the disobedient more terrible, then the euerlasting woes pronounced by our Sauiour Christ and his Prophets? more piercing then the relation of Hell-paines by a messenger from the dead? By your Churches continuall practise I should gesse this would bee your replie, (for there is no other left,) that the Pope can constraine men to subscribe to his decrees, by fire and sword. This might command their hands or tongues, but not their mindes. For the Iesuites would teach such as feared the smart of their fleshly members, to cosen their conscience for sauing their bodies, with this distinction, Iuraeui linguâ, mentem iniuratam gero. And if fire and sword be the best weapons of spirituall warfare, or vnrelenting persecutions the ensignes of infallible authoritie, then the greater tyrants may be alwaies the more infallible teachers: But these weapons, by your best writers consent, ye may not vse against any but such as are alreadie admitted into Christs fold: Quae foris sunt, iudicabit Deus: Such as are without, God will iudge: The Pope may such as are within, in what manner, for what cause, he please, not lyable to any account, whether in so doing hee doe right or wrong.So the Councell of Trent it selfe declares Sect. 14. cap. 2. Let the fruits of our practise then witnesse, whether, what is by you obiected to vs for vsing our Sauiours language, may not by fit analogie be verified of your selues in this point, whether we or ye be the men of whom our Sauiour gaue the world warning, when he told, Of false Prophets outwardly appearing in sheeps cloathing being inwardly rauishing wolues. Vnto such as are by vs wonne to the Gospell we grant that Christian liberty after, which before their conuersion we promised. Your factors abroad, (as in the Indies or Iapan) appeare to men in sheepes cloathing, making
faire promises of the glorious Gospell of Christ, and the libertie of the sonnes of God, but inwardly (as in Italy, Spayne, or generally within your owne folds) are rauening wolues. Or to fit you with an Embleme essentially parallele to your nature and custome, ye are 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
inuersi, men abroad, and wolues at your owne home. For whiles you seeke to conuert an Alien, you magnifie the doctrine of the Gospell, your speech is faire, your whistle pleasant, and your feeding sweet and good; if ye mention the Popes authoritie, it is moderately, and vrged in that stile, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Peter feede my lambes:
Iohn. 21. ver. 16. but when yee haue once drawne these lambes within yout hurdles, ye change your note, and turne into your proper shape, then you crie with rauenous mouthes, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : That is as you interprete, Rule my sheepe, or, Petre macta & mandata, kill and eate. Baronius Now all the pretended glorious promises of the Gospell, or large hopes of liberrie, which you had giuen them before, are sodainly contracted in these two maine commandements, the chiefe supporters of your religion, on which your Law and Gospell hang: If any thing be proposed to be beleeued. Beleeue or be burnt: If to bee acted, Doe or die.

5 But as I was saying, such kinde of weapons must bee vsed onely towards such, as are admitted into Christs fold: vnto them the Popes authoritie must be a rule, for they must bee ruled by his iron rod. But let vs suppose, a Christian (eyther wel minded Protestant or Papist) a Iew, or Mahumetan, all zealous in their kind, and of carriage moderate, should meete together: in some principles of beleefe they all agree, al acknowledge the old Testament to be the word of God, but differ in the true sense and meaning of it. What meanes would you prescribe to winne eyther of these two vnbeleeuers to the truth? I am sure ye would not begin with the Popes authoritie. Were not the readiest way to winne a Mahumetan, to shew him, that the greatnesse of that kingdome in which he glorieth, was ordained by God to punish the Christian world, as Nebuchadnezzars was to plague the Iewes, and should decay, would Christians amend: and (the strength of his affection to the prosperitie of that Empire abated) to propose the carnall affection of Mahomet, and his religion, most of which is lothsome
the eares of such as haue any notion of any religion; whereas the puritie of Christs Gospell is such, as a sober minde once therewith acquainted would reuerence, albeit hee could not obey.

6 This or the like methode is vsed by sundrie learned Papistes to disswade Mahumetisme. If they reply, that they first seeke to make them acknowledge the Scriptures, that they may thence learne to relie vppon the Popes infallibilitie: they vtterly deface their owne pretended glory, in conuertingTo conuert Pagans to the Romish faith as it is nowe taught by the Iesuites, is but to palliate infidelitie with hypocrisie: As the mysteries of that religions iniquitie are but a medlie or vntoward confusion of Gentilisme and Christianitie which cannot symbolize, or rather their imperfect mixture depraueth both, so as the compound is worse then eyther of the ingredients taken apart. Thus Lodouicus Viues complaineth vpon these words of Saint Augustine. (lib. 14. De ciuitate Dei. cap. 18.) Vsum scortorum terrena ciuitas li • itam turpitudinem fecit) concubine & pellices (saith Viues,) non sunt prohibit • : quemadmodum ex legibus Dei concubinarijs ostenditur libro Digestor. 25. Satis apertè Augustinus testator esse iure ciuili vetore Romano multa permissa quae sunt contrario legibus diuinis. Hoc isti nolunt qui dum gentilitatem coniungere & coaptare Christianismo laborant, nec gentilitatem nec Christianismum retinens. so many Aliens vnto the faith. For all this paines in such as follow this supposed methode, is but to purchase a double portion in the Pharisees woe, For compassing Sea and Land, to make others of their profession. The Pharisees, in such conuersions, did as it were quadrate the measure of Proselytes sinnes: multiplying Gentilisme by Pharisaisme: The Iesuites make vp the full cubicke, whilest they produce Mahumetisme, which is but a medley of Gentilisme and Iudaisme, into Iesuitisme, which is the sublimation of Pharisaisme, mixed with malignant Atheisme.

For it is impossible that this conuersion should abolish the forme or essentiall qualitie of the Mahumetanes former carnall corrupt Religion: but rather intend the badde temper of it, by superaddition of this second in qualitie more malignant. And yet for the effecting of this change, they make Christ Iesus, their crucified Lord and God, but a Stale for the aduancement of his Kingdome, that by their owne confession may bee for life and manners, farre worse then Mahomet. Suppose then a conuert-Mahumatane should know what manner of men most of their Popes be: how could he chuse but eyther repent of his conuersion, or turne trecherous Atheist; to out-luie the Iesuite in such villainous
gulleries, as this;So R.B. in his second booke of Resolution arg. 6. pag. 249. obiects such matters to Mahomet and his successours, as a man might iustly suspect, out of Platina, de vitis Pontificum. It is a pretie straine of impudency in him and his fellowes to draw such arguments from Mahomet, and his successors lewde life against Mahumetans, and not admit the same as good against themselues, many of whose Popes by their owne confession are as bad as bad may be, albeit euen vnto the most abhominable of them that haue bin or may be, they attribute as much in matters of religion as the Turkes can to Mahomet. Sed • illis aes triplex circa frontem fuit, their foreheads are fenced doubtlesse with a triple shield of brasse, that can without blushing obiect intemperancy to Luther, or infamy to Caluin (both, in respect of most their great Prelates, Saints for good life and conuersatiō) & vge their forged blemishes to the preiudice of reformed religion: which no way dependeth vpon Luthers life death, or doctrine, as their Catholik religion doth continually vpon their Popes. If Luthers life though we should grant it bad, might any way preiudice ours: the impiety of their Popes (frō whom their faith is essentially deriued) must of necessity vtterly disgrace their religion. wherein hee vseth Mahomets beastly life as an argument to disswade his followers from his religion: and yet vseth the word of God, whose sanctitie both acknowledge, but as a baite to bring men on to fasten their faith vpon a more detestable sonne of perditiō. This were indeed the best way to harden the Mahumetan in his preposterous beleefe: That Mahomet, (though as wee obiect a notorious impostor) might be sent from God to winne the world vnto that truth by the sword, whereunto Christ could not bring it by his godly life and most effectuall kinde of preaching. And I doe not see, what else, but this or like conclusion, can with any probabilitie be gathered from any arguments brought by the Papists, to proue the necessitie of the Popes or their corrupt Churches infallible authoritie, for supplying the defect of Christ and his Apostles writings. Finally, to bring eyther Mahumetan or Pagan to acknowledge the truth of the new Testament, or Christ for their Sauiour, that they might afterwards relye vpon such men, is but to leade them into the entrie of the Kingdome of heauen, that they may finally shut the doore on them, when they haue one foote within it: which is indeede the sole, entire, formall effect of this supposed infallible key. But my good liking of industrie, (though of our greatest aduersarie) in this sloathfull age, makes mee hope, (God grant I faile not in my hopes) that in remote countries, whose ayre is not pestered with the noysome and loathsome sent of Rome their mothers whooredome, euen Iesuites are inspired with more pure and hallowed cogitations; and that they vse not Valentian, Bellarmine or others of their Italionated fellowesBy Gods good prouidence for the poore Indians good, it was, no doubt that the Spanish Catechistes did not vse this which we call the Apostles Creed, lest they might haue bin thence occasioned to ouerlash in their blasphemous Encomiōs of the Catholik Church, which is scarce mentioned in that Creed or confession which they following Aquinas haue vsed, as Iosephus Acosta complains. l. 5. de procuranda Ind. Salute. ca. 7 De sancta vero Ecclesia articulus à vulgaribus chatechistis ferè omittitur, causam eam opinor, quod in mysterijs fidei explicandis, non taem symboli Apostolici seriem sequantur, quàm vsitatem istam distributionem articulorum fidei in septem ad diuinitatem pertinentes, & totidem ad humanitatem, &c. methods in catechising
Conuerts: or if they doe, yet God, I trust, will be mercifull vnto such poore soules as thus adore the Pope, not knowing what manner of creature he is, but rather in charitie presume him for such in the concrete as the Iesuites make him in the abstract, euen a second-Christ or Holinesse it selfe.

7 Were not the best methode to win the Iew, to compare the Prophecies of the old Testament with the historie of the new, and experiments of Gods iudgements vpon that nation? Some Iohannes Baptista was converted by this methode, as he himselfe expresly witnesseth in his Epistle to his countrimen, whom he well hoped to win by his lab • urs in this kinde: the best vse • e knew of the Popes authority, was such as is incident to ordinarie Magistracy, (whether ciuill or Ecclesiasticke) only to cōstraine the Iewes to reade his booke (as our lawes bind Papistes to heare Sermons) and for this purpose he intreates the Cardinall, vnto whom he dedicated his labours to sollicite thus much at the Popes feete in Purgatorie. Aduersum est sanè vt Ecclesiae authoritatem habeat discernendi verba Dei à verbis hominum, sensum Dei ab humano sensu non habeat. Canus, lib. 5. cap. 5. pag. 270. Quod si aliam authoritatem praeter scripturam necesse est esse infallibilem, Quae doceat id quod in fide est maximum, nempe scripturae ipsius doctrinam esse in vniuersum diuinam: profecto est insania (some editions haue, infamia, but falsely as I thinke,) non credere illam ipsam authoritatem infallibiliter item docere, quae sit sententia eiusmodi diuinae doctrinae, Valentianus loco soepius citato paragrapho. 5. Iewes haue beene brought vnto the truth by these meanes, who haue done the Church of Christ excellent seruice in the exposition of prophecies, concerning Christ, labouring to winne their countrimen vnto him by comparing the old Testament with the new. If the Scripture may be a rule, to compose the diuersitie of these opinions, most repugnant amongst themselues, may it not much more bee a rule to compose all controuersies amongst professed Christians, who agree in farre more principles of faith, and rules of Scripture, then the former did, if Christians would be as soberly affected, and not stand vpon the authorities and customes of men, the speciall obstacle that keepes the Iewes from Christianitie?

8 It is vsuall with your writers to argue thus, We cannot know Scriptures to be the Scriptures, but by the authoritie of the Church; therefore we cannot know the true sense and meaning of them, but by the infallible authoritie of the same. The antecedent of which argument, as we haue partly shewed, and hereafter (God willing) shall shew to be most false: so for the argument it selfe I only now say, that it may be farre more probably inuerted vpon you, thus. The Iewes may come to acknowledg the new Testament for the verie Gospell of their Messias, and to beleeue in heart, and professe with their mouthes the mysteries therein contained, by sober and diligent comparing them with the prophecies of the old, without the infallible authoritie of your Church: therefore they may know the true sense and meaning of the Gospell, in all points necessary
to saluation, without any such infallible authoritie. For it is a matter of farre lesse difficultie, for any man of sense and reason, to deduce particular conclusions from generall and euident principles, then to finde out the generall and fundamentall principles, by naturall notions, or other principles: And therefore more easie for any such man to resolue his conscience in particular pointes of faith or Christian obedience, after hee hath found out the foundation of Christian faith, (to wit Christ Iesus crucified, raised from the dead, and other generall dictates of faith in the Apostolicall writings) then to come vnto the acknowledgement, and beleefe of these fundamentall points themselues, from the broken knowledge (such as the Iewes haue) of the old Testament. And thus it euidently followes, that if the old Testament be a rule vnto the Iewes, for finding out the truth of the new, much more may the new, once acknowledged by them, and admitted of equal authoritie with the old, be a perfect rule for them in matters of saluation. And if these Scriptures are, or may be a rule to the Iewes, (if they will beleeue them) then must they be a rule to al Christians that beleeue them. No Christian I hope will denie, but that the old Testament is the rule of the Iewes: For the vnbeleeuing Iewes shall be condemned in what part of the world soeuer, for not following this rule, which God hath commended and made knowne vnto them, not for not acknowledging the Popes infallibility, of which many of them neuer heard. And if the old Testament be such to them, much more must the whole Canon bee vnto vs such a rule: and if we die in misbeliefe or infidelitie, we shall be iudged by this rule of Gods Law and Gospell, which we transgressed, not by the Popes decrees or expositions of it. That many Christians by profession erre in points of faith, or mistake the true sense and meaning of it, or peruert it to their destruction, proceeds from their ingratitude towards God that gaue it, and for their delight in falshood. Which is the reason why these Iewes mistake the true meaning of the old Testament.

9 If any of our aduersaries heere demaund, how chanceth it so many Iewes erre in the foundation of faith, if the Scripture be such an infallible rule? he must be content to resolue me in the like question: How chanceth it, so many Iewes liue vnconuerted
in Spaine and Italy, and other places, eyther in the Popes dominions, or where his authoritie is established, if the infallibilitie of his authoritie, or their Church, be such an excellent rule? If they replie, the Iewes might beleeue all points of Roman-Catholike faith aright, so they would admit their Church as Iudge or mistresse of faith: the Iewes might with as good reason reioyne: so might the Romanes beleeue all points of Iudaisme, would they acknowledge this supposed infallibility of doctrine to be in their Rabbinicall expositions, not in the Popes determinations. But the Romist, I suppose, would desire a signe ere hee beleeued them here: and are wee lesse bound by the rule of faith, to desire some tollerable satisfaction to these reasons following, ere we beleeue them in this point, as preiudiciall in our iudgement to religion in generall, as subscription to Rabbinicall doctrine is vnto Christian veritie.

10 The Iewes admit the old Testamentes authoritie as vndoubtedly as the Iesuites doe the Popes: yet it enlightens not their hearts. What is the reason? Because that part of Scripture is so obscure? So Valentian (and such as follow him) in all congruitie must say; yea hee hath said it:Before cited, lib. 2. sect. 2. 2. cap. 2. That veile which Saint Paul saith is put before the hearts of Iewes that they cannot behold the glorie of the Gospell (as the Apostle there argues) is wouen for the most part of the difficulties of Scriptures. Nor doe the Iewes onely denie the new Testament to bee infallible, but bitterly inueigh against it as erroneous and contradictorie to the old. What is the cause? Is it not that which Valentian elsewhere assignes? The Scripture alone (that is in his language, without the infallible auouchment of their Cburch) is so farre from ending all controuersies of faith, that it rather occasions controuersies and dissentions in doctrines of faith. If to the Iewe, through his default, the writings of Moses and the Prophets bee so obscure: adde your infallible key to open his heart to them, or them to it. If by this obscuritie they minister matter of contention, or their sense mistaken exasperate Iewish malice against Christians: Interpose your humane authoritie inspired from aboue, to allay the feruencie of their distempered zeale.

11 You acknowledge this obscuritie and other obiected insufficiencies
(disinabling the Scripture for ruling or iudging mens faith) to arise from the frailtie or vitiousnesse of humane nature, and hence you plead your Churches infallibility as necessarie and all-sufficient to supply these defects incident vnto Scripture, not in it selfe, but in respect of vs. Your Churches authoritie then (at the least adioyned to Scripture) should make men (oth • rwise subiect to the former infirmities or vitious dispositions) capable of heauenly doctrine. Tell vs then distinctly: Can it, or can it not make all, or most, or such as the Scriptures doe not, beleeue aright? If this it cannot doe adioyned to Scriptures: it is by your owne obiections against them, a rule as vnsufficient, as you would make them without it. If it can make all or most, or such as Scripture alone doth not, beleeue aright; this it must effect, eyther by remouing or not remouing those diseases or infirmities of humane nature, which Scriptures without it cannot cure.

12 First, if it would remoue that temper which makes the Iew a more vnprofitable hearer of Scripture, then young Gallants are of stoicall morall discpline, your Church is guiltie of wilfull malice and murther of soules that will not apply this infallible key, able of it selfe to open that veile of adamant, wherewith the Iewes hearts are so masked, that neither the light of Mosaicall, Propheticall, Apostolicall, or Euangelicall writings can finde entrance vnto them. Secondly, albeit this supposed infallible authoritie could remoue the former veile, yet were it not in this respect to be acknowledged an infallible rule of faith, but rather an ordinarie and necessarie meanes, (such as we acknowledge the lawfull magistracie or ministerie to bee) for squaring or proportioning mens fraile or exorbitant affections, the better to parallell with Gods word, the most exact, inerrable, and all sufficient rule of faith, euen by your consent: were it not for this infirmitie or vitious disposition of mans nature, which (as you likewise acknowledge) is the sole cause why the Scriptures are obscure and minister matter of contention.

13 But our aduersaries attribute not any such vertue to their infallible rule, as to make a foole wise, the lasciuious chast, the drunkard sober, a knaue honest, the impudent modest, or ambitious lowly: for euen the Pope himselfe, in whose bosome
this rule lodgeth, may harbour these and like vices in his brest: he may (by his owne followers confession) be as incorrigible for bad life and manners, as infallible for matters of doctrine. Seeing then their supposed rule cannot remoue those impediments which detaine the Iewes with other infidels and heretikes from the truth: can it make men beleeue aright whilest they remaine? If it can: it is of greater force than eyther our Sauiours authoritie or skill in Scriptures. Neyther of which, not all his trauels and best indeuours heere on earth, though infinitely surpassing any paines the Pope is willing to take, could instruct the Iewes in the doctrine of faith, whilest their carnall affections remained in strength. How can ye beleeue, (saith he, who spake as neuer man spake, Iohn. 5.44. and had wrought those works none other could) which receiue honour one of another, and seeke not the honour that commeth of God alone?

14 To conclude then, If the infidelitie of the Iewes be any iust exception, why Scriptures cannot be the perfect rule of faith: this exception will disinable the Romane Churches infallible authoritie, for being such a rule. But if the generall error of the Iewes, in the very maine foundation of religion, be no iust exception, why eyther the Scripture according to vs, or the Churches authoritie according to them, should not bee the rule of faith: then cannot the errors of heretikes, or varietie of opinions about the sense and meaning of particular places of lesse moment, impeach the sufficiency of Scripture, for performing all that is required by eyther partie in their supposed absolute rule. For it shall, God willing, be made euident in due place, that the selfe-same affections (only different in degree, sometimes not so much) which caused the Iewes infidelity in our Sauiours time, are the onely rootes and fountaines of heresies and dissentions throughout all ages.

15 And as elsewhere is already proued, wheresoeuer the habituall affection for degree and qualitie is, the heresie or infidelitie is likewise the same, euen in such as hold contrarie opinions, and would perhaps maintain their cōtrariety vnto death: for, as many, strongly perswaded of their beleefe in Christ, shall goe for infidels in that last day: so may such, as thinke themselues Orthodoxes, be tainted with the contrarie heresie which they impugne, if subiect
to the same affections which did breed it. But for vs to account such as make profession of Christianitie, infidels, or such as subscribe to Orthodoxall doctrine, heretikes, would bee iniurious and vnlawfull: not because the former assertion indefinitely taken is not warrantable; but because no man can precisely discerne the identitie of inward affection, saue he alone that knoweth the secrets of all hearts. Thus all the blasts of vaine doctrine they can oppose vnto the truth we maintaine, doe in the issue fasten the rootes of faith once rightly planted, howsoeuer they may shake the timorous or faint-hearted Christian, or cause the weake in faith, not cleauing to Scripture as their onely infallible rule, and sure supporter, dangerously to reele and stagger. But though they fall, yet Gods word shal neuer faile to approue it selfe a most perfect rule, besides others in these two respects: first, in that none can faile in that course which it prescribes, or fall away from faith but by such meanes as the Iew hath done, the true causes of whose Apostasie, and incredulitie it hath expresly foretold, and fully registred to posteritie: Secondly, because such as it doth not, no other rule, meanes, or authoritie possible eyther in the earth, or in the region below the earth, shall euer winne to true Christian faith.

div.head: CHAP. V.
The sufficiency of Scriptures for finall determination of controuersies in Religion, proued by our Sauiours and his Apostles authoritie and practise.
div.p:
1 NOr will they be ruled by an Angel from heauē, that will not obey the liue voice of the Sonne of God; whose miracles, whilest he liued here on earth, ioyned with his doctrine, we will suppose, were of as much force (if the Iesuit wil grant no more) as the Popes proposal of Scriptures, to beget faith, or cōuince gainsaiers of truth. The Iewes were of diuers opiniōs about his doctrine. some said he was A good man, others said no, but he deceiueth the people,
Iohn. 7.12. he giues them a rule (as you heard before) how to discerne it. If any man will doe his will, he shall know of the doctrine, &c. This contents them not,
albeit he had done many and good workes amongst them sufficient to haue manifested his diuine authoritie vnto such as had neuer heard of Moses or a Messias to come: Nay, they goe about to kill him for those workes, which bare testimonie of his woorth, and as they thought, had warrant of Scripture for so doing, because he did them on the Sabbath day. Heere Christ is of one opinion, the Iewes of another concerning the sense of Scripture: who shall iudge? or by what rule must their contrarie doctrine be tried? By Christs infallible authoritie? they admit it not: By extraordinarie and miraculous workes? they persecute him for his miracles alreadie wrought for their peoples good. Doth Christ heere leaue them, because destitute of a rule to recall them? If hee had none, how shall the Pope, (by his owne challenge but his Vicar) haue any to conuince his aduersaries? If Christ submit his diuine doctrine to any other rule, how dare the Pope denie submission of his to the same? what rule then was left? Onely the Scripture, which both did acknowledge. They pretend Moses law concerning Sabbath-breach why he should die: vnto their false interpretation of this, our Sauiour opposed the true meaning of another Mosaicall Sctipture. Moses forbad murther as well as Sabbath-day breaking: and yet they seeke to kill Christ, onely for healing a man vpon the Sabbath day, so forgetfull are they of the one, and so partially addicted to the other. But how shall they know, that to make a man whole vpon the Sabbath, was not to breake it, and violate Moses law? This our Sauiour makes euident vnto them, by exposition of that law, and their owne custome, which, continued from the first promulgation, was a good interpretation of it. Moses, saith our Sauiour, gaue vnto you circumcision (not because it is of Moses but of the Fathers) and ye on the Sabbath day circumcise a man. If a man on the Sabbath day receiue circumcision, that the law of Moses should not be broken, be ye angrie with me, because I haue made a man euery whit whole vpon the Sabbath day? Iudge not according to the appearance, but iudge righteous iudgement. Thus was Scripture applied to their conscience, the last and finall rule by which they stand or fall: and is alwaies a light eyther bringing men to see their owne saluation, or putting out their wonted sight, in token of their condemnation to vtter darknesse. And Christes last wordes in that
controuersie, Deut. 1. v. 16. & 17. Iudge not according to the appearance, are likewise a written rule of Scripture; so absolute a rule is this sacred word of God, (by our Sauiours consent and practise) both to informe the vnderstanding, and to moderate, affection which makes vs blinde.

2 The same methode our Sauiour vseth in a like dispute, with the last Glosse whereof if we compare the Romanists doctrine in this controuersie, it may appeare in som sort the same: Theirs is our Sauiours indeed, but quite inuerted, truly Antichristian. They teach we cannot know Mosaicall or other Scriptures, but by the Popes infallible proposall: The great infallible Teacher tels the Iewes, they could not beleeue him, or know his doctrine though proposed by him mouth to mouth, because they had not beleeued Moses writings, If ye beleeue not his writings,
Iohn. 5. vers. 41. how shall ye beleeue my words? yet Christs words registred by his Apostles and Euangelists must be at the least of like force and vse to vs, as Mosaicall writings were then to the Iewes. Our conclusion therefore is inuincible: If Moses doctrine alone were a rule to trie Christes controuersies with the Iewes, then must it and Christ conioyned be the rule whereby all Christians controuersies must bee tried. From the opportunitie of this place, the iudicious Reader, though not admonished, would obserue, that our aduersaries, vnlesse possessed with Iewish phrensie or phantasticke madnesse (diseases causing men vsually misdeeme other for such as they most are, but least thinke themselues) could not possibly account it a part of folly in vs,Qui fieri potest, vt quae doctrina tam facilè ab hominibus adulteratur vt in patrociniū omnium errorū aduocetur, eadem sit accommodatissima, appositissima{que} regula ad reijciendum omnes omnino errores. Non magis hoc certè stare potest quam si quis diceret, illud esse accommodatissimum remediū ad rectè vndendum ex quo accideret omnes caetulire quicunque fierent caeci Valentian loco saepius citat. §. 5. to make the WRITTEN WORD sole vmpeire in all contouersies of Religion, though not impossible to be thus peruerted by these Iewes, or others of Iewish disposition, as are all heretikes more or lesse. For we will giue our imaginations a yeares respite to roue about, vpon condition they will then returne an answere, what rule, eyther written or vnwritten, can possibly be imagined, which would not bee peruerted: what authoritie, eyther liuing or dead, which would not bee eyther disclaimed, abused, or contemned by men so minded as these Iewes, who in the liue presence of the Sonne of God, the heire of all thinges by whome the world was made and must bee iudged, thus sought to patronage the murther of his royall person by the authoritie of his Fathers
word, vnto whose sense they thought themselues as strictly tied as any Papist to the Councell of Trent. The Heretikes with whom Non est mirum si l'elagiani dicta nostra in sensus quos volunt detorquere conantur: quando de Scripturis sanctis, non vbi obscure aliquid dictum est, sed vbi clara & aperta sunt testimonia, id facere consueuerunt, more quidem hareticorum etiam caeterorum August. lib. 2. de Nupt. & concupisc. cap. 31. This was the place which Ʋalentian (as was noted in the first Chapter of this section) to proue the insufficiency of Scriptures for composing controuersies, would haue obserued. The reader I doubt not will note his shame or folly or both, that either could not or would not see how easily these men would haue wrested the Trent councel or any other rule they can imagine. For restraining such euident peruersnesse we acknowledge the necessity of a lawfull magistracy, whose vsefulnesse in this or like doth no way argue an absolute infallibility in determining all cases of controuersie. Saint Augustine had to deale, strangely wrested his words against a plaine and naturall meaning. Though so they had done the Bishops of Rome, or any others then liuing, not disdaining to call God his Lord: their practise had not seemed strange to this reuerend Father: for hee knew the seruant was not aboue his master, & therfore could not expect his or any mans should be free from any such wrong or violence which he saw offered to Gods word.

3 Our Sauiour in the fore-cited controuersies saw well how earnestly the Iewes were set to peruert Scriptures for their purpose, how glad to finde any pretence out of them eyther to iustifie their dislike of his doctrine, or wreake their malice vpon his person. Reason he had as great to distaste their practise herein as the Pope himself can haue to inueigh against heretiks for the like. Neither is there any person now liuing, against whom any intention of harme can be more heinous then the intention of murther against him, nor any sort of men (vnlesse the Iesuites, Spanish Inquisitors, or such as they suborne) so cruelly bent as these Iewes were, to seeke bloud vnder a shew of loue to pure immaculate religion. Yet doth not our Sauior accuse the Scriptures (though capable of so grieuous & dangerous misconstruction) of obscurity or difficultie, or of being any way the occasion of Iewish heresie, or his persecution thence caused: nor doth he disswade those very men, which had thence sucked this poisonous doctrine, much lesse others, frō reading, but exhorts them in truth & deed, not in word & fancie only, to relie on Scriptures as the rule of saluation. Search the Scriptures, for in thē ye think, & (that rightly) to haue eternall life. Not intimating the least necessitie of any external authority infallibly to direct them, he plainly teacheth it was the infernal distorture of their proud affections, which had disproportioned their minds to this straight rule, and disinabled them for attaining true beliefe, which neuer can be rightly raised but by this square & line.

4 It was not then the reading of Scriptures which caused them mistake their meaning and persecute Him, but the not reading of them as they should. Erre they did, not knowing the Scriptures
and know them they did not, because they did not read them throughly, sincerely, searching out their inward meaning. And thus to read them a fresh, as our Sauiour prescribed them, (laying aside ambitious desires) was the only remedie for to cure that distemper which they had incurred by reading them amisse. It were a mad kinde of counsell (better befitting a witch or cunning woman, then a wise man) to disswade one frō vsing medicines prescribed him by men of skill, because he had incurred some dangerous disease, by taking the like out of his own humour, or in a fancy, either without or contrary to the prescript of professed Physitiōs: yet such and no better our aduersaries aduise heretofore hath beene: and the strength of all their arguments in the point now in hand to this day cotinues this: We must not make Scriptures the rule of faith, because many heresies haue sprung thence, and great dissensions growne in the Church, whiles one followes one sense, and another the contrarie. Whereas in truth, the onely antidote against contentions, schismes, and heresies, is to read them attentiuely, and with such preparation as they prescribe; as Gal. 5. v. 26. not to be desirous of vaine glory, not to prouoke or enuie one another:
Pet. 1.2. v. 12 To lay aside all maliciousnes, guile, dissimulation, and euill speaking, like new borne babes desiring the sincere milk of the word, wherby we must grow,
Rom. 12 v.
• . not fashioning our selues according to this present world, &c.

5 These were deliuered as soueraign remedies against all epidemicall diseases of the soule, by Physitions, as both acknowledge, most infallible. For better vnfolding, & more seasonable applying of these and infinite other like aphorismes of life, we admit varietie of Commentators: but as farre from suffering any, of whose spirit we haue no proofe, (especially any not readie to submit the triall of his receits, vnto these sacred principles and experimentes answerable to them,)And good reason the porest creature liuing should tender the eternall welfare of his soule, as much as the Pope doth the transitory health of his bodie. to trie what conclusions hee list vpon our souls, as the Pope would be from taking what potions soeuer any English Empirick should prescribe, though disclaiming al examinations of his prescripts by Galen, Hippocrates, Paracelsus, or any other ancient or moderne well-esteemed Physitions rules.

6 If since this late inuention of the Popes infallibility our aduersaries do not now, as heretofore, condemne all reading Scriptures simply: what maruell? Ʋide lib. 10. secund. part. §. 2. cap. 4. §. 2. For as Sathan after once God had spoken to the world by his Son, began to change his old note, and
sought to imitate the Gospels stile, by writing his heresies as God did his new couenants in mens hearts: So in latter ages, since the Almightie gaue his word in euery language, and the number of Preachers hath beene greatly multiplied, the old Serpent permits the Iesuits & his other instrumēts to translate, expound, & preach the Gospell to the ignorant. And in opposition to the practise of reformed Churches, the lay Roman Catholike may now behold, yea read the words of life. What difference then can any make betwixt theirs and our doctrine in this point? such as in times past was betwixt true miracles wrought by the finger of God, and diabolicall wonderments, all which latter were vsually wrought to idle purposes, and by some apish tricke or other bewraied their authors sinister intendments:The Popes drift in permitting his laity to looke into the holy Scriptures and behold the maiesty of God speaking in thē (a matter heretofore held as dangerous for them, as for the Israelites in time past to haue approched the holy mount) is iust like the diuels in carrying our Sauiour into a high mountaine to shew him all the kingdomes of the earth, and the glory of them. The condition annexed to the Popes donatiue is the self same with that the diuell added to his profer, All these w • ll I giue vnto thee if thou wilt fall downe and worship me. For none may enioy Scriptures but with humble acknowledgement of asolute homage vnto the Pope as the sole & suprem iudg of all controuersie, cōcerning them: from whom all right vnto the means of their saluation must be deriued. Which kinde of worship is altogether as derogatory to Gods glory, as that which Sathan demanded of our Sauiour, or any other Idolatry that is or hath beene, as shall (God willing) hereafter appeare. So doth the cunning restraint of this liberty late granted to the Romane Laicks great in shew, bewray who was the author of this plot, and what his purpose. Some merry diuel sure is minded to make hell sport, by putting this gull vpon the learned Papist, his instrument to put the like vpon the ignorant, who now at length may read the Scriptures, but with absolute submission of their interpretation to his instructors, who may not take away any receit thence, but according to their supreme infallible Physitions prescripts, which may not bee examined by any rule of Gods written or vnwritten word: nor may any man call his skill in question, much lesse condemne him of imposture, by the lamentable issue and dismall successe of his practises. Should men vpon like termes be admitted to read Galen or Hippocrates, and yet the Monopoly of medicines permitted to some one Empiricke or Apothecarie, not lyable to any account whether his confectons were made according to the rules of Physicke art or no: They might be in greater danger of poysoning, then if these grand Physitions had neuer written: for that might be prescribed them, by such an authenticke Mountebanke, as a cordiall, which the other had detected for poyson. So should the Christian world, might, the Iesuites plea preuaile, be continually at the Popes courtesie, whether they should embrace that sense of Scriptures which Christ & his Apostles haue cōdemned for the doctrine of diuels, as the Oracles of the liuing God, & food for their soules.

7 But some man more indifferent would here perhaps interpose; Though theirs bee bad, doe you prescribe vs any better method of health? Your former counsell to practise the Apostles rules, is, as if a man should say to one sicke of a dangerous disease, Expell the bad humour and you shall be well. Yet as we said before, Est pars sanitatis velle sanari. To desire the extirpation of such affections as hinder our proficiency in the Schoole of Christ or know edge of his precepts, is a good step to health. The Scriptures are the wordes of life containing medicines as well as meate, and must purge our soules of carnall affections, as Physicke doth the body of bad humours: They teach with all what abstinence must bee vsed ere we can bee capable of that spirituall welfare, which they promise to the soule of such as follow their prescriptions. And because our naturall corruption cannot be asswaged, much lesse expelled, but by their force or vertue, which is not alwayes manifested vpon the first receipt; wee are to come vnto them with such reuerence, as the Moralist did to meditations of vertue, Vacua & sobria mente: in sobrietie of Spirit, not in the heat, abundance or actual motiō of such affectiōs as hinder their operation vpon our soules; as men vsually take Physicke vpon a fasting and quiet stomacke, although pestered with bad humours, which yet cannot be extirpate but by Physicke, nor by Physike, if ministred in the actuall motion, heate, or raging of such humours. If a man haue but this desire, to be ridde of such affections as breed this distemper in his soule, or worke a distaste of the word of life, he is capable of that promise, Habenti daebitur, and shall in good time see his desire augmented, whose encrease will bring forth greater feruencie in prayer; and prayers, if feruent, though in men subiect to such infirmities, auaile much, and shall in the end be heard to the full. And, as well in thankfull duty to the Redeemer of mankinde for his gracious promises, as in hope of being further partakers of the blessings promised; Euery one that heareth Gods word, ought, and such as heare it aright, will, as oft as they seeke recouery of their spirituall health by it, or such meanes as it prescribes, abstaine from all occasions and occurrents that may encrease, prouoke, or strengthen such affections as hinder the operations of it vpon their soules. For euen nature taught the Cynicke to accompt surfetting and intemperate diet madnes in the Heathen,
whiles they sacrificed for health. If any haue erred in hearing Gods word amisse, or in the vnseasonable applying of sacred prescripts: these errors must be recalled by further consultation with their dispensours, by more diligent search and better instruction in other parts of this method of life.

8 Saint Peter knew many ignorant and vnstable soules had peruerted some hard places of S. Paules Epistles, as they had other Scriptures, to their owne destruction. Did hee therefore aduise them to whom he thus wrote not to seeke their saluation out of Saint Paules Epistles, but with absolute submission of their iudgement, to his, and his successours prescripts? Or doth he not seeke to establish them in that doctrine which Saint Paul had taught, according to the wisedome giuen him, in all his Epistles, Or can any endued with reason doubt, whether Saint Paul himselfe did not expect his writings should bee a rule of faith to all that read them, without continuance either of his owne or others actuall infallible proposall of them? He had protested once for all, Gal. 1. vers. 8. Frō this place Ʋalentian after his woonted manner, would force an argum nt to proue the necessity of a perpetuall infallible authoritie to denounce viua voce the like Anathemaes against Heretikes. Whereas S. Pauls words, if wee consider all circumstances, do exclude any such infallible auhority or iudge of his meaning or other scripture by which he supposed all other doctrines should bee examined. And as a learned Papist well obserues vpon these words of S Paul to Ti. mothy, The scriptures are able to make thee wise vnto saluatiō (2. Tim. 3. vers. 15.) The Scriptures which hee had learned (to wit the old Testament) might performe the same to him in his absence which S. Paul had done in his presence; as he saith, sine schola Simonis, as we may adde, sine schola Papae, without the Popes cursing or blessing. vide Safhot. in cap. 3. 2. ad Timoth.
Though we, or an Angell from Heauen, preach vnto you otherwise then that wee haue preached vnto you, let him bee accursed. Hee had said before, and yet saith he now againe, If any man preach vnto you otherwise then yee haue receiued, let him bee accursed. For hee had taught them, as their owne conscience might witnesse, the doctrine of God and not man, as he intimateth in the next words.

9 Either Saint Paul is not authenticke in this protestation, or else all stand accursed by it, that dare absolutely admit any doctrine though from an Angels mouth, but vpon due examination and sure triall, whether consonant or contrarie to what Saint Paul hath left in writing. His meaning notwithstanding in many places as his fellow-Apostle witnesseth, was much peruerted. And seeing what was past could not be amended, it seemed necessary to S. Peter to admonish others least they should bee intangled in like errour. But what meanes had hee left to preuent this peruerting of Scriptures in them? Either none besides or none so good, as diligent reading or hearing the written word: For such was this Epistle, which for their admonition he now wrote, and was desirous, questionlesse, all of them should with attention heare or
reade, least they also might bee plucked away with the errour of the wicked, and fall from their wonted stedfastnesse: from which others had already fallen, For what reason? Because they were vnlearned: Vnlearned? In what facultie? In the Scriptures no doubt. For Saint Peter himselfe was learned onely in them, and would not vouchsafe the secular Artes of that time (standing in opposition vnto the Gospell) this glorious title of learning And is want of learning and knowledge in Scriptures, the cause of falling from faith, and former stedfastnesse? And yet must men abstaine from reading them, because they are obscure to such blinded guides, or may minister matter of contention to contentious spirits, or occasion of errour to the peruerse? Must we bee ignorant in them, and expert in other meanes of faith; Because ignorance and want of learning in them causeth errours in faith, and what other meanes soeuer of mens saluation? Quis furor hic (shall I say) ne moriare mori; or rather, ne possis aegrotare perire? That there is no danger can come by reading Scriptures for which the Scriptures haue not present remedy. Must wee abstaine from our spirituall food, and so ineuitably starue, because some others by vnreasonable or intemperate taking of it haue incurred, what? diseases indeede very grieuous; Yet such as might easily haue beene cu • ed or preuented, had the diseased beene more accustomed to feede vpon those plaine and easie prescripts vsuall in the latter parts of Saint Pauls Epistles, as (for example) amongst others vpon that most generall: Rom. 12. v. 3 • . Through the grace of God, that is giuen vnto me (I say) to euery one that is among you, that no man presume to vnderstand aboue that which is meete to vnderstand, but that hee vnderstand according to sobriety, as God hath dealt to euery man the measure of faith.

10 From carefull and assiduous attention vnto this and other like Elementarie precepts, those vnlearned but presumptuous readers of Saint Pauls Epistles might quickly haue grown so wise and well learned in Scriptures, as not to haue medled with these 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 so soone, at least not so much; rather contenting themselues while such they were, like new-borne babes with his milke, as much better for their weake digestion then his strong meate; so the same Apostle had else where expressely written for their instruction, had they not presumed to know aboue that which was written. Erred they had then from the truth, and fallen away from their former stedfastnesse, not so much by following the hard and
difficult, as by not following the plaine and easie places of Saint Paul, able to haue conducted them from knowledge to knowledge, whose mature fulnesse (could they with patience haue expected it,) might in good time haue ouergrowne the former difficulties.

Instances enough haue beene, more might bee brought, to reuiue the generall conclusion intimated in the state of the Question before proposed. There is no occasion or temptation which may moue men to obstinate mistaking or peruerting Scriptures to abet contentions, but the Scriptures one where or other haue a remedie as easie as soueraigne prescribed against it, so men would be diligent to seeke, or resolute to apply it found in their practise or course of life. If some Spiders from the fore-mentioned, or like difficult places, haue suckt poyson; yet other parts of the same Canon teach vs to lay aside the Spiders temperature, euen1. Pet. 2.1. all malitiousnesse,
Gal. 5. all enuie,
Iames 4. all indignation or conten • ion. Though sundrie as subtil as Serpents haue beene mistaken in the interpretation of some, or haue inuerted others, yet some third place teacheth vs to ioyne the Doues innocencie to the Serpents subtiltie; and vnto both adding the Bees industrie, these verie places, whence others suckt poyson, shall afford vs honie. For the word of God is in it selfe, and vnto vs (if we be not Spiders to our selues) Psal. 19. v. 10. sweeter then honie, and the honie combe.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

That all their obiections, drawne from dissentions amongst the learned or the vncertaintie of priuate Spirits, either conclude nothing of what they intend against vs, or else more then they meane or (at the least) dare auouch against Gods Prophets and faithfull people of olde.
div.p:
1 IT is a sure argument, the truth on our part is exceeding great, in that all obiections, hitherto brought by our aduersaries (as it vsually falleth out in men more eagerly set to offend others then defēd themselues, though otherwise vnequally matched) conclude,
Aut nihil, Aut nimium, either nothing or too much, or all for vs against the obiectours. But especially whilest they seeke to disswade the sufficiency of our supposed rule, by dissentiōs thence occasioned amongst the learned, or such as should be guides of others; as their proofes are curtailed, and will not touch the points they aime at, so the conclusion which they would shuffle in, not inferred from the premises, is aboue measure, euerlasting. First,Wherein our aduersaries proofes come short of what they aime at. they faile, in auouching that indefinitely of all, which is true onely of some parts of Scriptures. For many are so perspicuous and plaine, as they minister no matter of contention, no, not to the most contentious spirits professing our or their religion. These, well learned and laid vp in mens hearts, engaged in other particular controuersies, would be an excellent light to many other places, which for want of this method to most of both sides either seeme obscure, or of the same suite their seuerall dispositions are. But to omit particular causes of Heresies or Heretiques peruerting Scriptures (else where to be prosecuted) The most generall and Primarie is the quite contrary to that which our aduersaries assigne.

2 They except against Scripture, and say it cannot bee the rule of faith, nor ought to be so taken of all Christians, because it is so obscure, and apt to breede contentions among such as rely vppon it. Wee haue sufficiently prooued that all obscurities, all contentions about the sense of Scriptures in points of moment, arise hence; Because wee doe not admit of it for our onely rule;Partialitie either vnto our own or others opinion is the onely cause of contention amongst men, and dissention from the truth, euen amongst such as acknowledge the Scripture for their rule of faith: for it is one thing to say they make it, another indeed to make it or vse it as the rule of faith, in their practise or course of life. Whence our aduersaries obiections drawne f • om cōtentions amongst reformed Churches are easily answered. For these are not occasioned by relying vpon the Scripture, but because sundry in reformed Churches doe in deede, as the Papists both in deed and word, disclaime it for the rule of faith. all affection to mens persons, state or dignitie, all priuate quarrels laid a-part. If the Iesuite could prooue it should either continue obscure in points of faith, or minister matter of contention to such as conforme their liues to the Elementarie rules or easie precepts therein contained: their arguments were to some purpose. But while this they neither can nor goe about to proue; they shall onely proue themselues ridiculous Atheists, albeit we grant them all they desire, about the varietie of opinions (euen in places of greatest moment) among the learned. For, whatsoeuer they can obiect to vs, either concerning the varietie of opinions amongst the learned, or such distraction as might follow
thereon in the simple and illiterate,Wherein their conclusions ouer-reach. will conclude as much, both against that certaintie the Auncient Prophets themselues had of their owne visions, and the stedfastnesse of that beliefe which the faithfull amongst Gods people gaue vnto their predictions or prophesies. First it is euident from the story of Ahab, that lying Spirits did counterfeit visions then, as the Spirit of errour doth now the Spirit of truth; So as the false Prophets had strange delusions and appearances, as well as the true their diuine illuminations; where the contention amongst the professed Prophets themselues was as great as any now amongst the learned Interpretours of Prophesies or other Scriptures. And from this contention amongst the Prophets, the vnlearned, or rather all in that people not Prophets, were, by the Romanist obiections against vs, (were they pertinent) to wauer and hault betweene the contrarietie of illuminations and visions, professed as well by the false Prophets, as the true.
