These seducing Spirits hopes were not so desperate as to make them leaue their woonted trade, euen in Saint Cyprians time Spiritus insinceri & vagi, qui postea quam terrenis vitijs immersi sunt, & a vigore coelesti terrèno contagio recesserunt, non desi • unt perditi perdere, & deprauati errorem prauitatis infundere. Hos & poct • e daemonas vocant, & Socrates instrui se & regi ad arbitrium daemonis praedicabat. Hi ergo spiritus sub statuis atque imaginib{us} consecratis delitescunt. Hi ad flatu suo vatum pectora inspirant, extorum fibras animant, auium volatus gubernant, sortes regunt, oracula efficiunt. falsa veris semper inuoluunt: nam & falluntur & fallun • , vitam turbant, somnos inquietant Cyprian quod Idola Dij non sunt. Thus he spake of his owne experience, as he addes: nec aliud his studium est, quam a Deo homines auocare, & ad superstitionem sui ab intellectu verae religionis auertere: & cum sint ipsi paenales, quaerere sibi ad poe • am comites, quas ad crimen suum facerent errore participes. H • tamen ad • urati per deum verum nobis statim cedunt & fatentur, & de obsessis corporibus exire coguntur. These were the effects of Christs triall ouer Sathan, sure pledges that the strong man was now cast out. And the like power had not been so manifest before among the Sonnes of men. Nor will any Iesuite (I thinke) be so bold as to denie (least euery man might perceiue him to denie more, then possibly he could know) that those lying Spirits in the mouthes of Achabs Prophets, were then as cunning in imitating true reuelations, as now in counterfeiting Orthodoxall interpretations of truths reuealed. Or if this they call in question, let them resolue vs why Idolatrie in those ages, wherein true Prophets flourished most, should bee as frequent and various, as heresies in latter times, wherein the preaching of the Gospell is most plentifull. The true reason whereof as we suppose is this: These lying Spirits were alike apt to imitate Gods seuerall manner of speaking (whether by meanes ordinary or extraodinary) in diuerse ages. At all times, if we compare either their natiue capacitie or acquired skill with our owne, though in matters wherein we haue beene most conuersant: if to their sagacitie wee adde their malitious temper and eager desires of doing ill, which alwayes adde
an edge to wit in mischeuous inuention: In all these they so farre exceed the sonnes of seduced Adam, that vnlesse the Almightie did either assist vs by his Holy spirit, or restraine them in the exercise of their skill (especially in spirituall matters, wherewith the naturall man hath no acquaintance;) who could, in any age, be able to discerne their Iugling, much lesse, to avoide their snares, alwayes suited to the present season? Notwithstanding most euident it is, that in Ahabs as in al other times, tainted with the like or aequiualent sinnes; the Almightie giues them leaue to doe their worst; to practise with such cunning in euery kind, as leaues men, so disposed as these false Prophets were, (vntill they amend) no more possibilitie of distinguishing diuelish suggestions from diuine Oracles, than Ahab had (without repentance) to escape his doome read by Elias and Michaiah. For hee had not fallen, vnlesse his Prophets had beene first seduced; Their errour therefore was by Gods iust iudgement, as fatall as his fall; both absolutely ineuitable vpon supposition of their obstinate disobedience to the vndoubted mandates of Gods written law. Thus no one tittle of our aduersaries obiections (how the learned should be sure of their interpretations, when others as learned as they are as strongly perswaded to the contrary) but is as directly opposite vnto the certaintie of true Prophets reuelations; seeing many, yea most of that profession, and (in the iudgement of man) men of better gifts and places then such as prooued true Prophets, were otherwise perswaded; vsually such as the people esteemed best, strangeliest deluded.

3 That from this varietie of opinions among the Prophets about their illuminations, others not endued with the gift of Prophesie were in the selfe same case, the vnlearned people throughout the Christian world are in, wheresoeuer or whensoeuer dissentions arise amongst the learned, admit no question but amongst wranglers. For albeit the excellent brightnesse of diuine truth did necessarily imprint an infallible euidence in their apprehension, to whom it was immediately by meanes extraordinarie reuealed; yet could they not communicate this euidence or certainty vnto the people, but by preaching the word reuealed, after the selfe same manner we doe. Yea sometime it was onely communicated
vnto them by theIeremie. cap. 36. vers. 5.6. And Ieremiah commaunded Baruch, saying, I am sh • t vp & cannot goe into t • e house of the Lo • d Therefore goe thou, & reade the roule, wherein thou hast written at my mouth the words of the Lord, in the audience of the p • ople in the Lords house vpō the fasting day: also thou shalt reade them in the hearing of al Iuda that come out of their Cities. Ministerie of others, no Prophets. Here let any Iesuite, or other Patron of the Romish Churches cause, answere mee to these demaunds. First, whether the people were not bound to beleeue the true Prophesies (either deliuered by the Prophets owne mouthes or read by others, or directed to them in writing) to be the word of GOD; and to reiect the contrary doctrine of false Prophets, as delusions? Secondly, whether, if the ordinary people of those times could by any Christian, though priuate men in latter, may not by the same, meanes, distinguish the word of God (being in like sort read, or expounded or preached vnto them) from the word of man? The word remaines still the same; the truth of it better confirmed vnto the world, by the continuance of it in power and strength throughout all ages intermediate, wher • in Gods Spirit (by which it was first manifested to the Prophets, and written in the peoples hearts) hath beene more plentifull then before, especially since the reuelation of the Gospell; most plentifull in this present (if I may so speake) the second time of grac • . Our argument then stands good (A fortiori) If euery priuate man amongst GODS people of olde might and ought beleeue, and beleeuing obey, his word reuealed to others, onely read or expounded vnto him, reiecting all contrarie or erroneous doctrines; the people of this age must doe the like: and all obiections possible against the iudgement of moderne priuate spirits, conclude as much against all priuate persons of auncient times: For, their meanes of knowing the Prophets illuminations or visions were ordinarie; such as wee haue now; liable to all excep • ions that can be made against our knowledge or perswasion of the true sense of Scripture; But neither theirs nor our imbecillitie in knowing, or facilitie of erring, was or is any iust exception why the Scripture should not be a rule to both. Albeit all the Papists arguments might be vrged with farre greater probabilitie against them who were to beleeue propheticall writings first. For more easie it is to assent vnto particulars contained in a general Canon already established by the approbation of former ages, and confirmed by ioynt consent of parties most aduerse and contrarie in the interpretation of seuerall parcels; then to admit the gener •• l
Canon it selfe for the vndoubted word of GOD, or yeeld obedience to the particulars therein contained. Yet were the Auncient-people bound to admit the prophesie of Isaias, Ieremie, as the vndoubted word of God; albeit vnknowne to their Auncestors, but onely in the generalitie of Moses doctrine: much more (as we conclude) may Christians, now liuing, assent vnto the true expositions or particular contents of these prophesies, or other Scriptures; of whose absolute truth in generall they doe not doubt, and of whose particulars they may now beholde the sundrie opinions and expositions of diuers ages.

4 To presse the former arguments more fully paralelled to our presen • controuersie, a little farther: I would demaund of any Iesuite, whether the word of God taught by the Prophets, (who were to winne credite by their skill, not presumed skilfull for their authority in the Church, or credit in Common-weale,) or the definitiue sentence of the High-Priestes or others in eminent place, were to be the rule of Israels faith? Whether the peoples distraction in following some one false Prophet, some another, fewest of all, the true Prophets, most, their High-Priests and men in authoritie; might exempt any from acknowledgement of such Prophesies, as in the issue prooued diuine, for the rule of their beliefe? If that people, either vpon the varietie of opinions, or the authoritie of the Priestes or others, might reiect the word of God, either preached vnto them by the Prophets, or read by others; or appeale from it to any visible companie of men; on whose decrees they might safely relie: then may the Romanists with some probabilitie teach men to relie vpon the decrees of their Church, for their infallible rule, not vpon Scriptures onely. But if the people of those times were bound to relie vpon MOSES Law and the Prophets writings, against all the world besides, albeit ioyntly cōspiring to teach them otherwise, though with glozes and pretences of Moses authoritie: then much more must these writings bee of like authoritie vnto vs. And all the mimicall obiections which the Iesuites can frame to this or like purpose [If the Scripture be the rule of faith, and must bee discerned by priuate Spirits, how comes it to passe that Caluin expounds it one way, Luther another, Zwinglius a third, and yet all thinke they haue the spirit?] are the very same in effect, with the false Prophet
Zedkiah's exception against Michaiah 1. Kings cap. 22. vers. 24. When went the Spirit of the Lord from me to speake vnto thee?

5 Zedkiah had foure hundred more of his opinion; and this people had beene very dull, if conscious of their owne factious greatnes they could not haue pleaded all the Papists arguments against Michaiah; all that can be drawne from the vniuersalitie or authoritie of the Church: All which haue mere ignorance or incogitancy of a diuine prouidence for their root, but branch themselues in their after-grouth into positiue Atheisme, and contradictious infidelitie. First their Authours (the Priests • nd Iesuites) erre, not knowing the Scriptures nor the power of God, able to leade men vnto life, by this written way, though narrow and priuate, yet straight and plaine: Afterwardes (as if they were Satans sworne Takers, or authorized Purueyours to furnish Hell with guests) obseruing some, who rather idly wish or loosly proffer, then seriously purpose or earnestly striue, to enter in at the straite gate, either faile in their first aduentures, or finally miscarrie; they watch hence all opportunites of hailing passengers to their broad beaten Catholique way, which almost all heretofore haue gone, as they brag, wherein a blinde man, so hee wil • follow his guide, cannot easily trippe; so I thinke, vntill both come at the very Pitbrincke of destruction, whereunto it tends directly and infallibly. But is this your Catholike way more plaine or better beaten then rebellious Israels or Iudahs was? Could not these also (whilest backed by their blinded guides) haue mockt at priuate Spirits, and bestowed titles vpon Gods true seruants, (because in number fewest and most opposite to their Prelates) as foule and odious, as Sectaries, Schismatikes, or Heretiks? Or did these willingly and wittingly goe astraie, as knowing their wayes to bee the wayes of death? Esay. 5. v. 15. Therefore my people is gone into captiuitie (saith the Lord) because they had no knowledge. Ignorance, the nurse of your deuotion, was the true mother of their Superstition and Idolatrie: yet was this want of knowledge, which thus prooued the fertile seed of all t • eir insuing misery, the natiue fruit of their former negligence in not practising the knowne precepts of Moses Law. And because increase of ignorance in Gods word did breed in them a greater d • light of hearing lies, and pleasant things, then the truth, hee gaue them their iust, as he had done their forefathers quailes in his
displeasure. Ezeeh 14. vers. 3.4.5. Sonne of man (saith the Lord vnto his Prophet) these men haue set vp their Idols in their heart, and put the stumbling blocke of their iniquitie before their face: should I, being required, answere them? Therefore say vnto them, Thus saith the Lord God, Euery man of the house of Israel, that setteth vp his Idols in his heart, and putteth the stumbling blocke of his iniquitie before his face, and commeth to the Prophet, I the Lord will answere him that commeth, according to the multitude of his Idols: That I may take the house of Israel in their owne heart, because they are all departed from me through their Idols.

6 This euidently prooues, that vnlesse the Morall Law be duly practized, and those stumbling blocks which the wicked set before their faces remooued: to seeke after such a facile, inerrable rule, as the Papists haue framed for direction in points of faith, is, to sollicit a snare for their owne soules, as no doubt God gaue the Romanes, for their d • stast of his word and that longing after Gentilisme Cap. 3. before mentioned, this broken reed, whereon to this day they relie, as hee had done the Israelites a King in his wrath. And though in euery age, since the Go • hes and Vandals ouer-ranne the Empire, God hath raised vp some poore Michaiah to withstand their state Prelates: Yet those lying Spirits, which possessed Ahabs Prophets, haue euer borne greatest sway in that Church, seducing Princes and people, as they had done Ahab, by multitude of voices, to their owne destruction. That the Romanists can produce men of great fame and note through many generations for their defence in some one point or other, it skils not much. For as God, in This law of Deutronomie holds true in proportion through • ut all ages. Jf there arise among you a Prophet, or a dreamer of d • eames, and g ue thee a signe or wonder, (And the signe and th • wonder which he hath told thee, come to passe,) saying, • et v • g • after other Gods which thou hast not knowne, and let vs serue thē, T • o • shalt not hearken to the wordes of the Prophet, or vnto that drea •• r of dream • s: for the Lo • d you • G d, p ooueth • o • to kn • w w •• ther yee 〈◊〉
• e Lord ••• r God w h a • your heart, an w th all y ur sou • e. times past, suffered Prophets or Dreamers to take opportunitie, from their strange predictions, of inticing his people to Idolatrie, forbidden by his written Law: so in euery age, his prouidence permits men of excellent gifts, and great skill in Scriptures, to haue, yea to seek to establish their plausible errours vnder pretences of reuelations, secret assistance, or abundant measure of his Spirit; that by this meanes hee may trie our fidelitie in searching Scriptures, and diligence in trying Spirits, as hee did the Israelites by such presumptions of diuine Prophesies, or Visions. And if amongst this great varietie of opinions I might deliuer mine, as freely as I willingl • submit it to each sober Prophets censure, (much more to the correctiō of my lawful
Superiours,) I should (for ought I yet see to the contrarie) auouch; first, that no Christian in any age, but is oft put vpon his triall Whether hee loue God or the great ones of this world more? Whether he will confesse or deny Christ before men? Secondly, That, during these dayes of peace and securitie which we now enioy, our acquitall or condemnation in both the Two former mayne interrogatories, stands especially vpon our abandoning or abetting their errours in some points of danger, whose worth in others we iustly admire. So much addicted are we, for the most part, to such mens persons, as haue beene Gods instruments for o • r good; that vpon often experience of those wholesome medicines where with their shops are plentifully furnished, wee swallow downe whatsoeuer there wee finde: when as perhaps the disease they had to deale with, or some other circumstances of the time, were such, as required an extraordinary medicine, which whilest wee administer without mixture of like ingredients, or not vpon the same occasions, wee may chance to poyson both our selues and our Patients. Others of vs againe are so much accustomed to politique obseruation, that we commonly make no other triall of diuine truths, then by some such forinsicall forme of proceeding, as is vsed in secular inquisitions; wherein determinations goe by calculation of most voyces. But vnlesse the Lord did suffer vs to haue plausible shewes and goodly inducements in the worlds sight, for beleeuing that which is contrary vnto truth; our faith should not be sincere, nor as an Armour of proofe to resist all temptations; seeing there is no man almost, but is apt by nature to follow a multitude, to doe that which publique lawes haue iudged euill, much more to thinke or beleeue as most men, or men most esteemed, doe. On the contrary if wee looke into our calling,1. Cor. 1. v. 26. Not many wisemen after the flesh, not many noble are chosen of God. Such as are his ought to be like him in this, that they see not as men (not as naturall men be they neuer so many) see, nor iudge not as they iudge.

7 The stay whereupon they, as in all other difficulties, so especially in this triall of Spirits, must relie, is his prouidence; which in time will bring the truth to light, and daily diffuseth the odour of life, able, (were not our senses dull or prepossessed with the fragrant smell of earthly pleasures) to lead vs to that inuisible truth
which in this life wee must follow not by view, but by faith. Yet not by faith, if we take the Iesuites for our guides, who in this present controuersie play false Huntsmen, alwayes seeking to bring vs from the prints of Gods prouidence, vnto the pathes and footsteps of men, that haue corrupt their wayes; casting the forme of secular proceeding before our eyes, so to withdraw vs from following him who hath sweetned the aire wherein we breath, with the words of eternall life. If men would bee so mad, as to frame their liues according to their doctrine: Hell it selfe could not wish a more diuellish meanes to make men Christians in conceit, and Atheists or Infidels in heart. And yet besides the impietie of all other kindes of Heresies or Infidelities that are or haue bin, this of theirs is the most palpably absurd, and most contradictorie to the rules of reason and principles of Arts receiued by all. For if the arguments they bring against vs, conclude any thing at all, they conclude as much against all certaintie of secular or natural sciences.

8 And because (whether purposely or as meere instruments managed by Sathan to what vse they know not) they still labour to make ciuill modestie but a maske for infidelitie; rightly iudging (though to a wrong end) ingenuous humilitie and mens lowly conceipts of their owne worth the fittest disposition, whence vtter distrust of Gods fauour towardes such poore creatures, as men so minded deeme themselues, can be wrought; and if once wrought and deeply planted in soft mindes or humble hearts, the onely sure foundation, whence they can hope to raise their blinde implicite faith: It shall not be amisse, whilest we prosecute the second branch of their immoderate folly, last mentioned, to discouer withall, and partly dissolue, the snares which they haue set for the simple and ingenuous.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

How farre, vpon what termes or grounds, wee may with modestie dessent from the Auncient or others of more excellent gifts then our selues: That our aduersaries arguments impeach as much the certaintie of humane sciences as of priuate Spirits.
div.p:
1 LEt it bee granted, that many places of great moment are diuersely expounded by learned men: what will hence follow? That not the greatest Schollers in reformed Churches can bee assured of their true sense and meaning, as the Pope? Not, vnlesse you first can make it euident, that learning or subtilitie of wit is the onely meanes, whereby the true sense of Scriptures can be found out. And this being prooued; you must assure vs that the Pope is alwayes better learned then others; otherwise hee may faile as well as they. Or if you admit not learning for the onely meanes of distinguis • ing doctrines, as indeed it is not; yet must you secure the world, that the Pope hath all those other good qualifications, whose want caused the learned to erre. Or if you require neither one nor other of these; you must prooue that the best gifts of God, (the peculiar attribute of whose glory, is, to be no respecter of persons) are infallibly entailed to a certaine succession of men, without all respect of learning, wit, or honesty. Lastly you must proue that the holy Ghost was a priuate Spirit, and might erre, when he said, The Lord giueth grace to the humble, Or, the Law of the Lord, wisedome vnto the simple: And that our Sauiours words, Ventus spirat vbi vult, did not import, (as he ment) that his Spirit might enlighten whom he pleased: For if all these, and that, Deus cuius vult miseretur, be true; who can hinder him or his Spirit to open the eyes of some lesse learned, to behold clearely the true sense and meaning of that Scripture, wherein many excellent writers haue either erred or beene ouerseene? or who can hinder God (if these places be true) to reueale his will to little ones, and keepe it secret from the wise, and mightie, because it is his pleasure so to doe? and that for this end, that men should learne to relie vpon his mercy, and prouidence; not vpon the authoritie or skill of men.
Or who can hinder his Omnipotency euen in this age to make his power seene in our weaknes? If this his power be not limited now: then may he still both reueale the true sense and meaning of his word in some points, vnto men of lesse capacitie in others; and furnish them with abilitie too, for demonstrating by euidence of argument, and surest grounds of reason vnto others, that this sense must needes be the true sense, and that all other interpretations giuen of the same places, by men otherwise excellent for their learning and skill in Scripture, cannot stand with those principles of Christian faith, which all sorts of beleeuers stedfastly beleeue. Must such a man, or those to whom God reueales the truth by his ministrie, doubt of the euidence of the truth reuealed, and mistrust Gods word; because others as learned, or more learned then either he that hath the truth reuealed vnto him first, or they that take it from him, are of another minde? Hee must verily by this obiection. For a Iesuite would say, Why should he not thinke others as likely to haue the spirit, as himselfe? Let him esteeme of them, as farre better Schollers, and men indued with as great, or greater measure of Gods Spirit then himselfe; for so the Scripture teacheth vs not to be wise in our own conceipt, Phil. 2. v. 3. but to thinke better of others then of our selues. And againe,1. Cor. 14. v. 32. the Spirits of the Prophets are subiect to the Prophets.

2 And yet both these rules concerne the greatest Schollers, & most skilfull interpreters in some degree, as well as the meanest. For none is so absolutely good, none so farre exceedes another; but in part may bee exceeded by him. Nor doth this Christian modestie, which the Scripture thus teacheth, binde any Christian soule, or ingenuous minde, to such absolute seruilitie, as the obiection must inforce vpon all, if it proue ought: For there is no ingenuous man, especially of meaner gifts, but will in heart and conscience acknowledge many, both auncient and moderne, for farre more excellent Schollers then himselfe: and yet be fully perswaded in conscience, that in sundrie particulars hee hath the truth on his side which they oppugne; and the true sense of Gods Spirit in some pointes wherein they haue erred, or were ignorant. For neither will an indefinite proposition, in matters whose reuelation depends vpon the free will and libertie of Gods Spirit, and are in respect of vs contingent, inferre euery particular:
nor will one or few particulars in any point inferre an vniuersall proposition, or such as we call vera vt plurimum true for the most part. Now to say and beleeue, that such a man is a better Scholler and of far more excellent gitfs, is but indefinite, not infinite, for the extent of his Schollership, or gifts beyond mine: Wherefore it will not hence follow, that hee is a better Scholler, or interpreter in this, albeit he bee so in many, or in most other particulars; much lesse will it follow, that I am a better Scholler or interpreter then he, because I am better seene in this one, or few particulars. The consequence, or corollarie of which two assertions, is againe as euident: [I may without breach of modestie thinke I haue the truth on my side in sundrie particulars, against him that is farre better seene in Scriptures, and other sciences, then my selfe.] For albeit hee were much better seene in both then hee is: yet are his gifts measured as well as mine; although God hath giuen him a greater measure of such gifts, then me. Wherefore, as I would willingly yeeld vnto him in infinite others; so may I safely dissent from him in this or other particulars, that are contained in the small measure of Gods gifts vpon me; without any iust censure of arrogancy, or breach of modesty, for entring the lists of comparison with him absolutely. For now wee are to bee compared but in this one, or few cases; not according to the whole measure of Gods gifts in vs; which I acknowledge farre greater in him, and reuerence him as my superiour for them. And as I acknowledge him absolutely for my better; so is he in these particulars, in some sort, to yeeld superioritie vnto me. Christian modestie teacheth euery man not to bee hastie, or rash, in gain-saying the doctrine of the Auncient or other men of worth; but rather bindes him to diligence in examination of the truth, to vse deliberation in gain saying the opinions of men better learned then hims • lfe. But Christianitie it selfe bindes all Christians, not to beleeue mens authoritie against their owne consciences; nor to admit of their Doctrines for rules of faith, bee they neuer so excellent, vnlesse they can discerne them to bee the doctrine of that great Prophet, Cui DEVS non admetitur Spiritum: Hee cannot faile in any thing, and whatsoeuer hee saith, or what his SPIRIT shall witnesse to my SPIRIT to haue proceeded from him I am bound to beleeue. But for men,
to whom God giues his spirit but in measure, albeit in great measure, because I cannot know the particulars vnto which it extēds, I neither may absolutely refuse, nor absolutely admit their doctrines for true, vntill I see perfectly, how they agree with, or disagree from his doctrine, of whose fulnesse we haue all receiued. And euen the truth of their writings, to whom he hath giuen his gifts in great measure, I am to examine, by their consonancie vnto that small measure of his vndoubted gifts in my selfe, so farre as they concerne my selfe or others committed to my charge. And in the confidence of Gods promises, for the increase of faith & grace, to all such as vse them aright, euery Christian in sobriety of spirit may by the principles of faith, planted by Gods finger in his heart, examine the sentences, and decrees of the wisest men on earth: to approue them, if he can discerne them for true; to confute them, if false; to suspend his iudgement, and limit the termes of his disobedience vnto them if doubtfull; and finally to admit or reiect them, according to the degrees of their probability or improbability, which he vpon sober, diligent, and vnpartiall search directed and continued in reuerence of Gods word, and sincere loue of truth, shall finde in them.

3 All the arguments which they can heap vp from the varietie of opinions amongst the learned (albeit they could make a catalogue of confusion in this kinde, as long as the tower of Babel was high,) can onely proue thus much;That this dissention amongst the learned should rather moue all sober Christians to d • sclaime all infallible authoritie of men then to relie vpon any. That no man (especially no man indued with the gift of interpreting,) may relie vpon any other mans opinions, expositions, or decrees, without further examination of them: but onely vpon the Scripture it selfe, which neuer varieth from it selfe, nor from the truth; for this cause to bee admitted as the onely infallible rule of all diuine truthes, whereunto euerie man must conforme his beleefe and perswasions. For euen this varietie of opinions, about the particular sense or meaning of this Canon of truth, amongst such, as ioyntly acknowledge the infallibilitie of it in generall, is a sufficient reason to disclaime any mans authoritie for the rule of fairh: seeing experience shewes such varietie, and partialitie in them; and the generall foundation of faith, (held by all thus dissenting) bindes euerie man to beleeue, that the Scripture is not subiect
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
to any of these inconueniences. This vndoubted certainty of it, when it is rightly vnderstood and perceiued, should incourage all to seeke out the right sense and meaning of it, (which once found, is by all mens consent the surest foundation of faith, for by our aduersaries consent it is the ground of the Churches faith) and where they cannot presently attaine vnto it, to suspend their iudgements, & not to follow mens authori • ies (but onely in particulars, whose generals are contained in Sc • ipture) lest they may lead thē against the true sense & meaning o • i • . And if men generally should haue no other ground but mans authority, or beleeue this or that to be the meaning of Scripture because such a man or companie of men doth tell him so: beside • his wronging of gods spirit herein, he should also wrong many other men, oft-times far better learned, and skilfull in Scriptures more deare in the sight of God, & better acquainted with his spirit, then are they, on whose authoritie he relies. Euery one to whom God hath giuen a wise heart, & power in Scripture, might iustly challenge him of partialitie and disobedience, in not giuing as much to his authoritie, as to the former. But as the truth, reuealed vnto him by the meanest of Gods seruants, bindes his conscience to beleeue it: so the varietie of other mens opinions, (be it neuer so great, the authors and fauourers of them neuer so well learned, neuer so stiffe and confident in maintaining them,) ought to • e no motiue either to dissuade him from assenting vnto the truth knowne, or to discourage him in the industrious and sober search of it, by such good meanes as God hath appointed for his calling. For there hath beene as great varietie of opinions in other sciences and faculties, as in Diuinitie: yet no later Iesuite, nor other learned Papists, that I haue read or heard of, for these diuers hundred years, haue sought to proue, that no man can be certaine hee knowes any thing, because many think they know that which they do not. Or if any Iesuite will renounce Aristotle, and reuiue the old Academichs opinion, [That there can be no certaintie of any thing, but onely an opinion:] our Vniuersities shall be readie to answere him, albeit hereby they should disenable their supposed infallible rule as much as ours. In the meane time, holding Aristotles doctrine about the certainty of sciences for true, they answere themselues in all they can obiect against vs in this point.
For they neither denie a certainty in secular artes, because many erre: nor do they perswade young students in their schooles, to giue ouer their studious and industrious searching into speculatiue sciences, because many haue taken much paines in them to little purpose: Nor doe they hold it sufficient for good schollers in such matters, to relie wholly on other mens iudgements, without any triall of conclusions, or examination of arguments, according to the principles of those sciences which they haue professed. In a word, the varietie of opinions hath not yet occasioned them to create a Pope of artes, and secular sciences, albeit such a creature were (by their arguments) much more necessarie, or (at least) lesse harmefull in those faculties, then in matters of religion. For in them we haue no promise for the assistance of a secret teacher, the true illuminator of our soules, whose authoritie is as infallible, as the spirit of truth. Aristotle takes it for an infallible token that there is a certaintie to be had in sciences, because all men thinke themselues certaine in their perswasions of things that may bee knowne: as well those that know not the truth, but onely thinke they know it, as those that know it indeed. If Aristotles argument (which the Iesuites so acknowledge,) bee good: then is their argument in this cause most absurd. Many men (say they) perswade themselues they know the right sense of sundrie places in Scripture, when they do not, therefore no man, no priuate man, no man but the Pope, (qui neque Deus est neque homo,) by any search or industrie, can be sure that he hath it. Whereas by Aristotles reason, (which indeed is a rule of reason) the contrarie rather followes, That there is a certaintie to be had concerning the truth and true sense of Scripture by all such as seeke it aright,) because euen such as erre, and seeke it amisse, are strongly perswaded of their certaintie in it. From the same Topicke doe the schoolemen and other iudicious contemplators proue a certainty of true and perfect blisse, able alone to satiate the greedie appetite, and stay the vnconstant longing of mans soule, because euen miscreants and such as indefatigably hold on like dromidaries in those vngracious courses, which in wiser heathens sight lead directly vnto infelicitie and true miserie, cannot cast away all conceit of happinesse from which they wander, but rather suppose it to be seated in those sensuall
pleasures which they follow. Yet would our aduersaries arguments disprooue all certaintie in apprehension of true happinesse with greater probabilitie, then they can impeach the assurance of priuate spirits in any other points of faith, as might (to omit other reasons) bee proued by this one; Because some of their Popes (none of which as they suppose can erre in ordinarie matters of faith) neuer haue any taste or apprehension of true happinesse.

4 Of the manner of knowing the true sense of Scripture, occasion will be giuen vs in the last part of this discourse: of the impediments which trouble most men in this search, and of the originall of all errors in diuine matters, and the meanes to auoide them, wee shall speake, by Gods assistance, in the Article of the Godhead. Thus much may now suffice, that no man ought to be dismayed in seeking, or dispaire to finde, the true sense and meaning of Scriptures, in all points necessarie for him in his calling, because other men, much more expert in all kinde of learning then himselfe, haue fowly erred in this search, and finally missed of that they sought. For out of the rules of Scripture alreadie set downe, when such temptations shall arise in our breasts, wee may quell them thus. They who haue gone astray, were much better learned then I in all kinde of knowledge: It may bee they were hence more confident of their giftes; for scientia inflat, their excellent knowledge might puffe them vp with selfe-conceit; Isai. 29. v. 14. and hee that is wisest of all hath said, I will destroy the wisedome of the wise, and the vnderstanding of the prudent shall be hid: it may be, as they were exceeding wise, so they much gloried in their wisedome: but I will seeke to glorie onely in the Lord, of whom I haue receiued euerie good gift I haue, and will alwaies esteeme this best, which shall teach mee not to reioyce aboue that which is meete in any other: As they were prudent, so it may be they were proud, and the Scripture saith: Deus resistit superbis, God resisteth the proud, and such as trust too much to their owne conceit. As for mee I will not bee high-minded, but feare, for the same Scripture telles me, Deus dat gratiam humilibus, yea grace to vnderstand the true sense and meaning of his gracious promises made in Christ. And in confidence of them, I will continue these my daily prayers: Lord grant me true, vnfained,
Christian humility, and with it grace to know the wonderful things of thy law. Others haue erred, of farre more excellent naturall parts, euen men of deepest reach and surest obseruation. It may be, as their wits were stronger, and their vnderstandings riper: so their willes were vnrulier, and their desires of affections greener. But O Lord breake the stubbernesse of my will, purifie my heart, and renue a right spirit within mee: so shall I see thee, and thy goodnesse in thy word, which shall enlighten mee to teach thy waies vnto the wicked, and conuert sinners vnto thee: so shall thy law, thy perfect law, conuert my soule, for thy testimonies are sure,
Psal. 19. vers. 7. and giue wisedome to the simple. Yea but they who first instructed mee in thy word, doe dissent from mee in the interpretation of it. It may be they haue not folowed those rules, which thou taughtest thē, Lord giue me grace to meditate aright vpon thy testimonies, so shall I haue more vnderstanding then my teachers:
Psal. 119. v. 99. But what if the most reuerend and ancient Fathers of former times were of a contrarie minde? O Lord they were faithfull seruants in thy house, and yet faithfull but as seruants, not as thy sonne: and it may be thou didst suffer those thy worthy seruants to go awry, to trie whether I thy most vnworthy seruant would forsake the footsteps of thine annointed sonne to follow them: Heb. 3. vers. 5. but Lord teach me thy statutes, so shall I (in this point wherein I differ from them) haue more vnderstanding then the ancient. Thy name hath beene alreadie glorified in their manie excellent gifts, Psal. 119. v. 100 all which they receiued of thy bounteous hand: and it may bee that now it is thy pleasure, in this present difficultie, to ordaine thy praise out of such infants mouthes as mine. They out of this thy fertile and goodly field haue gathered many yeares prouision for thy great houshold thy Church, but yet eyther let somwhat fal, or left much behind, which may be sufficiēt for vs thy poore seruants to gleane after them, either for our owne priuate vse, or for that smal flocke which thou hast set vs to feed. And let all sober-hearted Christians iudge, yea let God that searcheth the verie heart and reines, and Christ Iesus the iudge of all mankind, giue iudgement out of his throne, whether in reasoning thus, we are more iniurious to the ancient Fathers deceased, then they vnto the Ancient of daies, and Father of the world to come, in denying the free gifts & graces of his
holy spirit, vnto succeeding, as well as former ages, we reuerence the Fathers as men indued with an especiall measure of his grace, as men that haue left many excellent writings behinde them, fit for the instructions of later ages as well as former: they will not honour God as much. For their agreements conclude, if any thing, him to haue beene a gracious God, and his spirit a guide only of some few generations of old: but in this present, & all late past, they make him a God, his spirit a guide, and his word a role onely of the Pope, who must be the onely God, the onely guide, and his decisions about Scripture the onely rule of all other mens faith, yea a rule of Scripture it selfe, as shall afterwards appeare.

div.head: SECT. IIII.

The last of the three maine obiections (before proposed) which was concerning our supposed defectiue meanes for composing controuersies, or retaining the vnitie of faith, fully answered and retorted: That the Romane faith hath no foundation.
div.p:
THe last obiection is: Our Church hath no meanes of taking vp Controuersies, seeing we permit the vse of Scriptures vnto all, and euery man to follow that sense of them which hee liketh best. We doe indeed permit euery man to satisfie his owne conscience in matters of saluation, and God forbid (for by his Apostles he hath forbidden) we should vsurpe any supreme Lerdship or absolute dominion ouer their faith. Yet a Christian obedience vnto Pastors wee require in the flocke: vnpossible in our iudgement, to be performed aright, vnlesse vndertaken more for conscience then for feare of punishment. And, as obedience, if not framed by conscience, can neuer be syncere, so conscience, vnlesse regulated by the sacred Canon, must needs be erroneous, and alwaies relish more of superstition then religion. The Gospell we euer esteemed as a
gladsome message of peace and saluation: and doe wee, by seeking to square mens thoughts and affections vnto it, prepare their hearts to deadly warre? It is, we know, and you denie not, the fountaine of life, apt to season the waters of Marah and Meribah, a medicine able to allay all bitternesse of contention, and qualifie the poysonous rootes of strife; and doe we, by setting it open for fainting soules to quench their thirst, digge pits of destruction for them to fall into? The Scriptures in generall wee haue proued to be a plaine and facile rule, a light vnto mens feete, and a lanterne vnto their paths: and doe we, by permitting the free vse of it to all, first explicated and vnfolded by the dispensers of diuine mysteries, lay stumbling blocks in their way not possible to be descried or auoided, or spread a snare to catch their soules in darknesse? we permit euery man to follow that sense or meaning of it which his conscience liketh best: but we permit no man to frame the liking of his conscience to his lust; wee teach the contrarie as a principle of faith and Christian obedience. If any disobedient spirits list to contend, where they should performe obedience, we know the Church of God hath no such custome: all such contentions we detest, and labour, as much as you, by all meanes lawfull, to quell: The same internall meanes [Gods word] are alike free to both, but more vsed by vs which relie more vpon them: all the difficultie is about meanes externall.

div.head: CHAP. I.
Containing the true state of the question, or a comparison betweene the Romish Church and ours, for their meanes of preuenting or composing controuersies.
div.p: 1. THe question then must be, first, whether we can as well discerne such as reade Scriptures, as you, such as read your Church decrees, with contentious mindes. Secondly, whether wee haue meanes as forcible and effectuall as you haue any to reforme them, or stay the spreading contagion of their heresie. To begin with the latter.

Our manner of proceeding against contētious spirits, as effectuall for the end proposed as the Romish Church hath any.2 Such as you discerne to bee contentious, or to dissent from that doctrine which you conceiue or teach for true, you threaten, with what? The Pope or Churches curse. Such as wee discerne to breede contentions amongst vs, or dissentions from that truth, which wee in conscience thinke all ought to professe, we threatē with death & damnation, and the terror of that dreadfull day which shall accomplish that wee denounced Matth. 18. against all such by whom offences come. Will not the continuall preaching of this doctrine bee as forcible to deterre a man from sowing sedition, as the anniuersarie solemnitie of the Popes curse? Will men beleeue a Iesuite from the Pope, when they will not beleeue Moses, and the Prophets, nor Christ Iesus himselfe? But you will say, although men will not be kept in order with Peters keyes, yet will they dread Pauls sword: or rather if they will not dread the fire of Hell, which must but long hence torment their soules, yet will they stand in awe of the fagot alwaies readie in your Church for plaguing heretikes. If this were the best meanes to stoppe mens mouthes, from professing what they are in conscience perswaded the Scripture telles them: The fundamentall pointes of Christianitie had neuer beene knowne eyther to you or vs; Christian Religion it selfe had beene martyred with Christs martyrs. But as their Ashes was the fertilest soyle, wherein the seede of the Gospell could bee sowne: so was the long and cruell oppression of such as dissented from your Church, as a lopping or pruning to cause ours flourish, and hath at length set the Israel of God at libertie from Aegyptian slauery.

3 But supposing this violent course, vpon great exigence of circumstances eyther in the matter, manner, or times of contentions, to bee both lawfull and expedient: yet could not the ordinarie practise of it bee more effectuall to restraine men from contradicting, then it might bee to enforce them to oppugne the truth. It might, according to the diuetse dispositions of such as manage it, be a meanes, one way or other alike forcible, eyther to retaine men in heresie, idolatrie, and infidelitie, or in the vnitie of true and liuely faith: albeit feare alone may make men perfect heretikes or infidels, but not inwardly or syncerely faithfull.

4 And as for our Church, albeit she search not so narrowly into the secrets of euery mans conscience, nor bee so tyrannically iealous of euerie word that might bee ill interpreted, nor so outragiously cruell in punishing knowne dissention from her, or discouered errour: yet (God be praised) she hath Pauls sword as well as yours, which our Magistrate beares not in vaine, but can vnsheath it, when neede requires, against such as are open and euident abetters of contentions, vnlesse perhaps you will except, that it hath not beene so much exercised in cutting you off from amongst vs, (who are the ringleaders of all diuision, debate and trouble in our Church,) as it might be according to your doctrine; if in the practise of this coactiue authoritie ouer contentious spirits, there be any fault, God amend it, for in our Churches doctrine concerning this point there is none: and God grant our Magistrates may practise as our faithfull Pastors teach: whose doctrine is, that this externall as well as the internal power is giuen for edification, not for destruction, and must be directed by the same rule; that the vse and practise of it must bee limited by the end; that the end of it is by iniunction of things good and prohibition of euill, to proportion mens actions and conuersations to the rule of faith, and law of God, that so euery member of the Common-wealth, thus wrought and fashioned by the coactiue power, may bee more easily conformed into a member of Christ, as being more apt and pliable for the word of life to worke vppon. Nor are wee precisely wedded to any determinate course for quelling or preuenting contentious schismes or heresies, but wee may admit what other soeuer time shall detect more effectuall for attaining the former end; vnto which our loue is such, as will not suffer vs dislike any meanes allied to it, though hauing affinitie with your Church: part of whose externall discipline we are not ashamed to vse vnto good, because by you abused to bad and wicked purposes. But for your Churches practise in the vse of your best meanes for auoyding all contentions, you plead no infallibility; therein you may fayle as well as we, and the question now is about our doctrine.

5 Out of that which hath beene said, our means for punishing such as we know to be contentious appeares as good as yours, whose vse, so farre as wee like it, is as free for vs as for your
selues, let vs now see whether we haue meanes as good, or as infallible as yours, to discerne who are contentious.

That our means for discerning the orig • nall causes or occasions of contentions are fully equiualent to the Romish Churches.6 For the Popes infallibility whether it be any or no, we are anone to enquire, and wee may not in this place giue you leaue to preiudice our Church with the supposall of it. Nor do your selues make this discretion of contentious spirits any essential part thereof.

7 None of you (that I haue read) doth attribute any Prophetical spirit to the Pope in this case, as if he could descrie the storms of contentions which might cause shipwrack of faith, before they arise, as farre off as Elias did the raine, when it first began to gather into a cloud like a mans hand. The excellency of his infallibilitie, by your owne positions (if I mistake not) consists in the decisions of controuersies brought vnto him, not in the discouery or finding out of such, as breed contention. But doth he vouchsafe to decide all controuersies that arise in his dominions, albeit brought vnto him?
div.q: Vix vacat exiguis rebus adesse Ioui.
div.p: The exercise of this Dominus Deus vester plenarie power, is much like the vse of the heathen Gods vpon the old Romane stage.

q.l: Nec Deus intersit, nisi nodus vindice dignus:
Vnlesse it be to loose some Gordian knot
The Popes decision is not easty got.

div.p: And where it is got, it goes no farther then to the iust and infallible censure of the opinion it selfe, in punishing the Authors or abetters of adiudged heresies or schismes: hee may erre aswell as we, because herein hee goes but by the information of priuate men, who neither are so absolutely holy, but they may proue partiall, nor so wise and skilfull alwaies, but they may erre in their information, especially where it goes successiuely fron eare to eare, and from one countrie dialect to another, (as drinke from vessell to vessell) alwaies loosing some part of its proper and natiue sapor, so that it may relish otherwise to his holinesse mouth, then it did at the first setting abroach by the author.

8 And seeing the best meanes to auoid contention is the iust puishment of them that causelesly cause them: your Churches authoritie being herein so much more obnoxious to errour and misinformation as her diocesse is larger, lesse vniforme or more
remote, is liable to many exceptions, from which such little ones, as she out of her greatnesse contemnes, are free. Nor is the question (as you beare the simple in hand) betwixt publike and priuate spirits, but betweene your priuate men, and ours; as whether yours can better discerne who are contentious throughout your vaste precincts; then ours, who are such amongst vs at home. That no man should dissent from the doctrine of the Catholike Church you all agree. Some of you dissent from it (as most of their fellowes thinke) who yet will not professe; but rather seeke to cloake their dissent, eyther with colours of consonance or pretended reasons of no repugnance vnto Catholike tenants. Bellarmine lib. 3. de iustif. cap. 3. 4. &c. disputes so eagerly against this Bishop as might haue procured a censure of irregularity had he liued in his dioces. Catherinus will defend the Councell of Trent, and yet hold certaintie of saluation. Soto & Bellarmine reproue him: but how could eyther of them discern whether Catherinus had the true meaning of the Trent Coūcell or not? Catherinus (I take it) had a suffrage in making those decrees, wherof neither Soto nor Bellarmine were allowed much lesse authentick interpreters: for the Popes BulApostolica authoritate inhibemus omnibus, tam Ecclesiasticis personis, cuiuscunque sint ordinis, conditionis, & gradus, quam laicis, quocunque honore, ac potestate praeditis, Praelatis quidem sub interdicti ingressus Ecclesiae, alijs vero quicunque fuerint sub excommunicationis latae sententiae poenis, ne quis si • e authoritate nostra audeat vllos commentarios, glossas, annotationes, scholia, vllumve omnino interpretationis genus super ipsius concilij decretis quocunque modo edere, aut quidquam quocunque nomine, etiam sub praetextu maioris decretorum corroborationis, aut executionis, aliove quaesito colore, statuere. Bulla Pij quarti super confirmatione oecum. gener. concil. Trident. cōfirming that Councell prohibits all priuat interpretatiōs of it, yet hath not the Pope or any publike authority since that time condēned Catherinus for this dissention. How knewMaldonatus censure of these men, for dissenting (as he thinkes) from their Church, is so sharpe & peremptory, as might wel haue caused contention, should his writings haue come into their handes. Jmpediunt nos quo minus acriter & vehementer inuehamur in haereticos, Catholici quīdam, qui, nescio qua imprudentia hereticis se iunxerunt. Neminem nomino, neminem violatae accuso religionis: scio Cathhlicos, scio doctos, scio religiosos ac probos viros esse, sed minimè profecto vtilem atque fidelem in hac re operam Ecclesiae nauauerunt, Quod contra scripturae sensum, contra patrum omnium interpretationem, contra tacitum imo minime tacitum, sed satis superque explicatum consensum Ecclesiae dixerint atque contenderint hoc loco de Sacrametntis non agi. Maldonatus comment. in sex. Ioan. Maldonate, that Iansenius Hesselius, and others which denie that Christs words in the sixth of Iohn are to be vnderstood of sacramentall eating, did varie from the receiued doctrine of your Church, and iumpe with heretikes? difference betwene your selues and vs in this point you shall neuer be able to assigne any. Tell vs by what meanes you can discerne who dissent from your Canons; and our answere is readie: wee can discerne who dissent from ours by the same, if no other were left vs. This briefly may suffice for remouall of preiudices easie to be wrought in such as compare not particulars with particulars
or consider not the vse of externall magistracie acknowledged by vs, for punishing contentious spirits, or our meanes of discerning who are such: In both which respects wee are least equall to the Romanes.

div.head: CHAP. II.
That the Romish Church hath most need of some excellent mean • s for taking vp contentions, because it necessarily breedes so many and so grieuous.
div.p:
1 FOR the maine point, as well about the originall of contentions, and schismes, as incorrigible continuance in them, onely this difference I finde, That wee permitting a sober search of Scriptures vnto all, not binding any mans faith to the iudgemēt of man, leaue a possibilitie to the learned of finding out a liberty vnto all of professing the truth found, for the health and life of their soules, without dread or danger to their bodies. And seeing we bind no man vpon paine of damnation, to beleeue any point of doctrine, which is not plainly and expressely set downe in Scriptures: we minister no occasion of deadly dissention vnto any. For contentions amongst our selues, they are rather distempers then dangerous diseases, nor doe they affect those parts of religion in which our spirituall life is properly seated. Yet euen these in latter yeares had beene, and alwaies would bee fewer, and their danger lesse, were it not for those Foxes which your Church subornes to bring fire-brands into the Lords haruest. And euen these your Foxes in this our land, howsoeuer, for this publike mischiefe against vs, and the intended combustion of our Church, their tailes were tied together by your Churches knot, haue yet wher their cankred teeth as eagerly, and opened their venemous mouthes as bitterly one against another, as any (but they) could haue done either against vs or any creatures liuing. But to leaue priuate dissentions amongst your selues; your Church prohibiting men the ingenuous search of Scriptures and free profession of their conscience
tying them to submit their iudgements at all aduenture vnto the corrupt doctrine of your Cleargie: hath set open a wide gap to such grosse opinions, and monstrous heresies, as no man, vnlesse his iudgement had beene surprised by your pretended authoritie, or his spirituall senses lockt vp in superstition, sleepe, and midnight darknesse, would euer haue assented vnto, much lesse haue tolerated, when men were taught to hold them for points of faith, as infallibly true as the Scripture it selfe, onely because your Church hath proposed and practised them.

2 Thus did your doctrine and filthie practise of Indulgences (to omit many moe) from some surmises of the Ancient, concerning a third place after this life, as it were, from a small seed or kernell, by little & little come vp to such a mightie growth, that it violently rent, & tore asunder the maine wals of Christs Temple, and caused that irreparable breach and rupture, betwixt the Southerne & Northerne parts of Christs Church, established in this Westerne part of the world. And albeit Cassander with diuers other learned men in your Church, both before, and about the time of the Trent-Councell, wished a reformation of many pointes maintained by you; hoping the Lutheran, and other reformed Churches. would thereby be drawn to vnitie with you againe: yet what one suspicious opinion hath that Councel cleared, what bad amended, what harsh or odious one hath it mitigated? Nay what possibility hath it selfe for the amendment of any in ages to come, amongst such as shal acknowledge that authority infallible, which hath thundred out so many Anathemaes to all gainsayers? Before it was lawfull for Cassander & Caietan, Espenceus & others, to shew their dislike of your doctrine, and signifie their desires of amendment, retaining some relicks, or fashion of men, that had bin free-borne, not slaues or vassals to corrupt and dissolute tyrants. They vsed their liberty of speech euen in those cases, wherein it is not now lawfull for any in your Church to mutter, no not so much as to sigh, or groane vnder that heauie yoake, which their forefathers grudged to beare, whose weight and hardnesse notwithstanding you still increase, whilst your vpstart statesmen the Iesuites, (like Rehoboams greene-headed counsellers,) daily seeke to make your Ecclesiastick Monarchies little finger, greater then his predecessors loynes.

3 Some Iesuite or other happily would replie: Had Luther beene quiet, the Church had beene still at such peace and vnitie, as it enioyed for many yeares before. What manner of peace and vnitie was that? Any other then such, as vsually is found in any poly • ticall Argus-eyed tyrannie, before the sinewes of it shrinke, or the ligaments be dissolued? where no man may moue but he is seene, nor mutter, but he is heard; where the least secret signification of any desire of freedome in speech, or liberty in action, is interpreted for open mutinie, and the least motion vnto mutinie held matter sufficient for a cruell death. These were the bonds of your peace and vnitie, in this point of your Ecclesiastick Monarchie. As for your peace in other speculatiue points of lesse vse or commodity to your state, it was like the reuellings, or drunken consorts of seruants in their night sportings, when the master of the house is a-sleepe in a retired roome. Any schoole-man might broach what opinion he list, and make his auditors drunke with it, others might quarrell with him and them, in as vnciuill sort as they list, so no weapon were drawne against the Popes peace. Albeit in the meane time the Scripture suffered as open violence and abuse, as Priscian doth, when drunken or dunsticall Grammarians braule in extemporarie Latine. As for your Cardinals and States-men they were at league indeed, but it was foedissimum foedus, a league solemnized with more then barbarous and heathenish sacrifice, with the bloud of many thousand sillie Lambes, for whom the Lambe of God had sacrificed his pretious bodie and bloud. What number of Hussits, Bohemians, Picardes, poore soules of Lions were made a prey vnto your wooluish (I may not say Lions) teeth, seeing as the Italian Poet argues, this title so ill befits your Popes:
Nec cadit in turpes nobilis ira feras:
No Lions they: for noble wrath
No place in such base creatures hath.

But what troupes of such harmelesse soules were slaine, burnt, and tormented, for their longing after the liberty of the sonnes of God, nor we, nor you that liue this day can know, nor shall bee knowne vntill the Register of the booke of life be opened. And howsoeuer they went (as their Lord and Master the great sheephe • rd of their soules had done before them) like sheepe vnto the
slaughter, whilest their friends and kinsfolkes cries were drowned with your Iewish melodie, and ioy at their destructions; yet we assure our selues, (and ye might dread Gods further iudgement by the euent,) it was the crie of their innocent bloud which fild the court of heauen, and in a iust reuenge of their oppression procured Luthers commission for Germanies reuolt. And yet saie you, Luther was the cause of dissention in Christs Church: why so? Because he burst your former vnitie, whose onely bond was hellish tyrannie. Of such a dissention, and of the breach of such an vnitie, we grant he was the cause; and you haue no iust cause to accuse him of dissention, or disobedience for it.In this sense Christ is said to haue come, not to send peace, but a sword vnto the world. For all kinde of vnitie is not to bee preferred before all kinde of dissention or reuolt. He that will not dissent from any man, or societie of men, vpon any occasion whatsoeuer, must liue at perpetuall enmitie with his God and warre continually against his owne soule. For there is an vnitie in rebellion, a brotherhood in mischiefe, a socitie in murther both of bodie and soule. Wherefore vnlesse you can proue your cause or title, for exacting such absolute submission of mens soules, and spirits vnto your Church, or Popes decrees, to be most iust and warrantable by commission from the highest power in heauen: Luther, and all that followed him, did well, in preferring a most iust, most necessarie, and sacred warre, before a most vniust, and shamefully-execrable peace: A peace, no peace, but a banding in open rebellion against the supreme Lord of heauen and earth, and his sacred lawes, giuen for the perpetuall gouernment of mankinde throughout their generations.

4 To presse you a little with your obiections against vs and our doctrine, for nourishing dissention:That this very challenge of this infallible authority of the Romish Church for ending all controuersies doth necessarily occasion the greatest dissention from it that can be in all religious mindes. Our Church (say you) hath no meanes of taking vp controuersies aright. If this were true, yet (God be praised) it ministreth no iust occasion of any dangerous quarrell. But be ours, as it may be: hath your Church any better meanes for composing controuersies of greater moment, that raigne this day throughout the Christian world? Or doth it not by this insolent, proud, tyrannicall claime of soueraigntie, and imperiall vmpiership ouer all other Churches in all controuersies, giue iust cause of the greatest dissention, and extremest opposition, that can bee imagined could be giuen in the
Church of Chiist? The whole world besides cannot minister any like it. Nature and common reason teach vs, that a man may with farre safer conscience take armes in defence of his life and libertie, then in hope to auoide some pettie losse or grieuance, or to reuenge some ordinarie cause of priuate discontent: the quarrell in the one, (though with assistance vnto our aduersaries bloud,) may bee iustifiable, which in the other (albeit within the compasse of lesse danger,) were detestable. But grace doth teach vs this equitie, Skinne for skinne, all that euer a man hath, the whole world (and more if hee had it,) is to be spent in the defence of faith, the onely seate of our spirituall life, or for the libertie of our conscience. You alone teach, that all men should submit their faith to your decrees without examinatiō of them, or appeale from them: we vsurpe no such authoritie, eyther ouer yours, or any mens consciences. You challeng our soueraigne Lord, and all his people, to bee your ghostly slaues: wee onely stand in our owne defence: we exact no such absolute seruice, or allegeance, eyther of you, or any other the meanest Christian Church, no not our Prince and Cleargie of the naturall members of our owne. They only seeke (would God they sought aright in time) to keepe them short at home, whose long reach might hayle ouer Sea your long-sought tyranny ouer this people of Brittanie, happily now diuided (Lord euer continue this happie diuision) from the Romish world. Vnlesse your meanes of taking vp so great contentions (as hence in equitie ought to arise,) be so superexcellent, that it can make amends where all is marred, (for which I cannot see what meanes can be sufficient, vnlesse you either let your suit fall, or proue your title to be most iust by arguments most authenticke and strong) you euidently impose a necessitie of the greatest contentions, and extremest opposition that any abuse or wrong, losse or danger, possible to befall a Christian man (eyther as a man or Christian, eyther in things of this life or that other to come, eyther concerning his very life and libertie, whether temporall or spirituall) or whatsoeuer else is more deare vnto him, can occasion or breed.

5 That which yee vsually premise to worke such a preiudice in credulous & vnsetled mindes, as may make your sleight pretences of reason or scripture (to be sifted anone) seeme most firme & solid
to ground your infallibilitie vpon, is, the supposed excellency of it, for taking vp all controuersies in Religion, and so of retaining vnitie of Holy Catholike faith in the bond of loue. If indeed it were so excellent for this purpose, you might rest contented with it, and hartily thanke God for it. Yea, but because you haue this excellent meanes, which we haue not, nor any like vnto it, yours is the true Catholike Church, and ours a congregation of Schismatikes. What if we would inuent the like? would that serue to make ours a true Church? Or tell vs, what warrant haue you for inuenting or establishing your supposed most excellent order for taking vp controuersies? Was it from Heauen? or was it from men? If from Heauen, wee will obey it; if from men, wee will imitate you in it, if wee like it. But first let vs a little further examine it.

div.head: CHAP. III.

That of two senses, in which the excellency of the Romish Churches pretended meanes for retaining the vnitie of faith, can onely possibly be defended, the one (from the former discourse) prooued apparently false, the other in it selfe as palpably ridiculous.
div.p: 1 WHen you affirme the infallibilitie of your Church to bee so excellent a meanes for taking vp all controuersies in Religion: you haueThis diuisiō is most immediate in our present subiect wherein we only examine whether from the knowne or possible fruits of the Romish Churches meanes (so excellent▪ as is pretended) for composing cōtrouersies, any argument can be drawne to worke a preiudicial conceipt in mens minds, that it were likely Christ had bequeathed such authority to their Church, before they come to direct examination of the maine point (what right she hath to the challenged Supremacie by Scriptures.) no choice of any other, but one of these two meanings; Either you meane, it is so excellent a meanes de facto, and doth take vp all controuersies: or else it would bee such as might take vp all, if all men would subscribe vnto it.

2 If you take the former sense or meaning: we can euidently take you (as we say) with the very manner of falshood. For this claime of such authoritie (as wee partly shewed before) is the greatest eye-sore to all faithfull eyes that can bee imagined, and
makes your religion more irreconciliable to the truth. And for this Church of England, as in it some dissent from you in many points, others in fewer, some more in one, some more in another, so in this, of your Churches infallibilitie, all of vs dissent from you most euidently, most eagerly, without all hope of reconcilement or agreement, vnlesse you vtterly disclaime the title in as plaine termes as hitherto you haue challenged it. Your dealing herein is as absurdly impious and impiously insolent, as if any Christian Prince or State should challenge another, as free and absolute as himselfe, for his tributarie, or vassall, and traduce him for a seditious member of Christendome, because hee would not compose the quarrell thus iniuriously sought, with the surrender of his Crowne and dignitie.

3 Princes may conclude a peace, for ciuill and free commerce of their people, though professing sundry religions: and they and their Clergie might perhaps procure a mitigation of some other points, now much in controuersie: but though all others might, yet this admits no termes of parly for any possible reconcilement. The naturall separation of this Island from those Countries wherein this doctrine is professed, shall serue as an euerlasting Embleme of the Inhabitants diuided hearts at least in this point of Religion: and let them, O Lord, be cut off speedi • y from amongst vs, and their posteritie transported hence, neuer to enioy againe the least good thing this Land affords: let no print of their memory bee extant so much as in a tree or stone within our Coast: or let their names by such as remaine here after them bee neuer mentioned, or alwayes to their endlesse shame; who liuing here amongst vs will not imprint these or like wishes in their hearts and daily mention them in their prayers,
Littora littoribus contraria, fluctibus vndas,
Imprecor arma armis, pugnent ipsique nepotes.

Which words, though vttered in another case, applied to this, sound thus much to all wel-affected English or Brittish eares,
Let our and foraine Coasts ioyne battaile in the maine,
Ere this foule blasphemy Great Brittaine euer slaine.
Where neuer let it combat floting in a floud
Of ours, our nephews, and their childrens bloud.

4 The leauen of the Pharisees, whereof our Sauiour willed his Disciples to beware, was sweet bread in respect of this pestiferous dough, whose poison is so diffused throughout the whole bodie and masse of Romish religion, as it hath polluted euery parcell therein, and makes in those particular pointes to bee damnable in moderne Papists, which in the Auncient holding them from other groundes were pardonable. Such as held a kinde of Purgatorie, or third place after this life, Euangelicall Councels, inuocation of Saints, or the like, because they thought the Scripture taught them, were deceiued in these particular Scriptures, but yet reserued their faithfull Allegiance to Gods word in general. Nay, euen those particular errours and mistakings of the sense of Scriptures, were witnesses and pledges of their obedience vnto the Scripture, or word of God; when they therefore beleeued them, because they were immediately perswaded in conscience that the Scriptures (the rule of their conscience) did teach them. But while you hold the same opinions, not because you are perswaded in conscience (immediately ruled by Scripture) that they are contained in Scripture, but because the Church, which as yee suppose cannot erre, doth teach them; or to speake more plainly, whiles you your selues either beléeue, or teach others to beleeue them or the Scriptures concerning them; because the Church, whose authoritie in this and all other cases you acknowledge for the infallible rule of your faith, commaunds you so to doe: you hereby openly renounce your owne, and sollicite the people to alienate their Allegiance from God and his word: and the passing ouer, or yeelding vp of stedfast and absolute assent vnto any particular point in your religion, vpon these groundes, is as euident a witnesse of high treason, committed against GOD by the partie thus beleeuing; as swearing of that Fealtie, or Allegiance to a pretended Vicegerent, or Deputie, which is onely due to the Prince himselfe, would be in a naturall and sworne subiect. Wherefore the supposed infallibilitie of your Church is no such excellent meanes of taking vp all controuersies, if your meaning be in the former sense proposed. For it is so farre from taking vp all, that it puts an impossibilitie of hauing any betwixt you and vs taken vp, vnlesse you abiure it quite; for it makes all the rest of your opinions deadly, to such as stedfastly beleeue it, or for it, them.

5 Your meaning then must be; That this infallibilitie of your Church would bee an excellent meanes for taking vp all controuersies, if all men would subscribe vnto it. Indeed I must confesse, there would soone be an end of all, or rather, no controuersies should euer be begun, if euery man would resolue with himselfe, not to dissent from others, but let them hold what they list, hee would hold the very same: or if all men would binde themselues to abide some one mans, or a Maior part of some few or more determinate persons, determinations without more adoe. In this case one might say of his Iudge, Hee shall determine for me; and another might reply, nay but for my opinion; the third might say, Hee shall iudge as I will haue him; and the fourth replie, or rather as I will: and yet neuer a one dissent from other, but all agree. All of them might haue the Iudges sentence at as absolute commaund, as the Shepheard had the Weather. For euery one might haue him determine as he pleased, because all of them were fully resolued to be pleased with whatsoeuer hee should determine. If you dreame of such an vnitie in faith, or such a manner of composing contentions; it must be further disputed, whether this were not an open dissention or solemne compact for mouing a generall Apostasie from the true faith. And they that labour for such an vnion in pointes of faith and saluation, doe in effect sollicite the whole Christian world to runne hand in hand, but head-long, into open infidelitie, least perhaps by breaking companies, some might slide into Schismes and Heresies. Should the Romists and Aristotelians, or generally all the professors of secular Artes and Sciences in our Vniuersities, binde themselues vnder penaltie of expulsion, or by solemne vow, neuer to swerue from the Beedle of beggars or Iohn-a-dogges his determinations, and resolutions in any point of Logicke, Philosophie, or Metaphysickes; would this be a sweet match to take vp all controuersies, or contentions betweene Colledge and Colledge, in our Schooles? were this so excellent a way, to retaine the vnitie of the truth, and skill in those faculties? or rather the onely ready way to make all bond-slaues to errour, ignorance, and falshood? And yet might wee, with more safetie, delegate greater authoritie in these cases to euery one, then we may to any liuing, in matters of faith and Religion; ouer which, or ouer our selues in respect of
which we haue no lawfull power or authoritie. For this, and other reasons, should wee bee more afraide to subscribe vnto any mortall mans authoritie, as vnto a Iudge most absolute and infallible, whose decrees we may not resist, from whose sentence wee may not appeale in matters of faith: then to referre our selues wholy vnto the sole iudgement of the meerest naturall foole liuing, in maters of secular learning and naturall knowledge. For, (besides the danger hence accrewing to our selues,) GOD our Creator, Christ our Redeemer, and the Holy Spirit our comforter and Instructer, haue farre g • eater interest in our soules and consciences, then either Aristotle or P • ato, or any other Philosopher, or philosophie it selfe hath in our opinions, or perswasions.

6 But though gratitude to our God could not moue vs; are those blessed hopes of immortalitie so little worth, as vpon euery light or no occasion wee should aduenture their eternall losse? And yet idly, desperatly, and frantickly, aduenture it we doe, vnlesse such as vrge vs with solemne subscription to this more then Monarchicall Supremacie ouer our soules, enstamped not with any Romane Caesars but Gods owne image and superscription, can shew vs sufficient warrant, that thus to offer vp not only the calues of our lips but euen our faith (the best tribute our heartes can yeeld) wholy into Christs pretended Vicars hands, bee not a witnesse of our rebellion against Christ himselfe the Supreame Lord as well of them, that challenge this authoritie, as of vs, of whom this seruile subiection is exacted. All the warrant or euidence, which in this case they can pretend, must either be drawne from the rules of reason, or from the Scriptures, the rule (as wee contend) of faith; which for this reason may iustly controule all pretended rules of naturall reason. And (as we haue said before) if the Pope bee (as vsually he is,) but Sect. 2. cap. 3. parag 4. 5. &c.
homo
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 with a witnesse: then both Scripture and reason teach vs, that he cannot perceiue the thinges of God, nor the meaning of his Spirit; for, as our Apostle saith, they are foolish vnto him. And if they be foolish to him; then is he as foolish a Iudge of them, and of all thinges that must be spiritually discerned, as the meerest naturall Idiote would be of naturall Philosophie, or other secular Artes or Sciences. Euen to this one place of Scripture, vttered
by the Spirit of God, and the Ministerie of that Apostle, no sufficient answere can be giuen, without the euident testimony of the same Spirit (vnder some Prophets, Apostles, or Euangelists hand,) either mitigating or restraining that sense which the words naturally import, and wee collect: whose probabilitie in it selfe, and consonancy with other Scriptures, are so great, that wee stand bound by our generall Allegiance, which we owe vnto GODS Spirit, to supect all men for incompetent Iudges, or witnesses in matters concerning GOD; vnlesse we know certainely of what Spirit they are, or haue great inducements to presume them of a better Spirit, and in more fauour with the Spirit of God, then they themselues report their Popes to be.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
That their arguments, drawne from conueniencie of Reason or pretended correspondencie betweene Ciuill and Ecclesiasticall Regiment, doe preiudice themselues, not vs.
div.p:
1 THat this is no generall Dictate of common reason or any part of the Law of nature, Reason and common sense make euident: And wee may rest assured hereof, in that no Iesuite, nor other Stickler for the Popes authoritie, hath beene so impudent hitherto, as to auouch thus much. That there are some probabilities, or conueniences, which in reason might perswade any indifferent man, that there must bee some one Vmpire, or Tribunall seate, by whose authoritie all controuersies of Religion must be determined,Nō ignorabat de{us} mu • tas in Ecclesia exorituras difficultates circa fidem; debuit igitur iudicem aliquem Ecclesiae prouidere: at iste index non potest esse scriptura, neque spiritus reuelans priuatus, ne{que} princeps saecularis; igitur princeps Ecclesiasticus, aut solus aut certe cum consilio & consensu Coepiscorū. Ne{que} enim fingitur ne{que} fingi potest aliquid aliud ad quod hoc iudic • um pertinere posse videatur. Bellar. 3. de verbo dei cap. 9.
BELLARMINE thus goes about to prooue: GOD was not ignorant that many difficulties about faith would arise in the Church, What then? In reason then he was to prouide his Church of a iudge; suppose he were. But this iudge cānot be the Scripture, nor any priuate reuealing Spirit, nor any secular: therefore an Ecclesiasticall Prince which may determine such matters either of himselfe alone, or at least, with the aduise and consent of Bishops his associates. Nor hath any as
yet nor can any indeede imagine any other to whom the iudgement of th • se things can possibly appertaine,

2 That neither the Scripture, nor any priuate man, nor secular Prince is this Iudge, hee labours to proue by arguments, whose strength hath beene broken in the former discourses, concerning the obscuritie of Scriptures and varietie of interpretations.
