But how cunningly soeuer his sagacitie may seeme to haue cast about, he is at the same default Valentian and Sacroboscus were: all of them ouerran the sent by leaping from one extreme to another, with out search of the meane betwixt them: for they take it as granted, that we denie all liuing Iudges of controuersies, because we acknowledge no absolute infallibilitie in any. Our assertion is; The Scripture is a Law or rule most infallible, whereby euery man must iudge himselfe; whereby such as are in lawfull authoritie may iudge others for not iudging themselues by it; but not alwayes infallible. Nor can it stand with the sobrietie of Christian wisedome to expect such a precise determination of all pointes disputed, much lesse disputable among the learned, as might bind all men to an absolute beleefe (whether explicite or implicite) of this or that determinate sense, all others excluded. Notwithstanding the more conscious any ordinary iudge is of his owne or others fallibilitie or facilitie of erring dangerously, if they should take vpon them strictly to determine all religious doubts, much more all doubts, in matter of Religion, might be moued: the more infallibly may he rest assured that many cases of that quality are very doubtfull; that in sundrie, of many opinions all to his knowledge possible, as much may be as probably alleaged for any one as for other. Now the true and proper vse of an Ecclesiastique Iudge or Magistracie, is, not onely to punish oppugners of truthes, either euident in themselues and infallibly beleeued of all Christians, or generally receiued by the best and most vnpartiall writers in euery age; but, as well, to moderate mens carriage in controuersies of the former nature; sometimes by restrainng all peremptory assertions one way or orher, all exasperating censures or contumelious contradictions (as in difficulties aequipendent betwixt an equalitie of contrary probabilities:) sometimes (as in matters not so vse-full, or vnto whose search the signes of times present doe not solicite vs) by enioyning a generall silence,
that all may hearken with better attention to GOD alwayes speaking by the ordinary course of his prouidence, albeit softly and leasurely, yet distinctly and audibly, to quiet minds alreadie instructed in that heauenly knowledge, though not simply vnto all: for many of vs can perfectly distinguish mens voyces whiles they repeate what in part wee know; though not whiles they pronounce matters vnheard before, or altogether vnknowne to vs.

3 By this it may appeare, would our aduersaries make an equall comparison, that God hath better prouided for hisChrists Church hauing by our doctrin a most infallible written Law, and liuing, though of fallible Ecclesiastike Iudges, is much better prouided for in all matters spirituall then Politike societies, whose lawes as w • ll as Iudges are fallible, in matters Ciuill. Churches Regiment in matters spirituall, then the Common-weale • in Temporall. First the Scripture is a rule, as all-sufficient for a • l such businesie, as any Temporall Lawes could bee for effecting their proper end, albeit we should suppose the Lord had dictated them immediately, as he did the Scriptures. This our aduersaries cannot deny, vnlesse they doubt whether the eternall Spirit haue as great skill in heauenly matters, as in secular. For (as we shewed before) hee moued holy men to write the Scriptures, that wee by them might attaine eternall life. Secondly, besides this most infallible rule or Law, wee admit an equall necessitie of Ecclesiasticall, and Temporall Iudges, an equall authoritie in both to giue sentence viua voce. And albeit we denie any absolute infallibillitie in either, yet the possibilitie of not erring wee acknowle • ge so much greater in the Iudge Ecclesiastique, as his directorie ru • e is more certaine, and authenticall. But here I must request these great disputers of Rome (if their frenzie come but by fits, and admit dilucida interualla) one time or other, vpon their good dayes, or in their sober howers, (if God send them any) to bethinke themselues well, what manner of Iudge they require in matters Ciuill or meerely secular? such an one as cannot possibly erre in iudgement? one whom neither ignorance, leud desires, nor exorbitant affections can cause to swerue, either from the vndoubted rules of naturall or Ciuill equitie, the fundamentall Lawes of his Countrie, or the cheife Law-giuers true intent and meaning? if they willingly grant that our Ciuill Magistracie, which they acknowledge lawfull and necessarie in it kind, may sometimes iudge wrongfully, in causes by nature most determinable by ordina •• e course of Ciuill Iustice; as for example, in condemning Priestes
and Iesuites: or generally in matters of life and death:The vtmost bounds of all Christian obedience vnto any authoritie on earth is only to abide a peaceable trial before their lawfull Iudges, patiently to imbrace the penaltie inflicted: but not to thinke, what penalties soeuer they shall inflict, or the cause for whi • h it is inflicted to be iust or such as shall stand for good in the day of finall iudgment; for so earthly powers should haue absolute authority ouer our soules, which is Gods peculiar. with what forheads can they demaund wee should beleeue the Pope or other Ecclesiastique Iudge cannot possibly giue erronious sentence in any matters of Religion, many of which are of that nature as can admit no other vse of externall or coactiue power, saue onely seuere restraint of all precise determinations, or curious search one way ot other? And to admit, though in cases meerely Ciuill, such an absolute inerrable Tribunall, from whose censure no man (though readie with patience to brooke the execution of heauiest bodily doome it could inflict) may so much as in the secrets of his heart or conscience so farre appeale, as to examine whether the determination be right or wrong; were either secretly to deny, or openly to praeocupate or preuent Christs finall iudgment: wherein euen Supreame Iudges shalbe iudged, and a • l forepast decisions examined by the written word, (which these men disclaime for any authentique rule of faith;) the right approoued, the wrong reuersed by Him, whose pecu • iar prerogatiue it is (though now vsurped by the Pope) to put a finall end to all controuersies vius voce.

4 Notwithstanding, be it supposed for disputations sake, that God had appointed such an authentique Tribunall (as these Drunkards dreame of) for deciding matters of Religion: yet were it most grosse to thinke (might reason alone without Scripture be admitted Iudge) there should be but one Supreame Tribunall for the whole Christian world. Euen common sense (were reason silenced) might instruct vs, that it were much more conuenient for euery seuerall Kingdome, euery free State or societie of men, to haue such a Consistorie, or Supreame Tribunall amongst themselues For by this meanes, might all differences in opinions be farre sooner knowne, more narrowly sifted, and present notice taken of euery circumstance, concerning their occasions, progresse, or fauourers; the controuersie it selfe quicklier decided; the offenders more speedily punished; and the like occasions better auoided. Whereas, for euery Nation to resort to Rome, or for the Pope to send his Legates into euery corner of the Christian world, would procure great toile, and long labour, with little successe. The causers of contentions, or maintainers of Heresies, might often die in their sinnes, before the controuersie
were examined, or the truth so manifested, as might moue thē to repentance, or recantation of their errours: the information might be impertinent, partiall, imperfect or false: the opinion, or supposed Heresie, being (happily) first set abroach in the presumed Heretiques Countrie Dialect, would be worse vnderstood of the Pope,Our aduersaries grant that a Prouinciall Councell confirmed by the Pope, is as authentike as a Generall, wherein he were present, though absent in the oth • r, and not acquainted with particular circumstances or cariage of the controuersie. Much more auaileable shold a Popes confirmation of such Councels bee, who were prefent and well acquainted with all occasions or other circumstances of the controuersie, or the diuisiō. Wherfore if reason without Scripture might decide this controuersie, it were more cōueniēt to haue as many Popes as seuerall free States or Monarchies. whose instruction in many principall circumstances must oft-times depend vpon disagreeing heare-sayes; for his holines • ees no better; his infallible-ship heares no farther in matters de facto, then meaner men; his plenarie power, euen while hee giues sentence ex cathedra, is not able to vnderstand more tongues, then many Linguists may in a meaner seate; his Fatherhood vnderstands none besides his mother-tongue, so well as the naturall inhabitants of euery Countrie doe their owne proper natiue language. Many such inconueniences might be alleaged, for which, (might wee chuse what manner of Ecclesiastique gouernment God should appoint vs) wee should make choice of a Supreame Iudge in all causes Ecclesiasticall at home, rather then go to Rome to haue them heard. If the controuersers were to goe from Norway, the Seas might be frozen and the enemies possesse the Land. The passages from sundrie other places might all bee so stopt, as we should haue greater controuersie in going to Rome, then that for which wee were to goe. Or if the election of men (for by man is the Pope elected,) could giue such infallibili • ie to any: the manner of such elections would bee much more agreeable to the rules of Gods prouidence, and the example of Christs Apostles, if all the congregation, which was to relie vpon his infallibilitie, should first make choice of some few most excellent and famous men, renouned for learning and integritie; afterwardes all with one mind and one heart, pray vnto the Lord to shew by lot which was the man, to whom hee would vndoubtedly vouchsafe this infallible assistance of his holy Spirit. Thus, might reason or common sense without Scripture be Iudge what manner of gouernment were fittest for Christs Church, wee could bring farre greater reasons for a multitude of Popes or Ecclesiasticall Monarches, (for one at least in euery Nation) then either our aduersaries bring, or can bee brought for one generall Monarch ouer the vniuersall Church militant.

5 And albeit this challenged large extent of the Romish
Churches authoritie ouer others, (were the authoritie it selfe otherwise for the qualitie moderate,) had beene in former times not all together so vnreasonable: yet were it at this day to bee abandoned, as a turbulent deuise, apt for nothing so much as perpetuall disturbation of publike peace throughout Christendome, now diuided into so many seuerall Soueraigneties, and gouerned by so many absolute Princes, or States, no way dependent one of another. And Bellarmines reasons, brought for to proue the Monarchicall gouernment of the Church, would with far greater probabilities inferre a conueniencie for a seuerall Monarchicall gouernment in euery particular State, then for one generall Monarch ouer all. While the Christian world was gouerned by one absolute Monarch or Emperor, and all the peculiar customes or priuiledges of seuerall Nations (like diuerse members of the same bodie) conformable one to another, by their common subordination to one supreame Imperiall Law, the vertue of a like Exclesiasticall authoritie might haue beene equally diffused throughout the whole bodie thereof; as the splendor of the Sun throughout the whole Hemisphaere of the aire, and other aetheriall and caelestiall bodies, all, though different in their particular natures and peculiar properties, vniforme for the transmission of light. But after the dissolution of the Christian Empire, and the seuerall States and Soueraigneties, throughout Europe, all compleat within themselues, and different one from another in Lawes and customes: the transfusion of such an absolute Ecclesiastique authoritie through all would be vnequal, and make Christendome like a monster compact of many seuerall entire bodies made vp in one, or like some vgly liuing creature that had many heads and but one heart or soule.

div.head: CHAP. V.

That the finall triall of this controuersie must bee by Scriptures: That the Iesuites and moderne Papistes fierce oppugning all certaintie of priuate Spirits in discerning the diuine truth of Scriptures, or their true sense, hath made the Church their mother vtterly vncapable of any play by Scriptures, for establishing her pretended infallibilitie.
div.p:
1 BVt what Christian heart could haue suspected, that any man, acknowledging the infinite Maiestie of an Omnipotent God, filling euery place with his presence, ruling all thinges by his power, and hauing euery least creature of the world a world of witnesses of his inconceiueable wisedome, and vnspeakable prouidence ouer the works of his owne hand: durst once haue presumed to thinke, much lesse haue opened his mouth to vtter, least of all haue imployed his pen to proclaime, such foule impietie to the world; as that a power so infinite, could not sufficiently prouide for his Church in deciding matters of faith, (surpassing all reach of reason,) vnlesse he had ordained some one Supreme Tribunall seate on earth; the Iudges whereof should bee but mortall men, whose bodies can bee but in one place at once, whose voyces cannot reach without the precincts of their Consistories; whereas the Law of this our God, (vnto whose sentence in matters of faith we appeale) is, or might bee (but for these our Antiscripturian aduersaries importunitie) euery where throughout the Christian world dispersed: &, besides the external helpes of an ordinary Ministerie or Magistracie: (alike common to all Nations) the holy Spirit is euery where assistant to all such as seeke him in the written word by him reuealed; whose liue-characters are as the prints or footsteps of his wonted motions in Gods Prophets, or Apostles hearts, by which the faithfull may discerne his approch or presence in their owne. Nor will the Iesuites bee so wilfull (I hope) as to denie that this Holy Spirit, who did dictate the Word to such as wrote it in these materiall Tables, (hauing
first written it in the fleshly Tables of their heartes,) is able now also to write the same immediately in the hearts of all such, as with feare and reuerence prepare themselues for his fit and decent entertainment. That this was possible to be performed by the Almightie wisedome of God, they would not (I know) deny, were this, in direct and plaine termes, made the mayne controuersie betwixt vs. Albeit as much as we haue charged them withall, will most necessarily follow from their absurde, and lauishly-blasphemous speeches, which in the heat of contention haue distilled from their pens in this present controuersie. But of the possibilitie of Gods immediate teaching euery Christian heart, or rather of the probabilites, which may induce all to relie immediately hereupon; wee shall haue occasion to discourse hereafter. Let vs now in sobrietie of Spirit, rather dispute of Gods will then his power: as whether there be any sure argument to perswade vs, that it was his intent or purpose, either to instruct men in the true sense of Scriptures, or to take vp all controuersies in matters of faith, by this supposed infallibilitie of some visible Church. All this, and somewhat more our aduersaries in this point seriously auouch, and earnestly contend for. Let vs therefore briefly see, whether or no Gods Spirit hath taught thus much. That the sense of Scriptures cannot bee had without the assistance or working of Gods Spirit, both ioyntly acknowledge. They must bee vnderstood and interpreted, saithConueni •… inter nos & •…

Non enim humana voluntate allata est aliquando Prophetia, sed Spiritu s •… inspirati loquuti sunt Sancti Dei homines. Vbi B. Petrus probat non debere exponi Scripturas ex prop •…

Nos enim existimamus hunc Spiritum, etsi multis priuatis hominibus conceditur, tamen certò inueniri in Ecclesia, id est in Concilio Episcoporum confirmato à summo Ecclesia Pastore, siue in summo Pastore cum Concilio aliorum Pastorum. Bellarmine ibid. In this place, as hee p •…
seth, he will not dispute, whether the Pope alone, speaking ex Catbedra, be the Church; for that h •… to dispute of afterwardes, and he and all his fellowes doe and must acknowledge it, as shall i •… place be shewed. That in this place he grants the communication of that Spirit, by which the Scrip •… were written, vnto priuate men, doth not argue any agreement with vs, but rather his disagree •… from some of his owne profession, who vrge the necessitie of the Churches proposall so much a •… farre, that not Gods Prophets or others to whom his word was extraordinarily reuealed, could 〈…〉 out it be certaine. Vide Bellar. lib. 3. de Justif. cap. 3. Whence likewise hee well collects, that the whole difficultie
in this question about taking vp controuersies, and finding out the true sense of Scriptures, consists in this; wh • re this Spirit is, and where the distressed soule and doubtfull conscience ought to seeke it. In the visible and C • tholique Church, saith Bellarmine, and all the moderne Romane Catholiques; that is, (as they interpret it,) in the consistorie of the Pope and Cardinals, or in the assembly of B shops, or (as the moderne Iesuites will haue it) in the Pope alone speaking ex cathedra.

3 Euery man (say we) ought to seeke the Spirit of God in his own soule and conscience, being directed and ruled by the sacred word, which was reuealed and vttered by the same Spirit. This word directs them in this search, and the Spirit once found out, or rather finding them thus seeking him, establisheth their assent vnto the word alreadie reuealed and written, by imprinting the same inuisible word, or the true sense and meaning of it, in their hearts.

4 Why this Spirit should bee infallibly present to the visible Church, all our aduersaries vncessantly vrge Scripture. I will not abuse the readers patience with allegation of the places, which haue beene very fully answered by many of our Church. That which I intend at this time, is. First, to debarre them by their own groundes of this plea of Scriptures, by shewing their absurditie, and folly, in vrging any Scripture at all for the proofe of their assertion: And secondly, to ouerthrow the assertion it selfe by manifest proofes, that either their Churches transcendent authoritie (as it is now taught) must fall, or Christianitie cannot stand. To make way for our clearer passage in the former.

5The Papists assertions whence the proposed conclusion is gathered. They generally hold, that this infallibilitie of the visible Church consists directly in this; That the holy Ghost is infallibly present to it, & giues it the true sense and meaning of Scriptures: which he doth not giue to priuate persons; whom, in their iudgements, he will not vouchsafe immediately to instruct; so that his Dictates alreadie reuealed cannot bee a rule vnto them, because they want his infallible assistance for their exposition; and for the same reason, Certaine they cannot bee without the Churches authoritie that they vnderstand the Scripture aright.

6 This their assertion being two fold, (for their Churches infallible expositions, and against all priuate interpretations,) is
grounded vpon these two principles. They are to bee beleeued in exposition of Scriptures fide diuina, whom the Holy Ghost infallibly assists. They are not so to be beleeued, whom the Holy Ghost doth not so assist. Whence what hee said before will follow, that no man, besides the Pope, may beleeue his owne interpretations of Scriptures: His or the Churches all must, nay all men must beleeue fide diuina, that the Church or Pope is in all determinations infallibly assisted by the Holy Ghost. For if wee were not bound to beleeue their infallibilitie most infallibly, it could be no rule of faith, but might bee reiected till wee see it euidently proued; whereas they contend it should be the rule of faith vnto all, and by their owne confession a mayne Article of their Creed: but (according to their positions as we shall hereafter proue) the onely Article of Christian faith; how destitute these their assertions are of all groundes of reason, or rules of nature, hath beene made euident. There remaine onely Two pillars possibly imaginable for supporting this pretended infallibilitie, Tradition and Scripture. Against Tradition all the arguments they can heape against the certaintie of Scriptures stand good; as shall hereafter (God willing) be shewed. That no argument can be drawne from Scripture to their succour, albeit the later Iesuites haue earnestly sought to scrape a many (for better then scrapings are not the very best they bring) we are now to proue.

7 That our beliefe of Scriptures truth and their true sense (by what meanes soeuer we attaine thereto) must be infa lible, Both agree: The meanes that must infallibly ascertaine or proue their diuine truth and true meaning vnto vs (say our aduersaries) is the Churches infallibilitie, which likewise must be infallibly beleeued; otherwise it could not be the rule of faith, or beliefe infallible. It shall suffi • e here (once for all) to admonish the Reader, That as often as we mention beliefe of Scriptures or the Churches infallibilitie, in this dispute, wee meane not any kind of beliefe, but that onely which is infallible: so likewise, whiles wee mention the meanes or proofes of either, wee vnderstand onely meanes or proofes infallible, whereon faith may immediatly relie, as vpon a rule most sure and certaine. In all these we demaund nothing but what our aduersaries most willingly grant. From their grant we argue thus.

The generall points of diff •
cultie how either the Church can ascertaine the diuine truth of Scripture vnto vs, or the Scripture the Churches infallible authoritie.8 If either the Scriptures can thus ascertaine or proue the Churches infallibilitie, or it the infallible truth of Scriptures to our soules: we must of necessitie, either beleeue the one of these before the other [The Churches infallibilitie before Scriptures, or Scriptures before it] or both together without all prioritie of beliefe, or praeeixstent knowledge of the one, whence the beliefe or knowledge of the other must spring. The members of the diuision are in the proposall actually two, but in the disquisition will proue three: To begin with the first.

9 If they say wee must beleeue the Scriptures to be the word of God,What inconueniences will follow if they admit the first memb • r of the diuision proposed • hat is, if they beleeue the Scriptures infallibly before they can beleeue the Churches infallibilitie so. before we can beleeue the infallibilitie of their Church: they ouerthrow their owne, and establish our positions. For thus they make the Scripture a rule of our faith, at the least in this one Article of the Catholique Churches infallibilitie; which, by this assertion, wee may and ought infallibly to beleeue, because the Scriptures, which we first infallibly beleeue, doe teach and proue it. Hence priuate men should be taught by the Holy Ghost, first to beleeue the truth of Scriptures, and for it the Churches infallibilitie. Wherefore the Scripture must bee the immediate rule of their beliefe in the Article of the Churches infallibilitie, which to them is the generall rule of faith; and so by consequence, the Scriptures which to vs are onely the rule of faith must bee more then so to them, euen the rule of their rule of faith. But if the Scriptures may bee the immediate and infallible rule of their beliefe in this one Article of the Churches infallibilitie; what reason possibly can bee imagined, why they should not bee the infallible and immediate rule of their faith, in all other parts or Articles of their Creede? For I call Heauen and Earth, men and Angels, to witnesse betwixt ours and the Romish Church, whether the Articles of Christs incarnation, his death, his passion, his buriall, his resurrection, his ascention, his intercession for vs, the resurrection of the dead, and life euerlasting &c. be not to any mans capacitie in the world much more plainely set downe in sundrie places of Scripture, then the infallibilitie of the present Romish Church, in these words, Peter feed my sheepe. Peter to thee I giue the keyes of Heauen. Thou art Peter and vpon this rocke will I build my Church. It seemed good to the Holy Ghost and vs, or in any place her sonnes can challenge for it. Wherefore if the Holy Ghost
teach vs this Article of the Churches infallibilitie immediately, without the Churches infallible authoritie, (which as wee now suppose must be proued from the Scriptures first infallibly beleeued:) then questionlesse he may and will immediately teach vs the other articles of our Creed, and whatsoeuer necessarie to saluation, (which are more plainly and perspicuously set downe in Scriptures,) without the helpe or assistance of the Churches infallible authoritie, which it is supposed to teach by places more doubtfull.

10 Or if our aduersaries will hold it no absurditie to say, that the holy Ghost may teach vs the true sense and meaning of the fore-mentioned places of Scripture, which seeme to make for the infallibility of the Romish Church, as Petre pasce oues, &c. immediately without the helpe or assistance of the Churches infallibilitie, (which is heere the lesson supposed to be taught,) and referres all other points of faith or matters of doctrine vnto the Churches teaching immediatly they are bound in reason to shew a Scripture for this assertion. And besides, they must (perforce) make the same comparison betwixt the holy Ghostes immediate teaching, and the Church or Popes immediate teaching, which our Sauiour Iohn. 16.7. Christ made betweene the holy Ghostes extraordinarie teaching which was to ensue his glorification, and his owne immediate teaching before his passion: and as soone as the holy Ghost hath once taught vs the meaning of these places, which make for the Churches infallibilitie, that may be applied vnto him in respect of the Popes supereminencie in teaching, which our Sauiour Christ spake of himselfe, and his owne personall instructions in the daies of his humilitie, in respect of that blessed Comforters illuminations to bee bestowed in abundant measure vppon his Apostles, immediatly vpon his ascention. For thus (by their assertions) that holy Comforter, after that lesson once taught, Tues Petre; should take his leaue of faithfull hearts in the same termes our Sauiour there did of his disciples: I tell you the truth, it is expedient for you that I goe away. For if I goe not away, the comforter (that infallible teacher, on whose authoritie your soules must rest,) will not come vnto you, but if I depart I will send him
Ʋers
• . vnto you: and againe, Ʋer • .
•• . I haue many things to say vnto you, but ye cannot heare them now: howbeit when hee is come
that hath the spirit of truth (your infallible teacher, whose tongue while he speakes ex Cathedra, I must attend) he will lead you into all truth, for he shall not speake of himselfe, but whatsoeuer he shall heare he shall speake, he shall glorifie me, for he shall receiue of me and shew it vnto you. These words (I say) might be taken as a typicall prophesie of the Popes infallible authoritie, (such a prophesie of it I meane, as the historie of the Paschall Lambe was of Cstrists passion:) if they will hold the first member of the former diuision; That the holy Ghost doth first teach vs infallibilitie to beleeue these Scriptures, which they vrge for the infallibility of their Church, and hauing once made vs infallibly to beleeue them, referres vs to the Churches infallibilitie, (taught and beleeued by them) for the rule of faith in all other articles.

11 Sed quia hac non successit, alia aggrediendum est via; Let vs now see,The inconueniences of the second member. If they should say they must infallibly beleeue the Churches infallibility, before they can so beleeue the diuine truth of Scriptures. whether they be like to finde any better successe, by following the second member of the forementioned diuision. (j.) If they should say, We must infallibly beleeue the Churches infallibility in expounding Scriptures, or points of faith, before we can infallibly beleeue them to be the word of God, or to containe in them doctrines of faith. This indeed they must say, if they hold their Churches authoritie to be the rule of faith, or whereby infallibly to distinguish diuine truth from Apocryphall.

12 Let vs first take the proposition for disputations sake; viz. [We must beleeue the Churches infallible authoritie, before we can beleeue the Scripture to be the infallible Oracles of God.] Secondly, let vs consider but this one part of the Churches infallible authoritie, which all the moderne Papists acknowledge [That the Scriptures cannot be knowne infallibly to be the word of God, but by the confi • mation of the present Church.] And let vs see how these two assertions can stand together. By the first, the Churches infallible authoritie must be infallibly beleeued before Scriptures: by the second (which containes the chiefe part of the Churches infallibilitie) the Scriptures cannot be infallibly acknowledged, or beleeued to be the word of God but vpon former supposall of beleeuing the Churches infallibilitie confirming this truth vnto vs.

13 Heere let all, whose braines are not intoxicate with the wine of fornication, pause a while, and contemplate what Babilonish giddinesse hath possest their braines, that haue runne
round about so long, (though alwaies staggering,) in vrging Scriptures for to proue that, as an Article of beliefe, which must be infallibly beleeued, before those places of Scriptures which they vrge for it; or else nor they nor any other Scriptures can euer be stedfastly beleeued to be the word of God, or to haue sufficient authoritie in them to cause stedfast beleefe vnto that which they teach. For this is the issue of all our aduersaries arguments in this point, That such matters as are contained in Scriptures cannot be stedfastly acknowledged, or beleeued, for supernaturall or diuine truthes, vntill they be confirmed by this infallible authoritie of the present Church. Where againe I would haue the Reader call to mind, what was before obserued out of Bellarmines positions; That this infallibilitie of the Church consists directly in this, that it is perpetually as • isted by the holy Ghost: and it is all one with them, to say, wee beleeue the Churches infallible authoritie in matters of faith, and to say, wee beleeue the Church is perpetually assisted by the holy Ghost: Againe, (by all the later Iesuites positions) it is all one to say, We beleeue the Church is perpetually assisted by the holy Ghost in determining matters of faith, and to say, wee beleeue that the Pope, speaking ex Cathedra, is assisted perpetually by the holy Ghost in determining matters of faith.

14 Out of these assertions compared with the proposition supposed, [The Churches infallibility must be beleeued before Scripture, or other Articles of faith,] this will immediately and directy follow: We must beleeue that the holy Ghost, the supreme Iudge of Scriptures and matters of faith, doth infallibly assist the Church, or Pope speaking ex Cathedra, before we can beleeue that there is an holy Ghost. For this is one Article of faith, taught in Scriptures, which Scriptures (say our aduersaries) cannot bee beleeued, but by the confirmation of the Churches infallible authoritie, and this infallible authoritie consists (as we said before) in this, that it is infallibly assisted by the holy Ghost: wherefore the conclusion of this absurd posi • ion is: That we must first beleeue the holy Ghost is perpetually resident in the Popes breast, or consistorie of Rome, before it can be beleeued that there is an holy Ghost, or diuine Trinitie in heauen. If we consider the practise of our Aduersaries in vrging Scripture, to proue their
Churches infallibility to be the rule of faith: they should in reason admit the first member of the fore-mentioned diuision, and hold that the Scriptures must be infallibly beleeued for the word of God, before the infallibility of the Church (which they seeke to proue by Scriptures,) can be infallibly beleeued. But againe, if we consider their obseruations concerning the Churches infallibility. [That the Scriptures cannot be knowne to be the Scriptures but by it; and that it is the rule of faith,] they must of necessitie admit the second member of the fore-cited diuision, and maintaine, that the Churches infallibilitie must infallibly bee beleeued, before we can beleeue the Scriptures to be the infallible Oracles of God: For Regula semper est prior regulato; but the Churches infallibility is the rule of faith by their positions, and to beleeue the Scripture to bee the infallible Oracles of God, is a maine point of faith, and necessarie to saluation:Valenlian. puncto 7. parag. for, This is the Iesuits principall Topicke, to disproue the Scriptures sufficiencie for being the rule of faith in all pointes, because it containeth not this one point, viz. that the Scriptures are the infallible Oracles of God. It is hence euidently proued, that neither of the two first members of the former diuision can stand eyther with reason, the allegators practise, or positions. For the first quite ouerthrowes their positions concerning their Churches infallible authoritie. The second proues their practise to be most absurd, in vrging Scriptures for to proue it. And yet the third member is of all the three the most absurd, albeit not so dissonant to their positions, or practise in this point, because as are they, so is it, senselesse both; which will euidently appeare by the bare proposall of it.The grosse absurdities of the third member, as well in reason as in respect of their assertions. If they should say they neither infallibly beleeue the Scriptures before the Churches infallibilitie, nor it before them.

15 The third member was, That we must infallibly beleeue the Scriptures to be the Oracles of God, and the Churches infallibilitie both together, without any prioritie of time, order, or nature. First, if this assertion bee true: then cannot the Churches infallibilitie serue as a rule to know the Scriptures to be the word of God infallibly, because regula prior est regulato. But by this assertion there is no prioritie in the Churches infallibilitie, (their supposed rule,) in respect of our knowing, or beleeuing the Scriptures to be the Oracles of God. Secondly, if the former assertion bee true: then neither can the Scriptures proue the
Churches infallibility, nor the Churches infallibility proue the Scriptures to bee the word of God vnto any beleeuer. For all meanes or arguments of proofe suppose a prioritie, in respect of the parties vnto whom proofe is to be made. And to say, that of two things, both beleeued and knowne together without any prioritie, the one might proue the other, were as much, as if wee should say, that a thing might proue it selfe, & as we say in scholes to proue idem per idem. For the very reason why wee cannot proue idem per idem, is, because there is no prioritie of knowledge in such identitie: for otherwise, where the thing prouing, and the thing proued, are indeed the selfe same, yet if there bee a prioritie of conceits or notions in the same thing, one of them will sufficiently proue the other; as is euident in the Diuine attributes, none of which are indeede really disti • ct from others, and yet may one of them proue another, because in respect of vs one of them is better knowne then another, and consequently being knowne may proue the other. But of such attributes as are neither better knowne then other, or where the termes are only diuerse, without prioritie of conceit or knowledge, there can bee no prouing of the one by the other. For all discursiue knowledge, (such as is all knowledge by way of proofe or syllogisme,) must bee ex praeexistente cognitione: And where one thing is proued by another, that which proueth must first bee beleeued; for the beleefe of the other must spring or arise from the beleefe of it. If a man should goe about to proue that the Prince was sumptuously arrayed, because hee was sumptuously apparrelled or attired, the proofe would be ridiculous: seeing sumptuous apparrell, and sumptuous array in common speech are all one, & he that knowes the one knowes or beleeues the other. But if a man should say, the Prince was sumptuously apparrelled, because he ware a sute of Tissue, or beset with pearle, the proofe were good, so it could be proued that he wore such a sute. For it is sufficiently knowne to all, that such attire is sumptuous: and therefore he that can make proofe that hee was so attired, hath sufficiently proued that hee was sumptuously arrayed. And thus, would our Aduersaries admitte, that eyther the Scriptures wee better knowne then the infallibilitie of the Church; or the Churches infallibilitie better knowne
then they the one of them might be brought to proue the other, without any fault in the manner or forme of proofe, howsoeuer their assertions in the proofe of eyther would ouerthrow eyther their owne positions, or the principles of faith, as appeareth in the two former parts of our diuision. But according to our supposition in the third member, to wit, [That the Churches infallibilitie, and the infallibilitie of Scripture, are both alike knowne vnto vs, and neyther beleeued from before other,] the verie manner, or forme of promising one by the other, would be as ridiculous and absurde, as if a man should prooue costly apparrell by sumptuous array: Or that one was costly apparrelled, because hee wore costly rayment.

16 The most of our aduersaries louing (in this point) darkenesse more than light, (like desperate debters, that keepe strict reckoning what others owe them, but are afraide to take an account of the debtes they owe,) neuer seeke to examine the particular difficulties of their owne opinions, but thinke it sufficient to cast stumbling blockes before their feete, that will not hoodwinke themselues, that they may stand in neede of leading by such blinde guides as themselues. Yet Valentian, who had gone so farre in searching the difficulties, Ʋalentians attempted euasion out of the inchanted circle of Romane faith, refuted. and dangers of this darksome inchanted way, vntill he he had come to see some lightninges of these obiections heere set downe, at the first representation of them is so affrighted, as if hee had seene a night-walker or hobgoblin, that had put him so farre out of his right minde, as he neither dare go forwards, nor can he pray to God to blesse him, or send him his spirit to conduct him safely backe; but runnes round with the Colliars Catechisme in his mouth, in steed of a better charme. His resolution is thus.Ʋt breuiter quae fasius disputata sunt de resolutione fidei, colligamus, placet modum tradere quo quis de fide interrogatus debeat respondere. Igitur siquie rogetur, v.g. Quare eredat Deum esse trinum & vnum? distinguat vtrum viz. firmiter & infallibiliter id credat, vel de causa ob quam acceptauerat eam fidem, si primum respondeat, quia Deus reuelauit: si rursus interrogatus vnde cognoscat Deum reuelasse, respondeat se quidem non nosse id clare, credere tamen eadem fide infallibiliter, & id quidem non ob aliam reuelationem, bene tamen ob infallibilem propositionem Ecclesiae, tanquam ob conditionem ad id credendum r • quisitam. Si rursus, vnde cognoscat propositionem Ecclesiae esse infallibilem? similiter dicat se clarè non nosse, credere tamen fide infallibili ob reuelationem Scripturae testimonium perhibetis Ecclesiae: cui reuelationi non credit ob aliam reuelationem, sed ob seipsam, quamuis ad hoc ipsum opus sit Ecclesiae propositione vt conditione requisita. Valent. tom. 3. in Aquinat. Epist. 1. quaest. 1. punct. 1. §. 16.
That we may briefly collect the former large disputes concerning the resolution of faith, it shall not bee amisse to set downe a forme of answering to such as demaund a
reason of our faith. If you be demaunded (for example sake) why you beleeue a Trinitie of persons in one Godhead: First, distinguish whether the question be of your firme and infallible beleefe of this truth it selfe, or of the cause which moued you to imbrace this beleefe. In the former case the answere must be, because God hath reuealed it: If it bee demaunded againe how you know that God hath reuealed it? the answere must be, you know it not euidently, but yet beleeue so, by the same infallible faith by which you beleeued the truth reuealed: and this not by an other Reuelation, but by the Churches infallible proposall of it, which is a condition necessary to such beleefe. If yet it be further questioned, how you know the Churches proposall or auouching of this Reuelation to be infallible? your answere must be againe, that distinctly and clearely you know not thus much, but yet beleeue it as infallibly as the former, and that for the Reuelation of the Scripture, bearing testimony of the Churches infallibility, which Reuelation you beleeue not by any other Reuelation, but for it selfe, although vnto this very beleefe the Churches proposall be required as a necessary condition.

17 It cannot chuse but be a great motiue to perswade any man (that doth not affect blindnesse in this point,) of the shallow and vnstable foundation of the Romish Church: when he shall thus behold so skilful an artificer as Valentiā, in laying the very ground-worke thereof, so grauelled in his owne obiections, that hee fares like one that had fallen into a deepe pit of loose sand, heauing and offering with might and maine to get out and goe forwards, but being destitute of all firme ground, whereon to rest one part till the rest be raised, beates himselfe blinde with too much strugling in such a sandie soyle. For surely, from more then Aegyptian or Sodomitish blindnesse did that attempted euasion of his in the fore-mentioned place proceede.Neque in sic • redge; • respondendo 〈…〉 aliquus vitiosi •… circulas tū qu •… reuelatio pro •… quā dicitur c •… infallibilitas 〈…〉 positionis, & 〈…〉 positio ob qua 〈…〉 dicitur credi •… uelatio, non bent vnū & 〈…〉 obiectum, se •… liud & aeliua •… (obiectum n •… propositionis ipsa reuelatio •… obiectum autem reuelationis est ipsa veritas credita; vt Deum esse trinum & vnum, aut propositionem Ecc •… esse infallibilem:) tum quia, cum ex reuelatione redditur ratio credendi propositionem, redtitur per cau •… (Reuelation • est assensus fide • ;) • um vero ex proposit • one Ecclesie redditur ratio credendi reuelationem, ratio 〈…〉 ditur no • per causam cred • nd, sed • er conditio •• m ad id requisitatu, & ita v • tatur vi • i • sas circulus & solum •… ditur ratio connexorum v • c • ss •• n ex • ipsismet connexis sub diuersa ratione, id quod omninò licet. Valent ibid. Nor doe we commit any circular fallacy in this forme of answering, Partly, because the Reuelation, for which the Churches infallible proposall is beleeued, and the proposall for which the Reuelation is beleeued, haue not one and the same, but each it seuerall obiect. For the obiect of the Churches proposall is the Reuelation, but the obiect of the Reuelation is the truth it selfe beleeued, as
that there is one God and three persons, or that the Churches proposall is infallible: Partly, because, when we assigne the Reuelation as a reason why we beleeue the Churches proposall, we giue the reason by the cause, (for the Reuelation is the cause of our assent or actuall beleefe,) but when we assigne the Churches proposall as a reason why we beleeue the Reuelation, the reason is not assigned by the true cause of our beleefe, but by a condition requisite thereunto. And so this Iuglers ring, or circular fallacie is auoided, and onely a reason is giuen of thinges connexed mutually from the things themselues connexed vnder a diuers reason or respect, which is nolegerdemaine but faire play.

If the diuers obiectes of the diuine Reuelation, and the Churches infallibity, were the onely cause or reason why wee take this resolutiō for circular proofe, then this exception of the diuersity of their obiectes, were to some purpose. But we impeach this his resolution of naughtinesse, for the verie forme or manner, because the proofe is idem per idem. And being so, albeit the obiect of the diuine Reuelation and the Churches proposal be diuerse: yet is this no sufficient testimonie to acquite it, vnlesse they will affirme, that there can bee no circular proofe where the obiect of the things mutually proued are diuerse, which if they vniuersally affirme, (as without an vniuersall affirmation in this kinde, there can be no proofe:) wee shall as easily impeach this affirmation of open falshood, as their forme of argument of circular fallacie. For wheresoeuer any thing vncertaine to vs, is in • erred by another thing alike vncertaine, and th • t other onely proued by the former: there is a circular proofe, albeit we should by this forme of argument seeke to proue one thing by another, whose obect was quite contrarie to the former. Nay although wee should proue the very diuersitie, or contrarietie of the obiectes in two seuerall termes proposed, by this or the like circular forme: yet were our proofe naught, albeit this same diuersity of obiects might be proued by some other lawfull forme of argument. For the diuersitie or identitie of obiects in syllogisticall termes, is meerely accidentall to the nature of circular proofe, or inference of idem per idem.

18 To fit our aduersaries with a familiar example, euerie way parallel to their owne resolution in this point, (if they will acknowledge their owne Valentians resolution for their owne:)
but more plaine and easie to the capacitie of the vnlearned Reader. Suppose some ambitious Captaine, or Courtier, (for whose integritie no man of place would promise much,) should bring vnto our King, or some States-man in this land, some forraine Princes (as the renowned King of Denmarkes) letters commendatorie, for his great sufficiencie in good place in Warre or State: I would request but any ordinarie Reader well to consider, what manner of resolution it would be, if with reuerence I may suppose that eyther his Maiestie, or any States-man in this land, in the bestowing of any such place of worth, as this supposed messenger would sue for, might thus resolue: Surely the King of Denmarke is a renowned religious Prince, and one that wisheth exceeding well vnto our King and State, and whatsoeuer he should write in any mans commendations, for his aduancement to such a place as this partie makes suite for, I dare not once call in question, lest I should seeme to disparage his Princely word: but how shall I know that these are his letters, and no counterfaite? If thus hee should doubt, and yet finally rest content with this or like suggestion; why? doth not he say they are his true letters, whose fidelitie and integritie the King in his letters commends? no man in the world (I thinke) of any ordinarie experience, although hee had neuer trauerst the schooles to know the meaning of a circular proofe, but could perceiue this resolution to be but dolus circulatorius: and he that would be cosened with this or the like, by any traueller of what fashion soeuer, may easily be circumuented by any domesticke Pedlar, or circumforaneall copes-mate. Yet is this resolution in euery point the selfe same with Valentians resolution, concerning the Romane Churches infallibilitie; and the exception which heere he brings, why this resolution of his is none, may altogether as directly and fitly bee brought to shew, that this supposed resolution is no circular resolution. First, let vs parallell the seuerall pars of both resolutions, in that resolution of faith which Valentian brings: All Christians beleeue, that whatsoeuer God saith is true; and so in this other resolution it is supposed that his Maiestie or any of his States-men firmely beleeues, that whatsoeuer the King of Denmarke writes or auoucheth in matters of this nature, (as of ciuill integritie, and sufficiencie for the discharge of such an office) is altogether true, and
may not be suspected yet may they suspect whether he wrote thus much in this mans commendations, as these letters import, or no. And so saith Valentian, & other Papists, all Christians may suspect, (certaine they cannot be) whether God wrote those books which we call Scripture or no. The assurance which Christians in matters concerning faith, and States-men in this present case could haue for their securitie, is altogether the same. For the Statesman hath no other reason to perswade himselfe, that these are the King of Denmarkes letters, but onely the report, asseueration, or testimonie of this messenger, whose preferment they concerne. And so likewise by the Papists positions, no priuate Christian can haue any other certaine assurance, that these Scriptures are the word of God, but onely the testimonie or confirmation of the present Romish Church, whose state and dignitie they likewise seeke to maintaine by countenance of the Scriptures, whose misse-interpretation did eyther first occasiō, or not hinder, her rising to that height of temporall dignitie which she now enioyes. Thus finally it appears that all the reason or ground of beleefe, which any Papist following the Iesuites for their instructors can haue, must be the infallibility of the Romish Church, whose infallibility therfore cannot be proued out of Scripture, because the Scriptures by their positions cannot bee infallibly proued to be Scriptures, or that authenticke Word which onely can affoorde sure proofe in matters of faith, but by this their Churches supposed authoritie. As for Valentians exception, concerning the diuerse obiect of the Churches Proposall, and the diuine Reuelations by it proposed, the selfe-same diuersitie of obiect may be obserued in the former instance of the counterfeit messenger, whose resolution in effect is thus; You must beleeue these letters, because I commend them vnto you in the King of Denmarkes name, and you must beleeue mee in commending them vnto you because the King of Denmarke, whose words you trust in them, commends my trust and fidelitie. To apply Valentiaes exception to this resolution; As the obiect of that the Church proposeth, or rather of the Churches proposall, is the diuine reuelation: so likewise is the obiect of this counterfaites proposall the often mentioned kings supposed commendation of him. Againe, as the obiect of the diuine Reuelation is the truth beleeued, [Veritas
credita, vt Deum esse trinum & vnum, aut propositionem Ecclesiae esse infallibilem, as that there is a Trinitie in the Godhead, or the Churches proposall is infallible:] So likewise the obiect of the kings commendation in the other instance, is the truth beleeued, or that at least which this counterfeit exactes to be beleeued as true to wit, that hee himselfe is a man of excellent partes, and one that will vse fidelitie as well in his doings as sayings, and in a word, one, whose proposall in matters of State or warre, is as infallible as the Popes in matters of faith. Yet notwithstanding that this counterfaites proposall or asseueration, which must be beleeued from the Princes commendation of him, which must be beleeued againe from his proposall, Non habent vnum & idem obiectum, sed aliud & aliud, haue not one and the same obiect: yet is the former resolution still ridiculous; and so is Valentians resolution of his Catholike faith most ridiculously most impious. For what other issue of such dissolute resolutions can bee expected, but that men who know no better, should hereby bee driuen to suspect the Scriptures for counterfeite, and the Catholike Church (if the Romane were onely the Catholike Church) of villanous forgerie, at the least in those places of Scripture which she pretendes for proofe of her owne infallibilitie.

19 As for Valentians later exception, why his resolution should not bee circular: it is more ridiculous then the former, most ridiculously false (to omit other points) in this one, that he dare denie the Churches proposall by their doctrine to bee the cause, why wee beleeue the diuine Reuelation, or rather that these Scriptures which we haue are diuine Reuelations. For by their positions we cannot assure our selues, that the Scriptures are the word of God, by any other cause or reason, besides the Churches authoritie: and therefore, by their doctrine, the infallible authoritie of their Church is the onely cause, why wee beleeue this sacred Canon of Scriptures, which wee enioy, to bee diuine Reuelations, although it bee no cause by their doctrine, why we beleeue that in generall diuine Reuelations are true. For this is a dictate of nature, not controuersed betwixt vs and them, or betwixt any who acknowledge a diuine power. And Valentian himselfe directly implies, that which he impudently denies in the selfe-same period. For he granteth, that Propositio Ecclesia
est ratio credendi diuinam reuelationem; & In matters of knowledge, or beleefe, reason and cause are synonymall, & euery cause in nature goes before the effect. And euen when we demonstrat • the cause by it proper effect, the effect must needs be first knowne to vs, seeing it is the reason or cause of our knowing the cause, though no cause of the reall cause it selfe. ratio credendi, the reason or rule of beleeuing, must needs include in it a precedent cause of beleefe, it cannot be onely a condition annexed thereto: but of this point (God willing) hereafter.

20 Sacroboscus intangled in the former circle, and caught in his own snare. Sacroboscus, (who hath followed Bellarmines and Valenti • es footsteps, as faithfully as any Irish footeman could his master, though sometimes taking a more compendious and smoother way, likely to entice pedestria ingenia, wits eyther by nature dull, or nouices in arts and smatterers in schoole-learning, to follow him sooner then those great ones,) hath taken vpon him to answere to this circle, in effect as Valentian doth, saue onely that he hath put more trickes of art vpon it, eyther to confound the iudicious, or deceiue the simple Reader. Which heere we shall not neede to examine, because we purpose to vnrip his mysticall euasions in that last Chapter of the next dispute. In the end of his tract in defence of Bellarmine, he frames his obiection, against both valentian and his owne resolution: Sed quaeris num quando quis credit aliquid propter authoritatem Ecclesiae, necessarium sit prius tempore vel faltem natura, formaliter, & explicite credat ipsam Ecclesiam esse infallibilis authoritatis, quemadmodum quando assentimur conclusioni propter praemissas, necesse est vt prius assentiamur ipsis praemissis. Respondeo, id minime esse necessarium: nam actus fidei sertur in suum obiectum, moda simplici, vt visus in suum: itaque ficut visus per speciem albi (v. g.) videt album, non videndo ipsam speciem, sic potest quis per Ecclesiae authoritatem: credere, ita vt non prius formaliter & explicite credat Ecclesiae authoritatem. Sacrobosc. pag. 13 • . 139. A good examiner may know this fellow to be a Iesuite by his answere, so full stuft with mentall reseruations, secret euasions, and ambiguities. First he will not resolue vs whether men ordinarily must beleeue the Church before Scriptures: but a man may beleeue the Scriptures, although he do not first beleeue the Church explicite or formerly. And in the very next words he impertinētly ads that beleeuing the Scriptures we cannot but implicite and vertually beleeue the Church. Which argues that the Scriptures must be beleeued before the Church. But say we could not beleeue the one, but we must vpō equ • l termes beleeue the other, this proues that neither could be any infallible or effectual means of beleeuing the other. For there is no man that knowes twise 4 make 8, but knowes as wel twise 2 make 4, yet is neither a means of knowing the other, for both are immediatly knowne of thēselues. This shews the impertinēcy of their answer that mutter they know not what, as if the knowledge of points of faith did resēble habitū principiorū, rather thē habitū conclusionis. If so they do thē cannot the Churches infallibility being by their positiōs a point of faith, be any means of knowing the Scriptures to be diuine, which is a maine point of faith. [Whether, in beleeuing the Church by Scriptures, and Scriptures by the Church, the beleefe of the one must in nature, (if not in time) goe before the other] He thinkes it not necessarie that the one should be before the other, Nam actus fidei fertur in suum obiectum modo simplici, vt visus in suū. And therfore as we see colours per species visibiles, by the visible shapes, or resemblances which flow from them, not by seeing the visible shape before the colours: so do we beleeue the Scriptures by the Church, albeit we doe not expresly and formally beleeue the Church before wee beleeue the Scriptures.
Quo teneam vultus mutantem Protea nodo? In the former part of this his discourse, the visible Church was vnto Scriptures, as theThis co •…
rison inde •… most con •…
nant to t • positions as we sha •… terwardes proue, do •… as clearel •… wray the i •… stery of t •… iniquitie, the sunne colours. light was vnto colours; now it is vnto Scriptures, as visible shapes are vnto colours. What then? Doe we not see visible shapes before colours, nor colours before them? no. For we see no visible shapes at all, but by them colours onely are brought into our light: and wee cannot see one before the other, if the one we see not at all. And in like sense it were true, that we should not beleeue the Church before Scriptures, not Scriptures before we beleeue the Church, if we were not bound to beleeue the one at all. But if we see one thing by another which we likewise see, we must needs see that first by which we see the other: and so if eyther wee beleeue the Scriptures by beleeuing the Church, or beleeue the Church by beleeuing Scriptures, we must of necessitie beleeue the one before the other. For that by which we beleeue a thing is the meanes of beleefe, and the meanes of beleefe must needes in nature and order go before beleefe it selfe. And if the Church be the meanes of beleeuing onely in as much as we beleeue it; or to speake more distinctly, if the beleeuing the Church be the verie meanes of beleeuing the Scriptures: then must we needs beleeue the Church before we beleeue the Scriptures. If our aduersaries affirme, that their Church is the onely infallible meanes of beleeuing Scriptures, in any other sort then by beleeuing it: let them in the name of God assigne by what means they will she can make vs beleeue the Scriptures, we shall not much contend;This in 〈…〉 of his do •… very well 〈…〉 strate o • mer asser •… concerni •… the vse of 〈…〉 ordinary 〈…〉 gistracie 〈…〉 ministry, 〈…〉 2. cap. 1. 〈…〉
• ag. ult.
〈…〉 the v • sib •… Church 〈…〉 bee said in such sense infallible as the shapes and resemblances of colours are called visible, 〈…〉 indeed by nature inuisible, and are visible onely by externall denomination, in as much as the pr •… colours to our sight, which onely are truly visible. Were they really visible themselues being rec •… into our eyes, they would hinder our sight of all colours so doth this admission of a reall infalli •… in the Church exclude all infallible beleefe of other points of faith. so they will not bind vs to beleeue this their Churches decisiōs. Sacroboscus his cōparison of rhe visible Church and visible shapes, we admit thus far for good, that as vnlesse there were such visible shapes, no colours could be seene so likewise, vnlesse God had some visible Church on earth, mē ordinarily could not see the light of the Gospell. For it is not ordinarily communicate to any, but by the ministry of others, but being cōmunicate, we beleeue it in it self, & for it self, not by beleeuing others; as we see colours in themselues & for thēselues, not by seeing the
visible shapes, by which they are presented or communicate vnto our eyes. But whether there bee any prioritie betweene the beleefe of these two, [Church and Scriptures,] according to our aduersaries doctrine, or whether the beleefe of the one be the cause of the beleefe of the other, or in what sort the cause, and what inconueniences will follow thereon: we shall dispute hereafter.

21 Let them in the meane time illustrate the manner, how we beleeue Scriptures by the Church, as they please. Let it haue the same proportion to Scriptures, which the light, or visible shapes haue vnto colours: they themselues make the beleefe of Scriptures most vncertaine, and for this reason seeke to establish the infallibilitie of their Church for to assure vs of the truth of Scriptures. We demaund how this certaintie of their Churches infallibilitie can possibly be proued? By reason? that is impossible, as you heard before. By tradition? of whom? of such as may erre; that is, vncertaine of the infallible Church? But her infallibilitie is called in question, and any Church may challenge this prerogatiue, as well as theirs, vnlesse they can shew a better title. Without Reuelation from aboue it is still vncertaine, fide diuina, whether we are to beleeue any Churches infallibilitie concerning Scripture:Jisdem fere argumentis efficitur neque solam traditionem vinae vocis eorum qui olim vita defunct •• ni, esse iudi • e insuffidientem f • dei quo vatea • per se • i ne alia aeliqua infallibli ac pr • sente authoritate omnes omnino definire 〈◊〉 quaestiones. Namprimum • eut de authoritate ipsius Scripturae necesse est per aliquam alia 〈◊〉 certam authoritatem constare: ita etiam de authoritate traditionis, si ea quoque reuocetur in dubium. Non enim traditio loquitur etiam ipsa clare & perspicue de sese, vt neque ipsa scriptura. Deinde cum traditio scriptis fere doctorum orthodoxorum in Ecclesia conseruetur, quastiones ac dubia moueri possunt de sensu illius, sicut dubitatur s • pede sensu & mente doctorum. Ʋalentianus loco citato paragraph▪ 11. Or if any, which of all. Reuelations from aboue we acknowledge none but the written word: they acknowledge traditiōs as well as it, yet so as the Scriptures (by their confession) are as certaine as tradition, which they make equall onely with the written word acknowledged by vs, not aboue it. Wherefore, if the Scriptures bee in themselues (by their obiections) vncertaine: then is tradition as vncertaine. What shall assure vs of the truth of eyther? The infallible Church? But this can assure no man, vnlesse he first beleeue it for certaine and infallibly. What shall make it certaine to vs? The Scriptures? But they are vncertaine, say our aduersaries, and the Church must confirme their certaintie vnto vs. Though this circle (wherein Valentian and Sacroboscus haue runne giddie,) were of force to raise vp all
the spirits in hell, and though they raised should sift all the Iesuites braines in the world: yet should not all the inuention of man, with the helpe of diuels, be able to finde out the least probabilitie of auoiding the former inconuenience. Nay they should farre sooner make ropes of the sand in the Adriaticke Sea, so strong as would haile Italy vnto the Ilands of Diuels, before they could teach all the Iesuites in the world so much Geometrie, as to make one of these vncertainties support another.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
The vnsufficiency of the Romane rule of faith, for effecting what it aimes at, albeit we grant all they demaund: the ridiculous vse thereof amongst such as doe acknowledge it.
div.p:
1 WHen I was a child (as our Apostle saith,) and spake as a childe, vnderstood as a child: I thought some great matters might bee contained vnder those hyperbolicall and swelling titles of the Romish Church, wherewith mine cares were often filled. And although I had beene instructed to the contrarie, yet could I haue wished her doctrine true, such was my affection to her shape, as it was falsely represented to my childish fantasie. But after the day-starre had shined in my heart, the former humour wherewith the eyesight of my infant minde had beene corrupted, was quickly dispelled. Once able to looke more narrowly into the subtillest of her schoolemens disputes, and examine her learned Clearkes Apologies for her, by the Gospels light: I saw clearely, how by presenting mere shewes or shadowes of truth, they led weake-sighted soules into error, as it were in a mist: in the beginning of their works vsually inserting pretended grounds (here and there as they espie occasion) of their intended conclusions, supported with some sleight reasons for the present; feeding vs with expectatiō of better proofes, either in some other work or (a great way after) in the same, which may stay our minds till we come at them, where they returne vs backe againe to what is past, and that being now far off, & most particulars out of mind, may seeme not altogether nothing to such as will not take paines
to reuiew it. And thus in fine, as the mist, so their proofes seeme euery where somewhat, till a man come neare them, but then so vanish as he shall see nothing of that he looked for.

2 Bellarmines bookes de verbo Dei, compared with those others of his de Romano Pontifice, &c. and Valentians Analysis fidei will easily approue this obseruation to him that shall read thē through with attention. Both of them in the beginning of their workes promising great matters made me expect some extraordinary proofe in the processe, but finding them best at the first, alwaies ambitious in producing multitude of allegations to little purpose, copious in bestowing glorious titles and prerogatiues vpon their holy Church, and yet finally contracting her Vniuersalitie and sacred Catholickship into one mans breast, (who by their owne confession may be so carnally grosse, that he cannot draw any spirituall breath) their former goodly encomions ending thus, made me cal to mind how craftie companiōs cosen children of what they loue, or stay their crying at what they dislike, by promising them some Gallant, Fine, Gaudie, Trimme, Goodly, Braue, Golden, New, Nothing. Such braue epethites so rauish a childs thoughts, as at the first hearing he parts with any thing hee hath, or forbeares to seeke what otherwise he would haue, in hope of such a gay reward, neuer looking into the substance of what is promised, which was indeed iust nothing. With like bombast outsides doe moderne Priests and Iesuites terrifie silly soules, (men or women meere children in vnderstanding) from all cōmunion with our Church, leading thē through such painted forefronts, or fained, but sightly entrances, into their vast imaginarie emptie Paradise, wherein growes nothing but forbidden fruit. Though volumes they write huge and large, and in the sublimitie of their speculatiue imaginations, fetch arguments from beyond the Moone: yet vnto him that hath but the eye of ordinarie reason in his head, (not blinded by their iuglings) their best collections proue in the end but like the drawing of a net spred farre and wide in the open ayre, able to retaine nothing of what it had compassed, onely such as looked a farre of, or had braines so weake or sight so ill disposed as could not distinguish betwixt the element of ayre and water, marking more then an ordinarie stirre in fetching so huge a draught, might happily suspect some goodly catch.

And it is not to bee expected, that the Pope will ex cathedra define what it is to define a thing ex cathedra, in such sort as shall leaue no euasion to excuse his errour if he should be vrged with a sentence ex cathedra; which to the Maior part of professed Christians might seeme doubtfull whether it were palpably erroneous or no. But suppose we knew directly and authentically what it were to speak ex cathedra, and when the Pope did indeede so speake, when not; (which no man can knowAlbe •… wee knew 〈…〉 what it we 〈…〉 speake ex •…
dra, and t •… when the 〈…〉 speakes 〈…〉 speaketh 〈…〉 infallibly 〈…〉 yet woul •… not follo •… we shoul •… infallibly 〈…〉 solued i •…
trouersie 〈…〉 greatest 〈…〉 ment. but onely by hearesay, vulesse such as heare him giue sentence) yet what assurance can the Iesuits giue vnto the Christian World, that his holinesse shall so determine or speake, as, often as the peace of Christs Church or Weale of Christendome shall require? That hee shall speake de facto ex cathedra, whensoeuer the Church stands in neede of a decision, the Papistes themselues doe not hold as any part of his infallibilitie, but onely that he is able so to speake, when his infallibilitie will. And a posse ad esse non sequitur argumentum. No man, in their iudgement, can or ought constraine him to a decision, except he list. And seeing they affirme, he may be an Heretique, or a Sonne of Sathan; although it were true, he could not propose an Heresie to be beleeued; yet is there no shew of truth why hee may not be so malitiously bent, as hee will not vouchsafe actually to determine that for Heresie in others, which in his iudgement, as he is a Doctor or priuate man, is very orthodoxall; thus doing he should goe against his owne conscience to giue sentence. Gods Spirit as they say will guide his tongue when or whilst hee speakes ex cathedra. But an euill Spirit may so worke vpon his affections, that hee shall not come in good time so to speake, especially against that opinion, which in his priuate conscience hee holds for true. This I thinke none of them can denie.

4 Now whilest these doubts stand vnsatisfied, and yee without further assurance of his infallibilitie in deciding controuersiies, then onely this Hypotheticall or conditionall. [if he speakes ex cathedra] all the comfort, which the Christian World (perplexed with the varietie of opinions and diuersities of Sects) can
reape from these faire promises of the Iesuites concerning their Church or Popes infallible authoritie, is, but as if a man should say vnto a Husbandman (doubtfull vpon the vncertaintie of weather, when to sow or reape) tush be of good cheare, you shall certainly know, what season is good, what not, for seed-time and haruest, when the man in the Moone sets forth an Almanacke. Veritas hypotheticae propositionis (saith old Iauell) nihil ponit in crumena. Many die with fewer pounds in their purses, then arguments in their heads, sufficient to proue the truth of this conditionall proposition, If I had fiue thousand pounds I should be a wealthie man. In like manner if this bee all the assurance their infallible rule can affoord vs. [That a generall Councell, if lawfully assembled, or the Pope if he speake ex cathedra, cannot possibly erre] The most pestiferous and noisome Heresies that now infect the Church may (perhaps) bee quelled, some hundred yeares after all, now aliue, bee dead. When the Pope will call a Councell, or consult his chaire, GOD knowes: what manner of resolutions were to be expected, if either should happen, wee may coniecture by their wonted practise; which is thus.

The politicke sophismes of the Papists in their Coūcels.5 After a Councell is called, the Maior part being made to serue their makers turne (for of Bishops the most must bee the Popes new creatures) the rest must subscribe to their decrees; vsually set forth, in the weather Wizards language, and their sceptique Schoolemen appointed to riddle out some good meaning that may saue their Prelates credit. In the meane time, the Pope and his Cardinalls may follow their pleasures, take their ease, and with it the dreaming Captaines Motto, Tot vrbes capio dormiens ac vigilans. Wee take vp as many controuersies, we edifie the Church as much, sleeping as waking. If no tolerable interpretation of their doubtfull decisions can be found; yet a good sense must bee beleeued; and priuate Spirits may not peremptorily auouch, that the Councell meant this or that, but onely it meant the best, and this we take to bee the best, and therefore we thinke it meant thus, but with humble submission to their infallible authoritie. All this while the Sectaries (so they terme vs) must bee set to proue negatiues, as that there can bee no true meaning, in those speeches, which may haue twentie. But if out of their Schoolemens wranglings (who can better seek out then follow the truth found)
any interpretation or manner of tenent can be found which may yeeld aduantage to them, or preiudice to their aduersaries; about some hundred yeares after, perhaps, (when they haue light on a Pope and Cardinals whose wits and they once in their life-times meet) a decision may bee had, vpon this opportunitie of seeming aduantage. And yet the Catholique Church, during this hundred or perhaps two hundred yeares of her silence, must bee supposed to haue held perpetually the selfe-same tenent, which this priuate man hath blotted out of late; albeit neither hee, nor any particular member thereof, did know as much, yea though fiue heads of the Church (and as many principall members) fiue successions of Popes, Cardinals, and Bishops, haue died in the meanetime, no one of which in all their liues did trouble their thoughts with any such matter: and whilest both their Schoolemens priuate speculations, and their publique practise haue witnessed the contrarie. Was the doctrine of iustification and merits held by any of their Doctours heretofore, as the later Iesuits haue refined them? Did any of their Popes and Councels determine of their manner of worshipping Images, as Vasquez hath of late? And yet (I thinke) if the Pope should bee driuen to a decision of this question, hee would define as Vasquez hath done; so extraordinarie is the approbation of his Apologie for imagerie; as if it likewise were worthie of adoration. And if this Pope should so determine it, you must thinke that all his predecessors were of the same opinion, if they had beene asked; eun dem fensum tenuit semper mater Ecclesia.

11. parag. 〈…〉 lud. &c. Some learned Papists haue beene perswaded, that their vulgar translators were docti a Deo omnes, all assisted by the Holy Ghost in their translations. But Bellarmine thinkes this opinion too charitable, for so they must grant that Theodotion the Heretique (the vndoubted Authour of some parts of that edition,) was infallibly assisted by the Holy Ghost. If he were not, how is that part of their Vulgar, which they haue
from him authentique and true? Though erre he might, as being a priuate man or rather a publique Heretike, Dicimus tamen eum non errasse in ea translatione quam approbauit Ecclesia, yet wee say (saith Bellarmine, but I hope no wiseman will so thinke) that hee did not erre in that translation which the Church hath approued. I see then it is all one, whether the Holy Ghost doe assist the translatour, whilest he is about his worke, or the Pope his translation, after it be finished, and He dead: nor doth it skill how he were qualified whilest he liued, either for integritie, wit or learning: the cause is all one as in the Pope himselfe, who may as freely bestow this particular gift, of not erring in translations, vpon whom hee please without all respect of good qualities, as Saint Peter did that transcendent donatiue of absolute infallibilitie vpon him and his successors. Saint Ieroms translation had laudable testimonies of antiquitie, yet not generally receiued in his time, onely preiudiced by the newnesse of it, and antiquitie of the Italique. But whole is the Vulgar, or how first came it in request? It is (saith Bellarmine) partly Lucians, partly Ieroms, partly Theodotions the Heretike, partly anothers he knowes not Nam vulgata editio non est vnius authoris, fed quaedam habet ex Hieronymo, quaedam ex Luciano quaedam ex Theodotione quaedam ex alio quodam interprete innominato: stultum autē videtur dicere, Theodotionem Haerel • cum non potuisse errare, & etiam Hieromymum nusquā • errasse, cum ipse in cap. 19 Isaiae dicat se errasse, & Ecclesia correctionem eius receperit. Non igitur authores illos canonizauit Ecclesia, sed tantum hanc versionem approbauit, nec ita tamen approhauit vt asseruerit nullos in ea librariorum errores reperiri, sed certos nos redere voluit in ijs praesertim, quae ad fidem & mores pertinent, nulla esse in haec versione interpretum errata. Bel. ibid. Why the Romish Church from Gregories time vntill the Trent Councell should vse the translations of so many sundrie Authours, no cause saue onely the negligence or mishap of former ages that had lost all choice of better, or the necessitie of the middle ages or times of midnight dark
•• sse, wherein the skill of interpretation was extinct.
whose. Doe wee thinke the Trent-Councell did examine euery part of that translation? or did they know as much as Bellarmine hath confessed, that it should call so many Fathers, and one Heretike amongst the rest? Doubtles this is a miraculous power of their Holy Church; thar the Holy Ghost doth but keepe men from errour whilest they are liuing, but the Pope and his Councels infallibilitie can keepe an Heretike (whom they knew not liuing) from hauing erred after he is dead. And whereas the Almightie Creatour of Heauen and Earth did but make light shine out of darknesse, the incomprehensible Omnipotence of the Popes infallibilitie can make darknesse light, and light darknesse. For otherwise, why might not the Pope, and the Councell, haue yeelded the assurance of their Omnipotent Spirit vnto some then liuing, for authentique translation? Or why
